reviews.review: Full of History. Enjoyed spending a few hours walking around this historical arae of Sydney. Lots of galleries to visit.

Be sure to catch the Sunday market at The Rocks. On my last full day in Sydney, I decided to walk the Sydney Harbor Bridge from one bank to the other. On my way back to Sydney's downtown I noticed that there were a couple of streets in The Rocks area that were lined with little vendor tents, so I decided to decend to the area and check things out. Wow! Glad I did. There were all sorts of local vendors set up and they had a ton of unique products they were selling. I bought a beautiful hand made leather wallet for a very good price. Totally unique and seems that it will last me for a long time to come. Be sure to check it out if you are in town on a Sunday. Even if you aren't, be sure to meander through the streets a The Rocks and check out the little shops scattered about.

So Worth A Visit. So worth a visit! It is a short walk from Circular Square to the Rocks area in Sydney. Once there you will find cafes, restaurants and plenty of places to explore. There are organised walks that cater for different groups. A must is the museum that opened in about 2006. The best part about the Rocks is you can walk anywhere.

Awesome historic centre of the City on the Harbour.. Great location with lots of great bars and restaurants. Cool markets on the weekends and lots of beautiful historic sandstone buildings. Heaps to do and see. Close to the Harbour Bridge walk, the ferries and international cruise terminal.

A walk through history. Great spot to wander around and discover some of Sydney's historical beginnings. Lots of good eateries, pubs and boutique shops. The Rocks markets are on every weekend with a wide variety of art and craft and food. Walking distance from Circular Quay. Be aware that as its a tourist attraction, the prices can reflect that. Some parts of the area has steep sections and stairs, so can be problematic with elderly or disabled. (We had a 90 year old in our group who used a walking frame, so some sections she couldn't negotiate)
Awesome.. We were thrilled to get the chance to explor the Rocks. We loved the weekend street fair and there are so many great places to go to eat, drink, have tea or shop.

An OK stroll around the shops and stalls. An easy stroll five minutes from circular quay The Rocks area is home of many shops and stalls very much focussed on souvenirs for tourists and food outlets. Allow an hour to browse - some good things on offer but, I suspect, at fairly high prices.
Top spot. Great area within Sydney to spend some time. Enjoyed wandering around the streets. Lots of good eateries. Take time out to explore some of the museums. Will definitely be back.
Shopping and eating at the Rocks. Spend many hours walking, shopping, looking at aboriginal artefacts, street markets, having a meal at the many pubs ( I suggest the Mercantile) listening to music.

Local History, modern vibe. We loved wandering around the Rocks on both our visits to Sydney, again it is one of those unique areas that has the mix of local history of early like in the city, which today is coupled with the modern vibe that so characterises this modern city. Lots of little alleyways and side streets, which hide numerous surprises for you.There are numerous very good restaurants and cafes, shops and museums to visit and plenty to see. Also do not miss the excellent market at the weekend.From here you can wander over the Harbour Bridge, get ferry from Circular Quay and have tremendous views of the Opera House. If you miss the Rocks, you have not been to Sydney.

Good place to explore. Wander around this historical area and be surprised by the history, and some interesting little shops or food places. Sure, it's touristy and there are places which cater basically to them, but wander the back streets and alleyways and you're bound to find somewhere to get your attention. We've found some good restaurants, an interesting building or two, and some really good cafes such as La Renaissance. When they had markets last time I was there, I picked up some cool fossils and sweets, and could have bought more.
Classy. The Saturday markets are shaded, organised stalls with friendly stall holders and wonderful food options. It's all treasure and no stash.
Old meets new. This is such a great place, for young and old. There is something for everyone. I thoroughly recommend it to all.

Welcome to the Rocks. The Rocks is a great place to visit while in Sydney. Located adjacent to Circular Quay there is always something going on. Ferry boats and cruise ships arrive and depart. Many shops, restaurants, hotels, museums and businesses thrive in this historic harbor location.

Vibrant place in an historic area. A walk through the Rocks is always full of surprises, the markets are great, lots of unique things, a bit of trashy tourist junk made in China that can be ignored. Great places to eat and drink often with some music playing - a Sydney must do!

This place rocks!. The Rocks. Where you get a little lost in the maze of shops, pubs and cafes. Sunday visit to the Rocks Market coupled with lunch at any one of the nearby pubs, a stroll along the waterfront makes for an awesome day...very busy on Sundays but well worth a leisurely day spent here. Awesome for a pub crawl as well !
The Rocks. What a historical & also vibrant place to be. Ideally situated to explore Sydney. It's where Sydney started!

Very cool neigborhood. Once we say the Opera House, the rocks were our next stop. It's a nice neighborhood with a wide array of restaurants and shops. If you go on Sundays, there is a large craft fair that shuts down George Street where a variety of vendors are hawking their wares. You will have no problem finding a shop or cafe that you like.
One of my favourite places. Played tourist in Sydney whilst showing are overseas guest around Sydney. The rocks is a great place to start and finish the day.

Love this place!. My husband and I got our coffees and walked along the harbour at 7.00am each morning. Magical. Also the weekend market has some fantastic good quality clothes, jewellery, gifts. Well worth a visit.

The Rocks rocks!. What a great area for a visit - so much to see and do. More restaurants than you can count, although some have poor service as they seem to have so many customers that they have no need to offer good service. Shopping mecca is only 10 minutes walk away. Spectacular views of the Sydney Harbour Bridge, Harbour and Opera House.
Centre of Sydney's tourism. I only had a few days in Sydney, I walked around the stalls on the weekend and photographed the Opera House. Definitely come here at some point.

Nice wonder through time . Sydney is just a beautiful city. I had to wait two hours so I went for a walk through the Rocks. The Sunday markets were on. And the vibe was lovely. The sand stone architecture. Takes you back in time to early Sydney. Cool little alley ways hold the stories of ghost. I can't see how anyone could feel bad vibes in such a gorgeous place. And it has some amazing restaurants.

Fun Place especially at the weekend. Great part of town to visit over a weekend - loads to do, good street market and some good pubs and restaurants. Especially like the music in the Mercantile Hotel by the Market on a Saturday.
Atmesfer plenty of Amazing Pubs , night life. must too see, lots of Shops and food , Markets I love it on the Weekend love the the Night life , Views outstanding
A very pretty Town.. A lot of old buildings, and very Rustic, The town reminded me of the old English towns in the UK and plenty to see, Great place for shopping or just a nice lunch.
Sunday Markets. Pub Grub & drinks , plenty of shops to visit , as well as street entertainment Love the German food & beer at the Lowenbrau Keller
Saturday and Sunday markets - tops. Great venue for history and shopping. Luk y we had great worthy and loved the markets. A tourist must do
Great Ambience. A beautiful area located on Sydney Harbour. Awesome views and wonderful resturants. A lovely place to stroll on a balmy night or enjoy the eclectic markets on Sundays.
Spot of dinner after a shop. Found a little pizza spot for a bite after seeing a show nearby. A lovely area of Sydney with great history.

Day trip to the Rocks. We visited the Rocks with friends, travelling by ferry from Cabarita to Circular Quay...walked along the markets to the Bridge and meandered along to our lunch destination at the Rocks Cafe. A thoroughly enjoyable day just chilling and walking, browsing the wares and whiling the day away.
Original but updated part of early Sydney Heritage - The Rocks. At every turn lies an interesting place, coffee shop or retail shop. There are also excellent hotels to visit or stay in.
Sydneys History. Its quaint its fun and its part of Sydney's convict history with good views and restaurants take your time and look its worth it

An interesting walk. Took part of a day to walk through the variety of shops and see some of the restaurants found here. Quite a collection of historic buildings mixed with modern stores. Go on the weekend when the market is open for a greater selection of local crafts.

Beautiful place and wonderful history.. Staying in a hotel and being in a walking tour in The Rocks was an incredible experience. I was fascinated with the history of The Rocks and would love to take my family back to visit.

Great area to walk around (plus visit a pub!). Take some time to walk and explore this area as it's lovely. However, make sure you take a trip to one of the pubs. Our favourite is the Lord Nelson Brewery and it's obviously a favouite with everyone else to as it's always packed! It's a very old school English style pub.

Full of historic charm. The Rocks is a beautiful place in Sydney. We had the pleasure of staying at the Langham and walking around the rocks area everyday. It is quaint, charming and beautiful while also being right in the middle of everything. I loved that you can see the harbour bridge and also the harbour/boats just while walking around the area. Felt like a little escape from all the hustle and bustle of the city

Arts and Crafts. A great area to visit if you are in Sydney during the weekend as there is a market here. There are several venders selling all manor of arts and crafts, souvenirs, clothing, and miscellaneous items. This is a old area of Sydney with lovely buildings, cafes, and restaurants.

Past & present collide. Just a stones throw away from Circular Quay the jumble of old streets and alley ways that make up The Rocks are a great way to immerse yourself in history but also enjoy all modern conveniences and top class restaurants indie shops and great weekend markets. We stayed at the YHA in this area and found it a safe place to be with two young children, everyday we seemed to see something different or stumbled across a new cobbled stone lane we'd not spotted before. We never tired of it for the week we stayed. I can highly recommend the weekend market especially for holiday souvenirs and presents, everyone of the stall holders we spoke to were very friendly and we never felt pressurised into buying anything.

Rocks markets. After spending hours shopping around the commercial shopping district we ended up at the Rocks markets around 2 in the afternoon. We found what we wanted immediately - unique clothing made and design by the stallholder. I can highly recommend heading to this end of town when your looking for clothing and something a little different.
Never fails to impress!. Clean streets, so much history preserved, fantastic eating, loved the markets, the buzz! Can't wait to return.

Birthplace of the city. We arrived early Saturday morning and stayed in The Rocks are hotel.
We went out for breakfast in the area and after we walked around for a bit. Later we contracted a tour guide for the day and he drove us around the area and explained us about the first European settlements in the city. Well worth it.

Plenty of Good Restaurant options. My husband and I stayed in the ShangriLa Hotel, which is located at the Rocks. There are so many good Rest. options, shops, and is also conveniently located near the Circular Quay.
Historic rocks area. Love the rocks area of Sydney, easy walk to circular key and the city. Good choice of restaurants and shops.
Lovely area of the city. Lovely area of the city, quaint neighborhood with lots of restaurants, shops, park area. Street Fair during the weekend.

Lovely quaint area full of character. Lovely area full of character with different style buildings and old shop signs. Some great bars and restaurants for dining in or out and be sure to go at the weekend when the markets on.

Old Towne Sidney. Walk the cobblestone streets near the docks for a great view of the harbor and a feel of what Sydney was like when it was first settled. Be sure to go there on Saturday or Sunday when there is an upscale outdoor crafts market with beautiful merchandise.

Always a delight. The rocks need time to explore and get off the main roads into the historic building and sites. We love walking through Miller's Point, the new Barangaroo gardens and ending up back at circular key. Great views, relaxing and always something new, stop at a pub for a drink, or food, take in the views and historic buildings. Oh and the views of the harbour are sensational.

Cool place. Great area with a tourist info location very helpful and knowledgeable staff. Booked a multi location program on s card system. Plenty of bars and food locations plus bijou shopping places. Tourist focused but that's what we are !

Sydney's Old quarter. This is where the first colonial masters came to.... just pulling UK's leg. The architecture reflects the early days that it was built remember though that Australia was found in 1788 so the buildings are not that old...still for us Aussies' its old. I love it there, apart from the history there is great shopping, fab cafe's and good quality restaurants. So its a delightful place for locals and a must for tourist.

an overpriced place that gouges the tourists. well i guess the rents must be sky high, because everything you look at in the rocks will cost you money, and plenty of it, beer overpriced, food overpriced clothes souvenirs if fact anything at all here is overpriced and then some, things you can buy outside the rocks cost anything up to double here and in some cases more, it is shame that visitors to our wonderful city with the best harbour in the world get ripped off by merchants restaurants and bars, it seems that if they could charge you for walking through or window shopping they would, its a shame that this happens and nobody will ever do anything to improve it, look outside the rocks if you want better value anything, you can buy the exact same things away from here much cheaper,

History, art and drinking all in one spot.. A great place to wander around. Some fab little museums filled with stories from the past from the arrivals of convicts to the lives of sailers and the people who once lived in this area, in a very modern city some of the buildings here date back to the eighthteenth century. There are many little shops and art galleries to look round as well a lovely weekend markets.Also an abundance of bars and sydneys oldest pub which always looks a fun time! Love this place :)

Mesmerised By Its Beauty. The Rocks boast lots of really beautiful pre-war buildings and on weekends, it is flooded with scores of people shopping for antiques along the Antique market. It is one of the coolest place in town and I love gulping down a beer while enjoying the majestic of these lovely buildings and architectures.
The same same. The Rocks area is interesting, we have been there many times, but it just the same as it was 10 years ago, nothing has changed or improved...

Find a souvenir. The Rocks is a lovely old part of Sydney near the harbour where you can go to one of many old pubs for lunch and a beer, while your there you must do the market , where you can find that unique souvenir or gift

Loved strolling area The Rocks. It is a little like going back in time to stroll around this area. It is easy to see it as it might have been a hundred years ago in another era, when it was a slum. Lots of points of interest and museums in the area. Nice places to stop off and have a bite to eat and or drink. Prices are not crazy either.

Never take the same route twice!. I stayed at a place in The Rocks, Sydney's oldest part of town, so I became very familiar with it. What I enjoyed the most was the character each street had, with it's old brick buildings and cobbled roads. Many cut throughs give shortcuts between streets; take them and lose yourself a bit.

Sunday market fun. The Rocks is a quaint area of Sydney, filled with cobbled streets, higgledy-piggledy building, roof bars, eateries, market stalls...It's actually walkable from anywhere or you can always take a water taxi which allows you to see the Harbor Bridge and The Opera House! Enjoy the market on Saturdays and Sundays.
Great place to visit!. A wonderful cultural area of Sydney, great restaurants,pubs, shops and magnificent views of the harbour!

Quaint walk down History. I love the architecture of houses and shops along the Rocks which is distinctively different from the rest of Sydney which reflects this dynamic city's early settlement. While it may not have the old world feel, it is quite a nice walk. I like how some parts of the pavement at the Rocks are not even and you can almost imagine people in big dresses and Edwadian shoes with hard soles walking on them. This area was considered a slum in the early days but now it is one of the most desired addresses in Sydney. I went during the weekend and I really enjoyed the Rocks Market with stalls selling very nice and interesting things. There was one stall selling jewellery made from vintage watch pieces. This is very unique. Tho I couldn't afford it, I think it is something worth buying. And there are small cafes all along the streets serving fresh pastry and coffee. After a long cold walk, it was really nice to pop into one to savour a cuppa and lamingtons. Spent half a day here before making my way to the Sydney Harbour bridge to watch the Sunset.
Great walking and many good restuarants. The Rocks is very expensive for both hotels and restaurants but it's worth it! Great to walk around and you there are lots of choices on restaurants

Explore, explore, explore. Get your flat shoes on, a bottle of water and your camera ready and set out and explore, explore, explore. What an amazing place with history, adventure and wonderful places to eat ~ the markets are a must visit.
Get lost in history.. Loved walking around the Rocks looking at all the history of the area and the unique shops and cafes. So much history so close to the CBD.

Touristy lacks historic feel . The Rocks is supposed to be the historical area of Sydney but I think it lacks atmosphere. Full of shops and restaurants aimed at cash strapped tourists. Maybe I should do tje haunted tour to get a feel for the significance of the area.

Quirky shopping . Stayed here at the end of our Australian tour. Interesting and quirky shops, lots of good food, both on and off street. Old buildings (for Sydney) some of which are under redevelopment threat.

Great weekend market vibe. We stayed in Sydney a few nights and wanted to enjoy the city. After a rough first night, we headed out looking for breakfast in the rocks. We stumbled across the markets with lots of yummy foods, craft, locally made treats and energy. The views of the harbour, opera house and museum close to the water were awesome... Perfect selfie opportunity!
GO HERE YOUR FIRST DAY IN SYDNEY!. It's historic Sydney. Great restaurants, lots of "nooks and crannies." Walk around and explore - just beautiful!!

True Australian city. Historical Rocks never disappoints me.I love how they have kept parts of the original city...old contrasting the new.Some original paved areas are uneven and a safety issue for those that are elderly or with a physical disability.So many eaterys catering for all budgets....the closer you approach the water the more expensive it seems.A must visit for all international visitors and all Aussies

Very interesting. Lovely area of Sydney , lots of history . We stayed close by so visited often. Lots of very good restaurants and cafes we tried many. Shops and museums to visit and plenty to see. An excellent market at the weekend .the views of the Opera house and Harbour bridge are fabulous. There is a surprise around every corner!!
Plenty of nice cafes and restaurants . The Rocks is a great place to visit or stay while in Sydney. Markets on Sunday and very close to Circular Quay restaurants. Must visit while in Sydney.

A great place to explore. I always find something new as I explore all the lanes and alleyways. This place is great at the weekend for the markets but do explore further afield as you will find some great museums, mural and shops tucked away.
Love the Rocks. One of my favorite places in Sydney. Amazing history. Lots of places to eat or stop at a Old Pub for a beer. Feel the Ghosts of the Past!

Vibrant and bustling with history. The Rocks Market on the weekend is great place to checkout the local crafts and food.Lots of restaurants and pubs down the main road.At night the Rocks area is a vibrant and happening place.There quite a few Hotels in the Rocks area.This place is just around the corner from Circular Quay to access Ferry and Trains.Must visit place of Sydney.

The Rocks original walking tour. Sophia our guide was an excellent guide for the walking tour of the Rocks. She shared her passion in the heritage and history of the area with very interesting stories of the many characters of the past. We were able to gather an understanding of the harsh conditions and strength required to survive early settlement. This tour was a real highlight of our trip to Sydney and Sophia tells the history well.

A Sydney Jewel!. Beautiful location! A must see for tourists.This spot allows you to view both the iconic Opera House and Harbour Bridge at once. See much of Sydney's history through the Rocks and on Sunday there are wonderful boutique markets not to be missed. There's also a fantastic view of the hustle and bustle over at circular quay from the Rock's. Don't forget your camera or you will be disappointed!

Nice outdoor market. The Saturday outdoor market at The Rocks is very nice. They have nice a wide variety of food and goods and the atmosphere is lovely. It's a nice place to walk around and enjoy a meal or a few beers.
Fantastic. Walk on down to The Rocks and enjoy the small eateries or the pubs. The weekend markets are a must there is something for everyone.
Walk through History. Great information about the history of Sidney with interesting points of interest throughout the walk. We took a guided tour that I would highly recommend.

Where Australia Began. This charming area is the spot where the British set up shop after they discovered Australia. There are a number of restaurants and shops to visit. A couple of bars were known for drugging sailors back in sailing days, hence the term "Shanghaied".
Historical buildings. It's a must to visit this area. Don't miss any corner in the rocks. Different things to do, such as: sight seeing and eating again.
Lovely cosy place. Great for a morning walk, before all the crowd is there. Very cosy and fantastic to have drink, enjoy the atmosphere, watch people around...

Trip to Sydney. The Rocks has been erected as the first settlement of Sydney. Today you can walk around in an area of heritage buildings flanked by the Harbour bridge and Circular Quay. Tip: have a visit during the day and later in the evening to discover the different vibes.

Colourful place to visit. The Rocks area in Sydney is alway fun with lots going on. This visit we strolled around the markets and visited an art gallery. It is always nice walking along the waterfront and stopping for a beer or a coffee at one of the many bars and cafes.

Holiday. Fantastic area to walk around - breathtaking views of Harbour Bridge and Opera House. Best weekend markets I have ever been to. Great eating places. So much history. Close to transport trains and ferries. A must visiting Sydney.

Small streets and big markets. You can really feel the history walking through The Rocks. The old cobblestone streets and stone architecture makes it feel like you're stepping back in time. There are some awesome food stalls set up on Fridays for lunch and Saturday/Sunday there's an awesome street market. With decent mix of touristy and niche wares it's a great place to get a range of souvenirs. Lots of great pubs to partake in, many with rooftop views. Definitely worth hiking the stairs to do the bridge walk as well. Awesome city and harbour views!

Quaint old town feel livened up with colourful markets, shops, cafes & bars. Anybody visiting Sydney should make a point of venturing down to the Rocks, to get a feel for the birthplace of the city of Sydney & modern Australia, brought into the 21st century. Really lovely part of town with some great views of the harbour, fantastic restaurants, shopping & drinking venues, inlcuding the oldest in the Sydney, the Fortune of War (debatable - Macquarie Arms in Windsor reckons its been around longer).
Great part of sydnet. An iconic part of Sydney, the Rocks has everything, the harbour, markets and great food venues and a wonderful nightlife.

Walk about . Interesting area to visit and find out about Sydneys dark history.Many places for a bite to eat and a drink.The pubs pride themselves on craft beers.I you visit Sydney spend at least half a day here.

Nice place in the city. Its like an old little town in the middle of Sydney, so it is nice. Pretty houses with the old construction style, it was one of the first populated spots of Sydney so you will get an idea of what it used to look like.

Be sure to explore street and the markets. Saturday markets are a must. The oldest part of Sydney hidden in behind heritage listed buildings on the harbour. Restaurants, shops and bars you will discover it all along the cobblestone paths.
One of my favourite areas.. A great community vibe with the markets and loads to see and do. Good for history buffs too. You could spend a few hours pottering around looking at all the quirky shops.
Cute area to walk around or shop. Lovely historic area to walk around in Sydney. Try and catch the Rocks markets on Saturdays if you can. Interesting alley ways to wander up and down!

Lots of history, old buildings and markets. Visited on the weekend. Walked thru the markets and stopped at a couple of pubs for a drink. Easy walking around the alleys and laneways looking at the historic buildings. Something for everyone.

Weekend market. There will be a weekend market at the Rocks selling local products and produce. Seems interesting enough to intrigue most people but not all. There was this one guy selling steamed corn on the cob and drinks for $5, which was pretty decent considering it was a rainy day.
Browse around you might find something that interest you.
Lovely Sunday morning . Great place to wander the market stalls on a sunny Sunday morning...lots of variety and lots of people .. be prepared to mingle with the crowds and not be in a hurry!!
Lots to see and do, you won't be disappointed.. Market Stalls, street performers lots of places to eat and drink in this iconic location. Great atmosphere almost everywhere.

Great place to visit. When in Sydney, don't miss The Rocks. It is a pedestrian friendly place with interesting galleries, shops and restaurants and some great views. There will probably be some street festivals going on. When we were there, there was a chocolate festival and other markets. You can also find bathrooms pretty easily. Just ask. All the locals are very friendly to visitors.

Atmospheric and historical. Apart from the great selection of pubs, shops and museums, there are many great spots around here which are of historical significance. Sydney Harbour YHA - The Rocks and Susannah Place Museum are two that come to mind. Be on the look out for the 'I'm Free' Rocks Walking Tour which starts daily at 6pm. Great way to experience the area.
it was part of the tour so I had to go. it was okay looking at the old neighborhood but it was not exciting. I would not go out of the way to see this place.

Lovely. We walked through The Rocks on a day that the market was on. Stall holders were all very friendly and we had breakfast at a lovely restaurant while watching the pedestrians walk past lovely strip to walk, nice part of Sydney.

Sydney Lover.. The historic convict built ROCKS region lies between Circular Quay, the harbour bridge and Sydney Harbour.There are early 19th Century warehouses on the water converted to restaurants,great food, uninterrupted views of the opera house and harbour/bridge.A must if staying in Sydney.
A Walk Back in History. From our nearby hotel, we walked through this section of town several times - it has old hotels, bars and quaint shops. There are also several new restaurants.

Lovely historic buildings, quality craft market, but very expensive. I would have loved the walk about the historic buildings but it was sooooo busy it was a struggle to stop and get out of the flow to look at something! The crafts were beautiful, novel, quality, unusual and very expensive! There was also some street artists (chalk, paint) and they had exceptional talent, so great to watch for a bit. Good for a quick stop on way to somewhere (we were on the way to do the Sydney Harbour Bridge walk), but not much of a destination in itself.

Old streets with a lot of character. Step away fro the harbour and check out the street, the buildings are old and well maintained. Great place to explore on a hot day with some cheap shops to buy water and treats if required.

Has it all No need to venture any were. This would have been my favourite spot due to the amazing choice of activities, you can be as relaxed as you want or walk all day seeing all the beautiful old heritage building and the clear view of Sydney Opera house, there is enough shops to keep even the fussiest person happy, Food and drink from all nations, then when the sun goes down there is even more.

Australian Travellers . One of my favourite places to visit when in Sydney. Close to Circular Quay with great views of the Bridge, Opera House and Harbour. Hearing the history, both good and bad, of this old part of Sydney and seeing the old buildings makes for a great walk through this area. There are some interesting shops as well as good eating places and markets on the weekend.

Sydney's party town. With the greatest concentration of bars and restaurants in Sydney, this is the party spot. Just below the bridge, The Rocks has preserved some historical buildings, while also keeping a modern tone. there are some real treasures on the small short side streets here. I found the perfect shop for Digereedoos there

Great area to stay.. We're staying in the Rocks area right now. A truly historic part of the city, so many old properties reminiscent of an old English town. We've wandered around and enjoyed the history. The Rendezvous hotel is right in the middle, and does great coffee in reception!

The Rocks. A very pleasant stroll amongst some very old history. There are many great eating establishments spread all around. There are great views of the Sydney Harbor and of course the unforgettable Sydney Opera House and the Sydney Harbor Bridge..

My favourite spot in Sydney.. We stay at The Rocks whenever we visit Sydney, there's something about the area that draws me back.Plenty of places to eat and drink and a short walk to Circular Quay, Darling Harbour and the Botanic Gardens.

Lovely to walk around. Just so enjoyable to walk around to see Old Sydney, they way they use to live, lovely old places. The Sunday markets are great if you like a craft market, lots of lovely eateries and old pubs. At night take the ghosts tour around the rocks very informative.

Vibrant place. We went on a Saturday and there were a lot of stalls on the streets making it different from the rest of the city. A lot of interesting items being sold. The restaurants and bars on the streets were very busy and vibrant. But you will have to bear with the crowds.
LOved it. We stayed on the rocks. Lots of places to visit, great location and a variety of pubs and restaurants. I wouldn't stay anywhere else if I were to visit again.
I sight to see. I think we all should take a walk through The ROCKS. It is a place full of history and a glimpse into the past. Full of rich history and nice places to eat
Lots of History. If you like history, you will love The Rocks.. Lots to do, things to learn, even ghost tours if you are brave enough and all with great views of Sydney

A walkabout. We took a wander around The Rocks without a guide. Thus we were unable to appreciate what we were seeing. It's a very interesting, historic neighborhood, but we should have had a guide, or at least a good guidebook. Well, it was the end of the day, and maybe we shoulda just gone and had a relaxing libation. Or been better prepared.

A pearl. We ended in the rocks by accident (I needed a toilet) and found this fantastic beautiful cosy spot just in the center of Sydney. A very cosy market and the best Italian restaurant we have tried in Australia. Go there
lovely market. Great market with lot of handy crafts hand made jewellery, scarfs home wares ,clothes and crafts,a lovely place just to walk around and take in the atmosphere.

Quaint "village" in the heart of Sydney!. The Rocks is a great area in Sydney near the Bridge and Opera House with cobble stone roads, art galleries, shops and a variety of coffee shops and restaurants. Lovely to stroll along the quaint village!

Great place to spend a weekend. Many interesting things to see and do over the weekend with its interesting market and food stalls. A great mix of history and present. Something for everyone from the young to the old.

History Beckons. Walking tour of The Rocks is a good way to know the city particularly for History Buffs. You can do the tour on your own, but the best thing would be to go with a guide. There are information centres located in The Rocks for tourists and plenty of eating joints

Great atmosphere and shopping. I am writing this review today although it has been several years since I have been here. I still want to share my experience. This was one of the highlights of my trip. The area is filled with lovely shops and not just the touristy kind. There are many art galleries and artisan craft shops. I bought lovely woolens , Aboriginal art, handmadeSilver jewelry , Australian opals and even a boomerang. I was able to do all of my shopping in one place. After all that shopping I was able to rest and relax at any number of local pubs. The nice things about the Rocks is that it is not far away from most attractions. I only had 3 days in Sydney so this turned out to be a very convenient stop for me . Don't miss out on this vibrant area.
Disappointing . For the oldest part of Sydney and most (historic) I don't see any history nothing for children. Disappointed.
Historically Interesting and Interactive . So much to see do and sample. Places to visit and see how our early settlers lived. Places to eat! Lots of them. And much much much (lots) more.

Loving weekend market!!. If you are visiting or going to visit Sydney, do not miss out the Rocks weekend market. You are able to find from food, hand craft, clothes and so on!! But make sure they close by 5 pm!!

Great market. We went to the rocks market. Lovely stroll through lots of hand made products. Good to take cash but a lot of vendors have tap and go. It's a good market because it's not huge and easy to get around. Also walked through susz alley. Interesting poems and information on the era. Worth a walk around.

Loved it here. . This is the best of Sydney. the historical streets are amazing and inspiring to think of all the feet that have trodden down those cobblestones before us. The views are great and we spent four days enjoying the sights. The markets were unbelievable.

The Rocks Really Rocks. This is a lovely little section of Sydney that has some terrific restaurants, great shopping and is a very historic area. In addition while we were here, they had a street market (The Rocks Market) on the weekend (Saturday and Sunday) where local artisans have some unique items available to buy as well as some little food booths. It gets really packed but it is fun to do.As others note, it is quite convenient to a number of other attractions such that you are not going out of your way to have a look see.

Renovations & current business prevent a lot of viewing of actual buildings inside.. Plan this visit in mid to late morning and forward. We did not get to view any of the buildings inside for their historical and architectural signifigance.
A piece of history. A must visit to get a real Sydney experience. Love this part of Sydney for its history, cafes and hip bars and restaurants
History!! . This is a must visit if you like history! There is so much information on the history of Australia! You and do a tour or just see everything yourself!
Great place . Must see. Lots of historic buildings to see. Lots of pubs and placed to eat. Its not far from the opera house either

It's a must see. The Rocks is an icon of Sydney and a must see attraction.
Close to circular quay, the bridge and other sights. Wander through the matket, walk up to the underside of the bridge, have a coffe, wine, beer or all three and just take it all in.

Wonderful piece of history. The area is old and full of interesting architecture and a rich history. It is definitely worth taking a stroll through the area and take it all in. If you come on the right days there is a market that sells a variety of items.

Australia's answer to the 5 points..... Great atmosphere around the Rocks at all times, lots of history to read about during the day and lost of eateries and waterholes during the night. Try having a early start with some food as many places have free music up until about 9-10ish.

History in Sydney. The Rocks are typical os pioneer settlement with stories of plague and also the struggles of the people in the 1800's. It is similar to Hobart. The "Big Dig" site is worth viewing as it reveals many relics and bones from the early 1800's. A climb up the Rocks stairways and you are up on the Harbour Bridge.

Walk with History. Great area to just wander, great restraunts quant shops.wonderful views of the harbour.This is one of our Favorite places in Sydney.
Easy to spend a full day.
Nice Part of Sydney. A good part of the city to visit. Lots of places to eat & drink. Walk under the Sydney Harbour bridge & Opera House. Recommended visit while in Sydney
Pancakes ;). We went there for the famous Pancakes in town. Yummylicious! Beautiful place to walk through the shops and cafes.
Just Beautiful. When in Sydney you have to visit the Rocks...so much history to take in plus cute little cafes everywhere!

History and culture combined. As a tourist the weekend markets at the Rocks provides fantastic souvenir purchasing opportunities. Artisan and locally made they are worth the visit. Take time to stroll through the back lanes and read all about the early settlers and original owners of this land.

Still a must visit. This is a must visit for tourists, it is so neat to wander around these beautiful old buildings where history is everywhere and view the quirky shops.The markets are first class and well ahead of any others in the inner city. There are plenty of places to stop and have a coffee/beer so allow two or three hours for your visit.
Saturday markets. Lovely and very cultural. We tasted some different foods and bought some lovely hand made presents! And its a beautiful place to walk around as well.

I love The Rocks. I love going to The Rocks, lots of great cafes, love the markets, so close to the Harbour Bridge, Opera House and circular Quay. Easy to get public transport or to walk to the city centre. Great atmosphere and lots of restaurants too.

The oldest part of Sydney. If you come to Sydney you have to visit The Rocks and learn about the history. The Rocks museum is worth a visit, is free and worth 45 mins of your stay.Also you can pop to The Lord Nelson brewery for a beer afterwards

Always buzzing and definately on you to do list. No matter what the season The Rocks always delivers. Buzzing with street buskers and hotel music, there is something for everyone. Food, food and gourmet delights. Artisans a plenty and the famous markets.. Be there or be square oh and history buffs will love it.

Over nighter before Cruise. The Russell Hotel, The Rocks Sydney. Right next to Circular Quay Train Station, Ferries and Overseas Shipping Terminal. Small and very personable and pleasant. Room we had was small but cosy. Alot of stairs so may need to check if need Accesabilty. Lovely bar/dining room with breakfast included. Close to all transport and within walking distance to CBD and popular sights. Only stayed overnight as i didnt want to miss the Ship! But would definitely stay again.

Best place to stay in sydney. I think if u really want to enjoy sydney the rocks is the best place to stay . Its small old cobbled streets , n number od cafes and bars . places to eat will make ur holiday complete. It has these small boutique shops for art and paintings will touch ur heart . The rocks market on sat and sunday is must visit .
Amazing Cafés. The eaters in this area is amazing, such great quality in such a unique area. Also has such a huge variety of different types of foods.

Walk back in time. Weave your way down Harrington Street and into the heart of the rocks. We were here on a Sunday, and found a section of Argyle street has market stalls for the tourists. Lots of touristy style eateries probably many which should be avoided (except Sake), but many narrow streets winding up from the foreshores with several original buildings. See it before the city council demolishes the rest of the historic places and the Packer group turns it into another big casino.
Historic . Lots of cafes, shops, bars and restaurants and pubs. Some pubs have amazing views of Sydney harbour from top floors. Great place for tourists. Very historic.

Nothing Special. Just another area to wander around. The market on the weekend is nothing special either, nothing you can get anywhere else in Sydney, although some great little cafes and bars. I wouldn't travel here for the market of the bars as you can see them anywhere, but if you want to have a good wander, and a coffee, it's worth it

Best historical part of Sydney. Enjoyed time here before seeing Fawlty Towers at Walsh Bay - still sense the history of Sydney although much of it is being transformed - so much of the area like Barangaroo is becoming high rise office buildings so the overall character of the area is changing So much to see and do with many shops and restaurants as well as a couple of Sydney's older pubs which have so much character.

Not as good as it was. Haven't walked around the rocks for years and found many of the shops I used to like have gone. I was told that they plan to do up the Rocks area again and places like the Waterfront Restaurant will be closed while the Rocks get a face lift

Just a 30 minute ride. Was a fine day and a smooth, easy ride. Ferry nice, snack bar, bathrooms good. Convenient run times. Leaves Circular Quay. Manly Wharf just across street from main town pedestrian mall that leads to the beach---less than 10 min walk if not stopping to shop.
Gorgeous. Gorgeous historic part of the City, With some duty free, wonderfull restaurant, pastry shop and view on the opéra house

This community is a wanderers paradise. Everything about this community is fun!This little historic community nestled within such an amazing metropolis stole my heart. The shops, restaurants, architecture, brick streets, hidden finds and quaint back alley ways... are all unforgettable.
Great Shopping. Very charming area with lots of shops and restaurants. The outdoor market was wonderful and offered many bargains. Some excellent, cheap food on the street and some local restaurants.

Old Sydney. The Rocks represent the old and new. It's old Sydney, part of the original European settlement but now it is a mixture of residential and street market with lots of ware, cafes, street food and some great people watching. The street peddlers seem mostly geared toward tourists and less toward locals. Definitely go around lunch time.

The oldest part of the city. This is where the city grew out from - the oldest part, the roots. Yes, it's very touristy, but there is a reason for that - it's really a attractive place with a lot of old history hidden everywhere and a lot of life bursting everywhere now. So if you have no idea what to do in Sydney, this would be a good starting point. Just get here, look around and you want be bored.

Sydney's redemption. As a Melburnian I am honour bound to put Sydney down but every time I am composing my cheap shots this place ruins it for me. I am constantly surprised by this place, there is always something on. Last week it was a chocolate fair, last year it was street food. Every weekend the market is vibrant and crowded. Even when you tire of beads and bangles and great food there is always a place to grab a cold beer and stare at the harbour and one of Australia's most iconic views.

Wonderful place to wonder around. We actually spent the better part of two days. There was a chocolate festival the day we were there. The entertainment was very good and some of the food was amazing. There was something the Rocks for everyone, Shopping at the market and the stores. Historical places to see and the view of the harbor was nice. The architecture was also quite interesting in that they had saved quite a bit of the 19th century buildings

The Rocks markets and Antico Resteraunt. The Rocks markets are a vibrant place to spend a spring Saturday or Sunday. Visit the artisan stalls for clothing, jewellery , pottery, foods, brick a brac. Don't forget to visit the Chilli Factory and sample the variety of chilli products on offer. Heat of the various products range from very mild to extreme, 1-18 strength. I purchased theFirey Frillneck Hiss, heat range 10. The variety of resteraunts in the Rocks precinct is May and varied. We visited the Antico, a fine Italian Resteraunt. The service was excellent and the wait staff were friendly and efficient. The food was excellent and well presented. This visit will be comfortly done in one easy day.
Great for lunch breaks. Nice area to shop, stroll and/or take a brake for lunch, coffee or drink. Mostly small, personal shops and cafés.
Historic sydney. Nice shops beautiful old buildings - we should have visited later when there was more open - saw some great little cafes
History. Wonderfull history as you stroll around the rocks of Sydney also markets Saturday morning adds extra fun to your day.

Sydney Break. A weekend break in Sydney, there is so much to see that you can spend a month and not scratching the surface. The Rocks is one place that should visit, restaurant and shops galore. When in Sydney the Rocks is a must to visit.

So much history!!. What an amazing place!! So much history around this part of Sydney! We really enjoyed the tour but also just loved looking around during the day. Great markets, beautiful old buildings, wonderful atmosphere! Highly recommend a visit!!
Great vibe in this place. Great location.. Stroll around for food/desserts/drinks..on Sundays they have a market that is nice to visit..

Historic and Fun. We recently visited this beautiful area with our 3 young kids, to celebrate a special milestone 10th birthday. We wanted to show our kids what it was like in years gone by. We walked around the pebble stone streets, over Argyle Street and Observatory Hill and saw Garrison Church and visited Susannah Place Museum which our kids were exceptionally taken with.Never forget the past - it is what creates your future!

Great, but avoid the pricey spots!. The Rocks is rich in history and some great little hidden gems. Avoid being ripped off by eating in some of the cafes near Circular Quay (for example Bakers Oven where you'll pay $7.50 for a stale cupcake!) But seek out some of the great pubs such as Harts Pub and The Lord Nelson. Also check out the markets at the weekend and the Museum of Contemporary Art. The back streets have the better cafes and shops rather than the more obvious ones.Good place to stay whilst in Sydney with Circular Quay boasting a trains station, ferries and regular buses to other parts of Sydney (The Ferries are amazing) but do your research and read menu prices before committing!

The Rocks!. Its a great place to spend your afternoon. Just take a stroll through those lanes and grab a bite in one of those eateries on the corner. And once you're done, just sit by the cruise terminal to look at the opera house and the life around it.

Enjoyed Sunday markets and chocolate festival. I always enjoy a visit to the Sunday markets in The Rocks... but it was coincidental that I recently visited on the same weekend as the SmoothFM chocolate festival! There were heaps of people, and it was great to sample lots of different sweets and treats (as well as savoury items) - and the vibe was really energetic on a beautiful and sunny spring weekend!
Good base for exploring Sydney.. We stayed in this area for 5 days..was a good base for exploring Sydney. A number of restaurants can be found in the area and the harbour views are spectacular.

Great for restaurants, markets, heritage sites, etc. Great old part of Sydney with lots of restaurants, oldie worldie pubs, markets at the weekend, heritage buildings, bridge climb, buskers, ferries. Spend the day there and see everything, especially good at the weekend.

A historic piece of Sydney. The Rocks was the oldest settled part of Sydney. It used to be a slum and then gentrified.It is now a tourist and commercial area with some buildings like the Cadman's Cottage were restored and converted into museums. Souvenirs are expectedly more expensive here. Dining options here are abundant albeit on the higher end.Access is easy as it is within walking distance from Circular Quay.It is a hilly area so good stamina is required if you are pushing a stroller, especially a fully loaded two-seater.

The Rocks, Sydney, AU. The Rocks, Sydney, AU is in the Circular Quay Harbour District of downtown Sydney and is a great place for shopping, entertainment and a great walk. Located at the wharf & under the Harbour Bridge & close to the ferries and the Sydney Opera House, it's not hard to find. There are lots of shops, pubs and activities happening daily. The weekend is the best, when all the 'tent' merchants are out with their wares. A great shopping trip, not to mention all the regular stores in the area.

Neat historic area. What a neat historic area. It's so cool how they have trendy shops and restaurants among all that history. Our hotel was right in the Rocks and I'm so glad. Put us very central to a lot of activities and restaurants.
Love Love Love!. Take me back! I love walking around this area, beautiful views, and buildings. cute cafes and shops.

Old part of Sydney. When you leave the opera house , do not forget to go in the area "The Rocks" , This an old part of Sydeny with some picturesque buildings. You will find descriptive texts on some of the walls that tell about the place.

Market Day. Make sure you visit on Market Day. You can watch people painting and sketching, buy all sorts of goodies, listen to music, have great food and there is history mixed right in if you look for it.

Lots to see and do, especially on the Weekends!. Such an historic part of Sydney, so much to experience which such a lovely view.
So many lovely places to eat and great places to read and learn about some of Sydney's interesting past.
Looks like Maze. The Rocks is just 5 mints walk from Circular quay station. There were lots of small street with little cute shops and restaurant. It's nice place to just wandering around.
Love the area. Gorgeous area to explore but very very busy the day we went as the Chocolate Festival was on. Will go back another time and do a tour.

The Rocks.. A lovely way to see old Sydney Town. A Saurday or Sunday for a stroll around the Rocks seeing all the old heritage buildings and seeing how they lived in yesteryear.,The old Bond sheds on the water turned into restaurant, a must is Wolfies for international quuizene and wines, lovely sitting outside looking at the Opera House and looking up the harbour watching all the marine vessels bobbing up and down on the water, So relaxing. Other things to do is to,do the nurses walk from one end of the Rocks to the old hospital following little nooks and crannies where various restaurants and little out of the way shops are. And then there is the markets, after a long afternoon there is the Hero,s Hotel where you can sit and enjoy a beer and a glass of wine and relax and listen to the live band playing.

Beautiful to see on a Sunday . Being a Sydney resident the rocks is a place I've visited over 100 times. It's beautiful, heritage and has gorgeous views of Sydney harbour, opera house and harbour bridge. I would recommend visiting on a Sunday as the markets are on and the streets are closed. Beautiful location to have breakfast lunch or dinner!

CRAFT SALE Day !. The Friday we visited was mainly a food exhibition put on by local eateries, but there were quite a few craftsmen selling art and hand-made jewelry. So wonderful to bring home a beautiful painting NOT made in China !
Must see. The Rocks has many historical buildings, restaurants, galleries, many interesting and unique shops, not to mention the markets on Saturday and Sunday. A must see for visitors to Sydney.

Sunday Lunch at The Rocks Waterfront. We had a family lunch at Woofies on the waterfront at The Rocks almost under the Sydney Harbour Bridge and looking across to the Opera House.We have dined here several times over a period of 10 years and it has always been a great experience.The servicce is always good even though on this occasion they failed to record our booking for 8 people.
Gorgeous area. We roamed around the rocks and had wonderful food and enjoyed the European small village feel to the whole place. Had wonderful croissants at the Renaissance cafe on Argyle st

The oldest and the best. The rocks is an area beyond Sydney harbour, indeed you go under the bridge to get there. It's easy to find as you simply keep walking along George Steet. I walked it in about 45 minutes from the central station but you could go by train (2 or 3 stops). The oldest pubs in Sydney, the garrison church of the original garrison and some beautiful old houses that look like alms houses. Sunday market is lively and I got some cheapish souvenirs there. well worth the effort.

Great location for restaurants and views. I visited The Rocks for pre-dinner drinks at the Hyatt which had great views of the Sydney Harbour bridge and the Sydney Opera House.We then went on to have dinner at Sake Restuarant which was excellent quality and value in a good area. Taxis were also readily available after the dinner to take me back to the hotel
Beautiful . This is a beautiful place to walk around. On the weekend there is a market that is very fun to visit.

Almost our 1st Anniversary. The Rocks is a great place to visit. Like walking back in time. Beautiful sandstone buildings. The markets are fabulous - if you don't mind a crowd. Vibrant and fun. Close to Barangaroo and Walsh Bay

My favourite spot in the city. Love the area; so many little lanes to explore and great cafes for breakfast or lunch. The atmosphere is so different; you can imagine what early colony life was like. The weekly food market (Friday- Sunday) always has some delicious treats on offer.

Lots to see and do. We walked around the Ricks with all its shops and restaurants many times. Plenty to see and to take in the atmosphere. Prices were reasonable and we did not think we were being ripped off.
Beautiful historical area. Very nice area to visit and to stayCentrally locatedMany restaurants and shopsGood views of the Opera house

Nice historic stroll. Interesting walk that puts you back in time with old buildings and some cobble stone walks. There were very cool bars and eateries mostly near the clock tower. After our bridge climb we walked the shoreline/ dock area through Bangaroo reserve to Hotel Palisades for a late afternoon cocktail - also interesting. We wanted to grab an early dinner so we navigated through the Rocks on our way to Mr.Wong.

The Chocolate Festival in Historic Sydney. Unfortunately for only two days, but the Rocks is always a great place as we have visited before. There are always lots of shops and restaurants and back alleys to wander in. Time slips by with lots of people and history to see

History, Shopping, Music, Food.... A lovely day spent in the Rocks, loved it so much we went back twice, Saw it on Friday and went back the following Saturday. It was nice to get into the shops on the Friday. More vendors on Saturday if you like that kind of thing.
Markets at the Rocks. Went to the markets on Friday afternoon for lunch. Had a great time wondering around & then went back Saturday for the Smooth festival of Chocolate. Fantastic morning
the rocks markets. The wonderful old buildings, the markets,the eateries,and the atmosphere and sheer size of the area,
Rocks . The heritage is clear in the buildings stumble upon this when looking for the sticky rock shop. Also the chocolate celebration. Worth a visit lots of cafes and variety of food offered.

Great place to spend a few hours. I love to wander around the Rocks especially on the weekend when the markets are on. There are heaps of different stalls, lot's of food stalls and interesting things to do

Perfect place to stay or give an evening visit. I stayed here, it's really a twenty minute walk from anything and everything( I mean darling harbour, china town, Philip gardens) ... Has beautiful views....the old Suzanne museum , the archeological site Big Dig, and the bustling weekend market are all plus points. Five minute walk to Wynard station, harbour bridge, and circular quay are big add ons.

Intersting part of Sydney. Definitely one of the better parts of Sydney in terms of built environment. The old streets are great and the history of how this area was saved from the developers' wrecking balls in the 1970's. Some lovely streets and houses on the rocky cliffs.It can get a bit too touristy sometimes but has the advantage it is located near picturesque parts of Sydney - you can stroll to Circular Quay and the Opera House and around the other side is the new development at Barangaroo. It's a nice visit best done on weekdays during the days for a quiet time. At nighttime it is a popular nightlife and drinking area which can be good or bad depending on what you are looking for. It's a must-see if you are visiting Sydney.

The Original Heart of Sydney. The Rocks still has many of the original buildings of Old Sydney. It is highly historic but has unfortunately become very touristic with prices that match. If you enjoy old original architecture particularly architecture made from local stone (sand stone) you will enjoy the Rocks, some of the old wool and bond warehouses have been turned into eclectic markets, but as I said before be prepared to put your hand deep into your pockets either for some souvenirs or food.

Great place to wander. My favourite place in Sydney. I lived there for several years and have enjoyed its many cafes, bars, restaurants and quaint shops. A visit to Sydney without walking around The Rocks does not feel right.
Australia's oldest. Very much a tourist area, and be prepared to pay tourist prices at all shopping and eateries. Historical precinct that is best seen on foot.

Love the Architecture. This is my second visit to Sydney, but the first visit to The Rock. I must say, if I stayed in this area during my first visit, I would have totally planned differently for this trip. I just love the neighborhood. The architecture here is lovely. I love strolling in this area and enjoy the aroma from the cafes and restaurants, or awed by the cobbled lane-ways and monuments...... There are so many things to do and so limited time for us. If you plan to come to The Rock in the future, make sure you have at least 3D2N here, and at least one full day people watching while sipping your coffee/tea.

The Rocks...filled with history. We took a walking tour of The Rocks. Although it was interesting and not costly, you could do it yourself with a guidebook. This historic area is being preserved and renovated. Most buildings are hotels, restaurants, pubs, and boutique shops. We enjoyed it very much.

A very pleasant stroll. I went with my family, and we followed a self-guided tour we found on the web. It was not too difficult, and very pleasant for the entire family. The area itself is nice, but does not offer any spectacular views of shopping.

The Rocks. Easily accessible by public transport and within a short walk from Circular Quay, this is a must see attraction when visiting Sydney. The history of the colonial settlement is seen through the beautiful sandstone terraces, cobbled laneways and stunning architecture. Information is provided at various monuments and there are walking tours. There are quality craft and art stores dotted throughout but be aware these are generally high end prices and you can purchase generic souvenirs at Paddys Markets for a fraction of the price. The Rocks also feature markets on the weekend with tempting food and craftsmen treats.

History, view and pubs. You get it all there. Lots of history walking around little alleys and discovering free museums. Honestly, if you're on a budget don't get a guide, it's pretty easy to find everything. Spend that money on the Sydney's oldest pub or in a restaurant with the harbour view.

The rocks. We visited on the weekend. It was a bit touristy but fun to browse the local markets. There are some local vendors but plenty of your standard tourist trapsWith check souvenirs for the visiting tourists.

Historical Place, Glorious Architecture. The Rocks is historic, and showcase an important bit of Sydney and overall Australian history. The buildings are preserved well, and the Rocks Museum is also an excellent place to visit when in the area.

Time Travel experience!. Walk into the dark history of Australia's European settlers. Picture British soldiers walking the streets, tall ships scattered in the harbor and convicts in prison garb with a continual scowl upon there faces caused by the misery they had to endure sometimes just for stealing a piece of bread to feed there families. Now its your turn to see how they lived, Walk around the "Rocks" visit actual dwellings these people lived in, become a colonial for the day! Then at the end of the day THANK GOD you didn't live in colonial Australia.

Historical area. Pop into the Museum of Contemporary Art, nearby... (closes 5pm) ..for a great view of the Opera House and Harbour. Then pop up the hill to The Glenmore hotel (roof terrace) at 5.30 for sunset drinks.

Best Pub Hopping. Getting lost in the cobble stoned Rocks Precinct is a delight and a must to get a hang of Sydney. With eateries, pubs and cafes scattered everywhere, the place is vibrant. Your trip is incomplete with a pub crawl spree from Harts Pub to Australian Heritage Hotel to Glenmore Hotel to Lord Nelson Brewery to Hero of Waterloo to the Mercantile Hotel and finally Fortune of War.

Rocks walk.. The historical Rocks is a must for visitors to Sydney. See where it all began.Taje a guided walk round the rocks by day learning of our convict past or for those brave enough take the night time ghost tour. Plenty of café's and restaurants to satisfy your hunger.

The Rocks. We had a lovely visit to the historic Rocks. Very beautiful old buildings and lots of restaurants. Sake was the restaurant we chose and it was truly excellent serving contemporary Japanese cuisine. We finished off with a walk through the nearby park where there was some live music.
The Rocks. This vibrant little area offers bars and cosmopolitan restaurants in the evenings.The market on Argyle Street is small offers some wonderful items.Well worth a visit.

Atmospheric. A must see in the cradle of modern Australia. Market would be one of the biggest and is very comprehensive but in reality lacks imagination. However, perfect to wile away an hour or two, good people watching and plenty of places to have a drink or bite to eat

cool old buildings and restaurants. The Rocks has historical buildings that are now occupied by many restaurants. On the way to it from Circular Quay we passed by the Museum of Contemporary Art. We looked for Pancake on the Rocks for a hearty lunch.
A must.... ...to visit for it's history, for the renovation of the whole area, for the nice restaurants and the shops and galleries. We loved it.
rock on. great markets, relatively flat, great variety - and majority are locally sourced; I like the licorice stall - fresh and genuine.

Steeped in history. Wandering around the rocks on a Saturday morning at the markets and stopping at a pub for a decent meal was a nice way to while away the morning looking at all the old building it was very interesting

walk around the rocks- great linch stop. there are many historic buildings in the rocks area, which in itself is very tidy and nicely presented. the area benefits from a number of eating establishments and a food market which seemed extremely popular with locals on their lunch breaks.
Old Sydney with great atmosphere.. The Rocks always attract people to come. In Saturday and Sunday, there is market which allowed you to choose items suit with you. Great place to explore.

Rockin' the Rocks!. We stayed in the Rocks with our teenage son and had a great weekend. It's a great location for visiting, Circular Quay, the Opera House, Bridge Tower and Climb, the Sydney Observatory, Museum of Contemporary Art and numerous eateries! The area is very hilly and there are lots of steps so access could be a problem. Would recommend this area and would stay there again.

Always exciting . The Rocks has everything
Restaurants, nightlife, views , great atmosphere
Just walking around and taking it all in, is so much fun

Nice Historic Part of Sydney. We took the ferry from our hotel in Darling Harbor over to the Rocks and explored the many shops and restaurants there. There's a lot of history here considering the old prison and penal system. There are historic walks like Nurse's Walk that you can follow or you can just browse the stores in this area. There are even a couple of hotels in this area that would be good choices to stay in because it's so centrally located to the ferry system and within easy walking distance to other attractions.

The must place in Sydney. This is the must place to go in Sydney, short walk from city centre toward the Sydney Habour. You can see the views of Sydney Habour from here; The Opera House & Habour bridge. And also a lot cafes, bars & restaurants, especially every sunday there's the outdoor market.
Vibrant Market. Visited the market for the first time on Sunday - really nice and exciting market - lots of unique hand-made crafts! A must for visitors.

Walk the Rocks. My second visit to the Rocks neighborhood, so knew the area a little. What I liked best was to wander the "Walks" (Nurses Walk, Suez Canal, Gloucester Walk, Playfair St, Argyle St) and the stairways connecting them. We found a small store selling opal jewelry at reasonable price points (pendants at $38, $49, $88) and also loose opals. Australian Arts & Gems Gallery @ Nurses Walk. Also went to Lower Fort St, and then to an unnamed walk that goes around the back of the buildings there. From there can see traffic circle of Harrington and Pottinger and the "Still life Car" (see Google Maps photo). The houses in this area reflect the character of buildings of the time period.

A must see. When you find yourself in Sydney, you have to spend a part of your day wandering The Rocks, The oldest part of Sydney on high ground near the harbour, the area has nbeen lovingly restored and is choke full of pleasant little eateries, pubs and the like and some of the best views of the harbour, the Sydney Bridge and the Opera house. Spent many hours there wandering it's very narrow streets and eating at several of the quirky little restaurants there. Make sure you have good walking shoes as there are lots of cobblestone streets and much elevation on many streets. I actually visited in November 2014 on an extensive trip to Australia and Sydney was a must stop for a few days. Beautiful and lively city.

Great weekend away. What a great place to visit for a weekend away. Not just for the tourists, the rock offers an easy place to get out and about and enjoy the icons of Sydney. Great place for food and walking and relaxing. Everything at your finger tips allowing you to relax and enjoy and find yourself.

The Rocks Friday Market. This place is the perfect place to walk around at. Time to spare? Go to The Rocks. Want to shop? Go to The Galleria. Feeling artsy? Check out Contemporary Art Museum. Want to think? Pier is right there. A plus? The Friday Market! A small strip of kiosks which sells fresh food and juices and chocolates on one side, small tables and chairs on another. Come in early so you can have a seat. Else, bring a blanket and sit on the side and have a picnic. Be considerate though. Once done, please clean and allow others to sit and enjoy the place.

Worth a Visit. The place is rich in history. If able, do schedule your visit during a Friday where they have the Friday Foodie Market. There were only about a dozen stalls operating when I visited. There were queues for the more popular stalls. One unexpected fine is the cafe facing these stalls. The beef pie and cakes were great. The Museum of Contemporary Art is worth a short visit.

Leave the rock as the rocks.. The rocks is Sydney. This is where it all started. It is full of history. Millers point which is the rocks. Had signs hung from the house balconies,saying. Leave millers point alone. As the developers wish to remove a lot off the houses & build high rise apartments. And that my freinds would be the end of the rocks. The cafes are great.The art gallery. Which use to be a sailors home. Is well worth a look. The 3rd floor has still one of the rooms. Unfortunately you cannot see inside it.which is a shame. Pubs are good.

Free Tour. I was seeking for something to do for my last evening in Sydney and I thought why not pay a visit to The Rock? However I have no single idea what to seek out. Fortunately I know about this Free Tour from Sydney Visitor Information Centre that there will be routine FREE bring around tour by volunteer. The experience was marvellous as she have bought the group of people and we have benefit ourselves with many interesting stories and comes around of The Rock-Sydney. Volunteer was helpful and tip-sing is not necessary unless you think it is what worth you gained from it.

A Living Museum. Walking through the Rocks area is somewhat akin to walking through a living Museum. While there is some development, much of the area is preserved. Unlike other areas surround Circular Quay, the Rocks area is devoid of significant development (i.e. high rise buildings).The Rocks area is owned by the government and is intended to keep the area as is. To gain a better understanding of the area, you should consider taking the Free walking tour @ 6 pm (I'm Free Walking Tours).
The Rocks has lots to offer. Whether you are looking for quaint shops, restaurants, cafes, markets or just a place to wander The Rocks is the place to go. A lively market on Saturday morning.

Best market ever. . We went to the Rocks on Sunday, and shopped at the Market. Beautiful clothes, gorgeous jewellery, with lots of different styles on offer, not what you find on the High Street. We had coffee and cakes listening to some live music, then carried on shopping. There is such a huge choice of lovely things, I could have bought even more than I did. Some stalls were selling their own designs at very reasonable prices, such as Silk Diva. There was delicious Cicada chocolate. Beautiful glass figurines...This would be a great place to do all your Christmas shopping.
Great food. Nice views.. Food was really great in this area, wasn't too expensive. Right next to sydney harbour bridge and close to the Sydney Opera House. Great location.

Take a walk into the past. Every city should be blessed with the opportunity to see into its past - cobbled streets and old sandstone buildings filled with shops, galleries, a wonderful market and excellent food options.
Great bars and food. Great area of Sydney - full of amazing places to eat and drink.The Pony is good for food and the Argyle is a great bar.
Historical Sydney. Visited the rocks for their food market, wow...hard to decide what to sample. This is the part of the city that seemed to have the most history. Well worth a visit.
Best area to stay in Sydney. So much character and fantastic pubs for meals everywhere. Location fantastic as right next to harbour bridge and circular quay.
Old school Sydney. Loads of old buildings and pubs and little boutique stores. Art galleries and designer clothes. Gift stores cafes and food joints. Never lacking options.

Fascinating. I thoroughly enjoyed this tour. Our guide, Sophie was knowledgeable about history and architecture and she was enthusiastic about sharing her city. The pace was perfect and tailored to our small group. I'm looking forward to revisiting some of the sites she pointed out on our walk.

The Rocks Walking Tours. We were already aware of Australia's convict settlement, but enjoyed our guide, Margaret, and her entertaining tales as we toured the historic streets. The walk takes you by some beautiful scenic areas of the Harbor Bridge and the Opera House. This tour involves a lot of cobblestone paths and sandstone steps. We logged many steps on my FitBit during this tour.

Where the history of Sydney gets a bit murky. The Rocks has a bit of a sorted history and if you take the free walking tour, they will tell you all about it. They even have one at night which goes into even more details and may be more suited for older children and adults. Today The Rocks is the perfect mix of restaurants, shopping and one of the best places to get amazing photos of the icons of Sydney. Friday, Saturday and Sunday are the best time to go to the open markets and see tons of local items, which are so much better to take home than the cheap touristy ones you find in the gift shops. Enjoy the restaurants and walk around the cool old building, thinking about how it would have been to be one of the many prisoners brought here from raining, cloudy England to the warm, sunny Australia... Not a bad trade until you learn how hard it really was to survive here. Dale - TravelingU
Wow. The Rocks is the oldest part of Sydney and a lot of history ... We went there as we waited for the home and away tour awesome area lots of beautiful old buildings

Best place to have food by the side of Sydney opera house ………….. The rocks is the heritage part of the new Sydney …there are many restaurants with Sydney opera house view …best to catch up some beer and fish and chips must try….

Appropriately named place. It sure is a rocky place. The roads and buildings here seem to be built on top of and around large rock formations. There are many shops and places to visit here, though I am not sure exactly where the boundaries of this place are. The Harbour Bridge passes over the area and it is bounded by Circular Quay and Darling Harbour. There is a quiet park and a promenade facing Darling Harbour. We just walked through the whole area heading towards Darling Harbour as there really didn't seem to be anything very interesting here.

Great markets. Went to rocks markets on Saturday before leaving Sydney- never disappoints with a great mix of upmarket handmade wares and fashion, as well as all of the food and entertainment - would definitely recommend to anyone looking for something unique and different.

Very similar to English pubs, cosy & warm. With a small family atmosphere!. Most of the PUB's are next door to each other! all with the greatest attitudes & typical Australian G'day Mate Howz Thing's! I love Australia it has the greatest attitude with all things! (Have a Ganda) ie. Take a look!

Fascinating Neighborhood - Loved the Sunday market. This is a very fun and historic neighborhood. It has been totally revitalized. The weekend market crowd really filled the sidewalks and some of the streets. We enjoyed the market and wished we'd had more time for the permanent shops.

View of a Glimpse of Old Sydney. My boyfriend & I vacationed, in Sydney, Australia, in May 2016. We waked to The Rocks where we got a glimpse of Old Sydney before the newer modern buildings were constructed. The area is well-maintained & the older architecture is well preserved. There are several shops and restaurants. On Saturday (when we went) there were several street vendors to purchase merchandise from and they are set up on closed-off streets. There is an interesting statute of a man, woman & child in the but the face and body is hollow.

Just a lovely walk!. You can do as much or as little as you like. Most of the tourist shops are a bot of a rip off but you can just walk at your own pace and enjoy some of Sydney's early (white) history
Nice place to visit. Leave harbour bridge and walk around the rocks. Is a very nice neighborhood, with heaps of restautrants.

Awesome. How do you describe a place as awesome as this? The rocks is steeped in history ranging right back to the first settlers. In the day there are quirky shops like the awesome button shop where every type of button can b found, to beautiful cafes & great walk ( be prepared for lots of stairs & hills.) In the evening it transforms to a lovely nightlife with historical pubs such as the Hero of Waterloo & the Lord Nelson with its microbrewery. There are also paid ghost walking tours at night or better still a free walking tour ( look for the guts in green) Finally at the weekend the rocks has a fantastic market. DO NOT miss this place!!!!

Cool streets, and funky markets. If you fancy a walk through quirky streets, funky markets, and want to stop for a spot of lunch, The Rocks are for you, and should certainly be on your list of places to go and see if youre in Sydney for the day. Whether youre looking for pizza, kebabs, traditional Bavarian cuisine or just a cheeky burger, The Rocks have it all. The narrow streets are off limits to cars which make them nice to walk down, and the streets are packed with market stalls, hand made scarfs and locally made toiletries. If you have spare cash its the place to spend it, but if youre a budget backpacker just have a look, as the prices are fairly high and you'll spend your budget in no time.
