An area near the harbor for tourists. This little area has some cute restaurants, coffee houses, shopping and walking areas. There are stairs, but worth it to climb up for some crocodile pizza.
Walking tour. Take a rocks walking tour to get the real history of the spot and see some of the small houses and lodging people lived in. Be prepared to take some steps so wear reasonable shoes.

Super cool on weekends!. The first time we were there, we experienced cute shops and mobile fooderies. There were several people playing live music and dozens of people set up in small, temporary tents, selling their original wares. The next time was a Thursday, and not much was going on.

Great place to find food and make friends!. I spent a few quick days in Sydney for work and stayed in the Rocks. Nice place to make a new friend and have a pint. I'm looking forward to a return visit.
This place Rocks!. There is always something happening, this time it was the Vivid Festival but any time you will find lots of people, good food, plenty to occupy yourself and lots happening.

A walk through time at The Rocks in Sydney. A great feature of Sydney's things to do. Do not rush, enjoy, find out about the past, take a tour, enjoy the steps going up or down, check Cadman Cottage, the MCA, the eateries and the pubs. Genial atmosphere and a lot of fun.

Walking thru Sydney history . The Rocks is today more commercial with the markets and bringing in the tourist. If you read more about the history and the signage placed on the building you will know the 1st road in Australia was build here and the great history of Australia.

Great place to wander. Whether on your own or in a small group the Rocks has much to offer. Wear your walking shoes - the pavement is uneven in parts. Explore old buildings whee convicts created buildings stone by stone. Interesting diversity of eateries. Quaint boutique shops. Worthy of a few hours or a day.
Great space to spend some time. A great area of Sydney to explore - history , food , shopping ( time it for the artisan market of home crafts etc ) .

Oh the Rocks are Rocking!. The Art Museum is plunked right here amidst the lively, youthful, laid-back eats and sights and shopping of the Rocks. So, in one stop you can get your culture, trinkets and a good meal and a beer. What is not to love? I was there in summer, dining al fresco by the sea.

Barangroo. A beautiful walk along the foreshore during the Survey Vivid Festival, views across to the Harbour Bridge, Vivid lights everywhere, with lots of smaller displays along the way. Thoroughly recommend this walk for visitors to Sydney or to locals.

A must for Sydney visitors and locals. Not only do they have the best restaurants, bars and micro breweries, there is always some market or festival worth visiting. Or just have a coffee and watch the crowds moving past.

Historical Sydney in a nutshell. The Rocks is not so big that you can't see it all in one day. But it will be one day full of history, great places to visit, fabulous restaurants and lots to buy. Take a guided tour if you want to know more about the beginning of Sydney's history or take a Ghost Walk Tour at night which is a tad spooky. It's a lovely part of town.

Great atmosphere. I can't quite put my finger on it, but I love the atmosphere of the rocks. Loads of cafes, restaurants, bars, diverse people. S market that is great for a browse. Worth a visit for sure.

Must Visit. A very interesting area to wander around at any time. Can access the Contemporary museum from here and continue wandering both under the Harbour Bridge or around to Circular Quay.Markets Saturday and Sunday well worth a visit.

Great time. What a fantastic part of Sydney, This is a must for any traveler to take a step back in time. Beautiful buildings fantastic atmosphere. There is so much to do with the pubs, markets, shops and the docks.

Interesting and "old" part of Sydney. This is the earlier settled and historic part of Sydney comprising a number of redbrick buildings, many of which are pubs and restaurants. Much of the character of the area has been preserved. There are a few notable historic pubs. It is near the South Shore tower of the Sydney Harbour Bridge. Quite a few places to visit are near.

Historical Area of Sydney. Nice easy walk through the historical area of Sydney. Lots of exploring through narrow laneways to appreciate what Old Sydney Town was like. Easy to find your way around - look for the Tourist Walk Signs located near the buildings.
ROCK. A magical place - so much history and real touristy day out adventure. Thoroughly enjoyed it and definite must see
Sunday markets. Well worth a visit on Sunday to have a nice walk around the rocks markets, lads of arts and crafts stalls and a great place to pick up some unique souvenirs from Sydney.

Historic area full of shops. Great place to stroll around and do some shopping. From hand made candy and soaps to clothing boutiques and souvenirs. On the weekend there are also markets outside. It is a bit hilly and some streets are cobblestone which may provide an issue for people with mobility issues

Sydney's historic roots!. You come to Sydney's Rocks, to feel the history and view old buildings, but the highlight turns out to be the cafes, restaurants and pubs that are dotted around the area. I am not attracted to the expensive tourist shops selling trinkets and souvenirs, or the expensive weekend markets. I like to walk around the narrow streets to feel old Sydney town and imagine the place 150 years ago. You can visit an archaeological dig under a hostel, see the Susannah Place Historic Houses museum or visit the Modern Art Gallery, but no matter what you see or feel, you will smell the wafting food fragrances of the eating areas and have a meal there. Worth a visit, though not with high expectations.
oledst part of sydney. stroll down George street and you are there it has changed a lot since it first opened up but that was 30 years ago
Lots of Shopping. Sunday afternoon is a fantastic time for the wives to visit the Rocks. Lots of street vendors, and everything that you know you never needed.
Historic Sydney - Shops, Pubs and Cafes. A great spot to wander around, lots of boutiques, cafes, restaurants and historical pubs.Lots of amazing old buildings and little streets.

Beautiful historic location. Situated right next to Sydneys beautiful harbour and in walking distance to the CBD. Lots of great cafe's and restaurants to enjoy a meal. Lots of historical buildings, gift shops and wonderful Sunday markets.

Read the info!. Whether there is something on, or a quiet day, this is a great place to wander. Heaps of info on walls and sidewalks. Amazing and interesting. If you have kids, stop off at the Rocks Discovery Museum.
Nice area. Very nice and romantic area, with beautiful views, and great restaurants. Perfect to have a lovely afternoon or evening with your beloved one

Beautiful atmosphere. Gorgeous atmosphere down there when the markets are on and to walk around. Be wary as it's always crowded on weekends so try to go outside of it if you can!
Great crafts, shops and architecture
Old part of Sydney. Love this area, so historic and on weekends there is a market. Pubs are very old and you can get a fairly cheap beer. Day or night it is a great area.
Weekend markets. Always changing with lots to see so worth a visit on the weekend, nice area to walk through as well with Australian products

A Booked Walking Tour of The Rocks. Two weeks ago, my partner and I participated in a pre-booked walking tour of The Rocks. The female tour guide was friendly and very informative, it was an absolute pleasure to be part of the small tour group for almost two hours. The tour was booked through the Company which is situated at The Rocks Tower Shopping Arcade. The Rocks area has always been one of my favourite places to visit for the architecture, history, restaurants, market and fabulous harbour views, but to have the experience of walking down back lanes steeped in history and to view actual living conditions from a bygone era, was unbelievable. The stories and history information the tour guide imparted to us was invaluable. Comfortable walking shoes are a must as the walk involved step climbing and lengthy periods of standing, listening and looking. On your next visit to The Rocks, go for a look at the historical building remains behind the main street shops - you will be surprised! Two hours of educational exercise very much enjoyed. Chris C. Melbourne

Revitalized historic area of Sydney. Well done historic area of Sydney between the harbor and the bridge. Many small and interesting shops, cafes, and restaurants. Lots of outdoor dining. There was an open air market with crafts, foods, clothing, much of it locally produced on the Sunday I visited. Fun to walk around, good signage to tell the history of the area.

Came alive for VIVID. It's always been one of my favourite parts of Sydney with its history - birth place of Sydney as we know it. The sense of history has been relatively well preserved with the clustering of historical buildings but it was even more special n the past couple of weeks with Sydney's major event , VIVID, an amazing show of lights and music.
Always enjoy visiting The Rocks. Heaps of places to walk for great Harbourside scenery, close to the CBD for business, unlimited cafe's and restaurants to eat at. Can't wait to come back again.
Saturday morning market at The Rocks. We loved wandering around the Saturday morning market, there was lots to see, not so much choice if you are wanting to buy food.

Interesting area to explore, but beware of the cobbles if your in a wheelchair.. This area by the base of the bridge is very beautiful and intriguing to investigate. Many many shops, some of which are extremely pricey but well worth a look around.

Where early settlers walked. So much history!. The family and I often meet at the Rocks when Biennale and Vivid are on. We love exploring The Rocks. We have stayed at some great hotels there and its handy to the Biennale venues, such as the ferry to Cockatoo Is, then an easy walk to MCA, botanical gardens and Art Gallery of NSW. The markets have unique Australian made crafts and delicious food! There are many handy little restaurants as well. I try to imagine what it must have been like to be an early settler there in the 1700's !
Nice surrounding and history. If you wanna feel the history of Sydney, you need to go there! Its so nice there and the market is really cool with so many friendly people

To every budget. Every time I'm in Sydney, I manage to visit the Rocks. It's a little bit of the old in with the new, a lot of creative industries and great food. Many of the shops and restaurants cater to the filled pockets of tourists, but affordable options can be found. Purchase something from the night and weekend markets, sit down and imagine Sydney in its foundation years. Wear comfy shoes, skip the heels as you will be going up and down little hills, stairs, steps and pavers. This area is beautiful at night time.

Terrific walk through time.. We had a great day along the Harbour and Rocks area, lots to see, eat and enjoy.Weather was perfect and there were festivals on with music, food etc.Recommend to take the time here.
One of my favorite attractions. Beautiful and historic location. Excellent food and market options. Great for all travelers. Take the time to walk through this area.
Worth visiting. Somewhere that you must put onto your itinerary. One of those places that don't really have much to look at, but are still certainly worth a visit.

Rocks Markets were great...a lot of uniquely diy stuff from Australia. Went to the Rocks & Rocks Markets on Sunday. The weather was very lovely & there were a lot of unusual & homemade crafts uniquely Australian. Definitely must go even if you are not buying anything. My shoes gave way that day & I got myself a pair of Ugg boots at the Rocks & a lovely homemade photo album signed by this local artist Lisa at the Rocks Market.Rare find as photo albums are obsolete these days. Also bought this beautifully painted bowl at the Markets by another artist. Love the Rocks Markets so much that we visited the following weekend but it was closed due to the tropical storm. Lots of eateries to choose from in the Rocks as well. A must visit as part of your travel itinerary
Pure history. We love the Rocks and love being tourists in our own city. There is so much to do and plenty to see. If you visit Sydney, steep yourself in the cities history.
Walking tour. This is a very interesting area with lots of history as well and restaurants tucked away. We were happy to take a walking tour to learn more about the area.

The Rocks. I love the rocks. I love wandering around exploring the historical buildings. There are plenty of cafes, pubs and restraunts to visit especially on the weekends when most of the cbd is closed. Market days are the best to find unique gifts and trinkets. Deffinelty worth a visit.

Interesting Visit. We visited the Rocks area at least twice while in Sydney - once at night and once in late morning (after walking the Sydney Harbor Bridge). Close to the harbor area, it is worth taking the time to shop the stores there, as well as grab a bite for lunch or dinner at one of the pubs or cafes. A very enjoyable part of our visit.
History at the Rocks. Thoroughly enjoyed the atmosphere and learning the history of this birthplace of British settlement in Sydney. Walks around the area with informed guides. Pub crawl fascinating.
LIvely Neighborhood Loaded with restaurants. Don't miss strolling around this neighborhood of Sydney with lots of history and great bars/restaurants.

Lovely area, lots of little shops. I love this area of Sydney, it feels so quaint, there are lots of places to browse, I bought some lovely pottery here as a reminder of my visit & it wasn't too expensive, although totally unique.

Go on Market day. Best part of the harbour. It's a fun part of Sydney with lots to see and do. Would recommend eating elsewhere though unless you're happy to have a really expensive meal. Alternatively go on a market day and have some yummy street food. The night markets are on through winter as well.

Great place to eat. We got off our ship in Sydney for a days touring and spent most of it in the Rocks enjoying the food. It almost became a progressive lunch. We had coffee at the rear of a small restaurant and then had a wonderful lunch at the Ricks Cafe where we finished off with the biggest piece of lemon meringue pie I have ever seen.Wonderful food, great buildings and lovely ambience

The Rocks at night. Unfortunately, we were unable to fit in a visit during the daytime, but managed to explore some of the Rocks area at night. The cobbled streets and alleyways leading to the old style pubs and restaurants were enjoyable, but a daytime visit might be the thing to do.

Walk and browse.. We have visited the Rocks area once again, after many previous occasions. It is Sydney's oldest area, full of well restored and maintained terras cottages and other, historical buildings. We enjoyed the pleasant ambiance of the place, the inviting pubs and eateries along the way, the bustling market (mainly souveniers) and the many photo opportunities.Great photos - amongst others - can be taken of the Harbour Bridge, from underneath and of one of the gigantic cruise ships, if one is there. Fair warning: check menu and prices before land yourself in one of the waterside restaurants, as they can be unreasonably expensive. The Rocks is not Sydney's "bargain basement", prices for everything are a bit above the avarage and this can be regarded as normal as this is a typical tourist place. The low exchange rate for the Aussie dollar probably supports the higher prices.However, we have found that the Rocks is a very pleasant and safe place, we never heard of muggings, pickpockets or any other criminal activities which sadly are the characteristic dangers of many other overseas tourist destinations.We will visit it soon.

Photography weekend. We went to Sydney for photography and the vivid festival. We were staying on York street, so a short walk down to The Rocks. Wandering around here with a camera is well worth a stroll. The argyle cut, the stores fronts, the markets and the cobbled streets and history. The autumn leaves on the trees were lovely. This is a great place just to wander through and stop for shopping, coffee and food.

Early history of Sydney. This part of Sydney is the location of the early indigenous people of Australia and later the landing point for the convict ships from England. It is an area rich in the stories of those days set amid the modern setting of today's Sydney. It's a great area to walk around and look at the few remnants of the early days.

Another tourist location. Another must go place when visit Sydney. Anyway easy to go when one reached Circular Quay as its just by the side. One can grab good photos of the Harbour Bridge and Opera House from The Rocks too.

The Old Heart of Sydney. Something for everyone is what you can find by walking the length & breadth of the Rocks ! From under the Bridge at Dawes Point to the Quay at George Street you will find everything from great old pubs (Harbour View, Mercantile, Orient, Fortune of War etc ) , many varied eateries, Street Markets Day/Nights, Historic Buildings , shops with nic knacks & Hotels and B+B's ! You could easily spend a weekend and only touch the surface ! Enjoy !!
good place ! old place ! best during weekly market. old traditional place !on the way to middle of opera house and sydney in middle of opera and harbour bridge , good if u like historic places
Expensive but worth seeing. Stayed in Sydney for two days on a cruise, and went to the Rocks for shopping and meals. Wife bought a rock (opal), so it was not an inexpensive outing.

Very impressed. The Rocks area of Sydney is very clean and well designed. Very easy to get around as the signage is good. As its central it's a good place to stay. Buses and taxi's are easily available and there are plenty of good shops, cafes and restaurants around to choose from.

Old charming The Rocks. Love this suburb. Vintage, old, charming style. Nice houses and little lanes and streets, places you could get lost and discover a new world. Nice places to eat and so much history to learn.

Must-see!. This is a great area of Sydney. I would recommend checking out the bars in this area (ex. Lord Nelson) at night. Even better is going to the Glenmore and going to the rooftop. Beautiful views of the city!

Weekend market . A relax day at the rocks weekend market , best food stall and try different taste of beer with BBQ lamb and salmon . This place open ever weekend from 10am to 5pm , can see a lot of DIY accessories for lady , fashion , home decor and more .

Usual Arty Rocks. Lots of markets full of different types of well made arts and crafts. Very historical area, so take some tours.Every Sydney trip one has to go to the Rocks, all sorts of shops & restaurants no bargains to be had, as the crafts all seem top end products.

nice location, freindly staff, good food. a little pricey. We stopped in for some lunch and was very impressed with the wait staff. Our guy was pushing drinks and food onto us in such a non pushy way that would be a boon for the cafe. He was friendly and seemed to genuinely like his job. The cafe has a great view of the bridge and the Opera house. The food was pretty expensive and while my risotto was good. The pizza was fairly average for $30
Nice market. Went there on a Sunday. U can find everything there.A lot of people, but a nice experience!!I think i loved everything in Sydney anyway!!!
Great place for family!. Great place and great weather :) Nice food along the street . Many handmade stuff along the market. Fresh herb soap and honey is a must buy item!
Rocks great at weekends. On Saturday and Sunday's the Rocks area is worth a visit. There are many crafty type stalls amongst all the cafes and restaurants

Intersting to walk around. we had gone on city tour, where the walk of "The Rocks" was included. Its nice to know the history of the place.
has lovely market, and cafes
if you have free time in sydney then you should visit
the walk takes around 1 hours time
the area makes you feel like you are transported in time

Great area!. Although not a huge amount to do here, there is a lot of little interesting places. Crazy architecture, fantastic markets and amazing history are the highlights. This was the first settled part of the Australian east coast, has some of the oldest buildings around, has spectacular views from up high, lavish and expensive apartments by the water and the best views of the New Years fireworks on the bay.

The Rocks harbour foreshore walk. Grab a bottle of water, take your time and enjoy the Sydney Harbour foreshore with many of its well known locations. I start at Circular Quay because I arrive by train. After buying a coffee at one of the two restaurants next to the railway station I set off towards the Museum of Contemporary Art where I turn left onto Argyle St aiming for the Observatory at Observatory Hill. On my right is the Garrison Church, its open, pop in. I am now well into old Sydneys The Rocks. Moving on I climb the steps opposite the Garrison Church and walk round to the Observatory set in a lovely little park. Views are superb especially from the elevated bandstand. I can see the Harbour Bridge up close. To my left is the Parramatta River and Darling Harbour. I often sit on the grass and take in the view. If I'm lucky a tall ship like the James Craig may go past. Call into the Observatory, it may be open.Leaving the Observatory I can lose myself in the wonderful old streets of The Rocks as I make my way down to the bridge pylon then follow the foreshore back to Circular Quay via the International Terminal or simply retrace my steps depending on how energetic I feel. Quaint, heggledy piggledy, charming, historic, vibrant, heritage, friendly all describes Old Sydney. It wasn't planned, it simply grew. Cul de sacs, side streets, secret passageways, old stairways, take a camera of some sort.Time to move on, refreshments are available in the Rocks or at Circular Quay as you pass by on the way to the Opera House.On arrival at the Opera House walk around and explore, it has super views and the ferries come in real close. You can get refreshments there too, there are so many places to eat.Just past the Opera house is the entrance to the botanical gardens, a great place to sit and rest on the grass, plenty of shade under some of the Fig huge trees. Not another restaurant / cafe for refreshments. You won't go hungry. This is a walk where you may put on weight.You have been following the shoreline so it is impossible to get lost. The gardens are a great place to visit with its fine sculptures and plant selections from around the world.Time to go, next stop is Lady Macquarie's Chair on the point. Have you managed to get this far? The whole walk is only a few kilometers but it is worth the trouble.From Lady M's chair you have fine views back to the opera House and Harbour.Bridge. On the way back I stop at Circular Quay for some typical Australian Fish n Chips, sit on a bench and watch the smorgasbord of faces go past. The hustle and bustle of Circular Quay is a delight, it's a great spot to sit and watch our unique and charming ferries as they speedily arrive and depart. As an immigrant to Australia forty years ago this place grabbed me and still does. To me this is Sydney.
History of the Early Days. In the 1960's when I was here it was a dump, WOW what a transition to a smart, upscale must visit section of the downtown area.

Wow factor. The area has such a history. Best visited with Sydney's Free Tour. Lily, our tour guide, made it come you life. It is also right by the entrance to the Sydney bridge walk entrance and right by the harbor with a million dollar view of Sydney's Opera House. Lots of eateries as well and surrounded by email cute shops.
漂亮的建築, 悠閒舒適. 比起Central Station, 這里的建築更加有古典美, 適合悠閒的散步, 或者在街角的cafe享受一杯悏意的咖啡。在海傍可以拍到Opera House和Harbour Bridge 的精彩照片。剛好是Vivid Sydney出遊, 晚上可以看到精彩的燈光秀, 推薦!

Fascinating District and Market. The Rocks area with its heritage buildings makes for a fascinating walk. It is quite close to all the major hotels so is easily accessible to downtown. The street market was open when we strolled around and provide some great shopping for items we were unable to find elsewhere.

Loved The Rocks Market!. We came on a Friday for the Foodie Market and on Sunday for the normal market. Both were amazing! The Foodie Market had some great places to eat and some other cute shops. The Sunday market was huge with tons of shops selling everything from jewelry to candles to chocolate. A great place for souvenir shopping as well as just a good place to walk around.

AUSTRALIAN HISTORY STARTS HERE. A historical place. Every one who visits this beautiful country must visit this place to know its birth. A guided tour will definitely give you an in depth story about Sydney and Australia.

Great for photos and sight-seeing. Love it here!
Quiet relaxing spot with great views of the Harbour Bridge.
Great cafes and of course opportunity to visit the Ken Done Gallery!

Fantastic market at the Rocks and great place to visit. There is so much about the Rocks that as a tip you should include a visit to this historic part of Sydney. It's walking distance from the Opera House and Circular Quay. Lots of shops, art galleries, historic buildings, bars, cafés, restaurants. Also most important is the market at weekends for great atmosphere and friendly people.

Trendy and Historic. Located next to Cicular Quays, it is a small area filled with restaurants, shops and hotel. Low built brick and stone buildings. Tried a couple of restaurants and food was good, as was service. Fun for a couple of hours to soak in the historic nature of the buildings and what was going on back in Sydneys early history. Locals and tourist hang out here.

Historic and vibrant. Historic, interesting and located right beside Circular Quay where ferries, trains and buses abound, The Rocks is easy to locate. Walking is the best way to explore this area with its nooks and crannies, galleries, numerous good eating establishments, harbour foreshores, history, theatre, bars, pubs and shops. During Vivid, one of Sydney's premium and popular light festival, The Rocks is the premium location.

Shopping. Weekend at the Rocks is great. Historic buildings, food, clothes, back streets, pubs and close by the Harbour. The Rocks Markets are fun with a large variety of goods, surrounded by even more shops and with beautiful museums.
One of my favourite places in Sydney. Love this place, full of history and so much to see. Nice and clean, friendly people, great place to visit.

The Rocks rock. If you like quirkiness and local history about the first settlers and the associated stories about the convicts this is the place to go in Sydney.It is located some 5 minutes from Circular Quay,which has a train station which will take you to and from the airport,I would recommend going on the free walking tour where a guide will describe the area and tell you all the stories you just pay what you feel is right for the tour(they also do a 3 hour walking tour of the city centre which is excellent)Whilst it is a historical area there plenty of chic restaurants,bars,pubs,street market and views of the bridge and the opera house.It has a number of modern hotels as you would expect I stopped at a boutique hotel The Rendezvous which is in The Rocks itself which was great for needs.Great place to go do your research online

Great area to walk around & on Sunday there is a very good Market. There are lots of art galleries around this area to both view and buy art. Also many restaurants & cafés. It is also close to the Iconic Sydney Harbour Bridge & the Contemporary Art Gallery . This has an outdoor restaurant on the top floor that has a beautiful view of The Sydney Opera House The Sunday market has some excellent stall holder with wonderful products

Weekend Market was great. There is a weekend market here which is fun to visit. The Rocks has a lot of shops also. I bought some handmade Christmas ornaments that are unique. It would be easy to buy a lot there! The area is also great to walk around . Would have eaten there but it was too early for lunch - several restaurants looked like they would be great to try

The most historic area of Sydney. We recently did a group tour of this historic area near Circular Quay in downtown Sydney. As a Sydneysider, I learned things about this atmospheric part of my own city that I had not known of in the past. There are lots of alleyways and views that most people walk past every day. Just google walking tours of the Rocks to compare the offerings.
Beautiful place to walk. The area resembles the European architecture. good place to spend some time on weekend as there are food stalls and clothing stalls put every weekend for travellers.

Old town.. A wander round the old streets and warehouse shops is a lovely way to spend an afternoon with stops for tea or otherwise in the original part of Sydney. The craft market is well worth a visit and in the evenings an essential place for dining is one of the open air restaurants alongside the wharfs - excellent food and wine at reasonable prices, don't miss out on this for one evening.

Beatiful place beside the harbour. The rocks is like the old part of the harbour or rather the place were all the docs are. There are a lot of nice houses and Shops very good renovated. A lot of Restaurants are there too. Nice for a walk.

Good bars and food . Bit of a treck from main drag uphill but has some nice bars and restaurants. Close to shangri la hotel area with a bar round corner that does micro brewery beers. I personally like it as not really an area most tourists know about even literally in shadow of the bridge. Lots of after work drinks happen here.
Cozy Historical Place. Nice place to have some coffee at the coffee shops but not just for hang-out, you also can get some knowledges about an history of Australia.
Loved the markets . Visited the Sunday markets, could have spent a fortune there the wares were top quality and very eclectic. Set in the beautiful Rocks area it is a must visit if on holiday
Visit for the Sunday market. The most compact neighborhood in Sydney. It's easy to walk and there are many places to eat.Sundays have a big market that is worth the trip.

Check out the tiny laneways. Most tourists stay in the main drag and don't get the true feel if the Rocks. Take time to do the nurses walk, read the signs and feel the history. Be sure to wear flat shoes as the cobbled laneways are bumpy but well worth it.
Visit on weekend- there's a big market. Lots of cute shops and restaurants. Recommend coming on the weekend as they have a big market with lots of local vendors.

Visit The Rocks. Very nice area for a walkabout. Beautiful park area, great walking paths, views of Sydney Harbour, many converted dock buildings and the Sydney Harbour Bridge. What more could one want?

Sydney's first settlement site.. The Rocks is a major tourist attraction given its excellent location on the harbour front and for its historical significance as Sydney's first settlement.Today, and while several areas of The Rocks still retain their original architecture and charm, massive urban development has also taken place in line with the city's growth and status as Australia's Premier city.I simply love walking around while browsing the galleries and of course sampling the excellent range of beers offered by the multitude of pubs in the vicinity. Having time to spare before a late lunch with a friend, I actually went on a solo pub crawl - not the same as undertaking a pub crawl with a group of friends ......

Guided Tour. We travelled with Sydney Sightseeing Tours. We were picked up at 7am sharp and driven to the Rocks where we were taken on a walking tour of the ROCKS by a very knowledgeable guide with a bent for history.

Weekend Trip to the Markets. Very pleasant Sunday afternoon spent wandering around the outdoor market,interesting and varied stalls, crafts art and food. Indoor shops, selling a variety of goods and then the designer ranges, all of whom are also open during the week. Cafes, restaurants, bars and ice-cream shop complete the experience. Then dropdown to the Quay or stay around to view Dawes point under the bridge. Watch the boats go by. Great day out.

A little disappointed.... I loved the feel of the Rocks area in Sydney but with all the hype hearing and reading about it before I was a little disappointed with my experience. It's way smaller than I imagined and the shops are ok, you can find better shops in the city centre imho. Nice place to sit and have lunch and people watch though, but wouldn't rush back.
a little bit of history. if you get off the train at the quay you can walk through teh rocks on your way to the harbour bridge...well worth it, nice pic's

SHopping and pubs--only gets better with the Sydney pub tours. I had a tour (the Sydney Pub tours) in this area. SO I spent a good three hours beforehand just shopping and looking around. There is a tourist information center located here as well. It's a short/decent (depending on your physical health--I'm 22 and had no problems) walk from the SYdney Opera House and Harbor Bridge. The area has an interesting history--it was blamed entirely for the bubonic plague and then had much of the area destroyed for scapegoat reasons and/or the construction of the new harbor bridge. My favorite part, though, was Sydney Pub Tours, which start at the Mercantile Hotel.
Sydney's old town. Anywhere else in the world it would be called Old Town. Very nice neighborhood with shops, restaurants and museums. Certainly worthwhile to spend a few hours in.

Lot of photo opportunities. We did the rocks tour by "I am free tours", the guide was a girl and was knowledgeable and helpful. She showed and told us many things about the rocks and adjoining areas. The rocks is architecturally beautiful and would love to take more photographs there.

So full of history. This has so much history. There are walking tours that do not run for a long duration and give you enough information. In the residential blocks look out for the pulley clothes lines. There is a building row which was accommodation in the early days that had a shared kitchen and laundry. There are still remnants of this too see. Plumbing is still not installed to individual dwellings, the tenants share a water tap outside. This building also has secret door ways between dwellings that take you from the front to the back. The shortest street is in this vicinity and on Sundays there is a market place that continues all the way around. If you love things of the past this is great

This is really an interesting place!. I wasn't sure why this rated so highly on Trip Advisor until I took a free tour of The Rocks. There is a ton of history here, and it is an extremely fun place to spend a day. I would suggest taking the I'm Free tour to get the basics...then spend a day wandering around. I love this place.

Interesting place to kill an afternoon. Quite unique neighborhood to spend a few hours exploring. With all the stairways/alleys it gets to be a bit of a maze and the are a handful of shops/restaurants scattered around.

Beautiful area. One of my favourites location of sydney is the rocks.
Amazing restaurants, pubs, bars and a during the weekend the have a lovely market. Its a must!
Go for a walk through the strees and u will always find a new view of the city.

Get your Rocks off at the Rocks!. What an amazing part of Sydney - something for everyone! The Rocks weekend markets are full of interesting buys; the ghost tours are frightening fabulous; the oldest Sydney hotel is there for your drinking pleasure and you can even hire a hotel room with a ghost! I never run out of things to do and see there, and if I ever do, I'll spend my time in the coffee shops, the Lowenbrau Keller or the Guylian Cafe sipping chocolate!! Delightful!

History comes alive!. The buildings around the rocks are amazing. Beautiful Sydney sandstone weathered over the years. Great for international guest to understand our history and the markets have great stuff for them that they would love!

A 'must visit' attraction. Take your time to browse the crafts on offer. Some are surprising, and most (?) seem to be locally made. Exceptional availability of photos and artwork of local places. Even able to purchase a cute nativity scene. Be prepared to be jostled and crowded, especially if a cruise liner has just docked ...but it's all part of the experience.

Markets and stalls, yummy food too!. Walking through the rocks, came across food stalls and markets on the Friday before Anzac Day, good food and interesting stalls made it worth a closer look. Do yourself a favour, even if a resident of Sydney, go have a look!

Love the Rocks, something for the whole family.. Just love walking around the rocks, great saturday markets, lots of old pubs, great food and the best view in sydney!! You can watch the ferries and sometimes see the big ocean liners, walk around and browse, art, museum, history, walk up the top to the harbour bridge. Love the rocks, the heart of sydney!

Nice markets. The markets along the rocks are great. Sydney rocks is great for seeing Sydney's history. We had a nice lunch at an old pub and shopped at the markets. If you plan on shopping take a backpack!!

Sunday on the Rocks!!!. Go on a Sunday to hit the market set up---this is fantastic!! The Rocks in general is a great place to stroll around and see some of the old houses of Sydney....it also gives great views of the Opera House and Bridge
Enjoyed the free guided tour. Anyone who comes to the rocks must experience the free guided tour at 7 pm. The 90 minute tour is a great way to get to know how the history of the city.

Great place to Visit and have Dinner or Lunch. Went to see The Rocks in the evening and ended up having dinner at one of the many outdoor cafes there. It is quite pricey, but we had a great meal and the weather was perfect. Many shops and cafes are located in this area and well worth the visit.
Great day spent. Spent a day walking around the Rocks, looking in the various shops. Relaxing. Met tons of interesting people from all over the world.

The Rocks!. A lovely place to sit down and relax after touring around the Harbour.
Has some really great cafes around so you can enjoy a good coffee and a great view of the ferries coming in and out...
There is also a great market that runs on the weekend with great little shops!

Rocks Shops too Modern. Walked around part of the Rocks area. Disappointed with so many modernised centres with modern shops. Where were the old fashioned centres with unique arts, craft and home-made stalls?

Surrounded by History. It is suggested that The Rocks is just a tourist precinct and honey pot, but it is way more than that. It may be suggested that tourists were in the area a few hundred years ago and not much has changed since apart for the population and the progress of "civilisation"The whole area and the adjoin area is full of character and history, I love it for the vitality and the cosmopolitan feel of the place.
Nice stroll for shopping . Nice to visit on the weekends when they have the markets set up. Lots of shops and cafes as well. Bring some cash with you as many places don't accept cards.
The Rocks. What a great place to visit and have a bite to eat. Interesting buildings to check out and shops. A great place to walk around and view.
Amazing. The Rocks is the Old Sydney. ..but with the right shops. ..bars. ..hotels. ...stunning architecture. ....i love every visit to this iconic address if Sydney
Sunday markets. Love the Sunday markets as they have lots of unusual and locally made things to buy. Will be going back there before Christmas to buy some original presents

Rocks walking tour. We went to the Friday Foodies Market at the Rocks. Not the biggest market we have been to, but there was a variety of different foods available. We loved this area, so much to see and do. Buskers were busy playing and singing down beside the harbour. We went on a walking tour at night to see and hear the history of this area. The tour was informative and free!! You gave a donation if you want too! We had a great volunteer taking our tour!
Back to our roots. If ever staying in the city a walk around the Rocks is a definite must. Learning about our past is something we all should experience.
Great Pubs. Plenty of good pubs around the area with lots of live music. Always a good area to meet new people and have plenty of laughs
great pubs and restaurants full of atmosphere. the rocks is a fun place to be. the roof top bar at the Glenmore Hotel has fabulous views of the Harbour. Good music everywhere we went.
Small area - with character. Charming area but rather small. Much of the "Outer Rocks" area is still being regentrified. Enjoyed the shops, restaurants, and character of The Rocks.
Beautiful view with spectacular view of the Sydney Habour. Sunday markets is must see at the Rocks, beautiful cafes, bars, clubs if you are young at heart night life is buzzing at the Rocks.

High end shopping and great service. I spent a day strolling the streets, looking in the jewellery and art shops, most of which were beyond my pocket, but they were far more interesting than anything you would find in a shopping centre. There are some fabulous artworks on show, and I did end up buying a Charles Billich in his gallery near the Contemporary Art Museum - although I didn't buy it until I had returned home! The lady there was very helpful without being pushy and (luckily) the piece was still available when I decided I could afford it after all! There are some lovely places to eat and have a coffee, too, and were reasonably priced.Finally, there are some great views from the top of the Art Museum, which is also well worth a visit!
A great stroll around the oldest part of Sydney. The Rocks is a great neighborhood to stroll around. It is the oldest part of Sydney filled with lots of restaurants, bars and great harbour views.

Yanks in old Sydney. This charming neighborhood is just a block away from Sydney's Harbor. It has many historical buildings - many of which house restaurants and pubs - and you can spend hours walking around.

Historic. The Rocks is wonderful to walk through and soak up the history of Sydney. Lots of things are going on here with markets and shopping. All the high end shopping is available here to, but I just liked to walk and admire the old buildings and imagine what it would have been like to live in Sydney back then

A Walk Through the Past. Enjoyed a beautiful Sunday in The Rocks. Lots of lovely cafés and restaurants for breakfast and lunch with great food (but bring your wallet along as some of the prices can be a little steep). The markets are fantastic with lots of interesting things and happily not all aimed at the tourist market. Would say you haven't seen Sydney until you visit The Rocks.

Fun Street Shopping. The Rocks comes alive with an outdoor market on the weekends. All types of local goods to look through! The area is surrounded by pubs so you will never get thirsty. Wear good walking shoes and must be able to walk up and down hills.

Nice spot to visit . Visited the rocks whilst in Sydney for a show recently. Lovely little spot with eateries and hotels. There are markets on and a shopping arcade with shops in side. Worth a visit if you are in Sydney

A must for a visit on Saturday and Sunday. Great craft market at weekends. I did a lot of my gift buying there as well as quite a few things for myself. There is also an arcade with great little gift shops as well as Opal Minded for Opal lovers.

Underwhelmed. We did a guided walk here and walked around on our own and expected more form it. It is mainly a place were people live. It has a couple of pubs, high end hotels, restaurants and even a market on a Saturday. But there are places that are a lot more active at night in Sydney.

An adverage area to view.. Located at the bottom of the Bridge, on the left side of Circular Kay.of course rocky, steps to climb. A few restaurants there..on the week-ends they hold a craft Fair which was very nice.

Fascinating view of old Sydney. Exploring all the streets, back alleys and hidden courtyards of the Rocks made it easy to visualize how rough and rugged life would have been during the early days in Sydney Harbor. Felt like we were in a Pirates of the Caribbean movie set....but it was real!

Old Sydney town in the middle of Sydney. Awesome place for a walk through and visit some old pubs, The Fortune of War is great and there a plenty of small specialty shops you are guaranteed to find something you want

Visit the Rocks, Sydney for an unforgettable experience.. The Rocks is surely one of the most interesting places to visit when in Sydney, especially over a weekend when the little streets and alleyways come alive with a fantastic artisan market. The whole area buzzes with colour, energy, music and a sense of excitement. I never leave the Rocks Markets without a treasure clutched in my hands. The Rocks is situated across the road from the Cruise Terminal and easily accessible by foot or public transport. Just take the bus or train to Circular Quay, cross the little park, up the steps and you are back in history, to the place where Sydney Town began, three hundred years ago! The historical buildings are well sign posted, and are used as shops, museums, restaurants and art galleries....the past blending seamlessly with the present. I recommend a visit to the Rocks for all age groups. There is a bustling Bavarian Bierhaus for those wanting to try something different. Enjoy!

Great location, access to everything!. The Rocks area of Sydney has it all. High end hotels, great restaurants, old classic pubs, and beautiful areas for wandering around in. We stayed in a Rocks based hotel (see my review on the Rendezvous hotel) and walked to all the major attractions. My GF even walked to the Sydney Opera House for an evening ballet without issues!Besides location, you can easily find transportation options from ferries (nearby at circular quay), to train, to taxis. Only challenge about the Rocks is many establishments close down early. It may be the time of year I went to Sydney but bars, restaurants, and shops closed way earlier than I'm used to living in the 24 hour a day Philippines. Be aware of thatFinally, I'm a cautious traveler and thoughtful about my surroundings but I always felt safe and had no issues in the Rocks or anywhere in Australia. Overall, great place for your home base as you explore Sydney!

Very unique stuffs!. If u like small and unique handmade stuffs. This place is for u! All the little handmade items such as rings made frm penny, bangles made from fork n spoon, handmade clothes for kids and adults, handmade cufflinks etc are so pretty and well.. unique!! They are not cheap since mostly are handmade. But they are of good quality and really pretty! Must visit!

Amazing views and atmosphere.. Take your time to stroll down the streets on The rocks. There are bars everywhere serving beers and food with exceptional views to the harbour. There are also markets in Sunday's and you can grab a quick bite and shop for souvenirs. A must if you are in Sydney.

Worth a visit!. When in Sydney it is a MUST to visit the historic Rocks area. The buildings and the names of the streets and alleys ooze history. We love it! There are so many little eateries here and also lovely speciality shops and art galleries. All of this so close to Sydney Harbour with the lovely views of the Harbour Bridge and the Opera House! You just cannot go wrong!

Cool place to wander and eat. Pubs and grub. Pizza and cafes. Pancakes. Pricey shops. Really cool antique shop with maritime stuff - antique cannons, bone carvings, just cool but kind of expensive stuff - in same warehouse complex as Pancakes on the Rocks. Fortune of War is the oldest pub in Sydney. A few cafes. Way pricey opals. The Sydney Bridge Climb is above the Rocks. It's just a trendy cool place in an otherwise high rise area. Close to the ferries and across the water from the Opera House. Fun to watch the ferries come and go.

Fun place to explore. Either meander through all the streets and side alleys or take a free tour. Worth an afternoon to explore this historic area with lots of small boutiques. Weekends has lots of outside vendors of all sorts lining the main streets.

Old, Old Sydney. The Rocks was where the convicts first lived in the early days of Sydney. Thus it was a rough and tumble area. Today it's full of a mixture of the old and new construction and Sydney is still trying to figure out how they are going to handle it. Take the Rocks Free Tour to learn more of the stories of the area.

Nice, but pricey. We arrived here for dinner, but found the prices a bit expensive for our taste. Nice to go and have a look around but there wasn't a huge range of establishments and they were expensive. Darling harbour offered more choice and value in our opinion.

The Rocks rock!. I highly recommend strolling around the area of The Rocks. Leave a full day for it, or even 2. It is fascinating, which a small museum, historical buildings, cosy and quaint pubs and great places to walk and walk and walk. Loved it!

Wow! What a stunning place!. Loved this place!!So many beautiful old buildings that have been preserved and some fascinating stories to be told.I hope others take the time to explore all of the funky laneways and historical information available.
Views views views. Rocks is the place to be especially for first timers. Views of harbour bridge opera house etc. Some very good bars/cafes with a great backdrop

Love it here!. From the markets, to the Irish pub, to the Italian restaurant and buskers, this place is very special!
The atmosphere is electric and it's an easy walk from ferry/train terminal.
Take your camera as the buildings are beautiful and there is a magnificent view looking up to the Harbour Bridge.
Enjoyed the markets at the Rocks. Lively buzzing market place with some very interesting stalls, and friendly people. Great thing to do especially on a lovely sunny day.
For the locals market. Always like to visit the Rocks for their weekend markets where I believe only local products are on sales. Love the vibes there!!!
just walk around. It is the oldest part of Sydney and as buildings from the 1820's onwards. Lots of cafés and shops to see, not that busy traffic wise.
Great Escape . I always enjoy walking around the Rocks. Quaint, slightly contrived but fun. Tourist shopping everywhere, and lots of little bars and cafes. It's fun. But don't take it too seriously!
Rock's Markets Sunday. The markets at The Rocks on Sunday are worth a visit whilst in Sydney. Lots of stalls selling everything from food, clothes, jewellery and anything else you can think of.

Great insight into the Birth of this city in the old town.. Some select hotels here, and quiet though much building work going on which may well darken this whole area, with Casinos and hotels on the Darling Harbour side. Heritage area, good shops, nice places to stop and eat. I hope it will not be spoiled by the developments, far too many have been allowed in Sydney.

Good neighbourhood to explore and have a bite to eat at. This is a good neighbourhood to explore and have a bite to eat at.There are a few pubs that are good and as well if you wanna stay in this neighbourhood the Holiday Inn is right there, as well as a convenience store.There are many little restaurants, boutique shops, some benches to rest your weary feet at and people watch, you also have some parks to relax in as well there is the neighbourhood centre where you can gather your bearings and get some information from the person at the desk if you have any questions on things while you are here.Lots of tourists are here but it is still worth it and close by to the big downtown hotels.

Charming with great Markets.. We walked from Darling Harbour to The Rocks. It is such a lovely, scenic area. The sandstone buildings are just beautiful and there are lots of charming little boutique shops to browse.A highlight for me, was the local markets, which operate on weekends. They were filled with plenty of great food choices, as well as some gorgeous hand made items from some of Sydney's talented locals.

Great little area in Sydney. We stayed in the Rocks and it really is the best place for many of Sydney's greatest sites - opera, bridge, restaurants, ferries, Botanic gardens, MOCA, hop on and off bus tours and simply just wandering. Of course there are other older areas to visit as well, but this is a great area for the visitor to stay and make the base for a trip.

Good restaurants and bars. The Rocks is a good place to go in the afternoon or evening to get a meal or just some drinks. It is a short walk from the Sydney Harbor. Many of the establishments have outside seating, which is very pleasurable on a nice day.

Quite Popular. This seems to be the place the younger crowd likes to hang out. There are many good restaurants and lots of bars here. We found a nice Irish Restaurant to duck into for a meal - if you aren't into partying and drinking, go early, eat you meal and head to the Harbor (we found the crowd at the Harbor more inviting ~ less drinking!) There is some good shopping and sightseeing, loved the old architecture.

History, history.... Nowadays The Rocks is like any 'old part' of cities around the world. It is a tourist precinct but it is still well worth a walk around. Lots to explore, places to shop, places to eat and great views of the harbour.
Weekend markets. Go on a weekend for the flea market. Tons of food choices and near Circular Quay for the Harbour, Opera and Bridge views. Fantastic place.
Favourite location. By far my favourite part of Sydney , old world charm with chic shopping and a wonderful market filled with delights including amazing hand made jewellery
The Rocks. When it was suggested to us that we go to The Rocks, I was expecting that it would be a particularly beautiful place. It was not even beautiful. It was essentially nothing!
Get lost in the Rocks!. There is so much history to see here you need to wander and lose yourself to take full advantage of this wonderful piece of Sydney history.
The Hip Place. This seems to be the happening place. A lot of good restaurants and bars here. Good shopping and sightseeing. Great for the younger crowd.

The Rocks. awesome! One of my favorites. short walk right off of Circular Quay. lots of walking except for St. Patricks Day where you just had to stop off and celebrate the day with all sorts of Aussies and tourists.

The Rocks Area in Sydney "Rocks". The Rocks by day is a treasure trove of history, shopping, sight seeing and degustation.. Make sure you visit on the weekends, to take advantage of the Rocks Outdoor markets.. The Good quality home made goods at reasonable prices are what attracts me. from kids toys and art works to clothes and jewellery. There are food stalls and all the usual market suspects. But take a hike up the back of the Rocks and discover the myriad of laneways, containing original dig outs and lodging if the early settlers, information plaques about the area and unusual hidden shops.. Like the Oracle.. By night the Rocks transforms to party central, with live music Thursday, Friday and Sat nights in the pubs and usually free to get in! More like Italy when you walk down the food alleys, where a violin or harp may serenade your dinner.. Very popular,, you might need to book.. Have fun

A must-visit when in Sydney.. This is the most historical place in Sydney and is definitely a must-visit when in the city. You don't have to be a historical buff to fully appreciate the area as the atmosphere of the district is really different from other parts of Sydney with cobblestone streets and quaint looking cafes. There are museums, galleries, and many shops and sites of interest in the area. I also did a short tour by the local tourism office nearby and I found it was worth the time. There is also a weekend market from 10am-5pm at Playfair St and George St if you want to be indie.

Rocks Walking Tour with students. My school recently attended the Rocks Walking Tour with our students. It was a very good day. The guides were extremely knowledgeable and friendly. Our students got to dress up and learn about various convicts or people who came here around the time of British Colonisation. Well worth it.

History lover's and Market lovers paradise. Going on a Sunday with all the markets open was awesome. I've been before quite a few times, from interstate, but never on a Sunday and it was buzzing with activity. We booked in for the Rocks Walking tour and it added so much to the experience. We could immerse ourselves in the history as well as contemporary culture.

Visited many a time and always a fantastic time.. I have lived in Sydney several times in my life, more than forty years ago and later a year in 2005 – 2006. Queensland is really my state. I mention this only to give you an idea of the value in visiting the rocks. It is one of the oldest parts of Sydney and has a great atmosphere. From the market, “a sort of a flea market,” to going on a pub-crawl or just enjoy exploring. Bring your camera and if you intend walking around make sure you have a reasonable condition and good shoes. It's not flat. bit of climbing here and there. You will love it.

Lovely area of Sydney. The Rocks area of Sydney has lots of interesting shops, from clothing to holiday nicknacks. Whatever your budget there will be something for you. The restaurants and pubs in the area are lovely and you will never be short of somewhere to eat or drink. There are cuisines from all countries there. The area itself is good to walk around if you fancy some intestine photos of your trip and a view of circular key or the harbour bridge.We spent a lot of time in that location.

A great spot to visit. So much to do and see here. A very touristy area and therefore can be pricey if you are not careful. We went to the rocks market and ate some great corn on the cob, and bought a few touristy things. It has some great views to the bridge and harbour, lots of places for coffee and eating. Lots of interesting historic places. Circular quay is the hub for all the ferries and trains to definitely worth a visit.
Have your walking shoes on. So much to see.. You need a lot of time to explore this area.hidden laneways, shops, galleries, museums. something for everyone.

Historic area of Sydney. Adjacent to the Circular Quay, Sydney Opera House, and Harbour Bridge is The Rocks. Compared to other parts of the world, not so old but part of Australia's history. Basically, a lot of shops and cafes.
Interesting Architecture. Love;y architecture formed with rocks.. Giving a 3D effect. This place was historically a jail and has many stories around. Some even horror :)

Pricey part of town. The rocks is quite touristy and a priced accordingly. There are some great heritage pubs, restaurants, boutique stores and galleries in the nearby area. Worth a visit as it is one of the more historic parts of Sydney.

Historic Rocks. This is where all the convicts were dumped when they were shipped to Australia. It's now one of the most expensive areas in Sydney. Full of original buildings and interesting streets, there is always something going on in the rocks area. The weekends are alive with street markets and cafes to chill out in the warm sun.Just a few minutes walk from Circular Quay, you can immerse yourself in the history of the early settlers in Australia and learn about how this area was literally cut out of the rocks that were here for thousands of years before.Get out of the main City streets and visit the rocks.

Comfortable stroll thru old town. The Rocks area is part of the Circular Quay area and is an extension of George Street. You can start your walk from near the Intercontinental Hotel and Alfred Street. Walk along daytime and nighttime for an enjoyable view of old Sydney with cobblestone street, old low rise buildings and great shops and restaurants. George Street will take you up under the Sydney Harbor Bridge, but when you get to the Holiday Inn, you have seen most of it. Also look into the side streets especially Argyle Street for good Italian and German restaurants. There is also a weekend market here. The back of The Museum Of Contemporary Art also borders The Rocks. You will love the wonderful architecture especially the old hotels, reminiscent of old times. We ate here 3 times during our weeklong stay because of the great selection of eating places, and good ones too as all were busy. Recommended, Pancakes on the Rocks, Munich Brauhaus, La Renaissance.

Great neighborhood to stay in Sydney. My hostel was here so had a chance to explore this area. Convenient to Circular Quay harbor, weekend markets, several museums and observatory. Glad to stay in this area.

Recommendations for The Rocks on the Weekend. Definitely go to The Rocks! It's a very interesting section of Sydney- right next to Circular Quay and the hills overlooking the harbor.In the Rocks area, I recommend climbing up to The Australian Hotel. "Climbing up" means just this- lots and lots of steps as the area is very hilly. If you have a problem with walking, there is always a taxi. At the Australian Hotel you will experience an authentic original bar with unusual (for us Americans) authentic Australian food. We had a delicious duck pizza, but weren't brave enough to try the kangaroo or wallabe pizza! Took a picture of the menu as it was so unusual! You will find lots of locals here, many of whom are college kids. Hey, Sydney is full of youth- a happening, young hip atmosphere. Hotel hopping in the Rocks area: Next, in the evening, be sure to go to The Glenmore Hotel on Cumberland Street. Have a drink at their bar and enjoy fantastic views of the city. Shoppers Delight: On the weekends there is a craft market with REAL ART- the "good Stuff"- items made by Australian artists!. This is NOT a flea market with junk- worth going to-located on the main streets. Just walk past the Quay area and you will see white awnings. Also there is a center large tented area with a variety of vendors. In particular, I found a vendor who had unusual wooden face watches with leather bands. Also, lots of beautiful handcrafted "high-end" jewelry in a wide range of prices. You will also find some fun and delicious food there- from handmade chocolates to grilled and buttered corn on the cob! Loved Sydney-Loved the Rocks!

Lots to do in the Rocks. The Rocks area in Sydney has so much to do for all the family. The market has so many great boutique stalls, with something for everybody. The Circular Quay is a buzz of activity with the Opera House bars offering great views whilst having a drink and food looking straight at the Harbour Bridge
Nice area. This area has a nice spirit, cosy and of good class. Beautiful area, nice restaurants, easy to reach By walking.

Enthralling by day and night. We did the free day tour which was very historic and interesting then the ghost tour by night which was just as interesting visiting lots of out of the way areas you would not normally see.

2nd honeymoon in Sydney. I really enjoyed walking the old streets and reading the history plaques. On the weekends there is a farmers market which had great food. Don't miss the free Rocks history museum.
Beautiful Sydney Centre!. Going to Sydney without spending time in The Rocks is a "miss". Beautiful architecture and impeccable!

A great find while visiting Sydney Harbor.. On our first full day in Sydney we caught the bus from our hotel to the Circular Quay near Sydney Harbor. As we walked along the terminals for the various ferries we continued toward the older section near the harbor. We walked up a few steps and came upon the main thoroughfare for vehicular traffic. Shops and restaurants lined both side of the street in this quaint area known as "The Rocks".There are many secondary and side paths where we came upon those special and unique places. On the weekend they also hold an open market which attracts many vendors and local artist.Here my wife discovered her favorite cafe for cappuccino and a pastry. We also found a great side street cafe for lunch nearby as well. In one of these stores, my wife bought me my Aussie Squashy hat for my birthday. There are a tons of stores in Sydney that sell them but this was special coming from a store in one of our favorite places to spend time while in Sydney. We will be staying in a hotel in this area on our next visit to Sydney. You must spend at least a day checking out "The Rocks" if you are visit the Sydney area.

Make sure you really take the time to enjoy these area!. Quaint shops, cafes and old pubs are to be enjoyed not only on the main walk but through its alleyways. And tucked away is also a Museum of contemporary art to explore. The Friday markets are fun with merchandise and food--ice cream anyone? For history bluffs there is Codmans Cottage, Sydney Observatory and Dawes Point Battery. The Rocks started as a slum for visiting sailors and prostitutes which was a perfect haven for the later Rock Push gang to dominate. Once the buildings started to decay and then the Bubonic plague came in, it wasn't hard to clear out the residents and start the Harbor Bridge. There were years of clashing between town folks and the Union with the town folks winning; and the area developing into what it is today.
Very popular place to eat. During the day, not as much going on as at night. Lots of places to eat here and very close to the tourist area of the harbor and Opera House, etc.

Where Everything Changed. The First Fleet landed in what is now called the Rocks in Sydney Harbor and established the first British encampment on the continent. The rocks in The Rocks are fascinating. Lean into the outcroppings you see everywhere, sandstone, shale and other rocks. Run your hand along them and think about the millions of years they have been there. The settlers/invaders did a great job of building in and around the rocks, preserving some of it for us to enjoy hundreds of years later while obviously putting their own imprint on the surroundings.
Good selection of restaurants. Great selection of restaurants all close together, great outdoor market at the weekends with an interesting range of stalls, also some up market shops.

a good feel of Australian history. a great place to wander around and soak up the atmosphere. stop for a coffee or bite to eat along the way in one of the many eateries in the area. finish it off with a walk across the harbour and a ferry trip back from millions point

My favourite part of Sydney!. This is by far my favourite little nook of Sydney. What a beautiful place it is. It reminded me a lot more of England, and the shops and cafes are great. I would recommend eating here one night. There is a great Cook House Pub we went to where you pick your own meat and BBQ it yourself. They also do markets here on Saturdays which are great for souvenirs and gifts.

A great Saturday morning. A damp Saturday was no deterrent to a sparkling morning. Great to visit this site again and experience all the ambience I remember from my twenties! Saturday stalls were so interesting and varied and the repartee of the stallholders such fun. Beautifully cooked herbed sausages and onions on a tasty roll just right on a dismal day weatherwise. The cheery disposition of the ferry attendant for the journey home further enhanced our enjoyment of such an interesting historical area.

Beautiful area with markets and a beautiful view. Worth going on a weekend day as the markets are on most of the year. In summer there are Friday night markets. Parking is a bit difficult but plenty of places to grab a bite to eat or a drink with a beautiful view of the harbor.

Old world meets Trendy. Birthplace of Australia The best place to find a Great CafeTrendy PubBrilliant Restaurant Night LifeHistory The one place in Australia that it's all at your finger tips Tourist Mecca

A 'MUST DO" WALKABOUT IN SYDNEY. A short distance from Circular Quay this part of the City is an easy walk and full of historic 'treasures'. Be sure to walk the lanes and read the information provided. Stay for a coffee or meal in one of the characterful restaurants and poke about the shops and stalls.

Historical Rocks.. We looked around the area on our way to catch the Manly ferry so did not have the time to take one of the tours which we shall most certainly do if we return. The area & back lanes were really interesting with excellent little cafes. We should have spent more time here.

Love walking here. This is one of my favorite places for a leisurely stroll in Sydney... I love the history associated with the area and the general vibe. Plus there are some great gems of cafes and bars to enjoy as well and of course the weekend markets!!

Boutique everything. So many interesting shops and stalls, we did go on Friday and there weren't as many as I remembered but what was there was top notch. Really enjoyed the chocolate, but then again who wouldn't.

Weekend Markets. An easy walk (for physically fit) from our Pitt Street Apartment to the area known as The Rock. We loved seeing all the merchandise stalls and street food available. We really enjoyed our sausage sandwich from "Munich Sausages". $10.00 AU seemed a little pricey but they were delicious and the price was definitely inline with the other food vendors. You can sit on a step or there are limited tables in the food area of the market. You are almost directly under the bridge. Lots of fun.
historical area of the city with market stalls at the weekend. visited on a Sunday so the market was one, spent a couple of hours wandering the stalls and nearby shops.
Away from the buzz. Chance upon the place on the way to the Harbour bridge. It's a quiet and cosy place away from the buzz in the city. Has a weekend market worth visiting.

Great Walkabout. This area is so close to everything. On the weekend they have a vast farmer's market and local vendors. Enjoy a stroll through all the various options. Plenty of food, coffee and bars to suit every style.

Great historic part of Sydney. The rocks is a lovely area of Sydney with many great viewing pojnts of the city.There many dining options but few that provide outstanding food. Definitely an area to see in Sydney
Must do in Sydney. Stunning location, views and atmosphere a must do in Syndey whether it be for exercise, people watching, good food and drinks you will love it. So much to see and do along the way.
Plenty to see. Pleasent walk through the Rocks viewing the many tucked away shops and stalls throughout. A large market was set up in the centre offering plenty of expensive dress options.

Reminded us of Glasgow's West End . Yet another cool quirky place in a city that just keeps giving!
We went to look for an opal stone, but were happily side tracked simply wandering the streets and lanes around this area, again, cafes, restaurants, chocolatiers & plenty of photo opportunities......what's not to like?!
Step back in time.. So glad this area wasn't demolished by the government of the day. Beautiful area full of Sydney's history. Well worth a couple of hours.

A must do while in Sydney. A lovely part of the city that should be visited in my humble view! It's probably the oldest and most historic area of Australia and I really enjoyed the atmosphere and shops and restaurants in this area.

small and quiet. I love this small district, quiet and stylish, with narrow street, small caffes and beautiful old buildings, could walk there for hours, this is oasis of tranquility after the rush of the City.
Buzzing place . The Rocks is just a buzzing area. The markets are on from 10-5 weekends and its just a buzzing area. So much to see, do and eat and has great atmosphere.
Rocks. Just love walking around the Rocks area. Full of history and little alleys that lead to places you wouldn't expect
Best views. Relaxing at the Rocks with a lunch or cocktail gives you the best views of both the Sydney Opera House and the Sydney Harbor Bridge. It is relaxing and peaceful.

Cool, Fun, Nice. The Rocks area just gets better and better, one would think their neighbors to the west across the Bridge Highway would take an obvious hint and glorify their run down neighborhood...it holds such a "New Orleans-Jazz French Quarter" potential...see the neat ironwork. The Rocks Foodie a Market on Friday is great. Hint, near the 3PM ending food venders offer awesome clearance deals!

Interesting history!. The Rocks has an interesting history. We visited this place through a free walking tour and our guide explained the different buildings and the history behind the narrow lanes of The Rocks. It also has a secretive (well not so secret) entrance to the Sydney harbor bridge. There are several restaurants around this area
Interesting history. Sydney seems to think the Rocks is old - it is not compared to Europe but it is important in the history of Sydney so worth a stroll. a bit touristy but worth 1-2 hours.
the heart of Sydney. This is an incontournable historic site when visiting Sydney. Nice little streets and shops (although quite tourism oriented) and esepecially great market ln the weekends.
Nice waking area . Nice walk if you're staying nearby. Some nice pubs in the area with a beautiful view of the Sydney Opera House. There is a museum nearby with lots of history about the old Harbour

Nice shops, restaurants and walking paths. The Rocks is a historic area of Sydney where some of the original arriving ships dropped passengers including the criminals from Great Britian.The area has been preserved with many nice restaurants, bars, shoppes and walking paths. The Rocks are adjacent to the Harbour, the Quay( the ferry terminal), the cruise ships docks, the Harbour Bridge, and the Opera House.You can easily walk the area but some sidewalks and paths would not be easily accessible for handicapped or limited travelers. Some streets are steep with steps and Australia does not have handicapped ramps etc for the wheel chair bound persons.You can would up the steps from the Rocks to the sidewalk across the Harbour Bridge.

Historic Pub Crawl. You don't get buildings in Australia too much older in Australia, than those found in the rocks. You cant help but appreciate, the history, the architecture, the atmosphere and most importantly the hotels.I loved this section of Sydney and the availability of a large number of draught and craft beers.Make a day of it, but be careful of the cobblestones when you have your wobbly boots on

Great tour area. I enjoyed walking around the ROCKS area of Sydney, taking in the sights and the atmosphere. Great architecture and history. Lots of unique businesses and markets. The Friday Food court is fun and a great variety of foods available.
The Rocks. Interesting place. Visited to look at history and culture. Some teally old heritage houses too. Took a tour so learnt a lot more. An icon of Sydney
Travelling back in time. this place is full of magic and of course is an old looking neighbor, you will find plenty of coffee shops and nice restaurants as well as pubs.
Amazing and Free Walking tour . Took the walking tour at night. It was very interesting, and amusing. Plus, it's for free. This guys work for tips. :) Loved it!

Historic Old Town of Sydney. Narrow cobbled lanes and preserved historic buildings make this a very interesting area to walk around. It is very touristy so the prices here for restaurants and shops are about 3 times higher than elsewhere, but it is definitely worth a visit.
the rocks sydney. had walk around both at night and then again in the day time, lots of history. check out the rocks market on a saturday, got a great hat. great music

Historical, beautiful . Went visiting again when friends from overseas came. The Rocks provides locals and visitors alike the opportunity to admire our local attractions , learn from our history and appreciate the pubs, bars and other culinary places that make Sydney one of the best cities in the world. This is our city, proud to be here
Fun history lesson. I downloaded "The Rocks" app and did a self guided walking tour. I later got my husband to join me in a few pubs we came across. I'm a history buff so this was a fun activity.

Lovely Neighborhood for Shopping and Eating. We stayed nearby at the InterContinental and walked over to the Rocks a number of times to eat and to shop. On Saturday there was a lively outdoor market going on. We found an interesting gallery where we purchased a small ceramic figure.For those craving a taste of home, MacDonald's and Burger King (Hungry Jack's) are nearby at the quay.We had a wonderful gourmet meal at William Blue Dining (made reservations in advance online) at a truly low cost.

Newly built YHA on the Rocks for great accommodation. We stayed in YHA accommodation in Australia and throughout New Zealand . This pur[pose built YHA accommodation in The Rocks is ideal for every age of visitor to Sydney
Worth the trip. We went on a Saturday morning and as well as being an interesting area we thoroughly enjoyed the atmosphere of the very good market.
Great shops and restaurants. There were a variety of shops and places to eat in this older part of the city. Look for the street market on the weekend.

A unique part of "Old Sydney". The Rocks is located very near to the city side of the Harbour Bridge. It is an area that was saved from being developed many years ago. There are a lot of old buildings as can be expected which are now either places to eat or shop. There are substantial areas for pedestrians only. It tends to be a little quiet during the working week but really shines at the weekend and public holidays. Every weekend there is a substantial market at the very end of George Street. The goods on offer are good quality not junk as found at too many markets. My favorite pub is the Glenmore 96 Cumberland St. It has a roof top bar with views forever overlooking the harbour.

shop till you drop. Shopping was fantastic!!! So many Ugg shops - the prices there are much lower than in the states; plus they have different things. I bought kangaroo coin purses for everyone back home - yep, made out of Kangaroo. Plenty of jewelry shops for opals and pearls -- the opals were just as expensive there as they are at home. Opal Mined was the best place I saw there and we went into every one looking for a deal. No deal, but Opal Mined seemed to be the most trustworthy.

A very old part of Sydney with lots of history. The Rocks is one of Sydney's oldest areas and is where the Harbour Bridge begins across the Harbour. The area has undergone many changes over the years with lots of shops with the usual tourist trinkets as well as a few with some quality goods. Lots of restaurants, some good and some bad, but all overpriced since the cruise ship terminal disgorges thousands of people who just want to eat before or after their cruise and it is just steps away.

I love the flea market. The Rocks is definitely rocking with the beautiful buildings. It's simply a walking distance from the Circular Quay.
