I felt like I was not in Sydney anymore being surrounded by these kind of structures. See it for yourself and you can tell the difference. It has some nice cafes to hang around and have some chat with your friends. What's even better is the flea market. I love the authentic, home-made crafts and arts. Though it's slightly more than the usual souvenirs you bring home, these are worth your every penny.

Early Australia or Europe. Cobble stones and older buildings, good shopping of Austaliana items and Souvenirs, particularly on Market day.While around there visit Reiby Cottage the first building connected to the Bank of NSW now Westpac estabished in 1817.

The Old Sydney... Hi guys, the Rocks is the old Sydney neighbour..very characteristic!!The style is completely different from the rest of the city and you can find inside good restaurants and depending on day you are typical markets..enjoy guys...enjoy!!
The rocks. Just about walked through this place without notice of where I was, the coat hanger distracted from the location, no market during the week
Love it here. We saw lots during our week stay in Sydney, but by far the rocks is the highlight for us. Quirky, quaint, cobbled streets, shopping and eateries.
historic area. spent a few hours wandering around this area and did a couple of the tours on offer visited the free muesem and did a couple of the walks in the area very relaxing and in formative

Busy Rocks area. I visited The Rocks on a Sunday and it was very busy. A lot of people were doing what I was and were visiting the stores and wandering around the old streets. The cafes were so busy I was unable to have lunch there so I walked to the Harbour area. The Rocks is a dynamic area well worth visiting.

Historic Area. The Rocks is where the First Fleet finally settled. Lots of history. Lots of bars, restaurants. And George Street starts in The Rocks. A 30 minute walk takes you to the main shopping centre in Sydney. It can be pricey.

Come see where our nation began. The Rocks has wonderful shops, restaurants, views, you name it. You can go to pubs with live bands and watch people enjoying themselves in the middle of a wonderfully historic place

a must for first time visitors. We had a great time walking along the Rocks. It was nice to know the history of the place especially when we went to the museum (free of charge). There are plenty restaurants to choose from and plenty shopping for everyone.
Food , shopping and nice views. Lovely market with lots of stalls on sat and sundayfull of art and great gifts for family and friends the friday food market is not great.
old and new. want to go back into history see the many shop cafes and just enjoy the day well worth the visit a nice day out
Family Holiday/stop over Cruise. Had an amazing day so much to do see eat and drink it is a bit of a foodies paradise looking forward to our return
Great Walking Tour. We had a delightful 2 hour walking tour of The Rocks that was very informative and delivered in a highly competent and professional manner!

Great Markets. Love the Markets here. There are always really great and interesting things to see. Lots of great Australian Souvenirs and many places to get food. Kids enjoy walking around and looking at all the old buildings. Nice views and short walk to the ferries and strain station.

For History Buffs. Make sure you pop into the tourist information centre in the Rocks (I think they are moving soon). They gave us a very handy self led walk leaflet to see all the historical sites. It took about 2 hours at a leisurely pace
Clean and great atmosphere. Great place to visit full of restaurants and bars, it's the history of Sydney. Combined with Circular Quay, the Opera house, Bridge etc it is a touristy yet a must visit

History, food, bars and shopping in Sydney. A must to do in Sydney is to go to the Rocks. The building all tell a story and there is a nicely done market on Sundays. The history, food, bars and shopping are all within walking distance from the ferry or hotels.

Interesting place to visit. The Rocks offers a great view of both the famous bridge and also the Opera House.
We visited both on a Friday for the Food Market and then also on the Saturday for the Arts/craft market (which had more stalls).
Easy to get to via Circular Key station if necessary but an easy walk from CBD.

A bit underwhelming . There isn't a great deal happening at the rocks so don't go in with huge expectations and you will enjoy it. The old buildings and historic features are great and the small market is worth a look with good little Cafes close. Quite hard to find your way around so do your research first.

Free walking tour from Hyde Park. Daily there is a free city walking tour which starts from Hyde Park. With this tour we visited The Rocks which is an interesting area of shops and restaurants. There is also the statue which represents the, military, families and miners. The Rocks became established shortly after the colony's formation in 1788. The original buildings were made mostly of local sandstone, from which the area derives its name and some of the original rocks can still be seen. Interesting area.

Love the sights and sounds of the Rock's Market.. Enjoyed a delicious breakfast and then had fun perusing the market stalls. Found some unique items and loved the music along the way. We finished with a gozlame - yum! Gorgeous morning and experience.

History on the doorstep. This time we were at the Rocks while the market was on. Nice to walk around and plenty of shaded areas to hide in from the sun. Museum (free) is worth a visit for a bit of background information about the area.

Skew-ngaroo. Kangaroo skewers made my day, here at the Rocks. Lean, tasty, and healthy. After a long walk from Sydney harbour, it's a greta time to retire by the food kiosks around this area. They've got Mediterranean, Japanese, Meat skewers, a hodgepodge of cultural delights. There are coffee and juices around, too. After food, take a little shopping (on weekends) by the streets. A lot of local, aboriginal products like soaps, oils, boomerangs, are available abundantly. The place simply, rocks!

Didn't like it. Well, all I found at Rocks are a bunch of restaurants and bars and shops selling expensive souvenirs. It probably used to be a historic place but now there's nothing. The lady at the information counter was extremely uninterested and unhelpful. Think they need to get some trained staff to try and promote the place than just hand over a bunch of maps to interested travellers.
Shopping. Fun to shop and browse the stores. Prices a little high but better variety and quality. A relaxing afternoon. A true Sydney experience.

Walk from darling harbour to rocks. Enjoyed a drink at the palisades pub at the rocks after walking from darling harbour via hickson rd very lovely old pub. Then it's a short walk to argyle st where we had dinner at the orient. Nice sitting outside in the street.
Great piece of history. The Rocks in Sydney are brilliant the architecture of the old buildings is great and the shopping is great the area is full of history and is a must see while in Sydney.
Don't miss the Saturday Market at the Rocks. There is Saturday Market at the Rocks; there are selling stalls and food stalls and musicians at the Saturday Market, good fun.

Perfect place for a wander. You can easily spend the day walking around the rocks!It's a hype of activity and lots to see and do!Check out the contemporary museum, walk the harbour or check out some great stalls and quirky cafes.The Heritage at the rocks had delicious meals but go easy on the beers here as they can knock you around!It's an awesome stroll to see the day away, enjoy!
Nice to Walk Around. We enjoyed a stroll round this historic area. Great for getting really good pictures of the Opera House.
Great area for nightlife. The Rock's is one of the oldest areas of Sydney. Well-preserved buildings house bars, restaurants and shops. I would recommend the Orient for a beer and fish and chips.

A must!!. There is a market that can be found on Saturday and Sunday only. You must go there!! Have a long walk, buy some things and eat something, everything is absolutely delicious!!! The juices and the food are a must. The shopping can be quite the experience also!
Neat area. Worth spending an hour or two if you are a history buff. There are some cool places to eat and shop.

So much to do, so much to see, so much history. Seriously: you want history, you need to go to the rocks. This is where sydney began from. It's just such an amazing place. If you come on the weekends, Sunday you can go to the Rocks Markets, which is under the Harbour Bridge. There are heaps of places to eat, and shop, and see. Highly recommend!!

Old Sydney. The rocks area (on the Western side of Circular Quay), is where it all began for the settlement of Sydney. Vey old warehouses, shops and cottages dating from about 1800. Don't be afraid to explore narrow little alleys like "Suez Canal" and "Nurses Walk", and take in the old timber and sandstone structures. Plenty of shops, cafes, and weekend markets.
Fun spot. Little cafes, shops and pubs just up from the harbor next ti circular quay. Good restaurants for a nice seafood dinner.

walking around The Rocks. there is so much to see at the Rocks ... whether you want to do the market on saturday or sunday which caters to so many different cultures or the food market on the friday which is bursting with so many diferent cusines ... it is amazing just walking around & checking out the old buildings
Rock markets . We had an awesome day out enjoying the different food, different stalls & vast variety of things to see & do with the kids. Was a fun day.
Loved it.. I love the Rocks. Quaint wee streets and alleyways. So much history to find out about. Markets on Friday and Saturday are a must with lots of interesting food and items for sale.

The Rocks - in particular, The Hero of Waterloo hotel. Go to Hero of Waterloo - up Argyle cut, then right turn - you'll find it.In the basement is a tunnel cut into the rock where "crew" was attained by visiting captains of sail boats moored below, in the harbor. Rum was bought for the unsuspecting "friends", then when intoxicated, ushered down to the moored boat - instant crew - they awoke when miles out to sea. Ask the publican if you can visit below to inspect - the tunnel may be boarded up? This is all true!!! Also, the bond stores are well worth visiting - their heritage listing are very interesting!! I worked at the Maritime services Board, Architects Office - on the harbor - this was all common knowledge back then - all so interesting!! Shopping is also exciting!! Eating as well !! A very striking area for the "nostalgic" - old Sydney at it's absolute best. Goat Is. is also phenominal if you can get there - an old convict driven island just off Walsh Bay - well worth as well!!

Our Europe away from Europe. This is where we hang out to enjoy European cousine: Belgium, Italian, French, German.......so special. Go by train, bicycle, on foot or by car. Very popular and could be very busy weekends. Nice buzz.
It's just a nice place!. Very iconic, plenty of cafes and some great watering holes. The weekend markets usually have something to satisfy everyone.

Make a day of it. If you have limited time in Sydney, the Rocks is a Must Do. Great heritage with wonderful historic lanes and buildings, incredible views, and one of the best areas for a Pub Crawl with at least a dozen venues to visit from incredibly historic to modern.
Great History. This is personally my favorite part of Sydney. The oldest part of town and history around every corner. The architecture is amazing and the scenery is amazing.

Interesting place to wander.. I found "The Rocks" an interesting place to wander and photograph from a historical perspective. However I found that the shops were very overpriced for what they were offering. Don't just wander the main streets but wander the ally ways as well. You'll see how the inhabitants lived so long ago. In some parts you can see the outdoor kitchens used during summer when it was too hot to have a stove running in the house. You'll also wander ally's and paths that have been trodden on for centuries.
Such a wonderful atmosphere. I love the rocks especially on the weekend when the Markets are on. Always lots of great food, music and atmosphere with some shopping too

Accidental find!!. We discovered this section of the city unexpectedly - it's an historic area with a few narrow alleys and charming streets. And a ton of restaurants. Be sure you wander about (unless you already know where you want to eat) and check out the menus posted on the windows. Remember - no tips in Australia, so although the food prices might seem high, they're well in line with any metropolitan area.

A wonderful journey steeped in history!. We stayed at the Russell Hotel close by to the Handa Opera on the Harbour venue. We so enjoyed wondering around the Rocks reading the story boards, experiencing the multicultural population, eating in warm and cosy cafes and generally soaking up the history. It was great to see the Jack Mundy mural definitely a blast from our past fondly remembered. There was much to see and do and we could have spent much more time - Ah next time!
Rocky!. The rocks is a nice historical area to visit. There are plenty of shops and a market. They are a nice reminder of Sydney's past and there is an excellent bookshop.

lots of restaurants and shops. neat trendy area near the cruise terminal that is steeped in history of Sydney. they have a wonderful outdoor market on Saturday and Sundays with over 200 vendors. on Friday they have a food market. there is live music Thursday - Sunday in many of the restaurants and live music in various spots on market days. great area for shopping, for eating, people watching and live music.

A day at The Rocks Sydney. Decided to take our visitors from Canada for a visit to the Historic Rocks in Sydney. We caught the train to Circular Quay and then began our walk starting at George Street and coming across the historic Russell Hotel built in 1887. The hotel was built on the site of the once Moveable hospital around 1790, also the Old Police Station, there are lots of lanes around the back of this with the Nurses walk, Surgeons Court, the site of the old bakehouse and the Suez Canal which was once an open sewer and where prostitutes and gangsters hung out. Lovely shops and cafes are now around these areas. There are also old cottages still in existence. We visited the Discovery museum which is a wealth of information of early years, wandering next through more back street areas and walked under the Harbour bridge through the cutting and came out on Lower Fort street which is steeped in history and now the properties there are worth millions. This is Millers Point. Departing from here we ended up along the old wharf areas, which are now beautiful housing properties adorned by shops cafes and businesses. From here you can continue on to Barangaroo and the whole new development. What a great day we had exploring Sydney's past. Jubeesydney.

A must do in Sydney. Love wAndering this area, so much history to check out as well as a beautiful old area. Cafe bars and restaurants. The old mercantile pub has wonderful Irish music and a great place to hang out. The weekend market is worth a looksy more pricey than most however hood atmosphere
Great place in Sydney to wander and loose yourself. Take a day just to wander the streets of The Rocks. Enjoy a street market, boutiques or a beer at the oldest pub.
Interesting area. The Rocks is always great to visit. We were lucky to be there on a day they had the Markets set up. Fantastic things to do and see.

A must see neighborhood. A trip to Sydney wouldn't really be complete without a trip to this particular area. There's shops, restaurants, etc in the district. We mainly just walked the streets and took in the sites, and did a lot of people watching. It's close to the Harbour so you can stroll that way.

Trendy area with great restaurants . Great trendy area that has lots of restaurants and pubs, definitely worth visiting. Nice to walk through and choose what ever you fancy to eat or just pop in a pub for a drink.
Nice place, must visit. The Rocks precinct is crossed by several streets and offers many different restaurants to linger. Between them caught again a look at the Opera House.

So much to do and see!. You can easily spend a couple of days just doing the Rocks. There is so much history, an incredible amount of eating, art galleries, modern and aboriginal, the list is endless.
nice place to look around. there are shops around this area you might want to check out. there are interesting restaurants as well. overall, good place to go to when visiting Sydney

Great old town atmosphere. This is the heart of Sydney, with great dining and shopping spots and awesome views of the opera house and harbor. Definitely the area to stay (we stayed at Shangri La, which was wonderful).

The best area in Sydney to stay for a short break. Wow!!! Here you are surrounded by so much of what Sydney has to offer and all within a short walk. Head to the water and you have Passenger Quay, Circular Quay and around to Sydney Opera House, Walk in another direction and the Old Observatory, all the pubs and the buildings and markets on weekends, little shops to explore and the Powerhouse Museum. Loads on offer form some of the best restaurants Sydney has to offer, to Pubs with a cold beer and solid grub. Walk around and immerse yourself in the earliest history and standing over it all is the Harbour Bridge. Spent a week and barely touched the surface and now have t go back for more.

Lots of walking but worth the steps. Rocks is a great place to while away a day. There are shops, historic sights, restaurants, and a wonderful modern art museum right there on the waterfront. Don't expect the flea market bargains, but for high end shopping and dining, this is the place for you. The scenery is terrific, and the sense of being an international hub is everywhere. There is a great open market on weekends, with lots of high end artisan created arts and crafts.

Past time atmosphere..... One of the most European areas in Sydney, very old style. Here you can feel just like one of the first settlers, strolling among those narrow streets and admiring the red bricks houses and all the shops and restaurants that make this part of Sydney so cosy and lively.

Explore the history here. I had the pleasure of doing a full day walking tour here and explored many of the back "alleys" of the Rocks. Seeing foundations for ancient houses, the archaeological dig, the oldest pub, historical buildings, Argyle Cut, the markets (Saturday and Sunday only), the Observatory helped my understand the history and significance of the area. Take the time here to fully appreciate the history - you won't be disappointed in what you discover.

Iconic Urban Walkabout. The Rocks has so much history from a bygone era but is now one of the best examples of 21st Century downtown renovation. GREAT shops, myriad outdoor eateries, many with views of the Harbour and a transport center for the waterfront ferries as well as the trains. I think the Rocks is one of the best iconic locations of any City in the World and is a must stop for a meal and a wonderful wander or urban walkabout.
Great place to visit. We stayed at the Rocks and loved walking around this historic precinct. It is really worth a visit as there are lots of nice cafes and restaurants

Oldest Part of Sydney - Good Nighlife. The Rocks is the oldest part of Sydney and is fun to explore. There are steep stairs along with some old buildings. There are a lot of good restaurants and pubs. It is popular with the locals as well as with tourists.

History at your fingertips.. You get a real sense of history when walking and exploring the Rocks area. Lots of interesting nooks and crannies to explore with many hidden gems to discover upon your travels. If you have the time book a walking tour is my recommendation.

A little walk around history. Travelled to Sydney for a look around and one of the places we visited was the Rocks. Amazing to see so early history of Australia, how people lived and worked. A great free experience. Bunch of shops and coffee places to sit.

It's OK - much more going on elsewhere. Not sure what the attraction is here. We passed through a couple of times and never found the allure. Perhaps the history. It does offer decent restaurants, tourist shopping and some views.Not worth going out of your way.
Wonderful Area. Beautiful old area just steps (and a few stairs) from Central Quay. Wander over and discover this charming old neighbourhood.

Morning walk glory. Visiting Sydney for the second time, and what a place to walk around for the morning. The history, the vibe, the feel and location of The Rocks is stunning and everything you need is here.

Nice, touristy spot. The place is packed when a cruisehip is docked (which is pretty much every day) but is much quieter in the evenings. Prices reflect the dominating tourist numbers but there are some deals to be had.

Unique Place. The Rocks area ❤️ in Sydney is an all time favourite destination of mine since I was a teenager! It is full of life and character with fantastic restaurants, bars & pubs! The live music is great at night and is a great party atmosphere! Whether you grew up in Sydney or visit it frequently, you never grow tired of the place!! A must for overseas visitors! ❤️

Great slice of history in modern Sydney. Murals, sculpture, historical buildings and Australia's oldest pub ! Designer stores, the contemporary art museum and restaurants all next to the Circular quay and surrounded by popular hotels. We attended the Friday Foodie market, tried some restaurants and walked the streets. Great place to walk around in with all kinds of food places and stores to visit.

Interesting historical site. Neat area of Sydney with historical significance. Today you will find lovely restaurants and cafes shops and outdoor markets on weekends. We found several excellent restaurants and just enjoyed the ambience of this area

Weekend markets!!. Restored buildings, public murals, terrific street food and first rate crafts at the weekend market. The Japanese and Wagyu beef stands were particularly busy and food was first rate at both. Unusual hand crafted items with real design flair were predominant. This is where we purchased most souveniers
History review. Interesting to see this in the middle of a metropolitan city.. a bit of history review of sydney, would attract history buffs.. just different from the rest of sydney..

So much to see....and eat!. We've spent hours exploring The Rocks area. So many places to shop, visit and dine. The Sydney Visitor Center is here as well as The Rocks Discovery Museum. Also, this is where the access to the pedestrian crossing for the Harbour Bridge is.

Part of the 'must do' in Sydney.. The Rocks is an area that needs a good half day at least for exploration. A whole day could be filled in here. There are markets, shops, museums and buildings well worth visiting. The Discovery Museum is worth visiting. Good for the history of the area. It is all in quite a confined area so easy walking around. Lots of cafes and restaurants to ease the feet as you go.

Fun spot. We were only in the Rocks for a short bit but managed to visit a great little pub and have a brew and people watch. It's a quaint little place and I'm glad we went. Also had a great local farmer's market the day we were there.
Always delightful. I spent a whole day exploring The Rocks and I could have spent another day more - so many places to explore and you can feel the history of the place

Rock On.... Stayed close to the Rocks while in town great area to walk round grab something to eat and drink and great for people watching...plenty of little shops and lovely little back streets..worth a stroll if you have time...enjoy...
Great atmosphere with plenty to see and do. Full of lots of history and mystery. Ghost tours a must. Lots of places to eat and drink. Easy to get to via public transport.

See it!. It's a historical area that is worth the visit. This is one of the stops off the hop on hop off bus and when we went they had an outdoor market with a lot of vendors selling a bunch of stuff.
The area has restaurants, bars and a ton of history. Definitely a touristy thing to do!

Nice place to dine. I love coming here to the rocks, you have the best and closest view of Harbour Bridge, and also Opera House.
You will find alot of great choices of restaurants, cafes, and bars to dine or just to enjoy the night.
Great area. We stayed two blocks from the Rocks area and it is lively, interesting and has great restaurants and bars. Lots to see and has shopping also.
A nice neighbourhood! . We walked to here from Town Hall station. It features a lots of restaurants and classic architectures. A night stroll here is even better as the lights are on!

A great place to wander in Sydney. A real mix of history, urban interest, and lots of places to eat. There is a brochure with a historic tour of old Sydney which takes you through, giving you a better sense of the beginnings of the city. Lots of alleys, nooks, and interesting places to see. And you cannot get away from places to stop for a drink or to east. Would miss much if you are in Sydney and don't visit The Rocks.
An evening walk. This is the older part of Sydney and the architecture history can be seen on most building. Try some of the restaurant here for dinner you'll get the best view of opera house!

It is a small area to see. Do visit this area when you visit Sydney opera house. It is walking distance. Nothing much to see there; there is a nice and busy italian restaurant that worth checking out.
Great Area. There are shops, restaurants, Sydneys oldest Pub and an outdoor weekend market in this easy to walk area area. Also close to Sydney Harbor.
Historic Australia. It's a place to see historic buildings, do some shopping, and appreciate local artists. If you like to have a look around with a bag of boiled chestnuts or a Hotdog, go ahead.
Busy. If you come to Sydney you go to the Rocks. Nightlife, shopping, history and food - all available. Friday food market

Guided walking tour of the Rocks, Sydney Harbour. We(wife and I) took a guided walking tour of the rocks area in Sydney. If you're interested in Convict history, architecture of the times, development of Sydney town or stone cutting and building this easy paced walking tour is recommended.

And Roll. Great place to hop off the ferry and spend a few hours exploring and enjoying; so many eateries, bars and shops. Good atmosphere and plenty of tourists from all over the planet. Often street entertainment too, to while away more time...

Fabulous! Had to go back for a second visit!. This is a lovely historical area with amazing restaurants, shops easily accessible via the ferry. Wear comfortable shoes and allow yourself a few hours to leisurely wander around.
Easter weekend 2016. A must see area of inner Sydney for all types. The old mixed in with new. Markets on the Sunday great area for a look around.

From Prisoners to Funky. The Rocks is an area of Sydney near the Circular Quay. It used to be a place where prisoners and low-life congregated. Now it is an eclectic mix of shops and restaurants. You can easily spend a couple of hours going through the shops and having a bite to eat at one of the many restaurants.

Nice walk. Just start to walk around the streets and find a spot to take something to
drink&eat! We found many small restaurants. Enjoy
historic site of early settlement Sydney. Full of everything you need for a history lovers weekend in Sydney. close to the harbour Ferries, Opera house and harbour Bridge
great area. excellent range of food and drink as well as some excellent shopping, go there, like you could miss it!!

Well worth spending time here. This is one of my favourite areas to wander around. It is close to the ferry and just an easy stroll away. There are lots to see and do and plenty of park areas for children to run around and play. The gun emplacements under the bridge is a great spot for boys to play battles with each other. On Fridays they have a food market and Saturdays and Sundays there is the general markets full of great eats and lots of interesting stalls. My son who declared the markets was going to be full of womans stuff had to eat his words when he found a great wire maker making alien toys.
Great shopping and entertainment . Sydney's answer to London's Covent Garden but with better weatherGreat food, shopping and live entertainment .It had a lovely relaxed feel to the whole area

Great place for a long afternoon stroll. The Rocks is has great shopping, and good food. Lots of little place to walk into and explore. There's also the museum of modern art that has a fantastic gift shop.

good for history buffs and walking enthusiasts. this is one of the oldest areas of sydney. there are many old buildings,hotels and a museum to look around . there are many walking tours available but we chose to walk around on our own with the help of maps .there is a visitor centre avbl near the circular quay and the lady there was very helpful. we walked quite a bit, some of it uphill and stairs n went to the rocks museum which is tiny but informative. some lookout points are also there if you prepared to climb stairs. we combined a walk to the pylon look out on the sydney bridge as well. if you are tired there are quite a few cafes/pubs to stop n have a cuppa. go in the afternoon as you can stay till sunset ideally. a not-to -be -missed part of sydney for travellers.
Well worth a visit. This area is well worth a visit it is a really vibrant area with lots to see. There are lots of cafes and restaurants live music and an interesting arts and craft market.
Don't miss The Rocks.. There is so much to see on a casual walk around The Rocks - lovely shops, restaurants, art galleries.

Interesting stores and wares. A convenient bustling walk from Sydney Harbour. You get to see cars, ships, boats, art, buses, dogs and lots of tourists all the way. The market was on and the fact that it was a craft market selling unique items was very fascinating. The place is full of charm and character. Great afternoon well spent.
George St, great pubs and restaurant area!. Sunday markets were excellent, lots of stalls and places to eat and drink. Loved the Irish Bar and the band!
Going back in time. This place has a story to tell. This was the spot where the first Aussie settlers landed. There is a big stone to mark the spot.

Full of history. Wander the streets and absorb the past. There are also helpful signs and explanations around. The YHA has an archeological dig at is open to the public and well worth a look. Lots of other places to look at in this area too.

History in motion. The Rocks is Sydney's oldest area from early white settlement days. It's not a museum but a living breathing bar and restaurant precinct that adds greatly to the whole CBD experience. Lots of historical plaques and information scattered around with the early 18th century architecture preserved and adapted for modern use. Great selection of bars.....international tourists beware, some are adopting a "service" charge when opening bar tabs.....reject this out of hand....it's NOT compulsory (barely legal here) and a blatant attempt to fleece visitors (shame on those who do, drinks prices already cater for staff penalty rates).

Emphasize The History, Not The Markets!!!. The Rocks is a very interesting area of Sydney, just an easy walk from Circular Quay and the CBD. This is one of Sydney's oldest and most historically significant places. Therein lies the problem, in my opinion. The Rocks has been turned into a cluster of open air markets, cafes and pubs. Nothing wrong that necessarily, but it distracts from the history of the area. I was disappointed with the crowds as that made it difficult to enjoy the historical buildings and to find the museums. Nevertheless, a visit to The Rocks is worthwhile. I'd suggest investing 2-3 hours. I would also suggest getting there early in the day to avoid the shopping rush.

The place to stay, the place to be- whenever you're in Sydney!. We can't rate The Rocks are highly enough - loads of great places to eat and to drink, live music, fabulous shops to suit all budgets, a great weekend market with lots of interesting items on sale, the Harbour Bridge and the Opera House nearby, opportunities for boat trips, motor cycle trips, Bridge Climb etc etc. Hope to return soon and wouldn't stay anywhere else in Sydney!

A great spot to shop. The Rocks in Sydney are where the first settlers set up home. This is a great place now, a little touristy but if you look hard enough, there is great history, nooks and crannies, shopping and turns into a really good market at the weekend. And of course some great pubs. Most do food but the best surprise is the little cafe at the back of the Irish shop. It has the best scones and tea!!
Great Architecture. I love looking at the buildings and the rock features. So many places to eat or have a drink. Amazing views of the harbour. The weekend markets, cafes hotels, tours. So much to do

Markets with History. Wonderful markets here on Saturday and Sunday. A great place to find brunch. Check out the back alley ways for interesting boutiques. The Rocks are the birthplace of Sydney so very historical and interesting buildings.
Sunday markets. Markets at the rocks on a Sunday are a must do. Plenty of stall with a great variety of thins to eat, purchase etc.

Great place to see.. A beautiful place to visit with something for all ages. Quirky alleyways, shops for all tastes and pockets. Historic and interesting. The markets are amazing too. Well worth a visit!!!
old world meets new. Lots of old world charm and small cafes and specialty food shops. The market is quite extensive and sells almost anything you can think of. Well worth an hour of browsing.

Fascinating historical wonders from a colonial slice of life.. From fantastic shopping to deliciously unique dining experiences, vibrantly colorful art galleries and even spine-tingling nightly ghost tours for the more adventurous! The Rocks is certainly worth a visit, close to many hotels, public transport and airport connections. A true tourist treat!

Sunday market!!!. Sunday market at the rocks !!! it's not the kind of market where you buy fresh food. it's more of craft market ! you can still get honey from the shops along the market. do try the corn with everything !

A must visit place on the weekend for the great market. The Rocks is not only a really cool old neighborhood under the famous bridge, but the weekend market has such a wide range of stalls featuring wonderful Australian artisans selling a huge range of reasonably priced crafts. And the number of pubs and restaurants compressed into historical area of Sydney makes finding a quick drink or meal of decent quality an easy proposition. One of my favorite strolls in Sydney!
MUST SEE. This is one place in Sydney you must visit or stay in as there is so much history to see with great Bars and restaurants and week end markets together with the wonderful old buildings.
Filled with history. We got to find out how rich in history this part of town is. Took a walking tour after walking the area by ourselves prior to the proper tour.

Great spot. History and modern all at once. Love visiting the Rocks in Sydney. Great to visit the market. Get their early as it opens at 10 and is flat out by 11 . Make sure you stop for a coffee and watch the world go by.

Wander through the market stalls. Check out this buzzy area for food, drinks, shopping and soak up the atmosphere. We visited on a Sunday and loved wandering through the market stalls selling everything from souvenirs to high end jewellery and cinema memorabilia. Definitely worth a visit.

Great to walk around history. This area is facing gentrification and removal of it's elderly residents. See it while it's still there. I recommend going on a free tour of this place at 6 pm given by I'm Free tours.
Great night out. Best place to go for a fun time in Sydney. we partied here a few times and there are lots of good pubs

An Experience Not To Be Forgotten. We stayed at the Russel Hotel on Gorge Street which is the Rocks. What a place! Right next to the ferries, cruise ship terminal, trains, Bridge and Opera House. We had the good fortune to be there over St Patties Day and George Street and the Rocks came alive. If we go back we will stay there again.

Touristy but intriguing and real at the same time. Wander the steep steps and twisty alleys of this small but intense area in the shadow of the Bridge and overlooking the Opera House, Circular Quay and the North Shore

The Place to Visit.. Anyone going to Sydney has to visit The Rocks. Its great to walk round the area where the City and Colony had its birth, and see some of the iconic buildings and places so significant in Australia's history.

The secrets you'll find. Through its twisted streets and narrow lanes, every time you visit the rocks you are bound to find something new. A rustic exciting adventure for everyone, tourists or not. A great escape after a busy day.

fabulous for shoppers. Very hilly area with many iconic stores and eateries, an excellent market (two on saturdays) and the oldest pub in Sydney (Fortune of war). Be prepared for steps and hill climbs!

Extremely popular area of downtown Sydney that features excellent outdoor market at weekends. A lovely area to explore on foot and visit the various boutique shops and outdoor stalls all selling handcrafts of various types, styles and degrees of ingenuity!

Fantastic Day Out. I have been to Sydney a couple of times before however I have not been to the rocks.....it was fantastic. Very walkable.Great food and shops.Very close to the CBD also so if the shops there aren't enough, a 20 min walk has you at the heart of George Street.On of the nice things about The Rocks is that it isn't overwhelming and has a very relaxed atmosphere.The history was great and next time I am in Sydney I will be more organised and make sure that I make the most of what The Rocks has to offer and properly explore.

Old timey tourist trap. Okay, so if you want to see the old part of Sydney it's definitely worth the walk about, but don't expect any artful sellers or fine dining. There are a few decent spots, but most pander to the tourists coming off the cruise ships. The street markets are a nice touch, but don't expect a whole lot else going on.
Nice area to visit Saturday & Sunday during the market. Nice shopping for unique souvenirs, variety of restaurants and cafes. Spend an enjoyable afternoon or morning.

Full of character. We were lucky enough to be staying on The Rocks, lots of lovely little restaurants and bars dotted about, very pretty, some nice coffee shops and boutique shops. A real contrast to the rest of the city and a must to go for a wander if you fancy a chill day.

It's a beloved historical area, always busy.. The Rocks area, which is adjacent to Circular Quay on Sydney Cove is with rich history and beloved. It was the first European settlement in Australia, established by Captain Arthur Phillip of England in 1788 as a penal colony. A lot of historic buildings are being conserved luckly. Take better a walking tour and spend some time to explore!

Might be OK when a cruise ship isn't in. I was really disappointed. The shopping was so-so - really not much of actual interest - and the area wasn't actually that striking visually. I should note that a huge cruise ship was tied up at the adjoining dock and the merchants were probably aiming directly at the cruise-ship demographic. If you’re in Australia and want interesting shopping, hop down to Melbourne and visit the Queen Victoria market.

Love a stroll around The Rocks. Each time we travel to Sydney from Perth we ensure we pay a visit to the Rocks area. We plan our visit for a Sunday so we can enjoy a stroll around the markets and see all the things the talented people of Sydney make.At the top end of the markets you can walk under one end of the Sydney Harbor bridge and get a glimpse of the people that take the tour to climb it

Enjoyment for everyone. The Rocks is a great day out for tourists and locals. Many wonderful shops and places to eat. The range of restuarants from inexpensive cafe to 5 star and lots of pubs just for a beer. A must do is walk around the whole area so you can appreciate the history of the area. There a number of companies who do walking tours day and night.

Heart of Sydney. The Rocks, historically and today, seems to represent the very heart of Sydney. A very walkable, approachable area with fantastic restaurants, galleries, and shops. Something for every taste can be found in the Rocks area.
Historical area. Touristy area. Lots of shops/pubs/restaurants. Rocks area information centre worth a visit. Market at weekends

Frankly, a Bit Disappointing Except for the Architecture. Located on a rocky point just to the west of Circular Quay and at the north end of George Street, The Rocks is one of the oldest, mostly intact areas of Sydney. It's also one of the priciest in every way: food, lodging, shopping. I enjoyed some of the old stone and brick architecture but was turned off by the superfluity of expensive tourist shopping spots. Ditto, the restaurants, which are priced high. The hilly nature of The Rocks works against tourist families with small children, too.There are so many more places in Sydney that have distinctive appeal than The Rocks.

Historic. Impressive to see. Many establishments and pubs. You can see the harbor from here, along with the Opera House. Also a huge cruise ship could be docked. Ours was one week earlier, Diamond Princess

The Rocks area is not to be missed!. This part of the city directly west of Syney Harbour is the old town area of Sydney.... there are wonderful cobblestone streets, The Rocks Discovery Museum, fabulous restaurants and wonderful old buildings to visit. Also, a great little park at the underside of the Harbour Bridge provides some unique views of the bridge and harbour. We also visited during the weekend market and while there were large crowds of people, found that to be a fun diversion.

The Rocks - A Cute Little Area. A great little area for a nice little stroll. Filled with boutique shops, souvenir stores, bars, restaurants, etc. Get lost picking up little trinkets or purchase high end jewelry. Easy walking distance to the Opera House and the Harbor Bridge. The highlight is all the historic buildings that are in this area.

Interesting old district of Sydney. A great place to visit after dark lots of bars and restaurants make sure you stop and look up at the amazing architecture and wear your walking shoes it's very hilly!!

My childhood playground. I had the good fortune of living in The Rocks during my childhood until I married. Being so close to the city it still had the feel of living in a small community. Thank you Jack Mundy for saving this special part of Sydney and preserving some of our heritage. Unfortunately today most of it has been tuned over to a commercial way of life, but hopefully most of the buildings will remain for many years to come
Very interesting. Nice place to shop, look around. Lots of history. Felt safe walking at night. Visit the official ugg store 140 George st Will make boots to your spec all others stores are frauds
Full of activity. Hiden restaurants and pubs. Art gallery. Beautiful view and street performance. I could see opera house,Sydney Harbour Bridge and giant cruise ship

Mixture of old and new. Walking around The Rocks is a great was to spend the better part of a day. There are many shops, galleries, restaurants and even a homey little tea room, The Tea Cosy, to engage your senses. This area was the first settlement in Sydney. It gets its name from, you guessed it, the rock formation into which it is built. Be prepared for a somewhat strenuous walk as there are hills to climb if you choose to do so.
Can walk from the Opera House or town easily. This is right next to circular quay (where the opera house is). Lots of shopping and restaurants. The bridge walk is there. Easy to access and beautiful.

The Ricjs. The Rocks is a great place to walk around. It has many restaurants, little shops and bars. It is very close to the harbor and you can even walk to the bridge from there.There are souvenir shops, jewelry shops ,art and other cute boutiques. It is a great place to just walk around and spend an afternoon or evening there. They even have little shops and malls that can be entered off the main streets. We visited a couple times and had dinner there twice. There is even a pub in the rocks that you can talk to all the people and get a real feel of Sydney.
Holiday . The rocks has nice places to eat . Really nice walk . A must see if in sydney . Enjoyed visiting there
Ordinary.. You may skip this if u running short of time.I found the place ordinary, or perhaps I was expecting too much out of it.
History. Lovely place to spend a Sunday wandering around the nice pubs and markets. There is a lot of history here that's interesting to hear about and you can learn about it on a free guided tour.

Loved the Rocks area!. The Rocks is a great area with an awesome feel. I would say it is more of an area then a certain spot. We walked around and explored lots of the nooks and crannies of the area. We probably should have taken a walking tour and would have gained a better understanding. The area has a great historic feel and fun pubs and some good food. Lots of little shops but it isn't overwhlemed with shopping, it just has a really comfortble authentic feel. Some pubs, some shops, a museum, there was a historic dig going on, lots of views up at the harbor bridge. I would recommend vistors take some type and roam around there which is really easy to do because it is right there between the bridge and the opera house.
Great area of Sydney to visit. We visited on a Sunday and the place was buzzing - there was a great street market lots of cafes and places to eat and it's just across the road from the circle quays

Plenty of history and shopping. The Rocks is the oldest part of urban Sydney, with narrow alleys and tiny shops. The Tourist Centre can be found here and the Rocks museum. Good souvenir shops, tearooms and eating places, as well.
nice. We found the whole area beautiful and fun.Great shops and restaurants in a well lite area of town.Also, great bars

We were rock dwellers for a while at least. In our recent trip to Sydney, we were fortunate to have chosen to stay at The Rocks area with is well preserved buildings and historic posters and tourist experiences. The first pub in Sydney is there, the one where press gangs shoved guys down a chute to the basement and thence to waiting ships eager for new crew. We spent as much time as possible just enjoying the history of the place and trying imagine how it was back when the first fleet arrived, as well as grabbing a meal here, a beer there, that is the nature of the place. Yes, it is steep in places and the stairs can be a bit crowded however everyone was helpful and courteous even though it was Easter. Definitely come here for an afternoon and enjoy the ambience, stay a while longer if you can.

True Australian History. The Rocks could quite easily be dismissed as just a tourist spot with lots of bars and souviner shops and markets. Except that it is real, living history!For the former colony of New South Wales and now the Commonwealth of Australia, this is important and vital history of the period of the original white settlement on this island.The buildings are fantastic, the old pubs a delight and the selection of bars & cafes just add to the enjoyment of the area.Well worth a visit - or two.

The Rocks. The best thing about this area is the plethora of restaurants offering whole food. Ate some of the best bread in the world here. Additionally, there are a number of craft markets open on different days.
Explore. What a great day. We walked over the Sydney Harbour Bridge, explored the Rocks and had a beer in the local pubs. I recommend it.

I love the history of The Rocks. We went to The Rocks for dinner at the German restaurant. I love the atmosphere at The Rocks. The buildings, the pathways and walks. If your a history lover, then this place is for you. So many shops and old pubs. They do hold markets also, which I love but can't for the life of me recall when they are held.You can go in to old houses which are set up as shops. I am not going to say too much, it's something you have to seek out and explore yourself.
A great craft market on Saturdays and Sundays. There are over 200 stalls of handmade crafts by the artists themselves on display, some very unusual.

Wander The Rocks in Sydney Australia. Love the market here. If it is on go..... Awesome juicy fresh sweet corn. Fantastic friendly stall holders and locals. Nice just to wander and browse around the shops and streets. Beautifully maintain heritage style building but many with steps and unaltered to original structure.Watch the length of parking your car. Parking can be difficult to get to or find so I recommend public transport and walking!Delicious yummy treats in multiple stores.Eat, drink, shops, markets, stay, history, meet locals and more.A+++Australian people are friendly, helpful and nice so if you're confused or need directions, don't be afraid to ask.In Australia they speak English so you will find it very easy to get directions. It's o.k to ask again if your English is limited. Most locals are great to recommend places to go to see, directions, eat or things to do so just ask. Australia is a beautiful country that is multicultural and a huge range of cuisine. Despite crazy news reports or youtube videos over the years what was shown was and is such a select minority that every country on this Earth has some degree of. I have had wonderful memories all over this world and some scary encounters but I bet those locals would have said their culture isn't like that so you will face many diverse people no matter what age or where you go.Australia is a friendly laid back fun filled country with beautiful landscapes from the city to the country with endless tourist attractions to go and see. Some 'slang' words that some Australians use are below not not everyone uses them so just English is just fine.Ambo : ambulance, ambulance driverBig Smoke : a big city, especially Sydney or MelbourneBloke : man, guy Bloody : very (bloody hard yakka) Bloody oath! : that's certainly true Boogie board : a hybrid, half-sized surf boarBrekkie : breakfast Bush : the hinterland, the Outback, anywhere that isn't in town BYO : unlicensed restaurant where you have to Bring Your Own grog, also similar party or barbecueCark it : to die, cease functioning Chrissie : Christmas Cockie : cockatooCut lunch : sandwiches Dag : a funny person, nerd, goof Doc : doctorDog : unattractive woman Esky : large insulated food/drink container for picnics, barbecues etc. Fair go : a chance ("give a bloke a fair go") Fairy floss : candy floss, cotton candyFlake : shark's flesh (sold in fish & chips shops) G'Day : hello! Good onya : good for you, well done Icy pole, ice block : popsicle, lollypop Lippy : lipstick Lollies : sweets, candy Lucky Country, The : Australia, where else? Maccas (pron. "mackers") : McDonald's (the hamburger place) Milk bar : corner shop that sells takeaway food Mozzie : mosquito Nipper : young surf lifesaver No drama : same as 'no worries'No worries! : Expression of forgiveness or reassurance (No problem; forget about it; I can do it; Yes, I'll do it) Not the full quid : not bright intellectually Pokies : poker machines, fruit machines, gambling slot machines Prezzy : present, gift Road train : big truck with many trailers Servo : petrol station Snag : a sausage Sunbake : sunbathe Sunnies : sunglasses Surfies : people who go surfing - usually more often than they go to work! Tea : supperTop End : far north of Australia Trackie daks/dacks : tracksuit pantsTrackies : track suit Ute : utility vehicle, pickup truckWhinge : complain Wog : flu or trivial illness Yabby : inland freshwater crayfish found in Australia (Cherax destructor)The currency is in Australian dollars.You can uses dollars, Credit cards such as American express, Visa and Mastercard but some stores charge a extra service fee so ask if they do.Australians do not tip each other but it's nice to show and tell them you respect their service and kindness, we all like that!​The temperature is measured in CelsiusLength measurements are in kilometers, meters and centimetersPower is 220 wattsThere are two time zones and daylight saving times so check where you are and what the time is for you.

Adorable shopping and plenty of food options!. Had lunch in The Rocks during the week and went to the outdoor shopping market on the weekend. Lots of local shops as well as tourist gifts. The buildings are unique and the bricks / stone walks make you feel like you aren't in a city at all.A weekend must see while in Sydney!
Walk around the Rocks!. The Rocks rock. Multiple shops and restaurants, a quaint museum, a feel for Sydney of the past and a quick hike to the Sydney bridge. It is all there!

Historic Rocks area. This is a lovely historic area of Sydney with wonderful little shops, eateries and places to drink. Do take time to read up about this area given this was one of the hardest places to live.Within this area is also the Duty Free shopping centre.

Lots to do and another great view of the harbour. Markets, restaurants and shops and another view of the harbour! The rocks are great to wonder round and to grab a bite to eat and relax. I missed the markets here but I've been told that they're pretty good :)
Great neighborhood. Tons of pubs, drinks and food...cute. Fun times. Just take a zip around and get caught up in the local flavor in this little historic neighborhood.
EXPLORE. The Rocks is a wonderful neighborhood to explore for restaurant opportunities and old archecture. We enjoyed some old pubs and a tapas style dinner.

Rocking Good Place. The Rocks is the oldest part of Sydney and is a must for a visit while you are there. The place throbs with life from the weekend street market to the abundance of great restaurants, cafes and bars. Steeped in colonial history you can visit some really old buildings and houses and get a feel for how the place developed back in the 1800's

Must see these old preserved buildings when in Stdney. Just a short distance away from Circular Quay the Rocks are a unique collection of old Victorian buildings preserved for the future thanks to some sympathetic builders Try the old pubs such as the Fortune of War or the Orient Hotel which are full of old photos and memorabilia but the beer is modern prices at Au$8 for a pint of Guinness Lots of souvanier hunters and shoppers all around but no need to spend any money but look at the old wrought iron and old structures now all gift shops
Living history. Walking through the streets and market, drinking in the hotels and enjoying the historic buildings, a great way to spend a couple of days.

Fascinating place. The Rocks is a great place to spend a morning or an afternoon. Great places to eat, great markets (on the weekend), lots of history to uncover. I definitely recommend doing one of the walking tours if you are interested in the history side, you can really travel back in time here.

Historical Building. I found myself quite enjoy there because most of the buildings were not more than two storey height. I went there on Saturday because I knew there was a weekend market. In the market, not only you could find the things from Australia, but also from other countries. Many local designers sold their own designed products. There was a lot of restaurants and shops there, when you tired after your shopping you can have a rest in one of the restaurant and having a cup of beer to spend your half day.

Lots of restaurants. Great area lots of restaurants the opera house, even though we went to the cinema and missed the rain and then had lunch and missed it again, not a good day for the weather when we were there.
" Lovely time at the Rock". We had a lovely time at the Rock, check out the market and taste some lovely foods around the Rock....

Always a great day out. We attend the markets on a regular basis and enjoy all the intricate details on offer at The Rocks. We were last there with family that were visiting from Newcastle. We took the usual quick, scenic ferry ride from home into Circular Quay so that we could give our visitors the 'all inclusive tour'. It was a great day out & thoroughly enjoyed by our guests. No matter how many times you have been there, there is always something different to do and see. It is a beautifully, spectacular part of Sydney and so full of life.
History for the imaginative mind. Well preserved heritage trail. Those who have an imaginative mind can travel back in time. Lots of opportunity for photography.
The Rocks. Walked down to the Rocks and checked out the Sunday market. Found a lovely Italian restaurant and had a great breakfast. Went back for dinner. It was fabulous.

Sunday relaxing at the Rocks. Quaint area, lost of history. Nice opal pearls for sale. Great food and restaurants. Next to Circular Quay - close to ferries. Nice for a day trip. The park next door had kids shows. Some nice Italian and gourmet dining.

Pleasant stroll. When we stay in the city,we always head to the Rocks Market on the weekend. The stalls have a variety of quality products[lots of home-made and good quality food stalls. Spend some time in the regular shops in The Rocks,grab a beer at one of the many hotels there,and enjoy lunch.YOU CAN SPEND QUITE A FEW HOURS STROLLING AROUND THIS PRECINCT.
A brief interlude. Visiting on a bank holiday there were limited places open. It was very picturesque and well signposted throughout. On a normal day there is plenty to cater for all ages.

A favourite location . I just love The Rocks, so much history, so much to see and do. The argyle arts centre is a classic with many books and crannies to explore. Street markets add to its charm and a wonderful place to wander and take in the magical sights. A must do!
Historic Sydney. The Rocks is a vibrant and varied experience. Shopping, Convict history, eating, walking, views - it has the lot. Give yourself at least a day to soak up everything.
a great palce to visit. my wife and I love spending time wandering around the Rocks, you can feel the history of the place, there are a few steps and hills, the side streets are there to be explored

A fascinating area to explore. The Rocks is a fascinating area to explore. With a range of historic buildings that are still used as homes and businesses, The Rocks has lots to see and do. Plenty of food options as well as interesting galleries to view. Also a great range of fashion. An easy area to spend the day or just a few hours. Well worth a visit.

Excellent spot for a 360 experience.. Very good food, friendly people, plenty of taxis to get you around, near the wharf, near Circular Quay and the trains. There's food, souvenir shopping, sites and plenty more.

The Rocks - The History - The Markets. Wandering around the rocks area there is so much to look at whether you are taking in the history of the area, certainly loads of information around and some great tours available. Visiting some of the great eateries in this area or to check out the amazing markets. Something for everyone at the rocks. The markets are a must. Great selection of so many different things. Something for everyone at the Rocks. A great day.

Boring, hard to get to for no reason. Takes a while to get to, bus services cut recently , train requires annoying change and ferry=long walk, but when you get there , you'll find The Rock has nothing to offer, no good restaurants, no good bar, no good shops, no good hotel, no nothing really...Don't bother

Early history lesson. I took a walking tour of the Rocks and it was excellent. An easy walk with the history of the Rocks and early Australia give by a very qualified tour guide. Well worth the time and price
Cafe lunch. Nice little area of older buildings, shops and cafes. Enjoyed a nice lunch. Not far from opera house and bridge.
Market Day is the Day. Walked up through the Rocks a number of times. But I think the best time was during the market. Lots going on! Lots of stalls to visit and peruse! Really interesting.

Great little slice of Sydney.. Full of interesting history re the origins of the place. Full of charm and atmosphere. Some great museums telling of its past, galleries, charming shops and places to eat. Well worth a stroll about.

take the time to visit the market. We went to The Rocks a couple of times while in Sydney, it has a great range of cafes, easy access to the Sydney wharf and a great place to get up close to a cruise ship if there is one in. The weekend market provides a range of ethnic food, and local art.

At he oldest settled area in Sydney. The rocks is wonderful for seeing Sydney's history and heritage buildings. There are many shops for art works, souviners, and many many restaurants for wining and dining the day away.It is linked to through to Circular Quay, and the harbour by a short walk.There are some lovely old buildings and the Contemporary art museum is located there. There are some great waterfront restaurants nearby that offer fantastic seafood and views.

Nice selection of stores, markets, restaurants. This is where the convicts settled and opened up their businesses way back when. Certainly some interesting history and good eats and stores along the way.

Interesting Historical Sydney Nieghborhood. We visited the Rocks on our second trip to Sydney. Walking distance from the Opera House and Circular Quay. The weekend markets are very good with alot of vendors offering many unique items. The Rocks free museum is worth a visit and give the history of the Rocks neighborhood as well as Sydney
A taste of old Sydney town. Something for everyone here. History, food and drinks, pubs, restaurants, great old buildings. A great place to wander with your camera and go as you please.

Fun for All with a dash of history and intrigue. The Rocks is a beautiful part of Sydney's colourful history. It has at times been a slum tenants village, a rowdy underworld lair and of course, as we know it today; a somewhat high end shopping strip with pubs and cafes and weekend markets. Basically, it's got something for everyone, even families with the fussiest of small children or the most opinionated and bored older children (No, seriously!)You can watch huge cruise ships come and go, take a self led or guided historical tour, or sit and enjoy the wurst and beer at Lowenbrau in the dappled shade. If you're on limited time in Sydney, definitely don't miss this area.

Real history without gimmicks. Every visitor to Sydney should spend some time wandering The Rocks. Art galleries and smart shops stand cheek by jowl with old pubs and colonial buildings, in a warren of hidden laneways that take you straight back to Sydney's earliest days. And when you're tired of looking at the past, enjoy the present in any one of the excellent cafes and bars in the area - there is something to suit everyone. At night, The Rocks really come alive when tourists retreat and locals come out to play. Have fun!

The Rocks in Sydney is an historical place to visit. There is so much to see and do at The Rocks, a must do is visit the Glenmore Pub for a great meal and if you are lucky a wonderful view of the harbour
Nice Walk. A must visit if you are in Sydney, great shops and very friendly, short walk from the bridge its a great historical place to visit. If your hungry there are many great places to eat.
historical lovely place. weekend market must visit, the whole place is like a small old village. Just stroll around the historical buildings and imagine u r there 100 years ago
The Rocks. A very historical place to visit. Very clean with many lane ways to go through to find so many cafes and restaurants to eat at.

Love. This area of Sydney is so interesting. There is so much to see and do. If you enjoy history or architecture in the least there are so many buildings to check out. Quite a few walkways from the beginning of the cities history. There is an excellent esplanade from the Opera House to the Bridge with restuarants and shops. Ferries and cruise ships come and go. It's just a neat place all around.

Great Shopping. My girlfriend and I went to the markets at The Rocks on the Saturday we were in Sydney and while I won't use the expletive I used to describe how long it goes on for, needless to say, it's long. Really long. They have something for everyone and I was able to pick up a lot of souvenirs for people back home that I wouldn't get anywhere else. One of the best things I was able to get at The Rocks was a didgeridoo. There were a few buskers in the Harbour playing them and we asked where we could get an authentic didgeridoo and they told me about a store in The Rocks called the Spirit Gallery.The Rocks is yet another perk of staying in the Harbour when you're in Sydney. It may be pricier but it is definitely worth the price.
lovely. Stayed at The Old Holiday Inn Sydney. On the doorstep of The Rocks, perfect location lovely market on the weekend, so many tasty places to eat. a must see!

Quaint shops and lovely market on a Saturday. Has a lovely market of crafts etc on a Saturday. Lots of restaurants, pubs and cafes. A great museum ( Susannah place) tells the history of people who lived here. The 4 terraced houses are pretty much as they were over 100 years ago. 5 minute walk from the harbour.

Great location to stay or just visit. Stayed at the Holiday Inn at the Rocks, best location in Sydney. You can walk to everything from here with ease, The Bridge, Opera House, Gardens, shopping, Darling Harbour, etc. It has some great pubs at the back (near the Bridge) and plenty of shops and good selection of restaurants plus it has a street market on Saturday

Stunning. Wonderful old part of the city. Great buildings everywhere, lots of history.So many little streets full of shops bars cafes and places to sit, have a coffee and watch the world go by.Love this area of Sydney, hope it never changes

The Rocks Markets. Besides the stunning views of Sydney Harbour, visitors must not miss The Rocks viz. The Rocks Markets which open from 10am till 5pm on every Saturday and Sunday only. Just a 10 mins. walk from Circular Quay towards Sydney Harbour Bridge direction, one can visit Museum of Contemporary Art, The Rocks and The Rocks Markets located at Playfair and George Street. There are some 200 stalls selling all sorts of clothings, souvenir, handbags, handicrafts etc.Many cafes and restaurants are around for visitors to relax and enjoy delicious meals and drinks. It's a pleasure and enjoyment to stroll and shop in the Rocks.

Not as good as i thought. I heard that you really need to go there, but its not so entertaining. Walking through and having a look is quite nice and you'll get some nice pictures of the harbour bridge as well but thats it.
Quay West. We spent 4 nights in the Quay West Hotel and was ever upgraded to the penthouse suite which was spectacular with views over Sydney Harbour. We would definitely recommend this hotel.

The first settlers picked a prime location. Just ten minutes walk from Circular Quay is the Rocks area. Shops, restaurants, pubs and a museum are all in this small pleasant place. Some original terraced houses with corrugated roofs still remain.

Sydney tour 2016. The Rocks is a great area to visit . The food, lively atmosphere and charming historic ambiance are all enjoyable . It's a great place to walk around especially for foodies and beer lovers. Wear comfortable shoes though because there are hills. The Sydney Harbour bridge climb is located in the Rocks and the Circular Quay is also close.
Great for a walkabout . Had a day out doing the history and culture and a night eating and drinking. Both enjoyable and fun to do and well worth the time and effort to discover.
Holiday. What a fabulous place the Rocks is.Plenty of restaurants and bars in the area. Not a place to miss. We have had a great time and would highly recommend this area of Sydney

The Rocks. The Rocks was a fabulous place to visit. The restaurants and bars were excellent and there were interesting shops to visit. The Fortune of War was Sydney's oldest pub and has been there since 1828. It is a must to visit. The staff is very friendly, the drinks are good, and the food is excellent.

Beautiful architecture. Staying at the Four Seasons so it is on the doorstep. Wonderful historic area of old Sydney with lovely old buildings. Lots of characterful cafes and bars. Interesting shops and art galleries. They have street markets at the weekend which are full of crafty stalls selling jewellery,artwork etc. Well worth a visit. Stroll to Dawes point for views of the bridge and Opera house.

Beautiful space, amazing staff!. Stayed here with my mom last December and had a great time. It's in a great location with walking distance to lots of places, the food at the bar was so yummy and the staff is so incredibly friendly and helpful! Would defo stay here again! Thanks!
Top. Good food and wine. Really nice ambiente and delicious desserts! Good for a dinner in the city. Try the spaghetti bolognese!

Charming - won me over.... A bt touristy, well placed to attract the gazillions of people off the cruise ships, it's almost a pastiche of itself. It just manages to retain its heart and you will find genuinely charming buildings and backstreets. The market is good and the views are some of the best in town.

Take a tour. The rocks is a neat neighborhood that I wish we had spent more time in. Visit the free museum and if possible take a tour. The I'm Free Tour starts at 6 pm daily, it is 90 minutes and gives a good overview of the interesting history of the area.
Self Guided tour. We picked up a self guided walking tour map and spent a pleasant hour wandering around the streets and browsing the shops

Great shopping and dining. Very close to Circular Quay. This is a great place to pick up that one of a kind souvenir or grab a drink and meal at one of the local pubs.
Explore the narrow little side streets. They will lead to some real "gems" in the area.
On the weekends there is a street market for even more unique gifts.
History. Arts. Food.. Get an immense sense of Sydney's history. Explore the arts scene in the museums and galleries. Indulge in some good food and drinks while you are there. Enjoy The Rocks!!!

Historic walk. Walking around the Rocks is reliving history. You can imagine the convicts toiling away under the Harbour Bridge. Lots of cafes and restaurants.There was a cruise ship in when we were there and we watched passengers going aboard. It's close to the harbour and there is so much boat traffic to watch.

Wonderful part of Sydney. The Rocks is a great place to wander, plenty to see around the harbour, including Museum of Contemporary Art. Lots of little restaurants and weekend market, also Four Seasons Hotel has a great street bar.

Fun interesting market on Sunday. Great place to buy souvenirs on a Sunday. The area is buzzing with lots to see and buy that is different from the shops. Nice places to eat and drink with a good atmosphere.

Interesting old town Sydney, and not as touristy as you might think. We were pleased to discover the old streets and narrow alleys of The Rocks on a pleasant afternoon, stepping out the back door of the Museum of Contemporary Art. Along with shops selling Australian boots and clothing, and The Oldest Pub in Australia (a pub full of guys with beer and tv sports, not much of a surprise there) we found interesting small and creative restaurants and bars, a midday street market, better shops and good harbor views. Could be that it is different in the evening, but we found it a pleasant contrast to both the festival marketplace that is Circular Quay and the highrise offices and hotels of the adjacent Central Business District. Definitely worth a look around and another unique side of Sydney which is a very livable city.
Loved it. The area is full of old world Aussie charm lots of nice but not cheap restaurants well worth a walk round

Australia's oldest settlement. Australia is not an old country. British settlement occurred just over 200 years ago. The oldest city in Australia is Sydney and the oldest part of Sydney is the Rocks. When I first went there it was a rough place, full of cobblestones and streets that shot off at irregular angles. The Rocks is only a few minutes from the centre of Sydney. Although it is partially gentrified, it can still be a tough place.; The Rocks has retained much of its convict character. The Rocks is popular with tourists, it's a unique part of Australia's heritage. It's amazing that the Rocks has survived.many attempts to make it "nice." The market is interesting, check for opening times.
Oldest part of Sydney. Fun to spend some time visiting, but the area is very small and merits a few hours at best. Great for a walk on a day that is not too hot or wet

One of Sydney's great little places. Stayed in the Rocks for a long weekend and love the place. Small little alleyways lead to something new, suggest you ditch the map and just walk. Lots of pubs and restaurants, especially recommend the Rocks Cafe. Great food, sit on the pavement to watch the people and traffic go by. Many places to visit, a must do when visiting Sydney.
Great Sydney Area. A great place to stroll around The area has been upgraded recently and is now a very trendy part of Sydney to visitBars Restaurants and environment delightful
Touristy area of shops and eateries. Located below the south end of the Harbour Bridge, this is a very walkable area which has a historic past. Lots of souvenir shops and restaurants.

Like the Opera House, a visit to the Rocks in Mandatory!!. I always love spending a day or 1/2 day cruising around the streets and shops of The Rocks. Lots to see and do including a local market full of amazing food, crafts, etc.Great place to find unique souvenirs and try local craft beers :)
Many interesting shops & restaurants. This area is full of shops with unique and artisanal products, as well as restaurants, wine bars with door seating, ad great harbor views.

step back in time. see how sydney started,great place to walk around see some interesting old buildings,weekend markets are good for a browse and souvenirs.many food options for lunch,rather expensive though.

Friday Foodie Market. We were fortunate to be wandering around the Rocks on a Friday morning. Nice selection of handicraft shops selling a wide variety of charming unique items - jewellery made from leaves, Turkish hand painted crockery, hand made soaps etc. Variety of food stores that sold burgers, nuts, chocolates, cup cakes and more. Really delightful!
Weekend is the best time to be here. The Rocks Markets are on Saturday and Sunday - it is the best time to go for a stroll through the Rocks. There are lots of restuarants and bars iin the area

Sunday at the Rocks. I went to the open air market on Sunday at the Rocks and found it to be enjoyable and entertaining. I was able to find some unique wooden gifts for family members and would recommend it to people who are hoping to find authentic Australian items to take home.

Great place to walk around, eat, drink, shop.. The Rocks is a great-for-tourists area on the southern shore of, and easy walking distance from Sydney Harbour, and northwest of the Sydney CBD. There are lots of restaurants, bars and stores (Australian clothing, opal shops), art galleries, plus a 100-stall crafts market on weekends. It has come a long way since its roots as a slum beginning in 1788, when it was popular by prostitutes and sailors.

Want to shop? Want to eat?. The rocks has every type of food imaginable. And shops - my heavens you will have to remortgage your home. The shops are friendly and souvenirs eclectic. But remember it is a tourist area. So shop carefully. The views of the harbor bridge and the opera house make the time spent there enjoyable

Lots of places to go eat or drink. Went to this historic place as part of a tour. There's some really well preserved buildings from the 18th century. Lots of quaint interesting shops, restaurants and bars. Walk down towards the cruise pier and you'll be rewarded with the view of the "coat hanger" (bridge) and the opera house.

The Historical side of Sydney. The Rocks seems to be set up for tourists or school excursions for primary school kids. Lots of cafes, and a few good restaurants. It is certainly worth a visit to see some of Sydney's convict past.

Market day marvel. Lovely afternoon spent strolling the cobbles, great little market. Watched a fabulous artist create an out of this world landscape using spray paints, no brushes, it has to be seen to be appreciated.Was so impressed I bought the picture I watched him create. Also bought some hand painted jewellery.
Sunday Market. Great Sunday market, it was our last day and found the market by chance - well worth a visit. Lots of great pubs/restaurants nearby

The Rocks really Rock!. Old town Sydney at its finest. Sidewalk cafes, boutique shops, museums, the harbor, all in a compact walkable neighborhood with cobblestone streets. A couple of hours walking about the Rocks is a good investment of time.
Lovely Spot. Lots of History and great markets. Easy to get around. Lots of quaint little shops. The pubs are old and welcoming.

Historic Sydney. Walk, walk, walk. You need to walk to see the Rocks historic section of Sydney. Yes there are steps and hills but it is worth it as the old buildings are charming.You can do as much or as little as you like. Visit the markets on the weekend, look at the old houses from the first settlement of Sydney and sit to enjoy a beer in Sydney's oldest hotel or dine at one of the many restaurants.All this and a short walk from Circular Quay past the famous Harbour Bridge

History. We visited the rocks every evening for a week,the area is full of history about Sydney ,and the shops were a big attraction for my wife,the bars were a good attraction for me,live music being played in quite a few of them .
Cool spot. The rocks are really fun to walk around in after visiting the opera house or before. Nice and colorful spot.

Fascinating history. Try to use a guide to walk you through the area. You will get to know much more about it. Once you have been taken through then go back yourself for another look and stop for a coffee in one of the little coffee shops around. Well worth the visit.
Lovely atmosphere, plus foodie places too.. Great to see and feel the atmosphere of the city. Lots of interesting history spots to see. Unspoilt by the highrise buildings close by.

Potential . Potentially a killer tourist trap. Scream but you won't get out. If you can get past the kitch, crowds and risking bad food, the Rocks is a beautiful place. Special with colonial architecture and Settlement history, there are some classy gems here and some of the views are spectacular.
