Fantastic area to walk and visit the market during the weekend. Lots of small shops, lovely area to walk around to view the OLD buildings next to the harbor. Lots of nice small restaurants and next to circular quay

Tremendous photo walk. If you're into architecture photography or colonial history this area is packed with amazing sights and tales. Plenty or trendy and prices cafes and restaurants for the more discerning foodie.

Eclectic Markets and wonderful Eateries. Lots to see … wander the rocks to see the history of the old buildings and to have a drink or a meal at the many eateries. Walk thru the markets … sit by the harbour which is right next to "The Rock" You will enjoy it.

Amazing Rocks Tour. We joined the one and half hour walking tour of the Rocks The people in the Rocks Office Tour were friendly and very helpful. Our tour guide for the walking tour was very knowledgable and gave an excellent commentary on the Rocks area - both historical and current day significance. The group was about 9 people so that made for a more personable guided tour that enabled opportunities to ask questions. The walking tour was quite manageable. I was concerned that it might be a bit difficult but the tour guide made sure we went at a comfortable pace so the was greatly appreciated. I would recommend this tour.

Fascinating historical area. Lots of interesting shops to browse in this area . Interesting nooks and crannies especially Nurse Alley. A vibrant weekend market offers food, clothing, jewellery and tourist souvenirs. There's often some wonderful music to be heard and sitting at a pavement cafe people watching has to be my favourite pastime here.
Great area to visit. and to think this area was nearly demolished in the 1970's- wonderful character and history- my favorite bit of Sydney

Great Place for history and shopping. We visited the Rocks briefly on our first visit to Sydney two years ago and vowed to go back. We spent time there on this trip and loved every minute of it. The streets are full of history and back alleys and steps from one place to another. The shops and cafes are great. A visit worthwhile is the Rocks Museum, free and in an old building.

Fascinating history. We visited The Rocks more than once while staying in Sydney as it was so interesting. We picked up some leaflets from the Tourist Information Centre and carried out a really excellent "Historical Walk" on one particular day. It was wonderful to learn so much more about the area and to see the buildings that had been preserved, most of which are still in use. The area has many cute shops, historic pubs and hotels, and a market on some days (I don't remember which days though). A great area to visit.

Beautiful part of Sydney but watch for uneven surfaces!. We loved exploring the streets, alleys, and secret passageways in The Rocks. The area has great pubs, small but nice "foodie market" on Friday, nice views, interesting history, and lots of character. Be careful with little kids on the uneven, rocky sidewalks. Our young son tripped and broke his arm!
Do the pub tour!. D the pub tour in the rocks it is amazing! There are so many bars and pubs in the rocks each of which have their own history to them!
A must do.. When in Sydney, spend some time "on the Rocks." Wonderful restaurants and bars right at the harbor, history, shopping, close to the Harbor Bridge.

Somewhere different. I have been visiting the Rocks since it was a primary school excursion.I love the vibrancy of the Rocks markets and the diverse crowds on a weekend.It changes, but much stays the same.The Rocks are a piece of our heritage that should be treasured and kept alive
A fascinating insight into old Sydney. This area is packed with interesting old buildings all with a story to tell. Some excellent information boards help you find your way. Very lively at night.

Nice little shops nothing much to look at. When I visited Sydney I was 23 and travelling alone so the rocks for me weren't much special. The cafes and eating & drinking places are great. Friday night around the rocks is a great place to drink and chat, with plenty of atmosphere.
Nice place. The Rocks is an interesting Place with lots of bars and Restaurants. You will find Shops and Hotels aswell. The old brik-buildings are nice

Awesome place to walk around. We were recommended by friends to visit this area and boy we are so happy we did! This area had a kind of laid back feeling, in the middle of the hustle and rush of a city. There are nice and small restaurants where there was live music and at a place even open cinema. We had dinner at one restaurant, then ice cream at another and just strolled around. I will highly recommend to visit this area!

Good Sunday Market. There was a very good array of different stalls at the Sunday market and seemed to be at a reasonable (city) price; also plenty of places for coffee, and all in a very interesting old area of Sydney.

nice way to spend a day . after visiting the opera house we decided to walk following some people. it led us to a market. nice selections of items, very friendly place. we were lucky to see the rocks. nice cafes n old heritage buildings. one of our favorite places to see in sydney
Bustling place . Great on the weekend with all the independent street vendors. Plenty of shops to browse through and lots of restaurants and pubs.

Great Area. Lovely to spend time round The Rocks area to see some of Sydney's history in the little shops and houses and small streets still there to tell some stories. There was a threat to pull it all down some years ago and this would have been so wrong, thankfully someone saw sense before it was destroyed. Some lovely bars and eats places in this area.
Historical. The buildings capture the essence of Sydney in days of old.Some wonderful shops for antique hunters.

The rocks. It's a nice place with a new park along the sea. It's a old part of the town where the most poor people where integrated by the state. It become a rich area with high buildings and fancy restaurants and bars. The high buildings cute the sky but you can get nice view points and visit some nice things in the area.

It is the part of Sydney with history.... We walked from Kingcross Road all the way to the Rocks...to where there are old buildings with restaurants, stores, bars...it is the area you walk to if you are going to climb the bridge...it is quite nice and there are some very nice places to hang out and see the world go by. We had lunch at the oldest pub in town, Lord Nelson....the usual pub food but the beer was good and the ambiance welcoming.If you like Ugg boots, there are many shops that sells them..and some pretty interesting and funky styles. But do notice that shops close at 4 or 5 PM except on Thursday...the taxi driver said it was due to double wage and some opt for not being open.Another good place for drinks is the rooftop of the Glenmore Hotel....you just a bit up the hill and there is the entrance for the bridge attraction...the climb.Best,

A visit to the Farmer Market. The farmers market at the Rocks is a good place to pick up local arts and crafts. It is surrounded by some very good restaurants but they do not open until 11:30 AM. Makes fro a good way to spend a couple of hours.

Historic area. Loved walking through this neighborhood with its old buildings, boutiques, cafes and museums. There are open markets at times that have a lot of unique handicrafts and clothing to browse. Take your time and wander through this area. Or better yet take the free walking tours where you get a wealth of information about its history.

Weekend stay. pre boarding the Cruise liner.. The Rocks in Sydney.This area is interesting for shopping at weekend markets, eating at indoor and outdoor restaurants. Art galleries, picking up ferries across the harbour and getting an impression of old Sydney plus the nearby Opera House.

Great walk. We took one of the free walking tours (look for the person with the green T-shirt). These walks are totally free, operating on tip-only. No pressure at all. My wife took a tour around downtown Sydney, then we both did the evening walking tour through the Rocks. A really interesting walk. Probably takes a couple of hours, but ends near lots of action near the harbor (pubs, restaurants, the opera house, etc.) so you've plenty to do when the tour's over. Our tour guide was Josh and he was very interesting, well-informed (a history major), and entertaining. I highly recommend the free walking tours.

The Rocks. Walking around this historic area is enjoyable. Easy to understand the history of this area. Many shops,cafes and restaurants. Spend time in the Rocks and you will not be disappointed. In fact stay at the Harbour Rocks Hotel. Enjoy the street vendors on the weekend. Close to the Sydney Opera House and the Harbour Bridge.
Yummy. I love the Rocks. Brings back memories of my visits there in my younger days. I especially love Pancakes at the Rocks.

Great location on weekends with vendor tents. Found some unique Australia products at the vendor tents at the rocks. Very hilly - wear comfortable shoes and shop away. Most all vendors take credit cards but beware some struggle with the technology. Enjoy

The Rocks Rocks. The Rocks is a very nice and trendy are in the heart of Sydney. Lively outside cafes and restaurants populate the area during the off winter season. The Museum of Contemporary Art is located just there. Also there is a leather store whose owner is Louis Cardini, who designs and makes beautiful bags and all sort of jackets in leather and with great prices.You can either have breakfast, lunch or dinner or just stop by to have some drinks. The area overlooks the Sydney Harbour and is really fun to be there.The Majestic Opera House building could be seen from parts of the Streets unless the view is obstructed by the cruiser ships docked at the pier. Which is also a marvelous view.I had a walking tour all over down town Sydney and spent some four hours trolling the streets. I also took a boat Darling Harbour, which is also a great Must visit area. Sydney is one of the most beautiful, diverse and peaceful cities in the world.

Browsers enjoy!. A feast of delights greets the browser when he or she visits The Rocks. There are many bars and restaurants as well as galleries and boutiques to linger in. On high days and holidays there are little market stalls with handcrafted goods and musical groups in little corners! And if that is not enough there are historical sites and an interesting free museum!

A brilliant insight into the early days of convict life in Sydney. We'd not expected to find much evidence of buildings from 1800s with so many modern blocks, and admittedly there's not a lot remaining - but well worth seeing. We went on a free guided tour from The Rocks DIscovery Museum and had a lot of our preconceptions of convict life overturned. Would definitely recommend a little time here if at all interested in recent history.
Great antique shops and markets. There is always something happening at the Rocks. There are great food markets and clothing/accessory stalls. It also provides great views of the Harbour Bridge
Perfect for a date. Nice food, nice people, awesome view and impressive architecture. What else do you need for a nice casual date!!
worth the look. so much to do and see around here and for travel to manly on the ferries and many other places . as bit of shopping and sight seeing as well.

Old worlde charm. This is located on the Southern side of the harbour and is in the North Western part of the Central Business District(CBD). One of the earliest places that got developed after the settlement in 1788.The early buildings were made of sandstone from where the name "Rocks" was derived.There are still lanes which maintain the old world charm though the place has been developed with beautiful hotels etc.. It is very close to the Circular quay and also the Harbour bridge. There are several historic buildings and old time themed bars/pubs.Nice place for a walk along the cobbled stone roads and pending time in the old pubs.
The Rocks. Lovely change from all the modern high rises in modern Sydney. Architecture, laid back atmosphere, shops, restaurants. Great stuff
This is an upscale locale. This is an upscale locale and loved by tourists and locals alike. Great place to sit, have a beverage and watch the world go by. Great nightlife and very safe.
A unique shopping cluster.. Walking around The Rocks is beautiful. The buildings are historic and lots of lovely little restaurants to eat at.We found a Billich shop and purchased a painting.
Old Sydney. Visited this as part of our free walking tour or Sydney. Our guide loved this part of Sydney. Were the original colonial convicts would have lived
weekends are great there with the craft market. wonderful to wonder thru and see the old Sydney....many fine resturants and the pubs are great there for a counter lunch
Nice stroll. Interesting place to walk around with some cool shops interesting restaurants and lots of random events like food stall pop ups and art installations.
Interesting. Great place to wander and take in the atmosphere many old historic Hotels and beautiful little restaurants and shops. Close to circular key where the ferries leave for Manly
Amazing place. Great place to visit, loads to see and do, lots of great shops, stalls and lots more. We seem to go back there every day to have lunch.

buzzing area.. Great area to visit, next to the bridge few minutes walk from the opera house and harbour ferries. Plenty of bars, eating places and shops, good for opeals all in well maintained victorian buildings.

Great place to walk around. Always enjoy walking, and eating and drinking around here
It caters for all tastes and there is always something new to see or d

Cool Weekend Market and Restaurants. We stayed near The Rocks, with some great views and the weekend market. I only had an hour or two because we arrived on Sunday afternoon, but it's definitely worth a visit. There is a range of things from jewelry to art to souvenirs, but good quality.

Oldest pub in Sydney. Nice Place to walk, enjoy the evening.
A fine Pub Tour or somthong special to eat from international cousine like Munich or italian kitchen. Livemusic in a Pub, or meet fine people...

What a change. Certainly a buzzy destination. We hit a street market on a Saturday afternoon, lots of street restaurants, people, buskers, hidden stairways, and small alleys to explore. I remeber my first trip to the rocks and we were hit with a flash downpour and flood. We laid in the gutter outside a pub and body surfed down the street. What fun we had. Sopping wet and giggleing like children. The local police drove by very slowly, took one look shook there heads, and drove on. The poor taxi driver who picked us up and four very wet bodys in his cab.

Fantastic. The Rocks area was very impressive great for overseas tourists Sydney has done us proud with this area Great Markets showing off our great Australian Gifts mostly hand made very much enjoyed my morning out here.

worth a visit. we wandered the rocks every day of our week in sydney it had everything you could think of from parks to booking tickets and restaurants seats to sit bikes to ride a funfair when we were there

Lots of History Here!!. This is where it all started, go look at the great buildings there. First and oldest Pub is still in business. Lots to see in this area. Sandstone is what make the buildings so unique.

A must. This'is where it all happens in SydneyMust do, must be "seen in "place. The Hip Australian youngsters are all here. Plenty of restaurants all of which seem to be very rowdy,noisy and full.I was very suprised to see a security guard in front of each one but I ´m sure therés a reason....alcohol maybe?....The Australians eat early so make sure you find a table before 20h30-21h00
A great place to mooch around. Interesting buildings, history & atmosphere. Well worth a visit. Stroll along the old passageways & streets soaking up the local history.

Great beers!. Attractive architecture and historical sites. Drinking establishments include The Lord Nelson (excellent beer selection) and the Fortunes of War (?..i think that was the name). Try the Pulses for a really excellent dish.

Wealth of History to enjoy. Many bars cafes and shops in an area which was once the Cove of this busy city several generations ago. Houses Information Centre and Rocks Museum as well as easy access to Ferry Quays and Harbour

Great Weekend Market. Loved walking around the Rocks, but we didn't see as much as we would have liked of the history. This being said we loved the weekend market that was gong on when we were there and bought beautiful goodies, met delightful people and thoroughly enjoyed walking the area.

The Rocks offers something for everyone. We love visiting The Rocks, walking stopping in at bars & eating along the way. The markets are great & quite quirky. The shops are a great mixture of new & old offering something for everyone. A fun way to spend a day or & night.

Fun sunday. Walked all around the rocks with a friend from Canada showing him places. We walked under the harbour bridge. Weather was nice. Markets were on. Lovely time!! Got the ferry from manly. Good times!!

Some great history if you look for the plaques. We spent our last morning in Sydney wandering around The Rocks. There is some great history in The Rocks you just need to look for the plaques that provide it. The rest is made up of a few stores, galleries etc., that are good to wonder round. It really is a touristy destination. We did eat at the oldest pub in Sydney - Fortune of War - which was great. See my review on the pub. You don't need more than a couple of hours to have covered all of The Rocks.

Lovely historic area. I am an architect so the first place I like to go is the historic area of any city. This is a very handsome area, mixing old and new. There are many original buildings, but mostly newer facilities bring a lively vibe to the area. There are good restaurants, shopping and a good museum giving history of the area.

Great place to walk around. We went on market day. Things were interesting but basically you typical tourist trap. Vendors basically selling the same items, although some booths were unique. Worth the visit to get yourself oriented to Sydney.

Great place to visit especially on market days.. The Rocks is full of interesting craft stalls and little eateries and the atmosphere is great, especially on market days when it is thronging with visitors. It is also very convenient for passengers on the many cruise ships which dock here as it is only a short walk from the berth.

Must go place in Sydney. It's a great walk around the Rocks. It's not only the local handicrafts and souvenirs that you can find. There are nice local cafes and snacks.. with great view of the Sydney Bridge and harbor. You won't regret even if you have limited time to go around in Sydney.
A very beautiful part of Sydney. Just go walking and get lost in beautiful old architecture and go over theHarbour Bridge. Lots of great Accommodation but need to book it early.

Old Sydney!. This historical section of Sydney is a must see. The restaurants, shops and art gallery provide the visitor with a sense of old Sydney. Shops tend to be pricey but food eateries are reasonably priced. Try to avoid the days when the cruise ships are in. The quiet streets of the Rocks are over run with "boat people".
A great area of Sydney. The Rocks is home to many lovely pubs and bars as well as lovely shops and designer boutiques. The Rocks market is also a good chance to buy souvenirs and high quality gifts.
great place to visit on Friday, Saturday & Sunday. They have food and street markets on these days and well worth the visit, food great and Art and Craft stalls very good also.

Historical heart of Sydney. Still the best place to sense the history of Sydney - it may be becoming more modern and retail oriented but you still sense what Sydney was and how it has changed. Great place to walk around and fascinating seeing the contrast of old and new.
nice walk. a must go place in sydney, unique atermposphere, very easy walk, good for family or singles, some unique stores

The historic heart of Sydney. A bit touristy in places but a must-visit area.. Landing place of the first fleet, this area is steeped in history. Would recommend spending a few hours exploring the various lane ways and harbour foreshore round Circular Quay to the Bridge. There's numerous shops, bars and restaurants, and a market at the weekend.

Lovely pace at the market. At some markets around the world it anyways seems so busy. Here the pace is relaxed and the people friendly and not pushy. It has been 20 years since my last visit to this market. Good to see the development.

History.. The Rocks.,an absolute must for everybody,who loves their history,(this place is steeped in History),and there's no shortage of drinking holes around here either.
Food and shops are also very good , and the weekend markets are a huge attraction to many a local,and traveller alike.A huge thumbs up here.!!
Walking tour.. Stopped here on a walking tour of the neighbourhood and found a little gem of a cafe for coffee. The old buildings were very interesting.

Nice area to walk around. Went there on my last day as a tourist. To visit the rocks market which is only open on weekends. Almost did not make it as it closes at 5pm. Nice place to walk around but not a must to visit the market as the items on offer seems boring. Nice atmosphere though.

Busy and buzzy. The Rocks area is a five minute walk from Circular Quay. The day we visited there were two large cruise ships in port so there were lots of tourists wandering but it did not impact on our enjoyment as it is a large area. There was a market (Saturday) selling crafts and clothes. There are many street cafes and restaurants. Excellent views of the Bridge and occasionally of the Opera House. A pleasant couple of hours.

Great place to stroll, learn. So many interesting things to see and learn! There is a museum and a visitor's center for information...but there is a free walking tour that meets at 6 pm that I think is the way to do it.

Old Sydney, but a bit touristy!. The rocks area is worth seeing if you are visiting Sydney, and given a small insight into what buildings were like in Sydney's early times. The buildings include timber and brick construction and some old terrace homes, but most are now used for shops. There are many hospitality venues for food and drinks and cater for most tastes and needs. There are also many art shops and some duty free shops, so it tends to be a bit touristy, but it's still OK. On Saturdays and Sundays it has arts and crafts markets and they are worth a visit if your have an hour or two to wander about.

Enjoyable day tour. Wear comfortable shoes! There's lots of places to see and shop, but like much of downtown Sydney, it's a lot of hilly walking!Nice souvenir shops, and it's all very close to the harbor, where you can see he Opera House, the Bridge or walk back into town.

Lovely pedestrian district to walk around. IT's been plotted as a pedestrian area for people to walk and look around with not much traffic so you can enjoy the shops, buildings and harbour view here. Need some walks up and down so make sure physical condition is affordable.

Pleasant to walk around - Tourist prices. It's great to walk around and see the architecture and check out the shops. Just keep in mind the prices charged are tourist prices and therefore slightly inflated.

Just walking around. Took some Canadian friends for a walk around The Rocks mid week and they loved the experience.They loved the shops, the buildings, the bird life and the cafes. We even saw a group of school children dressed up as convicts. What a way to explore our past with newcomers to our city.

A Village that has everything!. The Rocks area is located close to where the cruise ships arrive. Therefore its an area that has everything available. Hotels, restaurants, bars, shopping, coffee shops and one of the nicest markets on the weekends.

A walkable area with many sites to see.. You can eat in a restaurant, or shop in the stores or open air market that is there on the weekends. You can watch the busy harbor, or get on a ferry. A clean, easily navigated area on foot.

Fun Place. The Rocks area is fun specially on the weekends when they have the outdoor markets. There are very interesting arts and crafts to purchase. You have to try the corn on the cob that is sold there.
good for a historical walk. walk the walk the convicts walks and history is still present in many places,although this is definitely not the place to eat the prices are tourist priced so go elsewhere
Weekend shopping. Visited this place in city tour bus... Small shops around for cheap shopping... Some nice restaurants and a good place for walk around.... Close to many sight seeing as well!!
A must go see. Certainly a place not to be missed when visiting Sydney. Lovely shops, old buildings just so interesting with a really great vibe.

Happening place. The Rocks is such an interesting place to visit. There are lots of restaurants to choose from. We were spoilt for choice. It was nice to stroll around the place and soak in the atmosphere.
Great place to wander!. The Rocks is a great place to wander and look at the architecture! There are a number of good places to stop for a coffee or something to eat. Best of all it is free!

I Loved The Rocks. The house of the first settlers in Sydney, it preserves much of it's original architecture and has a great history to tell visitors. The Rocks Markets open on weekends is personally my favorite having much art, vintage clothing, great jewerly designers and great food to make up your day and enhance your experience. Also make sure to follow the walk designed to get to know more about Sydney's and Australia's history. It also has great places such as bars and restaurants. A place to remember, a place to walk and a must.
Take time to wander.. You get a feel of how Sydney was in the old days. Nice cafes and the local people are friendly. Shops a little expensive but good for window shopping.

Great place for exploring tourists and locals alike!. I often walk through the Rocks on a lunchtime stroll just to get out from the office. The alleys and laneways are what I enjoy the most rather than the boutique shopping. There are many ways to explore these:1. Take Globe Street off George Street and climb the steps at the end to Harrington Street. Cross the road and climb the steps opposite at #85 and turn right at the top to Susannah Place or continue up the next flight to the Big Dig.2. Susannah Place - continue exploring along here (Cambridge Street) past the Susannah Place Museum (or stop here as well) to Argyle Street, cross the road and climb Argyle Stairs follow the laneway (Gloucester Walk) along past the back of the Glenmore Hotel - great open air bar up the top) to the end which takes you to George Street. Here you are under the Harbour Bridge. Cross the road and continue to explore down to the harbour.These are just a couple of the walks that you can take but as the Rocks is quite a small area you won't likely get very lost so just wander and you'll find some very interesting sights.

The Rocks history and pub walking tour . We booked the Rocks history and pub walking tour with Lucy as our guide. The tour was very informative and presented a lot of Sydney and various personalities down through history. Lucy was very considerate and provided an excellent tour. The Rocks are in stark contrast to the Central Business District. I would recommend the Rocks over the CBD and highly recommend the tour.
Lots to see and walk around. Countless Pubs & Restaurants. Is a must visit if you are in Sydney, get a taste of the old town and history plus some of the best food seems to be located here.

Old world charm. You can't go to Sydney and not experience the Rocks. Great old world architecture under the Harbour Bridge. We had been here before however the markets were in full swing in Sunday which made for a great new take on an area with so many attractions already. We found a small alleyway which lead to lovely pub called Circus. Great hipster bar with craft beers and good food prices. Later found out from the bar tender that the building was an old rum store before money was used for payment. Still has the metal bars on the Windows. Make sure you take the time to venture the streets and alleys of the rocks area. You will not be disappointed.
Love this Part of Sydney. The Rocks is the area around the Park Hyatt Hotel. There are dozens of great shops and restaurants to choose from.

A great spot for pancakes and ghost tours!. I came here with friends for a ghost tour and we loved the area! It's packed with history and stunning architecture, has great cafes (including a lindt cafe), the pancakes are amazing and the ghost tours are fascinating (historical but not scary).

What amazing place take the time to seethe history here. There seems to be always some thing new discovered here every time i pass via the rocks so many nice places to eat out and grate cafes its amazing place

A Great Place To Buy Suvernir's. We visited The Rocks on Saturday Morning. The Saturday Market provided a large variety of unique handy crafts and souvenirs. This place is a must for tourists. Although they are not cheap they provide a great alternative to mass produced souvenirs The markets offer a wide variety of clothes ,handbags and salves .

History, Coffee, Candy and Food. We spent the day at The Rocks during a food market and had a great time. Sampled a few different plates, wandered through some of Sydney's oldest pubs for a couple cold beers, watched candy being made while having a chat to the guy doing it, visited the free Rocks history museum - very well done! - and finished with a strong, sweet coffee. One of the best places in Sydney!
Clean, tidy, beautiful. We stumbled across the rocks whilst finding a nice cafe for breakfast. We were there on a sunday and enjoyed the atmosphere of the local markets and cafes.

cute, lively ares, especially on a Saturday. we were walking around the harbour on a Saturday and came across the Rocks by chance. There was a market with a lot of art and hand-made products, quite nice. There were street food stands and musicians. We didnt realise that it was only a Saturday event. We decided to come back the day after for some food, but the area was quiet and empty. So if you have the chance to visit on a Saturday, do so.

My favourite heritage precincts. It's my sanctuary amidst busy life of Sydney. Along the walk in George street, many Cafes with European feel, which was part of my heritage.The Argyle is very inviting with Ananas as fine dining and every Friday there's The Rocks market. My husband gave me surprise to stay at Harbour Rocks M Gallery hotel for my 40th birthday and we had French pancakes for breakfast next door.Nearby iconic Sydney Opera House and Harbour Bridge, you feel walking down to Victorian era. I'm glad that we have respect to history that shape Sydney today

Lively and vibrant. Our hotel was adjacent to the Rocks so we were very conveniently located for visiting the many shops, restaurants and attractions situated in and around this area. It is very lively and vibrant and particularly compelling at night with restaurant and bars in abundance adding to the atmosphere. It always felt safe strolling whether day or night. Places to visit include the Customs House and the Museum of Contemporary Art. Observatory Park is perfect for relaxing with a picnic lunch with its panoramic views of Sydney Harbour. The Rocks Markets are open at weekends and are filled with jewellery, fashion and food stores among others.

Rocks at the weekend. The Rocks has a better vibe at the weekend. There is a large market selling some unusual gifts that you wouldn't find elsewhere. Ther are stalls selling food network drinks and there are numerous cafes, bars and restaurants to fit everyone's taste. We particularly like The Mercantile Hotel as it is next to the market and if you manage to get a seat you can sit and have a drink and people watch. The food is excellent and I would definitely recommend it. All those people can't be wrong!

On the Rocks or between a rock and a hard place!. Historical, interesting and novel area. Where it all began. Transformed from a quagmire of human depravity into a modern chic area. Worth a visit as it is here were the first convicts settled and you can imagine the mayhem. Of course, us Irish contributed our quota of convicts, mad men and drinkers. Go and learn the history.

Great markets. The weekend markets in The Rocks are one of the best in Sydney. They are always busy and have a great mix of stalls with live music happening throughout.We enjoyed the jewellery and art stalls, but my friend bought the best bright orange dress which became a Christmas party highlight!

Historical area. There is lots of history to find in the Rocks, a guided tour can be useful. Lots of restaurants and pubs of varying quality and value, you can get a good idea by looking at them. Shops are, unfortunately filled with tourist goods as are the stalls in the market. Well worth going but some people may be disappointed.

Historic and beautiful.. The Rocks is very much worth a visit. Some fantastic, very old buildings are in this area. Apparently one of the oldest parts of Sydney, you can take in the beauty of many a fine building. Also if here on a Friday between 9-3 you'll strike a wonderful food market. I recommend the frankfurters by Munich Bar, delicious.

Well Done. This is a very walkable area and they have done a great job preserving the historical flavor of this area. Lots of shops, restaurants and old buildings. There is a free museum that chronicles the development of the Rocks and the movement to preserve the area from high rises.

lots to see and do - especially the weekend market. at every turn there's something different. Lots of unique shops, eateries, and boutiques. It takes hours to see it all - we highly recommend the free walking tour at 6pm - hosted by history students at the university, it was very, very good
A truely amazing area in Sydney!. This area is Sydney known as the Rocks due to it being built literally on rocks is such a historical master piece in the heart of the city!
A wonderful strolling neighborhood.... We went for a Sunday brunch at a lovely little cafe and then walked among the street vendors. Don't miss the weekend market!
Very histroic. Walked around saw lots of older building stopped for coffee and cake then continued on for Pub lunch and a wine great place great feel finished off with Icecream
Nightlife fun. Was raining the day we went here but still enjoyed the vibrant atmosphere and night life. Deed some shopping and enjoyed the views of the harbor.
Good feel!. Lovely little area of Sydney - some old (for them) buildings and a lively market on occasions. Plenty of cafes . Makes for a pleasant walk about and is near to other attractions.

Take a tour, get a better insight - Worth every single penny!. The Rocks tour came as a part our daily package with our tour guys and we were quite intrigued to learn about the history of the rocks and what went into saving this amazing part of Sydney. Our hotel was not far away from it either (Marriott) and there are some nice restaurants and bars along this location. Might get a little uncomfortable if you are averse to second hand smoke!

Dont miss the markets at The Rocks if you are in Sydney. The Rocks at the Quay in Sydney is a great place to spend the day. Lots of speciality shops to browse. Good variety of restaurants and cafes for eating but would suggest you book for lunch if there is a cruise ship in port
Good Walking Experience. Allocate two hours for this walk. Plenty of Cafés to stop and have a coffee or beer. Very near the Harbor and bridge.

The Rocks dreaming tour should be listed!. We booked a rocks dreaming tour on line, it was an historical tour of the aborigines history, led by Margaret, an aboriginal resident, it was priceless. Booked with GoWay Travel not to be missed

Great neighbourhood . We arrived in the Rocks on a 'free' guided tour which finishes nearby and we then wandered round on our own. A busy lively area with lots of quaint sidesteps, coffeshops pubs and restaurants, with live music drifting out from Windows and from buskers. Great place to spend a couple of hours.￼

Absolutely stunning location, great fun!. The Rocks is such a fun, energetic place. The markets are a lot of fun - with food, handmade goods and much more, this is the place to be in Sydney! There are also a stack of fabulous shops dotted along the streets such as Sticky candy, BOMB Cosmetics as well as other places. Definitely check it out!

An old section of the city now overwhelmed by tourism. Once you get off the main drag and look around the back streets, you will get a clearer sense of what the Rocks once were. Now it is shop after shop and restaurant after restaurant.Close your eyes to the commerce and try to imagine what it was more than 100 years ago.

Lovely little market and charming old town. Really enjoyed the history of The Rocks and seeing the old fashioned buildings. There are some lovely little shops and a quirky little market on the weekends. There are some great cafes too with some great tea and scones for a mid morning treat. Would definitely recommend the fresh corn on the cob as well.

Our favorite Sydney neighborhood!. Wonderful area within walking distance of Sydney and Darling Harbors. Quaint feeling with cool buildings and good restaurants. Friday is the foodie market day...well worth a visit.
Love staying in the Rocks area. when I visit Sydney love to stay in the rocks area it's a great atmosphere place, close to both harbours and many other attractions

Utterly Amazing Experience. My wife and I were seeking an intimate boutique hotel with the city at our fingertips - big impersonal hotels are not our thing. Fortunately for us a good friend mentioned The Rocks and after some brief checking we decided it was for us. This hotel and the staff who run it are wonderful and we couldn't have asked for more. Casual yet extremely attentive from check in to the lobby library, cosy bar and superbly serviced restaurant.The minute you enter the street, you're surrounded by history and everything is just a few minutes walk away. We couldn't recommend it more highly.

My Stomping Grounds. I am a Sydney Local, but everything I have a friend from overseas come to visit, I always make sure to take them to the Rocks. Specifically to the Australian Heritage Hotel for some Kangaroo or Emu Pizza. Then you are spoilt for choice on which bar or pub to visit. But why not do a pub crawl?My personal favorite is the Glenmore and its rooftop bar.
Great walking area. This is historical Sydney with some modern elements added. Great spot for the markets at the rocks and a bit of history along the way

The Rocks Weekend Market. This is one not to be missed place to visit in Sydney but go there only during the weekends from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. where you will find stalls set up for you to shop for unique stuffs you won't find elsewhere in Sydney ! Besides there are other shops, places of interests and restaurants in the area for you to visit...

Vibrant historical area of Sydney - my favourite place in Sydney.. WE stayed in a B&B right near the bridge - great hosts, great old building with a courtyard dining area - food great as well. I loved the ability to walk around the old area, visit displays of old memorabilia and still be in close proximity of the city if we wanted to shop.
Very cool!!. Many shops and restaurants. On the weekends they have a market for local food and art. I loved the crepe place and seeing the cruise boats parked at the harbor

weekend attraction. the rock market very near the Sydney Harbour ,is a place to be during weekend,you have the street shops with lots of food n designer wear ranging from clothes to jewellery,this is a place where, you can show case your product,thus you have individual designers who peddle their wares,the items on sale are pricey
Sydney Rocks. This place is arguably the heart of Sydney, well worth a look around some nice old buildings and some great places to eat and drink, Lord Nelson my favourite.

A great stroll in the sunshine. We followed the route suggested in one of the many tour maps, starting at Circular Quay Station. An easy walk without any hills or slopes. There are bars a plenty on the route to stop and quence your thirst. At the end of the suggested route was an ice cream van in exactly the right spot. We continued on akong the road towards Darling Harbour and all its bars. We took our time...and took loads of photos, stopped three times on route for coffee, rest your feet break and ice cream, and it took about an hour to arrive at DH. There or course you have lots of choices for lunch. Not a walk in the heat of the day as there is not a lot of shade.

A very cool area with lots of restaurants . Staying downtown, it's a must see place with cool shops and lots of places to eat and drink, many being good and some very horrible such as the Löwenbrau Brew house, which was a rip off with terrible food and service. Other than that, it has great spots for breakfast and cool pubs for beer. We had a wonderful dinner one night too, see my restaurant reviews.Definitely cool part of town, check it out.
Easy walk.. Easy to walk around here. Some great stalls. Get here early for lunch, one was doing an absolutely roaring trade for a good 2 hours.

Downtown Sydney happening place. This is the place to go in Sydney especially on the weekend. Great restaurants and lots of outside stalls. Plus street entertainment and a few historic sites to visit. This is walking territory and the essence of Australia.

go to the market. Oldest section of Sydney that houses geat shopsk the contemplrary art museum and a great Market. Have breakfast or lunch at one of the many outdoor daves and roam the very narrow original greets of Sydney.

Need to spend some time exploring. The rocks is a great part of Sydney. It is a short walk from circular quay and has some gems of places to stop for a drink or something to eat. There is even a couple of shops to explore if you are that way inclined.

Good, interesting weekend walk through the oldest part of Sydney CBD. Most visitors don't realise that The Rocks area of Sydney is just a long block away from Circular Quay. Walk from the Opera House along the harbour walk to Circular Quay and keep walking along the harbour walk to the Overseas Passenger Terminal (so busy during February cruise ship month) and up one block to George St. You're now in the heart of The Rocks, with its historic First and Second Fleet sandstone buildings, all filled with shops and restaurants nowadays. Further along George St, almost under the foot of the Sydney Harbour Bridge, you'll find the weekend craft markets, always worth a looksee at handmade local souvenirs, tea, breakfast spreads, tea towels, hand bags. Wander around the The Rocks streets - you won't get lost because the area is well signposted.Plenty of cafe and bistro style eateries to choose from, including pubs.If you have time, and the weather is good, continue your walk from the markets under the Bridge and over to Barangaroo Park.

Plenty on offer . There's plenty to see around the Rocks area and is a must see for visitors to Sydney. If you're interested in the history of Australia then you'll find this area of great importance. Probably a good idea to arrange an organised tour to understand it all, but a self walking tour is also possible.

Walk it and savour. Our visit coincided with the week-end market which brings out the best of what is available. The stalls were eclectic and had some really good craft stuff for sale. Aside from the market there are some interesting streets and alleyways to explore and plenty of places to have a beer or a bite.
Where is the rock???. A tad disappointing. No rocks to see. A little dead area. Was told that there are night flea market on the weekends though.

Great area in Sydeny!. The Rocks section of Sydeny is the oldest area. It's very nice and has a different vibe from the rest of the city. Enjoy a stroll and check out the nice restaurants, Sydeny's oldest pub ( Fortune of War) and the gift shops along the way. Great views of the Opera House and the bridge.

New year 2015/16 To see the Harbour Bridge Firework Display.. Had a great time in Sydney,Did the City Tour on the hop on hop off bus,stopped off at the Rocks to see the Market,loads of varios stalls selling everything allthough a bit on the expensive side,Plenty of eating places and a good Irish Pub serving food.Its a must area to see and only a short walk round to the harbour and a veiw of the Harbour and Bridge.

Weekend fair. By chance, we were here on the weekend, and the street craft fair is worth visiting. Check out the small alleys like Nurses Way, AND eat dinner at Philips Foote....pick out your meat and cook it yourself on their 'barby'. Sit in the vine covered garden.

Walking Through History. It's a sign of progress that the oldest part of Sydney was partially razed long ago to make way for the iconic bridge. We walked the lanes and admired what old buildings were still standing. It's not a big section of town, so won't take long. Just hope you're not there when a cruise ship disgorges its load.
The place to be. Full of quality restaurants and shops. Choice is abundant, something for everyone. Walkinh distance to thr cruise pier and Circular Quay
The most historical place in Sydney!. The rocks is one of the most historical places in Sydney! All the buildings have their own story to tell and look just fantastic!
Fascinating. Fascinating and quirky area just above the harbour.Lots of little alleyways to explore.As everywhere in Sydney lots of cafes & barsVery good street market with a great atmosphere

When in Sydney, consider the Rocks for "the" place to go. This was my third visit to the Rocks and I find it to be my favorite area to explore in Sydney. In the Rocks, you will find history, nature, culture, great food & beverage, and fun shopping.

Saturday Street Market Fabulous. We walked to the bridge and found ourselves enjoying the Saturday Street market with wonderful vendors. Most took credit card. Lots of local art/craft/handmade items. We spent about 2 hours looking at the various vendors and bought several items that we never saw anywhere else on our trip.
An amazing place to spend a weekend... sipping coffee, listening to the street singers, visiting the sunday market selling handicraft and beautiful gown and dresses.....so nice ! Love it..
Do an I'm Free Tour. This tour runs daily at 6 p.m. and is quite comprehensive of the area. We enjoyed learning about not only the history but also what is happening with the real estate in the area.

An amazing little place. The Rock's has always been part of my life, from the days of drinking its it's pubs on a Friday ans Saturday night to now days dinning in its restaurants. IT has a lot going for it crowded noisy bars, interesting restaurants, quiet streets to wander during the day. I recommend visiting the back streets, get away from the touristy main drags. It is an amazingly interesting place. Interesting architecture, history people. One place I recommend is the Garrison Church, beautiful worth the visit.
Great shopping and eats. Cute neighborhood adjacent to the harbor with a number of small restaurants and shops along with a small street fair the day that I visited

A very particular place to go.. The rocks can offer you different experience depends on what you want to see or do.Since the best brands shop to the markets. Old fashioned side of the city can offer you pubs, nightlife or small restaurants for you enjoy!

Museums, Pubs and Markets. Best visited on a sunny day, The Rocks in Sydney is as close as you will get to an "historic" town center anywhere in Australia. Located next to the transport hub of Circular Quay and with gorgeous views of Sydney Harbour, it is a fantastic place for a wander, a meal, shopping or a couple of drinks at the oldest pubs in Australia (there are at least a dozen here).From the shady lawns of First Fleet Park, beside Circular Quay, where there is always music and street theatre, the Rocks is mostly uphill. We like to head to the top of the hill, while we are still fresh, and work our way down. There are lots of ways up the hill, but we like to walk to the Fortune of War hotel - the oldest in Sydney - (for an optional beverage) then through the "Nurse's Walk". Alternatively, walk through Playfair Street (everyone loves cobblestones). Stick to the little alleys and old sandstone stairs for a look at the oldest parts of Sydney. There are so many things to do and see. The Observatory right at the top of the hill has amazing views and is good for a tour (best at night), Suzannah Place Museum on the Cumberland Steps is a little-known museum with a really interesting look at how Sydney-siders have lived over the last hundred years or so. You can cross under the Harbour Bridge at the Argyle Cut (which convicts cut by hand) and wander through the wonderful old residential part of the Rocks on the Western side of the bridge. The Lord Nelson is a beautiful sandstone brewery/pub for a break (and also pretty much the top of the hill). From here it's all down hill. Head down Lower Fort St to the Harbour View Hotel and turn right, back into the heart of the alleys, shops and restaurants of the Rocks or continue to the bottom of the street and cross back under the Bridge and walk around the harbour-front park. From the Harbour View, you can also walk directly beneath the bridge toward the harbour and see the newly-excavated original fortifications and gun batteries. Back on the Circular Quay side, visit Cadmans Cottage, one of the original buildings in the Sydney settlement.Other things to do include the awesome Sydney Harbour Bridge climb (expensive), a cheaper option is walking across the Bridge on the footpath and climb the south Pylon (go up the bridge stairs on Cumberland Street near Gloucester Street). The Sydney Theatre Company is on Pier 4/5, the Museum of Contemporary Art is also an interesting (and argument-provoking) place to visit.On weekends there are big markets on George Street.

Spent a lovely Sunday morning at the Rocks. We first visited the Rocks on a lovely Sunday morning so we had the added plus of having the weekend market in full swing. There are always interesting shops and cafes in the buildings though we found the cafes to be VERY expensive. On the weekends the streets are filled with stalls selling interesting crafts, food and clothing. A nice historic area.

Old Sydney - Shopping and Pubs!. The Rocks is a great place to mill about, to shop, to grab a pint. Hobnob and socialize at a variety of great pubs and restaurants. Small boutique, one of a kind shops for anything from hats to custom clothes; upscale shopping for high-end labels too! Welcome or say good bye to the cruise ships coming in and out of Circular Quay. The outdoor market of crafts and clothes on the weekend is a blast too! In Sydney? Gotta stop by the Rocks!
So much to see and do!. The Rocks is simply beautiful, shops, cafes, markets, tours and amazing history to see here! The Rocks must be on anyone's Sydney to do list.

Totally worth it. Visiting the Rocks is an experience not to be missed. The history,the daily lives of survival,is only the beginning.You have the old road and paths made of cobblestone,old buildings,such a eye opener. The Irish pubs with Irish music filling the street, just makes younwant to do an Irish jig there and then.This venue is a must for any travelers, weekend markets can be found with the best day to visit is a Sunday. If you find the markets you will find the Mercantile Hotel, an Irish pub not to walk past without calling in.It has great food, nice cold Guiness on tap with excellent foot tapping Irish music.

A must for all visitors and Sydneysiders as well.. The Rocks has many good restaurants and is close to the harbour and it's many attractions. On Friday, Saturday and Sunday the exciting Rock's Markets operate from 10 am. with many items to tempt one. Spend the day at the Rocks -- maybe going to the movies at the Dendy, a trip to Manly on the ferry operating from the terminal or catch a ferry to the fish markets. The Rocks is a hub for many activities around the Sydney Harbour basin. See the original old buildings -- Argyle Arts Centre - the first hospital in Sydney - the Museum of Contemporary Art - the Police Station and the old hotels.

Rocks pub crawl . There is no where better on a nice Sydney sat arvo than wandering around the rocks eating and drinking
The secret though is to head to the back streets and find the old pubs like the hero of waterloo and the palisade etc
If you go to the palisafe make sure you head to the roof bar

Spend some time exploring. The Rocks is a great spot to meander around. Little laneways and old storage facilities turned into retail stores. If you can, make the time to spend at least half a day and follow the random signs to explore some of Sydney's earliest white history. Go up the random sandstone stairways and really get in behind the scenes. We ran into street food markets on a Friday which looked fabulous.

Alot of history. We like the Rocks because of the historical importance it has. Susannah place is a historic home to do a tour and there is a dig site opposite is well sign posted with information about how the Rocks looked and what was once there over a 100 years ago. If you like expensive cafes than this is the place for you.
rocks area. really interesting lots of history but a bit hilly in parts and you need a map so you don't get lost many interesting shops
lovely stalls. Great stalls to go and get a home made bargain. Nice walk to the harbour area and the opera house. Good views of the bridge!

Great place...loads of history.. Our hotel was on the rocks area so we had a walk about. Loads of history and really interesting. However used to be the slums many years ago......now its lively with lots of bars and eateries. We love it here.

Great place for a long walk - don't miss the market!. It is a nice place to just shop a bit and go for a long walk around the coastline . Make sure to go to the market - fantastic place to find souvenirs and local products. Lots of places for lunch dinner etc

Fun place on Sydney's harbour. The Rocks is a lively area, of attractions, shops, restaurants, and bars, overlooking the Sydney Harbour. It is an easy walk to Circular Quay, right next to it on the harbour.

Great Place to Shop & People Watch. We spent time walking through the market they have in the Rocks on the weekends. It was a great way to spend an afternoon. The shops were fun to wonder into and out of, and there's a little bit of everything there. We were there during the day to shop, have lunch, and enjoy a glass of wine, and again during two evenings for dinner. Great area!

History visited. Walking the Rocks area in Sydney is truely a great day/evening. Just to walk around, visit a pub, have a meal, enjoy the markets lets you enjoy one of our great tourist spots.Highly recommend it for an afternoon into the evening adventure especially for adults who enjoy a bit of history .
History comes alive. Great place to just walk around and enjoy the history a great area to just enjoy close to the harbour and easy walk to the CBD so go have fun

It gets slower and more comfortable on a Sunday afternoon. I love going to the Rocks, but Sunday afternoon the place slows down to a comfortable pace of stroll and enjoy. The markets are slowing down ready to abandon their ports and the evening starts to open. The galleries are easily navigated and the ice cream and coffee are slowing down to an added extra taste of care and ease. The early dinners are starting to role out as the many visitors and cultures blend seamlessly to take in the history and uniqueness of the area with a glass of white and a light meal.

The Rocks - Great place to visit and shop - don't miss the Markets. Having visited Sydney many times, last year I was able to share the experience with my wife for the first time. We spent some time around the shops and markets collecting items we will value for a long time and remind us of this great place.
Good walk around. A nice Sydney district to walk around with many small alleys (e.g. the 'Nurse's Walk'). Too bad many shops and eateries do not open until 11 am, even though many stay open late ...
Must see. A lot of history, especially if you take a walking tour. Take time to browse and explore; it is well worth it.

A little down at heel. It's been 16 years since my last visit to Sydney and 30 since my first. I remember the Rocks with fondness but over the years many stores are empty and it's looking run down in places. The museum is worth a visit and there are some fun restaurants still.

You must go here!. Lovely to walk around the old part of Sydney, experience the great food, markets, shops and cafes. Always a quick walk down to Circular Quay and down to the CBD. Great view of the Harbour and be sure to walk around to the Park Hyatt.
Awesome concept. A great place to strool anytime of the day! Great small shops and botices! Very relaxing lots of nice restaurants

Great Historic site. This is the historic landing place of the original prisoners with the streets they built. There are explanations of the history in plaques throughout the area. This is a thriving area with many great restaurants and hotel/pubs.
THE area to be based for sightseeing. We stayed at Holiday Inn for 4 nights in The Rocks area. Brilliant views of Bridge, Opera, Circular Quay ferries and loads bars/restaurants within yards.
Quaint part of Sydney. Lots of shops and restaurants in a quaint setting. Easily walkable from downtown but much more peaceful. This is a must see area.

Love it on market days. I know it is very turistic , but this advice of mine is for turists and so I hardly suggest a visit at the Rocks mostly on Saturdays when the market is on and make sure you take your time to browse around from one stall to the other ....Everyone is nice and friendly ,happy to show what they have made or what they sell.Lots of small gifts " really Aussie" that you can take home .If you love art there are a few galleries and some nice and quite expensive shios around ,but you can always get tax refund if you are a foreigner so do not forget your passport ! The buildings have a bit of history and are very interesting ,the highlight is always the view of the harbour from there ! Enjoy !
Great Vibe. Great place to wander around and enjoy the sights. Plenty of little shops and decent coffee or beer freely available!

Retail Galore !!!!. You can spend a day here. Full of retail and restaurants. The town fathers have put a lot of thought into the development. In a few hours here, you can find everything you could be looking for. This is really close to the wonderful transportation network !!!!
A great place to visit. This is a great area of Sydney to visit, nice views of the bridge and opera house. Lots of old buildings and history. Especially good on Saturday and Sunday market days.

Iconic Sydney. Located right next to the cruise terminal and ferry docks, The Rocks are part tourist center and historic location. It is full of eating spots and shops, and there is a street food market on Fridays, and and a street market on weekends. Many people start their Sydney experience here.
A must see in Sydney!!. My favorite area of Sydney! Shops and markets were great! Wonderful views of the Harbor Bridge and Opera House. Great history and story!

Interesting, but limited cafes away from the centre. Loved some of the backstreets and the big dig. Unfortunately in a 3 hour walk there were no open cafes anywhere away from the central tourist trap. This area lacks any genuine ambiance

Wow!. We came through here on our tour and the tour guide recommended this as one of those places which we should explore in depth by our selves! so we did, it is a simply amazing area. All the buildings have their own piece of history and are all so unique!
Great Market. The rocks market is the place to go on a Saturday or Sunday if you enjoy just browsing with the occasional purchase or just people watching
Great way to spend your time . On a Saturday after the bridge climb, we crossed the road and went down the steps to the Rocks area. It was nice to wander around the shops and market.
Great Location. The Rocks area is very nice part of Sydney. The old builds are great to photograph at day or night. Lots of restaurants, pubs and shops make up most of the tenants.

Historic area. The Rocks, so named because of the huge rocky outcrop on which the original settlement was built, is one of the most historic areas of Sydney. Wander round and look past the modern shops and changes and you can catch a glimpse of the early settlement of Sydney. Old buildings have been reused for modern purposes, but you can still see signs on the buildings which indicate that this was a thriving port and catered for many needs - the Mission to Seamen, the Seamens' Institute, tiny shops, huge warehouses....and all of it now a thriving area of cafes, restaurant and shops. Well worth a stroll around to look and absorb, and then to eat.
Where the action is!. Great bars and restaurants. Buskers and street entertainment. However premium prices are charged for the location!

Wonderful piece of history in the city. Great place to spend an afternoon. Usually something going on. Easy access to transport using busses and ferries. However, avoid the more touristy cafes- they charge a fortune for very mediocre food.

A Rockin' Place. Skyline, food, people, sidewalks, brick lined streets, shops and more. Take it all in.This area is really unique and well worth finding. We enjoyed the energy, history and now the newness of this area. Highly encourage you to find this little gem in Sydney.

Cute market on Sundays. The area is very picturesque - bring a camera! We were visiting from Melbourne and found that this was one of the most lovely places in Sydney to grab a coffee and enjoy the scenery. I believe on Sundays they also have a food and crafts market.
Charming historic precinct. The Rocks is a charming historic precinct full of shops, cafes, bars and restaurantes. It is a nice place to go for a walk, and get lost in the little alleys.
The best area is Sydney. The rocks are in my opinion the best area of Sydney! The buildings tell us so much about the history of Sydney and they are simply beautiful!

Great Historical Area for touristsshopping and eating. The Rocks is a great area, easy to get to by many means of transport. It has many shops, markets, eating and drinking places and is of interest historically. A great area for tourists (and some locals). Don't miss out on the Rocks, you won't be dissapointed.
The Best. There is a lot to do at the Rocks, Restaurants, Bars, Pubs, places to see. Just a great vibe there, short walk to the Bridge.

Lots to see. The Rocks is a host to alot of historic buildings and interesting things to see. If you like to see and learn things about the beginnings of Sydney & Australia this is a great place to go!
Loved it. I just loved this area of Sydney. Especially the museum of contemporary art. The green spaces were wonderful also. Great atmosphere.

Always worth a visit. This area is worth visiting just to see what olsd Sydney was like.
The area has plenty of great spots to eat
Always something going on here. Experience Australian history, beautiful old buildings and Pubs. Explore the back alleyways, there is always something new or different to find.

Great area. We did a free walking tour of The Rocks with Sydney Greeters. Greeters are part of the Global Greeter network worldwide. A truly wonderful service with locals showing visitors a part of their city. Our guide Peter was full of information about the area and a very nice gentleman.
Weekend Stroll at The Rock. There is a weekend market on Saturday/Sunday. Many cute things on display. Nice to stroll around. We can walk to Circular Quay thru ferry terminal.

The Argyle at the Rocks. Walking into the 220 year old cooled courtyard through the carriageway was a unique experience. Being part of the function for 350 people drinking and being provided with quality nibbles and canapés was a real treat. Service was surprisingly good considering the courtyard was packed. The event truly glittered and the vibe seamed to cover the entire Rocks with a golden hue.

The Rocks........where a new nation was born. Although the colony of New South Wales had its origin in Botany Bay, The Rocks is/was the true heart of the new colony that grew to be a new nation.History abounds in this area and visitors can take it in via several walking tours or just amble about and discover it as it unfolds, it can a little hilly in some areas, so comfortable shoes would be a recommendation for those using Shanks' Pony.There are many fine examples of old buildings and pubs for those who enjoy olden architecture and historical buildings.Definitely a happening place, with many eateries and venues to enjoy some music and a bit of craic.There is a market on the weekends and it is a colourful area to soak in some of the local culture.

Vibrant . What a great place to visit we thought it was good daytime but it really comes alive in the evening great for walking people watching eating and having a drink. Great views of the night scenery of the harbour. Pricey for dinner! Well worth a visit or two or three.

Great market and taste the variety of food. I like the market, visiting the different places, the food,we had lunch at the renaissance a french cafe which had freshly made baguette and different home made cakes . Really delicious. Even at the market there are foods and other products which are great. There is also a free tour of the old Sydney town which is very interesting.

Scenic Birthplace of Sydney. This is where the first ships landed to settle Sydney. It is easy to see why -- located on Sydney Cove, a sheltered harbor. Today it is a scenic neighborhood located just south of the Harbor Bridge and adjacent to the cruise ship port. So it is a great area to wander around and visit the shops and restaurants.

Free tours at 6pm every day. Excellent tour at 6pm outside Cadmans Cottage by students wearing bright green shirts. No charge just tips at the end if you want. Very informative, pretty extensive round the rocks area on both sides of the bridge. Definitely recommended. They do day time tours too of the city at 10.30 and 2.30 every day. I think they meet outside the town hall but check on their website.

Interesting historic environment for a leisurely stroll. We took a walk thru The Rocks to soak up the historic atmosphere, lovely old buildings and views to Sydney Harbour. Best time to visit is the weekend as the markets are operating. There's some good quality craft and edibles for sale, something for everyone and goods for a range of budgets. Great place for overseas tourists to buy handmade unique gifts. Highly recommend the $5 hot corn on a cob and drink deal, or $4 gelati from market stallholders.

Vibrant!. We visited the rocks on Australia Day which was amazing. So vibrant and so much to see and do. The markets featuring food to jewellery paintings shoes clothes etc etc was wonderful. So many pubs and restaurants to chose from and live music everywhere. Loved it!
Worth the visit. If you like to be in a slice of history, then here's the place to be ... and if you can make it on market day, you'll be in for a treat (especially of arts and crafts).

Great historical place!. A fantastic place to visit and spend a few hours exploring the most historical place in Sydney! All the buildings in the rocks are colonial era and each have their own story to tell!
Had tea and scones and visited the markets. A beautiful Sunday when there was a ship in the harbour, we went to the rocks for tea and scones. Afterwards we walked around the lovely markets

Went to the Sunday morning markets. My wife and I met friends and wandered the markets. Not a cheap hippy market either, this is much more upmarket. However everyone was lovely. Really nice atmosphere and friendly stall holders. Recommended.

A must visit to Sydney, one of the oldest places in town. The Rocks has very historical history and buldings, being one of the oldest in the area.. Its a must see for visitors plus it also have lots of good restaurants, bars and very old pubs to visit

Architecture at the Rocks. We stayed at the Marriot at Circular Quay (pronounced Key) and were able to walk to The Rocks easily. It is just a hop, skip and jump from Sydney's Opera House. The architecture is amazing. The restaurants are sumptuous.

Open Markets on the Weekend. The Rocks is a great area to stroll around. The open markets are there on the weekend, there are many shops and an I-Site Center located in a shopping mall. It is a very quaint area to enjoy.

quite a site. Of course lots of restaurants, little boutiques, (where I got another UGG) to maintain the nickname "centopeia" ... but back to the Rocks, great to find itens made locally, Food it is not a big of the deal, once the Rocks has many options do any taste. We had diner at the Caminetto (See review) an Italian restaurante with live music, the evening is very lively in all restaurants/bars.
Nice place to spend an afternoon. I was met by friends from Sydney, who showed us around the area and treated us to a great lunch. Great for roaming around and sampling some local beers or cuisine.

Great place to spend a few hours. Our Qantas flight arrived in Sydney at dawn and we could not board our cruise ship until after 11 am. The shuttle bus dropped us off at the customs house and our luggage was taken care of, but we had several hours to kill. Fortunately, we were at The Rocks and it was a warm, sunny day. We wandered around taking pictures and found a street market just getting ready to open. I found a perfect souvenir and made my first purchase of the trip. We walked up around the Sydney Harbor Bridge and then down by the docks. There are many restaurants in the area, all but a few closed at this early hour. We did settle in for drinks at Graze (next to the Museum of Contemporary Art) and enjoyed watching the ferry boats rushing in and out of the harbor.
Picturest and quaint . Lots of alleys with bars and cafes and designer shops lot of buildings dating back in time including Sydney's oldest pub fortune of war built in 1828

Great place to start your visit to Sydney. There are loads of restaurants around the Rocks so whatever time of day you're there you can find somewhere to eat, even if you're just after a coffee. There are also shops, interesting historic buildings and quaint alleyways to explore. Well worth a visit.

Find that little lane walk. There is a little lane within The Rocks connecting the weekend market to Cumberland Street. It is quite an amazing doscovery for those who likes to wonder around CBD. Have fun!
Had a ball. Discovered a lot of history of our country and the first settlers during a few morning walks through the little streets and laneways at the Rocks.

Steeped in history The Rocks. Just along the warf from the Opera House, an easy stroll past cruise ships and then into great Saturday markets, steeped in history with lots of plaques to read along your way, cobbled streets, old stone and brick buildings. Plenty of little shops too. Then when you need a meal or drink out of the baking sun there is anything from Italian to German , pub to restaurant to food truck to keep you fed and watered!

Inevitable visit by any tourist. The first buildings appeared in 1788 and they were made out of local sandstone. This material gave the name to the region, which had a very bad reputation until 1870 due to the gangs, the prostitutes and the visiting sailors. Early in the 20th c. the old buildings were ready to collapse and the Government inspected 3.800 buildings and started demolishing some of them but WWI stopped this action.In 1920 more buildings were demolished for the construction of the Sydney Harbour Bridge. Then in 1968 the Government decided to demolish all the old buildings of the area and create a new development. The locals resisted the decision. Finally in 1975 the buildings were renovated and the area turned to a tourist attraction. But the problem with the poverty of this part of Sydney still exists together with some street crimes.Between Circular Quay and Sydney Harbour Bridge, it's an inevitable visit by any tourist especially those who want to walk on the Harbour Bridge. A lot of old pubs, even the Sydney's oldest - Fortune of War (1828), many craft and souvenir shops, food and cloth markets, exhibition galleries, etc. fill the streets of The Rocks. Even the Museum of Contemporary Art is situated here. Entry is free.The colourful markets of the Rocks are open all the year round on Saturdays and Sundays from 10.00' to 17.00'.
Very cute, quaint houses. Travelled through in our trip, very cute houses and community feel, shame they want to knock them down! Nice bit of history attached to this area and be a shame to loose it!

Rock into History. Want to see how life was led last century? Take a walk to The Rocks to see cobbled streets, gorgeous terraces and don't forget to see the wonderful markets. The place has pubs and restaurants as well as marvellous Sydney sandstone buildings. It's seriously a must-see if you're in Sydney.

Fascinating history. Great area to wander around. Lots of history with plaques everywhere giving info on the first settlers, the hospitals etc really worth a visit to this area. Also plenty of little cafes and pubs.

Shopping, dining, perfect views. . My Aussie guide told me her fav places in Sydney and the Rocks were near the top. After going I can see why. We started at the tourist center and got a few recommendations for shopping and a snack. Walking around we found nooks that had unique offerings that were handcrafted by artisans and also aboriginal artists. There was so much that I liked which is not typical for me. Resisting the call of a didgereedoo, I knew my wife would ask what in the world I planned on doing with it and I also knew my interest would fade quickly due to a lack of skill. The Rocks has interesting watering holes that wound in and out and around the many different buildings. Great atmosphere, history, and unforgettable views of the Harbour. Enjoy and don't forget the camera. J
charming neighborhood. Plenty of good restaurants and pubs in this small section just behind Circular Quay. Really nice market as well for souvenirs and clothes.

Very trendy area.. Good shops and restaurants to visit. Also great markets at the weekend. Fantastic location to see so much, but can be expensive to eat around this area, however, we did and the food was well worth it.

Good Shopping. This shopping area is over rated for N Americans.If you have the needs to shop rather than spend time in the magnificent harbor staring at the bridge and opera house, than this is your place.Adequate but nothing special

Great spot for an evening stroll. Did the real tourist bit tonight. Started at the Hero of Waterloo and walked along the waterfront to the opera house. Checked out the locals fishing, the rich dining and living in lush apartments then hit maccas before walking up to Martin Place.

Oldest part of Sydney with a charm.. This is the oldes part of Sydney with a lot of narrow streets The area is very nice and reminds in some ways of towns in Europe. To find an good restaurant can be quite hard as they are often located in hidden backyards.But look around and look at trip advisor and you'll find what you're looking for.
Nice area to visit. It was a nice area leading from Sydney Harbour, past the contemporary museum, and off to food and shops. Easy access by walking or driving.
The Rock Markets. One of the best street markets which mixes old school charm and modern culture in a way that cannot be described.Definitley worth going over on a weekend.
Best open market in all the world. They have the cutest market on the weekends where lots of local artists sell their stuff. so totally worth a visit!
Perfect for a date night. The Rocks has many restaurant, live bands, pubs and coffee shops to choose from... even souvenir stores... i definitely recommend this area when in the Harbor.
Great place to visit in Sydney . Put this on your to do list if visiting Sydney. Full of wonderful shops and restaurants and a great little market on the weekends.

History and shopping combined . Very historic area. Buildings from the mid to late 1800s. Most well restorted. Good job of refitting new shops into the historic buildings. Good art galleries and plenty of places for clothes. Lots of restaurants and drinking places. Easy to walk around. Well worth an a couple of hours or so.

Markets are the best way to spend part of your day. Up and down the hilly streets of The Rocks, vendors set up to sell their wares. Most items are made locally but examine to be sure. The vendors are helpful and friendly; you will find items at all price points. Many food stalls too. Local established businesses in the area, including many restaurants and pubs are worth a look.

Probably one of the most important to see!. This area is wonderful and full of character and rich in history. I highly recommend this as one of the most important areas to see. It has great shops and food, views and interesting architecture. Near circular quay. Stop at the Australian hotel for some wedges! They're amazing!

Small stalls with interesting produce. We purchased some silver leaves, billabong, beautiful cards from a local artist, handmade pins and spoke to several other stall holders. Most were very friendly indeed. It is a pleasure to wander about here
Cool. Another area worth having a glance over in Sydney. Close to the bridge, one will love to still around here and see the harbour in there landscape.
Stroll on "The Rocks". Lovely shops to browse in and purchase items. Visited Lord Nelson Pub. A must do! The walk around the area was very scenic. A must do outing during your visit to Sydney.

Historic Australia. I thought this was cool as it's the historic side of Sydney. My boyfriend is into history so it was cool to see the early Sydney.
We had a friend give a small tour of Sydney, so she thought this would be great for us to see as it's our first time being here and didn't know much about it.
Historic area of Sydney, worth a look. Lots of Sydney history sits right here in The Rocks - view old architecture and take time to relax in the various cafes and restaurants.

Right down at the center of Sydney. The original spot for Sydney, it is still at the center of things along the harbour. Very popular with tourists, plenty of small restaurants and hotels. Convenient to Circular Quay ferries, buses, and trains.

Great for bars and restaurants. A great place to be either day or night.
Lots of bars and restaurants around the area and very near to the harbour to walk too,

Interesting place to wonder around. The first place that was settled in Sydney by the British, interesting and historical.
