Most of the area is now preserved and there are a couple of very early buildings, the area is full of craft shops and cafes but can be quite busy. Theres a really good tourist information centre based there as well.

Not so magical. Time was when I would visit The Rocks at least every six months if only to wander around and enjoy the atmosphere of the place but over the last five years this place just seems to have lost its gloss. I'm not sure why, sure it's quite commercialised now but it has been for quite some time; but over the last few years that small town feel in the middle of the city has been stamped out entirely and I can't even put my finger on as to why. I just know my little meandering visits are now no more, it's just not worth the effort

Nice area but touristy. Lots of shops and stalls when the cruise ships are in. It certainly caters to the tourists. Nice in its own way. The general area has a lot to see, and you get up under the Harbor Bridge which is cool.The street food smelled really great, but we were not ready to eat lunch when we walked by. The street vendors had a lot of variety and we appreciated the artists booths along the way. Some of the work makes for a good remembrance of Sydney.Overall, a nice area to spend an hour or so.
History, history, histoey around every corner and laneway.. Highly recommend booking a walking tour to learn about the story of the Rocks and access some places and sights off the beaten track.

Real Sydney. The Rocks is the best place to see how the first settlers felt like when they arrived. The buildings are old and they invite to stroll along the little lanes. And there are plenty of shops or eateries for a small rest. Great place to hang out

Important history but also enjoyable. The Rocks are a great area to visit while in Sydney. They have some of the oldest buildings in the city there as well as great historical information and artwork. We spent half a day walking around the Rocks area, taking in all there was to see. There are several quaint shops and restaurants in the area. Definitely worth spending some time walking around.
A wee bit of history. A quite interesting place with a large number of buildings dating back over hundred years. It also a happening place with a vibrant night life.

The more you know.... When us Aussies tell you this is the oldest part of Sydney, we should really manage your expectations. This ain't Europe. It ain't impressive. Without a little knowledge and a lot of curiosity this is a tourist trap. A stain on colonial Australia and the most saliant smear against Koori Australia.Join a free tour, rememver the first free nen, have a rooftop beer, think of the rum rebellion, workout on Observatory Hill, imagine a 60000 year old shell midden, visit the MCA, lament the lost culture, go down every little back street, be reminder of the garroters, smile at the out of place ness of the Asian weddings on white horses while remembering the out of place ness of all the white people on this land, and avoid the rubbish souvenier stores, for your own sake... this is a great little area if you can put it in context, especially if you can imagine pre-Toaster, and if you can do that, phwoar.

Best part of Sydney . My personal favorite area of Sydney. Has all the shops and great food along with quaint buildings to make this an easy place to spend a lot of time wandering. I think it has the best views in town.
Fun!. We happened to be here for Australia Day and the Rocks had a lot of activities and live music for the festival. Overall you could tell it is a good spot for restaurants and shopping.

Beautiful Place - A must in Sydney. This is a beautiful part of Sydney. The spectacular views, the pop up stalls, the entertainment as you walk through. There is always something fun to see or do. A lot of restaurants, ice cream shops, cafes etc along the way to stop at. Highly recommended.

Probably unfair but our evening experience. It was our first visit to Sydney and we arrived late on a Sunday afternoon. After checking into our hotel we walked down to the Rocks area for something to eat. We were in a strange city and tired so possibly got the wrong impression. It was very busy mainly with young people, back packers, with lots of discarded beer cans, etc Perhaps there had been some event. I don't know but we made our way down to the harbour and to Circular Quay that though buzzing was far more our scene.
Lovely place to wander . Spent a couple of hours wandering around, several nice bars and restaurants to choose from, and really good atmosphere in the evening.

Love this place, you should not missed it The Rocks. I love this place even I am a local , you should not missed it, is the Rocks area, lots of restaurant, and markets on weekend and Friday night... very relaxing by just walking about with friends and families. if you are from overseas to Sydney, you need to go there and feel for it...
Beer and fun. When in Sydney visit the rocks, not only the rocks but the German beer house Lowenbrau, always fun always god food, we love it

An historic area that offers many delights.... There was much to be seen & enjoyed during the time we spent exploring this popular destination... We found much of interest in this historic precinct including the buildings & museums... The weekend market was a good place to find some lovely & unusual gifts to take home... The Friday night 'Foodie' market offered many tasty treats...Fortunately, we were wearing good flat-soled walking shoes as there were many cobblestoned streets to navigate...

Street Markets. What an amazing colourful place. I wish I had more time to browse the wonderful stalls. Some beautiful craft, jewellery, novelties, eats and anything else one could hope to see. The only negative is that the stalls get so crowded, it is often hard to get near the front to purchase.
Exploring historic Sydney.. The Rocks is a great place to walk randomly and discover little pockets and places. The old buildings and alleyways are lovely. They have great markets on weekends too.

Art & good food. Visited the Museum of Contemporary Art cafe located in The Rocks on Australia Day. Needed to relax in the cool breeze after a very hot day on a cruise on Sydney Harbour. The Rocks is full of cafes and little streets and lanes one can explore but on this occasion, I choose to take my friends to the MCA for a snack and drink. The view of the Sydney Harbour Bridge and Opera House from the balcony in this cafe is spectacular. Where else in the world can you get a million dollar view like this for the price of a cup of coffee? I recommend all travellers visit The Rocks and all it has to offer.

A Great Place to Stay. This area has everything. Great restaurants, shoppiing, and a very short walk to the Quay (where you get the Harbor cruise ), the Sydney Opera House, the Botanical Gardens and the Harbor Bridge. We stayed at the Four Seasons and loved the hotel and the location. Could not have picked a better area to stay. Fortunate that we arrived on Australia Day and the place was hopping with rock bands, street vendors, and fireworks. Learned that it is not necessary to tip waiters unless you received exceptional service in a restaurant, as waiters are well paid, as opposed to in the US where waiters rely on tips. Also, know that at cafes, if you do take out vs. eating at the tables, coffee and food will be alot less for the same food and drink. Highly recomeend the Appertiv on George Street for great Italian food and the Fine Food Store has an awesome breakfast.

It's free!. It's rare to find anything free these days, a beautifully presented story of australia and the bridge, very informative. Good archive film footage to watch, learnt heaps! Good for kids also with quiz sheet to do.
Any easy walk but not a mandatory visit. Charming neighborhood, some fun shops and restaurants, but not a MUST SEE in Sydney, but a nice way to burn some time.

So close it's silly not to visit... much nicer than stopping on the quay. Who doesn't visit the Opera House or Circular Quay when in Sydney? That means you're near or right on top of 'The Rocks' so it would be silly not to take the little extra stroll. 'The Rocks' is indeed a historic little patch of Sydney, but it's now pretty touristy. Touristy? Get over it, you're a tourist too, and that means it caters for you! There's a street market full of souvenirs from the predictable to the surprising, lots of cafes and bars of a decent quality (one of the most popular bars being a German beer and ham hock place, weirdly enough, but you can just walk on past it) and a few plaques and plates explaining aspects of the history. Nice little Victorian shops sell all sorts of souvenirs ranging from the really vulgar selection of things made from kangaroo scrotums through Aussie art to the undeniably Australian take-home staples of RM Williams and Drizabone. If you've just got off one of the ferries or tours, or have walked around Circular Quay after seeing the Opera House or Botanical gardens, and are flagging a little, don't stop at the far too touristy places on the back of the quay, continue on to 'The Rocks' which whilst certainly touristy is much more pleasant and has plenty of places to stop for just a cuppa or a beer or a meal, plus the added attractions of the market etc.
Love the History. This is a great area to explore - history is everywhere and an excellent understanding of where the country started ! just great fun to trawl the streets!
nice place to visit. you can't go to sydney and not be there. nice place for strolling or dining. even see some nice place. people are friendly.
Just walk away from the rocks!!. A great place to stroll around the streets! Plenty of food,sweet shops,bars,restarants. Just looking at the hourbour . Donot miss this walk it's a walking city!!

Always a great place for breakfast or lunch, and the week end markets are also good value.. The Rocks Café serves a great breakfast in a quaint building. the food is great, but the coffee is about the best in the world.

A mixed bag. I went on the weekend so that you enjoyed the markets. I was pleasantly surprised to realise that while typical tourist type of items were for sale there were also things that would be more appeal is looking for more authentic merchandise. The places that I shopped did accept credit cards so you don't have to bring a ton of cash. And it's fun to just wander through the streets I bet. Otherwise this is an area that's decent for dinner. Just be careful if you go there on a Sunday night because they are breaking down the market tents and it can get very noisy with construction type sounds.

One if the best areas of Sydney. There is so much to see and do on The Rocks. You have beautiful views of the harbour, the bridge and the opera house and some of the very best restaurants are in this area. We spent a lot of time there.
A wonderful place to wander . Full of side streets and alleys. Mixed new and old buildings. A wonderful place to wander. Little cafes and restaurants are everywhere. Go look!

Great Place to Grab Food and Drinks at Night. The Rocks has its very unique history. It's fascinating to find evidence of the beginning of australia as a country here. But modern day The Rocks is a good hangout spot, with a lot of pubs and restaurants/eateries. If you enjoy Farmer's Market, there's one here on the weekend that has food, handicrafts and souvenirs and it's super fun for locals and tourists alike!

Sydney's Early History...Preserved in the Rocks. The Rocks offers history in a modern setting. Shops, museums, restaurants...the Rocks has it all. Walk through for a couple of hours at least...or spend a day.

Interesting History. A great place to spend a couple of hours walking around and learning about the history. Do a walking tour or find somewhere to eat in one of the many fantastic restaurants and pubs.

Ideal location. We stayed in the Rocks which we found to be an ideal location from which to explore Sydney as well as enjoying the spectacular view of the Opera House and of the Harbour Bridge. People watching also an option if you are so inclined.

You have to do The Rocks. We ended up in the Rocks on a Free Tours Sydney tour and the history here is amazing. They have done a great job trying to maintain/restore the architecture. In addition to the free tours, there are several online guides that can be printed and/or Kindle books. You really do need to have some of the history to really appreciate what you are seeing in the Rocks.Don't miss getting down to this area, understanding the history, and enjoying the food as opposed to just walking through.

Great area to walk around. A very nice area of Sydney that's a nice area to walk away from the main Quay and spend some time. It is a little more relaxed and some nice examples of the more quaint part of Sydney.
There are plenty of steep hills and steps around this part though so be prepared for some calories to be burnt.

Soulful Sydney. There's a lot of history, soul and character to this place! It contains some excellent bars, restaurants, cafes and museums too - worth spending an afternoon exploring these streets and side-streets.
Amazing . Plenty of little boutique shops to look at. Little cafes and pubs as well. Also there is a market there i think its every 2nd Sunday (not quite sure)
great history, and views. lovely place to soak in the Auz history. some fantastic shops and wonderful views. grab a cup of coffee and just soak it all in!
Nice area. The Rocks is a nice area, but not quite what I was expecting. It feels that modern aspects are starting to creep in and are diminishing the historic elements and charm of the area.

Historic part of Sydney. There are lots of great historic places to see, pubs to visit and character filled alleys and laneways to wander through! We visited the Rocks on both of our "I'm free " walking tours of Sydney. The Rocks has lots of historical places to visit, buskers pave the sea wall and lots of grassy slopes to sit and relax.
Just wandered through. Too many Opal shops too few pubs not enough signage or seats for people claiming up steep banks as required by mature folk on hot dates

A Crowd Pleaser. The Rocks encompasses the area from the Sydney Harbour Bridge to the Circular Quay. It has everything you could possibly imagine, and something for everyone. Museum for the arts and history lover, restaurants and cafes for the foodies, markets and boutiques for the shoppers, ferries and harbour cruises for the water lovers and iconic sights for the visitors. It is culturally stimulating and unique. What a sensory blast for the visitors! It is what a waterfront should be like, something for everyone. We visited every day of our stay, just couldn't get enough! There is lots of sun and shade as you walk along, places to rest, gelato to buy and friendly service everywhere. Yes, it is crowded but not overwhelming.
Scenery . Really lovely to see how Sydney grew up to the city that it currently is. More than enough possibility's to discover the history of this old piece of Sydney
Visit the Rocks Museum. Wandered around the Rocks, and visited the Rocks Museum. This free museum was fascinating detailing the history of the Rocks and the Aborigine connection.

Like going back in time. The rocks is a pretty traditional area of Sydney which transports you back in time to when Australia was first colonised by Europeans. Doing a tour of the area will help you make most of the historical aspect of it all. Otherwise the place is littered with great pubs and an awesome night out can generally be found in the area.

wow wow wow. We just fell in love with this place. If you like history then this is the place to go. Markets, museums, shops, restaurants, cafes and amazing old pubs! There are 5 pubs to locate at the Rocks and if you are from England you will fully appreciate these. Walking down the streets is a must but also sad. There are the most amazing houses owned by the council and some still have tennants in. However, they are rapidly being sold off to developers which is extremely sad for their long term tenants :( The Glenmore hotel is a must. Go up to the 3rd floor and just have a beer and look at the view of the Opera House and Circular Quay. Truly amazing. The market on a weekend does the most amazing food so make sure you take the whole family down here for this as there are so many different cultures to choose from. If you are staying at Darling Harbour it will take 15 minutes to walk here and it truly is a great walk.
Love The Rocks. Awesome shopping and restaurants at the Rocks. Short walk from the Harbor, or the Four Seasons....right down Collins St. The outdoor vendors have cool things to purchase.

Rocking 'Rocks'. Whether you are there for shopping or simply chilling at one of the many cafes or sightseeing, the rocks is a great place. It has some good clubs with great night life for those who are interested. The area has great water views & is definitely worth visiting.

The Rocks Walking Tour. My husband and I walked a couple of kilometres from our motel to The Rocks. We had a drink in one of the many old pubs and then met up with the free Walking Tour which goes every night (except Christmas Day and New Year's Eve) from 6pm from Cadman's Cottage. The young guide, a Sydney University History student was absolutely amazing. He was so knowledgeable on all aspects of the area and also kept us entertained with his humour. The hour and a half walk was over in a flash!

Hang out time. Great place to just hang out! Watch the street entertainers, the people passing by, the many restaurants and pubs, the ferries to different parts of the harbour and all the hustle and bustle of a great human space.
Connected to wooloomooloo promenade. This area became fancy.. maybe too much.Still there is something special in its atmosphere maybe linked to its past and residents and Sydney big history
Shops are amazing. Wonderful place to visit, great shops, restaurants and the markets are brilliant. A must visit when in Sydney.

Quick vidit. There's always something to see or entertain at the rocks Love waking around the little streetsLoads of history hereJust a short walk from circular quay Highly recommend this to overseas visitorsThe Dig site is new to me and its full of historyA must see if your in this neck of the woods
The Rocks. Shops, historic buildings, steps to climb, Sunday market, beautiful views, the Harbour....everything. A lovely place to visit

Great Fun. Love the Rocks... the best Pub there is the Mercantile its great fun over the weekend as they always have a Irish Band.. the music and vib is fantastic... the food is generous and tasty. Love this Pub...
Always lovely. It doesn't matter when you visit, the history of this place is worth it. Lots to see and discover, with anything from modern to traditional.

Nice area, like the arts and crafts market.. Interesting historic area, well signposted and a nice place to walk around. Fascinating to see all the old buildings and streets from the earliest part of modern Sydney. The artists market on Saturdays is lovely, and the pavement cafes in the old buildings give the place a nice relaxed atmosphere.

Everything you want!. Shops, restaurants, bars, nightlife. Everything you want and need is here, enjoy the rocks with family, friends or loved one or just take a little walk alone you will never feel bored of this place.

Historical Sydney. Situated close to Sydney Bridge this is the last remaining area of the old poor part of the city. Although it has become very touristy it still remains different to the modern city and certainly worth a visit. If you only want to look at the old buildings, or simply visit the great old pubs, try out the restaurants , browse amongst the craft shops, this area should not be missed.

Visit the Rocks. Great places to eat and drink , well worth a visit , cheap travel by train , for us its 3 stops away , or walk over the bridge , with a nice sea breeze , always something of interest to look down on

Great buzz on a Sunday. We walked from our hotel in Chinatown to the Rocks. Markets were on, lots of entertainment and beautiful wares to buy. Big Royal Caribbean ship in so lots of people around. All restaurants were busting! Great Vibe

Take the Walking Tour. Many restaurants and shops located in the old buildings. Walking tour provides excellent history on the Rocks. If you don't want a tour, just walk around and read the many plaques throughout the Rocks.
Great FREE tour. Lots of walking but a great tour. We were impressed that it was offered FREE by the Australian Tourism Board. We would have paid too, it was great.

Sydney's Oldest Quarter. This is about as close to history as you get in the modern metropolis of Sydney and it's pretty much at the base of the famous bridge. Nice, quaint, buildings with a lively outdoor cafe and market scene so it's worth stopping at on the open-top bus tour. Pick a day when the market is open and a cruise ship is in the harbour.

Fun place to browse. The Rocks is an interesting and fun place to visit with small alleys and winding back walkways. The variety of shops means there is someting for everyone from old pubs, restaurants, craft shops, boutiques, etc. etc.
A must for any visit to Sydney and not far from the Opera House.

Great History. The Rocks are between Sydney Harbour Bridge and the ferry terminal. It has many interesting historic buildings and sites. There are a number of street markets with good food available. The old wharves have been converted into a dance studio and other interesting uses. There is a pleasant park with great views over the water. Well worth a visit, take you time to just wandering.

Rocks Sunday Market. The Rocks Sunday Market is a must visit if visiting Sydney.Our highlight on this visit was the skill of the Spray Can Painter, with his unusual techniques to produce waterfalls , beach scenes etc

So vibrant and alive. Such an experience each time we went into the area by day and night. Lots to see and do; listen to the street entertainment, splash out in the shops (the didgeridoo one is so interesting, but expensive), eat your way through food from many different cultures or just have a snack and drink. Take a boat trip or sit in the grassy areas and watch the ibis - they are so tame. Watch the cruise ships and dream!

Shopping. Weekend at the Rocks is great. Historic buildings, food, clothes, back streets, pubs and close by the Harbour. The Rocks Markets are fun with a large variety of goods, surrounded by even more shops and with beautiful museums.
History Rocks. Great place to stroll around and Marvel at the workmanship of years past..Easy to get around and Shop Keepers very friendly but not pushy

History right there.. Always a joy to walk through these old streets to see and feel where white settlement began. Always something happening, street markets, food markets, cute shops, cafes and loads and loads of history to breathe in. A trip to Sydney isn't complete with at least a stroll through the Rocks.
Markets are great. So many food stalls to walk around and smell, music was playing food and drinks were flowing, some lovely hand made crafts.
World slows down. When we went up to the rocks, the hustle and bustle of Sydney Harbour just seemed to disappear. Fantastic place to go and sit outside a café and drink a coffee or whatever.
Sunday walk. A place buzzing with people....locals and visitors alike. Lots of shops, great atmosphere. You won't go hungry either.

Great place to visit. We went to a street fair that was held at the Rocks and it was amazing. Great food, shows, music and lots of booths with great gifts to bring home.
During the days there are lots of shops, good and views.
Do not miss, worth the visit!

Strictly for cruise ship intimates. This part of town used to be interesting but now it's a low class tourist extortion venture with very little to recommend it for. We were walking in the area and thought we get some late lunch and compared to other parts of central Sydney the quality is low and the prices are high.

Rockon. Stayed for seven days in the centre of The Rocks and there are three famous pubs within walking distance, The Hero of Waterloo, The Lord Nelson and The Fortune of War all claiming to be the oldest pub in Sydney. There are ample places to eat and a weekend market. Circular Quay is adjacent from which ferries are available to Manly, Darling Harbour and many other places. The Rocks are located close to the Bridge and Opera House and is an ideal centre from which to explore Sydney.

You have to visit the rocks. The rocks is one of those places which everyone has to visit while in Sydney. It has a fantastic colonial feel to it and is also a wonderful place to sit down and have lunch or dinner.

Our europe away from Europe. Europe more than 24 hours of flying away, we frequent Historic Rocks with European cafes and restaurants, gobble stone streets and heritage listed buildings. We love to visit. All weather destination.

Historic area with lots of bars and places to eat. Lots of street cafes and weekend market make this area very popular and has foot access to the bridge. You can also walk underneath the bridge which gives you great close up views of the ships and ferry's moving around the harbour.
Wanderings . Be good to see more folk in costume some street plays to share the areas history come on local council !

Love the self tours, great pubs and the old world charm of The Rocks.. A favourite place to visit right on the Quay, The Four Seasons has an excellent bar which is very affordable and comfortable especially with the open glass windows. Love to following the self guided tours and walk up the hill to see the Harbour Bridge from a different angle!
A must when in Sydney. This is a nice place to dine and shop. On the weekend there is a street market where one can find lots of souvenir items and unique finds.

A little piece of history. Love the atmosphere of this area. Quaint shop fronts, cobbled stone lanes, historical fact plates... Lots to see and do... Hand made chocolates and woollen wares to name a few. Fabulous walks and views.... A must do.

A Great Place to explore on Foot. Staying at the Four Seasons, we walked down to The Rocks for the morning and even though the weather was dismal, it was great to be outdoors exploring our country's history. This is a great place to spend the morning. If you are here on a Friday there are food markets which are popular and on Saturdays there are food and arts markets - which are also good.

History all around at the Rocks. A beautiful spot which is reeking in history of old Sydney. A nice spot to walk, see the big cruise ships come in or sit and enjoy a coffee watching life go by. Lots of nice eating places and good access to the base of the bridge. Do your own walking tour!

Some History there!. Every time I visit Sydney I have to go to the Rocks. Great place to spend time walking around and looking at the old buildings and the history behind them where the first convicts landed. The buildings are well kept and restored and the old cobbled stone streets add so much character to the place. The shops and cafes are great to sit and watch people. On Sundays the market is great and you could spend easily a day rooming around the Rocks.
Not to be missed. Usually make this area one of our "ports of call" when visiting Sydney. Especially love the markets and the walks along the harbour

Sunday Markets. I stumbled upon the Sunday Markets by chance and was very impressed. I usually don't enjoy markets but these were of a much higher quality compared to the usual run of the mill ones that I am used to. There was an excellent mix of craft, food and other interesting activities. My six year old daughter really enjoyed exploring for little treasures and holiday mementos. Surrounding the markets was the Sydney harbour and other retail outlets. An easy walk from the ferries at Circular Quay.Worth having a look if you are in town.

The Rocks. Established shortly after the colony's formation in 1788, it had a reputation as a slum.It is now part of Sydney's history, with it's beatiful old buildings, and lovely harbourside views. We enjoyed walking round the markets, and stalls, and having a few drinks, in one of the many bars and restaurants.

Loved this old part of Sydney. We enjoyed the Rocks area. It's very close to the water, with great views of giant cruise ships or tiny ferries going out and back out of the port there. Plus, there are some very old bars that are kind of fun (they look it). A couple of them claim to be the oldest bars in Australia. The shops there are perhaps a bit typical, but there are also some unique places selling art and local artisan crafts that are very nice.
The Rocks. The Rocks is excellent - we went on a Saturday morning when the market was on, was lovely, lots of nick nacks to purchase.

Shop eat and drink. Truly great place to shop eat and drink and weekend craft market,on the Rocks you have designer shops ,cafes and restaurants .In the evening you have bars were you can drink and dance traditional old pubs were you can listen to singers and also a beer Keller were you can eat and dance and slap your thighs and enjoy it.on a weekend there is a brilliant craft market were you can buy lots of stalls to suit your choice.

History in the city. We recently returned from a cruise and took the opportunity to see the markets and walk the rocks. Never a let down. Fabulously marked walls and historic sites. Well worth the walk

Sunday family outing. We decided to go to the rocks. It is always a great pleasure going. It is a little crowded but i think it was because a cruise liner was docked. A great place to find any kinds of foods from German to American. The markets are always good to go for a look and there are plenty of pubs around to stop for a beer. Its a must visit but do not drive public transport is the way to go

Feels like you were there.. The rocks are so well preserved and it makes you feel like you were really there in colonial Sydney. We came through here on a tour (free tours Sydney) and absolutely had to come back after because it was so beautiful.
Great for nightlife . Loads of bars, restaurants and historic places such as the oldest pub in Sydney "Fortune of War". This place is also a hotel and does a great pint of Guinness.

Food, cold beer and views. If you love great food, history, architecture, stunning views and generally going on walks of discovery, you will love The Rocks. It offers restaurants, pubs, markets, shops, beautiful Harbourside views (imagine this, sunshine, a cold beer, wonderful Italian meal, and outdoor seating along the waters edge - you can't get much better).Grab your camera, walk through the streets, narrow laneways, along the waterfront and take in the scenery, the architecture, history or maybe do a ghost tour at night but be warned, The Rocks is noisy at night so the spirits may stay away. The Rocks has great weekend markets that includes entertainment, when you are tired from walking around, pull up a seat in one of the many pubs, restaurants or cafes.

Not to be missed when in Sydney. The Rocks is famous historically and is evident when strolling around the market towns streets. It throws you back to the days of the early settlers and the ambiance is carried well with some vendors in period costumes. Many of the locals who hang around these quarters also get into the Bohemia quality that the rocks portrays in both look and feel. If you are a tourist to Sydney then The Rocks has to be visited. Spend a few hours strolling and walking around and do stop in and try the local beverages and food.

What amazing history. The Rocks is an area a few blocks from the Sydney Opera House. It's an old, historic part of the city and it feels like it. You step back in time and walk past some of the oldest bars and hotels in Sydney. Many of the buildings now are quaint shops and eateries, but you still feel the history. On the weekend there is an open air market with arts and crafts. Well worth a day, or a few hours of exploration!

Great place to see some early Australian history. The Rocks still has many old early Australian buildings, because this was where Sydney tiwn began. Easy to walk around. Lots of good cafes and restaurants, shops, bars etc. Right down on the Harbour do you can walk around to the water and go to the MCA too. Some shops are a bit touristy, but the area is so pretty.

The Rocks are Worth a Visit.. The Rocks sit along Sydney Harbor at the foot of the Harbour Bridge. The neighborhood features numerous little cafes and shops as well as imposing stone cliffs. It is worth a wander through the back streets as well as along the Harbor. This is a unique little neighborhood and well worth a visit.

Interesting but not a must see. I didn't know what to expect, there were several sweet cafes and shops, but we went on a weekday. We were told that the best time to come would be a weekend, because there is lots more going on with many street vendors... So I would suggest that.

Worth a visit, even for locals!. I spend a lot of time in the rocks with both family, friends, and work. It is a great environment with many good cafes and restaurants, specialty shops (if you like opals you need to check out the rocks!) and museums. The rocks boasts a very wide range of activities all year round for all ages, including ghost tours, tall ship cruises, historic houses walks and much more.Worth finding a tour that will tell you all about the dark history that soaks the area; razor gangs that used to attack people in the argyle cut are just the beginning!
Market and art stuff galore. The Rocks is known for its market and small art shops, nice restaurants and cafés. Really nice to walk through.

A Highlight Not to Missed. The historical area is known for its sandstone buildings and early-built heritages. Probably my second favorite attraction in Sydney (after Bondi - Bronte Walk), when we arrived in The Rocks, the Museum of Contemporary Art was right next to us (we are not pretty much interested in artworks so we skipped it) and walking is the best option to explore the area. Most roads are smaller than in CBD, and there are few pedestrian walkways for visitors.MUST DO : - Find a live street music band to enjoy  - Choose one of the restaurants to have a meal (highly recommended most of them) - Don't miss the weekend market (The Rocks Market) where you can shop handicrafts and weird souvenirs  - See some of its attractions : Cadman's Cottage, Discovery Museum, Campbell's Storehouses etc - Visit it during the morning (escape the touristy crowds, the earlier the better) - Walk to the Sydney Observatory Hill This is the finest place in Sydney to flip through the history of this vibrant city

Don't Miss This Neighborhood!. This is a lovely section of Sydney. More laid back and quiet. The Rocks is actually where the first Australians settled. It has some great restaurants and shops and should not be missed.

HIDDEN GEMS. Nearly didnt do this area as it was a wet day when first encountered it as a sneaky short cut to the brudge climb entrance...glad we went back on a sunny afternoon as its a hive stalls and sneaky nooks an crannies...lots going on very informative wall plaques.....

Walking Tour of the Rocks. We wanted to have a little more of the history of the area, so we signed up for the Walking Tour of the Rocks. We loved it! Our boys 12 and 15 years old enjoyed the colorful stories and we walked through many nook and crannies, we might not have otherwise explored. Another one of those must do experiences when in the area, to really get a better appreciate for the way things started out and the history of the area. Rock on!

Old.. If you are into old buildings to look at or to take photos. This place has great history behind it. Take your time to walk around what is old and new buildings. Architecture is great.Orjust watch the boats or cruise shops enter the quay is still good to watch.Spare some time in your visit and head down to the Rocks in Sydney.
Nice. nice place to visit it is kind of a hike coming from the harbor but well worth the exercise a must see

Great way to spend a day. Wandered through the great markets and around the streets, popping into the shops, window shopping, cafes, restaurants & bars are throughout the area. It is only expensive if you spend. It is a great way to spend a day, wear comfortable shoes and do a self guided tour.

The Rocks always impresses. Weekends are fabulous for visiting The Rocks. The Markets are of a very high standard with constantly changing things to buy; jewelary, clothing. cards, souvenirs, eats, drinks. With many surrounding little street cafes, patisseries, bars, restaurants, and a bit of History. A good holiday vibe with all the tourists. High quality street music too. Something for everyone. Also love the Bondi shop, if you can't get out there. Beautiful souvenir shops.... The Rocks won't disappoint!!

History of the Rocks is Interesting. We took tours and walked the rocks on our own. There is so much going on down there - you can do a self guided tour, or pay for a tour. There are open air markets going on all the time. And there is so much convict history to be learned.

Great place, but not for those on a tight budget.. This is a very nice area, with trendy cafes and a lot of history. Don't expect to keep to a tight budget though if shopping or eating in the area. Definitely worth a wander but for the more budget conscious wander further to find better deals.

Touristy. Went to the rocks to just check out the markets on a Saturday and it was filled with Tourists. This is a good place to go for happy hour drinks on a Friday and a nice walk for a Saturday/Sunday.

FRIDAY FOOD MARKETS IS TIME TO VISIT. Best German, Austrian hot dogs etc and multicultural food every Friday lunch. Locals know and go regularly, and there are French patisseries in the Rocks as well for crepes etc after lunch.

Piece of history. History is everywhere here. It is nice and cute walk between small and old houses. How brave and smart were the workers, who went to strike to save these buildings. It is must to go here.

The Rocks Markets are still good. The Rocks markets are still very good to attend but just don't attend with a cruise ship in port as the area is very crowded. WE were there when shi in and also the same time as people arriving to board. A very good wy to spend a Saturday afternoon just strolling and browsing. Lots of places to eat some quite expensive. We foun that the smaller cafes on the edge of the Rocks were more reasonable priced

An relaxing day out. The rocks is a must see when in Sydney. It has many stories to tell about the history of Sydney and many cafes, restaurants and pubs that offer amazing food and drinks. It also has weekend markets that offer something for people from around the world.
great to walk around. great to stroll around the rocks taking in some of the history as well as eating and drinking and shopping

Love this place. Great place to spend the weekend . I come up to Sydney and stay at the rocks one weekend a year and love it. So much going on you have the food markets Friday and then the rocks markets Saturday and Friday. Great placed to eat so much to do. Great little shops I don't go into the tourist ones they are just cheap and boring. ( Not cheap in price)
Great place to shop. The rocks offers designer outlets such as Ralph Lauren. There are also lots of restaurants and bars to visit too many to mention.If you are in Sydney definately worth a visit.

A nice walk..... A nice walk to get between other sights including the bridge and can be accessed via the harbour. Plenty of shops and places to eat. Points of interest are noted along the way with information plaques.
Trendy and a little pricey attraction. An attractive way to view Sydney's historic past. Gorgeous sandstone buildings on show with myriad businesses flourishing. Tourist walks available.

Great little pice of Sydney's history. A must when visiting Sydney. Greatfor a nice stroll,good for shopping (duty free shops) ,glass of beer and some food. Right next to Circular Quay and Opera House

Loved the historic location. We were at the Holiday Inn which is quite a good location right across from the walkway to the opera house and the museum that was lovely for breakfast and coffee in the morning. Access to all the boats jump on jump offs Harbour cruises etc. it was also located next to a type of farmers market and craft fair held weekly. The cruise ships also come in there. There is plenty of shopping and Resturants as well as a historical walk that does require climbing stairs. It's easy access to everywhere either by boat or bus or cab.

Sample The Old Sydney at The Rocks. The Rocks is the place to be. Sample the old Sydney as you walk about, you get the feel of how things once where. It's so picturesque and has been sensitively restored. The narrow, block paved, areas/streets make you feel as though you are back to a time when there were cobbles under foot, and horses and carts, were the only transport. There is so much to see. We loved this area. There are, as always, plenty of restaurants, cafes, and bars. Quaint shops selling souvenirs and all so close to the harbour yet looking a lifetime away. It's well kept, fascinating to walk around and see all there is. Sightseeing at it's best. The oldest pub in Sydney, 'Fortune Of War' is there too! Why not visit and pay a visit to The Russell hotel too, just a few doors away?

Cool. Great shops. I happened to go when they where having a festival. Lots of tents with local artists and shops. Great walking around. Also can see why they call if "The Rocks". Note hill and stairs.
Absolutely love it. If you travel to Sydney there is no way to no visit this beautiful place. Nice walk during a warm day with beautiful spots to get a drink or nice lunch.
This area rocks :). I love this area both with and without the market. I had several walk in the area and I love the houses and the stories the area tells.

First visit. Interesting to see another part of Sydney. Hilly, winding streets with lots of stairs. Went on a Saturday when the street market was open. Found Turkish street food and interesting shops. It is also the area where the cruise ships dock...that can make it crowded. Walked over to have a drink at the Lord Nelson Pub. What history, we even got a tour of the basement that was built by convicts. Bridge museum and entrance is in this neighborhood too. Worth the visit.

Free Walking Tour. Instead of paying for the various tours that were offered, there was a walking tour at 5PM on the day we were there for free. They took us around town and explained all of the buildings and told stories about the area--definitely worth going to. It was 1.5 hours and at the end, they asked for donations.

Old sydney. Starting at Circular quay with george st as its border is a fabulous old area under the sydney harbour bridge. Loads of bars and old hotels , old spaghetti factory , music / writers previnct. Base for sydney dance company and annual Sydney writers . Felt safe walking around at night. easy walk back to circular quay.

Coolest area of Sydney!. We enjoyed our time in other areas (CBD, Quay, Darling, Manly, etc). However, The Rocks is the coolest area. The bars, restaurants, and street markets are well worth the trip. Spend some time walking around.

Art and Craft. Unless you join a tour, there's not much to gain here. Mostly art and craft stalls, and cafés and meals. The old police station was interesting with original cell doors and very thick walls, occupied as a cafe now, so you only get to view it if having a meal there.

Lots of history. Wandered round the rocks with the kids. Lots of history, and shops and alley ways. The markets are really good on Friday - Sunday. Lots of stairs though. Was going to visit the Susannah Place museum but need to book. $8 each person.
Not much to see anymore.... This area should be rich in history and things to see. Only a handful of cafes and mediocre shops. Such a waste. Needs to be developed as a historical precinct.
Historic Sydney. This is the true heart and history of Sydney.A must for every person.Experience Sydney in the early days and see their footprints .

Lovely spot to wander for an hour. The rocks is a nice change from the rest of the city centre which is very metropolitan- old buildings and sites. The museum is a must as without a map or some information it's probably not so interesting, but there are good sites. There is also a free tour most evenings starting near the cruise terminal.
Historic area. This is the original Sydney area with lots to see. Some steep streets and steps but well worth the effort.

The Rocks.. yeayyy..... We went to The Rocks with Hop on Hop off bus. We loved the market. We loved the buildings and the restaurants. The place reminded me of the street and building in europe. Nice place to visit. Surely will come back.
Class. . Good spot for a wander and to drop by a pub or shop. Good view of. Opera house and bridge make it a must stop spot for visitors to the city.
Loads to do here. We went on a Sunday and enjoyed the market. Lots of history here, museums, art galleries, buskers, shops, arcades, coffee shops, cafes and restaurants - brilliant!

An Historic walk. A walk around the area called the rocks is not only historic because the convicts acutaly build the area out of rocks they were forced to mine, hue and place, but the market place is cool, shops to buy things and foods you have the harbour views, night clubs and fun people
Arts and Crafts Stalls. This is a fun place to stroll through the crowded stalls of arts and crafts vendors. There are some food stall as well making it a popular place to do lunch.

Great place to wander. Walking around this area is interesting at any time but the weekend market makes it even better. Many unusual things to see and try and buy.Great places for a meal and all in an area steeped in history. A must visit area when you are in Sydney.

Take a full day to explore!!!. So historic and amazing this place but make sure you dedicate a whole day or weekend to explore! Amazing little restaurants down the cobble stone lanes and music and night markets!
Fun place to be. The Rocks is such a fun place to hang out. Great places to eat, good shopping, beautiful views. Just a fun vibe. Loved it!
Market days are fun. Visited again on a market day and the stalls have lots of different things to look at and buy. The restaurants around are great
The Rocks markets. Enjoyed having a look around The rocks and especially the markets that they have which are probably more high end markets with a few souvenirs.

Different Sydney. The Rocks provide a different vibe on Sydney. Though the streets can get a bit busy with tourists in the afternoon, it is a great location with many old buildings and the park leading to the observatory. Various shops and restaurants around and a few minutes from Circular Quay.

Stay in the Rocks!. We visited Sydney for five days at the end of December, and we stayed at a nice hotel centrally located in the Rocks. We loved the Rocks! It was just a great area of Sydney in between Sydney Harbor and Darling Harbor. Because the Circular Quay is right there, the Rocks is the perfect place to stay to see many parts of Sydney. We very much enjoyed just walking around in the Rocks and seeing the sights. I do have to make one complaint. I don't know what idiot decided to let cruise ships block the view of Sydney Harbor for anyone staying in the Rocks, but whoever made that decision should be eternally embarrassed for such a dumb mistake. The cruise ships could easily have been put in at some other harbor, and the Sydney Harbor would have been there for all to enjoy. As it is, the cruise ships come in, everyone gets off their cruise ship and tours Sydney, and the ships block the view of everyone in the Rocks, while there's no one actually on the cruise ship during the day! It's an amazingly dumb use of a beautiful space. But don't let that disuade you. Stay in the Rocks and visit the Rocks, you'll love it!

Sydney- The Rocks. We were in Sydney over the 2015/16 new year. The Rocks is a short walk from Circular Quay and is worth a visit. It is a gentrified section of old Sydney and is full of quaint shops and a multitude of restaurants and cafes. When we were there there was also a large market selling clothing, craftwork etc. Some of the items sold are touristy but others are of very good quality.

A must to see!. I love this area. Lots to see and read the history. On a rainy day come into the info centre see the shops and the rock/sweet maker. Some lovely hotels and restaurants here and some good photos can be taken. walk the alleyways and se what they have done today.

Wonderful historic place to visit . We walked from Sydney cbd to the rocks. .we had a delicious brunch in one of many small cafes and wandered around looking at all the buildings entrenched in so much history. . A must do in sydney

Excellent place for local craft products. It is true that anywhere in the world you go, the souveneirs you find will be made in China. We went to the Sunday Market at The Rocks and enjoyed many displays of crafts and jewelry actually made in Australia. Products can be found in all price ranges and there were many items that were small enough to make them feasible for taking back home as gifts.
The Rocks. Nice and quiet at the time we were there, many little restaurants and cafes. it is very close by the bridge, which you can walk across (use of the pedestrian path)

Love onThe Rocks. While visiting sydney we visited here many times .It is situated by the harbour bridge.There are many bars, cafés, a street market, and interesting buildings.The mercantile is a lovely irish bar situated here but my favourite was the oldest pub in sydney, lovely staff and every time I went their was a singer on for entertainment. Well worth a visit.
Nice place to stay and/or eat. Beautiful location, close to the ferries, Harbor bridge and Opera house. Many nice restaurants in the area

Touristy but a must do. We went to see the Markets, and were actually impressed at the quality of goods available. Thought perhaps the usual touristy stuff, but not so. Some very good quality pieces, silver and jewellery spring to mind. The ambiance of the old buildings and history is great, but being right beside the International terminal means it's nearby first stop for people debarking. Great lemonade and icecreams, and the sapphire/gem shop up the Nurses' lane (?) is worth a look.

Sunday markets + Pubs. The historic pubs are great and on a warm day sold a great selection of beers! The Sunday markets are an interesting collection of stalls not crafts, not foods just interesting. This is a must go area for visitors
Great vibe and beautiful surrounding . If you visit Sydney you must assign one of your evenings to visit the rocks for a meal and drinks. It was the only area that was alive everynight.
Walking the big dig. This is a lovely area with shops and lots of history about the big dig that carved out the streets and the cubby holes in and around the sector of town.
Interesting stroll through time . Interesting places and spaces with great views across the harbour. Enjoyable day and night. Lots of food options and some huge cruise ships too!
Great Views. Great walking around the Rocks area, excellent pics from there across the bridge of the Opera House and other side of the city.

A real holiday treat at The Rocks Cafe. When tired and weary after taking in the sights of Sydney for hours, what a way to enjoy a treat at The Rocks Café with extraordinary Lemon Meringue pie. Needed two visits to really enjoy the experience, and check out a variety of treats from menu. Good service through very busy holiday season.

Lovely area, go when the market is on. Lovely area of central Sydney. We went when the market was on, i'm not sure when it is on so you'll need to look into it. The market was only small but had loads of lovely stalls with lots of unique and handmade items.
Best in Sydney!!!. Countless restaurants and cafes, amazing nightlife, beautiful old part of Sydney. Walking distance from and to Circular Quay, Opera house.

great, happening night life. Young or old, everybody can enjoy the atmosphere of the Rocks! There is something here for everyone! Friday night markets were wonderful; we spent hours here eating, walking and taking in the sights. Within walking distance to the city too so don't bother with transport.

Great local atmosphere!. We were fortunate to go to The Rocks on the weekend, so we got to check out the market stalls lined up along the streets. We found a lot of authentic Australian goods and souvenirs, and some amazing nougat we bought as gifts. This is a really fun market, crowded but polite people for the most part.
Buzzing. This area is buzzing especially on the craft market days with plenty of stalls selling a good variety of specialised good
Markets . Great day out great views with a great market as well . Museums and galleries as well as shops . Fair bit of walking around but we'll worth the effort
Excellent neigbourhood. This is a very nice neighbourhood, with a great nightlife, bars, cafes and good restaurants. There are also some nice small shops.Highly recommended for a nice walk.

The Rocks rocks!. We loved wandering around the market stalls, picking up all kinds of craft items we wouldn't have found anywhere else. And then we rounded off our visit with a delicious coffee and cake at Cafe Guylian. A great afternoon, much enjoyed by us all (mum, dad and two daughters in their 20s)..

Do it on the Weekend.... The Rocks is one of the oldest areas of Sydney with plenty to see and many places to eat...on the weekend there is a street market that has vendors in several areas of the Rocks...definitely worth the look...

Something for everyone. We visited on Saturday after New Year's Day, specifically for the market but also to have a browse around the area. We've been a few times before, but the place is always worth seeing when the market is up and running. The stalls themselves vary on a weekly basis by it was great to see I few I recognised from my last visit a few months earlier. All tastes are catered for, from bespoke jewellery, to woodwork, to clothes and t-shirts, trinkets, silverware - you name it, there's something there. It gets very busy so it's worth getting there early and taking your time - sometimes the flow of pedestrian traffic is so great that it becomes almost impossible to stop at a stall, and you end up looping back on yourself to see it again. The highlight for me this time was watching a chap painting alien landscapes using enamel sprays and a variety of ad-hoc stencils - spray tins, newspaper, bits of card. The pictures were created in about fifteen minutes flat and were frankly brilliant. Not my kind of art in general, but superb to watch him putting them together. And if you can find the Chilli Factory stall, go and challenge your taste buds there - the fiery frillneck hiss is worth sampling. There was also a stall selling home-made men's t-shirts with some very complex looking geometrical patterns on them. Kicking myself that I didn't get one. If you don't like this place, it's hard to imagine you ever being happy. Ever!
Not really our cup of tea. Felt more like a tourist trap, food and other stores were overpriced and it was very crowded, did not really feel special to us
Charming and fun. Charming and fun area of town. The weekend markets were a lot of fun and plenty of good dining choices. A must see!

The whole town on its doorstep. Magical. I have never found a better place to get a fix on Sydney's historic convict days, then this jumble of cobblestone streets and cul-de-sacs just minutes from Circular Quay. Stepping off the harbour foreshore we find sandstone terraces and cottages and some of Sydney's oldest pubs. This area is filled with museums & galleries, lively markets and hotels boasting the best iconic views over the Bridge and Opera House. The past and the present collide in the best possible way. steep, higgledy-piggledy streets and lane-ways sprawl out within sight of gorgeous harbour and its busy aquatic traffic. We took a guided tour to learn more about the early history which brought to life sailors, soldiers and stevedores creating this array of terraces, storehouses and workmens' cottages.Prowling or loitering this is the precinct for hand-crafted jewellery, gourmet bush tucker (condiments) and glorious patisseries, cafes and lovely pubs, most with live music.. Gently amble up and down the streets and visit the Museum of Contemporary Art , Sydney Theatre Company, the Justice and Police Museum, across the road from the Sydney Museum which lead to the sweeping Botanic Gardens, Lady Macquarie's Chair, alongside the iconic "Sails" of the Opera House and the fantastic Sydney's Art gallery.... around the block from St, mary's Cathedral, Expansive Hyde Park and the city.... not far from Cockle Bay and more harbour wonderland.Why try to see everything in one day?

Amazing area for food and shopping. We stayed near the rocks and visited multiple times. Great places to buy t-shirts, scarves, ugg boots, and nice food places, wine bars, gelato shops, coffee and breakfast places. Right near where cruise ships come in so can be swarmed when offloading passengers but great scenery abonds. Starbucks not far as well..one of only a couple in Sydney. Highly recommend this area.

Pylon. We walked through the Rocks to get to the Pylon. Very beautiful and you could view the Harbour Bridge and Sydney Opera House from the top. Well worth the small fee to walk up the steps to the top and view the small museum about how the bridge was built. Great view for taking pictures of Sydney.
Nice walk in an old cozy area in Sydney. Good atmosphere for slow walking to see historic background of Sydney. Everytime you will have new findings.
Interesting area of Sydney where the first explorers landed.. Loved the narrow alley ways and narrow streets. The interesting brickwork of the buildings and the architecture.

Good Neighborhood . The Rocks is a great neighborhood. It offers good places to eat, nice coffeehouses, nice shops and a visit to the art museum. It is also a great place just for a walk up and down the street.
If you have some time to spare, do walk around there.

Lovely feel of bygone days. The Rocks market is an absolute must and just the ambience of the place is lovely. The old buildings and laneways are very quaint with a spectacular backdrop of the harbour bridge. Love it!

Lucky to still have this prize. The Rocks is a wondrous walk every time we visit Sydney. Whether it be along George Street, or through the back alleys such as Nurses Walk there is always something fabulous to see and do.

Worth a visit. This is quite a buzzy area of Sydney I would recommend a visit. It is made up little lanes and alleys - it would remind you of the lanes in Brighton
Worth a visit

Almost a must visit. You almost will end up visiting the Rocks one way or the other cos it's adjacent to so many other tourist attractions. For example if you walk over the Sydney Harbour Bridge from Milsons Point railway station you will end up walking down the bridge to the Rocks. Or if you are visiting the Circular Quay again you will find the Rocks as well. It is a very interesting district with lots of historic colonial buildings, mixed with street side restaurants, souvenirs and gift shops, a craft market on weekends, plus a Ken Done gallery. It has a bit of everything and it's very laid back. The local advice is to venture all the side streets apart from the main ones.

Many layers of interesting things.. I really enjoy going to the Rocks. Often taking my school students to look at the 1800's remains. The buildings have quite a story to tell about early Australian history. The Argyle Rocks Dig is fascinating, the story of George Cribb an early convict is also well supported by the Rocks Museum. Remains of the old Battery under the Bridge and Suzanah Place Museum also very interesting telling a story of a new colony and the people who made it successful. Seek out the history through the archaeological remains then enjoy a good pub lunch at the Australian Hotel or one of the many other authentic early pubs. It's a winning experience.
Never get tired of The Rocks. I love wandering through the Rocks area, there is always something to see or do. Definitely worth a visit even when the markets aren't one.
So much history, so much to see and do. The Rocks are a must for anyone visiting Sydney, so much to see and do, excellent places for lunch, dinner, afternoon tea, and the place just oozes history

Fun and Interesting. We stayed in The Rocks area to be close to many attractions and things to do. Certainly glad we did. Most things are within easy walking distance with the added benefit of plenty of restaurants and bars. Be sure to enjoy the Village Bizarre.

Awesome Shopping in The Rocks. The Rock's Markets are a fantastic place to pick up gifts for everyone which will not empty your wallet. The stallholders are friendly and a pleasure to talk to. All of the stalls around The Rock's are wonderful with varying items that I have not seen elsewhere. I cannot wait to go back and potter around again soon.
Great artistic quarter.. Well worth visiting for the markets alone! The cafes and bars have great atmosphere & it's worth just sitting with a coffee/ drink and watching the world go by.
Lively Streets. Located nearby Harbor Bridge. It is a lively streets with bars, pubs etc. It comes alive especially on every Friday evening - the happy hours.

Ideal for weekend afternoons!. The rocks is a great place to laze around during weekends. The cobbled streets come alive with street food and stalls selling everything Australian. Even the bars and restaurants have a holiday feel to them as tourists flock to this side of town. The whole area feels festive enough to spend an entire day here.

Historic Tales. I downloaded the Rocks Tour Walk audio file for this outing. Wow, to follow the guide and listen to the history behind some of the buildings was amazing. I suspended it several times as I went through the markets or shops but it was well worth the afternoon I spent here.

Everyone Goes There At Some Time. Whether you want a pub meal, a restaurant, history adventure, or taking in architecture, The Rocks has it all. It is easy to spend a whole day here and go nowhere else - and you will still feel you have seen Sydney.

Visiting the rocks. I love the Rocks. I went there several times because there is so much to see and do. It also has excellent cafes for snacks and drinks. I visited the museum of contempory art which had very good exhibitions. On the 4th floor it has a terrace cafe with good views. The shop was very good for books and small things. Good for Christmas shopping. The Ken done gallery is there. A new summer exhibition which was colourful and bright and the staff were friendly and helpful. I also went to the museum which gives a history of the rocks which was very interesting and well laid out. There is also a very good information centre there were you can book trips and it had a very good shop as well with good Australian souvenirs. There are a lot of other shops and galleries there and at weekends there is a food market which was fun. It is worthy of a few visits as it is nice to wander and explore. It is also next to circular quay so close to ferries.
Nice place. Nice place to visit especially on a beautiful sunny day! A good walk around, doesn't take too long to go around. But some nice spots to take it all in

Historic. Always love walking around the Rocks. The history is amazing. It is trendy so has become expensive and caters to tourists but it is what you make it. Lots of places to eat and drink and different $. Lots of places to shop or walk around the market. You can wander to less crowded places, walk across or near the bridge or down to Circular Quay and the Opera House. Some lovely hotels to stay
Nice atmosphere . I was there for only one day and found that there were loads to do.. Highly recommend to go during the weekends where they have true markets selling authentic Australian products..

Great day out. This was a lovely day out, with plenty to see and a lovely hand crafted market with plentry of stalls. There was even a guy there making glass items, very cleaver. The little shops on the sides of the market are also worth a visit, don't miss them out as they have some lovely little treasures to be found.The under side view of the bridge, which you pass as you are going round the market, gives you an idea of the engineering that went into it.There are places to eat if you want to and plenty to see if you make an effort.

I keep coming back. Learn about the history, browse the little shops, eat/chill at the many eateries.... The Rocks offers Abit of everything.
It's popular with their weekend markets (Sat & Sun).... But if you're in the area on Fridays, they have their Friday Foodie Market which is great for a long lunch break.

Wonderful historic part of Sydney, with great dining options.. Walking in this area is fabulous - lots of interesting buildings of historic value, good signage and at the end of it all there are many many options of places to eat. Le Pain Quotidian is one!

"party @ the rocks". Here we have the markets, music, good ole irish pubs, and food ...it is also one of the oldest areas in sydney with many buildings dating back to the british settlement."Best of all it's easy access to buses,trains,and ferrys. It is not as it used to be, food etc is a bit overpriced, but hey thats what entices you to "THE ROCKS

An interesting afternoon walk. The Rocks has many little art and cultural shops as well as eateries. We ate at The William Blue restaurant which is a working restaurant which trains future chefs. A great experience at a reasonable price. There is also information locations to help with tourist needs.

Old Sydney Town-As close as it gets. As for the architecture, not much as changed in this area of Sydney since settlement, one can easily immerse themselves into what Sydney would have looked like at settlement. Take a stroll around some of Sydney's oldest pubs or embark on a pub crawl to see them all!

educational and recreational. Very nice historical place with restaurants. Nice to walk around . Must visit the museum that explains about its origin , the first place the city was set up. Learning about heavy drinking of people since early days and the people got rich by trading. Alarmed to know the story of a convict who poisoned his mistress after his business empire failed . Impressed with the people for setting up a new country and still keeping loyal to their Queen. The Rock is a must place to visit to know the origin of Australia.

A great Sunday out. My wife and I love Sunday at the Rocks. The market never changes but we keep going back for 'just another look'. Walking up from the city end (or the start) is the way to go. Once having looked at everything, go back to the guy selling chilly condiments at the top. Try half a dozen of these and then try the 'super red hot one'. Having finished that one, head straight to The Mercantile Hotel for a quick schooner to get over the burning throat. You'll need it. Really, anytime at The Rocks is an experience. To think that the government of the day wanted to tear it all down. We had a labor guy named Jack Mundie. This guy went on a one man crusade and won the fight - The Rocks were not torn down. Good work Jack.

Should be the center of your visit. The Rocks is the home of the original penal colony in Australia, and there are still a few related sites in existence. The old prison building next to the wharf hosts 3-4 waterfront restaurants, such as Wolfie's that offer a perfect view of the Sydney Opera house. Fortunes of War is located on one of the nearby streets and is Sydney oldest pub, and The Glenmore Hotel in the Rocks offers a rooftop bar. There is a small Rocks museum nestled amongst shops and cafes, and at least in the summer there is a Saturday street fest, where vendors sell wares and food A visitors center in the Rocks offers useful information, maps, brochures and souvenirs. The Circular Quay metro station stops here and offers easy access to the ferry station. A couple of blocks away you can find stairs up to the Sydney Bridge. Nearly every day, there is a street merchant next to teh ferry station selling didgeridoos and beautiful boomerang. Possibly the best hotel in Sydney, the Park Hyatt is located here. Across the harbor from the Rocks is the Opera House and the Botanical Gardens. If you are coming to Sydney, you definitely want to plan you stay around the Rocks. No question.

Not as good as it used to be. I don't care so much for The Rocks anymore. It seems to have lost its charm somewhat. It is nice to wander around on the way to Barangaroo or Dawes Point but other than that if you want history it seems to be feeling a tad too modern.
Australia's first settlement. Full of history and interesting cafes and pubs. Make sure you check out 'The Hero of Waterloo' and ask about the dungeons.

Historic buildings and history. One of the older parts of sydney there are a number of historic buildings to discover as well as some great pubs and restaurants to refresh at afterwards. Some beautiful sandstone buildings and great harbour vistas from the more elevated areas.
Nice Weekend Markets. What's not nice about The Rocks? U have the Opera House, Harbour Bridge and good food. The weekend markets were not spectacular but great for browsing.

Amazing. What an amazing place to visit on vacation. This a very historic spot and we were fortunate to have a great tour guide. She was extremely knowledgeable and accommodating. We learned about the rich history of immigrants and castaways who settled in Austrailia. They are so many great food places and the view is 1st class.

Unique. The lanes and alleys of the Rocks are interesting on any day, but get to the weekend street Market if you can, a bit different from the usual offerings, like everything else at the Rocks it has a style all its' own

An area with a variety of experiences and dining options. The Rocks is an interesting tourist attraction near the Sydney Ferries and the downtown hotels. It has placards and photo stories along one area that tell it's history, including how the hospital system developed. We ate at one of the Italian/pizza restaurants for lunch and had a lovely but expensive meal.Caution on accessibility: Although the area has ramps at each corner, the main street sidewalk is fairly tilted towards the street and is a busy pedestrian area to navigate with a wheelchair.

A must do in Sydney!. At night, the nightlife, historic pubs, early maritime area of Sydney, restaurants, the harbour, cafes, the views, by day, quirky shops, weekends, the rocks markets, (not trash markets) foody stores etc.It is a wonderful place, and I usually visit on visits to Sydney!
Walk and enjoy!. We went to a couple bars and food establishments. Nice place to walk and see a little history of the area. Close to quay and opera house.

Amazing weekend markets. The Rocks are iconic and beautiful in their own right. However this place comes to life further on weekends, with road-side markets springing up on Sat & Sun (10 am-5 pm). And the shops sell everything from jewelery, accessories, souvenirs, decoration pieces, gift items, all sorts of apparels, hats, and food...a beautiful mosaic of colour!Best to go after lunch and spend 2-3 hours. About 300-400 m walking from Circular Quay metro station/ 500 m walking from Opera House.

Visit the markets if you can!!. We were blessed to discover a fantastic market in the Rocks on our second day in Sydney and just couldn't stay away. The rocks became a regular part of our week, be it stopping for a coffee or lunch, or for a bit of souvenir shopping. The whole area has such a lovely feel to it.

Restaurant upgrade needed.. Thank God we saved the Rocks. The Rocks district is more than a shopping/eating destination, it is important in terms of the history of modern Australia; a history for which we should all become acquainted, more especially those of us who live or choose to live in Australia. Driven by 'greed' rather than the importance of preserving history, the economy would be more vibrant if re-crafted as a centre to promote Australian craftsmanship rather than to sell goods imported from other lands in Australia's name which is the 'ultimate' falsehood.

Edgy. I was here around Christmas and there were some interesting food and gift stalls along with the usual bars, restaurants and permanent shops (including some slightly disturbing dancing mannequins). Does get a bit boisterous later at night.
Good walk. the rocks is a nice part of downtown Sydney. Plenty of bars and restaurants. i recommend taking the free tour.

History plus...... A visit to The Rocks near Circular Quay, Sydney is a must do when visiting, especially if you enjoy early Australian settlement history. The area, though vastly different than it was around the 1800s, when it was the centre of a new, developing city, still maintains many interesting historical buildings, laneways & some of its colonial charm. An internet search will provide you with maps, directions and a list of must-sees to help you re-live the past. Cadman's Cottage & it's history sets the scene so maybe go there first followed by a visit to the information centre on George St. Take time to wander around the laneways & back streets to get a feel for the area & maybe fit in a visit to the Observatory too. The Rocks markets operate on the weekends & have wonderful boutique stalls selling jewellery, hand-made clothing items, wooden toys, great fudge & many other yummy food items. There are a large number of very good eating places to choose from, including those in the original Sydney Wool Mills - a fantastic building! Wander down to the harbour or under the Habour Bridge, The Rocks area is well worth a stroll around; great atmosphere, shopping & eating.

Interesting, funky. This redeveloped area is full of restaurants, cafes, taverns, bars and artistic outlets. Particularly interesting at night when it all comes to life though you may want to book a restaurant on the w'end.
Lots of history. There's lots of interesting places to go to in this historic part of Sydney. The contemporary art museum has special exhibitions thoughout the year and is free. The markets are great

Shoppers paradise. Nestled near to the Opera House and the Sydney Harbor Bridge is a neighborhood of shops, hotels, hidden alleys, pubs and restaurants. Quite likely a ship will be in the harbor so it's a busy spot. On Saturdays, local artisans offer dozens and dozens if unique handicrafts where you can spend hours just browsing or just walk down George Street towards the more traditional type of shops. Perfect way to spend a morning or afternoon.

Really cool place. I love this place, i went her on Sunday and they have a some kind of fair, i suppose. It was crowded, but there are lots of interesting things to buy there and i love it. The old and vintage looks compliment it really well.

Variety is the key. The Rocks area has a little bit for everyone with shops, pubs, a weekend market and Restaurants of all kinds. I like the views east to the opera house from the point and the events that go on at the International Cruise Terminal. You also have the option to go to the bridge pylon and get a chance to go up the structure for photos and walk on the bridge itself. Its a lot cheaper than climbing the superstructure.

Many free apps give you a wonderful audio walking tour. We used the PHM WALKS app which took us on an adventure around the rocks. The app even showed us pics of what the streets looked like in the 1800's. Many pubs, beautiful architecture and little lane ways and steps to explore. Good shopping along the way too. Be sure to have a drink at Phillips foote.
Great look into history. The rocks..... Well rocks! It's a great glimpse into early Sydney and plenty of boutique shops and coffee houses. The kids did the bridge climb while we were there.
Many stores food / clothes etc. A good time to spend your day if you enjoy market shopping. The market offers something for everyone.
Lovely location. I love this location in Sydney: proximity to the harbour, great spots for food, drink and shopping, as well as full of history! A must visit when in Sydney.

Great place for shopping, eating and visiting museums and art galleries. We love going to The Rocks, even though it's usually filled with tourists. Some of our favourite places are there, such as Le Rennaissance cafe, the MCA, The Rocks Museum which gives an idea of life in the days when Sydney began as a penal colony and with free settlers. There are plenty of shops, although they are mostly for tourists, on the weekends there's the markets, also a bit too touristy, but there are some good things on offer. Most of all, it's close to Circular Quay and the ferries. Go by train, ferry or bus, parking is a nightmare and terribly expensive if you can find a spot.

Highly recommend. The Rocks is one of the great gems of Sydney. Step back in time and explore how early Sydney looked. The markets are wonderful, as is the Museum of Contemporary Art which is located there too.

nice Saturday morning market. I went to The Rocks on a Saturday morning at 9 am. The market starts at 10 am. I had breakfast at Dare, a small, natural food cafe' in one market street, delicious. The market is very nice, with unique souvenirs, arts and crafts. There are also shops but quite expensive.
A really nice place to stay in central Sydney. Lots of nice independent hotels and nice restaurants and still in easy walking distance from the Sydney Harbour and all the attractions there

Not much to see. I expected to see many stores, but there are only a few. This is a historic site but other than that there is not much to see. During the weekend there is a market place. But if sight-seeing rather than shopping is your main goal, then you can skip it. Nonetheless, this is a very good viewpoint to look at the Sydney Opera House or the Harbor Bridge, but you cannot see them together or put both into the same picture. To get a good view, try the tower at the pier.

One of the best Crafters Markets I've visited. The Weekend Markets cannot be missed if you come to Sydney.Its not just the diversity ... its the raw talent and novel inventiveness of their wares and products. And not the crass chintzy stuff thats manufactured in Mass Market Factories but more local talents and artists. Inventive products that piqued your interest. Jewelry, leather products, home wall decorations, candles, soaps ... all sorts of really unique designs that conveys the character of Sydney and the creative Aussie outlook.We spent 3 hours there and didn't do all the shops justice. Wish we had more time there. The rest of the Rocks was also a nice stroll and allows very nice views of the Sydney Opera house and the Sydney Bridge. There is a pleasant atmosphere of creativity and liveliness that I think also encapsulates the fabulous city.

Love History? Love the Rocks.. It is awesome that some of the first environmental protest in Sydney resulted in the Rocks being saved from redevelopment.
