Blessings on those who stood up to the demolition plans. From the medical history to the oldest pub in Australia it is amazing,and just a five minute walk from Circular Quay. Catch a train and take advantage of the many dining options and the Rocks Discovery Museum (a hidden gem). Unique to Sydney.
Really interesting area. Good for shopping, especially opals! Nice pubs and bars. Interesting markets and artisan shopping and with very good street food.
Great place to stroll about. Nice places to eat, soak up the atmosphere . Saturday and Sunday markets with loads of lovely trinkets.

Shopping. I bought a really nice belt over here. I liked walking the area and seeing what the outdoor vendors had. I was told by some locals that the shopping here is a bit expensive but I didnt find the prices too crazy.

See a bit of the historic city centre. This is a great place for a casual stroll, some nice lunch or dinner or to head to the great weekend markets. It is very close to the city centre and an easy walk from anywhere in the CBD. Make sure you head down to the water front as there are some really nice places for a drink or dinner right under the bridge and next to the water.
The Rocks real rock. Fun place , easy to walk to many other attractions from there.Very good restaurants &good lunch specials There is good shopping here if time is limited .

A great place to stroll.. The Rocks area is a great place to stroll along the waterfront and enjoy the shops and restaurants which there are many to choose from. There is the bus and train station to bring you to this area or walk there if you are in the area staying.

Visit the Sat market . Within walking distance from the Train station, Sydney bridge and Opera house. Along the street there were a lot of choice of food from cafes to restaurants. We went to the market and seriously regretted not bringing enough cash. There were many unique souvenirs and good street food eg burgers, bbq meat, pastries etc. Some stores accept cards but most accept cash especially those selling clothes. From scarves, hats, baby fashion to ladies fashion, there is a wide variety. Parking will definitely be an issue so take the train.

Always good for a pub crawl. Nothing better than an afternoon in the rocks a couple of beers at the fortune of war listening to the guitar. Nice drink at the Glenmore .. All great fun fantastic people watching.

Charming little area with limited food choices at night. This is a charming little area with lots of steps and little areas where shops of various types can be found. The signage is a little bare for a first time visitor and food places don't stay open much past 10 (at least the kitchens don't). The food options are limited and the entire area seems under developed. Maybe this is intentional.
Good history. Good to hear and see the early history of Australia. Very informative via the driver and guide via Greyline. Would recomme d

The Rocks Market and Cafes. Go visit the market for your holiday gifts and to have a nosey round to see what is on offer. The restaurants are great as well, we loved the German restaurant and beer esp as we were there for the beer festival.

Plush and nice. We are staying at the four Seasons hotel the rocks. The area is perfect for everything including the ferry the buses and the harbour the bridge and the Opera house. Visit the ship Inn for a beer and pizza.

Interesting history. The Rocks gives you history of the area throughout the streets. The buildings are interesting & it's a great place to look for that special souvenir. On Fri. night the hag street food vendors & Sat. there were street vendors selling all types of authentic Australian goods.
Went to Belgian coffee shop and it was amasing for me.. The milkshake was very good and there are plenty of people around which gives it a great atmosphere.

Great area!. Great area to stroll around! Great food choices! And you must do the markets on the weekends, all the artisans have such beautiful pieces! And if you want Uggs stop by the store there!!! The woman inside is wonderful !!!

Great for a weekend stroll - Cafes and shopping. I've been to Sydney a couple times and each time I always visit The Rocks because of it's walking distance from the downtown area. It's also got a great feel about it with it's cobblestone streets tucked away from the main roads. If you're looking for souvenirs or if you're looking for something cool that's Australian made are are tons of little booths and shops. It's also a place to get great art. The cafes with seating outside usually offer great sandwiches or pastries with your coffee. Perfect for brunch.The Rocks is also by the water so on nice days you can stroll along the water after brunch. It's a nice place to walk around that's away from the hustle and bustle of downtown.

Don't bother. Tourist trap and not worth the time. I came here as a child and remember a really special place. I'm sure it's fine if you are looking for lively places to go at night but not a great Sydney attraction with the family.
Day out in Sydney. Lovely way to spend an afternoon, just had a lovely stroll and stopped off for a coffee, then later on for a drink, very nice hub about the place

Old Town. This is a lovely area to browse around. Lots of aboriginal artwork to be found. There are also some well priced cafe bars here too. Located at Circular Quay and the train drops you right there. This is where the cruise ships anchor. The Opera House is also located here.

A different side of Sydney. Lots of hills, stairs, tiny alleys and mystery as you walk the maze of paths around the Rocks. A tour will tell you more, but just to wander and think about the history here and beauty of the harbour , is a good way to pass the time. Easy access to the ferries and the Opera house.

Fun. Lovely area steeped in history and intriguing lanes and shopping. Lots of great stalls including one where I got a henna tattoo for a reasonable price. I bought lots of Xmas gifts here though hated the stall that sold animal bones and other body parts. Friendly stall owners happy to chat and help. Also loved the honey shop where I bought a jar infused with cinnamon.

Sat visit with market!. Had a good time walking along the shoreline and then went into The Rock for shopping at the street market. Too bad they close store so early at 4pm. Very interesting products on sale.

Village Bizarre on Fridays. We were able to visit the Village Bizarre "fair" last week on Friday. I think this was happening in Nov and Dec. Many stalls with music, food markets open air dances/performances, and hand crafted arts and crafts. Great weekend spirit.

Excellent. Go on weekends as it is more interesting with many stalls offering interesting arts, crafts and snacks….I enjoyed the place and I will surely be there on every of my visit to Sydney. My 5th times visiting Sydney. Good café, good people and good place to wind down too.
love it. The markets are fantastic, you can walk up and stand under the bridge, there is still a bit of the original road there, make out of this wood stuff, a lot of life going on there.

Wonderful Area. We really enjoyed our visit with friends to The Rocks. It was a Sunday so the markets were running which was great fun. They have all sorts of crafts and gifts to food for sale. We visited the Museum of Contemporary Art which was a must and afterwards had lunch in The Rocks. Expensive but nice if you only visit once in a while.

Full of Culture, History and Class. A must see location when visiting SydneyTucked underneath the Sydney harbor bridge the views and location are amazing. The cobblestone paths and old style buildings really add to the experience and bring alive the history the rocks have to offer.Bring your wallet however as nothing is cheap

History, Markets, Food, places to explore and magic views what more is there??. We spent a five day weekend at The Rocks. We stayed in a Hotel (reviewed later) in The Rocks and it was the perfect location to enjoy all the area has to over and there is so much to do, enjoy explore. The area is towered over by the Harbour Bridge at the top and Circular Quay and the Harbour in front. You can walk to the Powerhouse museum, around the Harbour to the Opera House and the gardens, catch a ferry or explore the shops and hotels and eat houses that are everywhere in the area. The market starts on Friday night and runs thru to Sunday with even more on offer. We walked around the area and into the main body of Sydney. Caught ferries and the hop on hop off bus. We walked upto the Old Observatory, had drinks on our balcony and watched life passing by and indulged in a range of food on offer from street stalls to Rockpool and Quay Restaurants. We maxed out every day and night and still left with more to see and do. Will be back to continue the fun. The tourist station can provide a list of many of the things to try, and if you just get out and walk around you will find a million things to do and how close everything is. Yes some of the area is steep but there are staircases and walk ways everywhere. The area is very safe and fun to get around in. The historical markers and signs provide information about he history of the area and the buildings your looking at. Go and enjoy.
Interesting hisptory. Very interesting history. We walked around on our own so probably missed a lot of information that you gain from tours but interesting all the same.

The Rocks is the place to hang out in Sydney, but it's an expensive tourist area so keep that in mind.. It really does seem that hipsters have taken over the world or at least people that want to be hipsters, because this area is primarily young people with money to spend because it's expensive you. You can enjoy walking about here and that is for free, but I'd suggest eating somewhere else in the city if you're really cost adverse because it's expensive for an expensive city. The value is high and I think if you're going to come here and then do it right and enjoy it with nice food and drinks and company or for a solo outing if that's your thing. That's what I do. Enjoy!

A small piece of recent history. I was expecting the Rocks to be something quite different from what it eventually turned out to be. There are a few short buildings belonging to a bygone era, but not too far into the past when you consider that there is not such a long history to modern Australia. So when you see these short old structures juxtaposed with the modern high-rises along the Harbour you might, if you come from an ancient land like I do, probably wonder what's the big history here to put it into the tourist itinerary ? Well, it's just a few steps past the Sydney Harbour and Circular Quay so just walk there and get another perspective of the Harbour.

History and Modern. The Rocks is a maze of early australian settlement,many old buildings to explore,close to the heart of the city and close to the most beautiful harbour in the world.Week ends are abuzz with modern markets. A joy for all the family.

LOVED the Rock Market!. What Sydney Harbour Bridge Climb is complete without some shopping below at the Rock Market. We scored big here - jewelry, arts, crafts, high-end touristy booths - we loved it. I found a jewelry stall at the beginning (by Cumberland St) and it pulled in about 6 others from our group (and I wound up being both the first and last purchase of the day). Great spot!!
Quirky area. Very quirky beautiful area, get lost amongst the bars and shops and discover hidden gems nestled away in the rocks, very good atmosphere and a wide range of bars and eateries

Hidden Gem Of Sydney. This is a must do when in Sydney!! Great to do the FREE walking tour at 6pm around the rocks tells you all the history of the area, so pleased that they never demolished it (as they wanted to) as some Great feeds here, we stopped at The Harts pub many times while here, also great little place to walk around and just take everything in.

Nice place to visit.. The place is very historical, it has good view if it happens there is cruise births there. There are good cafes and some big brand shops there as well. In all, it's a very nice place to go regardless you are a visitor or living in Sydney.
Must see Tourist sight in Sydney. Weekend markets. Lots of Cafes and restaurants. Gorgeous cobblestone streets to wander through and always something happening.
On the rocks. From what I had been told I was expecting more. It's quite nice a few shops a few restaurants not a large area. An average place to see once.
Historic, quirky. I love The Rocks - steeped in history, fabulous old pubs and places to visit. I go back every time I'm in Sydney.
Love this area. So much to do and see. Harbour Bridge, Opera House, Markets, Museums, Observatory Hill, History. Just walking around the old back alleys you get a sense of the past.
The Rocks, Rocks.. Bit pricey, but great food and pubs. Theres markets there on the weekend (the fudge is good) and great for a little day trip.
Great Location for Visitors. Great location to visit whilst in Sydney, bustling with tourists, great views of the area and a relaxing destination to spend a few hours.

The Rocks where Captain Phillips landed Rock. My son (12 ) and I clambered the stairs to see the Rocks Area near the bottom of the Sydney Harbor Bridge (I had seen in in 1972, 1984 and 1987 ). There were Crocodile Dundee Hats, wine bottle holders , lizards and hundred of t-shirts for sale. We went in one shop that was an exclusive opal dealer. I purchased my opals in Australia from 1972 to 1975. We walked around the harbour to the nearby Circular Quay. It was a very relaxing half day. There was also an open food market where you could eat a very nice meal.

Vibrant street walk. Do drop by here if you are around the area. The atmosphere here is quite pleasant and they do have nice restaurants around the area. The pubs can be buzzing with patrons on Fridays and Saturdays so do get there early. On weekends, there are flea markets you can visit in the morning.

Historic Rocks. We just can't get enough of this beautiful heritage area. The views are unsurpassed and you can't help but take a step back in time walking along the streets with it's beautiful sandstone and lovingly restored buildings. We always stop at Caminetto's for an Italian meal at a great price or a light meal on market day. The corn on the cob is the best. Superb.

Beautiful Historic Area. There are an abundance of cafes and restaurants in this area. So close to the city and amazing views. It is an historic area found nowhere else in Australia. The architecture and vibe of the area is stunning

Love the markets. Definitely great coming down here where the first settlers settled. Now abuzz with restaurants, cafes and shops. Best on weekends with the markets, lots of unusual crafts made by Australians. Great gifts to take overseas.

SO SYDNEY. the first time i went to the rocks i was 18 and went to the orient hotel. had a great great great night. night life there's always groups of people on night's out at the rocks.i think there was 20 to 30 of us when we went out that night. That was 20 years ago. now i do a food crawl at the markets. a wonderful patisserie but there's like million things to do there at the Rock markets. it's a must.
The Rocks Markets. Having been 3 times , enjoy the many tourists converging on the weekend markets ( Sat and Sunday ), we love a German Beer and continue the people watching at the L.. Keller
History and great pubs. a must see and do for visitors and locals. Great weekend markets. Historic pubs and landmarks. Good shopping

On your own or on a tour. If you do the free Sydney walking tour you will get some info on this area that is very interesting. We also did a pub tour through foodi that gave us history on this area as well. You can visit on your own but maybe read up on the area so you know what all the signs are referring to.

a bit over trendy, but nice bars & restaurants. nice place to stay, as the cbd is empty & chinese. rocks has good nightlife, is close to the water and has good bars and restaurants.
a bit over exaggerated by aussies, but still worth a look.
nice walk and ambiance. nice walk and ambiance, has a day market, at night NO place to find a table to eat, unless you have made reservations
Great trip. We went over to Manly and really enjoyed the views and the trip. It was good weather which helped with the views of the iconic buildings and the bridge.
Vibrant area. Great area to spend time wandering around the numerous bars, returns and shops. Some beautiful buildings and interesting alleyways and flights of step to spend hours exploring.

Amazing and Full of History. A well preserved area to depict the history of families living during 1800-1900, their lifestyle etc. Definitely recommended to do organized tours and visit the Rocks Market.
Fun, fashionable, historic. Beautiful enclave in Sydney with numerous eateries, a daily sidewalk food "bazaar" and location of the best opal stores in Sydney, according to residents.
Amazing history and buildings. A must visit with outstanding old buildings well preserved and the history of Sydney told here, great photo opportunities

Sydney's Early European History. A quaint historical area of Sydney with old sandstone buildings, pubs, back streets and interpretive information on signs, in street paving and in the buildings themselves. Many a tourist shop, cafe and on weekends a market.

Great place to wander around. As others have said its a great place to check out over a weekend. Good pubs and food. Don't stick to the main areas. Wander around the side streets and spend time along the harbour foreshore as well.

Always busy and full of life with lots to see and do. We love this area because it never sleeps so you have ample opportunities to wander and explore with good coffee and great food not to mention that wonderful harbour and the historic buildings.
Old time charm. This is a great place to walk around and take in the olden day charm, this is where the first settlers set up shop, many good drinking place and restaurants
Great area. The Rocks is a great area to walk around. If you go on a Friday or the weekend, there are markets to wander through. There are also plenty of restaurants in the area.

Enjoyed the historical significance of the area. We spent a few hours in the Rocks using an online recommended walking tour. It was quite interesting and we enjoyed the views and the people we talked with. Had dinner at a lovely restaurant with outdoor sidewalk seats. Food was amazing and the ambience was very romantic. Recommend late afternoon or evening to see the harbor in a different light.

Good for History & Charming pubs. Great place to stroll around and find little interesting / historical laneways to walk through. Be sure to head to The Lord Nelson, Glenmore (on the rooftop), the Australian and the Fortune of War for a brew or 2. In the past I would've recommended the Hero of Waterloo but it didn't have the same charm when I was there a few weeks ago. Almost felt like a tourist attraction. Drinks are relatively pricey in the area but definitely worth a visit.

Over estimated.. The Rocks in Sydney is extremely over estimated. It is quiet a pleasant area of Sydney however be warned almost everything you can purchase in this area is very over priced. The area itself is certainly worth a look with some nice hotels and eateries. With a mix of the old and the new as far as the buildings are concerned. Close to circular Quay for ferries as well as close to the Sydney rail network it is well positioned. The Street that the Rocks is in (George St) is currently undergoing major works so using public transport would be wise. From this area you can walk to Sydney harbour bridge, and the Sydney observatory both well worthy of a visit. Indeed from the Sydney observatory ( high up on a hill) you will get a magnificent view of the surrounding area including the bridge. Nice area for a half day stroll and meal. Most produce in this area is made in China and very over prices. You can walk to this area from anywhere in the city, if you require a reference point whilst checking a map use the Sydney harbour bridge.

Get away from the main strip. Get away from the main strip and take a wander down the back streets on the North side. Fantastic period buildings (sadly under threat from developers), micro brewerys and views across circular quay and the CBS and great place to while away an afternoon.

Explore it with ample time. I was there some years ago but never realized the beauty of it as I was only strolling up George Street. Give yourself sometime and enjoy the walk further along Kent Street. You will be amazed by all the old architecture and restaurants. See the pics for yourself.

Must see!. The best time to visit this place is during Fridays when there is the Foodie's Market or during weekends. This place has a whole lots of character and some amazing food and shopping options. About a 5-10mins walk from the Circular Quay train station

Great historical precinct. Ventured down to The Rocks on a Saturday arvo and Sunday morning. Visited the markets which had some different stalls on each day. Listened to buskers ate from food stalls and had a few beers at one of the many hotels/pubs in the area. Historical area with plenty too see. Always visit when in town.

Great area. I went to the Rocks often and definitely recommend it. I ate at a few restaurants that were good and also went to the Friday Night Bizarre event - worth the visit. Cool views of the Harbor Bridge and also right by the Opera house.
great old buildings steeped in history. This is a must see . Great to see the old buildings restored , there are lots of eating places here Great views all around but can be expensive place to eat at

Saturday markets. What a fantastic atmosphere so much to see and a great variety of stalls . But tge food is what we loved most and a quiet beer in one of the many small pubs in the area . We could easy spend a few hours jyst wandering around and checking out the great architecture

This place screams "PUB CRAWL". On a warm balmy Sydney night I can think of no place better to enjoy and easy stroll and taste all the various beverages on offer.
Start at the end near the Harbour Bridge and see how far you can get, if you're really adventurous take the stairs and head towards those 'hidden gems'
Cool to see. Was heat during week and on weekend. Weekend time to be here. Outdoor market, nice things to take home not flea market

Step back in time. Our ship berthed adjacent to the ‘Rocks’ – the historical first European settlement area of Sydney. on the other side of Circular Key and its bustling ferries is the world famous Sydney Opera House The Rocks area nestling under Sydney Harbor Bridge was once pretty derelict and almost forgotten however now it has been re-birthed and is a bustling entertainment and culinary mecca. The facades of all of the old buildings have been retained and in many cases the interior features remain but where there were ware houses there is now fine dining. The area is well lighted and very busy of an evening. If you are into photography, Make sure your camera is fully charged.

Wonderful. Great place!! So full of character and life. Loved it down there. A few schooners of beer and some great food ! Some of the classic Aussie hotels and bars really haven't lost the charm of old !

Walk among history. The Rocks is a cradle of early settlement in Sydney. Great upscale markets on the weekend. Lots of restaurants. Historical tours, even a ghost our. Close to Circular Quay train station, the ferries and the Opera house. Easy access to the Harbour Bridge, whether doing the climb or just strolling its length. Early preserved architectural features.
Charming area - terrific at weekends. Very large street market, with not too many daft things on offer - good for souvenirs and instant eats.

Walk through history. My advice would be to take a rocks walking tour otherwise you will not appreciate what you are seeing and you will miss a lot of others sight tucked away down the side streets and alleyways.Steeped in the history of a nation being born and surviving through very difficult times. I have been to sydney before in 2003 and walked around the rocks area but somehow had missed all this history.

Old time preserved. The Rocks would have been demolished and turned into high rise CBD in 70's. Thanks to the locals, the oldest part of Sydney is preserved. You are walking into old time once you step into the Rocks. European style architecture, interesting shops and good cafes. You will surely have an enjoyable and relaxing afternoon there. In comparison, Melbourne city is more like a circus.

Nice place to take a walk. Lots of cute shops although expensive fun to wonder through. Lots of choice places to eat. Pubs along the way too. Nice views with lots of photo opts bring a camera stop for cold beer. Full of history in the old part of Sydney
Love the Rocks. Plenty to do and see been several times and not seen it all. Always something new and interesting to see, do, buy or just stroll around

A great stroll through the origins of Sydney. We have strolled through the Rocks Precinct many times and always find ourselves having a coffee of combing through stores or the market stalls. The history and beauty is well worth the effort.

Interesting, historical, fun to walk around. Our hotel was right in The Rocks so we walked around a lot. A historical "dig" is ongoing with some access for the public. There are nooks and crannies to explore, little shops, interesting places to eat, and more. Just relax, and walk.
Worth a visit. Worth a visit if you like to shop. Also quite beautiful. Some wonderful heritage buildings and beautiful waterfront.

Nice buzz but a bit commercial. There is a little bit of history to be found here but it is really set up as a place for the cruise ship passengers to spend their money as they dock nearby. Good atmosphere and some interesting stalls. Couple of good pubs.

Definitely a MUST when visiting Sydney. Definitely don't miss an opportunity to wander through this old iconic part of Sydney. There are loads of trendy eateries and of course they have the Rocks Handcraft Market on Saturdays and Sundays where you have a chance to buy all sorts of quirky and interesting things.

Wonderful shops and atmosphere!. The Rocks is a wonderful area filled with cobblestone streets and artists displaying their many wares. All along the streets are old buildings which remind me of the French Quarter of New Orleans with more shops and charming restaurants. I highly recommend this as a must-see while in Sydney!

Rocks market. The market opens Sat and Sun from 10am to 5pm. U can find many local made products including home made candies, leather bags, paintings and all different sorts of souvenirs that u can bring home. Nice cafe around.

Fun Place To Be. The Rocks open market is great on Saturdays and Sundays. Lots of bars and restaurants in the area makes this the “in-place” to be for fun. Great location for visiting the Sydney Harbor Bridge and harbor. The Rocks' open street market was great on Friday and weekend.

Long Walk. We didn't plan properly and ended up walking toward Pottinger Street so we decided to take a break at Pottinger Park.The piers nearby were somewhat deserted but once we scaled a long flight of stairs towards George Street, we hit the crowd with all the cafes and restaurants.Lovely views of the Sydney Harbour Bridge from many spots at The Rocks.

A pleasant stroll. The area is full of shops from boutique to the usual souvenirs. Also has a lot of historical points of interest with details on plaques throughout the area. A pleasant stroll with fabulous views over Circular Quay, the Opera House, the Bridge & the harbour. A nice place just to relax and take in the sights.

Nicer on the Weekend. Great market area located around the rocks on the weekend (check for times and dates) heaps of nice resturants for breakfast lunch and dinner. Otherwise a nice area full of history great for a wander

Very nice market. The Rocks offers the best market in Sydney! Even if you don't buy anything, it is very pleasant just having a walk in the market. Many delicate artworks, accessories etc there. Prices are generally high though. Make sure you check their opening days before you confirm your journey if you are a market-lover. The museums there are interesting to visit as well. They tell you the history beyond the city we see today.
Very Nice Restaurant. Cant fault the place or the food, it was excellent and we even got a balcony table. Quite expensive but worth it for the food.

Beautiful old part of town. I never get sick of The Rocks andvits superb history. It is steeped in the olden day times with fantastic architecture. The Rocks market is eonderful on Saturdays and Sundays, i always stop by for a gozleme.

Overly directed at the tourist market. While the Rocks retains its charm having had an association with the area for over 40 years I find the loss of the original shops e.g. the Shell Shop with tourist tack disappointing. Naturall with the international terminal immediately adjacent to the start of the rocks at the Quay there will be enterprise directed towards collecting the tourist $ so my advice is to keep away for the themed pubs and move a little further afield to the western side of the headland for a good pub experience. Having said that the waterfront group of restaurants offer reasonably priced (for the location) meals and stunning views of the quay and the opra house. The Rocks were of course at the forefront of the Green Bans in Sydney in the 1970s - it will be interesting to see how matters develop with the NSW Govt pulling out of the home market in the Rocks/Millers Point area - hopefully much of the character can be retained even if sadly many of the residents will not remain.

CAPTURE A BIT OF OLD SYDNEY TOWN HISTORY. Sydney is relatively young but here at the Rocks, history has been preserved and it is delightful to stroll around the many alleys and back streets. There are restaurants aplenty to choose from, the oldest pub in Sydney to explore. Fantastic area and oh so close to all those other attractions that Sydney has to offer.
Fab. Fascinating place, so many interesting things to see, one of the highlights of Sydney for me, not to be missed.
Always interesting. Wandered around before boarding cruise ship, always plenty to see. Unfortunately it was raining so we just had brunch at a great cafe on the Main Street.
Fun place to wander and shop. I love places that have art and unique artifacts. Had a great time wandering the shops and stimulating the economy. I will go back to see the Rocks Museum.

Lovely walking and dining. The Rocks does have a special atmosphere. It is nice for just walking around, doing some small shopping or having a nice lunch or dinner (reservation needed) - excellent food including fresh fish.

Lots of history in these rocks!. We had a guided tour of the Rocks and surrounding neighborhoods. The area is very interesting, especially the "Big Dig" where you can see the various levels of occupation. To fully appreciate it you need to walk up the stairs and small streets to capture the feel of what it must have been like to live on a rocky hillside. The stories of the early convicts who lived there and developed businesses was fascinating. The lower part of the area now contains a number of botique stores and eating places, and there are also some of the older "hotels/pubs" with local beers that are great fun.

A Shoppers Delight. visiting at weekend the area was transformed into market stalls selling everything from food to souvenirs, handbags, clothes and much more. There were excellent musicians on every corner and in the bars and cafes. Very pleasurable.

Great option near our hote. We stayed at the holiday inn old Sydney and the rocks were right there near the hotel. They have several great options for breakfast, lunch, and dinner. Like most of Sydney, the food prices are a bit pricey.

A fun day out. You have to take the family down to the Rocks for the markets. Have a shop, have a few drinks and bring the kids. When you're done for the day head down to the docks and watch the street vendors and sit on the lawn.

Fun and light-hearted . We headed down on a weekend so it was a little crowded but the little pop up stores were really fun to look at. Easy to navigate and very relaxing to grab a bite and sit somewhere as you watch the crowd go by.

Nice place to walk around and eat. This place is opposite the Circular Quay and Opera house.There are many restaurants around. There is a market there on every Friday to Sunday where there are stalls selling souvenirs, food, clothings etc etc. Good to browse around as there are about 100 stalls there. From there you can get a good view of the Harbour bridge. There is also a small park opposite where you can sit and enjoy the cool breeze.

Friday Foodie Market. We stayed in The Rocks area and really enjoyed the two meals from the Foodie Market. We had Turkish Cozlene and Kabobs. This is an area that isn't very commercial and is close to the Circular Quay and its train station and ferry terminals. There are good restaurants and view of the Opera House. It's work walking around on your own or as part of a walking tour.
Must See. must see for great oldschool pubs like Fortune of War, historical laneways, awesome views and restaurants.

A very centric part of Sydney, where you can see wonderful views, walk and buy. The Rocks is a Harbour part of Sydney located between Sydney Cove and Darling Habrour. Here you can see wonderful views of the Harbour, the Harbour Bridge and the Opera House is in front. Here there are a lot of turistical attractions like Museum of Contemporary Art, Macquarie Place and Campbell's Storehouses. It is a very good site to walk, buy gifts and dinner in any restaurant.(thank you dad for this gift)
Walking Tour. Came to the Rocks on a walking tour. Not lots to see here but the stories related to this area a very interesting .

Best Way to see the Rocks and its history. If you are interested in the history of the Rocks, I highly recommend taking the I'M Free Rocks tour walking which starts at Cadman's Cottage 6pm and lasts ~90 minutes.
Markets at The Rocks. Great place to go on a Saturday or Sunday to look at all sorts of things at the markets and food stalls.

Great place to visit and explore. The historic centre of Sydney and a great place to explore with lots of little hidden little lanes and shops. It is well preserved and had lots to see and do. The markets on the weekend are well worth a visit especially by visitors who want something unusual or artistic. The pubs are great and it's an awesome place to stay in the local hotels.

Great to wander around the markets. Went here on a Saturday so the market stalls were on the streets. Nice place to go browsing and/or looking for a unique gift.Kids were with us so couldn't stay long as they kept running off. Best to go without them for a better time.A variety of lovely fresh smelling and tasting food being cooked there too.
Shop til you Drop. On weekends, they have an outdoor market. Tons of shops in this area with some unique products. And of course, UGGs are everywhere.
Great Place for a Stroll. The Rocks is an area which is a great place for a stroll. Check out the buildings and the market which features Australian-made goods. Also a great place to grab a gelato.

Super Trendy--Love the hustle and bustle. There was a Friday Foodie Market and then a huge Saturday and Sunday market with all local artisans. There are so many restaurants, good things to see and the hub of Sydney.

Historic Sydney. It is mind boggling to think that the local council actually thought about demolishing this iconic area some years ago. The Rocks is a Sydney landmark that gives a glimpse into its past. Well worth taking the time to look around and take in the sights and sounds. Be sure to check out the buildings themselves rather than just peer in the windows.

Rocks market rocks. We visited Rocks market on Sunday afternoon. This market is more than I expected. There are lots of Australian made products, from household products, leather, glasses, toys etc. We bought quite a few for ourselves and family. Just to note that market closes at 5pm.
Quaint scape. Quaint and beautiful townscape 5 minutes away on foot from the harbor. Lots of nice restaurants are there.

interesting markets. On weekends, there is an arts and crafts market.. many interesting locally produced goods.. some paintings, jewelery and other goods.. above all, it is a great walk around including the sydney harbour

Visit the weekend market. We just love the Rocks. A cool place to hang out for young and old. Great shops and bars. Street music adds to the atmosphere. Great place at the weekend as there is a market which is very up market!

Visiting the Rocks.. Very steep and hilly area. Looked at the market stalls with a very varied selection of goods on a Sunday. Climbed up steps and over bridge to grassed area by Observatory and found magnificent views arround Harbour. Lots of activity going on. Walked back down past 'Bridge Climb' start point and back through more markets and past 1800's buildings. Very interesting area.
Great area to spend the day and night. A village in the centre of Sydney, with Plenty of great bars and restaurants. Weekend market and unusual boutiques and gift shops.
Overrated. I had a high expectations about this area, because i read so many great reviews. Turns out it's just a so-so place.

What a fascinating place. We stayed for six days in The Rocks recently and enjoyed walking down tiny cobblestone lanes, up and down the many steps, and discovering the history of this beautifully preserved area. We ate at lots of different pubs and restaurants and walked everywhere. The Rocks is one of those gems with so much to explore. We'll have to visit again, as there's still so much to see.

A must visit when in Sydney, especially on weekends.. A walk around the rocks is amazing, ensure you don't just walk the main street, walk all the back streets. Our preference is to go on a weekend when all the street market stalls are open. Great variety of shops, great old pubs. A must when in Sydney.

Not much going on. Had a walk around here last night. Struggled to find the centre or something going on, it was very sparse and not very exciting despite all the hype. Not really sure what all the fuss is about

Interesting area to spend your day!. Went to the Rocks for its Sunday Market and was pleasantly surprised by the vibrancy of this area. A wine festival was happening while we were there, so we got to see wines from different regions around the world plus the cheeses. The market was interesting thought rather small in scale. Due to the rain, we went for lunch at a restaurant named "Pancakes on the Rocks". It was not that easy to find but certainly worth the effort as it offered many interesting varieties of pancakes along with other items such as crepes and nachos.

Bustling Rocks. On a chilly Sunday, we wandered down The Rocks, and smack in the middle of all the bustling activity of the weekend market! Came out with quite a few fine finds: luscious body butter, trinkets, massage oils, local artist sketches, all kinds of great stuff peddled there! The Rocks was so much more appealing appealing to me on this visit than years ago. Everything looked interesting and intriguing! The weekend market was great. Didn't get to do any wine-tasting since we were already a bit buzzed from our wine-paired meal @Lowenbrau. The Rocks really rocked (pardon the pun)! The markets made it just that much more fun!

History and Location. The Rocks is located in an area with early Sydney/Australian history mixed with a modern feel. The historic stone buildings, laneways and stairways entice you to wonder further through the area. There are plenty of eateries and lots of activity at Circular Quay.It is close to many Sydney sites including the Opera House, Harbour Bridge, museums, Botanic Gardens and efficient public transport. From our accommodation at The Rocks we were able to reach most places on foot.

Great area for a walk and bite to eat. Many fun shops, restaurants and bars. Local handicraft market provides nice Australian gifts to take back. Historical tours can be done via many of the hotel concierge.

Great tour. We had a short 20 minute tour as part of the grayline sydney tour. Needless to say it was great our guide Nathan was helpful and a great tour guide. I would definitely recommend going here

The oldest part of Sydney. Lots of older buildings and warehouses. The main attraction is the harbour, restaurants and shopping. We found ja great French Pastry shop and sampled the wares and the cafe. We were lucky to be visiting on the weekend hey hold an artisan market, a lot of fun.
Nice area! . We wondered through here after getting the train to circular quay. It's a lovely location right by the bridge and the opera house. Nice shops just to potter around.
Must do. A very history filled morning we had. Wander all the streets and alleyways in this area go to the fantastic small pubs in the back streets.

The Rocks - ROCK!!!!!!. Very interesting historic area to visit.Highly recommended to join the free walking tour that delve into the history of The Rocks, the site of Australia’s first European settlement. The tour explores its lane ways, pubs, and historical buildings and tell you its stories of murders, muggings and mysteries. At the end of the tour, give a token to the guide, if you wish.Lot of restaurants, café shops.Well worth spending half a day.

Plenty to see and do. Market stalls are open Friday nights and all day Sunday. Friday nights there are plenty of place to enjoy a drink. If you want a view try Cruise Bar and enjoy the Opera House view. The top of the Shangri La hotel also has a rooftop bar with fabulous views. The Argyle is popular with locals for after 5 drinks. The Orient has live bands Friday night if you feel like dancing. The Mercantile has live bands as well even on Sunday afternoons. Great restaurants from 5 star to great snack food at the markets. Plenty of tiny little streets to wander around. Lots to see and do here. The Observatory offers excellent star gazing tours.

Loved this older area of Sydney..lots happening here.. I loved this older area of Sydney, along the harbour, has some great old streets, now filled with cool boutiques, restaurants, and the Museum of Contemporary Arts is also here. A must see..

Lovely area with interesting and different arts and crafts. We rather fell upon the Rockes after a walk on the newly restored Barangaroo Reserve. It was a busy Saturday at the market but all the stall holders were really friendly and took time to talk about their craft. I found some great fabric bought direct from the weaver. The Irish pub,over 100years old, left a bit to be desired on the service front but ok for a drink. The rocks are well worth a visit.

The Rocks - Sydney. A must visit area especially if you are in Sydney on the weekend as there are interesting markets which are different from other markets, the stalls here are are makers markets and some interesting, different and quirky stalls from jewlery, fashion for women and children, toys, foods, fabrics, bath oils soaps and body oils, art etc. some things can be a bit pricey so be aware. Lovely cafes and eateries as well

Fascinating historic area. The Rocks area adjacent to the Circular Quay transport hub has many interesting historical buildings, places to eat, and go shopping. The walk along George St to the area under the Harbour Bridge is always a great thing to do - looking up at the bridge structure or out across the harbour with all its scurrying boats. Always memorable

Markets. Excellent markets option. Lots of food options. The rocks is an old beautiful location in Sydney with lots of quaint shopsand cafe right near the Sydney Harbour Bridge. Markets include jewelry, chocolate, clothes soap etc.

The Rocks Markets. Located at Playfair and George streets, Jack Mundey Place, The Rocks, the markets are open from 1000 to 1700 Saturdays and Sundays. Women will probably enjoy this activity more than their husbands. This open-air market is situated between the harbour and Harbour Bridge. Crafts, jewellery, homewares, beauty products, textiles, local art, and assorted doo-dads are to women what sports are to men.

Good tourist shopping. Nice shops, easy to walk and lots of choices for restaurants. The Rocks are right beside all the ferries and where the cruise ships dock. The cafes that are scattered throughout are all pretty good for breakfast or lunch.

Back to the old time. This is a historical site where I get to see the first settlement in Sydney was. The area around the Harbour Bridge has many alleys and history to learn about the earlier days. Not only that, there is a very nice pancake restaurant that opens 24 hours. A very nice area too from hanging out with mates in the evening as several bars and pubs are open. Although it is located in the CBD area but the old buildings are simply magnificent.

Lots of interesting nooks and crannies.. Beautiful historic area of Sydney. There is a free 6 pm walking tour available to do and a free Muesum also. Walking around here through the day is lovely too. Make sure to walk down the narrow alleys and be surprized at the lovely little places you can find. The is a great tourist information centre here and sweet little cafes. Good markets held every Saturday.
Sunday markets are the best my lady loves it. Resturants galore you could eat out every night and have something different , people all having a great time. Can walk from the hotel makes it. A must.

A Walking Tour of the city and the Rocks. We walked around the rocks and the market , and we saw what was the old houses, very small and on top of each other, in each space there were art work of large chairs, tables and cupboards.
Great Place one of the Highlights of a stay in Sydney. My Favourite pub is also here the Orient so it is always somewhere I head but also plenty of restaurants, shops and markets

Interesting - History - Markets- Location Location Location. Love the Rocks the buildings and history surrounding this amazing area right in the hub of Sydney is a MUST SEE ... all the cobblestone alleys you can almost hear the convicts and shenanigans that area was infamous for in our early settling days.
Shopping is awesome, eateries are plentiful and varied not to mention delicious.

Step back into history.. An interesting place to visit with some of Sydney's historical places to enjoy. Great shops and restaurants can be found and the weekend markets are a must for visitors with a variety of products to buy.If you are coming to Sydney on a cruise ship and berth at Circular Quay the Rocks are within walking distance to where you will berth.The rocks are also within walking distance to Curcular Quay railway station and buses .There are many waterfront restaurants here with Harbour and Opera House views, a great way to relax at the end of the day.If you are driving here, parking can be a problem,especially on the weekend.

Quaint & full of character . This little corner is full of heritage and character. The markets are a must see! And the cafes alongside them are very cute, all fitting the same decor style. Great area along darling harbour. Harbour side is full of buskers.

Must see if you are in Sydney. This area is full of history. Many Museums and historical buildings. There are tons of shops and Food and Pubs. If you can be there on a Sunday they have a Market Place that is full of local vendors and artist and all types of food goodies to try. This is a great place to spend a day at and still never see it all .. great on foot and some stairs and hills so if you have any issues with walking it might be a little challenge.

The Rocks Tourist Trap. My Mother liver there, so been all over. Great place to just walk around and enjoy our short history. Stay out of the overpriced and touristy stores. You can buy the same things cheaper elsewhere. If you are a foreign visitor do not expect to see anything on a par with Europe's old areas. A trip to the observatory is worth a visit. The food is very good at all of the restaurants I took my Mum to, for Mothers Day but I would not normally eat there due to price especially with the family and or on a budget. Not a place to take the kids to on New Years eve as it is so packed with people, many of whom have had to much to drink. Other side of the Harbor is far better.The old Pubs etc are nice but nowhere as interesting or full of character as those of Europe and Britain etc.Actually some of them are um um ....not so goodBasically the Rocks is just a nice place to walk around, take some great bridge photos and enjoy the harbor view
Soul of Sydney. In my opinion this is the soul of Sydney. Great pubs and restaurants mixed with the feeling for the roots of this great city

Surprises lurking around every corner.. The city of Sydney did a good job restoring the old streets and alleys of Rocks. Where I live in Los Angeles we have have Olivera St, which is only a couple of city blocks, the Rocks district must be at least 6 square kilometers of many historical buildings as well as modern facilities such as 5 star hotels, restaurants, and B&B's (old style not air).You cannot miss this area of Sydney!

Great place to walk around! . This is a historical part of Sydney. We tried to visit the oldest pub in the area, but we're unable to get in as it was so packed! We enjoyed the street markets! We had pizza & beer flights at the Australian Hotel, highly recommended by our tour guide.
Historic Sydney. The "Rocks" is the historic district of the original criminal colony. In addition to historic buildings and restaurants, it has a large & very popular market on weekends.
Moving in its simplicity . A moving monument to those who though at cutting edge of another imperial venture were striving for survival a world away from home.

Big big changes around the area.. I have always looked forward to a walk around the area known as the rocks, but on this visit it was apparent that the area is changing to a more commercial way of life. The old style bars and shops are gradually being replaced by modern facilities and l am concerned that in a few more re years the 'old' magic of the rocks will be lost forever.

Colonial Heritage Central in this unmissable place. Walk around the Rocks is an escape that I enjoy often. To walk in the footsteps of earlier days no matter what the weather is. The pubs have their own characters. The back lanes and food places are fantastic. To stand on Observatory Hill overlooking The Rocks and with the Bridge. So many photos launched by or from The Rocks. Escape the extremely close City of Sydney. Complete the picture of Sydney with The Rocks.
Lovely change of pace. After rushing around the city, The Rocks was a very welcome change of pace. Interesting shops and great little cafes were everywhere.

There is so much history at every turn.. The best thing about the Rocks Sydney is just being there, the atmosphere, the harbour at the bottom of each road, the cobble stone pathways. There are plenty of shops for tourists and various little converted restaurants and lovely old pubs for a drink. But the Rocks is so rich in Histrory of Australia it makes me proud to be an Aussie. We love it there and go oftern.

Quaint historic Excursion, must see. Weekend outdoor market is an attraction the bubbles with life, live music, and local artisans . A stop a the Rocks museum (free) and dining at one of the inviting indoor and outdoor eateries adds both satisfaction and character. Just a short walk from the Circular Quay (public transit and activity hub)

So much to enjoy. The heart of Sydney's origins and so much has been retained - the signs and photographs along George Street show the transition from a colonial settlement to a modern dynamic city. More than just history now, it is a major tourist part of Sydney with shops, hotels, cafes, bars and restaurants without the high rise that dominate the CBD not too far away.

History it's Best. Loved all the old building and laneways around the Rocks. There are information signed everywhere that give you all the background info you need. The free museum and free tour walks are a must. Such a well set up and run area of Sydney.
Day in the city. Always a great place to visit and stroll around the lanes and streets.Great variety of food places, boutique stores, galleries markets every Sunday.
Luxury. was a great place to discover..however time was an issue while travelling at the Rocks. the shops close very early and we had no chance to visit all the shops we wanted to..

History. We were lucky enough to stay on The Rock,I loved the feel of what it must have been like early in its history and enjoyed the atmosphere. The old shops are a detail and it's a short walk from the ferries and hoppa bus.
The heart of Sydney. Start in Argyle Street taking in the museum, shops, boutiques, cafes and harbour views then push on down George Street enjoying a pint in one of the pubs.

We stayed at the Sydney YH on the Rocks. The Rocks is a historic area of Sydney harbour. We stayed at the Youth Hostal on the rocks in a private room, and Sunday we enjoyed the art and food fair. There are very interesting shops in this area. It is UPHILL so be prepared to walk
The Rocks Market. Great little (well biggish) market, good stalls with lots of interesting things to buy. Great location for doing other activities before or after

Rocks Museum - great interactive exhibits. Great presentation of the discovery and early settlement of Australia - suitable for all ages with hands-on showcases ......
and free of charge!

Great place to pick up Australian gifts. Some really lovely shops and art galleries - I picked up some gifts ranging from Ugg boots to river pearl bracelets. A must if you are in the Circular Quay area.

Great to spend a morning. We only had a limited time here but well worth it.Beautiful weather and wondered around after having been on an amazing harbour tour.Nice little souvenir shops with local souvenirs .Bought some great coasters and a print of koalas.Not sure we would have wanted to explore if a cruise ship had been in.A small supermarket just up the hill stocked plenty of refreshments and we had an enjoyable time consuming them and watching the world go buy. Very clean here and would definitely go again.

Love this historic area of old Syndey town. As I get older I love this area of Sydney more. From the art and craft galleries, the historic pubs and walks and the history, take your time and fully appreciate this area, thought I wouldn't like to be there on a 'cruise ship day'!

Charming Place!. It's a charming, historical place where nice cafes can be found, and if you visit on a weekend, you'll find lots of cool stuff in the Rocks Market. The Museum of Contemporary Art is also in the area. It is accessible by ferry, train or bus.
The Rocks Markets are Unique. We enjoyed the Rocks Market as they offered stalls that we had not seen before. The location is wonderful - easy to get to - nice atmosphere on a sunny day

Amazing area . Before getting to Sydney I hadnt heard of this area and came across it on our way to Sydney Harbour Bridge. This area is amazing. Its full of so much history and is so well preserved. The houses are fantastic. Definately recommend and watch out for the weekend markets

Oktoberfest. Oktoberfest dear Ocktoberfest what a great experiance, drinking beer more beers and meeting new poeple what a great way to explore The Rocks when ever you are in Sydney this is the must gi to place lots of good drinking places especially during October 👍
Nice place for a stroll. Nice area near the Opera House. It has an interesting history. Little lanes, shops and restaurants. Nice place to stroll round.

Sydney's No. 1 place to Walk. A must to see when visiting Sydney. I recommend just walking and take in all the sites, e.g. Old original Sydney Buildings, walk under the Sydney Harbour Bridge, view Sydney Harbour Passenger Terminal, Circular Key Ferry Terminal, Sydney Opera House and the many many cafe's, restaurants and pubs/hotels.
A great day out for all people, whether young or old.

Sydney in one place. The Rocks is a must for all visitors to Sydney. Great views across the Harbour to the Opera House and looking towards Manly. Plenty of eateries & bars, quirky shops and fantastic history. A great place for a pub crawl !

Always interesting and full of history!!. I've loved the rocks since i was a little girl...but now I live away I find it even more fascinating....love the rocks markets...always find something different to buy!! Well worth a visit.

Rocks adventure. Rocks is a nice place to have a walk
Drink
Food
And markets on certain days and nights
Great get together for Friday drinks
Some nice pubs for celebrating

Wedding. We went for a friends wedding around the Rocks on a Saturday, the place was buzzing, the markets were amazing and varieties of lexurious goods on offer were great.
It's a nice place for a morning stroll, weekend brunch or a night out.
A hope and a skip from the train station, on the bus routs and near the ferries
Great day and night. I recently found out my wife's family owned The Fortune of War Pub est. 1828 and is Sydney's oldest pub. So many great pubs in the area!

Excellent views of the bridge and the Opera house from almost anywhere on the rocks.... If you visit Sydney you must walk along to the rocks and enjoy superb views of the bridge and the Sydney opera house. There are numerous shops and diverse places to eat and drink. Our visit this time encompassed the Wine Festival which took up most of the spare ground on the Rocks and was an additional attraction to this well visited area.

The Rocks. The Rocks is a nice area of Sydney to gain a better appreciation of Sydney's history since this was the initial area where the immigrant convicts from England settled. It is also a convenient area to visit since The Rocks is located near Circular Quay. There is an historic museum which I found interesting, however, I would have liked to have seen more history of Sydney and Australia in this area. The Rocks is dominated by restaurants and small boutique shops. Perhaps a museum which showed a short film on the history of Sydney would be a nce addition.
Great district.. One of the interesting sections of Sydney. Twisted streets, little pubs,fasinating architecture. One of the older sections of Sydney.

Fell in love with Sydney on our very first day.... Our first day in Sydney we set out to explore and ended up at The Rocks and it was love at first sight! The Harbor Bridge, The Opera House, the architecture 0f the old hotels, churches and cathedrals, art galleries, our glasses of wine and a bite at an outdoor cafe (Wine Odessy, I think). Just an absolutely perfectl day in beautiful Sydney. Can't wait for our second date!!

Be sure to have a walk around this area.. So much to see in do in this area. Have a walk there or get off at a stop on one of your tourist buses. Get there early on the weekend for the local shopping.

Walk Around the Historic Rocks. Early history Sydney in a compact size.Lots of little streets and lanes just a block to two away from Circular Quay.Variety of shops, cafes and old pubs.Visitors centre has lots of information about local tours etc.Markets held at weekends.
Plenty to see and do. Lots of bars, restaurants, markets and attractions to see in this neck of the woods. Interesting building that have a rich history and a stones throw from the opera house.

The Rocks rocks!. We stayed in this area of Sydney and concentrated our 3 day stay in the area. The Opera House, The Harbour Bridge, Circular Quay, for us the Wine Festival, Shopping at Pitt St, everything is just steps away. A lovely historic area of Sydney, definitely recommend.

History on the Harbour. It was Melbourne Cup day when we were at Circular Quay and the place was buzzing. The Rocks is the area just below Sydney Harbour Bridge and is full of history. There are little cottages and cobbled streets and winding laneways hiding lovely restaurants and little shops. Could have spent longer there and would like to go back on a quieter day ! Spectacular area.
Walk around the Rocks. A must do. Plenty of interesting Pubs and History. Lots of restaurants. Markets are well worth going too.
Great Day At The Rocks Market. The Markets are fantastic. Lovely to see different merchandise, hand made goods and wonderful food. Well worth sending the time

Good to be there, but nothing special.. The rocks were recommended by friends who said we must visit.
There was a fair there when we were there and it was very busy.
We sat and had a beer in a local bar which was good but to just people watch doesn't get a high rating in my book.
Good to do, but nothing special!
Ideal central location. The Rocks area is a great location. Within walking distance of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge and the Central Quay area. Lots to see and do and a really lovely area

Historic Sydney. The Rocks are enjoyable. Markets on the weekend, but cute specialty shops all the time. Cute little streets and steps leading to excellent restaurants and interesting specialty stores.

Lots of fun. I have visited and stayed at The Rocks Sydney, many times and have never run out of things to see and do.I would recommend visiting The Rocks and taking advantage of the beautiful walks, food and interesting tours about the region.If you are lucky to visit on a day (Thursday I think) when the food markets are on or the weekend markets are on you will really enjoy it. Well worth the visit.

The Rocks was the first area in Sydney to be inhabited by farms. The rocks has some old buildings still standing. There is trendy food shops but the history is what attracts us. Just admiring the old buildings and under one of the accommodation places there is an open 'dig' site where relics of the Byrnes farm were discovered and have been displayed and sign posted. The whole area was farm land back in the 1800s. We discovered it when we were walking to go up on the harbour bridge.

The Rocks. There is so much History in the area, one just needs to go one or two streets back from the main shopping percent to find all sorts of interesting things, there is wine tasting, a historical dig. We ate at an amazing pub, Phillips Foote. The food and service were amazing.

Atmospheric. We did a short walkthru The Rocks ourselves. We really wanted to do the Free Walk which is scheduled at 6pm daily..starts in front of Cadmans Cottage. But unfortunately it rained cats and dogs all 3 days that we were in SYD hence could not make it. We did do the Discovery Center on our own which was quite nice.
Great to walk round. It's really great to walk round here with some great little eating places and quaint little stores to go into, try to avoid when cruise ships are in port as it gets very busy

Nothing special....but worth a wander. It's right next to circular quay..It has a number of nice restaurants and cafes and shops and in the weekends they have a market thereNice place to have dinner against the backdrop of the Opera house and harbour bridge
Nice place. If you like walking this is a great place to go for a stroll. There are plenty of interesting things to look at and its a good place for people watching also.

Australian early history. I love the Rocks area for the market, the old buildings and having a drink at one of the old pubs.
A visit to the "Garrison church" is always on the .list. As well a finding out the original use of the old buildings.

fall in love with the architecture. when i went to sydney, i went to the rocks on sunday. biasanya emang tempat untuk bazar-bazar gitu mulai dari clothes, food, drinks and many more, and also you can get epic picture in there!

We've done the walking tour in the evening. We got to tour around the area in the walking tour which is just amazing, highly recommend it! Wish I had stayed in there, so that we'd be right next to the best area around Sydney. The historical spots are awesome and it's always great to hear about how Sydney developed!
touresty. very touristy nothing upscale as far as shopping , even the art wasn't very interesting especially the museum...it is definitely not a "must see"

Great Shopping and Lodging Close to the Heart of Sydney. Instead of staying in a high price hotel downtown, do a little research and book a room in the Rocks. It's a 5 minute walk to all the ferries and the harbor bridge and 10 minutes to the Opera House and Botanical Gardens. We stayed in a penthouse apartment overlooking the harbor for less than $150 a night. The area is loaded with wonderful cafes and shopping...it's a great alternative to the downtown high rises
Great place. The rocks is a great place to browse especially at the weekend markets, plenty of hand made crates on show and reasonably prices. plenty of shopping and restaurants nearby
Great markets on the weekend. Close to everything, great variety of high quality goods available at the markets. Great place for non-tacky souvenirs

Browse for a few hours. A great spot to while away the hours.. browsing, shopping.. walking and just soaking up the atmosphere of the Sydney harbour waterfront. Kids may get bored.. but there are several restaurants and rest stops through the streets of Old Sydney.

Rocks Markets. The rocks markets are great, with a good mix of tourist gifts as well as clothes, food items and gifts. Once you finish meandering around the markets, move onto the rocks precinct and view the historic buildings and explore the cobbled laneways.
Brilliant. Lovely area is Sydney to wander around. On Sunday's there are market stalls to while away a couple of hours. Plenty of places to eat and drink. Definitely recommend a visit.

Vibrant Sunday market in Sydney. The Rocks market on Sunday morning is a nice place to shop for unique handcrafts as well as local artists' and designers fashion in Sydney. Easily accessible from Circular Quay (reachable by train), one can stroll pass the Nurses walk with shops and restaurants to the Rocks market
Pleasant!. Great spot to walk around, buy some gifts or just have a coffee or lunch. Full of colours, music and very friendly. Sunday market is so nice...

Enjoyable way to spend a Saturday morning. Great place to wonder around exploring the streets of the early settlers. Thank goodness the area is a protected site. The street market is lively with local arts and crafts. I recommend waking a little further up the hill along Argyle Street to the new Baranaroo Reserve area for amazing views over the Marrinawi Cove and Walsh Bay.

The Rocks is Cool!. We took the "free" tour of the Rocks with Josh from the Syndey free tour project. He did a wonderful job! He was enthusiastic, knowledgeable and humorous. He try to speak to us in areas that minimized the rain. Walking through the district was a great learning experience and added to our appreciation of Sydney

Do not miss the markets!!. Always a favorite place to visit on the weekends. A gentle stroll around the rocks is a must for every tourist whether local or international. If you are there when the markets are no you will need an extras few hours!!
A MUST. This is the best part of Sydney. It is a small area that dates to the first white settlers. It is now a small area of shops and restaurants. You can not leave Sydney without going here

well worth a visit. There are many things to see for everybody. Gives you an insight to how it was when the first convicts arrived. Lots of lovely restaurants and cafes to visit too as well as museums
Classic Sydney. A must visit place for all tourists. This is a very beautiful and historic place with amazing eateries and pubs to hang out.

Rather disappointing- made worse by a big cruise ship in port.. I had been here about 15 years ago and remembered a lot more jewelry stores with more variety. Decent outdoor market but quite crowded. Not a spot I'd want to spend more time with all the other attractions in Sydney.
Historic and vibrant. Plenty of places to eat, regular markets, history walks and a little bit of controversy surrounding past and future developments. Lots to see and do and think about.

A Must See. Don't leave Sydney without a few trips down into The Rocks. There is history & beauty around every corner, great pubs, a fantastic array of eateries, museums, shopping & a huge market a couple of days a week that showcases the best of Sydneys creative side. A bonus is that Circular Quay is so close.

Rockin' the Rocks. This is my third visit to Sydney (work, alas). Every time I find myself drawn to this quarter of the city. This is where it all began! The architecture reflects the history. It's right on the water. The Sydney Harbor Bridge and Opera House are right there. Super cute, authentic pubs and diners too. For a nice walk and a bit of history, too, The Rocks really rocks!

The real old Sydney. This area was part of the old commercial area which the authorities considered demolishing and putting up more ubiquitous high-rise buildings. Thankfully, public opinion saved the area from destruction and it is now a real tourist attraction with numerous cafes, shops etc and a really delightful area in which to spend some time. If you are visiting Sydney don't miss The Rocks area, we enjoyed it immensely.

The Rocks rock ! So full of history.. Well worth the walk from Circular Quay to be surrounded by beautiful old buildings. So much of Sydney's early history to soak up. The market has something for everyone and there is an endless choice of places to dine. A short walk from here takes you up onto the Harbour Bridge. You can also pop onto the overseas cruise ship terminal and enjoy the vistas of the Opera House and Circular Quay from across the water.Relaxing atmosphere for any age group.

one of my favorite parts of Sydney. Love the history here and the small alleys! Be sure to take one of the free walking tours that do a nightly tour of the area. Lots of old pubs, the buildings make you feel like you stumbled across a completely different era. Definitely explore the area, lots of great history still remains.

Dont miss this area. The rocks were where the first fleet landed to colonize Australia. Full of history and old houses, we thoroughly enjoyed this area of Syndey. Take a guided tour such as the Rocks walking Tour to hear all the interesting stories.

full of tourist shops - lost its appeal. the rocks is meant to have historic appeal - not there - it is all souvenir shops and not worth the effort. Some good old pubs - and it is on the way to Barangaroo.

rock it. always something to do and treasures to find. The rocks is buzzing with festivety on the weekends, markets, pubs, restuarants. Plenty of shopping and food outlets. this place is beautiful. shop during the day eat and drink well into the night. a must see for all; young & old, travellers or locals. you will love it
Covent Garden in Sydney. Lovely area to stroll around. Great weekend makes, gift shops, souvenir shops, bars, cafes and restaurants. The who,e area has a really nice vibe.

Special spot. Whether it's a stroll through the area a bite to eat a late night drink or a shop. The iconic Rocks is a must see on your visit.Just walking through the cobble stone paths and taking in the area is great. Lots of atmosphere along with the history.With a view under the bridge also interesting especially if sitting having a drink in the Harbour View upstairs terrace

A nice spot in Sydney, nothing crazy. I've to Sydney many times and we always spend some times at The Rocks. Is a nice historical place, nothing compare to a real historic place for someone that comes from Europe, but is ok for Australia. Maybe is a bit overcrowded.

Lovely shops, bars and restaurants. A great place to have a potter around, shops, bars, restaurants and market on certain days. Interesting history of the city then sit and watch the world go by from here.

Walk around be a tourist for rhe day. Yes rhis the roc l s have become quite touristy but it is still worth the visit. Markets on Sunday with pubs and plently of restaurants combine with a walk over the harbour bridge.

Lovely area of Sydney. I visited this area on my first tip to Sydney and fell in love with it. The history, the buildings, quaint pubs and the delectible delicacies, are just a few of the drawcards, that sees me return here whenever I visit Sydney. The Rocks is located within walking distance to Circur Quay and the Opera House. There are some wonderful little shops, art gallery, plus the weekend markets, which are brilliant, if not a little overpriced. If you love history and old buildings, make sure you visit the row of houses that have been lovingly restored back to the bygone era that is called Susannah Place, also Cadman Cottage and Campbells Warhouse. The sandstone buildings just amaze me. There is so much to see and do here, you won't be disappointed.

Interesting place to visit, the true sights and sounds of a beautiful city. So much to see time just gets away, plenty of amazing top class restaurants to dine in, street buskers add to the experience

A vibrant and interesting historical town.. There are many aspects to The Rocks the original houses, laneways, a wonderful Discovery Museum, a variety of shops, cafes and restaurants. This area has a lovely old feel due to old buildings as well as a vibrant and busy atmosphere especially on the weekends.

Great for a walk and meal on a sunny day in Sydney. The Rocks area contains many old pubs, galleries and eateries and is fun when the weather is kind. Take a walk through the arcades And venture through the shops. Take a coffee and venture down to the museum of Contemporary Art walking through the gardens. Take a seat and watch the Sydney Harbour Traffic - it is a working Harbour.
A little less to see each visit. I do like The Rocks but there seems to be less to see each time I go. The markets are good if a little pricey. Enjoyable for a walk though.

Have a look. Rock market every sat & sun is a must suits all budget some great things to take home to remember your visit. Lovely place to eat just by the docks if you like seeing cruise liners. It a historic area.

Sunday markets. The rocks is a great place to unwind. Visit on Sunday to catch the markets. Stroll through the side streets to find little gems of Sydney past. Great for young kids as there are plenty of statues and other items of history for them to keep them entertained.
History, shopping, food. Great area. Maybe touristy, but almost everyone we met out & about were from Sydney. Historical information abounds.

Great place to visit. Historical place. Lots of interesting stores and amazing choice of placed to eat. Weekend markets with streetfood too. On the hop on hop off route, but walking distance from Circular Quay.

Every Turn a Delight. There's much much more to the historic area of The Rocks than first appears.This is where the fledgling settlement of Sydney (and of Australia) began. A couple of centuries later the area has morphed into a fascinating mix of old and new with evidence of that early settlement to be discovered not only in the grandiose sandstone buildings but through an intriguing network of small passageways, ladders, steps and quaint alleyways. Around every corner is a surprise - and a delight. As one who has visited and stayed in The Rocks on numerous occasions, I'm still discovering new delights that illuminate Sydney's rugged and simple origins.Go there! It's a no-brainer. You'll be enchanted. And as a bonus, you'll marvel at the up-close-and-personal view of the Sydney bridge - from directly below the iconic structure. A visit to Sydney without a visit to The Rocks is like a visit to THE ROCK (Uluru) - without getting out of your car!
Good shopping place. Rock market is a quite big market, good enough for half day shopping. Lots of craft work and small gift can be found there.
Have to visit!!!. lots to do around here and don't miss the markets. Lovely walk to the area through the harbour...plenty places to eat and to suit different budgets too

Close up view of the harbour bridge. Beautiful townscape design with a lot of eateries, gift shops and shopping available. I was able to get a really closeup view of the amazing harbour bridge as well. Great place for sightseeing.
Dawdle and enjoy. The Rocks is a great area of Sydney to stroll around, enjoy the markets, the food,the architecture & history and best of all the fantastic views of Sydney Harbour and the foreshore.
Nice part of the town. Take few minutes or a bit more to walk around in the Rocks. This old part of the city is well renovated and has now a special flair...

A step back from the mayhem. The Rocks is a place which feels totally different to the CBD or the city. The streets are filled with lovley shops with lots to offer. Though it gets busy, make sure you go on a Daturday or Sunday to see the markets. I would reccomend walking around Bangeroo ( if thats its name) after it.

Loved the Rocks area.. What a great place to be based.We stayed at the Old Sydney Holiday Inn and had the markets and entertainment at our back door.A must do is the weekend markets.Take a Trike ride over the Harbour Bridge was a lot of fun.Lots of food,Buskers and galleries.Easy walk from International Terminal.Try a German Beer
Modern and Historic. Right around the corner from Sydney Harbour. There were lots of great restaurants, bars/pubs, and other touristy venues. Worth a visit.

Nice area for afterwork drinks or weekend markets. Set below the Harbour bridge, the rocks offers a diverse mix of pubs, restaurants and cafes in a casual atmosphere.
There'll be weekend markets but best to check with the schedules as it may vary with season.
If you're staying in the city, it's not too far a walk and short hop to Circular Quay and Opera House.

Where are the rocks!. The first time I came to Sydney, I thought the rocks area actually had 'rocks' It doesn't, but it has so much history and fabulous cafes and winding alleys and interesting shops. Lots of steps to climb. Been twice now, need to come back again

Rocks Rock. We were fortunate to be on the rocks on a Friday morning where there was a food fair being held- Turkish Gozlema was wat we went for - what a long queue to sample it- n boy- worth the wait- and macaroons-and delicious coconut water- Rocks have a character of their own- interspersed with history, historic buildings, a ship ready to cruise- docked close by- harbour bridge a few meters away- uits just the best part part of Sydney- go there esp on a Friday sunny morning- for gourmet pride of tummy n eyes

Nice place to walk. Lost of historical buildings, nice views, to many options to eat and drink. A nostalgic environment inside the big city. You can see it all by walk, but remember to carry an umbrella. In Sidney you never know when you'll have rain.
amazing history. this place is lovely went there often on my three wk visit to Sydney . also have a big market on Saturdays.must see
Europe? :). When I saw the rocks i immediatly thought: am i in europe?Its very pretty, there is a market with local food and souvenirs. Its Actually one of the best part of sydney
