Nice area, interesting history, fun markets. This is a fun and interesting area of Sydney with a vibrant history. Check out the Free Walking Tour of Sydney to learn more. The Sunday markets are fun too.
Make sure you go on weekends. Visit the Rocks on the weekend and experience the buz around the market with great tastes and other interesting items for sale.
The best views. Leisure walk with so much interesting architecture to look at. Food and drink stop along the way. Great for locals and tourists alike. No fee attraction, very rare these days.

Where It All Began. To appreciate the history of Sydney, you must spend time in The Rocks neighborhood. This is where things have been preserved and the beginnings of Sydney can be appreciated. It is also the home of some good restaurants, bars and shops. On Friday night there is a street food fair and on the weekends there is The Rocks Market, both worth doing. To get the most from your trip to The Rocks, be sure to take the Free Walking Tour.

Historic buildings swamped with over priced shops. The Rocks is known for its historic buildings, however when visiting here you notice all the overpriced shops instead. And they are all overpriced catering to the tourist dollar.Best day to visit is Friday for the Rocks markets and the best gozleme ai've ever eaten.The visitor information centre is located in the Rocks and is the best place to get information on what to see in Sydney and surrounds.

It rocks (I know, easy pun). Well, it does rock there. Probably my favourite district in Sydney because it mixes a lot of good activities. It is well located, close to Circular Quay so after a visit there, you can hang out with for some nice views of the Opera House. You can shop at a special market on weekends or at luxury brands store or at other outlets. If you are looking for a massive Apple Store or department store, pass your way, The Rocks is about intimacy and authenticity. Yu will find different type of food from all other the world: pub, Asian, Italian(served with the charm and accent from Italy!) and so many others. Charm, the Rocks have a lot because the architecture is very colonial Australian with old bricks and it avoids straight long and straight streets. It does not stop here as you can have the views from the Shangri-La rooftop bar with excellent mojitos btw, to the view upwards the Harbour Bridge. If you come back to Circular Quay by George Street, stop at the art gallery; some works are simply stunning. And if you do not eat at the Rocks, come back for some interesting bar experience, either in a church or in a kind of very modern, well I was not sure what it was apart from awesome !!

The Rocks rock for the Tourist. The Rocks is this heritage area converted into beautiful pubs, bars, eateries, coffee and snack outlets, with numerous interesting shops. It has boutique outlets for OPAL stone jewellery, a unique silk jacket maker worth a visit, a great art gallery tucked away in its by lanes, a fantastic pub called ANANAS, and the walk along the stretch is so wonderful. Worth trying the bear outlets with the jumbo sized bear mugs...very German in character.It has resting benches if you have elders or children but it lacks a public utility loo.It faces the ferry wharf and is so close to Circular Quay station and the big hotels of Sydney like the Shangri-La, Four Seasons and the Marriott.Absolute worth a few hours of stroll, sit, shop, eat, drink and enjoy !!

Lots to discover and great cafes to test out. Wear comfortable shoes and make sure you carry water or stop for refreshments at one of the many cafes, pubs, or restaurants in the area as there is much to see walking around this older and historical part of Sydney. A whole day can be spent wandering tax free shops, cafes, markets and galleries - look out for the Charles Byllich gallery which not only houses his extraordinary work but is a lovely building in its own right and hosted by a vivacious, knowledgeable and welcoming lady. Further up the street on the same side is a craft shop which sells high end, beautifully made local silk scarves, metal works, accessories, clothes etc, - a real treasure trove for that extra special gift or memento.
Rocks great area in Sydney harbour. Stayed at the holiday inn old town Sydney rocks district great venue staff friendly and highly recommend staying there when in SydneyBill Stimson
The old Sidney. Nice to walk along and enjoy the colonial ambience. The oldest part of the city. I will like to go back at some point.
walk around when you are there. The Rocks has Hotels, Restaurants, Cafes, Bars and Markets. Well worth the walk around, tasted alligator and Emu for the first time here.

The Rocks Markets on Sunday. The top end of George Street closes to traffic Friday night through Sunday and becomes a market (see photos).This market has become a tourist mecca and seems to be priced accordingly. I enjoy browsing here a couple of times per year but don't normally spend any money

Hidden gems from Sydney's past. The Rocks is an area of Sydney that has been architecturally preserved. It is adjacent to Circular Quay and is a pleasant place to explore without a firm destination in mind. Narrow streets are lined with historic buildings, while boutique stores and market stalls abound for those perfect gifts to take home.

STROLL INTO COLONIAL HISTORY. Behind the modern facades of great shops, around every corner of The Rocks you will encounter aspects of Sydney's early colonial history. Once the hustling and bustling economic heart of the colony, The Rocks is now a major drawcard for tourists and locals alike, offering a convivial atmosphere where you sit and relax at a typical Aussie pub and rub elbows with the locals; stroll through buildings that witnessed the early life and growing pains of this penal colony; grab yourself fantastic bargains and momentos; and enjoy fantastic Aussie meals. You shouldn't pass up a chance to spend a few hours here in The Rocks—especially on weekends when the place is brimming with street vendors!!

You have to search. The rocks is one of the oldest parts of Sydney and hidden away are some wonderful pubs and restaurants as well as some interesting information on the history on the walls which will really give you s feel for the place. It also contains some lovely shops but really could do with a few more craft type ones which as u remember used to exist? Still a peaceful place to wander if your not in a rush.

Full of history at every turn. The oldest place in Sydney, The Rocks offers plenty to do. From Markets, Cafes, Restaurants, Boutique stores, Bars and Hotels.A must see area to explore when visiting Sydney.

Great market. This market is located near Circular Quay where I stayed. Nice morning walk along cobbled lanes with lots of stalls selling a myriad of handmade stuff ranging from jewelry, clothes, art, beauty products, food, small ornaments, souvenirs, etc. You will be able to take great pictures of the Sydney Opera House and Harbour Bridge too. Bought a dried mango which was yummy. Bought the big packet which had 4 mangoes inside for $20. There are cafes along the sides which you can stop by for food too. Nurses Walk is just around the corner and it is a great area to explore while you are at The Rocks Market :)
Awesome. Great stroll thru unusual stores to find that little piece of aus..Perfect tastes during Friday lunchtime market

Great day out. I love this area of Sydney, with all the early Australian history, the weekend markets, the buskers, the atmosphere, the great places to grab a bite to eat and the friendly pubs. What's not to love. Lots of things to do for all ages.

Sunday markets and buskers. Good for a Sunday stroll. The flea market is in full swing and the ambience is carefree. There are buskers for entertainment too. The restuarants are touristy and so-so. The contemporary art museum is also here but also average

This is where the life is.. Staying in the Shangri La Hotel, put The Rocks just a few minutes walk away and this is the hot spot for bars, restaurants and market shopping. It spreads out both sides from the base of the bridge and there is a noticeable difference in the vibe from the more staid aspect of Sydney up on the higher streets.Walk around and get lost in it, with the bridge as a landmark, you are really in trouble.
Great architecture, great shopping around the market stalls.. It's just an amazing area of old Sydney. A must see place when your in Sydney. Something for everyone.
Favourite place in Sydney. Loved this place. Shops to explore, restaurants were of a high standard. Even proved a great running spot, so much to see!

A Walk Through Sydney History - The Rocks.. The Rocks area of Sydney takes you back in time, with many of the original buildings showing amazing Architecture. Picturesque views of the Harbour, The Harbour Bridge Circular Quay and Opera House as well.

The Rocks at old Sydney. Loved walking around the old part of Sydney known as "The Rocks" great old buildings with history and character and followed by a visit to the Restaurants and Bars to make you feel so welcome and warm and relaxed!!
Loved the superb wine at Odyssey Wine Bar! Especially in the daily happy hour!

Iconic Sydney. We have visited here a number of times and never get tired of the place. Interesting original buildings, some great restaurants, shops, markets on Sundays and great views of the bridge and back to the Opera House
Worthwhile exploring some of the western areas of the bridge too
A must see while in Sydney. Loved the historical flavour of the area. A great place to stroll. Restaurants a bit pricey.the weekend markets worth a visit. Beautiful views of the harbour and bridge.

A Sydney must see.. A visit to Sydney is not complete without a walk through the rocks.
There are plenty of the usual tourist shops but still plenty of old gems like the Fortune of War pub and the original convict stone lane ways.
Of course there are also some pretty amazing views.

Hidden History. The free walking tour commences at Cadman's Cottage on the edge of The Rocks area and is run by a group of University Students. The tour is operated on the basis that at the end, which is about 1 hour 45 mins, you can tip the tour guide what you believe the experience was worth. You are not pressured or obliged to pay anything if you choose not too, however the knowledge of our tour guide prompted us to pay a small fee.Although we have been to Sydney numerous times and visited The Rocks on several visits, I was not aware of some of the history behind this area and current issues which affect this area. We were taken places we had not been before and saw things that tourists probably do not visit. It was extremely interesting and I am glad our friends suggested it. Highly recommend.
The Rocks. The market is nice and its fun to look through the shops, then have lunch or dinner at one of the restaurants or a drink at the tavern.

Loved exploring The Rocks. We enjoyed exploring The Rocks - the old buildings made of sandstone and learning some of the history of the area. Of course, this is only "old" in terms of Australian standards - 200 or so years is a drop in the ocean for Europeans. Yes, the precinct is full of touristy things - we didn't engage in this part - but given the proximity to the Bridge and the Opera House, you'd be crazy not to check it out for yourself!

Olde Sydney!. A walk around the Rocks should be a part of every visit to Sydney. Being right next to the ferries at Circular Quay it can get busy, but I always enjoy strolling around this oldest part of Sydney. There are tons of cafes, ice cream parlours, a weekend market, but best of all are the traditional pubs! The Fortune of War is the oldest pub in Sydney which is well worth a visit for the nostalgia. The Australian (serving crocodile pizzas) is a nice oddity, The Glenmore has outstanding views of the harbour from it's roof terrace, and the Lord Nelson is a great traditional pub. Pommies can also enjoy the beer in pint glasses at Hart's. Try the hangman's ale (not sure if it's meant to represent a final drink for the condemned or a refreshing pint for the hangman himself after a hard days work....)!
The Rocks. Great atmosphere and great eateries. They shopping is good, too if you look for the specialty shops rather than the tourist souvenir shops. A lovely setting and a place of history.

Upmarket overpriced underinteresting are.. Visited the area expecting to see all sorts of interesting shops and good eating places. Not many shops at all and everything ridiculously high prices. Hotel was cheaper.

good walk. The market is nice and some shops are interesting.
Go to the argyle to have a beer and some chips if you need a break after a big walk :)

Amazing place to wander round . There are so many interesting little paths and buildings that it's really easy to kill a few hours here.
Lots of nice restaurants too.

It rocks . It's a must see if you are into history.
You will have a walk at the place where it all started for Sydney.

Had high hopes but alas.... Had high hopes when planning the trip but it was quite 'normal'. Nothing exceptional in my point of view. Quite normal but maybe it's just becoming blasé as they all look and feel quite alike in all the cities in Australia

Essential Sydney Experience. Really the only precinct of the city where you can see and experience 19th century Sydney Town. Worth getting a self guided walking map or doing one of the guided tours to learn a bit about the history and the shady characters that inhabited the place. Make sure you continue over to the western side of the Bridge where you will find the most atmospheric pubs - The Hero of Waterloo, Lord Nelson and the Palisades and further on to the new Barangaroo Park at Miller's Point. The restaurant/bar at the end of the Sydney Theatre Wharf is great value, has great food and provides one of the best harbourside spots to sit and watch the western harbour traffic.
first time there. loved the walk around and it was just awesome. looking at the statues etc, stopped for coffee, i think we even had a meal somewhere.

Visit the Big Dig and Susannah Place for a history lesson. Amazingly, the Rocks still survive surrounded by high rise towers and cut off by the Harbour Bridge, hooray for an interesting piece of Sydney history. Somewhat touristy, but ignore that angle!

The old Quarter of this Modern City. I had a business at The Rocks from 1988 to 2007 it's called The Crystal Gallery and is located in Nurses Walk ( yes it's still there I sold it in July 2007)Nurses Walk is a small street that runs parallel th George St.. And has that name because it was the place where the first medicinal herbs were grown, and nurses we responsible for tending it etc.The Tocks is now a fabulous blend of Sydney's past and Sydney's today.. Wonderful views, wonderful art galleries, wonderfull restaurants, exotic shops etc!Visit The Rocks Centre & The Argyle Centre and walk up Argyle St to visit the oldest Church in Australia- The Garrison Church. You can spend an entire day there and never tire!

Go to the weekend markets. Lovely little pocket of Sydney, good to wander around. The market extends around the back, turn right at the Lowenbrau Inn. Market not filled with tourist tat, which is nice, has reasonably priced jewellery and bits and pieces. Though I don't quite understand the amount of Ugg Boot shops in Sydney!

History and fun. The rocks is a truly special place. Full of convict history with cobble stone paths and amazing buildings. The Sunday market is fantastic to wonder around and enjoy. Great food and some great restaurants.

Visit the weekend market at The Rocks. Known as the old town area for sydney, the rocks turn out to be famous for tourist. have been staying at the hotel around this area, you can find a good coffee around here, and also lots of restaurant, some bars, and they had weekend market here. worth to visit. Also been here at July 2013.
We loved it. We loved the traditions and the feeling of 'old' Sydney - found a great Irish Bar and had a great time at the Rocks

An outdoor art gallery! . I'd love the easy stroll through The Rocks after a baguette at Le Renaissance. The old Sydney brick and mortar blended in with the modern structures. Even the drizzling rain did not dampened our experience. So many little eateries to try next time. It's like walk back into time. The weekend market is also great fun, full of little treasures to be found.

An Essential Visit!. We visited on a street market day and excitement was in the air. Crowds of people, dozens of stalls selling everything from household items and clothes to gourmet food. Then there is the historic location itself, brimming with history. It is worth a visit just to see the historical architecture and the rocky outcrop on which they are built. They have a patina of age and give the visitor a sense of 'old Sydney'. Love it!

Historical and beautiful!. A great place to unwind and take in sights with plenty of restaurants and sights to soak in, The Rocks leaves you with great memories! Met really friendly people (young and old) in the area, who were ever eager to lend a helping hand!!

Food and fun. This is the entertainment section of Sydney with a plethora of choices. The historical part on the water with the remnants of the original settlements. Fun to walk around and read the interesting places that can be seen by walking.

Genuine living history of SYdney. A unique part of Sydney which still preserves a lot of the character and buildings of the earliest settlement of SYdney. Good to walk around and soak up the atmosphere. Of course lots of souvenir shops but being Sydney there is no hustle and everyone is friendly... Its so close to the main part of the city and is on the harbour so it would be crazy to miss it. Its in part living history and in part just a great place to visit
Fun to explore. We enjoyed exploring the Rocks! Very cool architecture with a lot of history. Definitely enjoyed it!
Historic, interesting, vibrant. Plenty to see, lots of great restaurants.good for a wander.with a visit. Great views. Rocks, I didn't see any rocks.
My favourite place!. You have to go during weekends. Best place for a drink and food. Cutes boutiques of arts and jewelry. Try the oldest pub : Fortune of War! The best
Rocks - a rocking place. Small allies, cafe houses, eateries. Blending old and new. Amazing how this area turned into a most enjoyable tourist attraction.

Lovely. One of the most beautiful places to spend the day, from the pubs, eateries, atmosphere, and did I mention the views! Make sure you discover some of the hidden alleyways, and Sydney at night! Awesome

Another, on the Must Do list. A vital part of Sydney history .Make sure that you drop by the Visitor Centre to pick up the info on the historical importance of this area. Make time to explore and read the stories and lifestyle of our ancestors .
A great area to browse , eat and shop for souvenirs of Old Sydney.
Great weekend markets .

Must see historical site. The Rocks was the first area in Sydney to be settled over 200 years ago. Thus you will find many historical buildings and cobblestone streets. It's a lovely area to take a stroll on a nice weather day. There are restaurants, pubs and gift shops. There is also a crafts market every Sunday.
Interesting walk. Wonderful place to browse as well as stop for a coffee or a beer and watch the cruise traffic at the international terminal
Happening ... A very unique place to visit. Antique buildings with restaurants, café, shops..you name it, you get it.

At the Rocks. Great historical sites, great shopping and a fantastic atmosphere is what you will experience when you visit the Rocks. After all our Mary met her Prince Frederick of Demark there and became Princess Mary. You never know it could happen again.

A different look on Sydney.. Pretty quaint place to walk about in Sydney on a spring day. The old buildings gives a different atmosphere from the modern look of Sydney, so we felt we were transported into a pretty village within the city. Love the little gift shops - spend some time there browsing, but not necessarily buying as the prices are a little bit steep.

The historic heart of Sydney. The Rocks is essentially where European settlement started in Australia. This unique part of Sydney is jammed packed with great restaurants, great sights and so much more
Vibrant Historic Area. A vibrant area of the old city with many attractions and walks. Good eating is also available to most tastes, especially cafes.

Don't Miss It. Located only a short walk from the city centre The Rocks is a must visit place for a good mix of the old and new. From reputedly Sydney's oldest pub to more modern ones and trendy restaurants - it has it all. It has views of the famous Harbour Bridge, Circular Quay and the Opera House. Simply walking through the area gives you a feel for the history of the place.It really has everything for a great night out.

An interesting historical part of Sydney. Definitely worth a visit to the bustling weekend market but also during the week to take in the pretty old buildings. Lots of handcrafted gifts waiting to be snapped up. The eateries were a bit touristy and not necessarily worth visiting.
The original part of the settlement of the city.. While not exceptionally old, it does give a little of the original character of 19th century Sidney as a much smaller place.

Nice design of the area!!!!!!. The Rocks holds the most antique part in Sydney holding famous ghost tours and market tours.From the rocks we took a lot of cool photos,in the area not too far from the rocks is an office that holds tickets for the Sydney harbour bridge climbing if you dare to. It also holds expensive Japanese restaurants and a lot of history dating back to the 17th to 18th century.I recommend this place for families and tourists.

Love The Rocks!. Wonderful historic neighborhood right by Circular Quay. We love The Rocks and always spend time there when visiting Sydney. Our favorite place to stay is the Russell Hotel in The Rocks. The Russell is convenient to everything, and just a short walk to the ferries at Circular Quay. Free walking tours are offered of The Rocks daily. It also has a good selection of restaurants.

Sydney Rocks. The rocks is a must see area for any tourist. Its one of the oldest parts of the city located just near circular quay. There is many bars and restaurants for high end to good value cafes.
Good with a Guided tour.. Some good view points and places on interest.It may seem a little odd without a guided tour to explain and show you the highlights of this area.

Must visit location. Sure The Rocks is a tourist mecca and over priced at that. However, you can't beat the views of the harbor. The Museum of Contemporary Art is there along with lots of restaurants and shops. Go to the end of The Rocks towards the Park Hyatt and there are outdoor restaurants to enjoy a drink or a meal. There is a street market on the side streets just off of the harbor to shop.

Tourist central. Lots of tourist stuff and pretty views. I would spend time at the archeological sites and living museums, as they give great insight into colonial times. Don't eat here as inflated prices for tourists.

A great place to just wander around and enjoy the harbour shore.. On our latest trip to Sydney we stayed at Darling Harbour and one day we walked from our hotel around the waterfront to Circular Quay, at first this was a hazard trying to navigate through the Bangaroo Development (talk about over development and greed, this place takes the cake) we broke into the light and fresh air and really enjoyed the day. Our walk took us around past the finger wharves that are now offices, apartments and restaurants, past the Sebel Pier One under the harbour bridge past the the Park Hyatt through the rocks to the Quay. If you have a few hours take this stroll and you will feel alive and enjoy the sights and sounds of one of the world's great harbours.

Dont miss a walk around the Rocks. If you are in Sydney this area is a must. There are a lot of interesting eateries and shops and the character is of the area is fantastic. This is a historic precinct that holds many stories.

Markets were great. Every Saturday and Sunday they hold markets at The Rocks. We bought a few items but mostly went crazy at the Licorice Shop. This is old type licorice that tastes like licorice and is hard, just like when you were a kid! They have also steped it up and we bought lemon and lime, and passionfruit - yum! You also are next to the Harbour Bridge for good views and photos.

One of my favourite places in Sydney. I first went there many, many years ago, and though it has changed a lot, it was still worth a visit. I didn't get to spend as much time there as I would have liked, but I did enjoy the time I had. Great Information Centre with lovely and helpful staff too.

Lovely historical area. The rocks is a lovely area to visit in sydney. The market on the weekends has many wonderful hand crafted products for sale. Food, souvenirs, clothing and all sorts of other things. Try some delicious scones at a place called Tea cosy.

Historical Sydney. It's the history of The Rocks that should be any visitors focal point, the shopping is there if that's what you want. Early Churches, Pubs, the places of the once thriving colonial business hub are there to explore, just relax, take a leisurely stroll around, let your imagination roam free, walk where convicts and the local gentry went about their daily routines, soak up the atmosphere, after exploring this historical precinct enjoy a meal and drink at one of many restaurants or pubs.

A view into the past. Thank you Jack Mundy for saving The Rocks for future generations to enjoy. Spend a good couple of hours wandering around and marvelling at the harbour views and the old buildings. Unfortunately there are not many of these places left in Sydney to enjoy.

History side lined . Found the huge number of expensive shops annoying but if you can ignore them and look carefully you can find the hidden treasures of the historic past. Some nice cafés but the markets were over priced and nothing special

The rocks are best place to visit.. The rocks are best place to visit in sydney. You could see harbour bridge very close from here. At the rocks they have market day, at the time you will see many people open bazaar selling things like antique staffs, candy, etc. On the way to the rock there are many fancy shop available. Such as LV, Gucci, etc.You have to come to the rocks on new year eve. Very good view to see fire works and very close to harbour bridge.

Intetesting walking tour & weekend market. A good way to learn more about Sydney and Australia from where it all began, the Rock. The walking tour is free and has time schedule.
Nice weekend market for souvenirs and snacks. Stalls open after 10 and starts to close before 4. Get there early and have a cuppa at lots of cafe there.
Touristy but fun...espeically on a Sunday. Very touristy but great on a Sunday when there are lots of markets and great street food. Avoid on a rainy day...mayhem.

Quaint history. Step back in time and discover the early history and founding culture of Australia.
Lots of great restaurants and cafés. Limited tourist style shopping. Great museums and galleries close by. Circular quay a short walk away.
The Rocks. The Rocks was an interesting area to visit, lots of old buildings, quite a bit of history in the area. Great flea market Saturday and Sundays

A BEAUTIFUL FUN PLACE. There are plenty of shops and restaurants there and it is beautiful. It is a DON"t MISS.
It is a beautiful historic place. If you are lucky, there is a flea market there once in a while. Have a Blast and Yeah Sdney.

Cool historic neighborhood!. Lots of cool restaurants and little shops and pubs. Great place to explore for an afternoon or evening. Let yourself get lost on the cobblestone streets and historic buildings!
The Rocks. Great restaurants, fabulous little shops to explore with great souvenirs on offer. Friendly people, awesome sweet making demos.

Wander, relax, stop for a beer or shop. The Rocks is one of Sydney's main tourist attractions and yes the souvenir shops can be a bit tacky but wandering around the little laneways is a great way to pass a few hours. There are guided tours but you don't need to take one of them to get the history as there are lots of plaques outlining the history and the significance of different areas. The weekends are also particularly good when the market is operating but there are more people to contend with. Don't forget to pop into one of the pubs and reflect on what it was like all those years ago.

The Rocks - weekend market. Haven't been to this market for a couple of years and decided to walk over from our hotel. I must admit it hasn't changed much. The same stalls seemed to be there. I am a bit of a shopper and I actually didn't buy a thing! Local artists selling their various hand-made jewellery, glass, artwork and leatherwear. Think we will give this a miss next time we go to Sydney.

Talk a walk through the Rocks, it rocks.. Alwaŷs good for a walk around. Markets on a Sat and Sun. Great vibe and always people around..many food choice from fast to slower. Don't miss the NSW craft guild shop just near Ken Done shop, well worth a look with hand crafted jewellery, pottery, art work, woven and knitted garments, art work etc

The Rocks, Sydney, NSW. A fabulous place to just wander around and marvel at the history of this area, lots of pubs to stop and prop, have a drink or a meal. Wander down to the Quay to see if a cruise ship is in, more often they are. Enjoy the Markets on a weekend, they sell the BEST nougat in a centre stall down near the bridge :-)

Great historic area!. Well worth the visit and walk through the historic old buildings of Sydney. There`s not much history in Australia so its nice to have this place to look around. Great shops and restaurants.

Easy to Spend Hours. Spent half a day at the Rocks, the markets were on so we walked all through them, some really nice things. Then lunch down near the water and for afters the Guylian Cafe. Awesome.

Rocks. The Rocks is a great area to spend time at. The other side of Darling Harbour, It's a very historic area with classic bluestone buildings, pubs and shops sitting under the Sydney Harbour Bridge. Good craft markets on Sundays with lots of good food and inexpensive souvenirs for tourists.

Best Place Inside City. Accessible to Circular Quay, Darling Harbour Bridge, Syndey Observatory, Sydney Royal Botanic Garden, Wynyard Station, George Street and much more .. Beautiful location to explore the city ...

Be saturated with history. We just love The Rocks. A microcosm of Australian history and a fascinating place to visit. You need your walking shoes as it's up and down. Wonderful eateries, access to the bridge, the harbour, the international cruise terminal. Historic buildings abound. Hotels range from modern luxury to historic fascination.If your cruise ship calls into Sydney, you can stroll into the The Rocks area and spend all day or catch a ferry to the ferry terminal and then your choice of destination is huge. Definitely one of the best cities in the world to visit and can't be beaten as a cruise destination.
Fun to wander. Great area to wander and explore the various eateries. Lots of history to enjoy as well. Worth an afternoon, for sure.
See the Rocks. Such an interesting place. We took a free Sydney tour and walked to the Rocks. Actually went back there a few times.
market. One of the best craft markets I've ever been to. High quality jewellery and clothes in amazing styles. good place to have brunch. Not to be missed

Lovely area containing the oldest pub, the Fortune of War.. We stayed in the Rocks area with its many restaurants and shops. We came upon the weekend market by chance and bought a few stocking presents for Christmas.

Beautiful area, combining history with a modern vibe. I fell in love with the Rocks, everything form it's historic precincts to it's bars, resturants and Quay side location will seduce you.
The Rocks is the perfect place for a weekend escape, only problem is you will want to stay.
Need for visit. The place is full of historical sites so it needs to be placed in your visit book. there are a lot of shops as well as little picturesque restaurants for eat and drink with mood

Used to be really worth coming here. But over the years the market loose more and more of its appeal. I'll still visit it whenever I visit Sydney but only in the hope to find the one or two stalls that' are worth returning for. It's the biggest weekend market in Sydney and should still be on anyone's bucket list if u don't go to Sydney often. I'll recommend visiting the other markets like eveleigh and Alexandra.
A step into yesterday.. Thanks goodness this area was preserved. A beautiful piece of Australia's history. I loved walking around The Rocks and stopping at Cafes and pubs as I travelled.
Good time. Burgers, beer and good times - good location NeXT to the ferry service to the rest of the city. Easy access to some major sights of sydney.

Historic Part of Sydney - Lots of Stone and Brick Buildings. After arriving at Circular Quay one of the first things we did was walk through The Rocks, an old historical district with dozens of buildings that were once part of the original settlement. Today, many of those buildings have been converted into apartments, shops, and restaurants bringing life to this historic area. We did our tour backwards, beginning at the Sydney Observatory and then walking down and under the Sydney Harbor Bridge back to Circular Quay. I didn't feel we missed anything doing it backwards, the stone streets, and narrow alleys between the brick buildings are fantastic no matter which route you take.

Look past the tourist traps. Some parts of the rocks area are interesting with historic areas. However, there are far too many trendy or touristy gift shops which seem to take over the experience. Some of the quirky little shops that were in this area years ago seem to have gone. There are a few interesting places but you have to look hard to find them.
The rocks markets. Love visiting the rocks whenever we are in Sydney. Great day out and the markets are always interesting
Markets and shopping . Walked up from Circular Quay, and it was worth the walk. Plenty of things to see and do, with plenty of places to grab lunch or a snack!
Worth a visit. Saturday market is fun to wander through. Good buskers and tasty food. Makes a lovely walk to go from the Opera House round the water to the rocks.

Nice little lanes with quirky shops. A nice area with a variety of little quirky shops. Some great restaurants and cafés and on Fridays they have a foodie market which is well worth a visit, I went to a Turkish stall and had a wrap it was very good value for money and so large I couldn't eat it all! The tourist information office is also here and they are very helpful.
Brillaint for dine out. Lots of good restaurant around the area. Different kind of cusine with reasonable price.This area has got everything for everyone.
Nice to go there once.. Nice surrounding, not quite big, nice restaurants,nice to walk through, but a little bit to commercialised and also to expensive. atmosphere was O.K. but a little dark.
nice. variety of shops and restaurants for lunch, dinner or wine night. Nice for small walks and talks. LOved the place
Restaurant and unusual stalls. The Rocks have good restaurants and pubs and on the weekend lots of stalls with unusual jewellery, clothing, food, souvenirs.

Very relaxed interesting morning.. Had a lovely morning walking around the Rocks and looking at the market. Lovely market with all sorts of interesting stalls, from Honey to glass blowing. Very well organised and the food was great with their choices. I noticed a lot of people going there to have their breakfast while they walked around. Lovely hand made chocolates available from Brazil.
Do an evening tour. We did an evening tour of The Rocks with Free Tours. Our guide was great, providing a lot of interesting information and detail about the area.

Enjoying the afternoon sun. We arrived on a Sunday filled with markets stalls. Busy and buzzing with people everywhere had a great atmosphere. My and husband grab a takeaway food. Wandered around enjoying the afternoon sun finished it off with a drink in one of the many bars. Great start to our first day in Sydney.

Stayed near the Rocks.. Enjoyed the history of the old buildings and had a beer in one of the old pubs.Nice breakfast at the Rocks Café , they make great lemon meringue pies, biggest we had seen.This area is a great location as it is very close to the overseas ferry terminal for our cruise ship and circular quay harbour ferries.Short walk to the Opera House.Also can hop on a double decker bus with the top deck open to view the sights of Sydney.

You have to visit the Rocks.. We went to the Rocks on a Saturday. There is a market on the weekend and it is worth a visit. There are plenty of places to eat, have a drink, a coffee or just take in the atmosphere and views - there were lots of little courtyards tucked behind the eateries and bars.

Lovely but nothing exceptional. If you come from Europe and use to see lovely streets and tiny places this quarter is not amazing, yes it's nice and pleasant to walk in but that's not soooooo exceptional to me.
You'll find a lot of cute restaurant but be carefull with the quality/price ... you'll pay the place more than the quality.
Worth visiting. Although there can be large crowds, this old part of Sydney is great to visit. Plenty of hotels and restaurants close by.

Best Place to Stay. I would thoroughly recommend staying in this area of Sydney because of how easy it is to get to everywhere you need to go. It is very close to Circular Quay and has a lot of great restaurants.

lovely place. What a amazing market late weekend~!
You can see world most expensive goods beside that street~!
And do not forget pancake at rocks~!

Australia's First Port. A wonderful place to learn visually about the humble begiings Australia had. Many of the buildings speak for themselves. There is something here for everyone from the pubs, galleries, cafes, restaurants and the incredible hrabour, Opera House and Harbour Bridge.

Walking around the Rocks, Sydney. Very interesting part of Sydney to visit. Full of history, lots of little shops - some very touristy and expensive but some good cafes. Also keep on going up out the other side to as there are some interesting buildings and view there.

Always an interesting visit. There is always something new to see at the Rocks whether it's a festival, community event, or just shopping for something new. The history of the area also makes this a great place to explore.

Historic stroll with great restaurants. I've been through the Rocks multiple times and always discover something new. The old brick buildings are charming and there are several historical walks you can take along the way. There are also lots of shops and restaurants - if you have time go to Paddys market to buy souvenirs - they're all over priced in this area.

Historic Area. We wandered thru the neighborhood on a lovely weekend afternoon. There were markets to shop and some historic dig areas. I was glad to see the areas preserved and hope they continue to share more information about the area.

A part of old Sydney. The Rocks is an area that still has one of the very oldest buildings of early Australian settlement by the English. The area has many pubs, fine restaurants and hotels. Nowadays it has great markets, and hosts special events like Coffee and Chocolate festivals. The Rocks is situated very close to the harbour where the ferries pull in and you can easily view the Opera House which is just across the water. You can walk from The Rocks around the foreshore to Darling Harbour another interesting place to visit. I would say The Rocks is a great place to visit.

Talla Wa La Doh, the Rock - Unique of Sydney. Never ever miss the Rock when visiting Sydney.talla wa la doh is the origin name of the Rocks. uniqueExplore the unique of this area with old building with cozy atmosphere and don't miss walking through nurses walk - fascinating.Capture the beauty of sydney opera house at night from the cruise wharf. it's Stunning and extraordinary. Visit the Rocks market on the weekend and try delicious lamb or kangaroo skewer.
Old meets new architecture. Great area to walk around and enjoy old meets new architecture. Thoroughly enjoyed the markets they hold here and great places to eat all around. Best views!

Great Sunday Morning.. This old area of Sydney is a wonderful place to visit on a Sunday morning. All of the market traders set up stall and it is a buzzy, fun place to spend a morning browsing a purchasing. The food area is particularly interesting a caters for just about ever taste.

Good restaurants, quaint little shops, old town feel, tourist prices. The Rocks is a nice place to visit, if only for the window shopping and to see how the area has been developed to retain the feeling of old town Sydney brought to the 21st Century. However, be aware that food, souvenir, or pharmacy prices in this area are high. We bought a 20 tablet box of Advil for AUD$10, which we later found out, we could get at Pricelline for AUD$4.99. We also stopped at a small little nice coffee shop where we paid AUD$40 for 2 coffees and 2 pieces of pastry. Moral of the story: anything you eat here or buy here will normally be 100% more expensive in comparison to other areas of town.
Great place great times. The best place to witness the New Year's Eve fireworks for the atmosphere and the lovely locals a like
Trendy. Must-goo. Trendy, vibrant, full of pubs and bars where you can enjoy a good wine. With an artist cosy flea market on Sundays. Nice views to the Opera and the Harbour Bridge,

Interesting. This is a small neighbourhood which has some of the oldest houses in Sydney and the oldest garrison church in Australia. Some of the roads are carved out of stone which is very interesting. The views from around the observatory are some of the best in Sydney and definitely worth a visit to see. There is an interesting market on Saturdays with local tradespeople selling various craft items. All in all a good time.

Always a plesure to stroll through the Rocks in Sydney. After walking through Barangaroo, we end up at the Rocks. Strolling through the Rocks area is always a pleasure because of the old colonial architecture and quaint buildings etc. Through the Argyle cut brought us to a foodies market which apparently is open every Friday - bought some gourmet deli products and strolled further around to Circular Quay. The Harbour was shining in the sun and there were lots of people around boarding one of the big cruise ships that was moored at the International terminal.
Nice area . Good for a stroll or a visit to one of the old pubs. I recommend the cook house where you barbeque your own steak from prime meat and get tasty sides for an ok price
Hens weekend. What a gorgeous place the Rocks is!! Great food,sites,shops,cafes,pubs,atmosphere. Spectacular harbour!!

a nice old town full of character. welcome to the old Sydney full of wonderful corner to be discovered you will find great little private hotel away from the commercial big properties So many restaurants to be find of high level and quality shops of all kind special opals and artsarcades and the the access to the bridge theatres and great living area The cruises terminal also and museums a full day can easily fill with wanders.enjoy your Rock experience.

Great way to spend a few days! . The Rocks by Sydney's beautiful harbour is a really vibrant place to spend some relaxing hours. Explore the area full of historic buildings and lane ways . Spend a lazy day at the weekend markets really quality and some very unique goods! Eat and drink at any of the amazing food suppliers . Catch a ferry across the gorgeous harbour and stop off at any of the lovely stops. Visit the iconic Opera House or climb the bridge. There's enough here to keep anyone amused for days either on a budget or cashed up . Well worth your time.
The Rocks. Our hotel was in the heart of The Rocks area Definitely the best place to stay in Sydney with access to virtually everything
Awesome!. The Rocks is indeed an awesome place. Highly recommended for all ages....do participate in the Free Walking Tours, good eye opener of the history of the place which is so rich and amazing.
Dining & Entertainment. A wide variety of restaurants and pubs and live music to experience on Friday & Saturday nights. There is a Sunday street market at the top end of George St the Rocks.
Walk around. The rocks is good for about 3 hour walk around, Looking at shops and craft markets , Shop rents are high so the prices are too , The best place to eat is Pancakes on the rocks ,Yummy!

The Rocks a 'must do' in Sydney. Food Markets are so interesting. Don't have breakfast so that you may me tempted to taste all the various ethnic foods on offer here. Take a walking tour to learn the history of this area or sit and while away an hour with a coffee. The Rocks - ROCK!

Australian Hispter Weekend Market. I know weekend markets or bazaars are so not mainstream these days. But then again it is integral to explore if you want to immerse yourself in the culture of the locals.I do recommend a visit to the Rocks and Circular Quay area over the weekend. Markets open from 10am - 5pm.You can find things designed and made by locals - jewelry, soaps, candles, clothes, leather items and more. Oh, I bought my boomerangs here. It's cheaper than the airport.But. As far as markets and bazaars go; I must honestly say the size and variety on offer isn't Bangkok. Or some of the expansive Middle Eastern ones.
La Renaissance Patisserie. A very cute little authentic patisserie with GORGEOUS cakes and pies. The out door patio dining is lovely ( weather permitting)

Happening Place. Great vibe, lots of energy and fab place to grab a coffee - or wine and sit and people watch! There was a chocolate festival on Saturday & Sunday with a few comfy chairs and big screen TV playing 80's classic songs. Fabulous sunny weather to sit around and munch on chocolate deserts!
The rocks rock. A fantastic look to our past . enjoyed every single step . Don't miss out . Do make the effort to see Barrangaroo.
Great market. Went to the market on Saturday. Wide array of products and food items to buy. Something for everyone set in a fabulous setting just neat the Harbour Bridge

One of my favourite places. The Rocks is a must when in Sydney. It's a historic sight of the city with buildings of lovely architecture. There are many things to do here - from eating to drinking to shopping or even just taking a slow walk around the area to soak up the atmosphere. There are some really nice little cafes and pubs in the area. One of the best times to come to The Rocks is over the weekend when the market is open. You can shop in a relaxed environment or enjoy some food sold by the vendors on the street. Truly a lovely place.

Lifetime experience. Beautiful cafes, restaurants, pubs and places to stay. Good shopping stores for clothing and food. Always can put on a show with their music and food festivals and definitely worth visiting being close to the bridge and harbour.

check out the rocks. great place for a market nice relaxing environment, lots of interested places to eat, bars, shops and buildings to see close to cruise ship and boat docks, many small streets and shops great place

take your time. Fascinating area, among old and well restored buildings, shops, pubs. I visited it on Sunday, when there is an interesting market of handicrafts. It is possible to spend hours looking around, snooping in the shops, stopping to appreciate a beer....

The Rocks, Market and Food. The Rocks was a very interesting place to visit. The different architecture compare with the rest of the sydney brings you back to how it was like when the colony started. The Rocks Market was lots of fun with things to see and buy. Stop by Pancakes at The Rocks and our kids were so pleased to have pancakes for lunch.

Great Market Area!. We truly enjoyed walking around the market at the Rocks as everyone there was so friendly and so nice. We loved all the local goodies that people were selling as well as all the great smells coming from every direction. This is a great place to go stroll around and just people watch for a few hours!

Wonder around the streets and the market.. Been there for a long walk. Had the luck to get there during the weekend there was the chocolate festival.I guess that usually there are not so many people there, nor so many things to do.The area itself is very nice, and has a special atmosphere.I recommend going through the market and get to the bridge walk.(I don't mean the climb that costs money. Didn't do that, simply walk on the bridge and see the view.
Visit the Rocks. A brilliant area tucked away near the bridge, full of interesting bars, shops and buildings. A lot of small streets with character.
The best place to get lost. Nice place for all day. Morning for breakfast or evening for great pubs. Relaxing environment. Recommend to stay in an hotel close by. Also near the harbor.

We walked around the rocks area. We walked around the rocks area and went out on the Docks. Then we found the Bounty was in harbor and decided to take a ride on it. It was a blast seeing Sydney harbor on the reconstruction of the original 1787 Royal Navy sailing ship. I even got to put on the captains hat and steer the ship through the harbor. That ship has since sunk in a storm a few years ago but it sure was a blast to have been on it. After that we went to a great restaurant and had a great pancake brunch. We then climbed the tower of the Syndey bridge and had one of the best views in the area or the Harbor and the opera house. It was a very memorable part of our visit to Australia.
The Rocks. Loved the Rocks, great walk , restaurant , food, wines Very interesting history. Highly recommend at least 1/2 day

Tourist Area Full of History. I really enjoyed our numerous visits to The Rocks, lots of great little coffee shops and the market at the weekend is worth the visit. Hard to believe its origins and history.

Nice area for shopping, eating...but not cheap. Based on local marketing I thought this was going to be a much bigger area than it actually was. Pedestrian-friendly and filled with cafes and boutique shops. There are also a number of walking tours that you can take although we did not opt for these. Sydney Bridge tours are operated from here. On the weekends there are a couple of different markets - a "foodie" market on Friday and a food, artisinal goods market on Saturday and Sunday. As it is a very touristy area you won't find a cheap meal here, or a cheap beer. As mentioned in other reviews, however, we found Sydney to be a rather expensive food city overall. The locals seem to agree. I would recommend visiting the Sydney Visitor's Centre at the Rocks. Tons of info and all for free. We tried to make a donation as we were quite impressed but it is all funded through the government and they don't even accept donations. Worth a look.
Great neighborhood away from the noise of the CBD. Loving the Rocks - some great small businesses here, great pubs with interesting history and my fav street food in SYD - the Japanese pancakes :)

Must see for tourists. The rocks is a beaitoful loacation and is a must see for all tourists and new comers...circular quay is the closest train station and from there you will find the Opera house and the Sydney Harbour Bridge, two iconic world famous locations ... also for those history buffs is the rocks precinct one of the oldest parts of Sydney. With beautiful heritage buildings, tours boutiques and kitch little business this is defiantly one of my favourite places in Sydney.
A little bit of History. The Rocks has such a great atmosphere especially when the markets are on each Friday. Lots of eateries and shops to browse with a vibrant feel

full of nooks and crannies. I visit at the same time each year and love to walk around The Rocks, most especially visiting the market on Sunday morning to stock up on goodies from The Liquorice Shop stall. Always something new to look at, the signs around the area the depict the area's history are fantastic
interesting market to walk through. vendors of the stalls were friendly. a lot of the usual fare but some interesting merchandise from individuals. worth a w all around and conveniently located

An important part of Australia's history.. First a quick history lesson. "The Rocks" is probably the oldest residential area in Australia. It's called the rocks because it is actually built on a sandstone rock ledge on the west side of Sydney Cove (now called Circular Quay). Like most cities Sydney grew organically from its original setup. The rocks provided good views, the Tank Stream, the only fresh water source, fed into the cove and was easily accessible and it separated the government "military" functions from the public (though they were originally mostly convicts). One of the oldest buildings "Cadman's Cottage" is wedged between the Rocks and the Quay near the Overseas Ship terminal. It's typical of the early construction, built in the first thirty years of settlement, and it was actually on the beach front, giving an indication of the change in topography over two hundred years. There are many other old buildings around the area and "The Rocks" precinct preserves much of the architectural evolution and history of white man's colonisation of an ancient land. The credit that it is preserved goes to the Builders' labourers Federation (an Australian workers union, since disbanded) and in particular to a man called Jack Mundey who instituted a system of workers strikes called "Green Bans" to stop the government of the day approving demolition and reconstruction and selling off much of the heritage buildings to developers to build high rise buildings (similar to whats happening at Barangaroo, just over the hill, as I write. But that;s another story). Had the Green Bans not worked, much of what can be enjoyed today would be gone. Today the Rocks is overshadowed by a great Sydney icon the magnificent Harbour Bridge. Nonetheless it is a very pleasant place to while away a few hours with interesting craft and specialty shops, some delightful Irish Pubs, brilliant cafes and on weekends "Craft Markets". A walk through "Argyle cut" in Argyle Street leads to Observatory Hill , the quaint Garrison Church and other historically significant residential buildings. On the Quay side are some of the original store houses, now converted into restaurants abutting the wharf, which make for perfect strolling conditions on a nice spring day. It's probably the best place in Australia to imagine what it was like in the "early days of settlement" and compare the "improvements" we have wrought since. But most of all it is a place to relax and stroll. Enjoy and savour the atmosphere, soak up the history, buy a unique bargain and enjoy a beer or a Guinness, eat a humble meat pie, a banquet or something in between, the choice is yours.

Great. The rocks market at the weekend is fantastic - lots of stalls selling a variety of different things. There are plenty of pubs and restaurants in the area - you will also be able to find Sydney's oldest pub here! Some great shops too....

A bit of history on a market day. This district has preserved its roots and architecture but can offer you a valid alternative to the city shopping on market days. In fact, its colorful stalls display different merchandise, from aboriginal art to pottery, from ethnic clothing to wooden furniture. It's worth a visit.

Weekend at The Rocks. Loved The Rocks. At the weekend there is a Craft Fare with lots of unusual things to buy. Lots of people snd shops all lend to the vibrant atmosphere. When we were there, there was a jazz band playing,and we sat on a bench enjoying people watching, listening to the jazz. Had a Harley Davidson ride on a trike driven by Harry. Great fun. Took us over the Harbour Bridge, around the beaches, and back. Another thing achieved on my "Wish List". There is so much go do and see. Allow yourselves lots of time if you want to go at a slow pace.

The Rocks. This a lively location within Sydney! you will find great shops, restaurants and pubs!! A must visit is the Sunday market, the stall holders are very friendly we found a guy that 'spray' painted different views of Australia, we purchased two which now hang proudly at home!

Best brekkie and market I visitwd. For a high quality breakfast and interesting markets this was by at a highlight. Far more interesting and beautiful stalls than other markets I visited, and the free Rocks Museum was a fantastic facility to see about the origins of Sydney.

Very unique!. You can find almost anything, and also almost anything you never even thought of, at The Rocks. With rows and rows of street vendors, artists, and various types of craftsmen, you can't miss. Fascinating variety of clothing, foods, artworks, etc. Hard to resist buying something!

Old world charm meets urban cool. If your visiting sydney don't miss an afternoon in The Rocks. Grab a craft beer while soaking in great views of the harbour from one of the many drinking holes.Try and avoid the souvenir shops and check out some Australian fashion on George St. There is often live music at some of the pubs in the evening from Friday through to the weekend and check out what festivals are on at The Rocks as they often have events throughout the year.

Australian History at it's best!!. The Rocks, right on Sydney harbour is a spectacular place to visit, to think all those stones where hand carve, all the roads were hand carved by convicts, because The Rocks is one of the oldest places in Sydney, the history and eeriness is a feeling like no other. There is always a market, or something going on in The Rocks. So much history to see.

The old town charm. Mmm... when I think of the Rocks. I think of markets, fine foods and the beautiful cobblestone path.The place is buzzing with all kinds of excitement on the weekend with the market stalls, and if you grew tired. Grab a coffee and a macaroon from the Renaissance Cafe. There are so many wonderful place to go around here.

A startling mix. The Rocks, saved from destruction by a citizen group and Jack Mundy's leadership of the Builders & Laborers' Union, recognises it history and demonstrates it in the wonderful buildings and rocks and lanes. Unfortunately, most of the shops Jack could never have considered entering - expensive and glitzy. Still fun, and the weekend market has some good food and lovely Sydney-made craft. Quite a startling mix.

Best place to take international visitors!!!. If you want to show off our city - THIS is the place to do it.From the rooftop cocktails at Harbourview Hotel to a beer at the Roof top at The Glenmore Hotel.It is just such a beautiful place.

ok. we visited rocks in the evening time so most of the shops were closing . we did manage to see the museum with interesting history. 30 min to 1 hour is enough to see this area if not shopping. will not recommend if your stay is short in sydney.

Make sure you're there on a Sunday!. A nice stroll around the Rocks area is a must. Lots of cafes and restaurants to choose from and some shops to browse as well. If you're a shopper, make sure you're there on a Sunday to check out their Sunday markets - lots of local artisans with edgy creations. The Rocks is very close to the Bridge Climb, so if you're planning on doing a climb, I recommend you start with a climb on a Sunday morning, then hit up the Rocks for some market shopping and food.
Perfect place to stay in Sydney. Perfect location to stay in Sydney. Close to tourist options at Circular Quay, close to Harbour. Don't miss the weekend markets!

Old and interesting. This is an older area of Sydney city. There are lots of lovely old buildings. Lots of bars, cafes and shops. Go at the weekend if you like street markets! You can take some great photos of the bridge and opera house from this area.

Contemporary & tasteful. A walk at The Rock will certainly enlighten your journey in Sydney. The atmosphere and environment there are so pleasantly nice that the whole area can be deemed as a outdoor open air gallery. There are so many eye-catching buildings and architectures which will keep you occupied and also the scenic view of Sydney Harbour Bridge as backdrop doesn't stop to amaze you. Many fine dining and eateries are situated there to pamper you with delicacies. A must visit when you are in Sydney.

Historic original neighborhood in Sydney. There are many historic buildings and a nice museum showing the early days of the British settling of Sydney. Cobblestone streets and many shops and restaurants make it a quaint reminder of the city's founding, now developed into a major yourist destination.

Historical Neighborhood . Our hotel was in the Rocks. So we ventured to the center area of Rocks few times during our 5-day stay in Sydney. Old Sydney started in this area. There were many nice restaurants, pastry shops and bars. There was also a market on Saturday with food and crafts.
MUST VISIT. A stroll around the rocks is a must with so much history to explore as is a visit the markets. A fabulous choice of cafes and restaurants. Not to be missed.
Sunday Market & brunch. Awesome spot even in the rain! best lovation for a stroll around the area and some unique little stores.

Worth a visit. A glimpse of Sydney's past,try not to miss the Saturday market which spreads through the Rocks area. Lots of interesting craft stalls and some of the bets buskers you are ever likely to encounter.

Sydney's oldest community with great history. Take a free tour to learn more.. It's a must visit for history buffs. Take one of the free tours to learn more about the area or go to the excellent free museum next to the visitor info office. Lots of restaurants and eateries.
Aussie Vacation. The Rocks is a beautiful place to visit, the Restaurants and Pubs is a place to relax and enjoy the view of Sydney.

Where European Sydney began. History, food, architecture, shopping, tours...it's all here.mdifferent vantage points for glimpses of the bridge. Old hotels, and terrace homes...garrison church. Lord Nelson Hotel. Argyle cut. Ghosts??

Looking a little bit neglected. Yes thus is a small area and probably done best at night when you're off to have something to eat or drink. Some of the warehouses have been turned into really nice seafront eateries. Overall the area just doesn't have a real wow factor like the darling harbour area which is a real shame.

Charming Neighborhood. The Rocks is a darling neighborhood, filled with shops and restaurants and lovely views. Amazing to see THE ROCKS next to what's been built there. Great for browsing and eating.

Don't miss the Rocks. If you really want to experience Australia at it's beginnings you shouldn't miss the Rocks. Loaded with Australian history, museums, shops and restaurants bring it all into focus. Take a walking tour and learn even more. Thoroughly enjoyed our stay and the experience..
Liked the museum. Nice area to visit, with some Sydney history. We especially liked the museum that told us lots about the arrival of The British and the development of Sydney.

A place with history. We spent two hours walking around this place and was worth it. Quiet, old neighborhood with some nice shops and cafes. Do not miss the shop with hand made soaps on the back street.

Relaxing & Vibrant - Great For Weekends. Definitely recommended for weekends when the markets are on. Heaps of things to see, do & eat. There are also some really nice quiet spots to chill out and relax with a view to boot.Prices may be slightly on the high-end for a number of places given it's such a popular tourist spot, but definitely worth going to experience the area and hunt for a bargain.A great spot for souvenirs shopping as well.
Sunday market. We wandered around the Rocks on a Sunday morning when it was market day. Lovely older area of town. Quiet area.
Historic. Great neighborhood, lots of old pubs, galleries and shops. My wife and I really enjoyed a leisurely afternoon taking it all In.
Go to The Rocks. Lovely place with nice bars and food outlets, if you can be there when the Market is on, make sure you go, lots of interesting stalls and merchandise to look at!

Fun place to take a stroll. Walked through The Rocks today to check out the Friday Foodie Market. Despite being pretty small, every booth had something interesting or yummy. Try the Biltong air-dried beef - it truly is better than plain old jerky! Lunch was a roast pork roll with ''crackling" from Phillip's Foote - it was so good that our original plan to just share a single sandwich went out the window. And the lemon sorbet from Giorgi's Gelato was refreshing and had just the right balance of sweet & tang. Wish we'd had room to try more items - the line for the Turkish Gozleme wound down an entire alley so it must be good, and everything else looked worth a try as well. We also enjoyed the live music by Lawrence Gratton who was set up in the public seating area. If you can't make it on a Friday, there are regular weekend markets on both Saturday and Sunday. Walking among the historic buildings on the cobblestone streets & alleys is a grand trip back in time. There are plenty of restaurants, cafes, and shops in the area to keep you occupied all day, and it's adjacent to the ferry dock so the convenience and views are great.
Full with Sydney's history. Defacto place to visit while in Sydney. You will experience the oldest buildings in the city. The tourist market that happens over the weekend is a must go.

Great little historical place. Sydney's oldest suburb. Nice restaurants and cafes here. Not very far from Circular Quay, Harbour Bridge, Opera House. Enjoyed my time there, although it's not a place where you can spend the whole day there. It's good to go there have a look, have a meal or coffee and then leave. If you go at night, you will enjoy the restaurants and bars there. There is also a nightclub there as well that gets busy on weekends.

History mixed with great food options, music and markets. I promised my wife that the next trip to Sydney we would stay in the Rocks area and it was fantastic. From the markets on the weekends, great choices of restaurants and pubs, a walk full of history and proximity to city I think it is the best area to stay in Sydney. My wife loved it as well.
Great views of the Bridge and Opera House.. This is a must area to visit and wander around in. Good spot to check out the bridge and Opera House views. Good market on Saturdays.
Not a lot to see. Not a lot to see in itself. However, if you have a guide to take you through the history, it is absolutley fascinating. A vist to the museum may do for some.

The Markets at the Rocks. I took my adult daughter to the Saturday markets at the Rocks. We had breakfast at a little sideway café and then roamed the markets. What a great way to spend a morning. There is a great variety of stalls - something for everyone.
The Rocks that rocks. Its definitely a great place to hangout in the evening or at night. Restaurants and pubs are plentiful.

Old mix New. Must visit list.. a good example of old mix new, and Sydney make this so nice and well kept Lots of bars and restaurants offer food at reasonable prices. However, it did not spoil the history inside. Fantastic job.

Charminho place. This is the oldest part of the city. There is a lot of charming little stores there and on Saturdays and Sundays there is the street market with a lot of beautiful and original artcraft and antiquíssima. Don't miss it.
There is also the Museum of Modern Art to contrast with the old building.

Explore. The Rocks is one of our most favourite places in Sydney. We love spending a lazy Sunday afternoon walking through the street markets, exploring the shops and eating in the Rocks fine restaurants and cafes,
Lovely area to wonder. What a lovely area to wonder and relax. We found that there was plenty to see and do and we could also sit and relax and enjoy beautiful views
I love to visit the market at the Rocks. Great area to have a wander and check out art and design. Short walk from Circular quay. Friendly market folk and my friend and I bought some clothes.

Micro brews and designers shops.. Designer shops and hipster bars have overtaken what was a historic piece of Sydney burying the past in bright signs and trendy markets, if your looking for some of historic Sydney visit bridge street. If you want a micro brew or Ken done art print then this is the place.

Weekend Market. The Rock weekend market is a Must go place for shopaholic. lots of stuff to browse and interesting art works by local artist.
A lot of cafes and bars.
Had the best German Pork Knuckles at Lowenbrau Keller.

Dare. Went to Dare for a great breakfast. On the 30th August. I had the full breakfast and the staff were friendly and efficient. Loved the eclectic cutlery and plates gluten free and cater for ceoliacs and vegetarians as well. Go check this place out. Highly recommend it.
Go get Glamourus!. my most fav place to go to ,I love window shopping and the Market on the weekend is lovely beautiful things and it lovely and clean and set out well

Grab some food at the markets. The Friday foodies market is worth visiting - there is a very long line up for the Turkish Gozleme. The things they sell at the markets are ok - nothing I woldnt find anywhere else - but it's a nice part of Sydney to be in so I recommend it.
Explore in peace and quiet.. Evocative old quarter close to the harbour bridge with period buildings and modern conversions. Take time to stroll around and take it all in.

A great excursion for the weekend. There is so much to see at the Rocks. You will be spoilt for choice for restaurants, cafes and bars. There are the markets on the weekend which offer a massive variety of merchandise to buy. The place is full of life and vitality and a must see place for locals and visitors alike.
really it rocks.. The rocks is a happening place in sydney. It has lots of cafes, pubs, restaurants and shopping. Saturday evening at rocks is really fun.

great area. There's a lot of good stuff in this area. There are lots of places to grab a yummy bite or bakeries that are serving amazing sweets. You can have a drink here or do a little shopping. It was such a cute, historic area.

Whiskey. On The Rocks.. The Rocks is a funny place. Funny because if you're a local it's often the kind of place you often only go to if you have visitors in town, and you get to be a tourist in your own city. Or otherwise if you get drunk, as I did in this case after some random function & end up running hi jinks on back cobbled streets into yesteryear and discover how incredible & beautiful the city was before it became ordered and designed into dull grids. The perfect solution to this is a combination of both the former. BYO hip flask or other fave device and go explore this incredible time capsule of Sydney's history with all its nooks and crannies. Perfect for lovers. And good friends. Under the stars.

Iconic area a must for visitors take in the history and views. Fantastic restaurants, chic shops, great pubs usually with entertainment and awesome scenery! wander through the Markets on weekends and just take in the sandstone buildings and history of this infamous area

Fantastic place on the weekend. The Rocks has some great local restaurants, but the main drawcard on the weekend are the local markets. Over 200 stalls with a variety of items for sale. Always a bargain to get and something different from normal shops.

Great place to shop & feel history of the city. This is one of the oldest parts of Sydney. The Bridgewalk is in this area so it's easy to visit if you do that tour. There's a tourist information center here that is very helpful and informative, and has a place for you to make bookings for tours and excursions, and answer any questions. There are lots of little shops to visit and we found all of the shop keepers to be very friendly and nice, and not at all pushy. Some things may be a bit more expensive here since it's so touristy so you may want to check out some other places first to do some price comparisons. We didn't take the historical tour but I was told by others that it was very good. We did see some school children on a field trip trip learning about their history. It's well worth a trip here!

Early History. We were surprised to find the little known diggings part of which were under buildings which show the footings of the small buildings built around 1850 and were demolished in 1902. An amazing piece of history. Lots of other interesting things to see in the area as well as great eateries.
my favourite part of the city -. just great to find yourself in the older part of town - I felt this area was quite authentic with some interesting shops and the oldest pub in sydney

History of Sydney. The Rocks is located around Sydney Harbour, Sydney central business district and Circular Quay, and is the most historical place in Sydney. There are guided tours for people to join and get to know more about its history. It is surrounded by many European style bars and cafes. A must visit place in Sydney.

Great place to stroll, shop and eat. It was a very rainy Sunday when we went to the weekend market. We were told that quite a few of the pop up market stalls didn't open due to the weather. It was still fun to browse the stalls. The information center had quite a few brochures and a great shop for Australian mugs, books, shopping bags and other items. There is a foodie market on Friday but we were a bit disappointed in that we expected more options. The Turkish stall had a very long line. The Contemporary Art Museum is located here as well as the Rocks Museum. Both of the museums were free when we went. The Rocks Museum talked about the early settlers in the Rocks area which was quite interesting. There is a wide variety of great shops and restaurants in the area. It is just adjacent to the Circular Quay, which is a transportation hub for trains, buses and in particular ferries. There is truly something for everyone.
An insight into historical Sydney. In part a bit touristy but your best options for a insight into historical Sydney & really essential part of any visit to Sydney
Love the rocks!. One of my favorite towns in Sydney, has a lot of character. Nice shops and cafes. They also have a market Friday-Sunday, just a beautiful place to take a stroll and grab lunch.

Great area with great markets!. The area is great to walk around to see a bit of history and architecture! Great views across the harbour to! The small food market on a Friday is a must the food all looked amazing I wanted to eat everything! The craft market on Saturday is also great to! Made a visit to the institution that is pancake on the rocks open 24/7 and does amazing sweet and savoury dishes!
Great Place to Visit. So many things to see and do in this lovely old area of Sydney.The shops and restaurants were very trendy, and we just enjoyed looking at everything.
Old Sydney & New Sydney. Excellent place with lots of nice bars and restaurants. Love the atmosphere of combining old Sydney and new Sydney.
Beautiful. Beautiful old buildings and can highly recommend the pancake shop, open 24/7, Pancakes @ The Rocks! The day we went the market was on and was very nice.
Party time. By the bridge over the Sydney Harbor, did quite a bit of partying here but ate elsewhere. Very touristy area, not many if any locals. On the pricey side.

"Old meets new at The Rocks". Beautiful, historical buildings amongst the bustle of The Rocks certainly is a lovely way to spend an afternoon.
Funky food stalls, great restaurants and bars and local musos make this an entertaining spot for a fun dinner with friends.
Its only downfall is the lack of parking but fortunately the public transport is excellent.

Rocks with a difference.. Spend some time just wandering the area. Plenty of shops,restaurants and bars to keep you occupied all day.Able to walk to the bridge towers and see some amazing views of Sydney harbour.
Lovely atmosphere. It is a pleasure to walk around the rocks, market is lovely, there is a new art gallery which has some beautiful paintings. Great cafe

Great place to spend a few hours. Loved the rocks, fun to shop, a nice little freebie museum to walk around in and overall very nice. On Sat and Sunday there is an open air flea market style setup in the street that was very fun. I bought some real licorice for a guy that makes it and bought the wife a nice Opal piece for around $350 bucks, but there are plenty at cheaper prices that will make your wife or mom happy.

The Historic Heart of Sydney. Get away from the harbour and head into the old lanes. There is plenty of history in this part of the city (well... for a city that has 200 years of history.... :) Be sure to check the weekend markets - always some nice local craft to be found.

Good Job only had half a Day. Loved The Rocks and everything it had to offer but glad a was short of time otherwise I could have spent all day eating and shopping, but great location and worth walking out around to Millers Point along the wharf/dock area especially under the bridge towers got a nice and different view of the famous landmark

Magnificent view of Sydney Harbour.. This is a truly fun place to visit because of the history in the buildings and the eateries and authentic pubs. You get a fantastic view of the Bridge, Opera House and get a real feel for the energy of the city with the comings and going of the ferry traffic.
Interesting place. A very interesting part of Sydney, it is the history that makes it exciting. We had a guide with us who took us on a walk and told us about the place. Thoroughly enjoyed.

Fantastic place to while away an hour or two. Great views, historic buildings, wide variety of places to eat and drink whether you want coffee and cake or beer and chips.The markets are a must see - not the usual market offerings but quality items of all descriptions, many hand made and with an Aussie flavour.
Welcome to Sydney - have a great day!. Lots of market stalls, some good pubs and a good number of buskers/entertainers. Very friendly people and a lot of fun

Lazy Day in Town. Great way to spend a morning before a great lunch in the nearby restaurants and pubs. lots of interesting market stalls set up throughout the historic Rocks area. If restaurants are not your scene the markets also have small eateries with a variety of foods from all countries available.

Holiday. This was the second time we went to Australia and the second time we chose to stay in a hotel near the rocks. A charming little corner of the city next to Circular Quay. Plenty of shops, market stalls, places to eat and in walking distance of Opra House. Would recommend.

Quaint location. A lovely location. The Friday Food Markets are fantastic. Get in early, or risk missing out on some great food. Grab yourself a treat and purchase some Chocolates from "Emporium of Chocolates". The flavours are amazing and the guys that work the stall are lovely.
