Historic area. Sydney Harbour, the Rocks historic area was once home to aboriginal people and later became the country's first site of European settlement.. I I believe, more than 100 heritage sites and buildings jostle along the narrow streets including very old houses.You can visit Rocks Discovery Museum. Afterwards, walking around the narrow streets with their souvenir shops, restaurants, cafés, and aboriginal and contemporary art galleries, or shop at the market stalls.
Old Sydney town. Great place to see a bit of old Sydney town. Little shops, galaries and cafee's galore.Make sure you walk to the waterfront. Saturday mornings they also have markets.

The Rocks Markets on Sundays . Hello Tripadvisor Blind Followers (which I can be also). The pictures and write ups for this area don't tell the full story. You are completely missing this area unless you are goi g to the "Rocks Markets" on Sunday's between 10 and 5 pm. This is the largest market of really classy and interesting merchandise I have ever seen in the world. I spent two hours going up and down St George street and all of the side streets. When the market isn't going on, it is just a pub and restaurant zone. A good one at that but the attraction is Sunday's.

Love the old historic pubs in the area. If you like the good old fashioned historic pubs with the sandstone walls & colourful histories you can't go past the Lord Nelson & Hero of Waterloo located up the top of the Rocks near the observatory. The Lord Nelson even brews it's own beers on the premises & doesn't have any poker machines or music playing in the background, so you can catch up with friends have a chat and a few beers and enjoy the ambience of yesteryear.

A must on your list - The Rocks,. Great place to mooch around and sample the wares at the food stalls, sit, relax & listen to the music and pass the time people watching. An amazing place. Suitable for children too, but as a couple the time is yours to peruse around, sit & have a beer/ wine or two. So much history to the place, awesome.

Best place to stay in Sydney. 5 minutes from our hotel and an area we came back to every nightThe Rocks comes alive at 5/6 pm onwards- weekend street markets, museums Restaurants and cafes. Favourite specialist shop was ChocolArts - sold wonderful chocolates and good value hot chocolate. Good restaurants- some gave limited seating inside Close to circular quay, human scale, interesting buildings and good mix of shops from high end to tourist tat and convenience stores

Not to be Missed. This is one of the most historic parts of Sydney that should not be missed. There are markets on some of the days and are fitting with the atmosphere. Pubs and cafes are not to be missed a must for all to stroll through.

Eclectic mix of old and new. A nice part of Sydney. Boutique hotels, restaurants, coffee shops, stores, markets and artisans. Lovely to walk all the cobbled streets and climb the crooked stairways. There are lots of stairs and steep streets so not very wheelchair friendly. Plenty of activity after dark - pubs and restaurants with music spilling onto the pavement. Close to the harbour, bridge and opera house and circular quay for transit. A good place to stay or explore.

Rocks and rolls. Nice place for a stroll, plenty nooks and crannies to explore with some nice galleries to browse. Friday food market was great, kangaroo was succulent and tasty., worth a try. Plenty places to eat and drink....... Worth a few hours of your time.
Beautiful. The Rocks is a lovely area to walk around and take in the sights. There are plenty of little shops and great restaurants to have a wonderful meal
Nice place. You can hang around the rocks and you can feel the Australian passion. Highly recommended, but a bit pricy.
Nice place to visit. There are many different kind of booths such as selling homemade accessories, craft and snack. It is a nice place to visit and just close to Sydney Opera House.

Rocks around the Pubs. Normally I go to the Rocks area on Sunday ! To have shopping in the area for fashion clothing or enjoy pizza restaurant there for lunch . There are many small shops selling antiques and painting or gift items for overseas visitors . There is Germany restaurant for Germany Cusine and serving Germany Beer . there are many pubs there . Visitors like the area for drinking in the pub. Most of the pubs are own by ex policeman . The area are very save for visitors there at night !

Historical Sydney.. This part of Sydney has been preserved over the years. The alleyways and little streets make you feel what is was like to live in Sydney back when it was a colony to Britain. Go views of the Harbour Bridge and Opera House. Plenty to eat too.

Lovely area, good shopping, well worth a wander.. A lovely part of Sydney. Lots of nice cafes and restaurants as well as boutique (and not high street) shops. Bought basically everything I got in Sydney here. Not cheap but lots of options. Also some of the only vegetarian restaurants I found in Sydney were here.

The Rocks, Sydney, Australua. The Rocks, Sydney, Australia - is a great shopping area in do wanton Sydney. Fun area to visit and explore. Bring your walking shoes and enjoy the food in the area as well.
Rocks. Great place to visit,lots to do and see. There is different markets on different days. Lots of shops and eating places. Worth visiting

Part of the place to visit. Very nice district of Sydney near the Harbour. Lot of shops, art galleries and restaurants. plenty to discover by walking around. This is the oldest part of Sydney which has been very well rehabilitated

What a Great Neighborhood!. My favorite part of Sydney; uh, check that, every part of Sydney is my favorite part! To me, this is an essential part of my arrival day . . . jet lagged, tired, but must stay awake -- stroll over to The Rocks Visitors Centre, get acquainted with its very interesting history, watch the video, and then stroll around the charming streets until it's time to take your Captain Cook Harbour Story cruise (formerly known as the Coffee Cruise) at 2:30pm. What a day!

Lovely area you should not miss!!!. So much history here and a lovely area to walk around. Lots of shops and cute restaurants with outdoor seating. Go in the day and at night. There was a lovely market there on Sunday.

The Rocks inviting always for look around and enjoy old Sydney sides. Just next to Circular Quay are The Rocks, enjoy good food, a beer or drink in an old pub there or yeah, why not, go a bit for shopping in nice little stores or look in to some galeries.

Great for everyone. The Rocks is one of those rare areas that I would take any and all visitors to Sydney and just know that they will love it! The markets have great food, clothes, art and souvenirs. There are so many good bars and pubs around for a quick stop in. It's in the shade of the iconic bridge and overlooking circular quay. There is the archeological dig and it is all so steeped in history, just a great, great spot to visit while in Sydney.

Few days stay. Enjoyable area with history to live in. Early morning walks a treat wondering around the back street discovering hidden gems of history. Transport easy access with arrange of food and drinking choices to relax in.

Great place to grab a drink and walk around. If you're visiting Sydney, you cannot miss The Rocks. The area is full of spirited pubs and great food, along with shopping and great places to stay. It's walking distance to the harbor and easy to wander by foot.

Mysterious history ;). This neighbourhood was amongst the first dwelling places, when the giant penal colony called Australia began developing. Read up on the history of the Rocks before meandering through the bylanes of this neighbourhood and you would be excited to know the mysterious historical escapades surrounding this area.

History, shopping, dining all in one fab location. Fantastic fun locale to just wander and soak up the history and great shopping here. The open air markets are great for locals and tourists. The dining options range from fine to pub grub and everything in between. You can't go past the walking tour that let's you in on the history of the area. Just a fantastic spot to take in what Sydney has to offer.

Great Place To Wander. There is so much of Australia's early history in this area with beautiful old sandstone buildings, pubs, eateries and shops. The weekend markets are great, then head down to Circular Quay and spend hours just people watching or visit the Museum of Contemporary Art.

Artsy, historical and cosy area to stay and dine in!. Great venue to stay , eat and watch the world go by! the boutique hotels were historical gems with cosy creature comforts; the restaurants wee trendy and offered great views from rooftops; and we chanced across a gorgeous art gallery featuring works by Ken Done and Billich!

Rockingw eekends at The Rocks, Sydney. If visiting Sydney Australia, you cannot go past the Rocks, weekends are a rocking with a huge market, fresh foods and giftwares for any occasion, go and see the Corn man for your lunch, I guarantee you, you wont stop at just one, enjoy

Great place for a slow leisurely walk on the weekend. The Rocks is well worth a visit when in Sydney. The weekend markets stock lots of handicrafts from local producers. There are lots of old pubs at which to have a drink and a meal and you can have a look at the Sydney Harbour Bridge from a different angle (ie from underneath). You are also a very short walk from Circular Quay with its Ferry rides and Restaurants.
Not overly interesting. I thought there would be a lot more history there, if there was it was well hidden. There are lots of bars etc

Iconic Sydney site with upmarket feeling. The Rock is still a must visit Sydney site..it got the authenticity of real classic Sydney.. There are plenty of shop which mostly target the tourist n Sydney deep pocket demographics.. They had Duty free shop.Most pubs n restaurant already well established.. N a must visit pancake on the rocks..which their BBQ ribs n original pancake my fav...In the weekend usually Saturday, the Rock market will be a place to see for the cool product n food stalls.If you catch a train,stop from circular quay..and if you from George Street city..catch free tourist bus that run till 5pm and stop at circular quay.Make sure you has good pair of good shoes..because the rocks hidden gem will be found by wonder around..You can also visit museum and an authentic old store if you walk bit more in the alley way.Take your time and enjoy the Rock charm
Shopping and eating. Great shopping, food and drinks. A smaller area to walk around lots to see and great shops. You can get there by bus, train, ferry, a must to see.

Where it Begins. The Rocks is a wonderful area with an overlay of early Sydney buildings that were fortunately saved from demolition and redevelopment many years ago from the efforts of Jack Mundey who had the foresight and vision that is truly appreciated by all Sydneysiders. You will enjoy wonderful walks, art, food, pubs and fashion and some leading fine dining restaurants all painted with the ambience of old Sydney. Situated right on the most beautiful harbour in the world. This is a bucket list place for any overseas traveller and you would do yourself a favour by attending the market days.

Australia Day at the Rocks. A must do. Australia Day at the Rocks Sydney is the most fabulous fun colour patriotic experience to enjoy. Buskers everywhere, music RAAF flying overhead not to mention Sydney harbour with all the yachts boats everywhere Food to enjoy with lots of laughter and meeting all international visitors and mixing with all multicutural Australians. If you haven't done it then you have missed the most wonderful magic of Australia Day.

Time capsule of early Sydney. The Rocks has someting for everybody. Its whats was once hidden but is now being brought back to life that is of most interest. Buildings that are being renovated or demolished to make way for new buildings are revealing the past. A pleasent walk around will be very rewarding historically. ... plus try the older style pubs for lunch. Gives you the opportunity to dream about what it might have been like to live here back in the old days.

Australia's history. You could spend more than a day here and you would still miss out something. So much history in such a small area. Make sure you look at everything including the pavement - you will be surprised how much history reveals itself.
Interesting Area. Love The Rocks area. Loads of things to do. Great shopping and eateries. This time we visited with friends.
The Rocks - Rocks. Great markets at 'The Rocks' Sydney during the weekend, plenty of stores to choose from and interesting people

Great place to visit. Really good to browse the shops and street cafés.
Great views of the harbour and the opera house.
Wear sensible shoes and be prepared to walk to get the best from The Rocks.

Great history. Check out the Aborignal walking tour to understand more about the history of this beautiful area. The area also boasts some of the oldest restaurants and bars in Sydney which are worth checking out.

The Rocks. Walked around The Rocks by ourselves and saw the old buildings, with a tour you may have a commentary. On Friday there is a food market and on Saturday the market is jewellery, crafts and clothes. Well worth a visit. The Rocks is just a short walk from Circular Quay.

Beautiful enclave!. Friday foodie market was on target! Heavenly Turkish Cözleme, sausages, the ubiquitous fish & chipa and the delicious skewers of octopus & lamb were available.
One can spend a whole day here!

Great Environment!!!. Close to the quay its this area that's a mixture of old and new Sydney. With an industrial set up as a landscape, it offers plenty of restaurants and small shops, and the occasional open market, for the common tourist and the near by local. A great place to see how small alleys and shops can be transform into a trendy area, this place its a modern beacon of urbanization. Interesting and edgy...

Morning, afternoon or evening - it's great. This was right next to our hotel which was great. Lovely area to walk around and some top cafes, restaurants and markets. Lovely ambiance.We loved afternoon tea with cakes at some lovely coffee houses there.

A step Back In Time. One of the great places in the works. An eclectic mix of very old and new, retail and food and beverage and accomodation. 3 star to 5 star. Much of it is hidden down small lanes and alley ways and behind the facades of nineteenth century. The harbour bridge sits quietly alon the western edge of the Rocks, with Circular Quay to the west and the the waters of Sydney Harbour to the north. The weekend markets are a must see. At the extreme northern end of the CBD, a visit to Sydney is not complete without a visit to the the Rocks.

Old Sydney and New Fun. What a delight! So many cool old buildings, bars an shops. Great green and wooded neighborhood streets . Great people and so much to do and see. My son and I checked out much of the area by foot while doing a bit of a Beer Safari. Had plenty of good craft beer at The Australian Hotel, The Lord Nelson and The Fortune of War (arguably Sydney's oldest pub). Barely scratched the surface. Passed a huge world class dance club, many great looking restaurants, plenty of shops with plenty of wares. You could easily spend a couple of days or more and never leave the Rocks.Be sure to check it out.

Old World Feel. Interesting place to visit and wander through the streets filled with restaurants, old buildings and shops. We had a very enjoyable dinner at "pancakes on the rocks"On the weekend, the market has stalls of food, jewelry, clothing etc.

Fun shopping stroll on weekends. On the weekend (Saturday and Sunday) there is an open marketplace in The Rocks. There are many tents with crafts, jewelry, clothes, artwork, leathers. Many are handmade and unique items so worth walking around the tents. There are cafes, restaurants and bars throughout The Rocks so many choices for food and drink. Even a small food court at the location of the Sydney Visitor Center building. There are lots of people in The Rocks since it is the closest place for cruise ship people (across from the cruise terminal) and also tourists in general since next to the Circular Quay. Nice on the weekend but less during the week since the open Marketplace is closed.

The Rocks rocks!. Historic area near Circular Quay that we always make it a point to visit whenever we're in Sydney. Plenty of shops and restaurants with views of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge. During this trip, we visited on Friday for the food market, which was basically food stalls put up by surrounding restaurants that offered relatively cheaper eats. The real find was the weekend market that we went to on Saturday, which featured several Australian handmade bags, crafts, leather accessories, jewellery, tiles, and other assorted products that were on display. As to food, the children liked the buttery, salted, and peppered corn on the stick, as well as the fudge bars.

The Rocks. Had a great time at the rocks loved the old buildings pubs and arty markets. Stayed at the YHA fantastic hostel. We had a double room with view from the window to the Opera house.The roof terrace has wonderful views of the Harbour. You need to book ahead to get your room. The Rocks is so central to everything trains buses and ferries.
Ok. Okay. An old part of Syd.A few nice shops good views of the harbour. All OK but nothing to rave about. But not knocking it.

Rocks Market. Fantastic and different type of market. Wonderful stalls with very unusual items to sell. We bought lovely earings, different baby clothing with unusual sayings on the front. There is a stall that makes musical instruments from wire - amazing.
Great places to eat. Great place to eat. great place to spend time wandering around . Lots to see and do/ Lots of little shops selling all sorts of things

Not very impressive, would not revisit. Had heard quite a bit about The Rocks, but it seemed a bit tired, with quite a few closed shops and crowded restaurants trying a little too hard to be trendy. (This, mind you, was off-season). If your time is limited, walk the Circular Quay for better views instead. Better yet, hop on the ferry to Manly.

A walk back in time. Although this has not completely kept its old world feel, there are enough old buildings around that we get a glimpse of life in early Australia. It's quite touristy but that's to be expected. N

Exciting Place to Be. It was my first time in Sydney for some years and I had forgotten how great Sydney was and especially the Rocks. I was there on a weekend and we went to the markets that they have. So many great stalls and interesting things to see. This is worth a look in itself.

Sydney Rocks!. The Rocks is Sydney's oldest residential area. It is full of early 19th Century buildings, great pubs, eateries, and a market where stall holders sell interesting and pretty things.Join the weekend crowds. Wander its interesting streets or stop for a drink or a meal or both. Shop for bangles or other pretty things. There is always something interesting happening here.

The Rock - the heart of Sydney. The Rocks is THE PLACE TO STAY in Sydney. Everything is close by.In only 15 minutes walk you can visit dozens of restaurants, great shops, the Sydney Opera House, the Sydney Harbour and the famous Sydney Harbour bridge.We stayed at "Holiday Inn Old Sydney the Rocks". It was a great Place in every way:Nice clean rooms, great service, best breakfast buffet and a breathtaking view from the roof-pool!

Definitely someplace you need to visit while at Sydney.. We were here during one of the Market Day's, which was great. Stopped by and had breakfast at Pancakes at the Rocks. We also did a Rocks tour, which was very interesting. Definitely

A differrent entertainment avenue. We passed through The Rocks on our way to the Harbour bridge climb. The small small paved roads alongwith multiple street cafes, well decorated bars and snack corners makes this area a beautiful entertaining place. The shopping mall beneath the information centre sells quite a lot of souvenier goods and hand made handicraft items. The Chocolate shop is also worth visiting.
happening place and great street markets. Great street market on Sunday, making it a fun place to browse; plenty of interesting eating options if the shopping makes you hungry.

Interesting part of Sydney. The Rocks was a centre of working class settlement in the early days of Sydney. If you take a walking tour, you can still see remains of the tightly packed houses that for years gave the neighbourhood a bad name. Now it has a Bohemian feel, with open air music performers and trendy cafes and street market. Well worth seeing if you are in Sydney.

Center of Attention. The Rocks is a great area to stay at. It is literally across from the Sydney Opera House and a direct shot to Downtown Sydney for shopping.The Rocks has amazing restaurants to dine and has easy walking access points all around.

The Rocks rocks!. Love going to The Rock and the excellent markets there on the weekend. The Rocks is steeped in history and wandering around the wonderful areas reading all about the convicts and early settlers is fascinating. It is also close to Sydney Harbour. I would highly recommend this area to tourists and locals alike who enjoy walking through historic areas. Lots of fabulous market stalls with locally made products as well as yummy street food.

Close to Darling Harbour. We stayed here for a few nights during a tour of Australia for our honeymoon, the hotel staff were so helpful and friendly. The rooms were contemporary in a heritage setting which was so convenient for Darling Harbour. We thoroughly enjoyed it and are looking forward to returning one day.
shop till you drop. Lots of places to eat and shop. Very busyy area and interessting old buildings. We also found the shops rather expensive and touristy

How can you not enjoy the Rocks?. we stopped here during our stay, and loved it it's right where you want to be no messing about getting taxis or other transport just out the door and your there!
Cafes, pubs, restaurants whatever you want it's here.
Nice friendly atmosphere and never felt threatened at all.
Also very close to circle quay and the ferry boats.

Great views of the Opera House and a museum of art to boot!. This is a nice shopping area proximal to the Sydney Opera House. The stores don't have anything original, but the Museum of Modern Art is a nice visit. The ferries are around the corner.

Rock On. Great place for a nighttime stroll along this area with great views !
There are some really lovely bars and restaurants along here!
The night we were there, there was fireworks over the opera house, great different views from the other side of the harbour!
Wonderful. How amazing is this place. It really blew my mind all of the rocks that we seen was so amazing everything around was great I would definitely come back here

Neighbourhood not to be missed. Interesting neighbourhood, old-world charm. Completely different front he rat of Sydney. Plenty of places to eat and pubs. And don't miss the Rocks Discovery Museum. The walking tour will give you a great insight on the neighbourhood.
Very touristy.

Great market. Fun, quirky market stalls filled with handmade goods in a beautiful location.There are plenty of restaurants and bars in The Rocks area for families, couples, and businesspeople. As with most of Sydney's attractions, The Rocks is very easily accessible.I would definitely not spend the whole day here but because it's so central, you'll be able to get anywhere you want with plenty of ease.

Love The Rocks. We spent a week at Sydney Harbour B&B located in the area known as "The Rocks". it is a delightful area filled with the charm of old Australia. From the lavish Shangri-La Hotel to the every day Pub, an area will worth experiencing. Only a short walk to the famous Sydney Harbour Bridge, or the world famous Sydney Opera House. The main transportation hub, Circular Quay, with access to all of Sydney and the surrounding area, is just a short walk down the hill. As is George Street with shopping galore I would highly recommend The Rocks area as home base when visiting Sydney.

On the Rocks - just the way I like it!. The Rocks has a fascinating history that you can learn about from the free museum and plaques along the walk. At the same time it is a happening place right now. Great pubs, restaurants, and the weekend craft and arts market is amazing. I loved our two walks through The Rock.

too much to do. i just love the rocks.we started walking from the haymarket towards the darling harbour and then the rocks.there is so much to see on the way to the rocks and lovely pictures to be taken along the walk of the rocks, bridge and the harbour and opera house.

The Rocks at Night. this is a walk with a twist! We decided to go on the early session of the Ghost Tour after a long day. As it is Winter, be sure to rug up as it was pretty cold on the night. Let your imagination run wild.We found it informative as the guide delved into the history of The Rock, digging up the eerie stories and ghost tales. Some of it are real and based on the past: murder, violence, disease and hauntings . We thoroughly enjoyed ourselves and I even got to carry a lantern. Be sure to wear suitable shoes as there is a lot of walking on uneven ground. You'll be advised of what to bring when you book. It's fun.

pubs a must backstreets please ignore the main street. YOU CAN GO SHOPPING HEREBUT THE Pubs are great, check out the nurses walkenjoy a beer at The Harbourview Lord Nelson The Hero Of WaterlooWalk all the back streetsSee if you can find the playground with harbour views pretend to be a pirate on the ship!!!!!!!So yes take the kids to the Rocks to.........head way up to the backstreets for a great view of the Anzac Memorial bridge too

Vibrant experience. Great day out whilst visiting Sydney. Vibrant markets mixed with the oldest section of Sydney settlement. History and art combined. For the keen photographer you could spend hours snapping away. Then relax at one of the many cafes and restraunts especially Wine Odyssey sipping Australian wines and people watching.Travel by ferry, train or bus.

A little area, that is in the big city, but feels VERY DIFFERENT. Fascinating! These historic buildings are a treasure. A great little perk, while you stroll, shop and eat, there are tidbits of history on the walls, that give a glimps into what you are seeing. I loved the Rocks!
Rocks markets. An enjoyable Sunday morning spent browsing the outdoor market. Very tourist oriented as you would expect.

Spend A Few Hours Browsing - It's Worth It. Go anytime to savour the atmosphere of one of the oldest areas of Sydney, now being brought back to life....although if you go at the weekend you have the bonus of a fantastic crafts market where, for once, the quality is first class (so many street markets around the world end up as a front for poor quality second class goods). Great fun exploring the market stalls, quirky shops, coffee houses and bars........blink and several hours have gone.

A nice old quarter in the heart of the city!!. Filled with shops, restaurants and bars, this is a great place to stay if you are coming to the city. Some nice food stands were set up on the weekend and the weekend market was also nice. The choice of restaurants was extreme, something for everyone.

True Sydney feels. The Rocks is a vintage market place with nice authentic Australian goods available on sale. I went on a friday so the foodie market was on that day. There is a bike rental shop where you can rent bikes and ride along the shore.
some great old buildings. get up onto the high ground and explore some fantastic old buildings and pubs, plenty of character and history, with glimpse of the bridge
Delicious Germany food. The Rocks have hiding delicious Germany Bar:Lowenbrau Keller !Big jug of beer. best pork knuckle in Sydney.live music !will come back soon

walk around. the Rocks is the area originally settled by the convicts and the British Army. The old barracks and gaol (Jail) is there. This area is at the harbor and is really work a walk around. There are tons of small shops from cheesy tourist to high end boutique. Lots of art too. Good cafes, bars and restaurants. Don't miss the history though of the area and go see the historical sights.

Visit "The Rocks" in weekend. I took a walk to the Rocks during a sunny weekend. It was a sunny day on 25 Jul 2015. Walked slowly uphill from Argyle streets. The fascinating taste of snacks stalls on both sides already attracts me. then turn right into Playfair street. You can easily spot a authentic German restaurant selling sausage and port knuckles. Keep going to the end and turn left to a true flea markets with all sorts of local handcrafts and arts. You can easily spend 2-3 hours here. Strongly recommend to start from morningly like 10am to take a breakfast or lunch nearby. Also don't miss oversea passengerter

Old Sydney. The Rocks are a short walk from the CBD and Circular Quay. The buildings are old and from another time, well preserved. You don't feel that you are in a city. It's lovely to explore the streets and side streets. I particularly liked the view in George St which had the Harbour Bridge looming on the skyline at the end of the street. There are some great shops, restaurants and centres around here. When you are done you can visit the Harbour Bridge or drop down to the Quayside and on to Circular Quay and the Opera House. When we were here there was a large cruise ship docked.
One will return..... Best food in town. Vibrant area with a lot of good restaurants and bars. I kept going back every night.

Where it all began. Our hotel was a short walk to the Rocks, so we decided to explore the area. It was a wonderful combination of restaurants and shops. We enjoyed a delicious dinner at an excellent Italian restaurant, and bought a lot of souvenirs in different stores.

Glimpse back in time. Lovely part of Sydney that shows one of the few places in the country that is well preserved and some of our history. In a country where we don't have 1000's of years worth, it's a testament to the Green movement who made this area what it is today. Went for the weekend markets and a walk around the old buildings, plenty of places to eat and drink as well.

Awesome. We spend the afternoon here and enjoyed every moment. This is a cool place with much to see. We had a drink at a small place and talked to other tourists and a few locals, all very nice. Will be back for more.
Interesting area. You must visit The Rocks whilst in Sydney, within walking distance of the harbour it's a varied combination of shops, restaurants and bars. Some lovely little hidden places.
Amazing Place. great atmosphere with amazing cafes and restaurants and such a nice place to walk around it always seems to be buzzing with entertainment and things to do

Must see when you visit Sydney!. We visisted the Rocks twice during our trip. Once to take in all of the old buildings in the area and the other to visit the weekend market.i suggest visiting the area during the week to take in all of the old buildings in this area as its not as crowded as the wekeends.If you plan on going to the markets, the earlier you get there the better. By late morning its completely packed with people and takes a lot longer to get around.

Great area to eat. Great choice of restaurants and bars, some with seating outside, where you can relax and watch the world go by. There are a few small restaurants specialising in pies which are very tasty - and good value for money.
Great Cafes. Visited this area for brunch. A great choice of eating places. Awesome views. Easy walking distance from CBD. Would definitely go back.
Markets at the Rocks. Loved wandering around the markets looking at (and buying) market goods plus being entertained by the buskers. It is a great atmosphere.

Historic Sydney. We went to the Rocks Sydney for an evening meal and were surprised how much was on offer ,some excellent pubs and Restaurants .So much History on every street so much to see and easy to get to with bus and ferry services .

Nice now and interesting history . You can learn everything about the history in "the rocks museum " (watch the movies) and the visitor centre next to it. It's really worth to go and completely for free. You could also join a free guide who is starting his tour everyday (except 25.12. & 31.12) at 6pm.

Amazing Weekend Shopping. This was such a treat. It was wonderful to walk up and down the street visiting all the local vendors. There were amazing things to eat and drink, and lots of great stuff to buy. It was one of the highlights of my trip and I was able to get all of my souvenirs.
Buzzing. Markets and cafes, waterfront and sunshine, all I needed as part of my city break. An interesting place to discover.

Buzzy, Modern, Old and plenty to eat and drink. Variety of food, clothing, jewellery and accessories all the stall owners are very helpful and friendly, we went to the Irish Pub called the Mercantile which is in the alley way where the stall holders are...food was great along with the company and the music was lively as you would expect an Irish Pub to be. The Sydney Harbour Bridge is a 5 minute walk and so is Circular Quay. Very busy but at a leisurely pace.
" the most wonderful 'slum' you'll ever visit". Spend an afternoon and well into the evening. Definitely turn into narrow alleys that you would otherwise avoid. You'll be awestruck!
Interesting area. The Rocks area is great to walk around and explore. There are markets every weekend which add to the nice atmosphere. There are plenty of places to eat.

Never tire of visiting the Rocks.. The Rocks is always interesting for a walk around. There are always people about, so many little pubs and eateries, the markets and history just make it a great place to visit.

Old and new together. One of the oldest small buildings is in the Rocks. As Sydney grew other buildings were built and many of those have now been given a new lease of life. A wonderful place to wander through. Lots of places to eat and visit. Sit and watch the harbour and gaze at the Opera house opposite. A great market on weekends.

Markets and Places to Eat. It was a nice area to walk around with some places to eat. We were there during Vivid so that was possibly why there were street vendors. I think most people would love this area. It was just ok for me. There's a free walking tour of the rocks so if you enjoy history then you should definitely look up the 6pm free walking tour that is also listed under the attractions. I heard a little about the area and saw it so that is enough for me and didn't need to do the full walking tour. The Rocks is something you should go see and is a big part of the history of Sydney.

This is Sydney !. Gorgeous area not to be missed! You name it, it's here at The Rocks- breathtaking views, awesome atmosphere, history and fun tours, museums, restaurants, bars, theatres, shops and markets, art galleries, unforgettable walks. We live in Sydney and live to visit this gem as often as we can. One negative - lack of parking.

Market is a must. Great walks around the Rocks to explore the back streets, the boutique shops and restaurants, and on certain days of the week, the markets. A great Irish bar half way up the road with live music was great, and up behind the Rocks you can access the Harbour Bridge climb. For those who just wish to walk across the bridge, the access is a little further up the road. Well worth visiting at the weekend.

Best internet find ever. Thanks to all you reviewers on TA, we blind booked a hotel on the Rocks and it is THE place to be as a tourist in Sydney!! Lovely little restaurants, my husband and I pick a different breakfast spot everyday and haven't hit a dud yet! It's been a week! Lots of bars and shopping and incredible views of the bridge and Opera house! Would come back to this spot in a heartbeat!

Not sure why this is such a popular area. The Rocks is one of the oldest areas of Sydney, so I suppose that makes it worth the visit. But after wandering around the area for a few hours I really don't know what the fuss is about. There are some smaller lanes off the main road with shops and a few restaurants, but nothing remarkable. We ate at the oldest Pub in Sydney, and it was okay. The ocean liner cruise port is there, so on days when the ships come in it can get pretty crowded. Some nice views from the foot of the harbor bridge.

Plenty great restaurants around. Spent the most time here during a ghost tour, atmosphere is great and restaurants are always full. Sometimes they host festivals like the White Rabbit and Vivid which are very entertaining and fun events to hang out with friends!

Fasinating!!!. Full of history, small lane ways and plenty of places to eat and drink. Take a walking tour through the area as you will learn heaps more than just walking around. Plus you will walk through different alleys and hallways while learning the history of the place.

Historical Sydney. Went on a Friday evening & it was a pleasant experience. Restaurants were pretty crowded but worth the wait. Walk around to see the old architecture. Nicely maintained by the authorities.
The Rocks ROCKS!. Well worth the trip for anyone visiting Sydney. Quaint shops, historical buildings, cobblestone roads, the best Pancakes in town, and overall a terrific experience.

Historic section of Sydney. The weather was terrible on the day we visited the area from a rain/wind storm. Many tourist shops mixed in with authentic and unique little restaurants and pubs. Historic part of Sydney that requires a guided tour if you want to learn the history. Due to the weather we weren't able to enjoy outdoor seating. I can only imagine how entertaining this area is during busy periods.

One of another highlight. This is one of Sydney highlight. It is located near Sydney harbour bridge. While walking along the street, it is a zone with lots of yellow and brown old style buildings. Enjoy the old town atmosphere.
European Experience . A very good European feel as we walk along the stone paved pathways of the Rocks. The restaurants and shops along there are really nice too.

The Rocks.. I love the Rocks. Its like the worlds longest ongoing party and the Aussies have reinvented that for sure. The area Isn't that big but its big enough with a restaurant/bar every door. Amazing. Disneyland for adults. I find Aussie Ale is too light for my taste but they make the best lager ever. Wait till you see the beer engines. The Sydney Opera house is across the road and across the bay. Tour boats operate nearby. And don't forget, up the hioll on the side streets are the hidden gem bars. Little wonders.

"The Rocks" Likes to think it does.. The rocks is a name given to an area below the Sydney harbour bridge. Legend states that this was the location of the first settlement. (That is if you discount the Aboriginals). Therefore is probably the oldest inhabited area in the city. Like old towns the world over the tourist industry sees a good earner. That being the case it has it's fair share of tourist tat outlets and a few reasonable quality restaurants. From here can be seen a fine view of the harbour and the world famous gig that goes by the name of "Sydney Opera House" A most remarkable example of imaginative architecture.All in all a good few hours can be frittered away here enjoying the sites or enjoying lunch. Oh yes if you like opals there are more than a few dealers in this lovely stone ready to take your money.This revue if based upon several visits over a 20 year time period.
Rocks markets. Relaxed interesting atmosphere with good variety of food and crafts at reasonable prices set in the beautiful rocks area Great weekend market

Vibrant, friendly lots to see.. What a great day out, had a spare day before heading off on our cruise, so we wandered to the markets which had lots to offer, saw families picnicking on the grassed area, two beautiful old sailing ships moored and taking on excited passengers for their cruise of the harbour. Very friendly and safe area for families.loads of photo opportunities.

A must see area on your visit. The Rocks is such an interesting area - with lots to see with an easy stroll. There are of course shops, places to eat or to have a drink, or see something cultural here too, such as the museum of modern art, and it's all a stones throw from circular quay. If you had limited time in Sydney you could spend the day wandering around the Circular Quay and Rocks area and you would have seen so much. And there's something for everyone.

The begining of the British colony.. The Rocks is an interesting place to visit. Lots of the first buildings are still there to be seen. Try and imagine the first settlers arriving. All gum trees and a creek to utilize as there first settlement. A small beach front in the bay now called Circular Quay is where they landed.

Lots to see. i love walking around this area - there's so much offer, no matter what you want to do there'll be something to suit you. Have a few beers with friends at a lively pub, do some top-end shopping, buy souvenirs, watch the harbour, learn about history or eat very well - take your pick or do it all! It's all within a few hundred metres. The atmosphere is lovely, with a hint of history and fascinating architecture too. Perhaps climb the Harbour Bridge while you're here too? Enjoy it all ...

The Rocks Markets are excellent!. The markets here were amazing, there were so many stalls with different items - loved exploring all the local designers and artists! Plenty to buy and see here! Some great restaurants as well!

Old part of the city. Sydney's Rocks is part of the old European settlement sector of the city. Here you will find old warehouses, now converted into smart restaurants or indoor markets and malls. The Rocks has it all and is a magnet for overseas tourists. Here you will mingle with people from all over the world, in the shadow of the iconic Harbour Bridge. On the weekends there are the Rocks Markets, which are great fun and where you might find that special treasure to take home. Located adjacent to the Circular Quay area and looking across the Quay to the Sydney Opera House, this is a good vantage point to begin a walking tour of Sydney City. Accessible by bus, train and car, you wont have trouble getting there. It is not advisable to take your car because city parking is a scarce commodity and paid parking is prohibitive. If you are in a nearby hotel, just walking is best.
Good weekend spot. The weekend markets are a great way of passing away the time. They have wonderful handmade goods, lovely food and some awesome buskers. Saturday's and Sunday's.

Ghost walk. We went on the ghost walk around the rocks which was fun and very entertaining our guide was dressed up in 18th century clothes so he really looked the part. He was really good and full of info about the rocks, the tour lasted about 2 hours and great value for money. My sister-in-law booked it for us and she also came and enjoyed, it which was good for a local resident. We would recommend this trip to visitors visiting Sydney.

Worth a visit. Would recommend doing it on the weekend as it is more interesting with the markets. Quite fun to just walk around even if you are not buying anything. Could be a bit crowded though. Do it together with a walk around the Sydney Harbour area and it will make a great day out.

Sydney rocks popup art walks. Plan ahead and get the most out of The Rocks. I was fortunate to chance upon free popup art walks at eventbrite. The guide took us to many places to view graffitti, galleries, Ken Duncan's gallery etc. Be prepared to wear comfy shoes as you will be walking alot.

An Extension of Circular Quay. The Rocks is just another area around the Quays. As a matter of fact, it is an extension of Circular Quay opposite the Opera House. It is lined with bars and restaurants (again, pricey - expected of a tourist attraction). We hang-out in a restaurant called Waterfront. They have great food and fantastic view of the harbour. It was also a great place to see the Vivid Light Show. Great place to take pictures, hang-out with friends and capping a long day of touring. For some reason, looking at the water just made me feel relaxed, after a lot of walking in the city.

Walk around The Rocks. From Circular Quay, walk to the left and you will find the area, interesting with lots of quaint little bars and restaurants. And after exploring The Rocks, walk the steps up the Sydney Bridge.

Loverly!. I love the Rocks. Reminds me of the old London. Little cobblestone alleyways with wee quintessential sandstone houses that you can just imagine to be full of drunken sailors, vendors and merchants. Think Jack the Ripper and Sherlock meets Harry Potter and My Fair Lady. The time seems to have stopped here. Enjoy shopping for bargains in many arcades full of wonderful galleries or just chill in any courtyard over a pint. Marvel at the wonderful harbor views or visit a little museum The Rocks for a dash of history.At nightime, this is a totally different story. This is when the Rocks come to life. No visit to the Rocks is complete without a long evening full of beguilement spent in one of the pubs here. Somehow, the walk to the nearby Circular Quays, where you catch the train home, seems a rather long way after too many pints.

A great urban treasure.. Loved the opportunity to see this historical urban area. It's great that its unique identity in a otherwise metropolitan city is thriving. To do a walk around this area is such a nice way to spend a couple of hours.

Great area to visit. Lots of history in this area and some great walking paths that lead to some excellent photo opportunities. I highly recommend that you check out the neighborhood "market" (one day a week but not sure of the day) where you will find locals selling unique arts, crafts and clothing. Make sure you check out the licorice stand as that was our favorite!
Pubs and History. Plenty of history and great old pubs I really enjoyed the Orient. A must visit when in old Sydney town.

If you love history a must visit. Thanks to the union movement in the 60's this fabulous historic treasure trove of Australia's white settlement was saved from ghastly high rises. Around every corner you find another historical treasure, not to mention boutique art galleries and great food. It's a must visit on every trip to Sydney I make and a bonus us it's right on Sydney Harbour with great views of the Bridge and the opera house.

Beautiful heritage sandstone buildings. If you are lucky enough to be in Sydney on weekends, you "HAVE TO" visit The Rocks Markets. Quite similar with what having in Paddy's market but I would prefer here because of its rich history. The vintage ambiance can be felt all around the area. They have handmade crafts, beautiful arts and great food. It is a very nice place to go in Sydney I would say ;)

Must go. Opera house is in the area too. Train station and ferry terminal is walking distance. Daily free tour is conducted by the local which will give u a in-depth understanding of their history and why the rocks come about. For info of the free tour, grab a Sydney map or ask your hotel concierge. The rocks is also a great place for dinning and shopping. The rocks market on every Sunday is worth going as well but the prices is alittle on the steep side but you can be sure you can get quality stuff there.

Worth the visit to The Rocks. Great spot to visit, the historic Rocks area is worth the visit, oozing with history with story telling all around the area, it has a lovely feel with its worn sand stone steps and narrow lane ways. Lovely in summer with its alfresco dining but even in winter most have heaters for outdoor diners. Good pubs and great restaurants and with the views of the harbour bridge all make for a great place to be.

Vivid Festival. Visited the Rocks during the Vivid Festival, casually strolling around in the evening, to view the harbour and surrounds to see the lightshow. The whole area is great for tourists or locals, alike with plenty of places to eat, drink or simply watch the wield go by.

My passion roaming around the Rocks markets. The Rocks is the place to visit. There are so many small art galleries and shops that will tantalise any passion you may have. The weekend sees the Rocks markets which is my favourite after a much love River Cat ride from Parramatta.The restaurants of an evening are fabulous especially in summer, The Waterfront Restaurant is one of my favourite places with its aray of food choices . After dinner I love a stroll along the water with my family.Special occasions we stay at Harbour Rocks Hotel a boutique hotel is such a lovely place full of character and charm.Its the place to be for a weekend away.
Jet Boat Rides. spent the day walking around the rocks,,there is so much to do...historical buildings every where...restaurants galore..the views are spectacular..

Interesting and historical. Really enjoyed taking a walking tour and learning about the history in this area. Lots of wonderful little shops and places to shop and eat. With the tour guide who gave the history it was a very interesting walk.

History at its best!. For out of towners, and even locals, there is nothing better than spending time with this old lady....The Rocks.So much to see, do and shop til you drop. Besides its right next to a great view. Visit one of the oldest pubs and enjoy a drink with the locals, or have afternoon tea at one of the best scone and jam cafes where the service makes you feel special. Want some art, pop into one of the galleries or buy some unusual clothing from of the boutiques. Spend big or just window shop. It doesn't matter as the place has so much character. Enjoy!

Not a shoppers areas. Sydney promotes this as a shopping area but Dont shop here. Its expensive! The place to go as i've discovered is Paddy's market. The Rocks though has very nice restaurants around the area which I would recomend.

Views, View and more views!. Do you like to shop and not have to be in your ususal Mall. This is for you. The shopping is easy and the food court is to die for. Take you food out side and enjoy the view of the harbor bay. Don't pass this one up it is a gem.

Great restaurants. Our daughter is having her wedding reception at a venue in The Rocks and we went for the final wine tasting snd dinner. Even though it was cool they had lovely outside heating. Great food, amazing view of the Harbour and a great atmosphere. A must to visit if you are in Sydney
Characterful. Amazing area to wander around dotted with local artists - do make sure you buy a lovely bright picture!

Beattie Bow and Beauty. I've had an infatuation with The Rocks since I saw the film "Playing Beattie Bow" as a child. The history and the beauty of the area are unsurpassed. The area holds much more allure for adults as well, the restaurants and authentic pubs create a culinary adventure and social experience not available in other pockets of Sydney. Be sure to take your walking shoes and a healthy appetite. Don't be afraid to venture off the beaten path!

DONT MISS A VISIT. When in Sydney The Rocks is a must see if you want to couple Sydney'sHistory along with the vibrancy that only this area has to offer.Markets are great fun and you can pick up some great artistic one off items.A stroll through the cobbled streets is a step back in time and there are an abundance of restaurants serving plethora of delicious food. Great hotels with harbour views.Close to ferry and trains so easy to get around.
must visit ROCKS. This place is near ferry terminal and one must visit this area to know the history of Modern Australia ,how this country has started its journey from ROCKS

Great place to spend time. Hotels, restaurants, cafes and beautiful historic buildings. Visited on a Saturday and really enjoyed the open air market. Speciality food stalls, interesting handmade items and good quality souvenirs. Also fun to get close to the Bridge.

Love the rocks. Every time we go to Sydney we visit the rocks, great location to stay as well.
Plenty of bars / cafes / restaurants around and the markets are great to stroll through.

The Ol' Lady has still got it..... I remember coming here as a kid of 8 years old. I took my kids there and we had a great time for sure. Its truly a must see in Sydney. Its the heart of the development of the country from the time of white settlement and significant for that if nothing else. It has great shopping and great places to eat and just enjoy the vibe.

buildings and cuture. this was a wonderfull stop to look around and i wish i had known about it before hand so i could of spent more time here...wonderfull older building on orginal streets....views of the harbour and restraunts galore

Great Experience. We have been to Sydney a few times now and always love heading down to the Rocks. The variety of shops means you can lose yourself with so much to see and do. Last time we were there was on a cruise ship that docked in Circular Quay, the light show was on and the markets were open. A credit to everyone. We will be back as this is always a must do.

The Glenmore pub. If you're looking for a vibrant pub at the Rocks ,the Glenmore takes the cake . Sitting at the top end of the Rocks with views from the rooftop beer garden over Sidney harbour , circular key ,the coat hanger and the Opera house , this is a vibrant meeting place for young and old. There are several quirky bars on different levels all catering for the discerning Pub grub diner and also providing a good selection of wines and beers. Enjoy !!
Historical area. Loved this part of the city. It feels a bit like an old village in a city centre. There are lots of lovely restaurants, pubs and cafes. Really enjoyed wandering around here.

Historic Sydney. Enjoy walking around Sydney's historic area. Lots of varied accommodation types. Historic buildings, Harbourside walk, restaurants, tours. Museum of Contemporay Art, overseas Cruise terminal. The Rocks weekend arts & crafts markets are a must see. A foodies heaven. So much to see for all ages. No visit to Sydney is complete withou visiting here.
Lovely!. Lovely place, a long time since I visited and looking forward to returning ! Very nice place to have a few drinks!

A market filled with treasure. Lots of good interesting creative stuff selling the the market! There was a cafe that sells scones and they were so yummy!!! Stall keepers were all very friendly! There was one who had a pet lizard letting my girl holding and petting his lizard for a long long time! And there was another stall keeper who gave my boy an Australian penny and a half penny as gift! The rocks is definitely the best place to stroll around in Sydney!

Walk and Shop. Prices are high but the markets caters to tourists- locals have to suffer. Know your prices and don't impulse buy. Foodies heaven, I did harbour trike ride- fantastic. Great place to hang out for the day on Sunday particularly. lots of history- so much to see
Pleasant area. This is a nice area close to everything. The assortment of restaurants, shopping and other attractions make it worth the effort.

Its friendly and a mix of old Sydney with modern today Sydney. I took a friend from New York it was her first visit and mine too. I had never walked the beautiful pebble stone streets. The food was amazing the people very friendly and the shopping quite unique and quality Australian made

The Rocks Markets. Came here recently on a Saturday and just loved it!This is a great place to come to buy beautiful gifts and treats made and sold by passionate creative people.Be sure to check out 'Mo Resin' for gorgeous jewellery, and 'Arthur Ave by Ms Tash' for the most delightful and beautiful baby clothes. I could have bought so many cute little outfits here. Your friends and family will definitely be envious when your baby is wearing these adorable clothes.The cobbled streets with the market stalls are surrounded by cafes and coffee shops. And then it's just moments away to the amazing views of the harbour.Definitely put this on your Sydney list.
Historical. This historical area is quite interesting, and really gives you insight into the beginnings of Sydney and Australia in general. We did this with a walking tour, and found it insightful.

as if you're in old times. I love visiting this area on weekends morning when you can feel as if you're among first settlers in Australia.It's a good spot accessible to all famous must see things in Sydney like Harbour Bridge, Opera House ,Museums, Ferries, and Circular Quays etc...You can enjoy clean well organized areas with nice coffees, breakfast,open markets with food stalls and galleries etc.You'll love it by simply being there.You just can overlook sparkling sea waters enjoying your coffee on weekends mornings.

The perfect start. If you want to eat good food and stroll around old buildings this is the best place to go. It's close to Circular Quay and a perfect starting point if it's your first visit to Sydney.

Sydney's First Township. You must visit The Rocks. It was the first township built by the convicts and early settlers. Fascinating history. If you can take the Walking Tour of The Rocks, do so as its full of so many interesting snippets of information. Cute little shops. Great restaurants by the water, and of course Sailors Thai.
Interesting area. We stayed at The Harbour Rocks hotel which was the old hospital.this hotel is part of what is a very interesting area of Sydney.lots of old buildings and history.
Beautiful area!. Lots of history in this area of Sydney, beautiful buildings and architecture! Fun bars, good restaurants.
strolling around. When you visit the Rocks take the time to stroll around the back streets and lanes. Every time I visit I find something new and interesting.

Love it. When in Sydney, its worth a visit to The Rocks! If in the area on the weekend, be sure to check out the markets. Lots to see and buy. Historical part of city, old ruins found in bottom of youth hostel. Easy to reach The Rocks from Circular Quay.
Fun area. Fun area with some really enjoyable and upbeat Sydney pubs. Great opportunity for a pub crawl. Comes alive each year during the vivid lights festival.

Beautiful old homes. Unfortunately we went early in the week when it was quite but it well worth walking around looking at the old houses. I believe that there are markets from Friday and over the weekend which helps give the place a buzz

Not the real Sydney. It would be sad if people thought they were seeing the "real" Sydney in The Rocks. While conveniently placed and offering lots of food and drink venues, it's extremely tourist-oriented and little frequented by locals. If you have limited time and want to see Sydney as it really is, go to the centre of the city, from Martin Place to the Queen Victoria Building and on to Chinatown.

Historical legacy (?). Ok, so if you are used to visiting really ancient stuff The Rocks will seem shockingly recent. Saying that, it's the bit of Sydney that you should visit to get a sense of the past. I wouldn't recommend trying to eat around that area though -expensive and mostly tasteless dishes-. Good for partying. Oh, and the Friday food market is worth it (as it is also the Saturday market, but it's a bit touristy).

Charming place. Great place for all to visit. Read up on the history on the information boards, chill out with a meal or drink or visit the lovely independent shops, treat yourself or purchase some of the great souvenirs. Definitely worth a visit, a great day out!
quaint place. We only came here after doing The Bridge Climb. We had lunch which was lovely. A good place to sit and people watch. Worth a visit.
Filled with characted and charm. Definitely the place to visit if you love laneway's, market's, the old building's and plenty of character.

A step back into the past. Lovely old buildings, well preserved and lots of character. This spot in busy Sydney takes on back to another time. Now well preserved and with an array of speciality shops and restaurants its a great area to walk around and takes you up close to underneath the harbour bridge.

Worth a visit. The rocks market is like about 5 mins walking from circular quay. This size of the market is decently big. Here they sell design and made in Australia items. You do get to see many interesting design. Overall, the price is still with some a bit on the high side. I feel this place is worth as it is just next to harhour bridge and across opera house where you can go next after the shopping.

It made me rock and roll.. I really liked the quaint looking buildings I'd seen so many times on TV and in films, it's sandwiched between the Harbour bridge and the Opera house I think it's one of the oldest area's built on after the first colonialists and the convicts settled, however there was no one to ask, so it's what I read. I found it very atmospheric, with boats, old 4 rigger sailboats, huge liner's tied up on the quay,near the old warehouses being renovated, and converted into restaurants, shops etc.Its a great area to wander about. Close your eyes, and travel back, to the 1700's when Australia, as we know it was born.

So picturesque! #1 place in Sydney!!. A must see place when being in Sydney!! There's no hussle or bustle, the markets are just fantastic, it's a little trip down some history without the bore! Also great place for quirky photos!! I just love this place!!!!

Spend a day happily here.. Wonderful place to spend the day. Art galleries, a museum, cafe's and fine dining restaurants are all to be found here in a relatively small area. Street artists are also plentiful, especially at weekends. This is one of Australia's oldest neighbourhoods. Historically interesting but spoilt, in my opinion, by choosing this area to moor gigantic cruise boats.

History up close. The Rocks locality in downtown Sydney is certainly worth a few hours of detailed inspection. Besides the touristy shops and restaurants there is now a wealth of information about Sydney's early history. There are some fabulous architectural designs and brilliant stone masonry which was created by convicts arriving in the late 1700s. Hidden steps, paths and alleyways are coupled with wrought-iron handrails. If you appreciate colonial buildings and details then spend a few hours wandering around the area. Of course there is also the Sunday market in The Rocks which is worth a look - lots of copies of old historical photos of the area and Sydney harbour. The area is also good for photographers and modelling if you just want to have fun.
Old World Charm next to 21st Century City. A unique mixture of quiet narrow streets and quaint buildings make the Rocks a must-see place in Sydney. Walk from Circular Quay or Wynyard station.
Sydney trip. Walked to the rock great old building stall in market was good to look at some are a bit pricey beautiful views of harbour plenty of food to eat will go back in November with friend

Totally free. I do know why we need a tour. It seems to me it is just a market. I walked there once last weekend, there were a lot of nice stuff and not very expensive. Everyshop looked nice and cute. The restaurants were beautiful.
Check to the FREE TOUR!. We went on the free tour, 6pm each nightSo informative, great stories, history and even current struggles of the terrace housing. A definite must do for all visitors
The Rocks. This is a very interesting place to take a tour and learn some of the original history of Sydney or to shop or visit the pubs and restaurants that have sprung up in more recent time.

Accommodation during Vivid. As a walking group from Newcastle we decided to explore Sydney by rail on our $2.50 Seniors Ticket during Vivid Festival of LightsOn arrival in Sydney we caught the Ferry to Manly (still on $2.50 ticket).Accommodation was shared (4 to room) at YHA Sydney Rocks. It is a relatively new building purpose built as a YHA and accordingly very functional, and clean.From the roof deck you have an uninterrupted view of Circular Quay and the Opera House. Could not do better during Vivid. We had dinner at the historic hotel next door which did offer reasonably priced Pizza. Meals were all good.From there we walked over the harbour bridge (great views of Sydney lit up) to the Ferry wharf at Milsons Point. We chose the long trip back to Circular Quay via Darling Harbour (all included in our Seniors ticket of $2.50 for the day).Spent thenext morning at Sydney Museum (special exhibition of "Australian Toys"then home

Beaut location to stay in Sydney. Staying at the top end of Cumberland St for 4-5 days has given us plenty of opportunity to "explore" the rocks, restaurants, shops, attractions - the observatory, Darling Harbour, Circular Quay etc all within a short walk. "The Tea Cosy" for afternoon tea & scones - yummy. The likes of "Fish at the rocks", "Sake" - Japanese, and just the cleanliness in general of the area is very inviting. Easy access to the Opera House, ferries n all ++

Full of History and Tourists. The rocks is a great part of Sydney to visit. Lots of shops , galleries and history. It has something for everyone. Weekends are great because they have markets there and are great for a stroll around. Nightime is good because of all the restaurants, and also you feel safe in this area, Take the time to absorb the history of the area.

Very nearly missed this place. . The rocks is full of history. I loved the way the area has been kept in good condition and the building s are really being used in a authentic manor. I did a tour of Susannahs place. It is a group of cottages that are in keeping with the time of the 1800. Some of the other houses are left in other periods of time its is like going back to another place In time, it was very reasonable price Only 8. / very reasonable.

my favorite part of sydney!. It's old style architecture and streets were alluring. There were many great shops and restaurants to choose from. On weekends, there was a great market there as well! Got some nice souvenirs. It is also right underneath the harbour bridge and within walking distance of circular quay and the opera house
Love the Rocks market. Love the Rocks. Lovely old buildings. The market on the weekend is amazing! Lots of restaurants to eat at.
Lovely night. Great food. Lovely atmosphere. The pub attracts tourists and locals. They also have a screen to watch the footy. Service is good. I would go back next time I'm in Sydney.
Weekend Flea Market. Interesting Place to Walk around in the evening, the weekend flea market is fun, lot of cafes to enjoy

Great little wander. Nice to visit and view the old buildings and the market. The market is still the same since my last visit 6 yrs ago. Still fun and a great walk exploring the streets under the bridge

Love the Rocks. A must do area of Sydney and even better if there for the Rocks Markets. So much to see, you are surrounded in the market area by shops, cafes and great goods from the market smallholders - spoilt for choice to dine, the scones, the corn on the cob, the street food and cafes - a real must do - take your time, meander and e not

Not bad, not great.. So The Rocks is kind of a cool place but I admit I haven;t been on the ghost tour yet so don't consider this my final judgement. They have weekend markets that are quite cool (if that if your thing).They also have a few bars and restaurants around.I would say go there if you are at the harbour and it is literally round the corner, but I personally wouldn't make a specific journey to go unless I wanted markets or a slightly overpriced beer or lunch/dinner.
Fashionable shops. Souvenirs, clothes, accessories, branded bags, food you name it they have it there. They may be pricey but you pay for quality.

Interesting ! ,every step around the Rocks.. Have a stroll around the Rocks and take at least a half a day of your holiday to explore. Look through the many shops, art galleries, soak up the over 200 years of history and have lunch at one of the great cafes,pubs or restaurants. We recommend for Italian foodies, check out Pia Zina's for brilliant pasta,pizza and the Calzone "Wow".

Worth the Visit. The rock is just a short walk away from the Sydney Harbor and the ambience and feel is totally different. It has plenty of restaurants who have outdoor sitting - somewhat like in Europe. Its just nice to sit around and have a drink or a cup of coffee. Plenty of Historical Sites to see.

Old sydney. The rocks is my favourite part of Sydney. I love all the little alley ways and history that comes with the place. Not to mention all the old little bars especially lord Nelson. And then there is lowenbrau great atmosphere and food.

Nice place to visit. There are many restaurants, coffee shops, and stores in this historic neighborhood. We preferred to spend most of our time viewing the harbor, but visiting The Rocks was a good experience for our meals.

Great place to walk. Shopping, coffee shops, every kind of food you could ever want. Quaint bars and restaurants. Recommend Captain Cooks for a quick drink and Good conversation from the chatty bartender. Fish at the Rocks is great for seafood. Fresh daily specials make sure to make a reservation as it is very small and popular with the locals.
Nice ambience around this area. Lots happening, nice shops. Market was a let down- much smaller than I thought it would be. Its easy to get to though from the CBD and nice eateries around
Must see. Like I said, its a must see in the city, a lot of stores, pubs and restaurants. Its the old/colonial part of Sydney. You can cross the bridge and its a beautiful ride ande excellents views.

A romantic place to visit. We went there without much expectations I confess. However, there was a lot of things to do and see. Live music, food market, food court, restaurants. Everything surrounded by beautiful buildings. Be prepared to walk.

Well worth the walk. The abundance of quality restaurants in the area is brilliant, plenty to see and do in the area. All visitors to Sydney will definitely love the vibe walking around the rocks on a sunny day.
Good Historic Site. We stayed here at the Holiday Inn and visited this mostly history area with it's own small museum. It's a nice place to visit while in Sydney.

Always pleasant to wander around.. The many restaurants and unique shops that dot The Rocks are well worth the walking tour of the precinct. All visitors to Sydney are encouraged to have a look around here, on foot!
Worth going down to!!!. If you are in Sydney - a walk around the Rocks is a must!! There is lots to see and do :) especially on the weekends!!

Good, not Amazing. it is not bad, would rather to spend the time at Darling Harbour, especially if you kids with you, it is good to pay it a visit but not really to spend time there.take George street up to Darling Harbour for better place.
Spend a Sunday. Great street vendors. I was there about 30 minutes before closing and found bargains galore on jewelry/cloths
Something for everyone. Visited the beer hall, art gallery (good view from the roof), cafes, and a few shops. Worth spending a few hours walking around the area for the atmosphere.

The Rocks Rock. Spend a Sunday at the Rocks, wide variety of great eateries, markets and entertainment.
I love tourist traps and buying over-priced souvenirs. The vendors are always happy to see you and happily accept your cash in exchange for their wares.
Walk around and enjoy the atmosphere, great food and atmosphere.

Bars resturants shopping. Markets are on Friday Saturday Sunday worth to visit.
Make sure you wear walking shoes with cobblestone streets in areas.
Do pop into bars pubs to get a feel for place.
Avoid pubs on Friday night if looking for a romantic quiet time
The Rocks ... rocks for young or old. Great day out .. lots of old pubs, chat to locals then lots of great places to eat out . Sit by the harbour and enjoy a drink .

Amazing. Amazing market on the weekends, and the pubs and bars are so much fun, music, dancing, the Mercantile (Irish pub) friendly and fun as too was the Fortune of War (oldest pub at the Rocks) Met some amazing, friendly people as well.
Great fun :)
Fun exploring. This is a good place to head if you want a break from the touristy thing--a fun collection of little shops and eateries right off Circular Quay.

A very unique part of the city. I loved just being able to wander around The Rocks area. It is a great historical piece of the city that they have preserved over time. There are great restaurants and shops in the area, and it is definitely worth a visit!

Great time out . One of my fav places to go on the weekends the markets there are great and the historic value means the world as an Australian
Very clean heaps to do amazing food arts buildings activities and places

Wonderful, buzzy atmosphere. A visit to the Rocks is a must! Fabulous, multi cultural restaurants. Shops. Great atmosphere, especially when the market stalls are there at the weekend! Amazing location, a few minutes walk from Circular Quays, close to The Bridge.

Just wandering around! . To get a taste of historic Sydney you can't beat just wandering around The Rocks. There's lots to explore, shops to poke around in, and plenty of food. The weekend markets have a large variety of local and imported goods. Be aware that many of the shops are vying for the tourist $ however there are unique items to be found. If you fancy wandering further, a walk across the Bridge is close by, or down to Circular Quay and around the Opera House.

First point for Tourists visiting Sydney. We stayed here for one night so had a day to be tourists and this is the ideal place. Close to interstate buses and trains to airport or other Sydney stations. This is the spot for wonderful views of harbour, opera house or bridge. Boat cruises around harbour leave from here as do ferries. Great coffee shops and restaurants for lunch and many choices for dinner. Both cheap and expensive choices. We were at the Rocks for Vivid so there were crowds at night which was fun. If you are looking for tourist merchandise this is the spot. We visited an excellent gallery with a huge range of affordable artisan created pieces. It is an older part of Sydney which has been kept and put to modern tourist use. We stayed in a boutique hotel in an old building. Was fabulous. At dusk we had a wine in front of the Opera House and looked at climbers on the Harbour Bridge. We walked up to Martin Place to have a coffee at the now famous Lindt Cafe. Was an easy 10 minute walk from the Rocks. There is a wonderful modern art gallery situated at The Rocks. This would be the very first spot I would head to as a tourist visiting Sydney.

Lovely Part Of Sydney. We were seeing the Vivid Light show and walked down George street to the Rocks that evening. Wow! A very active, happening part where Circular Quay is. Lot's of pubs, shops, eateries. A fun night life to be around when visiting Sydney. We had a nice evening walking around and enjoying the atmosphere. Please be sure to walk to the Rocks when in sydney.
must see. Have to visit here every time I visit Sydney. Such a lovely tourist destination - shops, history, views. Great farmers market too.

Less Crowd on a Sat. Is it due to all the late night from Vivid Sydney?. The Rocks used to be a lot more crowded on Weekends, but now seem quiet. Not sure if this is due to vivid Sydney, so many folks stay out late at night and so giving a much needed sleep in, in the mornings.

Cool place. It's great to wander around the streets of The Rocks. It gives you a real feeling of what it may have been like 150+ years ago. Some of the shops are quite interesting as are the stalls. However, like most places, you need to be aware of the places selling cheap touristy trinkets. Definitely recommend getting yourself a coffee and enjoying the atmosphere while walking around.

Great place to wonder around and see old Sydney. Great place to wonder around and see old Sydney and just a stone throw from Circular Quay an the great views of the Harbour Bridge and Sydney Opera House. There is also a little market that sells fashion/souvenirs by day and street food by night.

Upmarket and historic. The rocks has plenty of history if you love walking and discovering interesting places this is ideal the shopping caters more for the cruise ship customers with loads of up market shops

Old World. The Rocks is the bastion of early Australia. You can feel the convicts desperate plight at every turn in the worn sandstone walls and cobblestone streets. The historical society have done a marvelous job to maintain the buildings in almost there original format. You feel as if you are living with pirates and buccaneers as the steep stairs; cloying alleyways and cold stone walls close around you and create a claustrophobic environment of days gone by. The pub and restaurant decor & atmosphere enhances the experience and you come away with unexpected knowledge and memories of a different and exceptionally interesting day.

Lively and charming. We came here on a Saturday, while the market was on. So it was extra lively. Even then, it wasn't too crowded. The Rocks has a lot of little stores, cafes, restaurants and bars. It's nice to just stroll around aimlessly. There are signs everywhere that explains a bit about the history and maps that take you on walking tours of the area. It's a very cute part of the city.
Go for a free tour of the Rocks. Very informative and carried out by locals. This was a fascinating hour or two walking the Rocks area.

Relax. The Rocks has a bustling atmosphere and one can sense the history and the colourful past.Recommend going on a pub tour to sample local beer and visit the oldest pubs in Australia.Each building has its own atmosphere and there are stunning views.
Love the ambiance. I like the ambiance of The Rocks, a bit taste of European.... Just walking around this area, and you will find small stores and cafe.

Historical area of Sydney. We enjoyed walking around the rocks area, Saturdays there is a market. Try Scarletts restaurant which is the Rocks Hotel we found the food and service very good and the bar has a old rustic feel, There are many great cafes and restaurants around the area. The information centre is worth a visit.

Rocks of Ages. The Rocks is an old place in Sydney, not that Europeans or others will see anything Old in a country 200 yrs young but this is our Colonial Heritage, the place where convicts and free settlers began our colony. It has only a few streets but they indicate the style of life here, small dwellings, taverns, little alleyways. Nowadays they are filled with little shops of artisan wares, food, cafes and other small ventures. Old style pubs with modern cafes, book shops art galleries like the MCA and all a stones throw from the Overseas Passenger terminal of cruise ships, the quay for ferries and the central train line. A definite stop especially when the arts markets happen on weekends.

Fabulous history saved by the world's first 'green bans'. The Rocks is a tourist mecca.
