It is situated under the southern end of the iconic Harbour Bridge and was called The Rocks - why? - because it was rocky! Australia has a terrible history of destroying it's built history. In the 1970s all The Rocks area was to be bulldozed and replaced with ugly office towers. The Builders Labourers Federation (BLF), a construction union led by Jack Mundey, came to the rescue to save the area by imposing the world's first 'green bans', prohibiting the destruction. Today the area is known all around the world as a great record of the early Australian settlement in Port Jackson (Sydney). It is a lovely place to walk through, enjoy markets, admire sandstone structures, enjoy Sydney Harbour, and eat delicious food.

Nice feel. We strolled around The Rocks because we stayed at Four Seasons Hotel. The rocks has very unique feeling, we felt like we are strolling in the old city but it doesnt look old. I like the architecture and the feel of this area. Some cafes and shops nearby, very good to spend the afternoon time.
HISTORIC. This is the historic part of Sydney city from the colonial days with great old buildings and an abundance of shops and pubs and restaurants. A must see.

Best beer in Sydney. Please try the Lowenbrau keller.Crn.Playfair and argyle. We stopped for a beer Hugh selection of German beers priced reasonable for what we got we had a great time there My Partner doesn't drink beer but she what i was having paulaner Premium pils and loved it We will go back for a meal next time as they were serving what looked so Delicious meals. 10 out of 10 for us

Around the Rocks. The Rock area is always full of life, plenty to see and do.You can eat there, buy gifts, or just enjoy the atmosphere.I like the food shops, there are so many and varied, the gift shops are so good with a lot of hand made goodies. Every time you go its different. and exciting.Just sitting watching the people is interesting and fun.

A great place to hang out. We visit the rocks quite frequently,close to circular quay a great day out they have market stalls on the weekends with all kinds of arts and crafts home made chocolates etc it's a delight or just stop and have coffee or breakfast,it's a must do

Disappointing. Went to the rocks for vivid and was extremely disappointed. They cancelled the trains from Circular Quay as they couldn't cope with the number of people so we wasted our just purchased train tickets and had to walk back to Town Hall after the visit. Compared to last year this was NOT bigger and better than ever as advertised. No major lighting installations, very few interactive light shows, cheap nasty projections on the Opera House and not worth fighting the crowds who obviously, like us, expected it to be at least as good as last year. It most certainly was not! Don't waste your time.

Guinness On The Rocks. Whether you want to buy some souvenirs at the Irish Shop or want to relax and enjoy a meal, have a coffee, or a pint of draught Guinness in a friendly Pub, then the Mercantile Hotel in the Rocks is the place to go! Quite during the daytime the Mercantile comes alive particularly on Friday, Saturday, and Sunday nights where the place rocks (pun intended) with Irish music!

Gift shopping haven. I visit the markets a couple of times a year to buy birthday gifts for overseas relatives and am never disappointed. Last week's visit was no different and while there are many stalls selling touristy kitsch, I managed to find a couple of gift items that are unusual and locally designed. Gift-buying aside, it's always a pleasant stroll through the area with its old buildings contrasting with the modern towers a stone's throw away.

Charming historical area with some great bars and restaurants.. The Rocks is a bustling little area just near circular quay. It's a great place to have a wonder around on a weekend with plenty of lively bars and restraints to stop and have a bite to eat or a well earned pint. I'm not sure how old the area is exactly but a lot of the buildings look pretty old in comparison to the shined new city centre and have a real classic vibe to them, that you don't get other places in Sydney.

Good selection of places to eat and drink, interesting place to visit. Quite touristy but lots of places to eat and drink, at relatively reasonable prices. Something to suit most tastes and see the sights
Dissapointing. This area of Sydney has changed over the last few years and the attractions are no longer there with restaurants in their place. A disappointing visit.

Lovely old area of Sydney close to Circular Quay. Well worth taking a couple of hours to wander around this old historic area of Sydney. The highlights for me were The Rocks Discovery Museum - small but v interesting and the cafe on the 4th floor of The Museum of Contemporary Art - wonderful views of the opera house, harbour bridge and excellent food - what's not to like!
Great neighbourhood. An unchanged neighbourhood with real character. The markets here were great for a special one of a kind gift.

A must to see in Sydney. Always love the historical context here - so much to appreciate of how Sydney started to where it is today. Hopefully this heritage is respected and maintained without progress and high-rise offices taking over.
Even better this week with VIVID and the light show totally changing the character of everything around the Quay.

Wonderful historic neighbourhood!. Continuing to walk towards the bridge from the Sydney Harbour, we came across the Rocks area. There is history everywhere, and alongside it, the massive cruise ship terminal. Eating places and shops abound around various nooks and crannies. The view of the Opera House from here is also stunning.

Always worth a visit. The Rocks is a great place to visit to get a feel for the historical side of Sydney. Do some research before going and spend time looking around to find the original aspects of this area...look up at the buildings, don't just look at the shop windows. Read the plaques.The markets are great to spend a bit of time looking about and there are some great places to look around and some great restaurants to eat at.

Historic Area. The Rocks is a very historic area for Sydney. Hint: Find information on the "I'm Free Tours" that start at 6 pm in Rocks every day. We did not do this tour but it was a great price and came recommended.

The Rock. Enjoy the walk along the Rock and experiences the beautiful Sydney Bridge with nice waterfront restaurants. Have a coffee and sit and relax environment of the Australian style. Walk further inwards there are historical site and churches to explore

A superb (and free) historic introduction to the city. This area was saved from demolition by some local councillors who then set about sprucing it up whilst keeping its history in place. Plaques have been added around the area to enlighten the tourist and there is much to see. Superb views of the bridge and Opera House can be had, there is a delightful old church to view, some old pubs, many old houses and the streets ooze charm from long-past days. Set a day aside and talk a walk through history - you will not be disappointed.

Love the quaint yet chic feel to this place. If you love strolling small boutiques and cafes, you'll love this place. It has that European feel though the area is not so big. I saw a few cosy boutique hotels there and wish I'd stay there!

The Rocks rock. The shopping in the outdoor kiosks was fun. They appear to only do some of them on the weekends. I don't know if they are open during the week. This is a close walk to the Opera House and the Sydney Harbour Bridge. It is a nice area.

Always something happening here.. This is a beautiful area of Sydney with lots of heritage buildings and so much history. Street markets in the weekends and plenty of pubs and restaurants but make sure you have your credit card handy...not a cheap place to visit.
Great Exploring. This is a wonderful place to explore and check out the history and architecture . There is lots to see and plenty of places to sit and enjoy the views

Spend hours meandering and discovering. The birth of Sydney is the Rocks, a very hilly and unique area filled with history. While there aren't as many cafes and eateries as the last time I visited, it's still an area filled with interesting shops and outdoor cafes and bars. At the "bottom" along the Quay, views of the Opera House are stunning. There are often street performers and musicians, especially on the weekend. In fact, if you can time your visit over the weekend you'll be rewarded with a really fun street market. There are several accommodations right in this area, from luxury high-rises to B&B's. By the way, for overseas travelers, be aware that the service people make VERY good money and tipping is NOT required. I noted on this trip ALL restaurants, etc., had a place to add a tip. If you didn't know any better, you'd feel you have to. You do NOT!
Don't forget your camera!. Perfect place for photographs! Here you can get a great snap of both the Sydney Harbour Bridge and also the Sydney Opera House. Macquaries chair is also here.

The only way to see Sydney!. If you are looking for a centralized location with a bit of a funky twist, stay in The Rocks just off Circular Quay in Sydney. It's close to great restaurants and shops, plus the ferries and buses for venturing further out!
Pretty village feel. Away from the skyscrapers and landmark sights is The Rocks - a small area filled with shops, bars and restaurants all in pretty roads with nice older style brick work.

Historic Area. You can explore the rocks area for a day and not see everything, with pubs dating from the 1820`s to 5 star hotels. There are a wide variety of restaurants, cafes,pubs and entertainment . The markets at weekends are the place to visit with handicrafts, food , fresh fruit and vegetables etc.Just a great place to explore the history of the Rocks area.
HIVE OF ACTIVITY. A hive of activity great place to visit, something for everyone. go on the weekends and enjoy market days.
Great area.. A lot of tourists, but what did expect. Great bars, pubs, and restaurants, as well as a small street market.
Rocks. It is always nice to go to the Rocks to see the old buildings @ the history of the Rocks.We always walk around the foreshore looking at all the sights Pleasant lunch at a small cafe.

Good old Sydney. A lovely way to spend some time taking in the older parts and some new of Sydney. Tea and coffee houses found along the way serving beautiful morning tea or other foods ( sandwiches etc ).

An interesting wander. you have to go for a wander around The Rocks, which is the site of the original settlement in Sydney. Some interesting nooks and crannies! You may also find yourself going back there later in the day for food and drink in the many bars and restaurants in this area.

Great shops and food. Quaint area. Lots of places to eat and shop. Very interesting history and architecture in the area. Walk around through the little alleys and down to Circular Quay in just minutes.

Love the markets. Loved the markets, lots of different and interesting stalls, lots of friendly stall holders, a really great vibe in the markets.
Also great Irish bar smack bang in the middle of the markets..
THE ROCKS. A visit to Sydney must always, always include the Rocks. But the visit must be both day and night. 2 visits. Amazing, friendly, fun, vibrant, exciting and fab food. a delight for all ages.

Touristy but fun. The Rocks, although touristy is still a fun area to walk around and has many shops and restaurants. It is also the entryway to the Sydney Harbour which is a highly recommended walk for outstanding views of the Harbour and Sydney Opera House.

The Rocks isn't what we remembered. We were last in the Rocks in the late 1990s. There were lots of craft and artisans working. Now you need to be there on the weekend market days.
The Renaissance Patiserie Cafe is still there and excellent. Worth going just for the almond croissants!

Street Performance. Well, I get to see some really interesting street performance which I enjoy very much. The view was great as you are able to see the theatre and the bridge. Good spot to take photos too.
The Rocks. Had dinner at a Pizza House across from the Orient Hotel. Perfect. Went to the markets on Sunday and pottered around for a few hours. Lots of interesting stalls and buskers.

Get lost for an hour or a day!. Whether you're into bars, boutiques, restaurants, scenic views, history or markets, you'll find something to make the trip worthwhile. Wear flat shoes and be prepared for steps and hidden surprises. For a carnival atmosphere visit on Sunday when the markets are on.

The Rocks. The Museum is a great place to spend a few hours lost in history and meander the narrow streets. We had a great lunch in the most perfect setting, an historical building on an historical street in an historical district. Can't get better then that.
Definitely worth a visit. Lots of quaint shops and unique restaurants. Be sure to take a tour of the side streets as you will see different views of the Bridge and the Opera House.
great stroll. sunny day and arts/crafts market with eateries in buildings and outsside with interesting small shops- great day of wandering and exploring. Highly recommend.

Fun Area - Go for Lunch!. This is a fun area of Sydney with lots of cafes, bars, restaurants and shops. It is near the Sydney Opera House and you can sit outside and enjoy the view of the harbor. Include this area is between the Sydney Opera House and Bridge.

Enjoyable visit. I really liked my visit to the Rocks. I went on a Sunday and started with an Aboriginal tour which I highly recommend. There are plenty of restaurants to choose from. It was very crowded so plan accordingly. This was market day for the Rocks and it was very enjoyable shopping at all of the many tables and listening to some great street musicians. Learning about he history of the Rocks is advisable to really appreciate it. It was an enjoyable day exploring the Rocks.
Vivid viewing. Spent Saturday night viewing the Light show and was amazed at what was on show. Had a lovely dinner at Wine Odyssey which is a vey interesting concept!
The Rocks Discoery Museum. Great for history buffs and those looking to learn more about the history of The Rocks, from Aboriginal times thought to the First Fleet and modern times

The Rocks Sydney. It is nothing as the name suggests. It is an urban tourist locality of Sydney's City Centre. Initially it was the slums and then it was rebuilt. I liked the place very much. You can reach the Harbour from The Rocks.

The Rocks Markets: so much better than Paddy's!. Sorry Paddington's Markets, but The Rocks Markets are the best in Sydney. They have more of a range of goods and a fantastic vibe. There is also a little French style café off the Nurse's walk that used to be The Rocks Police Station and you can drink a coffee in one of the cells!

My favourite place in Sydney CBD. Without a doubt this is my favourite place in the CBD of Sydney. There is a great feel to it and a never ending choice of great oldey worldy bars and restaurants. A definite must when

Fantastic area in Sydney. Fantastic part of the to City to visit. Lots of interesting, markets, food stalls. Art galleries. Very unique as it is very old but restored to its former beauty, great place to visit.
Every Sunday rocks market.. Rocks area was historic place in Sydney. Rocks market opened every Sunday. You can buy souvenir and food. I enjoyed butter corn. Really yumm...
Unique and trendy. Loved this area, managed to have a walk around the market and the place has a great buzz about it. Worth a visit, no negatives.

Great market. Well worth a visit to the market for traditional souvenirs and special presents, even not on a market day there are a few shops worth looking at. It has a lovely cobbled street area, very nostalgic.

Sydney History.... Went here twice during our stay...needs more time! Once to explore the Museum of Contemporary Art (open late on Thursday nights and well worth it). Went again late Sunday afternoon. and treated to Buskers, Art Galleries, an early history Museum (fascinating) the Market, old Pubs and wandered around the back quiet area and under harbour Bridge, Gun Placements etc...All needed more time as there are little "extras" everywhere for history buffs.

Great old buidings, lots of character. Caught the bus to Miller's Point, and then walked down all through the rocks. Great atmosphere, as currently the Vivid Festival is on, and there is a lot of people in the area, all happy.Lots of families last night. There was a market last night as well.The buildings look amazing at night, all lit up at night.

Historical charm. Just walk around, read the small inscriptions, walk in to one of the charming bars and grab a beer, eat at one of the yummy dessert shops. All in all, a good lesson in history in what is probably one of the oldest neighborhoods in Sydney.
In the heart of Sydney. great pub experience , food and beautiful view in the evening .. Good place to spend some time and relax.
The Rock - Free Walking Tour. Greatly enjoyed the Free Walking Trip at 6pm around The Rock, Individual tourist will not wander into the street corners and the history becomes alive.

Sunday hang out. Great place to hang out, every type of good you want including pancakes on the rocks open 24 hours, takes some beating. Great bars especially lowenbrau beer Keller. Lovely market on weekends too. Only draw back is it's a bit hilly so mobility could be an issue for people who have trouble walking. Overall great place to visit, a must if you're in Sydney

Go to the Vintage Cafe. I kept hearing about the Rocks but I don't know what all the fuss is about. Yes, there are stores there but there are stores everywhere. Nothing special. My favorite thing about the Rocks is the restaurant we found and loved, The Vintage Café.

interesting part of Sydney. We took a city tour bus and passed through The Rock section of the city, which is close to the Opera House, the Harbor and the Harbor bridge.It is an enjoyable area of Sydney, with houses with an old architecture. There are lots of friendly shops and cafes.
Awesome spot to stroll. Historic and a bit touristy, great food the weekend markets are good and have a better range of products than most markets.

Lovely. This place is a historical place in Sydney. Just a little bit up past Circular Quay. There are lots of places to eat here as well as the views to see of the Harbour Bridge and the Opera House! Simply amazing

Good experience of a weekend market, but very overpriced. I thought this was much hyped - you get the same kind of souvenirs and purchases in Paddy's markets at less than half the price. Go for the experience and buy only what you cannot get elsewhere- some of the jewellery is quite nice

Great for Drinks and to chill. The Rocks is one of the great enjoyable places of Sydney. Apart from being full of history, it has an enjoyable old architecture that is very well kept. It is also full of nice cafes and pubs and on Sundays there is a beautiful market where you can find all sort of things, from the tacky souvenirs, to great vintage articles

Not skyscraper Sydney - but damned close!. Great area to go around. nice feel, lovely bars, relaxed outdoor feel. Extraordinary to see such working class housing rubbing shoulders with hardcore international corporations. alas, judging from posters around the area it looks like the corporations are about to win and the area may see some redevelopment.I really hope not. Sydney is not old, and this area is about as close as you get to what it may once have been like. Good luck with the campaign to save it.

The "Rocks" - a slice of Australian History. The "Rocks" is where the first Australian settlers arrived - and it is chock full of history and wonderful 1850s period buildings--and even pubs which have been preserved intact dating to the same time. You can enjoy the pub beer and the many interesting shops (not T-shirt shops, thank God), art galleries and boutiques. But you need to take a tour to truly understand the role this area has played in Australian history - fascinating! You won't look at the hand-hewed building blocks of sandstone on all the buildings the same way! Much to learn and it's all soooo Australian! We took Gary West's Sydney Pub Tour - and it was excellent! Strongly recommended.

The Rocks on Sunday. The area called the Rocks in Sydney is in and around the southern side of the harbor bridge. Its a good place to spend a leisurely Sunday afternoon. Thereare many places to eat and many pubs to grab a drink or two at. There is also the contemporary art museum down by the water and the wharf theater on pier 2 if youare after entertainment. Get yourself a map from a tourist information booth and head down there on a Sunday afternoon. Wintertime 12-5, Summertime 1-7. Youwill be bound to find somewhere you like, even if its just walking along the shoreline.

Great steps for all. I chose the Rocks as a place to visit on Mothers Day with the family - I'd forgotten what fun it can be - a meander around to arts and craft markets, coffee and chocolate in a convict cafe, cruise liners tied up at the Circular Quay terminal. There's a lovely curuit you can do around the Rocks which had people of all ages reading historical signage. We also strolled over to the Opera House for a gelato - everyone was happy father, teenage son and MUM!!!
Hidden gems . Too many hidden gems at the Rocks ! Plenty to explore and precisely great place to spend a great day there especially weekends ! A must to go not only for tourists but locals as well .
Loved the rocks. Great place to go on your visit to Sydney lots of interest shops, great places to eat and all with an historic feel

The atmosphere and buzz of the crowd on a Sunday. I loved the atmosphere of the Sunday markets! It was busy but not chaotic. There was a fantastic busker called Mark Wilkinson, whose cd I bought, the stalls were fantastic! I always buy something when I go to the markets! Finished off at the Guylian Belgian chocolate café twice! Once for baguettes for lunch and again for afternoon tea with pastries! A wonderfully relaxing stay!

A must see in Sydney. I live in Sydney and I just love visiting The Rocks for a day or night out. The true heart of Sydney with a rich history you can experience in any of the small alley ways, unique stores and fabulous pubs. Stroll through the markets on the weekend, enjoy a fabulous view on Observatory Hill or watch the Harbour come alive from Hickson Rd Reserve. And after all that, should you fancy something a little up market, try my favourite restaurants Ananas, Cut or Sake.
The rocks. I love the rocks in Sydney, there are so many cafes and entertainment going and the market, and the cruise ships

beautiful way to see Sydney Harbour. Either catch at Circular Quay, and head to Manly, for a lovely day, of shopping and great places to eat. Or go from Manly and spend a day in the City.A 30 minute ride, and you get to see our wonderful harbour, Opera House, Fort Dennison, and more.

Relaxing and interesting. I thoroughly enjoy walking around this area. There is much history to discover and a wonderful variety of shops and cafes. Worth trying some of the cakes and slices while you are there.

So much history. Living in Sydney you tend to take our surroundings for granted, but you need to get out and about and explore. The Rocks is amazing and full of history and old buildings, little alleyways lead you around the area with little gems around every corner.The markets on the weekend are great as well and so many restaurants and cafes to visit. And of course, the pubs! Pubs are certainly not in short supply around the rocks, perfect place for a pub crawl!
Saturday Markets. The markets are well worth a visit, full of different vendors, best get in early for lunch and coffee very colourful and cheerful place on the weekends

The Rocks rocks. The ultimate Sydney pub crawl. Start at Circular Quay and take in the history of early Sydney. Keep going past the Harbour Bridge pylons while getting a view of the harbour and take in the Bridgeview and Lord Nelson hotels.

Lunch at the Rocks. The Rocks feature restaurants for affordable and expensive taste, yet services were desirable. We found the price high. Lunch for two costs 60+ Aud$. Nonetheless, we enjoyed the relaxed and safe atmosphere.

Lively heart of the foreshore. The Rocks area is teeming with history and hidden gems. Cafes, shopping, and the Rocks Markets each weekend. Take time to really look at each building, maybe do the walking tour. Explore back lanes where the modern Australia all began.

Great walk around at Sydney history. Lovely to walk around and enjoy the sights of old buildings and the history of Sydney. Had a beer in a few of the old pubs. Visited mid week so a little quite and not much happening. But everything open Pubs, Food outlets and Shops. Markets open on weekends and more food stalls so can be very busy.

The Rocks, Sydney - Great Place to visit. The Rocks is a beautiful part of Sydney with historical buildings and stories at every turn. The Rocks markets on a Friday afternoon and Saturday morning are wonderful.

Historical walks. Little lanes, cobbled pathways, old buildings. If you want to take in the history of this place do make time for a visit. Museums, great restaurants, quirky little lanes. Put on your walking shoes and explore. Visit the Discovery Museum (free) for an overall view of The Rocks. Easy walk from Circular Quay if you go by train or bus.
Nice area. Nice little area to walk around for an hour or two. Plenty of bars and café's to stop in for a bite to eat or drink.

Chilled and relaxed atmosphere. Great way to spend an afternoon wandering through the streets. It's not a big area, just a few streets with nice shops and cafe/bars so you could plan in a couple of hours for it

Unusual Rocks. We visited the Rocks after climbing the Harbor Bridge. The place is full of vendors, artists, shops selling their wares which were on display. Full of tourists, nice dining places. Definitely worth a visit!
The Rocks. Visited this area for a second time though we were not staying in the same hotel. Really geared for tourists and would recommend it for any holiday maker

Go explore!. We opted to take the free walking tour that starts from Cadman's Cottage every evening so we saw the Rocks in the dark! Quite hilly so be prepared. This area has a great history so you might want to go with a guide and perhaps wander on your own during the day.

The Rocks ROCKS! Lots to see and fun shopping. A great view of Sydney from Circular Quay, great shopping, lotsof photo opps, great restaurants and lots to see and do. The Rocks rocks! Plan a whole day... shop the outdoor market, buy the world's hottest chili sauce (not verified), take the ferry to Manly and visit the beach and have some fish and chips, get great photos from the ferry of the Sydney Opera house and Sydney Harbor Bridge at sunset, visit the opera house and dessert and coffee at Max Brenner's. Nightcap along the harbor... you may want to return for more.

A Good Weekend wonder. If you are in Sydney over a weekend, head to the Rocks for a wonder around. You can visit anytime, but on weekends in Summer the streets are alive with stalls selling arty crafty stuff (no Chinese plastic here). The restaurants/bars are spilling out into the street and there is a throng that the places looses when the crowds go home. While you are there don't forget to look up and look around the restored buildings and stop and read the plaques and learn a bit about the history of the area and its occupants.

A fun place to party!. Although it's extremely touristy, the Rocks is a fun place to party and shop. There are a number of bars and restaurants in this area and at times it can get a bit rowdy. There's also an excellent Museum of Contemporary Art in the area and several historic sites.

lovely place to walk around. its a nice place to have the insight into sydney. the walk is lovely and you can see many nice cafes , buildings ...you cans have scenic views of sydney .....must visit place

The Place To Be. Thank God they didn't tear down the Rocks. This is the place to be. It's historic and a bit gentrified but where the excitement is. We visited in Australia's fall so the city was pretty quiet. Even so, we could find a musician (usually a solo guitarist) performing at any of the multitude of pubs. And there are plenty of restaurants to choose from. And on the weekends, there's a craft mart for buying those handmade Aussie items and souvenirs.

Lots of history great tour and good food. The Rocks was within walking distance of our hotel and had many great restaurants and bakeries. We did a walking tour of The Rocks and the history is fascinating. There's a lot of history behind the restaurant facades. Many many good restaurants that were unique.

Great atmosphere . The rocks boasts Sydney's oldest pub.... Two other pubs also have a similar claim:)Weekend markets are worth a visitFree guided tours are really worthwhile.... Take 2 and check for story consistency.... That makes sure you are paying attention.Just under the harbour bridge on George St is probably the most ornate men's urinal. There's a choice of eateries... From sandwiches to pub grub to finer dining

Wonderful. Fantastic place to walk around, history, galleries, restaurants, pubs and coffee shops.Gives you a great insight as to how the city started and developed as well as a very nice way to see the bridge and Opera House from so many different angles

Something for everyone. From the old-fashioned pubs to the trendy cafes, there are so many menu choices. If you're there on at market-time, look for some great buys, sample some yummy chocolate or watch the artists create. If you're there at night, you can join the ghost tour. You could spend hours exploring the many historical buildings and alleyways. Visit the museum or art gallery. Or you can just sit in the sun and watch the world go by.
If in Sydney it's a must. Especially on the weekends, this is a fun and casual place to hang around bars or dine, meet people and experience the aussie spirit. Lots of tourists and local.

Great view and view!. Gorgeous roof top bar.
Great beers and try the salt and pepper calamari.
Great staff and not too fancy.

Old Sydney.. Wonderful for tourists. This area is old world but with a huge number of restaurants, bars and hotels on offer. Be careful with your choice of restaurant as som could be considered to be charging more than you would consider reasonable. However it is a great attraction and should not be missed.

worth a visit. Lots of interesting, individual shops and places to eat offering plenty of variety.
The area retains many of its older buildings, which now offer a good range of shops, restuarants, pubs and hotels. It feels safe to walk around even late at night and it is easy to reach from circular quay.

interesting to walk around. This is an interesting place to walk around. We were there on a Sunday, hence the market place was packed with a lot of things to see, and shop. A lot of things were handmade, making it more interesting . We bought some home made nougat and freshly caramelized nuts which were very good. There are lots of restaurants around the place which served good food/coffee/pastries. A great place to spent for the weekends :)
Get Lost in the History of Sydney. Spend a coup,e of hours walking the narrow, hilly streets around the rocks to discover the first town in Sydney. Excellent food and bars as well as great sites
Great for a walk around. Original area of Sydney which has had lots of regeneration in the form of tiny shops and restaurants. Great place to walk around and just soak in the atmosphere.

The "Trendiest" Part of Sydney. The "Rocks" is an area located essentially under and around the downtown Sydney side of the Harbour Bridge. It is filled with one of a kind shops, restaurants, and great markets on most weekends.The "Foodie Market" on Friday's is especially fun with a wide variety of local merchants setting up tents and cookstoves right in the middle of closed streets. Find the fresh roasted "Corn on the Cob" for a special treat.On Saturday and Sunday, the "Arts and Crafts" market features dozens of vendors selling everything from homemade nougat to decorator aprons and toys. There is quite a variety here and something for everyone and every budget.The restaurants in this area run the full gamut from street stands to fine-dining with prices ranging from pocket change to pricey. See my review of "Pancakes on the Rocks" for a reasonable place to eat for extremely reasonable prices.

Sunday afternoon/evening beers and music. The rocks was thoroughly enjoyable. The whole place was buzzing, friendly with the markets and great live music in so many pubs. Lots of fantastic restaurants, bars and plenty to see. We induldged in a sunday afternoon pub crawl, it was awesome

Great shopping area. something for everyone, from the expensive international brands to some very interesting local shops, in all a good way to spend an hour. The Museum of Contemporary Art is across the street and should not be missed.

Back in time. visit the rocks and get away from the hustle and bustle of circular quays. Plenty of coffee shops , restaurants and bars. Explore the alley ways and be surprised at what you find! If you visit the rocks in the evening beware that there is a dress code for many of the bars where flip flops are barred. Suggested itineraries; ferry from darling harbour to circular quays, walk through rock and explore alley ways. Walk to harbour bridge via the stairs under the road bridge at the top of the rocks. Walk across the bridge + exhibition ( or bridge walk) eat at the Australian and take the ferry back to Darling Harbour after people watching at the opera house. A great date enretainment!

sunday attraction. the rocks market have been around forever theres a whole range of stuff to see and buy,close to the harbour there are many places to eat or drink some places are a bit overpriced but theres a pile of menu boards to check out before you commit well worth a sunday stroll for locals and visitors

Authentic Fun. The markets were a great place to get trinkets and snacks, the streets and buildings are old and very authentic, loved this area. There's also a German Beer Garden with great beer and good eats.

Nice to walk around, but overpriced to eat!. The rocks is a great area to walk around and close to the Harbour. Since it is touristy the restaurants are overpriced. Walk a couple blocks off the beaten path and you'll find some more affordable spots to eat and drink!
awesome spot!. a great spot in Sydney to check out the sites, hit up a restaurant, or visit one of the awesome bars the Rocks has to offer!

Awesome Markets. Really enjoyed the markets at The Rocks, they are boutique style, with a good mix of food, clothing, art and gifts, mainly made by the owners at the stalls, not mass produced. Buskers helped the atmosphere at well, and was bustling!

Vibrant Market. We visited The Rocks on market day and we felt that the market rocks if you will excuse the pun. The market is full of very eclectic stalls selling all types of local arts & crafts, hand made jewellery, fragrent mobile made out of various woods as well as some great street artists, a bit Covent Gardenish but with sunshine. There are also some great food on offer at various outlets. All in all a great couple of hours to while away. we will certainly
It's great wandering around this historic area. Plenty of history....wander under the Harbour Bridge & head up hill. Interesting eclectic shops& spaces. Great restaurants & pubs.

Recommend this area for overseas tourists to stay. Such a great experience to walk out of a hotel and have the Harbour and ambience of the Rocks at the doorstep. This is the place to stay for a different experience of a city.So many great places to walk and eat and so close tot he ferries and a pleasant walk to the Opera House.

Great market in weekends. The local market in weekends really makes it interesting. Those little shops selling amazing things. We met a lady who designed her own clothing products, which is sewed by her sister and tried by herself again for improvement, and then put into manufacture. If you were to go, go on weekends and DON'T miss the market!

Exciting. the Rocks at Sydney well worth the visit. Always something going on. I was on Queen Victoria at the same time as Queen Mary 2 in March this year. The fireworks were brilliant. Watching the Queen Mary 2 sail out of Sydney Harbour before we set sail is a sight to remember all my life. What a truly magnificent backdrop.

Scenic and Interesting.. Loved exploring the rocks on a recent girls weekend in Sydney. So many lane ways and corners to explore. Throughly enjoyed just wandering around The Rocks. Lots of wonderful cafes and eating areas.
Great weekend market. Good food good pubs and a great market, must visit when in Sydney, Lord Nelson and the Australian Heritage bar are the best.

The Rocks area. We visited on an Autumn Saturday afternoon and wandered around a few of the shops. We listened to a couple of really good buskers and enjoyed some of the quirkier stalls at the markets. The stall owners were, for the most part, engaging and interested to talk about their wares. We had our tarot cards read which was fun and stopped at the Orient hotel for a couple of drinks. It is a really pleasant way to spend a few hours no matter what the weather.

So interesting. It is the oldest area of sydney, where the ships used to be moored back in 18th century. Here is where people used to be quarantined or treated in hospitals right after desembarking vessels. This is where british sailors used to hang around after months at sea. It is so rich of history and you can find lots of plaques explaining the use of buildings or what used to be there 2 centuries ago. It is now a cosy area full of cafes and restaurants, only 5 minutes away from the Harbour bridge and Circular Quay. I thoroughly enjoyed it.
Historical Sydney. Good to visit away from the city and it has lovely buildings and bars and restaurants and a food market on Fridays.
Nice area to walk around. Great historic neighborhood, worth spending an hour or two exploring. One of the free walking tours gives a tour of this area that's worth checking out.

Fascinatiing. A very special part of Sydney. Lots of interesting buildings to see. Immerse yourself in the history of the area and finish with a drink at the rooftop bar of the Glenmore hotel with views over the harbour.
ANZAC DAY. Had a fantastic day in the rocks. So much to see and do and fabulous food. Had breakfast at a little cafe which was awesome and very reasonably priced

Very pleasant walk. We really enjoyed our walk through the Rocks - there is a very good one proposed by Lonely Planet if you have the guide. Don't miss the place where you can see the open air excavations of the old houses (I think it was at YCAA or something like that). The Museum is very good and can be done very quickly.

Great location to stay, and to explore.. Interesting history, great cafes, pubs and restaurants make The Rocks a great place to stay in Sydney. Take a walking tour, either organized or on your own. Excellent free walking tours are offered (in the hope you'll sign on for another paid tour).
Relaxing fun time. Had an awesome meal and caught up with friends. Very relaxing fun atmosphere with lots to do. Will definitely be a go to destination for my next visit.
Sydney & The Rocks. We loved the restaurants as well as the local artisans in the Rocks area. There is a lot to see and enjoy in this area - a must see while in Australia!!
Rock markets always interesting. Been there many times. Always have interesting things to see or buy. Love the views and interesting to watch the cruise ship passengers.
Historic Buildings. Old stone buildings, cobbled streets, fancy galleries and shops, statue of Captain Bligh, harbour views

Architectural gems. If history, especially architectural, is of the slightest interest, then the Rocks will be literally right up your street. Their origins as early settler's cottages built in the English terraced style, date back to when Sydney was first settled.The local sandstone gives the Rocks its name, and no better way of seeing this is at the Argyle Cut,carved by convicts. The remaining cottages have a charm of their own nestling, and almost dominated by the modern towers.Hundreds of these old houses have already been demolished, and should these remaining streets with their trendy bars, restaurants and markets, go the same way, Sydney's character will be much the poorer.Shady laneways lead the eye to harbour views with the ever-present dominance of the Harbour Bridge and contrast of the Opera House as well as Sydney's ferries busily coming and going; the Rocks are an absolute must visit and should be placed on top of every visitor's list.
Many cool shops and restaurants. This is clearly the place to go for variety and shopping. You'll find everything you need here and it's a short walk from ferries and the downtown area.
Rocks review. We take the time to visit this location whenever in Sydney. Great location with many points of interest and fantastic markets and speciality stores, pubs and eating choices.
beautiful. I love how the old buildings have got so much character about them.. and how different it is compared to the city as its just a walk away

Ahoy me hardies. Walking in the footsteps of sailors and old English sea dogs is what this place is about. Relive the lifestyle of the rich and infamous at The Rocks, lost in the 18th century.Olde world pubs, outdoor cafes, markets and restaurants is what this place is about. Look beyond the tourist traps and you'll discover another side to this unique little seaside port from ye olde days in Sydney Town.

Friendly market stall owners. Lovely fun part of town. So much to share with the shops , markets and bars in the Rocks. We visited three times in four days and should probably stay there next time. This area if town gas lovely casual and high end restaurants. We ate and wine tasted , shopped in the Sunday markets and partied at the Orient hotel pre Anzac night to a great two piece band. Can't wait to book another trip south.
A must to see. I love the style of the resteraunts, very varied. And a good place to have either lunch or dinner. You can sit for a couple of hours, relaxing and maybe some people watching.!!!

Sydney's most stylish area. We went to the Rocks on a Sunday morning in May 2014. The sun was shining, the sky was clear and it was simply a beautiful day. The Rocks was full of people (mostly tourists from Overseas) but we didn't feel it was crowded. At the many street markets people offered handmade art works, nicely made and at a reasonable price. There are plenty of shops in the area so shopping was alos very much an enjoyable option when visiting the Rocks. We had lunch at the German Restaurant Lowenbrau, another attraction of the Rocks. WE had a really god day!
our oz trip. Very nice restaurants area and a must visit part of Sydney , especially in aussie styled English pub

A fun place to spend an evening. We simply loved walking the area.It is a great place to walk around drop in at one of the pubs to have a drink.Do some souvenir shopping and end up eating a great meal.We had the best dinner of our trip in one of the German restaurants.Tables and benches placed outside the restaurant reminded me of my visits to West Germany.The food was great and the walk back to the hotel was exhilarating.A must visit place for all visitors and an area to have atleast one meal there.
Always a good visit. The market is varied and has some lovely products. People are friendly overall, plenty to see, eat and drink - a pleasant way to spend an hour or two.

Convict-era buildings. Worth seeing for the insight into colonial-era buildings and streets. Markets as tacky as they are everywhere, and lots of tourists (like us!) of course, but that is to be expected and doesn’t unnecessarily detract from the experience.

Old Sydney. Stayed in The Rocks section of Sydney. Many old architectural buildings with a backdrop of the modern skyscrapers in the background. Many beautiful sites to see. Great places to dine. Great places to walk and explore day or night. A great central hub to all locations in Sydney. There is a walkway from the rocks that leads you to the pedestrian walkway on the Sydney bridge. A great walk through a bit of history. Great pubs along the way too.
Old Sydney. It's how Sydney was decades ago. It's a nice place, peaceful but with plenty of restaurants for all tastes. It's like a jump into another world for little time. Must see!

Spoilt by Retail. This historic part of Sydney has lovely old houses and streets, right under the Harbour Bridge. The best thing is three pubs with bands, reasonable drinks and food, and great atmosphere. Sadly I found the streets chocked with market stalls and shops - retail has taken away the authentic charm that was there in past years. Still worth a visit, but pretty crowded on a weekend.

Quirky. Just a stone's throw from the main shopping area and the cruise terminal The Rocks is well worth a visit to read about the history of the area and to visit the many different and off-beat bars, cafes and shops contained in the small space it covers.

Beautiful eateries . This area of Sydney has so many beautiful restaurants to choose from, each offering different things, but you do get a lot places offering pizza. There are many pubs here, which on the downside becomes quite unsafe for young kids and teenagers to be exposed to pub and brawl fights, that spill onto the streets, which only ever occur on late nights.
Character. The old part of town - it had lots of character, and a good mix of new and old(ish) buildings. Walking through this area was always a pleasure at any time of the day.
THE OLD CITY. Very nice area, full of shops, restaurants and cafè, just next to Sydney harbour and Opera House. It the ancient part of Sydney, worth a visit.

Guided Walk Tour gives a great insight. Although we've been to Sydney a number of times before, we still found the guided tour provided new insights into this historic area. Perhaps we were lucky being a group of 4 but the guide was able to provide lots of information and answered all the questions that we asked. Highly recommended.

Stay Here !. I think this is the best area to stay in and explore. It can be summed up best in two words...Pub Crawl !Tons of great eating and drinking spots close to the best hotels the area offers. With great views of the Opera house and the harbor one could explore the area for days and never get bored.

The Rocks, Sydney. There is an abundance of things to see and do, food and artisan markets, historic buildings & laneways, street entertainers, stones throw from Harbour & Circular Quay - TAKE CAMERA!
Beautiful buildings. We did the walk. Not as good as i thought. But had fun. There some charming areas some very nice eaterys. The little derelict house nearby are cute but haunting

Quick view of markets. We were in the Rocks on Easter Sunday getting ready for a cruise next day and walked down to the markets. What a buzzing colourful lot of stalls and foods for sale. The atmosphere was alive and busy with holiday makers all around. It is situated in a prime place so near to Circular Quay and the rail terminal and would be very much appreciated by lots of tourists.
Every day walk and breakfast. Because we stayed at Pier One we came here daily to get to the harbor, train, ferry, Opera House and for breakfast.
Slightly overrated. Dint find it very exciting, can visit if you have seen everything else in Sydney. You must be sure of the directions or take a walking tour.
charming. definitely the most charming and one of the most beautiful areas of Sydney. offers beautiful views of the Opera House

Lovely spot. Went there on Sunday afternoon , some really nice crafts for sale, good musicians busking. The Mercantile Hotel was good for lunch and lovely friendly efficient staff. Band playing there were good too

Balmy stroll. The Rocks area in Sydney is perfect for a balmy stroll around before or after dinner. With lots of dining choices it's an ideal location to eat and then explore. With Sydney's beautiful evening temps, the Rocks is my favourite after dinner area. Always lots of activity and perfect for people watching. Check out the cruise liners nearby.

Sights, food and interests. The rocks markets is a hidden treasure, up through the Hickson steps, turn right and after 100 meters its on your right. It was simply exciting with great food venues, lots of art and craft and an exceptionally talented spray paint artist that had the crowd wowing. There was also a cruise ship docked so on that day there were many americans spending up large. The market had street show, music and Sydney put on its best weather. Houses were converted into shops where you can dine in the backyard gardens or upstairs looking down at the busy markets. My next visit will be to the german restaurant and then the french shop. Its really something that all sydney visitors must do.

The closest thing we have to history. We are a country with a relatively young history compared to the old world of europe. Yes i know that there is 40,000 years of aboriginal history but in terms of european settlement we are a young country. The Rocks is where the first fleet settlers clung to the shores of sydney harbour and started our modern era as a country.Sydney on line has an excellent online mobile friendly self guided walking tour. It starts at sailors home in the rocks at the end of george street and is a good walk past 31 points of interest down through the rocks. It is an easy walk and will save you money as there are commercial tours available. I find free is best when available as it keeps my budget under control.Whether you are an aussie or an international tourist, back packer or retiree this is a disability friendly easy walk. My recommendation is to give Tbe Rocks a big thumbs up. You won't be disappointed particularly if you visit on a weekend when the lower end of george street is transformed into a vibrant street market as well. Enjoy !!!
The Best. I love this part of the city especially when the markets are on.. I love the history in this area as well . It's a great place to have a lazy breakfast or lunch on a weekend...

Great Location to Stay and Hang Out. We stayed in The Rocks. Several good food and drink spots but not vegetarian/vegan friendly (almost none). Great shopping. Be prepared to do a lot of walking but its worth it. A lot to do and see within a short landscape. Definitely worth visiting.
Very interesting. There is lots of history in this area. There are also little shops and lots of good eating places. I highly recommend a walk through this area.
Great Shopping. Went there a couple of times. Lots of Australian made trinkets for presents. My wife bought a few of the locally made cloths and was very happy with the quality.

A lovely chilled and traditional part of the city. I loved it here. It was so close to the centre of the city but has not been commercialised. The cobbled streets and quirky buildings was what I imagined a film set to be like. Would recommend having a wander around if you are close to the Quays area.

It is a lovely but very touristy place. good stores, good food, but touristy- for some that is ok.
towards the highest point, there are a few pubs and restaurants, where you see the locals. That is nice
Brief relax in Sydney and a Show. We thoroughly enjoyed the 3 days in Sydney, great accommodation, clothes shopping for my best friend and partner and the Rocky Horror Show.

A must place to visit whilst in Sydney. Lots to do & see here, in this vicinity, from large ships in dock, to nearby Botanical Gardens, a street market on Sat & Sunday, cafe's bars & restaurants, narrow streets & alleyways, full of history from the early settler days!

Had a few hours to kill to we strolled around the Rocks. We had a few hours to kill as we were leaving at approx 6pm so in the afternoon we walked to the Rocks and had a good look around. We happened across a Sydney Harbor Authority museum which was really interesting, especially the old films showing the bridge being built and the Rocks being protected.The markets were good too with a different selection of things to look at. The little terrace houses were great stops especially the one that makes fresh scones

Historic Area with Great Shops & Restaurants. Fun area to stroll around while taking in some history & then stopping in at a pub before you shop in the market. Great spot to roam around without a plan.

A Must-See!. We did a walking tour which included The Rocks. I loved it! There were outdoor stalls with Australian made items; everything from clothing to hot sauce. There were just the right amount of people around to keep it lively without being overcrowded. We bought many beautiful gifts and souvenirs. Some items are overpriced but that can be an issue anywhere. Overall, we had a very pleasant experience.

The Rocks Sydney!!!. What a historical area! Really well laid out spot. Really business centred....And busy. One if the oldest areas in Sydney it has lots of character. If you like beer! There is the greatest pubs in this area.
Good market. Visited the Saturday market. Lots of local crafts available. Didn't buy anything but there was definitely a large selection of items and food types to choose from.

So much to see and do. The Rocks are rich with history and plenty of things to see and do. Great restaurants and pubs are hidden down sandstone laneways. Go and explore this wonderful part of the city. Fun for the kids as well

Pretty area. Lots of nice restaurants and shops in this area. The food market was amazing and loved the craft stalls. Like what they have done with th historical buildings. Nice walk along the harbour there and nice green space along it. Went back a second time to enjoy the area. Took a harbour cruise out from it.

Historic quarter with interesting shops and bars. Had a walk around the Rocks when weather was a little damp, and enjoyed it. Grabbed a drink and a bite to eat from one of the many pubs then visited the foody market pleanty of choices of street food the Turkish stall was very busy and looked good. We bought a lovely selection of mini cup cakes.... Delicious! Then went to a few shops. Then went to the harbour front to view a liner that had arrived overnight.
easter break. It was raining but what a great walk around the rocks and than stopping at one of the pubs for drinks and people watching very relaxing experience recommend the experience

Great for a drinks break. The Rocks has many interesting pubs, cafes and eateries to choose from. It is a great spot to stop before or after visiting the bridge. The shopping here I found pricey, but it has great atmosphere and well worth a visit.

Nice. The rock is popular with locals and tourist. Located in a high area which you can over look the beautiful view of the Sydney opera house. Lots of cafe and restaurants you can hang out and shops selling souvenirs and arts stuff. One of my favorite stop over when in Sydney.

Stroll around the Rocks. This place is a great place to wander round with no particular destination in mind. You can end up in some awesome drinking establishments, The Hero of Waterloo, or the Lord Nelson are highly recommended, The Glenmore or the Mercantile hell u can spend the weekend if you really try....
The Rocks. Went there on a Saturday morning and they had loads of different stalls selling lots of different products. Could not resist and bought a few trinkets

love it!. The Rocks is the perfect place to be. Great bars, pubs, restaurant and perfect to explore the old town of Sydney in the small streets that let you discover original buildings. Visit the explorer museum!
GREAT area. If you can't find something to do in this area there must be something wrong with you?? We were warned that it was an expensive area but we didn't find it so. Can't wait to return!!!

Worth a visit. Went to the Rocks on a Sunday this visit so the markets were there. Not brilliant but good to have a look at on a leisurely walk around. Some interesting old original buildings around this area so quite historic (so far as such a new country can be!) and if you walk through to the end you come to the Harbour Bridge and you'll have a different perspective of the bridge from this angle. Wanted to have pancakes at the Pancake Parlour as they are always excellent, but the size of the queue put us off. Probably a better option on a weekday, not weekend.
Sunday at The Rocks. Fabulous markets. Go to the Tea Cosy for tea and scones. It's a fabulous area to walk around for hours, any day of the week.
An awesome lively place. Get the pulse of Sydney. Have a drink at the Quay Bar. Walk around and enjoy the views. Must see the markets.

Special part of Australian colonial history. Always alive and interesting. It is an important testament to our early colonial days - the chipping marks in the rocks remind us of the hard work and suffering of the convicts and labourers who built these first colonial settlements

Different Sydney. We didn't study the icons of the Rocks well, so I think we've missed a lot, we just wandered a little bit around this place. I liked different style of buildings and the calm atmosphere. It almost felt like we were outside big city of Sidney.
Interesting shopping.. The Rocks is an interesting shopping area, with good shops and nice cafes (try the Bakers Oven for a great breakfast). Good starting point for hop on/off bus tour of Sydney.

Lots to see and do!!. We were in Sydney for the Easter break - while staying in the beautiful city of Sydney we went walking through the Rocks area on Sunday evening. We had dinner at the charming Rocks Café on George Street - very tasty food, lovely wine and great service - we really enjoyed our evening.

Great piece of History at the Rocks. Very interesting to stroll around the area and look at the buildiings and shops right at the base of the Harbour Bridge. Nice pubs and restaurants with a lot of Australian History all around.

Historical and Interesting. I enjoyed the Rocks area. It's home to lot of historical pubs that a worth exploring and the backstreets of the area are quite interesting. On the weekend the area hosts the markets which is worth checking out.
Interesting. A lot of old buildings that have been renewed with shops and places to eat. We were there when the market was open and found it interesting.

Very buzzy area to visit. Thsi are is very nice to wander around- just by the entrance to the Bridge and has lots of funky bars and restaurants and some nice high end shops. Good for a walk around the rest of the harbour and to eat out.

Rainy tour. This tour (free walking tour) was in the evening. At times it poured on us and it was cold. The tour was interesting but had a lot of walking up hills and steps at a fast pace. Many people on the tour dropped out due to rain and pace..

Lots to look at here!. Many cafes , pubs and restaurants to have a coffee or cold drink to give you enough energy to see all on offer here at the weekend markets. Far more varied than the Paddington Markets with huge variety of clothes, accessories , Australian souvenirs, candles, soaps and jewellery.You can take a fun ride on a Harley Davidson, view under the Harbour Bridge or gawp in amazement at a cruise liner moored so close you just wanted to board her.Fresh corn on the cob spiked and smothered in butter were selling fast.Something for everyone and an entertaining attraction.
Sunday market. Had breakfast at Swagmans on the rocks - really good blue cheese omelette. The markets were interesting and fun to explore but the prices are geared towards tourists

Always a fun place to visit. Lots of cool cafes and restos in the Rocks. My top picks are Sake and make sure to pay the Charles Billich gallery a visit. He is one of the most amazing artists you will find in Sydney.

Bustling/quaint. A bustling historic area of Sydney. Lots of quaint ally/pathways nestled in the character filled old historic buildings. There seemed to be an abundance of cafes, bars, and restaurants. We enjoyed wandering these streets, and looking at the buildings. Information Centre staff very helpful.

Historic and trendy. If you want to get a taste of Sydney during it formative years, visit The Rocks and its free museums. If you want trendy eateries and shopping, this is also a great place to see. It's an easy walk from Circular Quay and Sydney Harbor, so it's a can't miss attraction.

Nice to stroll around older part of Sydney. Nice to wander around this area. Cafes and restaurants a bit pricey, but look for the specials out front. Pub grub a good idea and tend to be of a good quality.

Thanks Jack and your mates - great save!. I love living in Sydney. I love the city vibe. So whenever I can, I take myself - on public transport - into the city. Last Saturday, was lovely sunny day, so off we went - me and Happy Hubby - to the Rocks.I am a child of the 70's and remember the Green Bans that the NSW Builders Labourers Federation placed on the demolition of this magnificent area. They were pilloried at the time, but wow, don't we love them now.Walking out of the train station at Circular Quay, always makes me feel happy. I glory in the view - the Bridge, The Opera House, The Ferries - this is Sydney and I'm never ever ever sick of it.Walk around towards the Rocks, listen to the buskers - I always give to buskers - I have my special buskers purse at the ready.Through the park and Cadman's Cottage.Up to the Rocks. The markets are always interesting - my special interest is the young guys who make jewellry out of the innards of mechanical watches - just wonderful and they know their stuff. They can tell you all about the pieces, where they come from, how they work - but I digress.There's plenty of good quality and reasonably priced food and drinks, there are plenty of souvenirs to buy - all manner of paraphernalia is available. Yes tourists come here, but I'm a Sydneysider - born and bred, and I come here all the time.Every time I come, I always think of Jack Mundey and his mates from saving these and other wonderfully historic spaces from demolition.You can google - Jack Mundey and Green Bans if you want to know more about the history of Sydney.

Nice but scruffy. We dandered around the Rocks as you do when in Sydney but we weren't that knocked out by it. Yes, nice shops and places to eat but we would have like a bit more way finding to help us make sense of where we were.
Nice area.. The area is nice to explore during the day as it has markets and affordable places to eat. I do not know what it like at night.

Very Fun Area. we came on a Saturday and the street market is here Saturday and Sunday. Very good quality and great selection of vendors. The cafes, bistros are a little pricier but there are some nice ones with daily specials. It is a fun area and lots to see. Circular quay is adjacent to the rocks and both attractions are fun.

Take a step back and look at the History.. We did not bother to check out the eateries, we were too busy taking in the History in the little back streets including the Digs.
A lot of effort has gone in to making this a must visit to see what you missed last time in Sydney, it's free and user friendly.
shopping spree. the rocks was a delight to visit for shopping, eating and drinking, the variation of shops was good, staff were friendly and very helpful

Overated!. THE ROCKS IS SUPPOSED TO BE THE BEST PLACE.
Its really not!,. It's expensive, the bar staff were rude in a few places.
And there really is not mush to see other than Sydney Bridge .
Darling Harbor is much better & cheaper.

Great Neighbourhood. Love this little area of Sydney, one of the first established and settled places in the Sydney. Lots of small streets and alleys ways to walk around with all sorts of shops and restaurants to check out!

Lovely place but.... When in Sydney you should go to the Rocks at least once as the place is lovely. By the waters and there are shops abound. We went on a sunday and it was very crowded, the markets were quite nice but pricey and nothing much to buy. The restaurants were heaving with people but it is a nice place to walk around, sit and people watch. It is historic and old and the buildings are lovely just to walk and browse or have a drink. We went through there as we went on the harbour bridge walk through the rocks.

Vibrant atmosphere. Although the Rocks has been gentrified it is still worth a visit. You can still get an idea of what it was like 150+ years ago. There are interesting shops and craftspeople and good coffee shops, pubs and restaurants.

Colourful in history and character. The Rocks has a great feel to it, if you're already in Sydney and checking out the harbour there's no reason not to have a wander around The Rocks as it's right next to it.There's a good little free museum, The Rocks Discovery Museum, with some information on the original inhabitants of the land and the first European settlers to arrive.Plenty of places for food and drink.I would definitely recommend the free walking tour of The Rocks offered by the "I'm Free Walking Tours", they give some great information on the area and some good interesting stories about certain individuals that lived there.

My favourite place in Sydney!. The Rocks is such a beautiful area just by the Harbour Bridge. We mainly go for the amazing weekend market but even just to stroll the cobblestone and visit some of the art galleries and pubs is so beautiful. We go to The Rocks every time we visit Sydney!
Take a stroll. get off the main street. Climb the various steps away from the throngs of people and tourist shops.Stop and read the many inscriptions and pause to reflect on how is was at settlement.

Interesting historic area. The weekend markets are fabulous - a great selection of food and local handcrafts. Good bars and restaurants abound, and there is a self guided walking tour you can follow. Lots of interesting historical sights.

The Rocks!. Was a nice walk from Darling Harbour. Very enjoyable breakfast , then a stroll around the Rocks market. Lots of places to eat and drink. Also easy access to the Sydney Harbour Bridge - if you don't mind a few stairs!!
A historial and interesting neighborhood. Had a fantastic time walking around the Rocks. A historical neighborhood with lots to see and do. Great food options and museums. Views from all over!

Old city. The Rocks is a must see. The history is fantastic, imagining the first settlers in Sydney while walking around in the very narrow streets, having a cold beer looking at the Harbor Bridge. Very nice.
Good diversion. A good diversion from modern Sydney with some well thought out street preservations. Interesting museums and old buildings with narrow streets.

The rocks market. Was great to visit but a bit over priced with some things. A very quaint area around The Rocks, reminds me a bit of Tasmania's Salamanca Market. Lovely little cafes in the surrounding streets to have a nice lunch.

Picturesque and Historic. Definitely a must see! Although this area is a bit touristy, it has a very authentic feel to it. Great shopping, restaurants, cafes, and more! Take a walk down the many historic roads and under the Sydney Bridge. Look for open markets on the weekends.

The free walking tour of rocks is a must!!. Love the history and stories of the Rocks. The free walking tour starts at 6pm each day opposite the overseas passengers cruise terminals. The vibe is great and lots of places to eat around the rocks area and circular quay. Must do!

The Rocks Markets, Sydney NSW Australia. I love The Rocks Markets on the weekends. I get in by ferry and have a lovely time wandering along the stalls, shops, pubs and cafes. There's a good variety of food - from vegetarian, Asian, German to Australian pub food. The market stalls are a cut above the other Sydney markets, e.g., Paula Church's paintings of Australian fauna and flora (I bought a lovely painting of lorikeets), Middle Eastern spreads and pottery, cookery herbs and spices, and fresh nougat bricks - yum!! The buskers are very talented, and the clothing stalls bright and colourful. Often, there's an ocean liner docked in the Overseas Terminal and a chance to see it close-up. Overall, a lovely weekend experience!

Great shops, close to train. If you make it to the Opera House then keep walking over toward the Bridge and you'll find the great shops and decent quick food selection over at the rocks. Much better gift selection than the shops by the Opera house. Fun place to spend a few hours.

Rockin Rocks!. Visiting Sydney you've got to home in on the Rocks.Great pubs like Fortune of War.Great shops like the helpful Ugg shop and designer wear outlets.Good view of Opera House unless a mega cruise liner is in.Under the start of Sydney Harbour Bridge you cruise back down the lanes n bye ways.Sunday morning the Rocks are transformed by the street market a maze of stalls n food.A great experience don't miss the Rocks!!
Great. The Rocks is something you need to see when you are in Sydney. Great market place and nice atmosphere. Visit the rocks museum to understand what The Rocks means to the citizens from Sydney.

Wow!. I just love the whole atmosphere of this place. My husband & I were spending 3 days in Sydney over Easter & I would have liked to have spent more time here. I was really taken by the beautiful sweets in the bakery next to Phillips Foote. I will be trying both of these for sure next visit.

Shopping with a view. The Rocks is always a good place to visit particularly over the weekend. Lots of good cafés for breakfast or lunch and the trendy Rocks Markets are open for food, jewellery and clothing. If you're looking or something different this is the place to shop with lots of Australian made products to buy. For visitors to Sydney a walk will take up to Millers Point where many of the buildings are heritage listed and show early Sydney architecture at its best.

Feel the History. The Rocks provides a variety of interests from shopping for clothes, nick naks and Restaurants. You can enjoy beautiful waterfront upmarket dining to casual cafe style. I find most enjoy is you can feel the history of Australia while just walking around this amazing place. A must on your visit to Sydney.

A must visit area of Sydney!. This is the area where Sydney was born. The old building are well preserved, some of the warehouses have been converted to beautiful restaurant & bars & there is a great weekend market.

Great walk. Walking around The Rocks was just amazing. We were able to see so many of the businesses that are located in the area and the whole gamut was just so nice. From little shops full of knick knacks to lots of bars and restaurants. The neighborhood is so nice and the houses are gorgeoulsy quaint. Love it.

WHERE ARE THE ROCKS?. Travel books I read say that Sydney started at the Rocks. Located near the Opera House, both attractions can be visited together. It has museums, restaurants, ports for the ferries, docks for the cruise ships, the Sydney Harbour Bridge, etc. Along the way to the Rocks, I noted a building that has a plaque on the wall stating that this is where the first National Bank of Australia was located. I continue to wonder, where are the Rocks? Why is this place called, " the Rocks"? Need to research this....

Convenience . I stayed in this suburb for 3 days it was walking distance to everything the harbour bridge, opera house, botanical garden, circular quay where cruise ships come and go as well as daily pier entertainment, lots of lane ways lined with with shops and cafes, you can hear live music every night from the pubs, train station is next to pier

stroll through the rocks. It's where Australia was founded by the English (after a short stay in Botany Bay). There are markets on the weekend and the orient hotel used to have trad jazz on the weekends. The original Customs house is there 200 years old and a maritime museum.The overseas terminal also is there and often a big liner is in town and that makes for a great viewing as well. opposite the rocks of course you look at The Opera House

Old Sydney. If you are visiting Sydney don't miss The Rocks area.It is charming old Sydney and only a short walk from Circular Quay. Has a brilliant market on Saturday mornings. One of our favourite places in The Rocks is The Rocks Cafe....best breakfast ever!

Great shopping and browsing opportunities. We visited the Rocks during the weekend and had the pleasure of visiting the market as well. A good eclectic mix of things for sale. The food stalls were my favourite.

Sunday fun. I did not do any of the organized walks but went as an off chance on a Sunday. In addition to the expected crowd there was a international children's carnaval going on . This added to the festive and happy atmosphere I witnessed. The Sunday market at the Rocks was not dissimilar to that of the likes of Convent garden. The same can be said for the artisans who were selling their handcraft there of course there were exceptions but from my recollection I could only think of a couple. I would not say it was value for money either . A usual craft market scenario with the normal crowd hub

Times changes. The Rocks changed, but it's still a must during your trip in Sydney. Important that you go by foot and not by car. Have a nice walk and try to feel the history, even if there is now a souvenir shop ..

historic market. There are historic buildings on each side of the street. You may find assorted shops selling handicraft articles, food...Of course, you can have some cofe and snack in the restaurant nearby when you got tired.

What a lovely way to orient onself with Sydney's layout and attractions! Really gives a clear insight into the surrounds. We greatly enjoyed the vista. Seeing Sydney from this vantage really brought a focus and orientation to Sydney for me. I was unawRe and in fact confused about the layout until I had had this most enlightening education about the general geography of Sydney. From ground level and in an enclosed taxi one simply cannot easily orientate oneself as to the layout of this very large and sprawling city! I am very happy with the experience!

Great place to go and just do!. This is a cool place to hang out and just find out whats going on, whats hot and whats not. The ghost tour is great. You meet so many nice people and you can just wander around as though it was a couple of centuries ago. Good fun, not just for historians

Strolling. Really nice place to stroll around, plenty of little shops , cafe's, and pubs, there is a very good market on Saturday, which is worth a look. There is a museum which is free and a very good tourist information shop which is huge.Some great old buildings including Cadmans cottage, which l think is the oldest building in Sydney. Great place to spend a few hours.

Nostalgic charm, an explorers playground. I can't rate this wonderful place high enough, I come here often and still find new things to amaze me. The Rocks is great during the day but at night it is so beautifully lit up with fairy lights. The ghost tour is well recommended as is the Harbour Rocks cafe (awesome food and wine). Bring your camera this place is great for photos.

Fun to Walk and See Historic Sydney. We stayed close and enjoyed our walk around the rocks and historic Sydney. We walked on Saturday and Sunday, there was a market open which was fun to see along with the retail and historic buildings. Well worth the visit....

The Rocks, pearls of Sidney Australia. The Rocks is as an urban locality, tourist and historic area of Sidney. it is near the city center and is located in New South Wales. Complete renovated old buildings and a lot of nice small gift shops make a feeling that you are walking in the time more then 200years ago. The most famous buildings are Cadmans Cottage, the Sidney Observatory, the Museum of Contemporary Art, and a few of nice pubs as the Fortune of War and Lord Nelson. You can reach from the Rocks the famous Sydney Harbor bridge. From this bridge you have a beautiful view to the famous Sydney opera house.I visited Sidney 10 years ago, it was a wonderful experience.

It's not all about the harbour bridge and the opera house - the rocks is the real history. I've been in Sydney for 3 days and I think I've photographed everything , today I went for a stroll around the rocks and also popped into the free museum .The rocks is were it all started with the setters way back in the late 1700s , fascinating history and walking around the streets and lanes you can see a diversity in nationalities and cultures .On my stroll I came across the First Impressions Sculpture by Bud Dumas. The Sculpture is in sandstone with figures cut into the stone of a soldier, settlers and convict. These figures represent the original settlers to the area.What a piece of art there are lights on each side so it can be seen at night , for me this sculpture is as impressive as the opera house and the harbor bridge ,they say art is in the eye of the beholder -first impressions to me will last Long I'm my memory as long as the bridge and the the opera house.Mr Bud Bumas take a bow .

Steeped in history, a fun place to visit. Always love visitingThe Rocks. The beautiful old buildings, variety of shopping, including wonderful markets on the weekend,, eateries, pubs and foreshore walks and views makes this an enjoyable place to visit ..

Historic. Great place for a home base.Situated close to everything! This is the oldest party of Sydney,beautiful architecture,pubs,restaurants,shops,outdoor market on Friday, Saturday,Sunday. You can walk to many places
special place. it is very quiet and good view, also we can see different traditional building and unique restaurant

Love this part of Sydney. Good area to visit, views of the Harbour Bridge and short walk from Circular Quay. A place with a lot of history. Some great pubs cafes & restaurants in the area especially the 100 year old Mercantile Irish Pub with good pub grub & great staff. We were fortunate to have a great dime on St Patrick's Day 2015.

One of our Favorite Neighborhoods in Sydney!. We visited the Rocks frequently during our 9 day visit to Sydney. The ambience is welcoming and relaxing. Great bars, restaurants, shops. Lots of people who live there, too. Not just tourists. We took advantage of the FREE walking tour that takes place most nights around 6 pm or so. It was sooooo informative. We loved it. It starts by the oldest house on the Rocks. Also, on weekends there is great flee market that we thoroughly enjoyed. For us, it was the best!

Tourist traps & museums. It's extremely touristy so don't expect good value for your money from the many restaurants and bars.The contemporary art museum is the highlight for me, as well as the views.
Funky spot.. Went for a girls weekend in Sydney and cruised the night markets and wine bars. Loved the vive, loved the variety and loved the red wine.
