Thanks. Wow wow wow. Whatever you do while your visiting Sydney, do NOT miss this area. We kept hearing about it from various tour guides but couldn't figure out exactly how to get there. Finally at the Circular Quay we asked a ferry sales person and they gave us directions. It has wonderful shops, great art galeries, fun eateries, and lots of history. So glad we were persistent in finding it.

Great place for a visit, lots to do. The Rocks is a great place to visit and judging by the crowds of visitors (and a few locals) lots of other people think so too! There's lots to do with boutique shops everywhere, good (but expensive) dining and a vibrant night life. My favourite is an early evening pub crawl (no obligation to get drunk though) with live entertainment and people watching a great way to observe some quirky characters in old fashioned pubs. If you're cashed up some of the best hotels in Sydney are right here.
walk. A very pretty place , terrific views , you can walk a long way , got some great pics , the cliffs give you great views .

The Rocks. The Rocks area facing Sydney Harbour is a truly amazing area of the city. The preservation of historic buildings is admirable and the many lane ways and 17 old pubs in the area make it a great place to browse and to learn about the history of the port of Sydney.Accompanying the pubs, are unique restaurants, art galleries and shops. The area is within a nine iron of the cruise boat docks and the Harbour bridge.It's a can't miss area when visiting this beautiful city
Just love this feel. It just feels soulful and historic. With a gutsy bit of charm. Take hours to spend quality time here, please.

The Place to Stay and Eat in Sydney. Great location with the Sydney Harbour Bridge and Opera House as the backdrop. Many wonderful dining opportunities. We stayed at the Shangra-la hotel in the Rocks and it was wonderful. This is also where you start the Sydney Bridge Climb/Walk.
Use the Free Tours. Around 6pm there are free walking tours of the Rocks area. You tip your guide at the end. Nice walk, plenty of interesting stories and well worth the time.

Can't Complain. Try it.... you will enjoy it.... its out on the rocks ... but then it's out on the rocks...... try it if you have time. The GOD & have other rocks that are incredibly better... Go for them if time & permits.

Fascinating history. We toured the Rocks area on our City Bus Tour and made note to go back on our own to walk around. The tour gave us a good history of the early days here, and it was really inspiring to see some of the original buildings and get an idea of what actually went on around these streets. An area your glad they preserved, even though the early days were very seedy! On Thursday and Friday they have an open market and we decided to combine that with walking the streets again. Check out the Nurses Walk, and Suez Canal and hopefully get the history. We also enjoyed a light snack in one of the many little cafes serving pastries. Also check out the market if your there - we didn't go at night, which is also supposed to be pretty special. The market is very similar to any open market here in the US, but was really fun to see some of the special talent - the guy creating absolutely beautiful pictures using paint cans! I would have LOVED to have taken a photo of him, but didn't want to disrespect his request that no photos be taken. He was amazing! Also the woman that made framed, multi-dementional pictures from Australian postage stamps! I'm sorry I didn't purchase one, but this was the first leg of our month long trip.There also, was a great little museum and I'm sorry I don't remember the name, but is was all about the history of Australia. Very, very impressed on the information and displays they had in such a small location on two floors. They even offered a treasure hunt for the kids, which I thought was great! As I said, this was a fun area of the city to spend several hours in. I hope you enjoy it as much as we did.
Trendy location. have a walkabout and soak up the atmosphere and then stop by any enjoy one of the many places where you can grab a large or small bite to eat

Relaxing and fun. I always go here almost every weekend, well mostly. I usually just walk aling the harbour and relax by sitting viewing harbour bridge and opera house.Do not underestimate a free sightseeing as this one worth of your time for inspiration hunting and romantic place at night.

Must stay here. As its name implies, it is built on rocks and there are steep,slopes and lots of stairs carved into the rocks. We stayed in a bed and breakfast inn and enjoyed exploring the neighborhood shops and restaurants. The Market on the weekend was festive with lots of creative crafts.

LOVE THE ROCKS. I just love The Rocks it is such a nice neat clean historical part of Sydney that just makes me want to live there. It almost does not look real it looks like a little model town with its beautiful clean paved streets and perfect old building and street lamps and cute little shops and cafes. They have great markets on the sits on a hill that just adds to the charm of the whole place.
The Rocks. The Rocks was a really nice area of Sydney to walk around. There are a lot of shops and restaurants.

"This is where it's all about!". Loved being in the Rocks area. Visited the week-end markets, took in the view, and loved our dining experiences! Take a ferry from Circular Quay to anywhere for a wonderful experience! We stayed in the Haymarket area and took the free shuttle bus-Number 555--to the Rocks.

The Rocks Rocks. This is the central part of Sydney city and the CBD is integral to this area. Where the new modern glass façade buildings vie with the old Victorian era that include quaint churches. Easy to walk around Rocks and several interesting places to see. Lots and lots of eating places and cafes to choose from.
Great bars and restaurants. So easy to get to on public transport or even on foot. Great place to meet friends for drinks and dinner. Beautiful area.

Take your time and walk around. Take your time and slowly walk around the rocks. It has some great old building and a lot of history. I think every time I walk around I see something different that I hadn't seen before. Great just to sit and watch the day go by as well. Love all this area of Sydney
Not to be missed. Excellent place to see "old" Sydney and plenty bars and restaurants all bursting with history. Well worth a walk around.

Saturday stroll in the Rocks. Wonderful..after great lunch we wandered through the Rocks and the markets were on, which was lovely...just meandered around, got some goodies and enjoyed the great atmosphere, then wandered down to the Orient pub and listened to a fabulous muso for rest of the day....

Fun place to explore!. The rocks area was a nice area to walk around and look at the shops and there was plenty to eat and drink in the area. It was neat seeing them take an old area and making it into a new area that had a little of everything there.

Nice walk around the Rocks!. After I wandered around I ended up at the Rocks! I enjoyed my stroll and the streets entering several shops as well as an eatery or two. Nice museum as well! Then continued my walk to the Opera House....

What a Place!. What an amazing place, we got lost for hours, around each courner is another surprise, the history of this place is amazing. Great food and a festive vibe with the markets. Will deffinatly visit again!!
Rocks area. An easy walk to the Rocks area where you see "old" Sydney and can visit a vibrant market. There are many restaurants and hotels in the area and the views of the harbour are magnificent.
Interesting. It was great to be able to walk around and view past history buildings. It was very interesting. Excellent food and eateries without over the top prices.

Great place to wander. This place is so full of history and older buildings it gives you a great feel of what Sydney was like in the past. I recommend doing the rocks tour to get a feel for the history and the shopping is also good
Great. Really enjoyed the rocks, great places to eat and the markets are great plenty of variety at markets.

Historic area. The first Europeans settled this area and you can walk around the older buildings in complete contrast to the high rise CBD close by. The Rocks museum is free and provides an insight into how the indigenous population were effected by the Europeans. The markets are nice to walk around although I would not say they charged market prices. A must visit area if you are looking to explore Sydney and Australian history.

Love this historic area.. Lots of bars & cafes in this area. Seems to be both a tourist & local hub, so quite pricey. Right next to the main cruise terminal. The architecture is splendid! A must see for visitors.

Full of History. The Rocks is the oldest settled area in Sydney and an enjoyable place to spend time wandering while soaking up the history and enjoying the atmosphere. The Rocks street markets are open at weekends with many arts, crafts and souvenir stalls. The Rocks and markets are adjacent to the main cruise wharf and Circular Quay ferry terminals. Everything is within easy walking distance and only a few blocks from Sydney City centre.
Historic area. Can't go to Sydney without walking around the rocks area. Plenty of eating spots. Just to walk in an area that is so historic to Australia is awesome.

BEEN A NUMBER OF TIMES AND ALWAYS COME BACK. If you do not go the Rocks area of the Harbour you have missed a great little spot. Full of history, and in these days restaurants, cafes and arts and crafts outlets.
Essentially nestled under the Sydney Harbour Bridge it is ideally positioned for all visitors to Circular Quay and the Bridge.
Took a nice historical tour of the Rocks. The Rocks weren't that special but a walking tour of the Rocks is a nice way to learn a bit about Australian history.

Beautiful old suburb in the heart of Sydney. Lovely area, to take a stroll in after you've been to the Sydney opera house. There are plenty of places (very cools spots) to eat. If you're lucky the markets on!

Amazing History. A visit to the Rocks should be very high up on anyone's agenda when in Sydney. This area is the first one to be settled by Europeans. What is has gone through, and is still going through is a facinating story. We went there on 3 separate occasions, and will be going again once we go back to Sydney.
The Rocks. Very clean, very historical, the lots of nice restaurants and bars. It should be part of the city tour bec it is very different , less crowded and more cultural I shall say.
Very cool and trendy, either at night or during the day.. The Rocks has a colonial feel to it, right by Circular Quay. At night you a choice of trendy restaurants or bars with live bands,

Fun distraction on the weekend. We came here for the weekend street market, and had some great street food. We wandered through shops, and had a "15+" hot sauce that took me out of the equation for a few minutes, and effected me more for about another 40. It was great though.

Famous Rocks!. We always go to the Rocks area when in Sydney as the atmosphere is great with original bars and a great choice of restaurants. easily accessible from Circular Quay with great old buildings and some fantastic views of the harbour.

i absolutely love this place. This has to be one of the most amazing historical places in Australia. The atmosphere and vibe just walking through the back alleys and into the shops is amazing. So much to read about and see, the history is young but intriguing. Fantastic way to lose an afternoon.
Historic. So much to see and do in the rocks, whether its markets, shops, restaurants, history, cycling tours, pubs, the bridge or just a walk around to see some of the oldest housing in the city.

Hive of Activity. The Rocks area is alive from morning to morning. There are plenty of pubs & restaurants to suit all tastes (you can get Crocodile & Kangaroo Pizzas at one pub) as well as individual unique shops. It is only a few minutes walk from both Circular Quay & the Sydney Opera House as well as the main shopping area of George St. The Hotel (The Rendezvous) we stayed at is in the heart of the rocks but we were never disturbed at night. All in all a real buzzing place.
A relaxing place. I love this part of the city , a great place to enjoy a wine and bite to eat. Just walking around here is interesting we visit Susannah place museum.
Great to wander around this Historic Area. Love all the history in this area and the Markets are a great place to wander around. Also all the old pubs are full of character & charm.

Love the Rocks. Always a great place to visit in Sydney for its historical background and there is always the wonderful markets on the weekend.My visitors from Brisbane loved the atmosphere here and thoroughly enjoyed the walk around this historic area.The food stalls were fantastic offering hungry visitors a good range of our multicultural food and always great to have a beverage in the many pubs around.

Historical building more interesting than market itself. Worth a visit as it is only few minutes away from circular and some nice spots for a good photo of the opera house and harbor bridge.The red brick buildings give a charm to the place while the market itself sells a wide range of stuff from souvenirs, handcraft, art and other items. In the are there is large Sydney visitor and information center.

Tourists, tourists....... Lots of restaurants and little shops for tourist. It was not one of my favourite areas to visit. I can only assume that the evening my be a better time to go for nightlife exeperience at the restaurants and bars. The food at the restaurant we stopped in for a quick lunch was very disappointing.

Love the Rocks and the weekend markets. My Family and I often go into the Rocks area, just to explore and look around the weekend markets and take photos. It's such a beautifully Historic part of Sydney to walk around, and a place not just for visitors, but for Sydneysiders as well :)

A great walk. What a great way to spend an afternoon! Strolling the streets of the Sydney area called "the Rocks" will reveal beautiful architecture, scenic views, wonderful eateries & nice shopping. Ideal for women, not the best spot for kids.
A lively place - nice to visit. We enjoyed walking along the old buildings, finding a wine restaurant and sitting outdoors watching people come and go.A place well worth a few hours visit.
Wonderful Market. The Rocks is worth a visit for the historical value. Quaint resturants and pubs. Best attraction for sure the Market on Sunday afternoon. Wonderful variety of Crafts. A must see!

Cultural walk. The rocks was where our cruise ship boarded and returned. It was a wonderful place to learn the history of the area and get a bite to eat. The area is trendy and touristy with local market fares on Fridays and weekends, but we loved it.

One of my favorite Sydney neighborhoods to explore. There are so many great things to see, places to eat, or have a beer/wine. There's also a great sense of history while walking around that I fully enjoy. The markets on the weekend are great, especially if some of the very talented live musicians are there playing. I've purchased a few prints from the market recently, can't wait to frame them and get them on my walls.

Touristy but worth it. Our cruise ended in Sydney and docked within steps of the Rocks. The Rock's is a trendy neighborhood. So the area was extremely busy as I am sure it is when any cruise ship is in port. They had market going the weekend we were there and it was very nice. I bought things to take home. The restaurants and shops were very busy and people were having a good time. The prices at the restaurants are high. We were going to stop for to try an Aussie Meat Pie and they wanted $19 just for the pie. We did not stop, but I did find one a few blocks later for $4.50. So be careful of that. Food in the Darling Harbor area is more affordable. The pubs are very entertaining...lots of people have a good time!!! It's worth a walk through at a minimum.

The Rocks, Sydney. Great experience at the weekend, when the place comes alive, with the markets in full flow. Friday Foodie Market is good. But the craic over the weekend is even better. There are some great sites around. The Observatory on Argyle Street is terrific - though don't try the climb unless you're fit! The Rocks is full of early colonial architecture - and history, like Australia's oldest pub. You can lose yourself there for hours. Decent street music acts come out at the weekend. Lots of nice eating places as well. As a photographer, I love all the opportunities The Rocks offers.

worth visiting again and again. The Rocks is one of the highlights of the harbour area. The street market had a wide and very interesting array of merchandise for sale, including unique Australian crafts. The quaint cafes in the area were excellent and offer good food at reasonable prices. The covered shopping arcade was a welcome haven in the rain! If you go to the harbour, a long stroll on the Rocks area is a must-do!

Historic & beautiful. It's a wonderful place to wander around, learn about the history of the early settlers and admire the buildings. We watched a group of kids, dressed in the olden days attire, having a great time with their guide, as she led them through the history and characters.

Plenty to see, do and eat. The Rocks is a great place just to walk around. There are plenty of restaurants and pubs and there are markets at different places at different time during the week and weekend.

Charming and full of history. Loved it couldn't help thinking whilst walking along the cobblestone streets how life would have been back in the days of the discovery of Sydney. Great shops , pubs and markets and lots to see in the Museum.

Interesting View of Old Sydney. The Rocks is actually an area that includes the remains of some of the oldest houses in Sydney, as well as shopping and restaurants. On Saturdays it is home to an extensive market, with stalls filled with clothing, souvenirs, art, and food.

Nice area to relax or shop. We would pass through "The Rocks" almost everyday while in Sydney. Usually just for a bite and a drink before going back to the hotel and resting up for dinner. There are many food venues to choose from but we kept going back to the same one everyday. (see The Rocks Cafe in a separate review.)

The Markets. A trip to Sydney isn't complete without a walk through the weekend markets at The Rocks. There are vendors with handmade products made locally, food vendors with all types of food and best of all entertainment at different locations where you can sit and listen while you enjoy a bite. Always a pleasure. Lots of indoor shopping near this location too and stop by the information center for things to do while you are in Sydney.
Well worth a visit.. Fabulous. Loads of small unique shops in old buildings. If you manage to go when there is a craft market on don't miss it.

Sydney History still alive. this is a great place to explore some of the original Sydney, the old buildings, the history of the area plus great markets. also so close to the bridge and the opera house. always a highlight

What a wonderful Sydney treasure. If you like great museums, markets, designer shops, tourist shops, pubs with character etc (the list goes on) well, this is a must see in Sydney. In such a small area you can get lost with historical alleyways weavng through this area. History, both Aboriginal and 'invaders' abound in the many museums - some are living museums with work ongoing. Definitely a must see if you visit Sydney .
What a buzz. Atmosphere abounds in this location. It's like stepping back in time. Historic buildings occupied by trendy restaurants and retail outlets offer a real treat for eating and shopping.

ROCKIN' IN THE ROCKS. The cruise liners, Queen Victoria and Queen Mary 2 both large cruise ships plus the fire works when they both departed.Almost every day there are ships docking at the Rocks, we found that it was so close to Circular Quay (3 minutes) with it's buskers and artists plus the ferries and also the trains. (we took the train to the Domestic Airport $A13 approx. for seniors using the Opal card)
So Historical and beautiful.. Love The Rocks area, thank goodness they didn't pull down those historic beautiful buildings, so much history here, take a walk through yourself you will appreciate it.

Australia Day. Australia Day at the Rocks is amazing and a must for next year. You can walk around the rocks and down to the harbour to watch the ferry races and plane flyovers whilst enjoying the atmosphere of all the locals. Best venue to take it all in from is the Park Hyatt
Hidden gem. Lots of lovely wee shops, quality food if a little expensive. Quality and service is great. Worth a nosy about. F
Love the weekend market. Lovely market every weekend with lots of handmade unique items. Friday afternoon food market is also worth a look - lots of tasty treats!

Lots of great things. A lot of history in this area, many shops and restaurants. Friday Foodi Market on the street is a great place to grab some real local food. The Saturday Market is a great place to get some gifts and great food as well. You can use the steps at the side of the Rocks to take the walk way onto the Harbor Bridge, get some great photos of the Harbor area.

Old Sydney. Luckily we had locals with us to find this gem up the small lanes. Looking around all these old buildings with the new buildings in the background was spectacular. Well worth taking the time to seek this out
Shopping treats. The best place to get souveniers. I liked the shops and do not feel that we were being ripped off. Friendly staff and good gifts.

A Unique Quaint Part of Sydney. I loved how different the buildings were. Walking through the rocks and learning about its history is a must do for any trip to Sydney. Lots of history, cafes, and cool stuff to see and do.

Quaint narrow streets, busy market stalls, good street food. Tucked behind the harbour area , the Rocks house several narrow historic streets. Shops, cafes, and Market stalls selling colourful dresses and craft good? We had lunch at a simple cafe serving excellent food much gluten free and gluten free beer!! Ther is also an excellent community garden where one can freely sit and an indoor shopping area. An area close but contrasting to the wide harbour area

A bit overrated. Still, an historic area with some fun places. This is where Sydney began and there are a number of historic buildings. There can be some steep climbs and lots of steps but well worth exploring. Near to the harbor and other attractions. We enjoyed the Australian Hotel, a great old pub where you can sample Kangaroo, Emu, and Crock if you're so inclined, or just kick back and enjoy a schooner. The shortest street in Sydney is there. It runs from a cross street about a block to a sheer rock wall. A good illustration of why the area is called the Rocks.

Good for watching the world go by. We were lucky enough to be staying while 3 cruise ships came in so each day had something different to look at.Lots of seating, good coffee, great restaurants and fabulous views

Street vendors with great food.. We happened to visit on a day when the street vendors had their booths setup. The booths were quite busy but one vendor (Greek food I think) had a long long line. We opted for a more reasonable line. The variety of food was quite good.
Great craft Market. good selection of craft stalls at very reasonable prices and really friendly people selling, not pushy or anything.

The nicest part of Sydney city. This is 'old town' Sydney, or the historic part of Sydney, where it all began. It is the best part of Sydney to wonder around aimlessly for a while soaking up the atmosphere. I find it a relief to get down to the Rocks and out of the CBD area away from the echo of the traffic. It seems to quieten down considerably in the narrow streets down in The Rocks. Because of its location close to the entrance to the Habour Bridge and Bridge Climb, there are some tourist traps here, but there are also some very fine restaurants and cafes, and a couple of little unique shops. You will also find the exclusive brands harbour-side. You can also just wonder down a set of steps into the harbour area and walk around to the Opera House whilst you are there. That way, you'll get a glimpse of the lovely botanic gardens.
Historic area with lots to explore. This is a lovely part of Sydney with plenty of bars and resturants plus a market on a Saturday. Easy access to the Harbour Bridge
nice place to visit. when you come to this place you can feel very comfy, and have a small market on saturday which is very brilliant idea, also the view is very good, many bars and many restaurant.

Give yourself time to explore. The Rocks is the site of Australia's first European settlement. Yes, there are a lot of tourist traps here. But, if you look real close, there are still remnants of times past.
Everyday at 6PM. there's a free 1-and-a-half-hour tour that starts in front of Cadmans Cottage.

Nice park. This is an historical area of Sydney and has a small park area overlooking the harbour, where the large cruise ships dock. Nice to walk around and take pictures of both the bridge and opera house.
Very under-rated. do visit this place in the evening, to feel the vibrancy, the warmth of the people and experience the night life of sydney.
the rocks markets. great, The Rocks market is a great place to see and get a bargan nice food and lots of home made items, shirts jewels that something special. would recommend it.

Don't just scratch the surface. It would be easy to dismiss The Rocks as a bit of a tourist trap but if you take the time to walk around there is plenty of history and interesting buildings and lanes. if you read the signs you can easily imagine being here in the early days and the whole place can take on a different character.Still a good place for a meal or a coffee or a beer. Worth a visit especially if it is your first (or only) time.

Plenty of atmosphere. I sat here and watched my husband walk the bridge until I realised I had been waving to at least a dozen strangers for an hour . I then discovered the shops and treated myself to a couple of pairs of uggs ! There are at least 4 shops selling designs you cant get in the UK and there was also a market on . Great handcrafted items .
Walk and Eat. Lots of walking and lots of outdoor dining. Find a walking tour to get the history of the area, which are very well done.

look out for the market for a great place to wander. lovely cafes that serve excellent brunches. weekend upmarket market stalls, bars and lovely shops, all very close to the harbour... what's not to love??

A MUST visit. This area has retained its atmosphere - with some great pubs and restaurants and, at the weekend, a really good market - a lot of markets contain mostly tat - this one was different - we could have given house room to stuff from most of the stalls

Not Bad. If you are a fan of great good buys, then this the place for you. You will see here items that you do not normally see in regular shopping centers. Just keep walking around this small areas and you will also find foods that are not common.
Great vibe. One of my favourite places in Sydney. The restaurants, shops and vibe is fantastic. The view of the Opera House is probably the best near the Park Hyatt.

Place near the bridge. The Rocks ... next to the Harbour bridge a very touristy place, packed with street markets, coffee shops, restaurants and bars. Nice to see them once - then go to a quieter place ...

A must see and do. We walked out of the harbour over to the Rocks. There is ample street side shopping and a bazaar type atmosphere. Some great little souvenir shops and cafes adorn the area. Spend a couple of hours and enjoy.

Foodie Friday. I loved the feel of the rocks. Great architecture and old city feel. The market on Friday is Foodie Friday and was a great assortment of cuisines. Lots of nooks and crannies to wander around in.

Eat out in Sydney. If you don't know what you want to eat for either lunch or dinner,The Rocks area is a short walk from most hotels. You can find just about any quisine you're looking for. From pub grub to white linen french. Get out of the hotel, you'll be glad you did.
Great pubs/restaurants... pleasant to walk around.... Great pubs and restaurants in this area... very pleasant to walk around and people watch and kill some time... and of course eat/drink :-)

A good Sunday Day Out. Go to the markets at the rocks and wander around the crazy and colourful stalls. Have a sweet, coffee or cake at La Rennaissance (as the chef's recipes are to die for) and perhaps walk up through the rocks to the old pubs and have lunch there. A cocktail at the Park Hyatt is a real treat as well.

Great market Saturday,Sunday. The rocks is where everything is happening only a few steps from the Quay where all the ferries exit and enter. Great market of vendors and even when they are not there museums, restaurants and bars are the best!

Historic. many hours can be spent just mooching around here. Or just try all the restaurants. Arcades with shops hidden everywhere. The museum is interesting as are the many plaques/ posters in historic locations.
Phillips Foote is fantastic for food... you cook your own on giant BBQs and also the best draft beer in town.

Australia Day 2015 Fun & Frolics. Who would have belived it- torrential rain almost all day in Sydney while the rest of Australia Day celebration around the country based in warm sunshine. The Rocks just gets on with it though and maybe the presence of so many lively pubs make that difference on a wet day - The Observer Hotel was jumping with covers musician have the audience in full blown song. Well done guys!
nice little market here on weekend. WIfe had a lovely time at the markets and i enjoyed the food and beverages at the market. Real awersome food at the markerts. had a great time here.
A Nice Place to Wander. Come to The Rocks and just wander through the streets.There are nice coffee shops and cafes. We preferred the area near Circular Quay, however.
Something Different. The Rocks have a mixture of restuarants of all prices and a variety of shops. A bit of climb from the harbour up to some of the places, but a quaint and colourful part of Sydney

Great Historical Site. The Rocks is a must visit place when in Sydney. Quaint streets good shops and restaurants and excellent pubs. Its great to see the cruise ships dominating the old original centre of Sydney where sailing ships used to moor and the Museum is a great place to learn of the areas history
Nice area for shop and eat. Great slight over price shopping area with good view and great ambience and delicious selection of food.
A great walk. What an interesting area - lots of history. Many great restaurants and shops. Also some great galleries to wander through.

Good fun. I loved the museum - funky but gave a good view of the population who came from Europe. Some nice shops and a beer hall. You can also rent your bike from a local shop and start your ride from The Rocks.

Tourists not Locals. If you are like me, you prefer to enjoy what the locals do.Well, the Rocks is not for locals most of the time.There are better markets elsewhere eg Paddington or Glebe.There are better restaurants elsewhere eg Paddington, East SydneyFor me the oversaturation of tourist buses means locals go elsewhere

The Site of Sydney's First Settlement. A must-visit when you are in Sydney so it's full of tourists but a delight anyway. Think heritage, winding, cobbled streets, old buildings, pubs, leafy lanes and steps, fabuous harbourside walks and views, and a place to eat. There are lots of restaurants and cafes, and a street market with food and other Aussie goodies.

Great location to stay in Sydney. The Rocks is in a picturesque historic district of Sydney, only minutes away from the Quay. There is abundant shopping, which my wife liked, and pubs and restaurants, which I liked. Everything you need is within a 5 minute walk to enjoy your time in this great city.

Beautiful area to stay and visit. Amazing location with the harbour bridge, the harbour itself and the ferries, plus the opera house and botanic gardens nearby, as well as George street. There is so much to see and do. We would love to come back.
Want to live here!!!. Love it! Brilliant weekend market, not overpriced. Amazing buildings, culture, restaurants, bars, atmosphere. A must to visit.

Restaurants. This place has old buildings and talks about Sydney's history - The movement that helped this place to retain its aboriginal stature which otherwise would have been modernized. There are a few restaurants around too. You may skip it if you are not into history.
Great restaurants and street markets.. Real buzz around the Rocks area. Lots of restaurants to choose from. Markets had nice jewellery and souvenirs a bit more up market than some shops.

Great markets on weekends!. Be sure to visit The Rocks markets during the weekend (both Saturday and Sunday)! Tons of stalls selling a variety of items-- clothes, jewelry, prints, chotchkies, etc. Plus there are yummy food vendors. Well worth a walk through! (And super close to the quay)

Walk around. The neighborhood is worth a walk around. It isn't necessarily a place you have to stay. There are some shops and restaurants but many of them are elsewhere in Sydney so it isn't worth an huge amount of time. It also gets very crowded when cruise ships are in port.

Always bustling, try doing the weekend markets. A must do in Sydney. There's a significant part of Sydney's early history here, some signs around describing the old buildings etc. Plenty of shops too for souvenirs etc. But the place really transforms on Fridays and weekends with the markets. Friday is foodies market - fantastic produce available, Saturday and Sunday is more general, great to browse and find a gift. If wanting lunch suggest you be early for any of the restaurants there as it can get very busy. It's only 5 minutes walk from Circular Quay and hand to the city. Also good views of the harbour and bridge.

A Must Do. Sure it's touristie but ya gotta stroll the Rocks and check out the shops, restaurants and bars. On the weekends they set up tents and there's a crafts fair that is extra special. I visit Sydny once or twice a year and stay at the nearby Marriott and make it a point to walk over here.

Great to Explore. A HUGE tourist trap of course. Lots of expensive shops aimed at tourists. But still such a charming area to wander around. I also love the little lane ways, hotels, bars, cafes and shops. The old sandstone buildings are just gorgeous. They have fantastic quirky markets on a regular basis. The museum is interesting. The Guylian Belgian Chocolate Cafe is delicious. The old hotels are full of history and great places to stay, eat and drink. I would actually choose to live there if I could afford it. When I visit our city offices for work meetings, I always spend time here. I would recommend it to tourists and locals alike. I think it is generally a safe area at night if you stick to the busy areas and avoid all those quite alleyways and side streets. Not only muggers you need to be wary of; as the sense of paranormal activity in this area is rather creepy :)
OK Shopping. Spent some time in "The Rocks" on a recent trip to Sydney. The history of the area is very interesting, but I found a lot of the shops to be overpriced. Overall, nothing really special.
Fabulous area. Fabulous area for just relaxing or shopping. We spent hours just looking around and stopping for drinks. The area is very quirky.

Interesting buildings. The Rocks is full of history and has lovely old buildings. It also has interesting shops and galleries selling things which are a bit different. There are many bars and restaurants for a drink, a snack or a meal. It is worth taking a tour of the area and hearing about the history.
Favourite place to explore. Lots of little lane ways and cafes, and places to sit and drink coffee, or have a wine if that's more your style. This is my favourite part of Sydney.

Great Night Out for drinks and dinner. A must to soak in the atmosphere of the whole area. Great for drinks and dinner but be sure to be early as seats/tables are almost full by 7pm especially on Fridays and Saturdays. Dress appropriately i.e. casual smart. Best pub/café is The Australian at The Rocks
Nice and quaint place to walk around!. The "Rocks" as they are referred is walkable from Circular Quay, with many shops and restaurants, can get quite busy at times, but nice place to explore.
Wonderful area to walk!. We very much enjoyed walking around this area and there are lots of places to eat. We chose an old pub and enjoyed fish & chips with a beer.

Busy yet an oasis of quiet. After our Free Tour of the Rocks we returned twice more. Easily attained from the Central Quays and a hive of busy streets, narrow alleys and inter - connecting snickets. There are overt pubs & bars with people spilling onto the streets, smaller bars with discreet beer gardens and small restaurants not always at street level. You can wander around and find your own favourite spot. We did. Our last evening was spent cooking a massive piece of chicken on a barBQ in the open garden section of a pub/restaurant. Good beer and wine in a secluded little courtyard with like minded clientèle made for a super evening. Phillip's Foote Restaurant for the record. Shops and other attractions - The Rocks Museum (free) are available cheek by jowl.

Sydney's Rocks - Feel the history under your feet. On a recent warm summer's evening my partner and I embarked on a gentle stroll through the cobbled streets of a bygone era. A twist-and-turn meander along Harrington Street, through to the Argyle Cut and under the Bridge revealed some fascinating turn-of-the-century architecture, original pubs bursting at the seam with cocktail drinkers cooling down in the night air; narrow alleys leading to hidden courtyards and inviting cafés and cosy restaurants. Rows of terrace house line the streets, many the subject of recent controversial sales, reaching an apex crowned by the historic Garrison Church on one corner and the seemingly ancient yet thoroughly contemporary Lord Nelson Hotel diagonally opposite.With the sun setting, our stroll culminated in a restful pre-booked seat at the very popular, renowned Fish at the Rocks Cafe located at the northern end of Kent Street. A glass of crisp white wine accompanied delicate pillows of seafood ravioli and a whole grilled snapper with Asian greens to top off a delightful and memorable summer's eve.

you need to visit the Rocks market. Saturday at the Rocks market is a must, The alley ways you can just stroll up and down and find some wonderful bargains. Lots of Australian hand made products, but all top end items. and then stop at Irish pub at the end and have a much deserved drink while crowd watching

Love this area. A great piece of Sydney. We were first there on a Sunday so the place was buzzing. There was a market with everything for sale. Pubs and restaurants were full. So much history. Great view of the harbour.

Historical buildings and restaunts. We stayed in this area, ate in restaurants here and sailed from the Quay. Active busy area, lots of street performers. Tourists and quay workers. Very hot in February, no shade near the opera house, so wear sunscreen and carry an umbrella if you cannot be in the sun. Park was nice but benches are limited and on crowded days you will need to be able to sit in the grass or on the cement curbs. Copenhagen Ice cream shop at the corner of the Quay was great but expensive (as is everything in Sydney). $14.00 for two small cups of ice cream. If you want to eat take away in this area, you have to go to the park and find some shade to enjoy your food with the birds. There are no tables to sit at anywhere unless you go into a restaurant. We ate at Hungry Jack ( Burger King in USA) and their tiny table area was gross and dirty. We took our food elsewhere. If you can make the climb, go up to Gloucester Street and visit the Susannah Place Museum. Must be able to climb lots of stairs. Spent about 6 hours down here and walking around the Rocks area. Try to find the back alley stairs in the daylight. There are secret passageways and small gardens and little pubs hidden everywhere.

Great vibe. Walk around the side streets. The cruise ship crowds predominate the Circular Quay area, but The Rocks has much more to offer off on its side streets. Shops are beautiful for browsing but really expensive, even by AU standards.

Thanks Green Ban for Keeping The Rocks. We really enjoyed our time walking through The Rocks with friends from Sydney who explained the history and gave us a better tour that a paid guide. It is a wonderful area and not to be missed when visiting Sydney. The Visitor Information Center there is also very helpful.

great tourist spot. This is a hand made market mostly. The market are open Saturdays and Sundays. You can see all wonderful old building and views across the harbour. All good restaurants nearby. Sidewalk seating...etc.Duty free shops, street shows, the opposite view is Sydney Opera House. Definitely great location for tourists to visit.

Nice walk, great food, good weekend market. I'd been to the rocks market on a sunday afternoon, and the market there was pretty decent. The food was equally amazing. Lovely museum telling history of the rocks, a must have coffee at one of the cafes..

The Rocks Markets. The Rocks is within easy walking distance of Circular Quay. It is an historical area with cafes, really nice gift shops from budget to expensive possum & merino goods, this is Lovely knitwear mostly found in Australia & New Zealand. Opal jewellery in various price ranges.The markets are open Saturdays & Sundays. They used to have moonlight markets on Friday nights during the Summer not sure if that still happens. There are food stalls from all over the world and really different cottage craft that cannot be bought in the shops. It is a must visit! Great for unusual photos too, eg looking up under the harbour bridge. Lovely old terrace homes as you walk around the back of the markets.

A good place for a wander. I enjoyed wandering through The Rocks to see all the wonderful old buildings and the views across the harbor. There are lots of restaurants and many with sidewalk seating so you can watch the tourists stroll by. The Saturday markets provided a nice diversity of wares from cell phone cases to original design clothing from spice mixes to jewelry. This is the area I chose to visit during a long layover in Sydney and it is quickly accessible from the train station at Circular Quay.

Hip Historical Cool. This is a great place to just walk around. It is a hip locations with many restaurants, bars and good shopping. You can check it all in in just a couple of hours. It is a small area right by the harbour.

Nice Historical Walk. The rocks area have no rocks. There are only many bars, cafes, and restaurants. There is a also a harbour next to it, which have many ships. At the rocks area, you can have a good view of the magnificent harbour bridge and the opera house from across the rocky sea. Check out the Sunday market on a Sunday as well, it is not open from Monday to Saturday.Good place for selfie to be taken and post on Facebook and instagram
Great for photos. If your after a great place to take photos, The Rocks is it. Evening time you get all the lights on Sydney harbour bridge and Sydney opera house.
intresting and historical area full of character. lots to see and do in this area i didnt have time to do everything but would stay in this area again.
great area. lovely museum telling history of the rocks, nice bars and restauarants. Market on Sunday morning highly recommended

Best pubs in Oz. Since I was there in 1977 the Rocks district has come a long way. It is the oldest part of Sydney and has a great atmosphere. Old warehouses and businesses have been regenerated and there is lots to do. Eating out and shopping very well catered for - check out the side streets and alleyways. Great Sunday market on George St. Visit Sydney's oldest pub The Fortune of War and its oldest Hotel the Lord Nelson with its own brewery. Other favourite watering holes are Harts Pub on Essex St and the Australian on Cumberland St.

Great historical area. The Rocks area is a must-visit for any visitor to Sydney. It seems that the bulk of tourists tend to stick to the harbour and CBD areas but the Rocks will pleasantly surprise you. It's a pretty laid-back area with well-restored buildings from one of Sydney's earliest settlements. There's a small museum here with artefacts and information about the area but the real attraction is the entire area itself. It is well-worth an afternoon just walking around the narrow streets and having a cup of coffee at one of the many cafes in the area.

Coffee - pastries - culture. The Rocks rocks. Weekend markets, the smell of coffee, cafes, restaurants - just everything. So close to the city if you want more but a day in the Rocks will keeps you occupied. Then take a ferry to Manly for a swim!

A wonderful historic district. Preserved by union bans on redevelopment in the 1970's, this area has become a treasure in the heart of Sydney. Interesting both for it's historic buildings and it's restaurants, pubs, street market, and shops. Particular highlights are The Lord Nelson pub (one of Sydney's oldest pubs, housed in a beautiful convict built sandstone building, it even makes several different ales on-site) and the Rock's Markets (includes artisanal jewellery and crafts, as well as food). If you have the time it is well worth spending an afternoon wandering the winding streets of this district to find hidden gems and sudden beautiful views of the harbour. As an aside, if you're there during Oktoberfest period the Lowenbrau pub in the main part of the Rocks just off George st is a fun place grab a stein and get in the German spirit.

The Rocks really rocks!. The Rocks area in Sydney is a must for any visitor as it is the old centre of the city and full of places of interest such as the Observatory, the Museum of Contemporary Art, the Discovery Museum and the old Customs House. It also is home to weekend street markets - great for genuine Aussie souvenirs - and some great restaurants, shops and bars. And did I mention that it is situated in the shadow of the Sydney Harbour Bridge, adjacent to central quay with great views out over the harbour and easy access to the numerous harbour ferries?It really is a great place to while away a few hours sightseeing, do a bit of retail therapy and then settle down to a nice lunch and an ice cold beer or glass of chilled white wine. The whole area has a really historic but nevertheless trendy vibe ... in fact, it Rocks!!

Tourist Trap But Worth a Visit. The Rocks is the birthplace of modern Australia, the area where Captain Arthur Phillip landed with his ships full of convicts to establish the British penal colony of New South Wales in 1788.The area has many historical colonial buildings, including Cadman's Cottage, which is worth a five minute visit. Walk to the end of The Rocks and you will be under the Sydney Harbour Bridge. Looking up at this monstrous iron structure gives you a very different perspective.The Rocks is full of restaurants and shops selling souvenirs, like fake aboriginal boomerangs, and toy kangaroos and koalas. But beware. Prices are aimed at loaded tourists so unless you feel like splurging, look but do not buy.There are many old pubs in The Rocks which have been restored. If you are thirsty, enjoy a cold Aussie beer in the pub. That, at least, will not break the bank.
Quaint. Great place to find a hidden gem or two as you meander through the little lanes, discover your history at the museum or just relax with a coffee in one of the fantastic cafes!
The Rocks or what. Well, I was disappointed, I expected to be wowed with a good selection of restaurants and bars and not just street market stalls.

Historic Rocks. The Rocks is a very old part of colonised Australia. This is where the first British people came to in Sydney. There are all these historical buildings. The museum is absolutely full of marine utensils and scenery there are nice pubs and around the wharf are lice restaurants. There are bikes to hire and an easy biking trail as its all flat. We walked and it took a few hours but very nice.

Love The Rocks!. I live in Sydney and I try to get to the Rocks any time I can, great restaurants and bars … but walking amongst all the old buildings, streets and laneways makes it feel like authentic Sydney.

Sydney 'On The Rocks'. I love this part of Sydney with its heritage buildings and designer shops. Some great cafe's and restaurants too as well as the iconic views over Sydney Harbour, the Harbour Bridge and Opera House. Great view points include the Observatory and one of my favourite haunts is the Lord Nelson - the oldest Hotel in Sydney.

It's like stepping back in time to see how Sydney was 200 years ago. To experience and see how Sydney was originally built before the big city skyline a visit to the rocks is worth it. Also great restaurants and great views of the Opera house and Harbour bridge. The Rocks markets are also another great reason to visit

The Rocks, so much to see and do. I love the Rocks, not only is there a lot of history but an amazing market at the weekends, a food market during the week, and a French patissiere that make the most amazing chocolate eclairs. The weekend market has a lot of locally made goods which I like, and there is something for everyone.
Cool & edgy. The Rocks area is truly a cool and edgy section of town. Lots of shops and outdoor cafes (my favorite!) in an old section of historic buildings. It sure beat downtown Sydney.
Living on the Rocks. We spent a week in a marvelous hotel in the Rocks area, Delightful, convenient and scenic. Great restaurants and the harbor ferries are just steps away.
Great place to be part of the scene in Sydney. Loved the place. It was so vibrant. Do much going on and lots of places to eat. Make sure you see it when going to Sydney
The Rocks. There's a great market on the weekend and some good pubs and entertainment. Always very good fun with many types of restrants and a nice walk around the hourber side

Lunch at the rocks. We found affordable street vendor food that was tasty and filling. The Rocks was filled with travelers from the ship that had docked for the day. Lots of character and great for people watching!

Day out. This was a very good day out with lots to see and do. Famous for its art galleries and bierkeller of which we thoroughly enjoyed with live music. much walking but so much to see they have a food market.We had to back another day as did not see all there was, we met an aboriginal musician and thought the music hypnotic so much so we bought a tape also had picture taken with him. I bought several paintings from the art gallery as i do some art work myself only an amatuere of course.

historical sydney rocks area. I love the old historical buildings, the archeological findings that can be seen by the visitor, these have been found while building new buildings. Artifacts are shown on display. You can do self guided or guided tours, local markets are usually on every Sunday. Please take your time allow 1 day to see all comfortably

The Rocks Sydney.. Love spending time at the Rocks Sydney. Every time I come to Sydney I go tothe dress shops in The Rocks area where I am sure to get something different.Lots of places to get lovely food, coffee or drinks, lunch or dinner depending what time you are there. Days the Rocks Market is on is well worth a look. Lots to see and do.
Wonderful. And on Sundays they have quality markets. Wander around this historic place which is a favourite of mine
Fantastic. Go on the weekend when the Markets are on. Lots of quirky stalls. Great pubs, sampled a few (quite a few). Lots of history

The Rocks Rox!. It is as much history that Australia has to offer, and on the whole is very well retained right in the heart of Sydney. Don't miss the chance for lunch at the highest point on the roof top of The Glenmore Pub.
Sydney Rocks venues. Sydney Rocks on a sunny day just amazing, lots of atmosphere. Plenty of places to eat or drink and entertainment. Rocks markets on the weekends with lots of Australian product.

charming and genuine. Many restaurants, art galleries, The Museum of Contemporary Art, walk the quay and even catch aferry.Walk up a few blocks from the Quay and find a great restaurant named Mr. Wong!!!. Very busy always, Arrive as it opens

Little Gem. Lovely old area in the shadow of the "Bridge". Over 100 sites and heritage buildings with Cadman's Cottage (albeit small) a must as it is one of only a handful of buildings to remain from the first decades of the colony. Lovely old pubs and some top notch restaurants that you will need to book ahead to get the best table/views. Some are rather expensive but you are dining in some of the countries best eateries in beautiful surrounds. Some good hotels here too but costs can get a bit steep (location) so check out "specials". Great area to walk around day or night and to dine at an outdoor setting on the pavement is a must - a terrific way to get the vibe of this great city. Some good galleries here; including Aboriginal art. Bridge climbs can be organised from here too - dawn, dusk and day hikes offer panoramic views of the city/harbour (if you're up for it). Many houses/shops were lost with the construction of the Harbour Bridge and Cahill's Expressway so it is interesting to wander around here and imagine life pre those days. Ghost tours available too, if that's your thing.
time warp....in a fun way. great to have so much history right by the harbourgreat food ,so many optionsgreat pubs....phillips foote a mustso much history,very clean & tidy

Weekend at The Rocks. So much going on, street threatre, fantastic markets, amazing buskers, historic walks and quirky museums (Susanna Place old style shop particularly interesting) pubs that brew their own beer on the premises, loads of cafes & street food vendors.We had a great family day.

Historic buildings of times past. When visiting Sydney, it is always a treat to visit the Rocks area. There are many historic buildings to appreciate for their architecture, along with an interesting shopping precinct with various types of merchandise for sale, and at the weekends there are the craft markets, and on the day we visited during the week, there was a food market in the precinct selling various taste treats from many vendors. The Rocks is situated in close proximity to Circular Quay railway station and, of course, the ferries which go to various parts of Sydney. It is easy walking to explore the various tourists destinations and you can meander along under the harbor bridge.

A little taste of Sydney's birthplace. A great venue for first time visitors to stroll around the area, climb the SydneybHarbour Brudge, soak up the atmosphere of one of the many cruise ships calling into Sydney during the season or enjoy the weekend markets

Architecture. Some of the buildings here are old and magnificent and you can do your own guided walk with an ipad. The market is quite extensive and I guess it's what a lot of people go there for but I was happy just gazing at the architecture.

Love The Rocks. Best pubs in Sydney are found at The Rocks. Great markets on the weekend with such different food all cooked in front of you. Also good for unique souvenirs rather than the mass produced stuff at The Quay. All with great views.
Locally and Internationally, worth a visit.. The Rocks has a lot to offer, cafés, all categories of shopping, restaurants, pubs, places of interest and sights, all on one infamous strip.
Lots to do and see!. I have a really great time on The Rocks... it is close to everything, and has an amazing array of food and things to do.Stunning views of, and from, The Rocks.

Must do......... You must do a couple of days at the Rocks. With in walking distance to everything ie Harbour Bridge Climb, Susannah Place Trust Houses ( a must see through times of the past living).In winter you can stay at the Rocks and walk around the Vivid Light Festival. We go every year.Grab a couple of friends or a weekend away or a family day out. My girlfriends and I go into the Rocks for a girly weekend every year, close to great pubs or restaurants. You can just grab some chips and sit down at the Quay and watch the Ferries and trains come in and go out again.There is always entertainment.

The original Sydney town. If visiting Sydney, The Rocks are a must. The secret is to do your homework as there are self guided tours which will help you visit many of the hidden gems in the back lanes. Aim to do this in the morning so you have the rest of the day to explore. Remember to wear a good pair of walking shoes as a number of the lanes ways and roads are cobbled. The markets are fantastic as well with the foodies market on a Friday from 9am to 3pm and the craft markets on Saturday and Sunday from 10am to 5pm. There are a number of great watering holes as well with my favourite being the Harbourview sitting in the shade of the harbour Bridge. Pull up a seat on the upper deck and watch the people exploring the bridge on the BridgeClimb

Playing make-believe. Did you ever wile away the hours as a kid playing make believe? I know I did, in fact on occasion, unbeknownst to my psychologist I still do. But when I get around pretending to be a late 30's billionaire who, as luck would have it, stumbled across his ever increasing fortune overnight, I can't say I pretend that I own an entire city. But on any number of my very late night power walks around inner city Sydney, that is literally how I feel, like the man who owns Sydney. This is never more so than when I make it the 3km from my place to the Rocks. Catch it at the right hour on the right night/s of the week and the sheer wealth of history, the mishmash of settlement era workers cottages mixed with some of the city's most stunning hotels, all squeezed together on a relatively tiny chunk of land, smack bang underneath one of the most recognizable landmarks on earth, the imposing harbor bridge, is nothing short of magical. Now while many locals and visitors clamber to the area for the vibe and pace of night (and day) life, especially as a glamorous vantage point for so many annual festivals & events, I favor the Rocks when there is absolutely nothing on, when all I can hear are empty chips packets and discarded newspapers being blown down the streets and alleyways by the soothing harbor breeze, when I am truly alone with my city. On some nights it's as if the Bridge too is deserted of the typical non-stop moan of traffic heading back and forth and back and forth. I love the fact that my city is a city that does sleep, because on the nights she does, as I slowly make my way through the cobbled lane ways and side streets, under the bridge, along the wharf, if I listen very closely, I can nearly hear the steam engines and horse drawn carriages, the whips being cracked, and the street markets of 200 years ago. That was of course long before her title was transferred to my holding company in the Cayman Islands for taxation purposes.
History revealed. Beautiful harbourside heritage area, lovely to stroll around, explore the laneways, the convict built buildings, the harbour views and the many cafes.

The Rocks.- What a wonderful experience.. The Rocks is the place that Sydney was born, this iconic area is one place that all visitors to Sydney must spend time in..Restaurants a plenty, and there is one particularly restaurant I can recommend it is "The Waterfront" located in the Rocks and in one of Sydney's oldest buildings the "Old Campbell's Warehouse", with probably one of the most spectacular views in the world, the famous Sydney Harbour Bridge on one side and Sydney Opera House on the other, also with views all the way down Sydney Harbour,There are many unique shops to visit as well, and each weekend you have the famous "Rocks Markets" So do yourself a favour come visit this wonderful City you will be amazed at what you will find.I can also recommend the "Old Sydney Holiday Inn", a great Hotel located right in the middle of the Rocks area.

Weting your thgurst. The Rocks is a a great area to see the sites of the harbour some of the historical sites and in-between the history stop of at the historical watering holes that populate the Rocks, The Lord Nelson The Mercantile and The Heritage just to name a few. And if you are around on the weekend there is a great street market that will occupy your time for a couple of hours
A bit of history. Great place to experiment with your family and enjoy some historical sites, museums and restaurants,
Amazing. Best place to stay and eat in Sydney! So many things to do and all main attractions not to far away. Every time I visit this place I fall in love all over again

An interessting week-end market. The week-end market on the street is a very interesting place for shopping for souvenirs and artefacts. you can watch artists performing and buy out of the way art and craft items, while you eat on the go or sit down for a drink at a restaurant with in the market.

Something for Everyone. The Rocks has something for everyone in the family and the business visitor also. Excellent restaurant's throughout, great Pubs with value meals and live music, tourist gift shops and weekend markets. The history walks take you to the earliest times of Sydney settlement and through some of the more poignant moments in Australia's growth. Hidden away little gems for a, bigger and better, value breakfast than the hotels are scattered throughout, for example the Bakers Oven. The views during the day or night are excellent and well serviced by public transport. A not to miss spot on your visit to Sydney.

Amazing restaurants, breathtaking views coupled with cobble stone laneways, truly unique. Sydney's The Rocks are a must see for any visitor to this great city. Take a walk over from the Opera House, along the waters edge, through Circular Quay and past the Museum of Contemporary Arts and take a walk through cobble stone lanes. Enjoy the markets, the fab cuisine or a refreshing beverage at many cafes and restaurants, or have a boogie at the popular night spots!
Great place to live.. Close to CBD but far enough away to skip heavy traffic or congestion. Always a festival around the corner. Fireworks all the time.

Intersting. We stayed near by for only 1 night and walked around in the evening. There are lots of different eating places, some with live music. Being next to the harbour added to making the stroll worthwhile.

Explore!!. As a Sydney sider, we often do not venture too far outside our own area ! I recently attended a hens day and it was an activity called the Amazing Race, where by you went in a group and completed challenges around the Rocks area. It took you to backstreets, alleys, old convict buildings and pubs, all having history plaques along the way to just let you know where you were standing that over 200 years ago it was either a hospital, a bakery etc., Sydney is built on sandstone and it has worn the test of time. You can see some old buildings that harbor some great little restaurants, galleries, etc., The Rocks Markets are an abundance of local talent and offer great souvenirs or artefacts, not available in retail stores. If you come to Sydney - spend a day or more exploring our wonderful city! and if you live here - get out and do it too!
Excellent Markets. The Rocks markets are amazing and full of all sorts of arts and crafts.This is a great place to explore on the weekend and pick up something special.

A piece of history. Always enjoy a walk down to The Rocks. The many narrow streets and historic buildings are not to be missed. There are many cafes in the vicinity and it is just a walk away from Circular Quay if you want to jump on a train or ferry.
The Rock, what a fun area. The Rocks area is not to be missed. Within this area is lots of history, Visitors Center, shops with art of the Aborigines, restaurants, pubs, Hop on-Hop off bus stops.

Atmospheric. Retains a certain magic of the original settlers.One can imagine walking the narrow streets as a pioneer (or convict).Great place to visit in one of the Most Iconic Cities in the world.Best to go on a Sunday when there is Craft Fair in the morning.

Go back in time to Sydney's beginning.. The Rocks is very special to Sydney as most of it is convict built and shows how the original European settlers lived. It was rough compared to how we live but it shows the fortitude of the men and women of the time. Great food and entertainment at night and during the day... treat yourself.

A Happenning Place. The Rocks is quite entertaining and just seeing how its was blasted out of the rocks is interesting. We had taken a harbor cruise that left from Darling Harbour. Our group leader got the captain to drop us at Circular Quay so we could visit The Rocks and not return to Darling. Lots of restaurants and shops to browse and of course people watching. There are outdoor markets there on certain days although we were unable to see them.
Trendy area. The Rocks is a trendy little area with shopping, restaurants, nightlife. Very clean and felt very safe walking around at midnight.

Pay the price for nice. Great location and marketed to the hilt but felt something was missing, and it was high ticket items . Nice to browse but felt a little unwelcome if I did didn't purchase at every shop. Still would go back at a later date for the views and the vibe.

A happening place!. The Rocks , especially in the evenings represents a great place to be. Lots of people, great restaurants, pubs, coffee shops, shops and a joyous friendly atmosphere.Eat at any of the places but for great steaks etc. Go to CUT. Super food and drinks.On the weekends there is a great flea market ,with many reasonably priced goodies to buy.

Radical Rocks!. Having no previous experience in Sydney, we were fortunate to book The Russell Hotel in the Rocks. What a fun place to see old and new Sydney! Our trip coincided with Australia Day which, despite the rain was great! Lots of activities - bike race, the green, markets, music and fireworks!

Rendezvous Hotel at the Rocks Sydney. Nice hotel in the middle of the Rocks in Sydney, AU A little pricey, but in line with all the other choices. Friendly and attentive staff. Conveniently located to the Sydney Harbor, just two blocks from the Cruise ship terminal. 100 meters from Daniels Coffee Shop, the best coffee shop in Sydney.

Great market. We visited at the weekend when the market was on and spent about an hour wandering around the stalls and the shops on the edges of the market. The market has a good selection of different stalls and is a genuine craft market with individual stalls selling a range of different products. Not like some markets which have the same six or seven stalls repeated over and over.It's a nice part of the city to look around and has a few of the older buildings worth seeing in the area.

Interesting and historic area. I stayed in this area. It was a great base for the Opera House and Bridge but also a really interesting place to explore in its own right for those interested in architecture (which I am). If I go back I'll will stay in here again. Felt very safe at night too.

Nice wares but expensive. The rocks market is nice to walk around and has lots of handmade items for sale. Everything was fairly highly prices but that didnt stop us buying a few things there as we liked them so much. Something nice to do on Saturday morning.

Historic as well as hip.... Historic area that's been gentrified with restaurants, cafes, small shops and galleries.Browse the Internet or look at some of the signs to learn the history of this neighborhood.A nice mix of cruise ship people & other tourists, area hipsters & other locals.Clean-Safe-Comfortable-Stylish. Weekends have a flea-art-handcrafts market good for both locals and tourists.The food stands are really good...but then I love food trucks and food stands.Gotta visit the Rocks neighborhood. It gives a nice balance to the skyscrapers!

Saturday morning market is quite fun. Not the typical junk of a flea market, this Saturday treat has well made unique goods. Wander the many stalls and you can tell there are hand made finds. Jewelry was great, some art for the home, spices and food stuffs, clothing that's different, and great places to catch a bite along the way.
Love The Rocks. Great food, markets, awesome shops, history. Too much fun. Loved the food, hated the sudden downpour!

old sydney. You step back in time when you visit this part of Sydney, History is all around you, the sandstone is amazing and its hard to believe that is was such a poor and desolated part of Sydney then and one of the most expensive parts now Visiting the Rocks today the great eateries, all the tourist sights easy assess to the CBD come and have a look you will be impressed

Nice Roadside Market. The Rocks has very nice road side market mostly on weekends. There are good things for shopping if your a person who ventures and like different things. One shop was amazing watches made of Bamboo so light weight. I could not get what I was looking though.
Interesting. Go at the weekend as there is markets on then. Expensive some of the stalls but interesting. Visited one of the oldest houses on the site and also a museum. The area is worth a visit.
Great food and scenery. We liked a very nice Pancake shop near the waterfront.Great walking around the harbour although lots of people it was fun watching very thing, loved it.

Historic area that has been upgraded. A historic area with a large number of buildings from the early days of Sydney. Most buildings have been renovated and you will find signs here and there informing you about the original function. The area is full of pubs, bars, restaurants as well as a number of small shops. During the weekend there is a market with a lot of activity. A tourist trap to some extent but also an area worth visiting. Close to the Harbour Bridge, The Museum of Modern Art and the Quay.
Street life of Sydney. Cafes, bars, restaurants, ethnic mix, fun street market, the usual tourist fare but good. The Rocks is pretty muchwhere the modern Australia we know today started.

A great day out. As a child I always loved a day out in The Rocks & still enjoy this area. There are many great restaurants, shops & galleries to visit. I recently found a gorgeous Gallery which displays beautiful handicrafts from a group of very talented Australians. It is located at 104 George St & is a must see for tourists wanting to purchase a memory of our beautiful country. From the ferry terminal you are able to catch a ferry to many beautiful destinations including Taronga Zoo & Manly Beach. A fantastic place for a day out with the kids. On a recent visit I got a great pic of the Harbour Bridge & went home & painted it. Beautiful place!

This was my favorite area of Sydney!. Very quaint, European, great restaurants and shopping! Away from the hustle and bustle of the city environment. Much outdoor restaurant seating with attentive wait staff. I loved it! My favorite place in the city!

So much to do - a must see. There are so many things to do here. Many restaurants (Aria has fine dining near the Opera House), boat excusions leave from here, there are also many outside dining selections with a more casual feel. The Botanical Gardens are delight to visit and is a perfect place to run or walk and is right there too. Shopping is just a block or two away as are small wine bars and eateries. The Rocks is the place to be while visiting Sydney if you want alot of things close to you well within walking distance.

Interesting old (still) residential area. An intesrting area practically under the Harbour Bridge. If you visit on a Sunday you also get bonus of the busy craft market. The old houses here are quite unlike anything we have in England but are typical of their time & all still occupied so not a museum piece..

Great history. If you've only a couple of hours in Sydney I'd stick to the Rocks and Harbour. There is real history at the Rocks, and the place tells a great story about the early settlers. Plenty of bars and eateries too - then wander round the corner and you're on the quayside looking at the Bridge and Opera House.
buy stuff. love the rocks as this is the best place for food and to buy nick knacks.everytime i have visited this place i end up shopping like crazy.just luv it .my fav haunt

Busy fun area. We always stay close to The Rocks when we are in Sydney. There's lots happening in this area. Near Circular Quay there is a wide variety of restaurants for breakfast, lunch, and dinner. The ferries leave from this area. They go many different places so it's a handy place to be able to walk to. From The Rocks you can walk into downtown Sydney with all its bustle and entertainment.

Interesting.. Friends raved about this area so expectations were raised and not met. It is a historic area but essentially a tourist spot with bars (including a Lowenbrau bierkeller),restaurants and shops selling upmarket souvenirs close to the cruise liner terminal and Circular Quay.
Great to explore. The area is clean, has lots of restaurants and side streets to explore. Great to just wander round and see what you find

Sydney's birthplace. The Rocks are really the heart of Sydney and a walk about through the histrorical streets give a little feeling to the past. This is where England placed their problem of criminality, and it did a lot of good to Australia, new start right here after they did their time.
Sydney History. Always come to The Rocks when I visit Sydney. Has my favourite pub in Sydney (The Lord Nelson).Good street market and plenty of places to eat.

Hidden treasure. My husband and I were just exploring Sydney and came upon The Rocks. We had not read anything about it and thought it was, in fact, some rocks. First of all, it is a very unique part of the Sydney with many wonderful and diverse shops. The very best part for us is when we happened upon The Rocks Museum. It's free. If anyone goes to Sydney and does not visit this museum, they will not have a true feeling for this great city and its history. We found a shop where the owner just makes jewelry out of old watches. The pieces are amazing and of course we bought one for a gift. The Rocks should be at the top of everyone's "go to" list.

Quaint and historical. Loved the cobblestone streets. Good variety of places that to eat and shop. Very easy to reach from Circular Key. Refreshing to be in somewhere genuinely old. Plenty of museums to help you to begin to understand the area. Tourist Information is exceptionally good.
historic past. LOVED this area it just reaks of sydneys past marvelous sandstone bldgs,and cute pubs,great weekend markets,plenty of atmosphere,totally recommend
Great Markets. Go there on a Friday or Saturday and check out the numerous markets. I guarantee you will find something you like. Arts and crafts food ect.
Great area. Spent a few hours wondering around this area. There are some great little quirky shops and fab restaurants.

Great neigburhood..... We stayed in a hostel on The Rocks, and we were very pleased with the area. It offers all the services that you ask for and besides that a part of Sydney's history.
There is a market in the weekends and nice bars to visit as well.

Went on a Saturday for the Flea market. Made up of an L shaped street with about 30-40 stalls selling handcrafted stuff from Australia.
Interesting but many of the hand made items are high priced.
Do walk down to the harbour to get a good view of circular quay and other areas.
Beautiful spots for coffee and cakes around the Rocks.

The Rocks Foodies Market. If you are in town on a Friday (9AM - 3PM), be sure to drop by the Rocks Market at George St and get yourselves a Wagyu burger from The Fine Food Store. There is a row of interesting food finds.

Great for Special Souvenirs. We were in this area on a Sunday and there was an additional street market going on. If I'm not mistaken this happens every Sunday. We got a lot of great souvenirs that aren't your typical Australia souvenir. There are also a lot of quirky shops on the street and it's generally an interesting area to stroll through.

History of Old Sydney comes to life.. We enjoyed our walk around this historical area, discovering quaint laneways, old restored buildings, statues, historical markers and lovely old worn stone stairs. We had lunch at one of the cafes and stumbled across the Rocks discovery museum which was free of charge and very informative.We loved seeing the beautiful cruise ships and happy tourists, all milling around with excitement, it gives the area life and purpose.TIP-Next time you board a cruise from the Passenger Terminal, check in and dump your bags in your cabin as soon as possible, and make your way back down to the rocks area nearby for great photos and exploring!
interesting area of the city. It is a great area to explore. I ate at one of the restaurants (poor choice unfortunately) but there are many to choose from. The Contemporary Art Museum is fantastic.
Historic. The history of the rocks is great. We always enjoy the shopping and dining especially when we are staying by the quay......very convenient.

Nice area of Sidney.. We enjoyed walking in the Rocks. It is a shame that the huge ugly cruise ship blocked the view for blocks! I imagine the view used to be gorgeous. The restaurants and shops were very nice.
brilliant. great area to stay in loved the bars and nightlife, the hotel we stayed in was very central to everything
Inspiring evening walk.... Great place to wander and check out some history. This area has been nicely restored and offers plenty of places to grab a good meal.
Cute. Cute little place with lots of trendy restaurants and pubs. The markets are fun and the Ugg store is spectacular with many different limited edition pairs to buy

Like old town Sydney. Great art galleries, eateries, bars and great views of both harbour bridge and opera house, well worth a visit or two. You will probably see a cruise ship in dock. Well worth a long day out here.
Good variety of shops. Weekend visit early February was reasonably quiet. We found a good variety of shops with some unique but pricey goods.

Fun Shopping and People Watching. There are so many people from all over the world who visit Sydney. The Rocks is a great place to grab a bite to eat, do a little shopping, and people watch! You can also, cop-a-squat in the park area under a tree or in the sun and watch the boats and ships go in an out of the harbor.

new life in the old dog. We just love this area, from old historic buildings, houses that look so from any century and still being used to the art galleries and boutique shops, around every corner is another experience. The weekly market is just great fun, with many attractive stalls The old pubs and restaurants serve fantastic array of beers and food.
