Love this area. We loved this area of Sydney. Our hotel was located here and we had so many bars and restaurants located close by. There really is something for everyone here and located right next to circular quay and the main overseas passenger terminal.

Walking area with history near the bridge. This quaint area has some great small shops ,arcades and restaurants mixed in with the history of the old city.
However, when cruises are in port it can get very crowded.

Lots amazing handmade crafts. I have to say that after visited many markets around AU, this one is my favorite! Still regretting that I didnt buy those clocks and cheese plates made from beer bottles and mini leather cover journal necklaces ... hopefully I will visit the rocks again soon
Great little spot. Lovely area to explore and get a great feeling of Sydney. Lots of nice restaurants and pubs, open air markets, circular quay and good hotels.

Historic place to visit. Very nice place to visit, right near circular Quay. Try and take one of the organised walking tours to learn a lot more about the very historic area. Weelkends are great for the markets, with food and trinkets, prints etc all available to purchase. Plenty of restaurants also

Great market and exploring!. I loved this area of Sydney. The cobblestone streets and cool little shops. So much to explore. There are also many quaint restaurants. My favorite was the large outdoor market. Great place to pick up some souvenirs. The Rocks had a totally different vibe than the rest of Sydney, definitely check it out!

Fun. Yes, this is touristy but it is a wonderful place to visit and spend an afternoon. Historic location. Wonderful pubs and restaurants. We had no complaints although it was crowded. Definitely a must see in the Sydney area.
Great place to base yourself in Sydney. First time in Sydney and the Rocks was a good choice for me and I would think any other visitor might have in mind while on vacation
touristy buy nice. Lot's of restaurants and shops, usually lots of activity. Only down side is it was tough to determine when things would be open or closed. Logic of business hours escaped us.

Wonderful history. We live here and love it with its choice of restaurants, specialty shops, markets and points of interest. We have the most fabulous views of the world's most beautiful harbour. The only pity is the number of cruise ships in Summer which sometimes partially interfere with our view of the Opera house.

Packed with history. There's always plenty going on at The Rocks on a Sunday with the market and the musicians but don't forget to look up and down all the alleys and side roads and the place is so full of history. The market never disappoints and if full of interesting stalls for everyone.
history. this is a great place to visit, one of the few places you can find some history, the bars are full of character and some lovely places to eat
Delightful to walk round - stop and have a coffee/lunch/dinner?. Lovely setting and full of lovely artisan restaurants and interesting shops. Definitely worth a visit.

Old town spruced up to the nines. Every where has one, that old part of town where it all began all those years ago and now has become a main tourist environment.Absolutely nothing wrong with that and worth a browse around just to get a feel of the place especially with its juxtaposition to cruise terminal and skyscraper buildings.

Excellent Shopping and Dining. A very historic part of town with many great pubs, restaurants and shops. It is adjacent to the Overseas Passenger Terminal and the location where you enter the Harbour Bridge Climb.
Nice part of the city. This area is pretty cool to walk around it has loads of character and plenty to see and do. Good pubs and eateries around this area too worth checking out.

Worth the visit.. This area is well worth wandering around. The many little streets, stairways( some very old - like walking ON History) were fascinating.the markets themselves are full of interesting people and stalls- very colourful.Plenty of art galleries to wander around, excellent placesto eat in and also to sit and enjoy the view of the Bridge, Opera House and that magnificent harbour. Go and wander....
The Rocks Area of Sydney. A truly lovely area to visit, but go during the early or mid day while the market is still open. Historic old buildings and many nice restaurants in the area.

Interesting with lots of history. We walked through this area which was where the convicts first came to Sydney and literally build the area up. There is a Big Dig going on to provide historical information on the area. There are plenty of places to eat and drink and close to the center of the city - at least close to the Four Seasons Hotel. The area is hilly with a lot of steps and close to the Harbor Bridge - a great place to walk and look at the city. The Rocks is a definite area to check out during the day or evening.
Nice area for shopping. Nice area for shopping around and going out eating and drinking, I tried my first crocodile burger ! it was good

Variety. This place is fantastic. It has a huge choice of shops, restaurants and bars. It beholds a very distinctive history of through-out the 1800's of being the renowned hang-out of criminals and outlaws. The architecture makes you feel like you're in a Spanish or French town, clade with sandstone and terracota colours.It has a wonderful atmosphere, mainly family orientated with no sign of trouble. Try and visit the market on a Saturday and you'll be spoiled for choice with the eateries and stalls for your shopping pleasure.

Give it a go but take a guide book. There is so much history in this old part of town that it could be easily missed. The city has done a great job of placing placards describing life in the early days of Sydney. There are some fun cafes and bars scattered along the way.
old world charm. really enjoyed the old world charm and heritage of the buildings. Lots of lovely shops and the markets were on whilst I was there. The rocks had a lovely atmosphere.

Great area for mooching about. Theres loads of history around here as it was the original settlement area but it has been re vamped and the cafe vibe is great. Just stroll around take the little alleyways and stop at the numerous cafes great fun
So much to see!. We spent a whole day here in the museum, pubs and galleries. It gave us an insight into historic Sydney and didn't get to see everything. Must come back!

OK to Walk Around. The Rocks has an interesting history (recommend the Free Walking tour), but the roads as twisty and the only things to really do are to stop at restaurants or bars. Worth a quick tour.
Great markets. If you get to Sydney on a Sat or Sun visit the Rocks market. It is such a lovely part of the city and historic. The stalls are wonderful with lots of choices and very talented people.

Underwhelmed. A great location close to Circular Quay but maybe we expected something better. The area has history and some interesting looking buildings but there are better museums in the City and in parts it is a little seedy There are lots of shops.

Try to get there at the weekend. Place is buzzing every day of the week but even more so at the weekends when the market is in town
A bit touristy but hey, we were tourists!

Beautiful part of Sydney, full of historic architecture!. The Rocks was fantastic, Sydney feels very much like a modern city but the rocks areas felt like a different time. Lots of historic pubs, tea places and cafes scattered through cobblestone laneways... Highly recommend going on Friday (foodie market) and Saturday (tourist, craft market) really full of life highly recommended!!
History. The history of The Rocks, the age of the buildings the ambiance of the town make for a lovely stroll through there.

A bustling place full of atmosphere and history. This major tourist destination is full of shops, restaurants and cafes. Even so, the atmosphere of the past is not lost and it is possible to imagine what it would have been like to live in the Rocks a hundred or more years ago. By following a walking map, it is possible to get a full sense of the history of the place and also to view old buildings and important historical sites.

Full of history, charm, and interest. The Rocks area of Sydney is a hive of restaurants, cafes, shops, markets, and other places of interest - there is something here for everyone to enjoy.Admittedly it is quite touristy, but there is still plenty to enjoy.A definite must to get a proper background on the place is The Rocks Discovery Museum - this is a small (and free) museum full of the history of Sydney's founding and you can easily do this museum justice in under an hour.Highly recommended for pleasurable wanderings.
Old part of town.. Get to see how Sydney started. Some nice old structures and many nooks and crannys to discover and get lost. A new place around each corner.

Best place to stay in Sydney. This is where Sydney began, and today most of what is going on happens here or can be easily reached from here. It is especially impressive on a holiday, like Australia Day.

Still lots to see.. As well as the old buildings and alley ways. There are numerous shops that cater for most tourists. There is a weekend market that covers a fair amount of area. The prices are a little steep compared to the rest of Sydney, but that is the area.

Old Sydney must do, filled with pricey tourist traps!. The Rocks is an old worldly historical part of Sydney. And well worth a look if it's your first time to Sydney. It has some gems for expensive tourist goods (like opals, akubras and that sort of thing). It also has some super uber cool great bars/restaurants as you walk around. It has an old feel, that reflects the Australian colonial past. A must do for tourists in town. It has some little gems in it, if you know where to go. Well worth a look, and a must do if you're new to Sydney.
Great place to see. Lots of history attached to this place lots of Irish history enjoyed our visit here again would go back if I visit Sydney again which I will !!

The soul of Sydney. If you'd like to get a taste of the origins of Sydney, then head to The Rocks. These days, you'll find designer shops and high class restaurants but if you care to dig deeper, you'll find a taste of Sydney's origins.The architecture in the Rocks, dominated by sandstone, generally remains intact and well kept. Head for one of the many pubs along George St if you'd like a cold beer in some very original housing (my favourites are the Mercantile or the Australian for some old Australian charm). If you head off George St, visit the Lord Nelson which is Australia's oldest pub and still brews some fantastic beers, sold across Sydney.For dining, you can't go past the entertainment block owned by the one consortium on Argyle. Our personal favourites are Sake and Cut but the open courtyard bar in Anannas is great on a summer evening.The best activities, outside of climbing the bridge if you haven't done that before, is a leisurely stroll around the markets, held in the weekend and mostly Sundays, when they close a part of George St off.

Coming to the rocks ?. U would do yourself a massive injustice if u did not book yourself onto one of there fantastic nightly ghost tours. The tour hosts r exceptional and though they cannot guarantee ghostly sightings there vast amount of local history will have u seeking more

Best part of Sydney!. I wouldn't consider staying anywhere else in Sydney. The hotels are small and cozy on cobblestone streets, and we were able to walk easily to the Circular Quay and across the Harbour Bridge. If you appreciate historical places, this is the place to be.

A big tourist trap. Ok there are some histical buildings but that is it. Restaurants are overpriced, food is below average and drinks are ridicilously high.the weekend market stalls charge 50 percent more than any shop in the city.And this must be the only place where aussies throw out the work politenes.
Great Atmosphere. We went to the rocks markets and the rocks Museum. Definitely worth a visit it had a great atmosphere.

Enjoy exploring the Rocks. This was our second visit to Sydney. We had a great time exploring this area of the city again. So many lovely historical buildings, a very impressive restoration project. Lots of little side streets to explore.

My favourite area of Sydney. This is a must if you're visiting Sydney it's a really interesting area to walk round with lots of history attached to it. There's loads of great restaurants & a market every Saturday.
Oldie worldy. Worth a look round,old shops and houses and some interesting reading on the history of Australia on statues and monuments .

Great place to explore.. There always seems to be something new to explore when you visit the Rocks... whether it's finding new water holes or old ones or cafes for coffee, there seems to be something for everyone. Perfect for sitting back with a drink and people watching....
Changed a lot. Most of the quaint little shops that used to be there have all gone. I guess the rents have gone up a lot and driven them out. Mainly bars and cafes now but still worth a look.

Great place to walk and people watch. I love this area of Sydney. It is a great mix of "old" Sydney, giving it a historical feel, chic shopping, dining and entertainment - all within eye sight of the Harbour Bridge and Circular Quay. I think the best time to wander around this scenic area is around sunset, as the air cools off and the night picks up. I highly recommend several restaurants in the area (Sailor Thai, The Cut, just to name two).

Something to see. A good place with old vibe. It's nice to see a bit of history amidst different kinds of restaurants around it. Some restaurants are quite pricey but you cannot argue with that having such amazing view of the harbour.
Very quaint. We walked around Rocks that was very nice. Expensive to eat and nice photos of harbour. Recommend to visit.

The Rocks Markets is a Must do. The Rocks Markets, held on the weekends, and the The Rocks Foodie Market on Fridays are a fun way to explore the very best of The Rocks. Follow cobblestone pathways and tented avenues of wonderful stalls selling anything from artisan jewellery and clothing, adorable dog collars, all things Australiana and delicious treats. A perfect spot for tourists, both international and local to find that special gift or souvenir, its simply a great place to enjoy its energetic atmosphere, have fun, be curious and find something nice, unique or even unusual. While there, its a great chance to check out the arcades nearby, with souvenir stores, boutiques and art galleries to find even more unique items to take home. With plenty of cafes, restaraunts and food stalls offering great places to sit, have coffee and enjoy a snack or meal. As a chocolate lover, I enjoyed the Guylian Café where I had a lovely hot chocolate and an éclair. I've also tried the French bistro Baroque and Le Pain Quotadien for breakfast, which were both nice and relaxing with good food. Lowenbrau's is a meat lovers paradise and perfect for a hearty and fun lunch. For the markets, food outlets and stores, prices vary from the very reasonable to the ridiculous, and depending on what you're looking for, you're sure to find something to suit your budget. Overall I love coming to The Rocks Markets. Whether you're a tourist or a local, a newbie or a seasoned stall browser, its a wonderful place to vist or revisit again and again. It's a fun day out and walking down to Circular Quay to see our stunning harbour is a great way to enjoy Sydney at its best.

human scale part of Sydney. There are not so many things that a European will like in Sydney, but this neighborhood one should enjoy. It is calm, I would say even cosy, and it is very pleasant to just have a walk over there.

Go outside busiest periods- & try to be here for the market. The Rocks are great to visit. I was here on my own years ago and loved the market- lovely unique items and an amazing atmosphere. It is quaint but not twee, thank goodness.Sadly, this year we came at the busiest time and it has a very different feel at NYE time- you cannot get in anywhere leading up to the big day and we missed the market.It's still lovely, but come here outside the crazy busy time and for the weekend to potter around the market- I will come back and take my own advice, especially after bragging about it to hubbie! It is still good to stroll through, which we did.

Typical tourist area where cruise ships dock or like any big city. South Street station, Pier 39, Navy Pier... now you know what the rocks are. Nice area, pleasant enough. Smaller than the aforementioned places but, nice boutiques, old pubs, some good restaurants, some history. Mostly touristy. Then again, we ate here three times as it was a simple walk from the hotel and cruisers do not eat while in port given all the food on bord.

Historic and great place to eat.. Great place to eat and the view of the bridge and opera house is amazing from here. if food or shopping is your thing then this place is the place to be. We took the guided walk and the history of this place is

Restaurants galore. It's beautiful to go somewhere and have so many options of dining. The views are fantastic although most of the restaurants are actually on a slant so do keep that in mind if you prefer level dining. Also do yourself a favour and check if there is a cruise ship in town this will not only increase how busy it is but block most of your view.

A walk back into Sydney's history. The Rocks offer a glimpse into Sydney past. Wonderful Sydney sandstone buildings, walls and stairs set the mind wandering while one contemplates the conditions under which they were built more than 200 years ago. Lots of food on offer from coffee shops, restaurants, tea houses or pubs and even more if you visit the weekend markets where you can buy some great food or a genuine Australian souvenir.

Gorgeous. We visited the rocks on a Saturday when the markets were in full swing. Loved the markets lots to see, some beautiful unique stalls. Loved the atmosphere of this area very relaxing packed with history. A must see
Many unique shops. A heritage spot that Sydney has to offer, it has nice cafe with good view of Sydney's bridge and Opera House. Very nice to have a lazy day...
A pleasant place to while away an hour. A great place to walk around n the evenibg, lots of resturants bars and shops, always busy especially when a cruise ship is inA Sydney must do
great for history. The Rocks is a very colourful and vibrant place. Full of history and plenty of pubs to visit and also some nice eateries.They have good markets there of a weekend

Must be seen to be believed. This area is steeped in history. If you have time, do a tour, you wont be disappointed. I believe there is even a ghost tour. My experience is a slow walk, strolling around the little streets with the beautiful sandstone buildings. Down the alleys, stopping for a coffee or lunch. Take yourself there on Saturday or Sunday morning and look at the market stalls. Walk down to Circular Quay you may be lucky enough to see a cruise liner in for the day, it is a hive of activity. Watch the ferries as they move in and out of the busy harbour port. Take your camera because your can't fail to capture one of those special shots. Also a great place to catch a trip on the tall ships.
great urban vibe. very walkable area with lots to explore and do - restaurants , clubs cafes . lots of places to just sit and soak in the ambiance
Great for wandering and soaking up the atmosphere. Daytime or night time, both great. Good selection of bars, eateries, coffee shops. Market at weekends, easy access to harbour bridge.

Walk around the oldest part of Sydney. It is a great place to wander around and see all the old buildings which were established when Sydney was just getting started.
Lots of interesting buildings,shops and places to eat.
Youth hostel Australia (YHA) @ The Rocks. It does not matter how old you are become a member of the YHA today. This hostel has the best views of the harbour. It's cheap as well. 😀

Great for strolling!. The Rocks is a great place to stroll through as you walk around Sydney. It has a great atmosphere with the boutiques and coffee shops. As you walk further down, you get to the Harbour and the view is spectacular! A cruise ship ported, along with great weather, is a perfect photo opportunity. The Rocks is also famous for its Pancakes on the Rocks which often is jammed pack with people enjoying their pancakes. The menu has different varieties of pancakes to choose from at a mid-range price. For most places at the Rocks, the price range for lunch is reasonable as many restaurants offer lunch specials. If anything, there are many things to explore around the Rocks!

The Rocks. unusual shops to be found amongst the alleyways of the rocks, a wonderful button shop with hundreds and hundreds of unusal buttons!. Lots of bars and restaurants to choose from.The cruise ships dock here.

One of my first stops in the City. I've always travelled to Australia. I have more family there than I can count. Mostly Ex. Pats. who moved over during the recession in the 80's in view of a good life for the them and their children. But usually two days after landing or so I take the venture from the suburbs with the family into the city. Standing on the platform in Circular Quay I find myself more confident in getting around than most of the locals it would seem. So I wander up past the gallery and make a bee-line for the rocks.I've always loved markets, I've always loved good food and architecture, and that's exactly what you're greeted with here. I usually spend the best part of my first day here and just wander round and take in all that I've forgotten, then up to the Mercantile for a jar. Perhaps its the little taste of home I'm in love with, with a huge number of Irish / Celtic Shops and Pubs. It reminds me that even so far away, I'm never that far from home.
Lovely. The rocks is a great spot for a nice walk and offers many photo opportunities. The are lots of great little restaurants

Interesting. This area was very interesting, lots of historical facts about the origins of Sydney . There are nice little boutiques and coffee shops not forgetting Sydney's oldest pub the fortune of war, a great little watering hole.

Woooow. It's a little like someone's snatched bits of Paris, Lake Como, Canterbury and plonked 'em next to Sydney harbour. Gorgeous winding streets through patisseries and chic hotels, art shops, cafes, all sorts of daintily designed buildings (and curly street lamps! Who doesn't love a curly lamp?)Nice for a sunny stroll, or go see the different events like the Rocks Markets or the Smooth Festival of Chocolate and so much more

Great place. I simply loved The Rocks, I visited at least 3 times. The atmosphere was great, so much going on everyday.
All the different stalls, plenty to buy.
Lord Nelson Pub. Excellent British style pub- great atmosphere. Walk behind the bridge and around local streets was also extremely pleasant (off tourist grid) experience.

SydNYE 2015. On our first day in Sydney we walked around the Rocks.
It's a great area for seeing more traditional buildings and businesses.
Good choice of restaurants and cafés.

Lovely old part of town. Very easy walk from Circular Quay and right on the water front. Very old part of Sydney with lots of older character buildings, cafes and places to eat. Look out for the Sirius Building which was formally a social housing apartment block with million dollar views of the harbour and bridge. Built in the 1980s and originallyused for housing those requiring social housing. Really sticks out in The Rocks and is now being used for private apartments. The views from this block would be outstanding! The Rocks is a gorgeous place and very old and you can access the harbour bridge from The Rocks and walk along to Kiribilli. There is an amazing Saturday market at The Rocks with all sorts of interesting bits and pieces and gorgeous jewellery but rather expensive but quite unique!

Not what I expected. The Rocks was pleasant but not the type of area I was expecting. Loads of bars and restuarants but no atmosphere. Nice boutique shops but not many to choose from. Very good Tourist Information Office, plenty of information and helpful staff.
Full of history. Loved the rocks. When we visited they had a market on. Loads of stalls selling original wares, great to see the nurses walk. Very quaint.

Lowenbrau Keller. We arrived 5 adults 2 preschool age and 2 older children, desiring sweets for the children and drinks for the adults. Although very busy the staff were accommodating found us suitable seating inside and we had prompt service and enjoyed the whole experience. We also had 1 adult with a wheelchair and made to feel very welcome they have a portable ramp to bring to the stairs.

Nice Location. If you're in Sydney it just wouldn't be right if you didn't visit The Rocks. With it's cobbled stoned streets and plethora of shops, bars and restaurants it's the place to be. Probably the oldest area of Sydney once housing convicts, sailors and ladies of the night this has always been a busy area from one point of view or another. There is also a busy market on Saturdays.Adjacent to Circular Quay with it's own array of restaurants, shops and bars you just can't go wrong in finding something to suite your tastes.

The rocks , great place. We visited the rocks , on a number of occasions for lunch , for dinner and for drinks , it's a really interesting area , with great historical features it's a great place for strolling around , great vibe there , it's a place well worth a visit ,

stalls under cover. whether its raining or the Suns out the Rocks have you covered. Loads of stalls selling everything I don't need, at least the wife is happy! Plenty of bars for an escape beverage to ease the pain!

Take a stroll, food, drink, and prison cells.. I lived in Sydney early 2000's, and recently back from my bi-annual visit. I love the rocks area, there is various shopping. Local foods, casual or high collar eating, and history. Some of the old prison cells are open to visit, and the owners have eclectic shops in front. Its easy to spend a day here visiting all the places, and still feel you have not covered the place. On the weekend one end is closed for flea market shopping, if you have time on your trip; definitely worth a visit.

Historic and Facinating . We took the 1 & half hour walking tour (The Rocks Walking Tours ). This is the oldest part of Sydney, first settled by the British in the 1700s as a penal colony. The convicts quarried the local sandstone to build many of early properties and warehouses still standing today. It's like stepping back in time. Cobbled streets and alleys, history around every corner and some of the oldest pubs in town. Must see when in Sydney and I recommend the guided walk to get the most of your visit.

The Rocks is a unique part of the city. Indeed, this place is something completely different ... there is a special soul, peace, warmth, you can definitely nice to drink and eat, relax Seil relax after a long and exhausting working by this extraordinary city ... you absolutely must visit this place. This place I visited ten years ago and I'm sure it is not n and little has changed.

Quaint Area. My husband and I toured this area today. It wasn't quite what I was expecting but what we did see made up for it. We were there on a Saturday and there were several stalls set up as a type of farmers market. We also found indoor shopping where we were able to watch candy being made. That was fascinating to watch. There is also a jeweller in this mall which had great deals on opal jewellery as well as other items. You can find great prices on a lot of items in this area, you just have to look for them. There are a lot of restaurants here which gives you a great variety to choose from.

Quirky City Gem. We visited The Rocks food markets this evening, which was lovely. A short walk from Sydney's iconic Opera house before your surrounded by tree lined streets and market stalls. The stalls are filled with delicious food, jewellery, artwork and many other crafts. It's was absolutely brilliant and a place we will return to during our stay in Sydney. Cheap and quirky dinner out in the city.
A place to wander. The rocks is a good lace to wander around. The older part of Sydney with some character. Not a shopping centre, just an old fashioned part of the city
Go for a wander. It's an interesting area to wander around but don't expect any shopping bargains. Great roof top bar at the Glenmore pub at the top of the stairs in Argyle street.

Wonderful!!. The Rocks is an excellent spot to visit full of history and great restaurants! The Glenmore Pub rooftop bar is great fun! Also the tours that start at the Cadmans cottage are fun and free! The Holiday Inn is right in the middle of the Rocks and an awesome spot to stay! Would stay there again!!!

Old Charm. Nice old part of Sydney, lots of history and small shops in the back alley ways. A few good eats and Bars for a good night out. worth a visit if you are in the area of the Sydney Harbour Bridge.

Site of First Settlement. There is a 1-1/2 hour tour everyday at 6pm here and it's free. Just turn up in front of Cadmans Cottage. The guide will lead you on an discovery walk, showing you the historic sites of this first European settlement in Australia. There are also many interesting shops and cafes here.
A charming spot. We spent a few days in Sydney, and this was one of our favorites places to go. The old buildings, the market, and the views are fantastic.

Go to the rocks museum. Free entry into the museum and it opens up a link to our past with fascinating info on how the rocks became the birth place of our nation
Gold coin donation,
Must see if in sydney and allow at least 1.5 to 2 hrs

Must see!. Great area for a stroll, shopping and eating! Lots of choices of restaurants and stores, interesting architecture and nice atmosphere. Easy access as it only a short walk from the Opera House.

Don't miss the Sunday Market!. Interesting history of The Rocks and there are many restaurants and shops in the area. Don't miss the Sunday Market which has a lot of good things for tourists to look at and to buy.
Great Place!. The atmosphere here is lovely! It's honestly just refreshing. Especially when it's not peak season. There's a lot of good restaurants, parks, squares and places of interest to visit.
A part of town near the waterfront.... I didn't find anything special about the Rocks unless I missed something. It is near the harbor. We visited it, but was not impressed.

the rocks. We stayed in sydney before our cruise just before Christmas. We loved visiting the Rocks. There is so much to look at and we were lucky to be there when the markets were on. Its great to walk around the old area looking at the stalls and seeing what there is to buy. The old buildings in this area are just great and there is a lot of history. It's great for a history lesson for people of all ages. The Opera is not far away as is the ferries. Catching a ferry is a wonderful way to see Sydney Harbour and get a feel for Sydney.

The Rocks is Fantasic. The Rocks is very easy place to visit and enjoy and just off Sydney Harbour near the Museum , whether a couple, a family or a group of friends. Lots of restaurants, shops and pubs. The open market was something new for me and friends. This area has so many little alley ways and niches that it would take a long time to mention them. But this place is a deffo visit you will love it

Old Sydney. A taste of Old Sydney, the Rocks is where the original settlement was situated, narrow/ streets close by the coat hanger bridge and Circular Quay so a good place to be situated to get around the rest of Sydney. Quaint and old fashioned with good pubs and eateries and some hotels .

History awaits. This area has so many little alley ways and niches that it would take a long time to mention them. Take the time to get there in the morning and just meander throughout a part of Australia's history that is very unique. There are special little cafe's and tea rooms along with pubs etc. Australia's oldest pub is worth a visit. Take your time to read the plaques and stories. The rocks is only a short walk from circular quay and on weekends there are markets. Take the time to go through the antique pavilion.

Fun at The Rocks. There is so much to see and do at The Rocks- for adults and children. The Rocks Museum is free and takes you through the history of The Rocks and settlement at Sydney Cove, there are interactive activities for children to do. Lots of shops and buildings as they were during convict times. On weekends The Rocks' Markets are held up the main streets - blocked to cars so you can walk around freely and check out the artisan stalls. Lots of good souvenirs and gifts available. Heaps of cafes and hotel/pubs to cater for everyone. 10 minute walk to Circular Quay to catch a ferry, bus or train. You will always see a busker or 2 around the Quay - very entertaining. It's about a 30 min walk to the Opera House from the Rocks or if you walk 30 min the opposite way you can walk along the Harbour Bridge walkway to the Pylon Lookout. There are many hotels at the Rocks so it's very convenient to stay there and walk to many other places of interest

Iconic Sydney attraction. Very easy place to visit and enjoy, whether a couple, a family or a group of friends. Lots of restaurants, shops and pubs. The open market was something new for us and reminds us that even old favourites change when you don't live locally anymore.

Unique and cool gifts. The market is only open on Saturdays and Sundays. There are other shops in the Rocks, but it is not the same as the vendors' stalls at the market. Some of it is touristy crap, but you can find a lot of interesting jewelry and art as well as some food. I would definitely recommend going.

Good markets. The Rocks is a great place to just walk around and take in the beautiful surrounds and architecture. The markets on Sat have a great variety of crafts to purchase, but I have to say the few food stalls that are there were my favourite. A must try is the $10 wrap with chicken tikka and salad. It's huge and delicious and they also do 3 or 4 other options like meat balls, falafel etc.

Food, fun and interesting architecture. Great restaurants in this area - including delicious chocolate cafes and seafood specialists. There's a range of styles and prices and while you eat, or hunt for a T shirt, you can watch the visiting cruise ships glide in or the nightly promenade of tourists, buskers and beautiful people.

A Fantastic Weekend Destination. Need a great day out,try the Rocks in Sydney.The weekend markets have a wide variety of items while permanent specialty stores like the Tea Cosy Tea Rooms and The Irish Design Shop are great fun.There are plenty of cafe spots and I would recommend the Mercantile Hotel for lunch or drinks while you listen to the live bands.So much to do ,make a weekend of it by staying in one of the local hotels.....Fantasic fun!
Lot's to do. So much going on. Extremely clean, friendly, every day they havesomething different going on. We stay in the Rocks and it waslike being in a small friendly town.

Beautiful just for a stroll. Its an easy walk around the birthplace of Sydney, with many small great coffee houses and eateries. Walk along the foreshore , right around Circular Quay, right to Opera House, them onto the botanic gardens. All beautiful

Nice place to spend some hours.. This is really a beautiful part of Sydney, not all the highraised buildings like in Darling Harbour. It is the old part of Sydney and a lot of the old buildings are still there. Some have very nice restaurants, pubs and bars. I would say some of the best restaurants in Sydney are located here, but that is a personal opinion.Use some time and use the stairs which will give you an excellent view. The harbour is often full of visiting cruise ships!
The Rocks. Nice tourist district, shopping and lots of dining options, coffee & tea houses along the rocks below the Sydney Harbour Bridge and adjacent to Circular Quay

Loved the Rocks. This area of Sydney is delightful, full of interesting shops, bars and restaurants. The area has a very bohemian feel to it and the architecture is a real delight. Spend time walking around the streets and looking at the buildings, they are lovely and all very well preserved!!The street markets are excellent with some very interesting stalls. The Friday night os particularly good. Lots of traditional pubs around the area, all very friendly.Really enjoyed our stay in this area and will definately go back again.
A must-visit, but not impressive. Certainly a place in Sydney that deserves to be visited. Some nice architectural attributes on some houses, but overall not too impressive.

Sydney's gem. We spent a few evenings at the a Rocks. The rocks has a lot of heritage history a good time tourist information centre. Fantastic markets and street performances. Caters for all kinds of culinary tastes it is and exciting and vibrant place where all ages flock to. We loved it, one of my favourite places . You can experience a good mixture of cultures that make Australia so full of new and exciting beginnings.

Great way to start your Sydney exploration. Flanked by architecture of old rock and brick and 200+ years of history, you could easily spend days eating and sight-seeing your way around the rocks. Featuring museums, pubs, purveyors of savory pies and an endless series of cultural events, The Rocks is a destination for tourists and locals. We spent a pair of mornings amongst the food stands and artisans. A "licorice stand" manned by a charming couple who plied is with samples resulted in us leaving with a kilo of sweets (look for the passion fruit licorice, not really licorice, is pretty tasty.) Grazing for breakfast, I enjoyed a salmon kebab, lamb kebab, veggie Japanese pancake (essentially a mix of hash browns and stir-fried vegetables) and a variety of cupcakes. Look for the man selling a variety of golf-ball sized truffles wrapped in aluminum (I think he was on the corner of George and Globe Street.) Be sure to check the calendar of events for The Rocks.
Good But A Bit Tacky. The Rocks is a great place on a sunny day but it can be a little tacky. It is very much worth a visit but commercialism has made it less than the best place to visit.

Very convenient to Circular Quay. Next to Circular Quay, so it attracts the cruise ship crowd. My wife bought some locally designed and made clothes at the Saturday market and an Akubra hat at one of the shops, so that was good.The same burgers and pizzas are $5 more in The Rocks than across the road. Service was especially poor at the Orient Hotel. Asked whether they had pickles for my burger, the manager said "If it's not on the menu then we probably don't have it." While the bartender completely forgot to pour the beers we'd just ordered and paid for. But the burger was good.

Shop & Eat. My wife and I went to the rocks area on a Saturday morning. She wanted to do a little shopping. There are also a lot of restaurants in this area. I am not a shopper, so the rating is just average, but if you are a shopper, this adventure would have made you extremely happy! They had a street market on the morning we visited, and it was huge! Just when you thought you had gotten to the end, it turned and there was another block of vendors. My wife was in heaven and even though her feet were hurting from out activities of the previous 3 days, she explored every inch of the market and she did some areas twice. If possible, let the wife do this activity with a friend.

Lived in the Rocks For 2 Years. I lived in the rocks for about 2 years. I simply loved the heritage area, the old pubs and beautiful restaurants. The regular markets were a highlight of the time I spent there.Next time I visit, I definitely want to do a ghost tour. The only thing I think I missed
The Rocks Market. Went there on Saturday during our trip - fantastic market, especially liked (and loaded up on) the ceramics at a stall featuring Australiana, like the koala tea mugs we got.

Old and very interesting district of Sydney. The Rocks is a very interesting, nicely renovated old district of Sydney! A very nice place to have a walk or to go for lunch in the good looking and promising restaurants!

Old Sidney at Night. When in Sidney, must visit this spot. Brings nostalgia back especially for history buffs like me. Pier One hotel is a old fish market converted to a luxury hotel. Old pubs and antiques. At night, this place comes even more alive with pubs and music. Must visit

Quaint. We spent a full day and an evening at The Rocks. Day we spent walking around the area where there was a market which consisted mainly of local crafts (bought few items) had lunch at a Irish cafe scones freshly made - not to be missed. Evening had a meal again an Irish Hotel food excellent

A step back in time. We had a wonderful tour of the Rocks district, imagining times gone by. Sad to think that they are modernising this area which will see buildings of interest gone forever. You had better see it soon!

Shop till you drop. Just love the Rocks,plenty of lovely Resteraunts to visit, also the beautiful market stalls something for everyone,the stall holders are just so friendly,and plenty of bars to sit outside relax and have a bite to eat just perfect and in beautiful surroundings!!
Orient Hotel. Went to Orient Hotel for a couple of drinks and then Pancakes on the Rocks for dinner, It was Excellent!

Very pretty but a bit too touristy. The best side of The Rocks is on the other side of the Harbour Bridge, around Millers Point...very old streets and homes - fascinating and much quieter, good if you like history. We had a drink at a gorgeous old pub there too.

History, food and shopping. The Rocks has a charm of its own separate from this busy city. Wonderful weekend market, lots of lively restaurants and interesting shops, adjacent to the ferries at Circular Quay.

Interesting view but very commercialized. Nice historic place but it has become very commercialized . The buildings have been refurbished but to me it js nothing more than a mall in a historic building. Mainly full of cafes and tourist shops selling overpriced food. Will take you about 20 -40 minutes to finish this place. Go after you gave looked at opera house and harbour bridge.

A must. We stayed in George Street which is within easy walking distance of this area whilst visiting Sydney and loved the area. The streets and houses are quaint. The Sydney Harbour Bridge towers over it. Loved it.

Nice area away from the city burden. The Rocks is the name of an area near the harbour where you will find bars, restaurants and shops. It's a really nice area, less busy than the city center so I really liked it.
Great For A Stroll. Old Architecture, mixes with modern fit outs. Good shopping and small bars. Sunday is market day with lots to see.

Something for everyone. This is an amazing place. So many different shops & locations to see. The weekend markets here are always bustling with so many different stalls. A real fun place to shop, eat or just walk and take in the atmosphere.
Historic walk. Walk around The Rocks area and take in the history of all the buildings, eat in one of the many cafes etc and take a drink at one of the Pubs.

The Heart of Sydney's Transportation Systems and Harbor Gateway. To enjoy Sydney in its entirety, you must see Sydney, get out in it. And the best way to do that when visiting is learn how to use the buses, ferries, trams, trains, and taxis. They all begin and end here, at The Rocks. It is a close walk to the nearby cruise ship harbor, the iconic Sydney Opera House, Sydney Harbor Bridge Climb, street vendors, musicians, and artists. Haven't ever heard a didgeridoo being played? ... I mean ... really well? Chances are you will find a street musician playing out a tune with a beat that you have never experienced, but it is not to be missed on your visit. You can purchase all day, or two- or three- or more day passes for all the public transportation (except the taxis) at an extremely good price. The taxis may be faster and more convenient, but quite expensive. In most cases public transportation will take you anywhere you need to go in fairly short order.

Weekend markets a must. Loved the Rocks. The markets are eclectic and there is truly something for everyone. We managed to get some great Christmas presents; find a great coffee and enjoy awesome street food. A lot of the markets are undercover but be aware of the sun as you wander down the side streets - it's ferocius. Recommend taking the opportunity for a cold beer at one of the many historical pubs in the area. Very authentically Australian!

Love The Rocks. I Love The Rocks and the markets there. I visit almost every month to see what's new and buy some of my faves. Whenever friends or family from overseas come we take them here. When I go overseas I come here to buy little gifts for friends and family. The variety of food has improved too. I always end up having a good day here.

Stepping back in time. A stroll through "The Rocks" can reveal many factions of its past history while enjoying the street markets, food stalls and restaurants dotted throughout the area.Boutique shops, direct clothing outlets, street stalls and original buildings add to the overall charm of this much visited area.it is well worth taking time out on your visit to wander through this unique precinct.

Quaint night life. Really enjoyed the food stalls selling pork barms and other delicious fayre and the varied entertainment such as the flame dancer, the shop window performing artist, the stage singers, etc;Definitely a place to visit at night.
Vibrant Night Life. Great historic area full of bars and restaurants of all types.Relaxed atmosphere and people very friendly in bars etc....

Really nice area. I really liked this area and had a lovely afternoon here. It was a Saturday so there were the markets, which were really nice. The buildings were interesting, nice harbour, cute shops, had a beautiful lunch in the Irish tea rooms (the tea cosy one, what a treat!). One of the highlights of my trip.
Iconic. Worth half a day, especially the Museum and the audio visual. It just makes you appreciate wheat your seeing.
Dinner at the Rocks. Great italian food with family. Fresh pasta, service was fantastic. Reasonable price. It was a busy saturday night, so taxis were in demand.
Cute!. The Rocks Market had a great atmosphere and plenty of cute stalls! I got great Christmas gifts for my family here, and I really enjoyed the energy of the place!
The Rocks, Sydney. Great area, full of history and really comes to life when the Market is on on a Saurday. Lots of cafes etc.

Even more beautiful than the pictures. To have the complete view is a real treat. We were able to watch all the ferries, cruise ships and other boat traffic day and night. It's an amazing choreography live! It was a lot of fun to walk around and see the various art installations near the Musuem of Modern Art, street artist and just great people watching. Great little lanes filled with galleries, restaurants and shops. Fantastic location! This would be my first choice for location of a hotel as well.

Rockin' Good Area. A very cool part of Sydney. Less commercial and more quaint. Charming restaurants that offer many dining options. The open air market stands on Saturday and Sunday offer wonderful hand crafted items, food specialty items, and food stand type dining options. This area of the city is older and adds a charm factor to Sydney.

Somewhat overrated in my opinion. The area has historical importance and it's certainly quaint. But I've never really enjoyed The Rocks—it's too touristy for my tastes. The shops and restaurants are oriented toward the visitor; there is an air of artificiality.

Tour of The Rocks district. I only had a couple of days in Sydney as I was waiting for a cruise to Hawaii, so one of my activities was taking a tour of the historic Rocks district. This was the area where the original convicts who were brought here from England were told to go "over to those rocks" and construct shelters for themselves. There is a very interesting history in this area. Many of the original buildings are still standing thanks to some forward thinking residents who fought off developers who wanted to take over and build the land. In some of the hand make bricks that make up the walls of these buildings you can see marks made by the convicts or animal tracks made in the bricks before they dried hard. You need some good walking shoes and don't forget your cameras as you take this journey back in time to Australia's origins.

Gotta love The Rocks. The Rocks is in my opinion the best part of Sydney to hang around in other than the beaches. The historic buildings and the cool surroundings close to everything else are a big drawcrd.
Wonderful Food. Was there on a Friday and a lot of the restaurants have stands in the street that day. All cooking the most amazing foods. Went down to the harbour and ate our lunch.

Best place to enjoy new year festival. You would love to sit, relax and watch new year welcome festival .... lovely fireworks, scenic view and that roaring sound ...... Happy New Year 2015 to all visitors

Take the Free Walking Tour. Go to the Information Office, pick up a leaflet about the free walking tour at take it - 6pm for 90 minutes. It was a really good way of getting an overview of some of the quirks of this fascinating place.
Great place to eat. Lots of lovely restaurants to choose from for lunch/dinner, or just to sit and have a coffee. And a nice area to mooch around.
Walking at the Rocks. This is the oldest part of the town where quite a few historical buildings have been preserved. Lots of pleasant walks through narrow passageways

Sunday markets, great cafes. Went to the Rocks on a Sunday. Lovely artisan stalls to browse. Made it harder to appreciate some of the architecture of the area. Lovely cafes and restaurants in the area would appeal to most palettes.
Not sure what the hype's about. Nothing really stood out to me, and this is coming from someone who enjoys just wandering and meandering about cities.
attractive old building. if you want to see the old building, you can come here..kinda cowboy town but still have it's own charm.worth a visit for pictures.

Over-rated tourist trap. There really isn't anything to see or do much at the Rocks. If you are out of time, this is one area you can skip. A few shops and that's it. I was quite disappointed that there's not much to do or see there.

THE ROCKS, SYDNEY,A MUST, ESPECIALLY IN DECEMBER. During the 7th to the 19th December, 2014, the Rocks is transformed by offering markets, music and mystical light for those meandering through. Discover the History of the Rocks. Ambiance of music on Sundays at Argyle. The cobbled streets of Old Sydney, little alley ways and so many restaurants and street food to complete the experience. A must visit.

Great spot for a walk. Interesting history surrounds the Rocks and little plaques give you information on bits and pieces. Found an awesome Bavarian/German restaurant and bar and had one of the best German meals around.....try the sausages.

Loved the Rocks, a "Must Visit" while in Sydney. We loved the free Rocks Open Air Museum, the shopping, the Lowenbrau brewery and restaurant, Hart's Pub and the walkway up to Sydney bridge from the Rocks. Use Argyle street to access the Sydney bridge.

Walk Round The Rocks. Interesting area of Old Sydney. We visited on the day of the Melbourne Cup so went into a pub to have a drink and watch the race on one or more of the wide screen televisions in the bar. Good fun.
MCA. Great walks around old Sydney - but don't miss the world class Museum of Contemporary Art; and then grab a meal outside in its restaurant.

Was a fantastic experience. The views are to die for such breathtaking views :)
The restaurants around the area are great.
Lowenbrau restaurant is great

Return Visit Didnt Disappoint. The other reviews say it all really, this is an area with something for everyone on the weekend, food, shopping, ambiance, history, walks, kicking back with a beer watching the world go by, reviving after walking the Harbour Bridge, going on a Motorbike tour (leave from the end of the main Market stalls) or just gazing in awe at the huge cruise ships berthed below. If you visit Sydney and dont visit the Rocks you will be missing out on a good experience

Very quaint older part of Sydney. This area was very close to our hotel so we spent quite a bit of time here or passing through. It seems like there is always something on here and with the good restaurants, craft scene and reasonably tasteful redevelopment it is a nice compact area to spend time with a good feel about it.

IMAGINE. The history of this place makes it feel real at times. Now fairly commercial there are bars and side streets where you can let your mind drift and try to imagine how it was at the time of the First Fleet and how it all developed from here. Lots of good bars and places to eat. Enjoy.

A must for all Sydney visitors. One of the oldest parts of Sydney, museums and historical interest mixed with interesting shops and a wide range of eateries and pubs. Enjoy the weekend street markets as a welcome addition to the normal

Interesting place to wander. Great to stroll around the streets and excellent food outlets. The food market - I think on Fridays - is a fantastic place to pick up an interesting lunch - spoilt for choice
Love the Foodie Market. If you are in Sydney on the weekend, drop by The Rocks for its market where you can get some good food plus hand made crafts which is ideal as souvenir.
Heritage Sydney. The Rocks in Sydney is famous. This area is Old Classic Sydney offering Hotels,restaurants heritage listed pubs.On the weekend the rocks host a market which is worth visiting.
Great spot!. Every time I visit Sydney I like to have a walk through the Rocks..and preferably a meal and a couple of drinks. A fantastic spot very close to the iconic harbour bridge and opera house.

Fascinating. Located in the heart of the city centre, The Rocks represent a nice and lively historical area full of nice and interesting places: curious shops, restaurants and pubs, nice nuildings, and also a few hidden sites where the history of this part of the city is described on panels. I recommend a visit to the shop of the Museum of Contemporary Art.
scenic. A famous location in sydney , tremendous views from the top , the site of many unfortunate leaps to the ocean below , great for pics .

Interesting. Be sure to read up on the history of The Rocks and you will enjoy your stroll through this historic area more. There is a Saturday market that was really nice. Food, local crafts, local designers it had everything. Then go back when market is not there looks totally different.

Historic Town. The Rocks is located near the area of the Harbor bridge. It is a small area that is the oldest part of Sydney. There is a small museum called Susannah Place. It had limited tour hours and cost about ($8 aus) for a guided tour. It has been around since 1844. The area was built on the harbors rocky area, hence the name the "Rocks" it is a bit hilly and narrow. There are many restaurants and shops in this historical area. It is a very different part of Sydney, but nice just the same.

Explore!. We saw something different around every corner! There are a number of historic buildings and archaeological sites hidden in the nooks of this area of the city. The Saturday markets were tourist-y, but we found some great gifts.

Oldest parts of the city. The place takes you back in time, where the city had started. Still with the 'rocky' old buildings this place has its own charm. The beauty is, its in the heart of the modern city. With some great pubs to just chill and enjoy some good beer.

So much to do = The Rocks. Its always lovely just to wander around The Rocks area with the great ,atmosphere,losts of cafes and places to eat. You have the Rocks Markets which is good as Australian products are sold here with such different things you dont see elsewhere. Watch the guy paint just from pressure cans making amazing pictures, find Xmas decorations, clothes and every isle is different. Especially a great place to buy something to take home from Australia or just give as a gift. Walking distance of Circular Quay and so many interesting sites all with in walking distance. A must visit place. Something for all ages

fell alive - complete happy area. Either for a drink or dinner, you must go to the Rocks. Plenty of restaurants. I would like to recoment the Cut and after, some of the Bakery or better, CAKERRY with those amazing options.
Warm and Friendly. Just wandering around is great, lots of interesting people, spectacular food, if you are there on Friday the farmers markets are excellent.
Great atmosphere.. Plenty of shops , bars and restaurants here. Avoid when a cruise ship is anchored up in harbour. Restaurants close there kitchens early at 10 pm.

Great place to wander around, especially on weekends. The Rocks is a tourist precinct and historic area in Sydney's CBD. It's located on the southside of Sydney Harbour, within walking distance to Circular Quay. Historically, it's the site of Australia's first European settlement more than two centuries ago. The people of Sydney have done a marvelous job preserving the old buildings, and giving it a new lease of life by converting it to cafes, restaurants, hotels, specialty shops etc. It's an ideal place to spend a leisurely afternoon, and get lost amongst the quaint old buildings. On weekends, parts of the road will be closed for the weekend market, and you'll be spoiled for choice what to buy from the street vendors.

classic. so nice to walk around freely and safely the rocks area of Sydney full of history and sights everywhere from the unusual people to the unusual art instillations A massive cruise ship was in dock so there were heaps of American tourists everywhere chatting and asking questions. Road Works make it a little difficult to get around for elderly folk near the docks
Unique. This area is charming with lots of public art and tremendous views of the Opera House, Luna Park and The Sydney Harbour Bridge.
Rocks cafe. We had a sensational lunch, chicken breast wrapped in prosciutto. Followed with a crisp cider. The staff were very attentive and the location is brilliant.

THE ROCKS SYDNEY. No trip to Sydney is complete without a trip around the Rocks area .This is the old part of Sydney and is great to walk around , especially at weekend when the street markets are on and the place really comes to life . Plenty of food and drink places as well as regular shops and a very big tourist info. centre which could be your first stop for info. on getting around , prices , tickets etc.

Love it!. Wish I would have arrived earlier so I could have gone on a walking tour or into some of the more historical buildings. Would be really interesting to have a guide, but love walking through and going through the shops and pubs. Must go!

Will only stay at the Rocks. This location is perfect if you are visiting Sydney. There are so many little cafe's and restaurants that are great! You can walk to the bridge, walk to the Opera House, walk to the harbor. It was such a great quaint neighborhood. I also recommend taking a ferry to Manly Beach! or any of the beaches. All beautiful!!

Wander through Sydney's history, with great pubs too!. Sydney was first settled around Macquarie Street & the Rocks area & many examples of this early settlement remain. The Rocks offers Cadmans Cottage, once right on the shore & many old bond stores where wool & other valuable items were kept for sale & shipping out abroad. There are many old pubs here too, as well as great hotels & restaurants, so take your time & enjoy Sydney's historic Rocks. The restaurants near the Overseas Passenger Terminal are with a visit too......

Lots of things to do and see. This is a really neat place in Sydney. There are tons of things to see and do including plenty of food options, tours, and attractions. We stayed about a mile away in downtown Sydney and walked here every day for breakfast. We also strolled around, exploring the sites and history. Highly recommended is The Rocks Walking Tour - an exceptionally fun, entertaining, cultural, and educational experience. Le Pain Quotidian is a great place for breakfast and Sydney's oldest pub, Fortune of War, is located here. Scenic views of the harbour and bridge abound and people watching is at a premium. A definitely must see and do while in Sydney.

Historic Sydney at its Best. You must go to this historic area of Sydney. Saved from destruction by the actions of many concerned people when it was planned to be razed for a container terminal.. One can see the vestiges of how the architecture was in the early days of the colony, and the huge bond stores and cottages alike have been faithfully restored to house businesses, artisans' studios, great restaurants and little cafes. We went on a Sunday, and the place was buzzing with a great market place atmosphere. The passenger terminus is nearby - though that is being renovated at present. One can walk alongside the Harbour to see a spectacular view of the Harbour Bridge and the Opera House on the other side and walk around to Circular Quay where the harbour ferries leave from. Walk along the road through the Argyle Cut up to the Garrison Church - also well worth going inside. The buses to Millars Point stop in this area. Wear walking shoes, as the pavements are a bit uneven in places, and there are often steps to get from one road level to another. The area is literally built on 'the Rocks'!! Well worth the visit. Visited November 2014

Always love to visit!. The Rocks is a wonderful place to visit. There are plenty of shopping opportunities, loads of eating options and cultural attractions. I especially like The Rocks Markets on the weekends in summer where local artisans sell their wares. Definitely worth a visit!
a unique place in a big city. a unique place in a big city. Historic buildings and unique food selections. great for late lunch or dinner.

The Rocks!. Casual strolling of shops and eateries, street musicians playing all types of music. A must go to place while in Sydney! Something for everyone in the family. Great place to purchase souvenirs or fine jewelry or sit and people watch while having a wonderful cup of coffee.

One of Sydney's best attractions. The Rocks in Sydney at Circular Quay, is a must see for all visitors to Sydney. There is so much to see and do, a great selection of eateries or coffee stops that cater to many tastes. Weekends are especially entertaining, lots of shops, market stalls with local products as well as lots of good street entertainment. Whether you are looking for souvenirs, or just out for a stroll you will find it memorable. The Rocks is so close to Sydney Harbour, you can stroll down along Circular Quay and what great photo memories you can create with the Opera house and the Sydney Harbour Bridge as back drops it's one of the most beautiful harbours in the world. And when there's a big cruise ship docked at Circular Quay it is just magic. Also at the Rocks is a selection of great accommodation, from budget through to extravagant indulgence. I recommend it for a weekend to spoil that someone special in your life.

The Rocks Sydney Simply Rock!. Simply one of the best places to be if you are in Sydney. Walking distance from beautiful harbour and in the evening plenty of great eating places. Romantic dinners and great wines. Afterwards take a stroll round the harbour with all its dizzy lights and sparkling water. The warmth of the evening and the smell of the flowers is delightful. Stop for a coffee and chat with the cafe owners. Shops open so you can check out the many different wares available for sale. I love Sydney.

The Rocks, Sydney. Great part of town, with it's heritage buildings, and views. The Youth Hostel archaeological dig site is interesting. Nearby is the Bridge Climb office, and the pubs are always a good for a break.
Get away. Seen lots of places around city and rocks area and Sydney harbor , hard to beat these place , for their beauty

Great Place to Walk Around. The Rocks is a great place to walk around on the weekend. There are lots of interesting market stalls to look at including a wide range of food to buy and some shopping arcades to wander through as well. The terraces beside the markets have shops that are worth browsing in and a couple sell freshly baked scones in the back courtyards. You can even take a motor bike or trike ride around the city and Neutral Bay (helmuts and jackets supplied). We did this and it was great fun. The historical buildings and cobbled paths add to the area's charm with the added bonus off being right next to Circular Quay, the Harbour Bridge and the Opera House. If you go down the steps to Campbell Cove and walk around the harbour forefront you get a great close up view of these attractions. There are a few nice (but expensive ) restaurants along there also and you might see either or both of the tall ships that sail from this area. There is so much to see and do in the Rocks.

A great day, even if you are a local.. I have lived in Sydney all my life & have been to the Rocks many times over the years. I thought I knew it all! , but a recent trip to the Waterfront restaurant for a birthday celabration renewed my affection for the area. It is always bright and bubbly with plenty of interesting things to see and do. If you are there on the weekend, check out the Rocks Markets which wind through a number of streets and laneways, ( a bit touristy, but if you are a tourist...... Its just what you are looking for!). There are cafes & 'watering holes' aplenty intermingled with art galleries & historic buildings. This is all accompanied by the scenic backdrop of our beautiful harbour with its iconic Opera House & Harbour Bridge. Ferries hustle & bustle while street buskers entertain.I think you will enjoy a trip to this historic & interesting area of Sydney.
Weekend in the Rocks Sydney. We stayed at the Rocks and enjoyed the markets and the lovely eateries around there. Very interesting, and the Harhbour is always wonderful
great. My husband have stayed at the rocks even though we live in the eastern suburbs and we would recommend staying there as you are close to all sight seeing attractions and just love it.

Go to the Rocks Markets, it's fantastic!. I've just been to the best Markets & apparently it's been operating for 20 years, Who knew?!! Lots of original stuff that's actually been made & designed by the stall holders! Not just cheap made in China junk (though of course there was still some of this, unfortunately)Best stalls in my opinion were Katsui hand painted fabric items, Gojo hand-painted ceramics, great hand made soaps, sandstone art. Spray painting art... loads of good stuff

Where old world meets the new. A lively but easy going harbour-side destination for all.. A stroll at The Rocks will take you back in time to when Europeans first settled in Sydney. Quaint cafes and great pub food against a spectacular Sydney Harbour backdrop make for great photo opportunities. Lovely way to spend half a day taking it easy in sunny Sydney. It so boasts of a lively and vibrant night life with its many pubs and restaurants, some of which are by the water.

Nice day out. Spent the day in Sydney 'The Rocks' area. Interesting place with lots of history and plenty to see and do. The area has a great atmosphere for enjoyment, catering for children and adults alike. A range of restaurants from take away to table dining. Ended up in a local pub with a live band, and had a brilliant evening meeting some very nice people, some local and some on holiday. The 'pub food' was very enjoyable too. Would recommend a visit.

Our History. As an Australian it is wonderful to explore The Rocks area with a true historian. There are so many little back streets which you may not have explored which are so fascinating. There are Ghost Tours too which are also really interesting and captivating.

Great Cafes and old style street markets. Loved walking around and checking out the wares over the weekend. Ended up buying a leather laptop shoulder bag. Cafes and eateries are great value and the Rocks area is fantastic in general, especially down on the harbour. Great for just wandering...

The Rocks many times over….. Every time I go to The Rocks, I enjoy it more and more. From the markets on the weekends, to taking photos in the alleyways to checking out the view at the Glenmore and much much more, it is a place you can keep coming back to for more exploring, shopping and fun.

Steeped in history. I suggest for overseas/interstate or first time visitors to The Rocks,to do a walking tour and give yourself plenty of time to explore this amazing area.The beautiful sandstone buildings,are a must to explore,with plenty of pub's cafe's restaurants catering for all budgets.The weekend markets are lively and you can always see something for free happening in and around the harbour foreshore.

Something for everyone. The Rocks rock!
Beautiful quaint classy cafes, bars and restaurants
Shops galore specialising in Australian goods of the souvenir variety including opals, ugg boots, leather goods and fashion items
Be it by day or night the Rocks will be a wonderful experience for the entire family to enjoy

A beautiful part of the city. The rocks is located at the North end of the city and is a nice way to spend a few hours.
Great shopping and historically sydney oldest town

Busy historical hub with so much to see & do!. I love The Rocks. There's so much to see and do, whatever mood you're in. You're right at the Sydney Harbour Bridge steps, next to Circular Quay and just a short walk away from the Opera House. With so many great old pubs and fantastic restaurants it's a great place to hang out. The markets are fab too and then there's the Bridge Climb if you're more daring. It's nice just to sit outside the many bars and restaurants and people watch too though! Very touristy but also lots of locals make it a great hive of entertainment. :)

The Rocks. Great place for the tourists or even local people to visit.Personally, we visit The Rocks couple time a month and always can find something interesting there. Place filled up with the small shops, galleries, museums.Lot and lot of cafe and restaurants. "Pancake on Rocks" one of the famous, i believe that it open 24 (or almost) hours."Guylian" anther place to visit for some sweet, coffe or high-tea.Parking reasonable easy to find (even during market days).

Turning Back Time. Over the years I have visited athe Rocks area of Sydney and always loved being there. Recently spent two nights stayng in a hotel at The Rocks. We enjoy just walking around visiting the Markets and also being a part of old Convict Sydney.There are lots to see and you are never far from our beautiful Harbour.The Rocks is a must see when in Sydney.

So much to do and see. Sunday at the Rocks is definitely fun. Always busy. After catching a ferry meeting up with friends we decided to mooch on up to the Merchantile Hotel. Full of character, about 7 mins walk from the ferry wharf. A Band starts playing Irish music around 3pm, always gets the crowd going. Best to arrive at least an hour earlier if you need to eat. There is an all day bistro. Guinness on tap, a must. The food is fine pub food nothing to write home about but never complained. The atmosphere is fantastic everyone has a really great time, friendly people from all walks of life mingle happily together. Quite an array of people from locals to tourists. You can either sit outside and people watch or sit around the bar listening to the music. Afterwards you can browse through the market, directly outside. You'll find a display of wonderful stalls enticing you, buying some extraordinary merchandise. Back at Cirqular Quay we finished off with an ice cream before catching the ferry back home again. It's s great way to spend a Sunday.

Rocks = Family. Atmosphere for all to enjoy sights, sounds, people, Watching the constant movement on the water, and many many restaurants catering for all types of food. I personally think children under 15 need to be out of the Rocks by 11PM as it can become a little rowdy later in the night. Fantastic Hotels are all through the Rocks.

Cool part of town. Strolling around the Rocks, visiting a pub for lunch is one of the best things to do in Sydney. It's the site of the first settlement and is full of colonnial history. And the backdrop is the view of Sydney Harbour. Plenty of hotels, shopping and things to see.

A Great Part of Sydney. I have lived my whole life in Sydney and always enjoy a visit to The Rocks. There is so much to see and do; lots of craft shops, cafes ,restaurants and pubs - all with a wonderful view of Sydney Harbour and the Opera House.Unlike Darling Harbour, visitors aren`t ripped off with exorbitant prices. You get good quality food at reasonable prices.For anyone visiting Sydney, and not wanting to venture too far out of the city, try The Rocks.
rocks. an enjoyable day spent walking around the rocks especially the markets lots to see and do. nice day out with family and friends

Pricey but amazing.. The rocks is great for weekend markets, great food and even more amazing views!
Overall the rocks is a bit pricey. But it's great for a day out. There's bits of old sydney preserved throughout the back streets and is pretty good for tourists. The best views of the opera house and the harbour bridge.

Sunday afternoon at the Chocolate Festival. Great place to visit when a festival is on and the markets are in full swing. Only issue is it gets very busy with people swarming all over to buy food. Has a great ambience and plenty to eat and drink. Markets are OK and offer some speciality items for sale.

Great place. Great place to explore near harbour front. Loads of little shops to explore and even better on the weekend market days.
Best street market.

Ripoff Supermarket at Clocktower Square, The Rocks,Sydney. Travellers are probably used to the high prices and cynical attitude of grocery type stores that operate around tourist districts the world over. You need to get some basics and its the only place available...o.k. You put it down to part and parcel of travel abroad.This place however, takes it to a new level. It's located directly underneath the Clocktower on the corner of Harrington and Argyle streets in the rocks district of Sydney.Its a medium/small supermarket. First thing you notice are there are almost no prices marked on the items on the shelves.When you get to the checkout the 'Customer service' consists of an openly contemptuous attitude delivered by a Middle Eastern Male.I have been to this establishment several times and confirmed it is a manner shared by all the staff I have encountered.Unfriendly bordering on hostility.As expected the prices are very high. Needless to say, they will not be getting any more of my custom.
Still good as ever. Still good as ever on weekends. Lots of crafts and some music by artists. Short walk to Sydney Harbour bridge. great view of the opera house and the ferry terminal too.

Disappointing . The place has not changed much from my last visit and this time which is 10 years. Infrastructure lack of maintenance and no obvious capital investment to lighten up the place. Sad story.

good start to tour Sydney. Interesting market with restaurants and bars galore. If you want some atmosphere this is the place to wander. Don't overlook the Visitor Centre which houses a fascinating museum.

A Walk Through Sydney's History. This was a nice little stroll first through the old hospital grounds, with winding, narrow walkways and shops interspersed among them. There were craft fairs going on (a weekend), and a lot of interesting buildings. We followed a recommended walking tour down to the shoreline, and around the point with great pictures of the harbor.

Charming. We walked along the George Street from Liverpool Street to the Rock on a Friday morning. It is a charming place with lots of small stores: art gallery, cafes, bakeries etc. There is also a small street market with food vendors and others. I like the little shop that sells different types of honey and you can try some of them before you buy. The whole area was not busy at that time (Friday). I am sure there will be a lot of tourists during weekends.

The street market is excellent. Interesting colonial style area. Lots of good bars and shops. Excellent street market but can get busy when the cruise ships are in port. Worth visiting the little museum which tells the history of the Rocks. Close to Circular Quay and great views of the harbour and Opera House.

Historic area with weekend markets. Historic area of Sydney, Small Art Galleries, restaurants and specialty food shops. Shopping is expensive as geared towards the tourist. Saturday & Sunday morning markets are a bonus, with craft and hand-made items, especially jewellery, well made but not cheap. Lots of items featuring Australiana.

A great place to explore . A great place to explore at the harbour front. Avoid the expense restaurants on the water front as most offer lousy service. Find a cafe or restaurant in the shopping area as they offer better value and service. Loads of little shops to explore and even better on the weekend market days.

Worth walking through. The Rocks is a historical part of Sydney which shows it's convict past. The tourist shops (many of them selling Australian jewellery, clothes, souvenirs, etc.) were expensive - selling many luxurious items. There are a number of cafes and restaurants which are attractive places to eat. It has lots of atmosphere and is close to Sydney Harbour - which makes it appealing to tourists. Worth walking through!

Trendy area. Great place to walk. Shopping, coffee shops, every kind of food you could ever want. Quaint bars and restaurants. Recommend Captain Cooks for a quick drink and Good conversation from the chatty bartender. Fish at the Rocks is great for seafood. Fresh daily specials make sure to make a reservation as it is very small and popular with the locals.

Shopping stroll. Plenty of Sydney history on show at The Rocks and an interesting range of shopping.The best time to go is on a Saturday or Sunday morning when the local market is out and supplements the bohemian offer of galleries and gift shops.A pleasant stroll which is sure to discover something for everyone.

Trendy & historical. This area dates back to the 1800's and was the original site for the hospital, police station, post office, etc. The brick bldgs and cobblestone streets are mostly original. Of course the store fronts have been modified for today and the restaurants and cafes spill right onto the sidewalks. Many little laneways with small shops are fun to discover and has a European feeling.

what a really nice place.
