I took my wife to the Rocks at the begining of November to show her around as she has never been, we were lucky enough to go when the evening markets were on, it was such a lovely place the smell of fresh food and being able to enjoy the sights at our leisure we really enjoyed it. We also enjoyed looking at the shops and just browsing in general.

Great area for history and shopping. Good area for sightseeing. you are able to enjoy cobblestone streets and cafes. The weekends have market stalls and the main road is blocked off so you can walk around at leisure. You can get some lovely harbor and water views. There is a free tourist trolley that does a stop off at the Rocks so you do not have to worry about parking in the area. Great historical architecture. The area is slopped and hilly and many stairs to get around the area so I am not sure how convenient it would be for wheelchair access.

AH-MAZING. We loved The Rocks! What a trendy, cool, historical part of Sydney. Great eating, drinking, shopping, sightseeing... plus a great history lesson. Would love to spend more time here if we're ever back in Australia!

Great area in Sydney. The Rocks is a charming area with lots of beautiful old buildings and small lanes and basically the foundation of Sydney so lots of history there. My accomodation was in The Rocks and I was really glad that I stayed here as other parts of Sydney were not that convincing. During the day it's just nice to wander around and visit the small interesting museums (The Rocks Discovery Centre, Susannah Place Museum), in the evening there are lots of restaurants and bars to spend some time in a nice and relaxing atmosphere, even though it's bustling with people. I really enjoyed the view from the rooftop bar at the Glenmore hotel and the kangaroo and emu pizza at the Australian Heritage Hotel are supposed to be really good, wish I could have tried those. For me The Rocks is a place not to be missed when visiting Sydney and if you can stay there, even better :-)

Great area to visit. Great area of town to visit, so much going on. Pubs, restaurants, art galleries. Old buildings nicely retorted and converted, a nice place to find yourself walking around. Take your time, get the feeling of the place.

Worth a visit. This is I believe the oldest part of Sydney and is worth an hour or two strolling around to see the buildings, many of which resemble those of city wharfs in UK. There are plenty of places to stop for a drink or meal and the area has its own charm quite distinct from the bustling harbour area just a short distance away. It's very close to the southern end of the harbour bridge and you get a real idea of the scale of the bridge looking up at it from almost beneath it.

The Early History of Sydney. Wonderful place to wander round. Tourist information very helpful and pleasant people working there. The Rocks museum is worth a visit. There are shops and restaurants to suit all pockets. Do not miss the area if visiting Sydney. A MUST!

the rocks. it is beautiful location to hang around in evenings and at night. it is one of the few places where you can see old buildings preserves and renovated along with the new infrastructure development done in the area.
Slightly over hyped. this is touted as best heritage area of sydney in fact there are not as many historic buildings as in Melbourne and I was slightly disappointed

Old world charm. A nice place , full of old buildings and the charm that goes with them . Lots of little side streets with nice little shops to browse in. Always clean and freindly.You could spend a couple of hours just wandering through , then its only a short walk back through the city.

More than one reason to visit. If you're interested in getting an unobstructed look at the small, early colonial stone buildings, narrow side streets, early residences and steep flights of stairs, visit the Rocks by day on foot, preferably in the earlier days of the weeks when the area is least congested. If you're more interested in shopping, crafts and market stalls, the weekend is good. And if you most enjoy crowded pubs and eateries, the Rocks is terrific at night.

Don't miss a trip to the Rocks when in Sydney. A visit to the Rocks is never complete if you don't visit the spray-can artist tucked inside the last shop at the end of George St under Sydney Bridge. It is amazing how a picture appears just from spraying colours on to the paper.Another great treat is the steamed corn. Eat it without butter or pepper and you can taste the juiciness.And of course the view of the Opera House and Closeup view of the Harbour Bridge is always a great sight.

From Shabby to Shiek. The Rocks by definition is a section of Sydney on the harbor where prisoners where housed and worked in the early days. The area has gone through a metamorphous and is now an upscale area of shops, restaurants and housing. As so many inner cities low income area it has reinvented itself. Located right off Circle Quay, it's an easy walk. The area has maintained much of its early architecture and is best seen by walking through the area. There is a helpful information located in the area. Several restaurants have outdoor seating, making prople watching a pleasure. If you are a lucky a cruise ship may be docked there. Not to worry the many ferrries that service the city can be seen.
The Old Sydney. A must for anyone who wants to see the 'Colonial Sydney' amazing buildings from the past along with some very nice places to eat and drink. A few minutes walk from Circular Quay.

Nice for a afternoon stroll. I had some time to kill on a Friday afternoon recently so I went for a stroll to the Sydney Rocks area. The quaint little streets and multitude of bars, restaurants and shops are sure to keep the vistor entertained. I was happy just to window shop and get a feel for the local atmosphere in this historic part of the town. After a heavy week of travelling and business meetings this was the perfect place to unwind. And all in the shadow of the huge Sydney Harbour bridge and a stones throw from the iconic Sydney Circular Quay.

Touristy, but nice. I usually hate tourist areas, but this one was great with plenty to do, lots of restaurants, shopping, entertainers, and great views. Even if your hotel is not in the area, it is worth a day visit to the Rocks.
The rocks 'rocks'. i like this area with all its lively pubs! Make sure u visit the area when the market is open.. They sell very interesting stuff

Interesting historical area. Good to walk around and try the various pubs and cafes spread throughout the area. Great views of the bridge, city and harbour from various points. Can be infested with tourists on weekends.

The WOW place. Usually, everything around Sydney is new and modern. The Rocks is one of the little places that can be called "old" which impressed even the Australians themselves. I love the atmosphere of this quarter - it's full of small cafes, bars, restaurants, not to mention the famous "Pancakes on The Rocks" - all reasons to love wandering around there.

Historic Rocks. I'm never tired of going to the Rocks. I love the history of it all. There are lots of plaques around for you to read and learn something. Very touristy and on the weekends there are markets. It is a hilly area to walk lots of stairs, but if you look there is always an easier way to go. Lots of eateries.. restaurants and take away places to choose. You can walk across George Street and you at Circular Quay, there you can catch a ferry or train.

Great for gifts. This place is great for the old style cafes and lots of them, this place really comes into its own at weekends when the market has lots of art and craft stalls ideal for travellers taking genuine Australian gifts back home, there are lots of art and craft shops too, plenty of opportunity to buy those " UGGs"
Interesting and historial area!. Intertesting place to walk and think of years past and how it start here. What it is now and what it offers to locals and as well as visitors. A major attraction.

History and Atmosphere. Booked a bed and breakfast in the Rocks, it's been 10 years since I was in Sydney last and the place was all a buzz. The Friday night was full of market stalls selling lots of different foods and tourist bits. The streets were packed and there was a great atmosphere. A lot different from last visit.
The Rocks, rocks. We love the historic feel of the older buildings, cobbled streets, and views over the harbour, the bridge and the opera house. So much to see and do, so close by.

The Weekend Market. There is a weekend market at The Rocks. The stalls are many and varied, however what makes this market different to many others is the merchandise is of high quality. Every stall is different and interesting.
nice area to walk around. Great historic neighborhood, worth spending an hour or two exploring. One of the free walking tours gives a tour of this area that's worth checking out.

Terrific atmosphere and favorite spot for wedding pictures!. This is where everyone comes to takes pictures of the Opera house and the Harbour bridge - no surprise there are lots of wedding pictures here as well - also good location for restaurants although a bit designed for tourists!

Excellent location for touristy stuff!. I have previously lived in Sydney for 15yrs and it's only after I've left (for dull, ugly Melbourne) that I'm returning and discovering all these wonderful places to visit throughout Sydney including The Rocks area. The Rocks is the perfect place to stay (book early) for an overseas or interstate tourist as you are just so close to the ferries, the vibrant Circular Quay and the restaurants throughout The Rocks and Circular Quay. There's a convenient raised walkway/cycleway in The Rocks that most people are completely unaware of called the Cahill Walkway that gives you convenient and speedy access to the Royal Botanical Gardens, Circular Quay and the Opera House. During our stay we:cycled across the Harbour Bridge, Ferry to Taronga Zoo, climbed the Harbour Bridge, watched the many local Brazilians gathered at Observatory Hill on a Sunday performing their Capoeira Dance to only us, Ferry to Fort Dension for lunch, chilled at the many outdoor restaurants/live music alongside the harbour at the OperaHouse, The Rocks Markets on a weekend (brilliant) and that is only the beginning... Just love 'the vibe' around Circular Quay and the harbour - Melbourne has nothing like it - just a dirty river.

Walk the rocks. Had a walk around the rocks last week while waiting to board the Pacific Pearl.I visited about ten years ago, it has not changed that much still a lot see and a couple of old pubs worth a visit.Wear decent walking shoes if you are planning on a long walk and check the weather because it can get really hot. I agree with Kaye M go twice.

The Rocks, Rock!. What a great place to spend a morning or afternoon sightseeing round Sydney. Here you have a spot that is good for families, or couples looking for a nice place to get away together. The historical buildings, local museum, and laneways are a constant delight. The market is well worth a visit and there are all types of cuisine for the hungry traveller. If you are in Sydney, you have to go and enjoy this literal landmark.

Living History. Definitely a must if you visit Sydney. It’s where the colony started. Lots of history, restaurants, shops, views and a market on the week-ends. A bit expensive and some areas are all about extracting dollars from tourists. To fully explore the area allow at least half a day.

Great on Market day. Walked here from the opera house. Went to the oldest pub and had a German beer, ate in Philips foot. The markets are great but do detract from the surroundings. My advice go twice ensure you visit when the markets not on. Also great place to visit in the evening and have a meal

Wandering around the Rocks on the Weekend. This is a place which becomes very crowded over the weekend but there is such a good vibe it doesn't matter. There are interesting stalls selling all manner of things worth looking at even if you don't buy anything. There are plenty of little places to eat along the way. A short climb westwards under the Harbour Bridge brings you to the S.H.Irwin gallery (small entry) where there is usually an interesting exhibition of paintings. A walk around Circular Quay brings you to the MCA (free entry, small fee to special exhibitions) if you like modern art, It is very picturesque around the waterfront with some extra special restaurants if you feel like splashing out. There often boats moored which take passengers on harbour cruises. It's a very pleasant place to spend a morning or even a day wandering around.
Historic District. Did a free walking tour one night. Quite a unique area. Lots of history.Interesting cafes and shops. Right at the Quay.

Sydney's history. You have the best of both worlds, history and the best harbour views. So many quaint little places to explore, you can wander for hours or sit and soak up the atmosphere.  Markets on the weekend, also guided walking tours availablePlenty of places to eat, some can be expensive but can find reasonable prices if you look.The Rocks can be reached by train or bus so are easy to get to.

Bondi to Coogee Walk. A lovely walk along the coast with excellent views all the way. Well graded path, suitable for strollers most of the way.Cafes and refreshments never far from the trackAvoid weekends in the summer unless you can be there early or late afternoon.
rocking. a must see for visitors to sydney ,shops,lots of buzz ,street entertainers pavement drawings but dont feed the pigeons near to the ferries shops ect great place

Great place to visit, locals and tourists. I had not been down to the Rocks for some time and decided to go down there on a weekend to look through the markets and then stop and have lunch. It was a glorious day and so we wondered through the markets, which I have to say had a lot of quality things I would not normally associate with a market in a tourist area. I actually purchased two Christmas presents while wondering around to take back to the UK with me this year. After that we walked to Campbell Cove where there is a group of Restaurants to have lunch. While it was OK, it was a expensive for what it was, so would suggest going to one of the local pubs in the area (of which there are many) to have lunch a drink. From there its an easy walk around to the Opera house and stopping off at Opera Bar for an afternoon drink while listening to live music.

My wife loved the Atmosphere. we arrived on the Hop on Hop off bus that was the very best way to get around. It gave us easy access to all the tourists sites & attractions. It also took the worry of where to park out of the trip! The Saturday market was really good and could have stayed much longer. Recommend a visit to the Rocks - just for the view.

Great Markets!. We recently visited The Rocks which is in an old area of Sydney and houses a lot of history. Much to do & see, plenty of historic places to explore. Every weekend there's an amazing array of Market Stalls in the historic Rocks Markets... had the best time! We'll definitely be back!

Waterfront Restaurant. Awesome part of Sydney and got re-acquainted with for a dinner out on business with Italian visitors. Forgot about the refurbishment of the Overseas Passenger Terminal, yikes what a mess and the views to the Opera House were somewhat blocked. Never mind, we were well indulged at the Waterfront Restaurant and the staff there did a great job in looking after us even though the environment (due to the construction works) has killed the atmosphere somewhat.Food and wine was excellent too.

Rocks exploring. The rocks are a great place to visit on any fine day. Being one of the oldest areas not just in Sydney but Australia makes it of hugh historical importance to every Aussie.The best way to explore it is by foot. The trick is to get off George street and wander the back lane ways. This is a very safe area so have no fear.Every pub you pass has a story .For lunch or dinner I recommend walking all the way down the bottom , around under the bridge and up the hill slightly to the Harbour view hotel.Opposite old terrace houses , its bar and restaurant on the 3rd floor of this historical pub has a wonderful view of the bridge and harbour.Don't forget on weekends there is a massive market selling a variety of hand crafted items as well as various foods . It goes all day .

Interesting area to have a wander. It's always nice to have a wander around The Rocks. There are lots of little alleyways, quaint sandstone buildings and little cafés and pubs. We recently discovered the Big Dig (an archaeology site) which is quite interesting. I especially like to go on the weekend when the Rocks markets are on.

A large step back into Australian History. The Rocks, on the northern stretch of George Street, Sydney, is Australia's oldest continuous settlement. Once the slum area of the city The Rocks has transformed into a tourism hub with Hotels (lots of), Restaurants, Art Galleries and many,many more attractions. It's situated adjacent to Circular Quay (the main ferry terminal for the harbour) and connecting Railway Station. It is also only a short walk around the Quay to the Sydney Opera House. Lot's of cafe's, great vibe and a really exciting place to visit when in Sydney.

Sunshine, drinks and the view of the harbour. It was the perfect sunday, sunshine, the boats passing by the harbour, drinks at the opera bar with the opera house in the back. It is such a nice place to spend a few hours, have lunch, some drinks and enjoy the view.

Great place to stop for a drink. A day out at The Rocks in Sydney is a must do if visiting the city. It is very close to circular Quay so it's easily accessed by public transport. There a lots of places to eat and some of the views are fantastic. There is also lots of history from colonial times, so it's a great place to have a walk around after lunch!

Must-see part of Sydney. I live in Sydney and I feel like a visitor every time I come to The Rocks as its a unique piece of Australia notmfound anywhere else. It's Australia's history and the beauty of its harbour in the one place. As well as divine food and fun things a,ways happening. A must see for any visit to Australia. And a must for Australians.

My Favorite Part of Sydney. And rocks (sorry about that!!) pretty much 24/7. Lunch outside at the Lowenbrau Kellar or dinner upstairs at the Orient hotel. Cook your own monster steak at Phillips Foote or just wander around the always interesting Rocks Markets on the weekend. Always fun at the Rocks AND the best views of the harbour in Sydney

Historically Amazing and Fun Too. The Rocks is a taste of Colonial Sydney, wonderful pubs and cobbled areas. The Ghost tour is amazing just for the history of the first settlement. The Saturday morning markets are so much fun with lots to see and buy along with the cottage shops in the area. A great place to spend a few hours.

Interesting history for this part of town. Hung out in this part of town due to its proximity to Circular Quay. Took a walking tour and got the history of how the neighborhood started and what it's evolved into. Great area to walk around to enjoy the culture and the great food.

Old Sydney Australia. The Rocks near Circular Quay is very interesting historical interesting part of Sydney. There is a neat circular map of the area, statue of Capt. Bligh, oldest building in Sydney woth GF above the door (King George). There are lots of restaurants and some shops. There is not much left of the old part of Sydney in this area.

A taste of colonial Australia. This is probably the best place to visit to get a taste of colonial Australia if you happen to be stuck on a cruise ship and only have a few hours on land. Mind you, being next to the Oversea's Passenger Terminal helps a lot, but as a memorial to the first settlers I've seen a lot better. Mind you, it is the actual location of the original colony, but the freeway running through the middle, and the modern development that seems to be invading this district is slowly destroying the historic charm. Still, enough has been preserved to still capture the essence of the original colony.

Interesting!. It's an interesting part of the city where you can stroll around where you can have a taste of an old and modern Australia. Souvenir shops and restaurants are also everywhere, so it's a nice place to spend a lovely afternoon.

You can't miss this one! A definiate must!. In my opinion, nothing defines Sydney more than the Rocks and Circular Quay holding the sites of Sydney's most popular tourist attractions. You can easily spend a day in this area when combining with the Quay, Harbour Bridge walk, Sydney Opera house and the botanical gardens. There are many nice eateries around and so much to do. Expect a good full day to tackle this area however if you're on a budget, consider staying somewhere a little outside with accommodation as it is a little more expensive in this neighborhood.

Throwback to what pubs were (should be?) like. Had a great couple of visits to the pub. Not the most sumptuous you'll visit, but it had a nice "pub" atmosphere when we were there. Barmaids quick to spot that empty glass and be ready for the next one. I probably indulged a bit too much in the "Crushed Orchard" cider I discovered there, but I definitely had a good time at the old place. Even if you only go in for the one, you've got to visit the oldest pub in the city.

Lovely old sydney. This is a must to walk around and soak up the atmosphere and look at the boutique shops. Stop and have a drink and a bite to eat, relax and people watch for a while. Leave feeling refreshed before heading back to the buzz of the city.

Great for walking and a glimpse into the past.. The Rocks is a really interesting area with lots of nooks and crannies. It would have been a great shame if we had lost this area. Be warned though. It is expensive to eat and shop almost everywhere. Beyond that it just so nice to stroll through the streets and imagine how it was in the past.
Great Market. Went to market on the Saturday was an awesome market to wonder through and they seemed to have something for everyone. Food, clothes, unique souveneirs etc.

Sightseeing trip. This is a historic part of Sydney adjacent to the bridge.We stumble on it by accident really.It's a nice area to walk through and see the old fashioned streets.You get so e brilliant views of the Sydney bridge from ground level here.Worth a quick visit

Interesting place to walk around.. This area is a mix of new tourist outlets,restaurants,art galleries and some interesting old buildings and terrace houses.Worth the time to just walk aroung the back streets and alleys and imagine what it was like in the early days of Sydney.Some great restaurants....
Sydney Icon. Such and amazing part of the city. The blend of new and old makes it such a pleasure to stroll around and soak it all in.
The rocks, Sidney Australia. Very interesting to see where the 1st settlers settled, if you ever go to Sidney you must visit the rocks, lovely little Irish pub there, serves great food
NOT SURE. Went to the rocks nice views but restaurants seem over priced $41 for pizza ? good food but pricing ? alot of choices close bye
Pretty place. Very quaint area of Sydney boutique type shops and a very pleasant area to walk abound. Much more quieter than Circular Quay.

Great for Wandering. Wonderfully scenic, the Rocks is a great place to grab a drink and some dinner, or to just have a wander in the evening. The streets are closed off every friday night for street markets, and they are definitely worth a visit.
It's all started here. Wanna to know the history of Sydney, these is the spot....love the weekend flea market very much....

For the shopper in you. I loved the area. The cobblestone alleys, beautiful buildings but most of all the weekend market. Loved the bush jewelry shop where they take eucalyptus tree leaves and dip in gold. For 25 for the necklace that is a good buy for family souvenirs and something one of a kind. Beware of the fake Uggs everywhere in Aus. I wanted a pair but for the price i can get them in the US f the same price and know they are real. Too many knock offs and very expensive. For cheap filling lunch so you don't spend a ton at restaurants go to the lowedenbrau outside food tent. For 10 bucks you get a huge sausage and roll which is cheap considering the process i saw in Sydney. I would rather find cheaper food and spend that extra money on gifted for myself! You will love the Rocks.

The place to be for shopping and dining. Found some nice shops and restaurants there on a lazy afternoon with friendly people, but as a warning lots of tourists there so lines at popular places are to be expected.
Sydney rocks markets. Fun at the markets lots of hand crafts and looking around old Sydney town , chance to look at the MCA and visit the cafe
A nice walk. A great walk on a Saturday. There is a great market that is on where you can purchase delicious treats or gifts and wander in the sun and then take in the gorgeous view over the water.

Nice plenty of shops. This can be expensive especially for the backpacker however this is nice and in a way its nice to get away from the backpacker places in sydney this is the place to go really. Its pretty with shops and beautioful views of the Opera house and the likes. Enjoy

Heaps to do. There's a lot of history about the Rocks and many places to explore. If you time it well you can wander through the markets when they are open, otherwise there's heaps of cafes and shops and some great restaurants and pubs also. It's also a lively spot of a night.

Interesting History. Worth visiting for it's historic value. Lots of cafés and small shops as well as galleries. We had lunch at The Rocks cafe. Food was basic and ok. Service as also OK. We did get entertained by local birds who landed at our table, tore open the sugar and proceeded to gobble it up.

A piece of timeless history. The Rocks are very conveniently located not far from Circular Quay. An easy stroll through the cobblestone streets, quaint restaurants and loads of history to see and read. On the weekends there are also markets available its lots of art and touristy things.

Visit the past!. Once one of the poorer places in the city, The Rocks is now a trandy part of the city with alot of history just waiting to be discovered. This is the place to visit the past, and the more darker time of australian history. Lear about the hard times of working people and the often tragic ending life of many Aboriginals

Great walking and discovery. Everyone should take the time to walk around this area of Australian history. To experience the great engineering feat of the bridge by walking alongside and beneath it. You can feel the energy and lives that have walked upon the rocks over the ages. A great place with nice pubs and restaurants to compliment it.

Wide choice.. Wide choice, this covers lots of things at "The Rocks". Once one of the poorer areas, now a very trendy place with lots to do and see. Some excellent restaurants and bars, all very diverse and lots of character.Some great views of the Harbor and bridge.

Rocks a place to visit. Most people think of Australia as a new country; shiny and, perhaps, in the case of Sydney, slightly superficial.Contra this view, of course, is the ancientness of the country's Aboriginal population and culture, anywhere between the conventional 60,000 BP (Before Present) to the astonishing 150,000 BP. So-called "settler Australia", those of us whose history in Australia at most remotes to 1788, may try to appropriate this sophisticated and fascinating Aboriginal element, but it is more than a bit of a stretch.When you visit the old Sydney area called "The Rocks", try to imagine people living on this land without the brick and stone constructions that you have come to see. Those rocks that are covered by docks and hotels supplied a resident indigenous population with an abundance of luscious food diversity.So you will find the settler "Rocks" of today. There are one or two of Sydney's most expensive restaurants, along with fast food easy feeding places. The numbers that visit this historic part of settler Sydney tend to eleminate the tacky and tasteless: they close after a while as people are seeking something else.That something else is the sort of history that most people come to a modern city to see: solid human constructions, comfortable hotels (let's be honest, if we can afford it) and a reasonable feed at a level that is affordable and attractive.Food and drink are not just to satisfy bodily needs, especially not for the visitor struggling with an unfamiliar milieu, but to delight and entice.Whilst there are many parts to The Rocks, there is a totality that I am trying to portray.Visitors can come back to this place many times, as do residents like me.Couples can find intimate places for their pleasure and families at whatever age will be able to occupy themselves. There are quiet corners as well as raucous night spots for a group of friends. A solo traveller will not feel alone for long.Not that long ago the narrow lane ways were not to be frequented in the night, but rarely is The Rocks anything other than a vibrant touristic experience.If you can, as a visitor, try to stay at one of the variety of accommodations in the area so that when you return from other places, you have a lively and interesting evening.I have lived in Sydney most of my life and find The Rocks still a place to visit.

The rocks market. The rocks market was bigger than expected and a good place for surprise finds! It is walking distance form the Sydney oprera House and Darling harbour. Take your time and enjoy a relaxing stroll and feast your eyes on the colours and items on display at the stalls.

No matter where I started out it ended here. The Rocks is a great part of Sydney you don't feel like you're in a huge city, but a quaint village by day and just a bit exciting at night. I bought my opals here most of my souvenirs and just as expensive water here. ( Water don't leave your hotel without it) found a great Bar to eat at good food good price. Wonderful mix of people all ages 18 and up not to rowdy but not stiff. The Orient Bar and grill, Orient hotel
Recommended for first time visitors. Very touristic place - highly recommended for first time tourists. Pleasant market on weekends, and good for a short walk.

Brilliant Sunday afternoon. A brilliant way to spend a loverly sunny Sydney Sunday afternoon. Catch the ferry on Sydney Harbour into Circular Quay and then walk around The Rocks. Numerous cafes, bars and shops to enjoy as well as a street market. This just highlights what a world class city Sydney really is!!

Divine. Take a walk around this area and see the gorgeous old buildings and alleyways. Stop in to any of the cafés, pubs, and restaurants and soak up the atmosphere. Great b&b's and lots of hotels to choose from.
Great Shopping!. Walk along cobblestone streets while purchasing souvenirs! Lots of people and very busy but worth it!

You have to explore on foot. One of the best areas to explore in Sydney is the area adjacent to the Harbour referred to as "The Rocks". This area contains lots of the history of early Sydney, and but was nearly lost in the 1970's when there were plans to demolish the streets and old buildings to make way for redevelopment. Luckily there are still wonderful streets and lane-ways to explore, stopping at interesting shops and cafes on the way.And on the weekend, you cannot miss the market that takes place at the top of George St. There are lots of stalls with food, jewellery and souvenir items. And on many stalls you can talk to the people who make the items, which adds to the experience.
A step back in time. Great HistoryArchitecture Plenty of places to eat & Drink !Take the sightseeing bus and you can get to see more of this fare city

A spectacular part of Australia's History.. This has become one of my favourite land marks. I thoroughly enjoy walking around the The Rocks and admiring the old houses, buildings and the architectures. The pubs are great. Cafes area a plenty and of good quality. I can spend days here.

Lots of history by oz standards ;-). Lots to see and do. Plenty of stories to hear about. I suggest the late night free tours. Just leave a tip to the guide at the end. Lovely places to eat and drink nearby and lots of local people live near here. Really rustic for a place so close to the harbour bridge and opera house.

Markets-Food -Coffee-Sight Seeing. Pop down early and have coffee and pastry before the markets are set up (there is a cafe smack bang in the middle with a couple of tables market side). And watch the stall holders create the tourist icon.The markets have plenty to enthrall and the location easily lends itself to a great starter for the day, or sneak back in the evening and visit some of Sydneys oldest or newest bars (depending on what you enjoy)

The rocks Sunday markets. We walked to the rocks on Sunday great markets lots of very interesting stalls and great bars great atmosphere fun place to wander around and purchase the more unusual type of things specialty jewellery, silk clothing, t shirts and the like, plenty of bars and bakeries coffee shops this place was buzzing with people.

Not just for tourists. We had a great meal at the Lowenbrau German restaurant complete with tradition German musical trio. Great choice of eateries from the waterfront to back lanes. Includes Sydney's oldest pub from 1828.. a little taste of early settlement... also wander through the Argle Cut to the Garrison Church, Argyle Place and then up to Sydney Observatory, or the South Pylon or walk across The Bridge walkway and back around to Circular Quay on the elevated walkway. You can continue to the Botanic Gardens and Opera House. Locals discovering our city too. Even better during VIVID light show week.

Old history at it's finest. In true Sydney charm, the Rock offer a peak into the oldest part of Sydney, and there are plenty if ways to explore. By day, on a walking tour, or by night on a pub crawl, or maybe you are interested in a little of both. The location is quite central to so many of the other sites of the city it is quite easy to pop over for a visit. Walking guides area available online, in tour books or at information desks throughout the city. It is a beautiful area you won't want to miss.
Old architecture. Great place to visit if you like old architecture and history. We did a good walk around this place where it makes you travel to the past.

Nice area, surprisingly not so expensive. This is a nice area for walking, shopping, taking food or just relaxing little bit in a Cafe and enjoying a Cappuccino. Surprisingly most of the Bars and restaurants are even not so expensive as you might think.
Historic spot. A nice area to be visiting and walking around. Lovely historic buildings, look up to the harbour bridge

Unique. We were there for their weekend market. Although the things were a little expensive, it was different. There were special items and what captivated me was the 3D stamps. They took about 5 of the same stamps to make the 3D effect. They have beautiful dresses along the way. Worth visiting.

Quaint and colorful. We enjoyed the historic architecture and pleasant atmosphere. Many bars and restaurants. Fun open air market on the weekend. Favorite find was Wine Odyssey Australia wine bar (wineodyssey.com). You buy a debit card, then sample wine by the ounce from enomatic machines. Efficient way to get an overview of Australian wines. (There is a similar wine bar, The Winery, in Queenstown, NZ).
A little history lesson. One of my favourite places in Sydney and one of my favourite pubs is the Fortune of War. Markets on the weekend is great where a bargain can be found.

Perfect location to explore Sydney Harbour from. Historical, central, beautifully situated near Circular Quay to allow easy exploration of the Harbour, Opera House, the Sydney Bridge, access to the various ferries, lovel restaurants and pubs (oldest Irish pub) etc. We stayed in the Mantra Hotel. Perfect location.

Nice vibe. We were here on a Friday when they had the food market. Too many yummy options. The shops were interesting and we especially enjoyed being able to purchase a rough opal (not the usual polished ones. Lots of people around as a cruise ship was in. Would recommend a look around and a stop for a bite to eat somewhere.

Many hidden secrets.. A nice small area off the Circular Quay. Varied restaurants here and there. A relaxing place with nice bars and good food. The Argyle is a quaint bar with friendly staff; has live music in the weekend. The Wine Odyssey is a relaxing bar with wine tastings from all over Australia. There is a Lowenbrau German beer garden. There's Phillip's Foote with cook-your-own steak at the back of a boisterous bar. In short, many choices in a small area.

The Rocks. A must to go either on Saturday or Sunday as they have Markets all around the streets. This is the historic area of Sydney City with Arts, Culture & RestaurantsGet a sense of Sydney's cobbled laneways, cosy cafés and oldest pubs in the country. Throughout this historic precinct quiet beautiful.

Good on weekends. Went to The Rocks midweek and during the weekend and found it much better on the weekend for more vibes and action. The market was great. If you want to just shop midweek is good with less people around but I loved pele watching on the weekend.
COZY DINNER PLACE. Beautiful place , covered by big-big rocks, inside great food are awaiting. I suggest your to have Lowenbrau and ROCK's pancakes.yummm

Great festive air at weekends...... The Gadigal people were the original people living in the Rocks area then came the Europeans to manage the land and natural port harbour. For a long time it housed what was then known as the 'slums'. Gradually through trial and protest it now remains as part of the Sydney Harbour foreshore historical area and an interesting area to stroll around.It is probably easier to walk from Town Hall Station to the Rocks rather then the other way round, however, Circular Quay Station or ferry is is another option with a flat stroll of around 15 mins. Car parking is available but like most cities, it can fill up quickly and cost too.Sydney Visitor Centre at The Rocks is located on the corner of Argyle and Playfair streets and is a good way to get some information. A walking map will help in identifying the historical buildings, locating museums and restaurants in the area. On Saturday and Sunday you will find the Rocks Markets with one off or local designer items plus on Friday there is a foodie market with home made delicacies and onsite food for a late breakfast or lunch.This area is best explored on foot or bike with just one or two steep places to negotiate. Late at night you can dine in many different restaurants - some renowned. Allow at least a few hours particularly at weekends when there is a festive air from the markets and day trippers.Enjoy your experience!

Food, drinks, history and more!. There's something for everyone at The Rocks and nearby Circular Quay. There are many food and drink places ranging from Australia's oldest pubs to cafes and much more. There's also shops selling clothing, shoes, souvenirs and much more. Within the area is the Museum of Contemporary Art. Also, during the weekends there is a market selling all sorts of interesting things! The Rocks is a great area in Sydney that is easily accessible by buses, trains and ferries. It's also walking distance from major CBD attractions. Highly Recommended.

Awesome history. Had a guided tour of the rocks. It was amazing you could litterally feel the present of the hard working people and thiefs that had lived there. It was a real historical tour, where you could feel how they had to struggle to surviev.

Pubs galore, history & more. A visit to Sydney would not be complete without a visit to the Rocks! When we head up there we always stay in the Rocks area. Some say it is touristy, but when you're having a weekend away and want to enjoy a few trips to the pub and a bit of sightseeing, to me, it is the perfect spot.The pubs are like stepping back into old Sydney town, they hold a special history and some have original features, the bathrooms in pubs like the Australian are amazingly old and it's like a history lesson just visiting the loo!The Rocks is vibrant, full of life and there is loads to see and do. A visit to the Harbour bridge is a must and just strolling the streets provides an insight into the beginnings of Australia.Make sure you visit, if you're an Aussie, it's a great way to get to know a bit of Australian history and for tourists from abroad, it's a must visit, you'll be sure to enjoy.
Around The Rocks. So much to do around the rocks - you won't be bored Lots of nice Historic Pubs , Great cafés & Restaurants Markets . Sit under the Harbour Bridge and take in that gorgeous view.

Old Sydney restored. A walk around the Rocks especially on the weekend is a unique opportunity to see a bit of Sydney's founding by British convicts almost 230 years ago. We are not an old city by European standards but what we have is nonetheless fascinating and informative. So many little old laneways have been opened up to allow a vision of what was and what now is with shops to supply anything a tourist or local can want

Historic Sydney. Go on the weekend when they've markets on - interesting architecture, museum of how people lived in the colony from the early days really interesting but you must book before you go... all the tourist trinkets are cheaper in Paddy's Markets!

Historic. Plenty to do and see at The Rocks in Sydney. Easily accessible and in a perfect position to enjoy Sydney Harbour foreshores. An older part of original Sydney Town where convicts hid in the rocks that were home to poor settlers...it's an easy walk up to the Garrison Church, Observatory Hill and The Harbour Bridge. Not to be missed. Favourite waiting place is Waterfront Restaurant...(look for scoupons for a good food deal)

The rocks Rox. I go here as it's one of the last ports of call for a Guinness on tap. Since "I like to watch" a Guiness and a perve of the pedestrian traffic is always a stimulating and relaxing pastime at The Rocks. I also love walking the nurses steps and somehow finding my way through the labyrinth of the rocks back to the start.

The Rocks has it all. The Rocks has the best variety of entertainment for everyone.Its easy walking to shops, market stalls,restaurants,historic pubs ,Art galleries and Observatories with the most spectacular views over Sydney Harbour
Fun and interesting! . Great place to spend some time roaming around and looking at the historical sites. Lots of cool boutique stores, and cafés. Though most things are more on the expensive side.
Something for everyone. the area has a bit of everything - early sandstone buildings, great restaurants, weekend markets also open some evenings, the harbour's edge.
Early Australia. Walk through the development of early Australia, and see how they lived. Sandstone buildings and the hard toil of the people of Sydney.

The Rocks Really Do Rock. The famour Rocks has something for everyone. If you are a Sydney-sider or an over-seas visitor you will find something just for you at the Rocks. It is a great place to meet up with your family and have a gander around together. Just steps away you can find fine food and drinks for that late after-noon lucheon.

Great part of Sydney. When in Sydney a visit to the Rocks is a must!! Especially at the weekend when the market is on and has loads of beautiful crafts!! Great view of the Bridge and great bars to visit!! Especially the Merc on a Sunday
Great experience. the Rocks has a lot of history but you can still enjoy the modern touch with lots of restaurants and pubs and bars. Good food too.
Historical. A fantastic sight seeing historical adventure , where you can explore where the first convicts & how they arrived in Australia!! A must view attraction

Must Do History. The Rocks is what Sydney was, it's a must that you take the time to walk around and see the cobble stone foot paths and the small lane ways, the Rocks is the history of Sydney. Plus it is only a 5 minute walk from Circular Quay train station.
Sydney's best kept secret. I always try and do the rocks scene when I'm in town and it never disappoints. Thank you Sydney for keeping this attraction still alive. I will be back.

Market Visit. I was at The Rocks to visit the market during the weekend. The market was quite small and mostly selling handicrafts. Besides the market, there were a few restaurants and cafes in the area. It will be nice to be there for afternoon tea.

Lovely place to spend a few days wandering around. We stayed in the Rocks district and loved the time that we were here. There is so much history, museums, restaurants, walks, boat trips and shopping to do while you are there. Great place to visit and stay in

Not much atmosphere in The Rocks. The view of the rocks from Opera House is probably the best part. I recommend to walk under the bridge and then enter The Rocks, it's mainly a place for restaurants and little more

I love the rocks. The rocks it easy to get to & easy to get around. We went twice, once to see the street markets then again during the week. Beautiful quaint buildings and streets a great place to visit

Amazing district. A peaceful neighborhood surrounded by the worldwide famous Sydney Opera House, the Harbour Bridge and the Royal Botanic Gardens.
The Rocks also offers a big variety of stores and good places to eat.

Head to the Markets and the Susanna Place Museum. We went along on a Saturday to see the markets, eat some treats, see the sights and go the Susanna Place museum. All were worth the effort of walking over from the other end of town. A great part of the world and if you take the time to learn some of the history, it gets even better!

Sydney as it was!. This area of Sydney is full of plaques and remnants from the first settlement in 1788 .
Located by the side of the harbour bridge and across from the opera it's full of photographic opportunities

What a market. The Rocks Market is fantastic. Plenty of variety, and plenty of opportunity to stop and eat and drink, Would be useful for more stall holders to have POS so those of us who carry little cash, or not enough cash can make purchases when we want to. Sadly I had to miss out on a couple of purchases as I didn't have enough cash on me. Yes I could have gone to an ATM, but it's not like I can't come back again with more cash..........

Great place to explore and enjoy the sights and foods.. Great destination for any Sydney visit. Abundant restaurants and pubs. Make the time to visit!The area is a bit hilly and many cobblestone areas so wear comfy shoes.
Old worlde.. Enjoy the ambience of the area , take in the atmosphere of tourists, shops and cafes. Loved the old sandstone buildings and it is a good retreat from the busy city.

The Rocks. The Rocks are on very high grounds and the conference that I presented my research paper was in the hotel. I stayed at George hotel walking distance to the Rocks and was enjoyable and memorable

Great walking around. We first visited the rocks on our tour around Sydney and then went back there after the tour by ourselves. We had a great day just walking around. There's many hidden shops that can only be found by walking all around. It's a good idea to get a map, because it's very easy to get lost there. Many cafes and restaurants to eat at, probably a bit more expensive than in other places in Sydney, but it's worth it, because the atmosphere there is great.

Aka, Friday Market. Its the market only opens on firday, and the locals used to sell their production direct here, though little expensvie because of high advertising for this market, but certainly good for a visit.
amazing history. great history and amazing buildings, definitely go on a weekend and check out the market! the architecture and the fact the bridge is in the background make it a definite go to!
good for strolling and looking around. I loved walking around here just to see some unique stuff like foods and clothes and a lot more. you'll see some awesome performers too.

Fantastic historic site. A fantastic area of Sydney. A must see. Great to purchase opals, visit art galleries, markets on the weekend, coffee, lunch, awesome restaurants around, beautiful views of harbour bridge and opera houseMy blog www.mskotravels.com

The Rocks.. not what I remember!. We visited the Rocks on our stay in Sydney and I was there in 1996, but it was completely different than what I remembered. This was probably because there was a lot of construction going on and we found it difficult to find a really nice restaurant (preferably seafood) to have lunch at. We ended up finding a gorgeous little restaurant called Pony, it was great and we ended up going back there for lunch again the next day!

Fun shopping place with a history. Oddly enough this place had some of the best prices on Australian souvenirs...even opals. Quaint shops...nice t-shirts, boomerangs, kitschy items, etc. Charming and fun. If you have issue walking on uneven surface or up/downhill, it may be a little challenging. Highly recommend...

HISTORIC PLACE. when you arrive sydney the rock is the historic place wherein you can see the historic places of the city. restaurant is just around the corners and some local shops. you can just walk around and see old places and houses. bring with some water and some junk foods.
Old area and full of nostalgic. When you walk around the rocks you get a sense of the old times and with all the cafes and sites to see you can easy spend a whole day in this area

Best location for a city tour. Ideal place to start your city experience (walking distance to Harbour Bridge, Harbour, Opera ...) and very nice flair with old houses, nice small restaurants, interesting galleries.

The Rocks - "Rock". Wandered around the Rocks while waiting to board a cruise ship we spent over 2 hours enjoying the atmosphere , lots to entertain us ,being on a weekend ,the markets were on .Found a tourist information but it was upstairs , not ideal for those using walking sticks. they were very helpful and supplied maps to show us around .Everyone we spoke to was very friendly .

Quaint. The Rocks are really very cute. It sort of feels like entering a completely different city. And, of course, the combination of street food and homemade candles means it always smells like homey, almost like a fantasy-version of grandma's house.

The Tea Cosy. While at The Rocks visit The Tea Cosy. It's a terraced house that's been turned into a quaint little cafe. It serves the most wonderful afternoon teas in china teapots complete with floral cups and saucers and multi coloured hand knitted tea cosys. There's a wonderful friendly atmosphere and you wouldn't believe that you're in the heart of Sydney!It's a unique place to visit! I loved it!

Perfect area. The rocks is a great suburb in Sydney. The weekend markets are a great day out with crafts, homemade goods and food. Many old buildings, hotels, restaurants and alley ways with lots of history.

Where else in Australia?. Regular visitor to Sydney, the Rocks are always on the list for a visit. Not that it changes, but its my Sydney 'fix'.This is the only place in Oz where you can get a feel for the 18th and early 19th century, very north european in its old buildings, little lanes and walkways and cobbled streets and on the weekend a street market. All genuine, updated over time but none the less reflecting the really old Oz.Meander, don't set a time frame, wander through the back lanes and the streets. It can feel a little commercial/touristy but still worth the wander. Little shops and arcades throughout and the Museum of Contemprary Art is worth the visit.Stay in Harrington St. This is the middle of the precinct with easy access to everything including the Quay and the ferries and railway station and the Bridge and the Opera House. All the hotels are OK.The 'Rocks' IS Sydney i think.
Nice. We enjoyed visiting the shops and seeing when area. I may have missed something, but I think the primary purpose is shopping
The old mixed with the new. Full of history and a feel of the old days as well as modern restaurants and markets make this a great day out.
Worth some time. Quirky, lovely history and lots of little alleyways to explore. There is a food market on the weekends.

History. Good. We find YHA in the Rock. We saw a lot of history in that area. We go the weekend market. That's a nice place and a lot of food we ate. We bought a lot of special things in the weekend market.

The Rocks, Sydney. Excellent old buildings and well kept surrounds. A lot of history here. Beaut Sunday arket with many local art and craft stalls. Plenty of nice restaurants and eateries in the area. Well worth a visit.Cheers Niels and Mary, Humpty, NT, Australia, Down Under
Charming. The rocks is filled with quaint shops, restaurants and cafes. Great place to meet with friends, shop and have a drink.
Old Sydney. Full of history and historical old buildings. Markets on weekends. A must see for overseas visitors. Adjacent to the waterfront area.
Nice area. walking through the Rocks was a very nice addition to the trip. The markets were well presented and were a joy to walk around

fabulous. Love the Rocks area. The markets are fabulous with high quality crafts. Especially enjoyed unique local crafts. The workmanship is inspiring. Being in old Sydney town there is a great atmosphere walking through the paved streets with lots of eateries and pubs.
Great Location. Great place with good vibes. Lots of choices for eating and drinking. very close to the quays so you can sit and have a drink whilst enjoying the views.

Buzzing. The rocks is a lovely area for a stroll. Lots of nice little shops and galleries to wander round. We were there when a coffee festival was on and it was chock full of people. There were plenty of street performers making it an entertaining area. We went back on different days when it was quieter and it was lovely to stroll round, may be sit at one of the outside bars with a glass of wine and watch the world go by!

Throw back to a simpler time. European character. (New York prices).. A 5 minute walk from Circular Quays brings you to this heritage precinct near Harbour Bridge filled with restaurants, cafés, rooftop lounge bars and restaurants and shops.

Trendy area with good restaurants. Plenty of shops, art galleries and restaurants. We ate at the Argyle - fun outdoor seating area with three other restaurants and an outdoor bar serving the area. Worth checking out.

Nice for Australia but nothing compared to Europe. The rocks is worth having a look around when you are in Sydney. ITs nice to have a walk and get a feel of what Sydney was like back in the days but is it far from impressive and nothing like the old cities of Europe.

Up there markets. This is not the first time that I had visited the Rocks on a market day. But I was impressed again at how classy these markets are. The stalls are full of quality and interesting craft that you don't see at other places. And surrounded by such great buildings and places to eat and see just adds. My favourite touch was the herb and vegie planter boxes all the say down the main street.

Great mixture of old and new.. Fantastic area of Sydney, from quaint markets to trendy bars.
Once again, easily reached by the ferry or train. Great Irish bar here with great live music and cold cold beer.
The Rocks definatly feel more relaxed then the rest of Sydney, and Sydney is one of the most laid back cities I've been to, so that says it all.
Awesome historical place. Just brilliant, very historic,you can go on travel tours,grab a bite or a pint at the many little pubs,great little shops,nice food too
Tourist trap. Not sure what there is to see here apart from some old buildings housing overpriced cafes and restaurants.

Spoiled by the new Cruise ship terminal. The Rocks is a well preserved area to keep the history alive. Then this huge Cruise ship terminal is build that spoils the view from the rocks as well as looking onto the rocks from the water. There could have been a better place to put this terminal. To bad for the Rocks area.

History, Modern Boutique and Markets all rolled into one. What a lovely place to visit over the weekend. Markets with interesting things to buy, and food to taste, cafés and restaurants to choose from, quiet places with nice views and a bit of heritage character and noisier places with lots of bustle, overlapping with the Circular Quay area which is all go at peak times with didgeridoo players hyping it up with a modern beat. A short walk away is the harbour bridge, which you can walk back and forth on and it is possible to walk to Darling Harbour in one direction or the Opera house and Royal Botanic Gardens in the other, it is all really close and easy to get around. The old buildings amidst the modern ones are all very cool, overlooked by high rise hotels and office towers. You can spend as little or as much money and time there as you want.

Historic Rocks.. The Rocks area of Sydney is densely packed with historic houses, restaurants and tourist destinations. Always busy with tourists offering great views over the City and Harbour. Visit the nearby Bridge and take a Bridge walk .. exhilarating!

A look back at our past. Visiting The Rocks in Sydney is like taking a look back at our past. The beautiful worn cobble streets and sandstone buildings are such a surprise so close to the city. The markets with their music, stalls, colours and food are a wonderful place to visit.

Strolling around The Rocks. Strolling around The Rocks is a great way to spend your time in Sydney. You will be near the beautiful harbour, experience a bit of the past of Sydney and hear and see some interesting things about the history of old Sydney. Great restaurants and pubs for a meal and the Markets on the weekend a worth a visit.
never get tired of The Rocks. Just love walking around The Rocks, we never tire of it. Laneways & steps, interesting shops, oozing history. Fabulous sandstone everywhere.
Great food. The rocks offers a nice assortment of foods, and the "Pancakes" on the rocks is great. You will want to come and see it and experience the flavors of Sydney...
Great Experience. I absolutely love the rocks!! It feels like you've stepped back in time and there is so much to see and do. It's a great area!

The lovely part of Sydney CBD.. The area is full of nice shops, cafés and restaurants. Just a few steps from the Sydney ferries wharf, Opera House and the Botanic Garden. We love to spend of Sunday lunch browsing around the weekend market and have lunch at the local cafe. There are plenty of interesting products that made locally.
Interesting history. This area has quite an interesting history. There are fantastic nearly free tours to this area. Quite picturesque with interesting architecture

Fun Area. We enjoyed walking around this historic area which is very close to the ferry terminals and cruise port. There are lots of restaurants, bars, museums and shops. You can find some unique gift shops where I actually bought quite a few gifts for the folks back home :-). The people working in the various establishments were all helpful and welcoming - no problem with staff anywhere. It's a nice safe area day or night. As a side note, it's a very easy walk if you arriving by cruise ship.

Unique, historical area. Quite fun to have been able to meander about, without really knowing what we were doing at the moment, and encounter this really interestingly cool area, very easy to get to and comfortable to explore on one's own
Good view. Was a really good walkway, you've a great view about the Opera House, and quite nice small old style street on the way to get the Harbour Bridge.

Lovely place to go and shop and have lunch!. We went for a walk around the Rocks. Great place to go to pick up your souveniers. We stopped and had luch on a sidewalk cafe! Walked through the markets and picked up some souveniers.

Great Photo Op for the Sydney Opera House!. Great place to visit and had some great looking restaurants! It was nice to take a stroll during the day and at night, plus the views of the Opera House are unmatched.

The place to watch Sydney Siders. A really great place to see the local folk wander by and to absorb what's going on. It's especially good to go on a Sunday morning, street entertainment and market without any traffic make for a great place to have brunch at leisure

friendly. I visited the Museum where I was met at the entrance by a lovely young lady who was more than willing to impart all her deep knowledge of the 'Rocks'. The actual museum is pretty limited in displays but informative. The tour of the old buildings again is limited but enjoyable. Apparently the 'rich' folks of Sydney appropriated the rocks area by devious and unscrupulous means, leaving very little for posterity. It is worthwhile giving it a visit.
Great spot. A MUST for all visitors to Sydney with shops, cafes, pubs, restaurants, views, entertainment and close to circular key and the CBD.
Enjoyable. Whilst Brian did the Bridge Climb - I had a cream tea in one of the little cafés in The Rocks. Also had a wonder round the outdoor market which is quire interesting.
Walking around. Just a short walk from the ferry terminal and so different. A large market, interesting shops and bars. A must when in Sydney

Hidden history.. Wander through the Rocks, stopping for a few beers along the way in the famous pubs.
Always seems to be something happening in the streets and the history is what makes Sydney.
There are restaurants and shops in the labyrinth if back streets and the food is good.

Interesting historic area of Sydney. Excellent restaurants, museums including Museum of Contemporary Art, many housed in old sandstone buildings. Also of interest are some of Sydney's oldest hotels, including The Lord Nelson and Hero of Waterloo. Home to some of Sydney's top hotels as well as Harbour Bridge as well as a short walk to the Opera House. Good shopping, luxury as well as markets.
Sunday morning markets. Lovely area - a tiny bit touristy, but very atmospheric area. Good market for souvenir-hunting and gift-buying, with an excellent Tourist Info Centre.
A must-see. When the weather's nice, this neighborhood is the best in Sydney! Stunning views of the harbor and harbor bridge, crooked stairs and hidden shops. It's easy to spend 3 hours there.

Amazing meandering . Really charming part of town with little alleys and lane ways everywhere. Charming little eateries and pubs everywhere. Sitting outside you can get glimpses of the bridge from certain places. Awesome place to explore and very rich in history.

Charming Rocks. It's al ways lovely to stroll around the rocks whether it's day or night. It has a lot of history,we visited the museum,very interesting. Walked up to Conservatorium which is also interesting & great views go Luna Park, Balmain etc.

cool neighborhood. This is a terrific neighborhood that has a great street market. There are several pastry shops and bakeries that serve excellent feta and spinach pies as well as meat pies for a reasonable lunch or dinner.

Lane filled with many cozy shops. Went there in the evening. Many shops selling UGG kind off boots and leather products. It is a cozy lane filled with many small shops. Sat and eat in a small cafe. Good area to just chill and maybe read a book, if you have the time.

The Angry Ant.. By all means take a walk around the Rocks area...some interesting views and also Pubs and restaurants (if you can afford to eat at them) but in all the older buildings are a treat to see. Get some "real" photos of the Harbor Bridge from the angle of "under the bridge"...pick your days...wanting people everywhere and street stalls...go weekend...if you want some quite and the ability to walk around...go mid week!

Plenty to see & Entertain. It's obviously primarily a tourist destination but nonetheless great fun if you go in the right spirit.Apart from the usual collection of tourist traps there are some great little shops & places to eat. If you explore the side streets you'll find some wonderful colonial architecture like the Garrison Church. Obviously there's the harbor traffic to watch & all sorts of street entertainers, some good & some not so. If you like modern art there's the MCA in George St North. All in all, plenty to keep you occupied & it needn't be expensive. It used to have somewhat of a rough reputation on weekend nights. Maybe it's calmed down but I suspect not. Like any big city best to be cautious where there are crowds & alcohol. At certain times of the year they have a moonlight market which is definitely worth a visit.

Pub and grub. Lots of pubs who serve food. We had dinner and drinks at one pub and breakfast at a small cafe, all reasonably priced and atmosphere and food good. Checkout the Museum of Contemporary Art for something a bit left of centre, or the Ken Done Gallery for iconic Australian Art. The Rocks Markets are great for quirky gifts with tea shops and coffee houses along each side.

Beautiful little spot!. It's a beautiful area to go shopping, spend your time and your money! It's a very tranquil area, in contrast with the hustle and bustle of the city. Definitely visit if you have some time on your hands!
Great area for a stroll. There are lots of good and varied restaurants and shops. It's a great place to stroll around, stop for a bite to eat or have a drink, and stroll some more!

My weekend getaway !. I live in Sydney about 30km from circular key at the Rocks the heritage area of Circular Quay and 10mins walk to the Opera House. My wife and I often just drive to the Quay and spend the day on a weekend just to get away from it all. We walk every where have lunch at the many restaurants, pubs, and market eateries there's no shortage of eateries. I always bring my SLR and shoot some great photos of the old Heritage Building, Harbour activities and street photography. There is an open market at the end of George Street every weekend. Just a few minutes from the commercial area is residential, where you see some old Victorian terrace houses, old schools,and quaint Chapels, old milk bars,and beautifully printed tiled Pubs that have been well preserved. We never tire of visiting "The Rocks, Sydney".

Market Buff. Had a great day at The Rocks browsing round the markets. Really unusual stuff. Had the best scones at an Irish cafe. Lots of pubs with great atmosphere with great entertainment. Plenty to do and see.
Nice area on a sunny day. This area has many good restaurants and cafe. Nice for a walk on a sunny day to enjoy the Harbour bridge view.
Must do location. Greats eats ( both restaurants and stalls), great shops, great views of Opera House and Bridge. Don't miss!

going to the rocks with mom. had a chance to take my mother to australia. while in sydney, we had a chance to be around the Rocks often. we had gone to a few restaurants and a few bars there. also on saturday and sunday, there is a farmers market/artisans show at the rocks. some of the arts and crafts are actually very neat. there are many hotels and many bars. also along with this, you are right next to the ferries, so very well placed. and on top of you is the sydney harbour bridge. wow.lots of fun to be had. maybe think about staying here directly.

Steeped in History. I love walking around the Rocks - the quaint old buildings hewn from convict stone - if only the walls could speak - it's easy to imagine what it was like 150 years ago - squalid tenements; drunken seamen and ladies of the night. Today it is a vibrant piece of history smack bang at the bottom of the CBD - a great place to wander; a huge choice of restaurants and bars - Go to the rooftop of the Glenmore Hotel in Cumberland Street for the best view in Sydney - all for the price of a beer - or two.
Walk about in the Rocks. Great area to walk, dine and a beer. Close to the harbor, lots of old buildings re-purposed for relaxed tourist environment. Good place for lunch
An area with something for everyone. Shops, Bars, Restaurants, Historical sites, Hotels, you name it The Rocks has it - and all within a reasonably compact area.

The best views of Sydney Harbour. The Rocks offers some of the best views of Sydney Harbour with excellent restaurants, patisserie, pubs and hotels. From her you can admire the Harbour Bridge, Opera House and have access to ferries, trains and buses. The Sydney Theatre is within easy reach as is the CBD.

The Rocks Market. I love the artiste stalls selling home made jewellery ,art, soap, home wares and etc. When you feel tired , lots of pubs and cafe just round the corner.Simply love the German pork knuckle and beer at Luwenbrau .
Beautiful. This was a great side trip we took. It is beautiful with beautiful views. You can spend the whole day there taking it all in. Try to go if you are in the area.

Quaint shops at The Rocks. Visited The Rocks with friends wandered through the market stalls & the shops. Market stalls are great & are cheaper than their shop equivalent. After a lengthy time exploring & shopping we went to TheTea Cosy where we enjoyed a delicious lunch of ribbon sandwiches, plough mans lunch & Devonshire tea was scrumptious works highly recommend this.

It's the happening Place. The Rocks its where it's at. Great restaurants, cafe's and bars, the footings of the Sydney Harbour Bridge and adjacent to Circular Queue - where you can catch the ferries to other parts of the harbour, excellent views of the Sydney Opera House.

Relatively new hostel at the Rocks... This hostel is really kool, as from the rooftop you get an excellent view of the bridge and opera house. It really is an great view. This hostel is only a few years old,and has some historical value on ground level. ie archival findings from the past...there are alot of rooms at this one, and vacancies should not be a problem, at any time. > Sydney Harbor YHA on Cumberland.....
Lovely part of sydney!. Love the rocks, trendy, hip, and bohemian! Gorgeous part of Sydney to spend a day! Bars are col, markets are funky - plenty of shopping and choice!
Great weekend market!. Was fortunate to be there over the weekend and visited the market twice as easily reached via the free City Shuttle which operates till late afternoon on Saturdays.

A great spot night and day. Lots on offer ...the MOMA, for the culture vultures, pubs, cafes and restaurants galore. John Cadman's cottage, The Argyle centre and the Sydney international cruise terminal 'must sees'....the Irish pub, or the Orient for live music! and the Rocks Market on the weekend! Spoilt for choice!

Stunning :). The Rocks is historic Sydney at its best! This is a very safe place where you're truly able to bring your family even your lil ones on the day lights or nights :) Tons of Beautiful restaurants and cafés also traditional pubs, Clean and neat area with impressive cute little alleys to explore, Great ambience, Packed with Amazing historic buildings around you and ahhh how can I forgot to mention about the modern street arts?? for some people (including myself) The Rocks might be the great place for selfies! (duck face anyone? ;) Nice walk and Excellent place..Another Good place to be hang out with family..You haven't been really in Sydney if you haven't been to The Rocks!...and tothe Opera House...and to the Circular Quay also the Darling Harbour...oooohh and the Botanical Garden too..hhhmm so many beautiful places to go when you are in Sydney but you should really start with The Rocks! Or the Opera House..Or the Darling Harbour???
Great day out.. The weekend markets are full of people, great food and lot's to see. The oldest pubs in Australia are a must to have a drink in.
A favorite!. Our favorite area of Sydney - lots of shopping and eating. We especially enjoyed the open air market/vendors on the weekend.

OLD SYDNEY - THE ROCKS. I have been several times to The Rocks and visited the market, which seemed to have less stalls this time, However, it is always interesting to wander amongst the buildings and streets and there is something new to find each time.
Typical Rocks weekend.. Historical shops/buildings, the Aromas festival was on and yes there were plenty of aromas to be smelt, good and bad. Just so crowded as per usual.

Lots of eateries. When we went to do the bridge climb we walked through The Rocks district which is an older section of Sydney. It has historical old buildings with quaint little shops and eateries. We ate at a little sidewalk cafe and just enjoyed the view. It is a nice place to go for lunch or dinner. Once again, a very safe place.

Old meets new. The rocks never fails to reveal new points of interest, no matter how frequently you visit. Discovering a new exhibition or gallery, the busy clatter and bustle of the markets on a Sunday afternoon, with people jostling for position, to re-examining l the mix of old and new architecture. Great place to while away a couple of hours in Sydney.

Soak up a taste of historic Sydney. It's busy with tourists but always worth a walk around The Rocks, hopefully with a person or a guidebook who can tell you about Australia's history. Lovely buildings and if you ignore the Ugg shops, you can get a wonderful sense of where Australia began.

A stroll amongst The Rocks. Beautifully restored area of Sydney. Plenty of traditional pubs with excellent beer and food. Restaurants galore, trendy bars, a host of shops. The weekend markets are a must and the food available is brilliant. Brilliant free walking tour which will get you up to speed with the history of the area. You could spend the whole holiday in The Rocks.
Really nice. Is the old part of Sydney, unfortunatlly like everything they create shops everywhere in there but even that still a good place to vist even romantic if u want be there for one date!

Quality Unique Shopping. The Rocks has an art market on Saturday/ Sunday. Well worth a visit. I found some of the nicest gifts for my friends and family. This is quality arts, crafts, photo's, etc. I highly recommend it.
The Rocks Orient Hotel weekdays. Ambiance was great with excellent value fine dining in the upstairs restaurant and not too crowded during the day especially enjoyable if the sun is shining

Walk through history. This is a beautifully restored area of Sydney with magnificent old buildings and great water views. The Rocks has some of the quaintest little pubs and restaurants you will find anywhere. The prices can be a bit high, but it is certainly worth spending a bit of time here.

Must do place. When in Sydney you must visit the historical Rocks area. Markets on weekends, plenty of eating options and loads of history. Make sure you get a map of the area so you can find the little hidden pieces of a bygone era. Beautiful sandstone buildings, old pubs with great ales, simply a must do place! Enjoy

A glimpse of some of early Sydney. A walk around this area is very rewarding. Especially if you keep away from the touristy shopping area. The old streets are well worth the walk. The houses, old building and their gardens are well worth a look see.
Diverse Sunday market stalls. Great market stalls. Too many souvenir options to buy! The Hop-on Hop-off bus stops just right outside, making it very convenient to visit.

Historic area of Sydney. The is the best area to explore the old days of Sydney and enjoy some great bars and cafes. You get to walk around all the old places in Sydney, and when you get thirsty or hungry, there are so many places to stop off and grab a bite or have a few drinks. And lots of photo shoots of the Sydney Harbour Bridge and Opera House.
Great Markets and food. Great place to visit and check out the markets, eat some street food and listen to the buskers play. Love coming here every couple of months for a chilled out Sunday afternoon

Makes for a nice walk about. This is where Sydney started. It's got some of the oldest extant architecture in Australia. It makes for a nice walk. The neighborhood isn't all that large and can easily be strolled in an hour or less, but it depends on how much stopping you do for shopping or eating/drinking. It's proximity to the cruise port (literally at the base of the neighborhood), makes it an attractive, easy-to-get-to spot to enjoy a bit of Sydney. I thought in general, the quality of souvenir shopping in this neighborhood was higher quality than what I saw in other areas. Your mileage or opinion may vary.
Markets. Great area to visit. Markets on the weekends are full of interesting items and good eats.Some really fine cafe's and restaurants in the area.
Loved the markets. The rocks markets are a must-do. Other than that, plenty of shopping and eating options. Great for all the family.

Enjoyable older part of Sydney a must see!. I just left the Aroma Festival in The Rocks featuring booths of coffee, tea and chocolate samples. Thousands of people so crowded but traffic flowed well as George Street was closed in Campbell's Cove area. I loved the older buildings still showing the vintage facades. I even had a beer in the Fortune of War - Sydney's oldest pub. There is even a weekend market for vendors selling crafts, artwork, jewelry, foods. Some really unique items at the Market so don't miss it (Sat and Sun 10a - 5p).

A favorite place. Lots of history here,you can do a walking tour. Many cafes,restaurants and unusual shops.The Rocks markets on the weekend are excellent.Always busy,but not crowded (unless it's New Years Eve!)

Best part of Sydney. Definitely the highlight of our trip. Beautiful heritage and architecture, especially if you get off the tourist streets. Lots of great restaurants. Don't bother with the street markets.

Rocking it at the Rocks. Loved our time visiting this historic and interesting part of Sydney. We were there on a Saturday so the Rocks Markets were in full swing. There were so many stalls to browse and some great entertainment happening. We had the best devonshire tea at a quaint little shop and thoroughly enjoyed a tour through the Susannah Place museum. This is not really a museum but 4 original terraces which have been preserved through the different era's in which they have been occupied. It was great value for money and the guide was obviously so passionate about the history she made it come alive. We really enjoyed a drink in one of the historic pubs and I would have to say the Rocks would be one of the highlights of our trip.
simple yet unique. beautiful place with a special charm of its own. cute shops and unique experience. surely must visit place when in sydney.
great little market. This market was a little different than the Chinese Market, handmade things and things a little different from the norm. Well worth a visit.

Definitely visit The Rocks. One of the oldest parts of the city, The Rocks has been delightfully preserved and restored and now offers some chic shopping opportunities, quaint and highly atmospheric cafes and restaurants plus the odd Pub or two, including the oldest in Sydney.
