Great Location. Our hotel was located in The Rocks, which made everything within walking distance. There are plenty great eating and drinking establishments in The Rocks. We made sure to visit two that claim to be the oldest pubs in Sydney. On the weekend there is a great street fair in this area.
Exciting and Varied. Great buzz in the area. Th markets were on and the array of stalls was fabulous and very 'tasty'! Definitely worth a visit. I think they are on Fridays.

Great place for a brunch or evening drink. Very cute little neighborhood. Perhaps a bit touristy, but with good cause. Worth spending a little time exploring (30 minutes will let you see pretty much everything) and then stop for a meal or drink in one of the many little restaurants, bars, or cafes in the area.
Travel back in time. An exhilarating place to look for bargain souvenirs, pubs everywhere indicative of how the place used to be. A great place to unwind after an adventurous harbor bridge climb. :)

Not the most fantastic market. Visited the rocks market on sunday and it was ok. But no great. There were many stalls selling quirky stuffs. But maybe because Ive also seen those stuffs selling at many different parts of the world so... The art prints or paintings sold there werent that great too.. There's this stall with fantastic vintage posters and postcards replicas for keeping though..
Worth visiting. There is nothing particular to visit but it is a nice area to walk around full of quirky pubs and over priced eateries. Great views of the Harbour and Opera House.

Sydney History. The Rocks area is situated at the southern end of the Harbour Bridge and around to Circular Quay. It was one of the early settlements and contains many historic buildings, most of them built from the typical Sydney sandstone. It is a souvenir hunters delight, but like most sites, don't expect to find many genuine items, (ie made in Australia, not China, Japan, etc.) particularly if you are wanting Aboriginal artifacts. There are dozens of restaurants, the best being alongside the harbour at Circular Quay where you will always find buskers and also the Harbour Ferry wharves. Walking around the Rocks area is the only option really as car parking is rare and expensive, however the area has many steep streets, alleyways and stairs.
Interesting. A good place to get some food and a drink, an amazing place to people watch and soak up the atmosphere of Sydney too.

Mystical. Thank goodness this area has been listed so that it cannot be changed.Its a testament to the men and women who first travelled to Australia, convicts or not. This are is like an old English town.

awesome food and nightlife!. The rocks have never disappointed me! the restaurants are amazing, the night-life is always a good time and on the weekends the market is such a good way to spend your day!
good. had a great breakfast at the rocks. was a nice quiet little place during the day. i can imagine at night time it would get busy

The Rocks - A great place for business dinner. . Went to The Rocks for a business dinner with colleagues. The atmosphere is very nice - it's buzzy without being too loud. The decor and architecture, being an old bank - all add to the experience. For starters we had the house chopped salad, the crab , and steak tartar and oysters all of which were very nice. Also I had to take a phone call for about ten minutes and our waiter noticed I was away and waited to bring the food until I returned which was nice. We all had different steaks all cooked perfectly. The bone in Rib Eye was particularly nice. For dessert only one person ordered ( me !) The salted Carmel and chocolate tart was excellent. All in all an excellent meal. Although price wise if you are there on expense account you might be glad you are.
Great Shopping & food. We spent most of a saturday walking through the shops and the artist tents that were set up. We found some of the best and most unique shopping here.
The Rocks - a different view of Sydney. Very pleasant area. Many bars and restaurants away from the newer more busy Sydney. One of Sydney's very diversified areas

You can feel this history. My Dad used to tell me about the notorious people that lived in and around the rocks when he was growing up. That was in the early 1920's and his stories intrigued me. He use to tell me about the "Hole in the Wall Gang" and the "Razor Gang", I have forgotten the details now but Dad made it sound very exciting. My husband and I have gone to The Rocks for lunch and dinner often and to just catch up with family. It's a great place to just walk around and turn up little lanes and walk ways. It is probably the richest spot in Sydney historically and as I walk around there, I think of the stories Dad told me and feel very pleased we have kept the old features of the area. There are lots of good restaurants, art galleries and of course, the harbour. It's all just there.
Interesting. A taste of what Sydney looked like 100 years ago. About the only central area that is still "historic" in its appearance.
The Rocks. See a bit of the old Sydney, lovely buildings and lots of things to see and do. Great for a day of walking.
Fantastic street markets and great cafes. This is one of the must do locations when visiting Sydney. Great street markets, shopping, pubs and cafes. If you're in Sydney you have to go to the Rocks!

Rocks walk and Market. A must when in Sydney - the market is held Saturday and Sundays - there is a tourist information centre in the middle of the rocks to grab some ideas of what to do whilst in Sydney
Fun shopping!. The Rocks is a great area for shopping and dining! When looking for unique souvenirs, something can certainly be found at The Rocks!
Not really nice for me. I did not enjoy walking around the area. I find the bargain items still expensive. but to be fair, the foods sold around the place are reasonably priced.

Our favorite Sydney neighborhood!. We loved this area of Sydney and spent hours walking around and visiting all of the shops and pubs. We bought a digeradoo at Spirit Gallery, ate breakfast one morning at La Renaissance Cafe (a wonderful patisserie), popped in for a Belgian hot chocolate, perused a swanky upscale mall, visited a free historic museum about the area and drank a few too many beers at some great pubs including The Orient and Fortune of War (there were a few others that I can't remember). Highly recommended.

Nice, but nothing too special.. Lots of restaurants to choose from. We did not a take a historical walking tour, but that may have enhanced our appreciation for the area. The street market was nice, but really not much different from the typical street art fair that I have seen in many places. There were a few Australian souvenirs that I thought were nice.

History and Shops. Get one of the free self-guided walking tour brochures online and read about Rocks history, walk the paths and enjoy the shops and crowds in between historic sites. On a beautiful day, it's easy to walk from one area to the other around Sydney Harbor. It can be as relaxing or as busy as you like.
Wander thru Time. Part of Sydney's earliest European history with buildings frozen in time. While it may not be the oldest architecture in the world, its Sydney's oldest.

Pub-to-pub-to-pub. An Icon of old Sydney, not surprisingly dominated by a large police station and a lot of pubs. The question to ponder, which came first (first after the convicts that is)? Aside from establishments in which to indulge in a libation (and be warned, most of them are pretty dusty old venues) there is a number of small boutique galleries and interesting stores. Often a market or two. You can while away an afternoon easily, do your research on where to eat first or risk being caught in a trap for cruise tourists.

Very Unique. Spent the morning walking the streets and alleys of The Rocks with weekend markets. What a great place to relax, enjoy a latte and people watch. Some great bargains and fantastic creations available for souvenirs to purchase. Reminds me of Tasmania .

The heart of the Action. Walking distance to the Harbour, the Opera House, the Botanical Gardens and the ferries. A great place to feel the past (crowded) life of colonial Sydney.Attend the markets on the weekend and watch out for local specialist markets and one off events - we were in town for some Regional Food and Wine exhibition - food and wine tents lining the cobblestones giving free samples and selling their wares. 5 little glasses of shiraz and merlot before the morning coffee made for an interesting day!

Interesting. We spent a Friday afternoon wandering around the markets and shops.It was a lot of fun.Looking at all the historic buildings with our kids was very interesting the views of the harbour was a great backdrop to the afternoon.I recommend a trip to Sticky watching them make rock candy was so fun and also TASTY.

History and shops. The rocks continues the stroll from Circular Quay and is full of history. There are also markets and numerous speciality shops and galleries. It feels like I always come across something new each time I visit. A worthy place to stroll aware a few hours.

The Rocks Rock. We went on Friday for the markets. It was marvellous. We had the most awesome Turkish pancakes, bought cufflinks made of watch parts, explored the rocks museum, browsed the wonderful shops and spend ages people watching. It's a fabulous place, but beware, hours disappear before you know it!

History. An afternoon spent exploring the Rocks is a fantastic way to get to see some of the oldest parts of Sydney. There are cafes, restaurants, pubs and boutique shops for those who just have to spend money, but the area is fantastic and don't forget to walk around Circular Quay.
Great shopping.. Really lovely shopping/dining area for a more personal shopping experience. I revisit every time. Go for pancakes too!

Tourista. The Rocks is a tourist area that has been popular for as long as I can recall. I stay out of it because I don't like the grasping nature of the shops, bars and restaurants. However, it is interesting historically, and it is a great place to go for a bachelor party or similar.

Interesting market. The Rocks had many kind of intereting things. Clothes, food, craftworks and so on. The most impressive thing is very small ceramic doll. I saw a kangaroo doll which was just 2cm height. But, it's very sophisticated! It even had a baby kangaroo in its pocket!!! I had no option but to buy it.
Time travel in The Rocks. In the Rocks you can travel from 2014 to the 1800's. Explore Sydney history including Cadmans Cottage built 1816

Lazy Sunday Afternoon. We strolled around the markets, had a great burger for lunch and watched sweets being made at a lolly shop in a small arcade. 1 day was not enough, there is a lot to see in this district!
Feel the history. The Rocks area has a great historical feel to it. Great food, markets, views of the Bridge, opera house & close to Circular quay for a wine & meal.
Rocks WOW. We went to Pancakes on the Rocks and wandered around the markets, what a fantastic day. Cant wait to do it again.

Nice walk. Good restaurants. Excellent market.. Our family of 4 went there on a Sunday afternoon after coming back from Manly. There were lots of tourists at the open market. The market is like normal art-and-craft market with jewelry, clothing, touristy stuffs, etc. It's a good way to burn 1-2 hours strolling around.

The Rocks Markets. If you love Australian history or just want to get into the atmosphere of an earlier era, then the Rocks is an important place to visit. My visit happened on a Saturday and I saw the markets at The Rocks. The Irish pubs and the lovely little Irish style tea rooms in the old cottages are really quaint. The markets provide a good selection of goods and mostly hand crafted from a very mixed ethnic group is exciting.

Step back in time at The Rocks. The Rocks is well worth exploring. Start your journey at The Rocks Museum to get a taste of life in Early Australia through go the present day. Fun interactive things for the kids to do which helps to leave an impression of those early years. Then explore the streets and lane ways and use the stone staircases to go from one level to another and discover interesting shops, galleries and cafés. Well signposted to help you find your way. Something for everyone.Enjoy!

Go to the Free Museum on Kendall Lane. The Rocks is very touristy and the shops and cares are "seen you coming" places, but you still have to tick it off your list of places to go in Sydney. It has a lot of history, so it's worth going to the free museum on Kendall Lane. There are activities for children to do, which is useful. It's only a small place but there is plenty of information. There are a number of films about Sydney, The Rocks and The Bridge on a continuous loop, each about 7 minutes long. It was great for Free. It was too small though to not be free. Even so, you could actually spend ages in there if you read or investigated every display.
Busy. Always something to look at from shops to markets. Great for the whole family. Very uneven surfaces tho,

The Rocks Weekend Market. The Rocks Markets is a cool little spot where you can spend on weekends exploring the cool stalls where you can find some equally cool gifts. You can find a variety of fashion, jewellery, art and food stalls, all on the backdrop of the iconic Sydney Harbour Bridge and Opera house.Sunny weekends are the best time to come and experience the sights, sounds, smells and fun of The Rocks weekend markets.I would recommend checking out the range of great food options around the area, the stalls can be a bit pricey for gifts, but stall owners are friendly and helpful for the most part. Check out my pictorial tour on my blog to get a feel for what the markets are like:http://www.downtofeed.com.au/p/the-rocks-weekend-market.html
The rocks. Short stroll from the harbour ferries. Unique and quaint with many restaurants. Friendly people. History abounds in architecture and layout . Enjoyed every minute.

Great weekend market. I think the best thing of the Rocks is its weekend market with variety of stalls that sells food, accessories, gift etc. It's a nice experience to walk along the market. Try to experience this market while you are in Sydney.The Rocks is surrounded by restaurants and cafes. There is one Germany reataurant with serves great pork knuckle and beer. This area becomes alive during weekend, besides the weekend market, people enjoys dining here. It's located near Sydney harbour, an integrated ferry terminal, train station and small bus "terminal" and it's also near the Sydney Opera house.

The place to be on a Sunday!. "The Rocks" is a shopping area along with Different places to eat and drink,just beside Circular Quay we went there on a Sunday morning and there was a street market in place with over thirty different stalls. it is a great place to fill time if you are waiting on a Ferry.

Nice area. The Rocks is a wonderful neighborhood in Sydney. Lovely restaurants, shops, bars, cafés, museums.....walking around here is a must. You should spend at least one day here. Great food, great vibe, great sights. Located close to the Sydney Harbour, you can combine this with a visit to the Sydney Harbour Bridge and the Opera House. Highly recommended.

Why Else?. Want food? Want history? Just want a beer? The Rocks has all of this. Plus, you get to see the Harbor Bridge!! Bugger, you can climb it if you want to!! Then, take yourself over to Darling Harbor, I'm pretty sure that was named after my wife eh!
LOVE THIS PLACE. Always stay here when in Sydney. Close to ferries and city. Awesome atmosphere, so many pubs and cafés. Always something new to discover every visit. Highly recommend staying here.
it rocks. Great time walking around the markets at the rocks and then wondering around the area, we had a great walk and just soaked up the atmosphere.

The Rocks totally rocks.. I loved hanging out in the many bars and restaurants that are located in the rocks. Most of my evenings in Sydney resulted in my friends & I in the many pubs there. It was SO fun and I wish I could be there as I'm typing this-- so fun!

Great area!. This is a great area for eating and there is also a good craft /street market. It has been regenerated, so is a very attractive area too. Nice to just walk around. Can be found near the "foot" of the bridge on Circular Quay side. On the downside it can get very busy at night, but then so can the whole of Sydney!
Hyped. OK, what about The Rocks? It's hyped by so many people that you'll feel obliged to go. However, there are better places in Sydney, such as Surrey Hills.

Historical Sydney. If there's one thing never to miss when visiting Sydney that would be a Rocks walking tour. Such an in site into Sydney's original Rocks all preserved for our enjoyment. You will be amazed by the heritage buildings condition and just such a good feel.
Great markets. Always buzzing with great weekend markets and food. I always love going there when I visit Sydney. Markets have a lot of unique things
Sunday Markets. What a great way to fill in some time in Sydney. We wandered through the interesting street markets and had lunch at one of the cafés.

History starts here..... Its a place you must visit while in Sydney. Highly recommend this legend, this place is very interesting and has a lot information about Sydney's origins and how it comes and developed into a very sophisticated and very popular city in the world. Very easy to get here, by bus, by train, and if you enjoy walking, maybe its just about 30 minutes walk from Darling Harbour. One day is not enough to get to see the ins and outs of the neighboring attractions, like the Opera House, the Botanical garden, etc. etc. Lots of café house, restaurants, and on weekends, have the Rocks Markets, which is more upscale and lots of goodies to purchase. This is really one of a kind, must visit The Rocks.

History. I love the Rocks, its quaint little village feel in the heart of the city, with the harbor bridge and opera house peeking through at every turn. There is one thing that the Rocks needs to do, and that is up the tourism there. Its always just a little too quiet (except on a Friday when the food markets are on). I think there is a lot more that the rocks has to offer that Sydney tourism needs to capatalise on.

Sydney Harbour Vantage Points. I lived in The Rocks for 15 years. There's plenty of attractions. Start in George Street at The Museum of Contemporary Art walk across to historic Cadman's Cottage, past the status of Governor Phillip and towards the overseas shipping terminal, opposite the Opera House. Pick up some tourist brochures there with a map. Lunch at any number of waterfront restaurants there. Continue walking around under the Harbour Bridge on Hickson a Road to Walsh Bay Wharves, home of the Sydney Theatre and Dance companies. Views across to North Sydney. Take the steps back up to Millers Point in Argyle Street. From there you can have a drink at The Lord Nelson Hotel, with it's own beer brewed on the premises. Walk further to the Garrison Church, Australia's first church. You can go for a walk from the bus terminus there up Observatory Hill and see out to Sydney Heads from there. The Bureau if Meteorology is up there and you can go in and view a great presentation if how the weather is predicted. You can also learn about the harbour's history and importance to the colony of Sydney. The S H Irwin Gallery and the National Trust is also,up there if you are interested in viewing art and objects of preservation. You can walk across the Harbour Bridge from there and back across the other side. There are signs everywhere. It's free, unlike the expensive Bridge Walk, where you are chained in and walk up over the steel arch of the longest single span arch bridge in the world. If you want to do the bridge walk, you can book that via their office in Cumberland St. Continue along Cumberland St and you will find old pubs, archeological remains of old 18th C houses and various museums, such as Museum of Childhood and Mary Reby's convict history. Just wander. It's the best way to discover that part of Sydney. There's also plenty of shopping, including duty free. On Sat-Sun there is a street market.

Love The Rocks. Adjacent to Circular Quay and a short walk away, the area has a number of small restaurants and bars, and small shops. Take in the large "craft" shows on weekends, featuring a big variety of offerings from clothing to jewelry to home decor. Many different vendors and hand-made items. We enjoyed!

The Rocks a fascinating walk through history with plenty of refreshment and shopping stops.. This area has plenty of good places to eat and shop. It is the oldest part of sydney which was saved from demolitions many decades ago. You can stay as short or as long as you like but I recommend a couple of hours which would include a refreshment break. It is right on the harbour.

Lots of history to see. Probably the best part of Sydney if you want to see Sydney's origins and feel what it used to be. It has retained much of the character of the past whilst the rest of Sydney is constantly changing and "progressing". Easily accessible by train, bus or ferry. Lots of shopping , cafes and bars if you want a break from history.

Lively and interesting. Really enjoyed The Rocks area . It's a regeneration of the area where the first settlers landed and set up homes both large and small. There is Cadmans Cottage, the oldest house in Sydney built in 1816, cobbled streets and lots of other old buildings now mostly housing cafés, bars and galleries. Some lovely restaurants harbour side, fascinating buildings and great views of the Harbour Bridge. The atmospheric weekend market was good with lots of local craft stalls. An eclectic mix of old and new very cleverly woven together.

Try the weekends. From Friday night to Sunday, there are the Rocks markets and an entirely different market as compared to those found at Paddy's Market in Chinatown or Paddington markets. The Rocks Markets seems more upscale and products found different to what we saw at the other markets. This plus the ambience of the Rocks, the restaurants, shops,heritage buildings, etc. makes it a must see.
Quaint. This is quaint area in Sydney with a fair bit of history. Its great to walk around in the day and in the night with a lot of bars and restaurants.
A place to relax. It's a perfect spot for relaxing! See the whole view of sydney opera house and the sydney harbour bridge! You can even read a book or sleep on the grass! Perfect!

A must see historic place. The rocks area is stepped in history with some fantastic photo opportunities as well. A lovely variety of quaint shops and restaurants. Plan your visit for a weekend if possible and visit the market at the same time. Well worth a visit.

So much history. Amazing history, beautiful buildings and great nightlife all in one place. Best explored on foot as there are many hidden gems. The rocks allows you to really appreciate the history of Sydney and the settlers, but is also an amazing place to drink and eat - well worth a couple of days out of your schedule!

The Rocks at Sydney. There is a free bus service from Meriton Apt, Campbell street to The Rocks.
Very nice architecture at the Rocks.
Went to "Pancakes on the Rocks" and the pancakes are delicious.
Also wen to this café, Le Pain Quotidien which was once an old prison cell (if I remember correctly). Nice coffee and bread served.

Interesting for a first timer. You can find lots of interesting stuff at the Rocks though most of them are priced higher than items found at markets like Paddy's. Its easily accessible from the city by train (stops at Circular Quay station) or bus (use the Google map that helps with bus schedules and routes).We enjoyed going there on 2 Saturdays - a must visit is the Honey Bee shop, Pancake on the Rocks and a stall selling homemade fudge. Along the way, you can also enjoy corn on a stick.

Nice, quirky but a little bit costly!. I went to the Rocks to take photos and ended up sitting down and having a coffee. They had some nice markets selling foreign foods and i was almost about to buy some until i saw the prices. Really charming place and atmosphere!
Busy busy. What a great place to sit ,eat ,drink and enjoy the opera house, circular quay sights.a lovely sunny tourist packed place but does not put you off.

Nice history, hidden next to massive office towers. Great character neighborhood, with plenty of exciting shops and restaurants. The weekend market is filled with all sorts of exciting booths, with trinkets, jewelry, clothing, etc.

Return To Rocks. On our recent trip to Sydney we did a return visit to The Rocks more particularly the weekend market. Many of the stalls we remember from previous visits were still there which was good to see together with some new ones. The score of the day was a birthday gift for son-in-law an avid Star Wars fame - a limited edition framed print containing a Return of Jedi print and 3 photo cells. Cafes still abound in plenty and seemed to be doing a fantastic trade in the glorious weather and we enjoyed a coffee and pastry in the courtyard of a French type café.

A great, fun way to spend an afternoon. My husband and I only had 3 days in Sydney. We chose one afternoon to devote to the Rocks. We should have given ourselves more time! We walked all around, stopped at friendly pubs (and, of course, sampled the wares), looked in shop windows, visited some beautiful and historic churches. The streets wind around but are easy to navigate. The area is close to the downtown area and worth the time spent.

A delightful detour that does not empty the pocketbook.. The Rocks area is art deco, homes made of rocks, shops, dining if you like, or just browsing and exploring every corner. As with all of Sydney, the shop keepers and street food vendors were delighrfully welcoming. Everyone seemed to have a story or stories to tell on the history of the area, Circular Quay which was within walking distance, their own BridgeClimb (we had just finished ours when we walked over to the Rocks, and the Discovery Museum is a must see. If for no other reason than there is no charge which after some sticker shock at Sydney restaurants and stores was a welcome break. VIVID was awesome here to and if you can plan your visit to Sydney around VIVID, I would definitely do. It is well worth what will probably be more crowds than usual as well as some event pricing at hotels. The fact you can walk to all these areas of Sydney that are so inviting and interesting is a great bonus. Reminds me of the hills of San Francisco but a bit cleaner, fresher, and even more vibrant.
Rock on The Rocks. Great good shops and tourist info all on the original landing site in Sydney. Close by (10 mins walk) the Lord Nelson brewery pub well worth a visit for pub grub and good ale.

Beautiful Art Deco Area. We spent several hours walking around taking in the quaint area with much history. The markets were on the day we were there as an added bonus. Easy walk from the city or you can get on the free bus.
Love the food market. Friday market was awesome the food was delicious and a lot of fun plenty of bars and restaurants as well if going there for fun.

Discovery Museum , Rocks Sydney. This museum is fairly new. Entry is free.A very interesting visual and audio presentation of the early history of Sydney and this area in particular.Very hands on and most interesting exhibits of early implements associated with the area.Lovely restaurants and shops nearby, next to Circular Quay.A lovely day out to this area, and very accessible.A ferry ride after is just the thing to make your day complete and get a real feel for how Sydney developed, especially the bridge.Top class!!!
like a rocks star. yea, it rocked like you knew it would ... bring your old friends, or your newest acquaintances and enjoy
Not a big area but fabulous. It's really just a small little pocket, but such a fabulous and interesting spot to wander around. Great cafes and pubs, little lanes and history plus. A must see
Awesome Pancakes. You want Yumiee Pancakes..??? Go to the Rocks.. You want the best view and service..???? Go to the ROCKS....

I love it!. I minute I turned into the area from the Circular Quay Station it felt fantastic. I wish I had longer to spend here. I loved the vibrancy, the history (although I was told there was no history here), the friendliness (I popped into Syndey's oldest pub for one drink and didn't leave for 4 hours) and the general vivacity of the whole area. Looking at the Opera House is so surreal - it's like being on a film set. I kept finding myself stopping and looking at it and throughly enjoyed coming into the harbour by boat to see it from another angle. The Harbour Bridge thrilled me less, it looks better with fireworks coming out of it but that didn't stop me climbing it.

Step back in time. You feel like you've travelled back in time when visiting this area. Exploring all the tiny alleys and nooks and crannies of this place is so much fun. The markets on Saturday and Sunday are a must!

The Rocks - where the old meet the new. Explore the Rocks, it's old buildings and historical and heritage sites perched on the edge of beautiful Sydney Harbour. Visit the shops, art galleries, restaurants and the Rocks Markets. There's something for everyone

Plenty of places to eat. I had been to Darling Harbour a few times, but decided to explore the other side, The Rocks. Plenty of places to eat here, but so busy during Vivid that it was hard to find popular places without a queue.

Pleasant walk amongst friendly people. Have been to Sydney on a number of occasions and always end up at the rocks, This place is easy to navigate with plenty of shops to while away the time....if you truly want to just sit and ponder all the history at your feet just pitch up in one of the cafes, order a coffee and just sit.....i guarentee if you sit outside someone will just say hi as they walk pastStress free and simple.........exquisite

Great for History Lovers. The historic centre for Sydney and European arrival into Australia. Easy to navigate around on foot. Plenty of bars, shops and restaurants, but as it is a tourist hub, few bargains

Great on Saturday. The Rocks comes alive on Saturday, when the flea market vendors open there shops. There's restaurants, entertainment, museum's and lots of different things to buy.Great for the young, old and families

A Must in Sydney. I love The Rocks. Recently took some visitors here and they thoroughly enjoyed wandering around the lane ways, taking in the history. The markets are good and it's a great atmosphere and a drink at a pub, like the Phillips Foote or Lord Nelson are must. For families, there is a lot for kids to take in relating to Sydney's history, so make sure you visit The Rocks information for a history guide.

Amazing historic area. You can walk around the alleys of he rocks for hours, visit the shops and get a real sense of early Australia. Many great restaurants and pubs. Make sure you visit the puppet shop, this is a really a treat.

Historical Corner. The Rocks area is so steeped in history that almost every building there seems to have a story. Sometimes however if you get back to the history of that building, you might be forgiven for thinking that the history being referred to is a little too local for a traveller from abroad. That said (and I did not mean to trivialize the history so painstakingly and admirably being restored and maintained by the Sydney-siders) the Rocks has just so many of them to see and admire and pose for photo-op's that you can spend at least half-a-day (hurriedly) and two days (relaxedly). Go for it and stay somewhere in the Rocks to make that visit to Sydney a memorable one.

Love The Rocks. Love walking around The Rocks on a Sunday. Plenty of drinking and eating places. Try The Pony Lounge awesome food and cocktails (though some of the staff are clueless). The Argyle Tavern is great for drinks.

Awesome, historical part of Sydney to walk around or grab some drinks. I loved The Rocks District in Sydney, we did a pub tour and had so much fun!! There is so much history for each pub and the area in general, which was very interesting. There were so many nice markets, and I went during the lights festival so it looked really cool off some of the old buildings. Definitely walk around if you get a chance!

The Rocks - I'm Free 6.00pm Tour. Low key run by the team in the green shirts - certainly value for money because you pay what you think the guide is worth. Meet the guide at Cadman's College. The stories of past convict deeds are retold as you access back alleys and view locations around The Rocks you may never think of visiting by yourself. Always good to be in company at night in this area. Walk is at a pleasant pace and guides have an ability to manage and personalise diverse groups of people. Recommend. Which is the oldest hotel in a Sydney? I did tip the guide because he was worth it - I stood off the group but he made contact - drew me in and attempts to be attentive to the groups needs - remember you can do it for free if you choose!
If u need anything. Worth a visit if you need anything. Shopping is good. Not a huge mall but sells most stuff. Restaurants and bars are plenty.
Great Markets. We shop at these markets found all sorts off goodies, great food , music and bargain's to be had, don't miss them.

Quaint. Love wandering through The Rocks, great places to stop for a drink and bite to eat. The Markets are worth a wander and some cool little shops tucked away - was thrown by the Mooloolaba shirt in a shop! Ugg Boots Galore. Little galleries tucked here and there are worth a look.

Nice view from the International Passenger Terminal. I walked from Darling Harbor to the Rocks. There was a market there with stalls selling sausages, and clothing. I heard that on Fridays they have a foodie day there with various food stalls.
Off the Beaten Track. The Rocks is a wonderful little group of neighborhood shops, galleries, cafes. Located a few minutes from the Sydney Harbor, it is a real feel of old Sydney.
Fantastic for a date. This place has so many good bars and restaurants. The markets on the weekend are also worth a visit. I've had some great nights out here too just jumping from bar to bar.

Historical Neighbourhood. We spent a long enjoyable afternoon wandering around this area taking in the week-end market. Lots to see and do with buskers on the street, treasures to find and treats to eat & drink. I found two bundles of round type sterling soup spoons to compliment my collection at a bargain price & couldn't resist. They did require an explanation and secondary inspection going through Hong Kong on the way home to make sure they weren't forks. A great place for a relaxing tour when you're in Sydney and you need a down day from racing around. We were a week in Sydney in June 2008 and chuckled at the signs for mid-winter sales. It was 21 C at the time & of course they know you're Canadian when you're in tee shirt & shorts.

Old Sydney. Thank goodness the locals objected to redevelopment & their lobbying & demonstrations saved the day.Without that an interesting area of Sydney would have been lost no doubt to concrete & high rise tower blocks.See Sydney as it was with many interesting bars & restaurants & a superb museum

Not quite like it used to be. We wandered through the Rocks a few times on our weekend trip. I have very fond memories of the markets some 20 years ago. Not much had changed I expect but the rain probably meant it wasn't quite the bustle of yesteryear. Not really any bargains out so it wasn't like the previous fossicking. There is a very nice, moderately priced jewellery shop along the back alley near the Italian restaurant. I chose four pieces that I anticipate I will wear a lot as it goes with my other silver pieces and the greys and pearls suit my style. The shopkeeper was also friendly - his wife makes most of the pieces. I will probably go back there. It just feels a little tired but maybe my recollection is just more vivid than the reality.

Very enjoyable area of town.. Leave lots of time to meander around and stroll trough the alleys and the shops. Take in a visit to the oldest bar in Sydney Fortune of War. Have a sidewalk coffee, hike up the stairs to the Sydney Bridge, or walk over to the Opera house, but don't miss The Rocks. Definitely visit the Visitors' Center, where we picked up coupons including coupons for a free drink (alcoholic) at The Morrison Bar & Oyster Room. Make an after noon Oyster Bar crawl and walk from pub to pub sampling a variety of oysters and beers. We loved The Rocks!

GReat Aussie History. Spent part of two afternoons here, and wanted to go back. Wonderful to learn the history of the Australian settlement. Great shops and restaurants, and easy to walk. Could have spent more time and $ here. Be sure to include in visit to Sydney.
Interesting. I liked seeing the historic area of the city, but our map took us way out of the way so lots of back tracking.
Old World Charm. Like stepping back in time. Old shop facades are fantastic. So much to explore and do. Felt very safe here during the Vivid Festival

Stroll through history. The Rocks is a wonderful little pocket of Sydney by the harbour full of history but with lots of wonderful restaurants and unique shops. Take some time to go for a stroll under the harbour bridge and through this historic area.
Great Place for Snacks. There are many stalls selling snacks and hot food for takeaway. Great place to shop. Lots of cafés nearby too.

exceeded my expecations.. Loved all the shops and restaurants. people watching from pubs was one of the highlights of our stay in Sydney. If I were planning again it would include more time at the Rocks

Unique area and great weekend market. My cousin and I happened upon the Rocks craft area on our stay in Sydney. The area itself is unique and on the weekends there is a weekend market under the bridge. We were able to get unique gifts to take home, and a few for ourselves. We had a great afternoon exploring the area with its sculptures, quiet streets and little boutiques. Even without the weekend market the area is great for exploration. Even though it is near the busy part of town, it feels miles away and very relaxing. If you are in Sydney, go for a visit.

Lovely place to explore the history of Sydney. You can easily spend several hours wandering around this part of Sydney with a nice combination of architecture, quiet streets, views, market stalls and shops.

The Rocks...so much history!. I just love walking around the rocks, so much history to be seen everywhere. All overseas travelers should enjoy an afternoon stroll looking at the galleries & boutiques & grab a good coffee too!

My favorite place in Sydney.. Love the Rocks!? It is so addictive that I can never not go there whenever I am in Sydney. I can spend hours walking around the Rocks, sipping coffee or having lunch and reading inside one of the great restaurants in this area. Love the weekend markets.

A must see for overseas visitors. This area is iconic. The old pubs, cafes restaurants and bars all overlooking the most beautiful harbour in the world. From the ferry terminals and the old overseas terminals where our migrants arrived, to the Opera house. Although there are a lot of tourist shops there are also a lot of quality retail places as well. The markets at the northern end on the weekend are great fun to stroll through, then grab a bite to eat at restaurants and cafes catering to all tastes from the cheap to very expensive, but you do get what you pay for. The views and the atmosphere are second to none and you can leave the car behind as parking can be difficult and expensive and catch the train to Circular Quay and get off right in the thick of things
Relax at The Rocks. Pretty atmosphere, somewhat European. No wonder when you realize it's one of the oldest places in Sydney

Lovely historic place to walk around. The markets here on Sat and Sun are great, all located at the rocks and under the end of the Harbour Bridge. and there is foodies markets every Friday. Heaps of restaurants. A must do
Love the roks. Always a great place to go. Love the area and the feel and the history always have to do the nurses walk :)

Great History and Shopping. We took a walking tour of the neighborhood (http://www.rockswalkingtours.com.au/) and enjoyed the wandering though small alleyways and historical insights that it added to our visit. We also had a nice lunch and stopped by some of the local shops where you'll find a lot of local artisan's work. There is also an outdoor market on the weekends that was a bit expensive but had lovely crafts.
The Rocks Market. Love The Rocks Market. Found so many great things to take home and idea of thing to still get.Definitely worth the walk around on a Sunday morning

no better way to spend a lazy sunday. The Rocks market has so much to offer many food options and has a wonderful vibe about it. The markets on Sundays have top quality items on offer and a large range. The Observer Hotel is pretty cool particularly on a nice sunny day when there is live entertainment nothing like a relaxing stroll and soaking up the atmosphere. The hardest choice you will make is where to eat!

Birthplace Of Our Nation. The Rocks located on the southern shore of Sydney Harbour, immediately north-west of the Sydney central business district. Gets its name in 1788 as all the buildings were made from the local sandstone which is in abundance in the area.The Rocks is tiny only about 0.2 km2 (0.1 sq mi) but is chock a block full of history.Standing in The Rocks and looking east you look across Port Jackson or better known as Circular Quay (it's not circular any more). This was the prefered settlement prefered by the first fleet after Captain Cook's landing site at Kernel in Botany Bay was rejected due to its very sandy ground and was not suitable for growing crops immediately.Right in your line of site is one of the modern wonders of the world on Bennelong Point,The Sydney Opera House.This was the winning design in a competition for an "Australian Opera House" submitted by a young Danish architect Jorn Utzon in 1957. He said he came up with the design by cutting an orange into segments, thus its truely unique shape and form.Unfortunately he never saw his master piece completed due to differences with the NSW State Government. The project was completed by the NSW public works and opened by Queen Elizabeth II in October 1973. Jorn Utzon died without ever laying his eyes on the completed building.About face and you will be looking accross George St and into the heart of The Rocks.As the oldest settlement in Australia, some of the oldest and most beautiful building still exist here, however not the oldest. That title of Australia's oldest building is in Parramatta, which will be for another review another day.The buildings in the Rocks area in George St, Argyle St, Hickson Rd, Lower Fort St & Cumberland St are some of the oldest. They consist of mainly smaller terrace type homes, and working buildings. As this is Australia's oldest shipping port (and still the busiest) many of these buildings were used for food, drink and entertainment of all sorts. Still today, Australia's oldest pub is still in operation in The Rocks and is worth a visit. I am pleasently surprised that since this small little gem of a place is right in the heart of Sydney and right on the edge of the most wonderful harbour in the world, many of the eateries pubs and resturants are still very reasonably priced and very affordable. Children are welcome in the area and most places have kids menus available.It is very easy for 2 adults who like their food and drink to have a good time for under $50AUDBe careful as The Rocks shuts down pretty early during the week, you will struggle to find food at a pub after 9pm, some bigger places (nightclubs) have food till around 11pm.Food at one of the biggest nightclubs in The Rocks was quite reasonably priced and the food is plentyful, very tasty and the beer is cold.You will also find some of Australia's MOST expensive dining in The Rocks as well.Many 5 star, Michelin rated & world famous chef owned resturants are to be found here so be sure of pricing before you eat. Most establishments (except the high class) all have menus outside for you to check whats on and how much.On weekends there is The Rocks Markets, but these are not now as good as they once were.A walk up Argyle St and right into Lower Fort St at the top of the hill will bring you in sight of the dominating Sydney Harbour Bridge. This bridge has been looking over The Rocks area since it's opening in 1932. Cumberland St and George streets are next on your walk towards the bridge and of course there are many watering holes along the way. The Sydney Harbour Bridge Climb offices are in Cumberland St, so If you are game to climb the bridge, this is where you go.The Rocks can be very loud from time to time and very quiet from time to time, but there is always something interesting to see and do and eat.

The Rocks: Still a Gem, Get Creative. Despite the fact I have visited The Rocks so many times, and despite the fact it is definitely inundated with tourists and the usual accompanying gift shops etc.....I still love every it every time I chance to be there. Because despite the tourist trade, I can always find atmospheric little lanes and alleys away from it all - there are always quirky photo opportunities to be found, quiet corners where for a second you can be transported back in time, a la 'Playing Beatie Bow'. Away from the bustle of George street, there are many, less visited gems - just grab a map and a bottle of water and wander! If you're serious about getting to know the Rocks, do some research on its history before you hit the streets - its a great way to set the scene and have a better understanding of the Rocks and it's role in early Australian history.

Great pubs, restaurants, shopping. we went on a Sunday when they had a market and lots of little street vendors, it was great! some things pricey, but we were able to find some good deals. lots of pubs and restaurants and shops there daily too.

Touristy but still fun. The historic area is very interesting to see, and shows the humble beginnings of the city of Sydney. Lots of places for tourists to leave their currency of choice, but it doesn't overwhelm the charm.
Fun place. Good area to walk around especially with the weekend markets. We purchased some interesting reasonably priced clothing and jewelry
Old World Charm. This is always an excellent place to go and with VIVID on display it was spectacular. The cuisine is always exciting and there is always lots to see and do.
Fun to walk around to look, see, smell, eat and drink. Nothing much changes but still a good time. Just found the staff if Irish pub to be surly-spark up life is good

Don't overlook our history. We truly do have a magnificent history in the Rocks. Wandering through laneways and up and down steps, you find all kinds of gems. I love it's history and every Aussie should go there and find the mystique in our own backyard!

so much to see and do. Weekend markets, lots of restaurant choices from cheap to very flash, nice area to walk around in, lots of history and a cool vibe. Some great pubs with some having live music on a weekend (Bar 100, The Orient). Glenmore Rooftop Bar is a must. Sake restaurant is delicious.

A Sydney must do. The rocks area in Sydney is on most visitors list of places to visit. The weekend markets, views of the bridge, harbour, opera house and the circular quay are all excellent. I would suggest that time is worth investing to take a short stroll into the adjoining area called Millar's point which is easily accessible by walking under the Sydney harbour bridge at the top end of the Rock's market. Here you will find an abundance of terrace houses and old world pubs with a few shops and restaurants. It is also an easy walk back to the city centre as an alternative to George street from Circular quay.
Great. Have lived in Sydney for 10+ years and still love visiting the rocks, one of the most beautiful parts of Sydney. Definitely recommend visiting.
Nice walk. A good place to pass as you walk the Circular Quay and boardwalk. Lots of shops and food establishments . Historical with good hotels to stay in

Cool little area. We have stayed here on a number of occasions (wife and I). The markets are always neat and some of the eating places are among the best in Sydney. Definitely a place to come visit when in the city.

Lord Nelson Hotel. Great pub. It's a must do experience for visitors and locals alike.The micro brewed beer is classic .... And you must dine here. Great quality food and wine.All in the heart of Sydney's historic Rocjs district.

Great way to spend a morning or afternoon. We enjoyed walking around all the cobblestone streets and looking, learning all the history in the arena. I did think several of the shops were a bit pricy, but in the galleries, I'm not really an expert on what is pricey. Several places to eat, get a nice drink and relax. This is easily a way to. Spend half the day. One of the musts when visiting Sydney

Another Tourist trap. My family visited the Rocks last year and were hyped up about it. To the two of us it was just another series of shops and restaurants. Not our cup of tea, the beaches were better. But if you like to shop this could be your ticket

Quaint and leisurely. Nice little cobblestone area and the rock carved formations are just awesome! Vendors and restaurants galore. Did pick up one or two items from the handrcrafted items being sold. All and all just a nice area to stroll and sit and talk.

It rocks. I have lots of fun walking around the place I enjoyed the market and my favorite restaurant, its a German place with their specialty crispy leg of pork. was delicious and made my trip to Sydney complete.
great markets. The Rocks markets are great lots of variety. Area is so rich in history find it very interesting. Great spot for accommodation as it is so handy to transport

A bit pricey. I guess all tourists like to visit "The Rocks" but I feel locals are taking advantage of this and getting greedy. The markets offered some really nice things for sale but were way over priced. There were several things I liked very much but was not prepared to pay the asking price which was way too much. If only people realized that if they kept their prices fair, they would sell far more !
So much History and Charm. The Rocks has it all, the best pubs, eateries and views as well as plenty of history and attractions.
Lots to do. Great eating options, we had dinner at Sake one night and loved it and also found a small french patisserie and had breakfast there one morning.
So much on offer!!. The Rocks has great little chops, pubs, bars, cafés, restaurants and shops. The heritage buildings make the area unique.
A Walk trough time. This 90 Minute walk was most informative and helped one understand the interaction among the settlers of Australia that explains so much of the Aussie attitude and culture today.
good for breakfast. Met here with my son to meet the parents of his fiancee before their wedding. Nice, relaxed outside back patio. Good egg dishes with coffee.
Love the rocks. Whenever we head into to the city we always end up at the rocks. Great pubs & places to eat, excellent place to walk around and take in the city views

Activity aroud the clock. A very clean and tidy place with stunning surrounding landmarks its gorgeous at night especially when I saw the prestigious Queen Victoria leave the dockland. Lovely places to eat, drink and relax.

Great Atmosphere!!. I enjoyed the sidewalk cafes and shopping! You must stop over at Dare for some amazingly freshly squeezed juices! Ask for the organic vodka with freshly squeezed watermelon juice! Refreshing!

Load to eat and drink. This area is a great place to unwind and relax. There are loads of places to eat and drink, even a shop that sells nothing else but chocolate, nice if you can stomach it, but a few beers will wash it all down!!

The Rocks - Sydney. A step back in time for travellers to see the original settlement area of Sydney. Great shops, cafés & markets. A short stroll to Quay & Opera House. While in The Rocks enquiry about a Bridge Walk over the famous Coathanger. In summer take the evening walk over the bridge & take in the magnificent views. The Rocks YHA is an excellent place to stay - centrally located, new & clean. Enjoy this beautiful country we are so lucky that the Poms decided to send us here!!

Plenty of history, great food and excellent pubs. This area of Sydney to close to and adjacent to Circular Quay and therefore in easy reach of all travellers. and a visit should be a must for all travellers both overseas and within Australia. Even us Sydney siders need to visit here more often. The area is sprawling and loaded with Australias early settlement history. A lot of the history museums and places of interest here are free as well. Loads of good food outlets at all prices and the pubs are the best in Sydney. All full of early history charm and friendliness.
Rocking fun. Great to walk around, especially when the markets are on which is weekends. Lovely cafés and hotels to have a drink or coffee. We'll worth a visit. Wear comfortable shoes!!

Window Shopping at the Rocks. I love the Rocks, I love the oldness of the area, the way the old buildings are jumbled together, the alleys and lanes. The curio shops cheek by jowl with something totally upmarket. I love the way I can turn a corner and find a treasure, completely unexpected! It is so Old World in a very modern city.
Bars, Restaurants. A nice place to go chill out! There's bars and restaurants all over the place, so you'll find something that will suit you! Just a few minutes away from the Harbour!

Strolling through The Rocks. I love wandering through The Rocks area of Sydney. In and out of all the different shops that are there. There are lots of cobblestoned laneways that you can walk through to something else of interest. Lots of pubs and coffee shops.The Rocks area used to be a settlement of convicts etc. 200 or more years ago and is an integral part of the history of Sydney.There is a Foodies Market on Fridays, then on Saturday and Sunday there are weekend markets.Also plenty of accommodation options.Love it.
good for a walk around. The Rocks is a typical city historic district, nice for a walk around with some over priced gift shops.

really fun vibe!. so much history and charm in the rocks, not to mention cool bars and places to get awesome food there are markets every weekend from 10am, great for couples and families. wear good shoes because the streets are cobble stones

More for tourists. First time at rocks area for a couple of years and really noticed how it is now focused on tourist (overseas) trade. I feel most shops and hotels are overpriced in the area. Drinks in hotels are fairly expensive considering the hotels are old and do not offer much more then a place to have a drink and an average meal.

The Rocks Sydney. There wasn't anything I disliked, loved the place. Lots of small shops that were the old original homes, lots of nooks and crannies to have a look around, even candle making, very interesting to see, sometimes there is entertainment out in the open.air. Restaurants too.

Interesting Sydney History in the city. I found the Nurses walk , hospital and small alleys. Very interesting to see the history of Sydney in it's glory. I also went into the very first WESTPAC Bank building built in 1853 i think it said. The old teller boxes and bank is in it's glory as you enter this beautiful and Historic Building as is the old CBC bank now named the National both which are in George Street. Both beautiful, historical and now glorious in a new life
Worth seeing. Great to just walk around the Rocks area and take in early settlement in Australia. Great History. There are also wonderful cafes, restaurants to enjoy!

leave a whole day to explore.. Great spot for couples or families. We often grab a hotel room and make a weekend out of it. Lunch in the gardens, dinner in one of the many pubs or even do a ghost tour. A place you can visit time and time again as it never gets boring.

Hidden delights. When visiting the Rocks area head away from the harbour up a gentle hill and you will start to find glimpses of Old Sydney town which thankfully avoided the demolition ball and developers greed. Away from the tourist tack you can see original homes, a local pub or two and the Garrison church Stop by the Lord Nelson brew pub for a refreshing local ale. All in all good for a peaceful meander, some unique views of the harbour bridge and more and avoidance of the cruise liner hordes!

What better way to spend a lazy afternoon.. I have fond memories of spending many afternoons visiting a number of the local hotels in The Rocks with family and friends. Not only is there some great pubs to eat and drink at but you have to appreciate the history that goes with the territory and not to mention the great views that can be obtained from a couple of special places. I thoroughly recommend a pub crawl through the Rocks. Its something that everyone should experience at least once in their life.

Beautiful historical Sydney. The Rocks has everything you could want from lovely markets at the weekend, lots of good drinking holes like the Argyle, or just take a walk round a look at the historical area of Sydney. You also have the benefit of being right by the bridge with some amazing views of the harbour. This is a beautiful area for tourists and residents alike and we enjoy spending many a weekend here as a family.

Original start. The Rocks is very diversified, mixing the old with the new. Lots of places to enjoy good food and spectacular views of Sydney Harbour. It's a busy place on weekends with street stalls and the marketplace in the old woolshed. Eating al fresco or wandering around the area to view the Opera House, Harbour Bridge with plenty of accommodation in the area and the heart of the city a few blocks away. A great tourist place.

Great for history buffs who appreciate historic buildings, right on the harbour.. I must admit, I rarely visit, but when I do, I like this area because of all the old buildings. There's a lot of history here, but sadly it's not as concentrated as somewhere like Gastown in Vancouver, and therefore lacks the 'wow' factor. It's best combined with a short tour - of the rocks, the water tunnels under the city, the tour of the jail and seedy side of Sydney or the ghost & scary tour. It adds to your knowledge and appreciation of the area to know what it's about and also, you'll then start to see things that you may have otherwise overlooked.

Tour of the Markets. Always good to have a walk around the rocks and see our local people selling their goods - some home made, some not but a great atmosphere. Would recommend the Harley motor trike tour ride what a great experience that was.

Vibrant part of the city. Can't really add much to the other reviews here - great open-air food market with lots of delicious smells as a wide variety of food is being cooked, plenty of places to get a drink, and - amazingly - plenty of public toilets! For free! Allocate a couple of hours to wander round, even the cafes do great food and cakes if you just want to sit around. They do candy-making in The Rocks Centre, you can watch it being made (I watched it being made with a koala running through it, very clever) and then can of course buy some afterwards. Ugg boots all seemed to be in a sale up to 30% off, if that floats your boat. Visit Susannah's place for an hour at 2.00pm, 3.00pm or 4.00pm for a 1 hour tour (8 bucks) of 4 old terraced houses, more interesting than it sounds as you can see how the early settlers on The Rocks lived, and the guide Ivan has plenty of stories and local knowledge.

Favourite Part Of Sydney Harbour. The Rocks has character, charm & plenty of history. Cobble stone paths & cute places to discover. Amazing restaurants, delicious chocolate stores, fantastic Markets & a very interesting shop called Sticky to visit and watch as they create and make their special sweet treats in front of you.

Nice vibes. I did not have time to visit Surry Hills and Paddington. The Rocks is probably our most favourite place. Went there once on a Saturday with the weekend market and or a Thursday evening. Just feel so nice strolling along the old alleys, docksides and a couple of street performers.

In The Middle of The Action. This area has great character and reminds me some of the Boston area. Lots of restaurants and water holes. Another great place to hang out. Right next to the bridge and harbor and across from the opera house.

Incredible. What can I say about The Rocks. I chose hotels based there and quite frankly could not have chosen a better location for my Sydney holiday. Perfect location, everything is central and on walking distance and such a lively hub, street entertainment, great cafes on harbour side, Opera House, Harbour Bridge. Loved it.

Nice place to visit and, yeah, I could live there!. Just walking around this area to view a different perspective of the Opera House, Circular Quay, and the Harbour Bridge was an absolute pleasure. The variety of eateries and architecture added much to the experience.

Wash on the Rocks. After unexpectedly stopping in Sydney for a week on our way home, we realised we needed some laundry done. Paying $5 for each item of underwear at our hotel laundry service seemed over the top. We bundled our big bag of laundry up and took it for a scenic walk along the harbour past pier 1 and on to 16 Hickson Road. Wash on the Rocks charge $16.50 per load ($18.00 including fabric softener) and $7.00 each way for pick up or delivery (really well worth delivering yourself at least). We returned to our hotel that night and in our room wash freshly washed clothing all neatly folded and the coast was a fraction of any Sydney hotel! They also offer express service, dry cleaning, etc.
in Sydney don't stay anywhere else it Rocks. what a perfect historic and bustling place to stay. brilliant location, bars shops restaurants, markets galleries the list is endless.

Great place to stay in Sydney. Wonderful place to stay and enjoy the best of the city - loads of cafés and restaurants, shopping etc. and only a short walk to circular quay to go exploring or to get to the bridge and opera house! Perfect location for a week's visit to be in the centre of things! Feels safe at night too, the kids loved it.
Sydney Rocks. You cannot miss the rocks in Sydney especially since they are so close to the Opera house and the Sydney Harbour Bridge. A different kind of location for sure...must see.

Quality souvenirs of Sydney at Rocks Market. Great music, food and pubs. The Rocks is an historic part of Sydney's early European settlement. Every time I'm in Sydney, I buy crafts from the markets as gifts, souvenirs for friends and family. The colourful braided bracelets are always a big hit with young and old

Sunday Market. Great place to do some walking, easily accessible from Circular Quay. We had just checked into our hotel and our receptionist suggested the Rocks Sunday Market. Being mothers day, they were reasonably quiet with most people seemingly heading to one of the many restaurants for lunch or afternoon tea. However we did find some unique buys at one of the market stalls. One being a lovely hand made plaque that sits on top of a wine bottle - with 4 indents to hold glasses. The plaques are painted (and lacquered) with different Sydney scenes & designs. One of them an aboriginal theme - a nice gift. We had afternoon tea there and just enjoyed taking in the atmosphere.
Top attraction.... While it feels quite during the day, it fills with life after sunset. A lot of good restaurants, clubs and coffee shops.Make sure you stop by during your visit

Quaint area. Nice quaint area with an olden feel.Cobblestone streets, with some alleys with hidden finds! Be sure to explore corners.We went when there was a night market and it was fantastic.Lively, good food, great atmosphere. One of the most enjoyable nights I had in Sydney.

Great area. I walked here almost nightly while in Sydney to have dinner or at least a glass of wine. There are so many nice places to eat and drink here. A great area and close to the CBD which is where I was staying so it was very convenient.

Loved This Area. Very cool area to walk through and grab a bite to eat. Very old area of town but very interesting to see. It's close to circular quay so it's not out of the way but it is quaint and a nice spot to see.

Pretty touristy are with a lot of arts and handcrafts. The Rocks is nice to walk through on your way to or from the harbour. there is a large vistor information centor which is convienent. Lot of restaurants and in the weekend a nice market with handcrafted items. For us it was nice to see but would prefer Paddington area

Historic Sydney. Although I think The Rocks precinct is a little overrated, once you walk beyond the main streets, there are lots of interesting buildings - especially the old terrace houses - to be seen. Some nice eateries can be found away from the busy areas, and prices are much more reasonable too.

make sure you go through the Argyle cut and have a look at the oldest residential area in Sydney. I love the rocks and believe you need to spend at least half a day wandering and browsing. The markets on Saturday and sunday are awesome, but the shops that are pen every day are all small businesses and have unique aspects you won't find anywhere else.

Historic Heart of Sydney. Ok, Australia doesn't have hundreds or thousands of years history like Europe, but what we do have, starts in The Rocks.It's always worth a wander, especially when the Markets are on to take a look at the start of our very young nation and soak up the atmosphere.It's hard to image what life would have been like a couple of hundred years ago when the seedy city began booming, but there's a couple of museums to assist.And you can always finish your walk at Panckaes at The Rocks.

A bit touristy - but a very nice area to walk about and get a feel for Old Sydney. You access the Bridge from the Quay by walking thru the old-town part of Sydney – called the Rocks. This is the area full of small shops, kitsch cafes, restaurants, etc. It was the site of the first European settlement. It has evolved from a place of open sewers and squalid alleyways and shameless pubs to on this particular Sunday, the streets were packed with a large combination of what can only be described as farmers market meets large craft show. Booth after booth of stuff – mostly local craft issued – but some items that you be proud to own made by some local craftsperson. These narrow streets take to you the base of the Harbour bridge. It is a fascinating place to explore on foot, for the history of the buildings is retold on countless historical signs. Many food options line the streets, from bakeries to outdoor restaurants.

Slightly over-rated. The Rocks is just one of those areas that you return to when in Sydney and there are some interesting shops, bars and restaurants. Weekend markets are fun but the place is expensive and a little over-rated compared with some other, less touristy areas. That said, we always stop by when in Sydney, so it cant be all bad.

What a place. This is another place not to be missed especailly on market days. The quality of goods/crafts was excellent. The choice of restaurants/cafes is amazing and all those we tried didn't disappoint.

Worth a visit. Good shops ,interesting area, street artists, singers etc and very central next to theharbour bridge and harbour ferries makes it well worth a visit especially in the evenings when it comes alive

Historical place must to see.. Visited with friends and its a nice place to see the history of Australian sailors and soldiers place of return after their hectic duty. Nicely maintained the historic view and preserve well for future viewers. There is a great carving in between two stare cases , thats an old mans portrait and a must see.
Market Day. Sunday morning stroll around the markets, lots to see and lovely cafe's for a spot of brunch. Watch the Artists creating their work or just sit and watch the Ferries come and go.
Trendy and quaint. Great place to spend a morning, wandering around trendy art galleries, admiring the iconic Sydney sights, some lovely little shops and very scrummy cafes!
Historic. Interesting to visit the ruins and museum, lunch and a pint at Lord Nelson's Pub as well as the Observatory.

Fun area to explore. My favorite area that we explored in Sydney this trip around. Historic with a cool atmosphere. We ate several meals here and walked around the cobblestone streets. We also did an hour and a half long walking tour of the area with I'm Free Tours, which we enjoyed! We got to hear a lot of interesting stories of the area, from when it was a convicts slum, up to today and the controversies surrounding some of the housing.
Nice Piece of History. Walking tour recommended. Several companies do these; we booked at the Rocks information centre and had a great tour with a personable and knowledgeable guide.
Great place to grab a bite to eat. Love walking around The Rocks and shopping or getting a meal in the many shops and restaurants lining the streets.
Great Atmosphere. I never tire of visiting The Rocks. I love the historic environment as well as the friendly atmosphere. This visit we were able to attend the markets which is always a treat.

Saturday markets. A hustle bustle area when we visited the markets on our first Saturday on our trip to Sydney. Lot of nice quaint shops and had choice of many different restaurants for lunch. Lot of history and historic buildings in the area - made for a nice casual stroll through time.Enjoyed the visit

Returned here again and again during our visit. The Rocks has lots of restaurants, shops, a lovely street market and atmosphere. I especially liked The Rocks Market, which had some upscale arts/crafts on sale (instead of cheaper, mass produced stuff available in many other places). Nice handcrafted souvenirs I never saw elsewhere.Within easy walking distance of the CBD (Central Business District).

Disappointed. Visited The Rocks recently, first time in a few years. used to be a favourite place but it seems to have lost its sparkle. Maybe I went on an off day. Markets were just a bit boring. Needs new life.
Interesting. The Rocks is a very interesting area but a little too touristy for me. There are several interesting eateries too.

Nice walk around the Rocks. The Rocks is a lovely area to walk around...walk into the laneways...where you will spy cottages which have lovely goods to entice you to buy. Nice eateries for coffee/pastries...Pancake on the Rocks is there including the Waterfront Restaurant & others...all nice.

Very Interesting History. We walked around the rocks, visited the Big Dig and the rocks museum. It was all very interesting and informative, giving us insight to what life in the colony was like back then.

The rocks. being worth to visit - nice restaurants - busy place with marvelous view to the famous opera house and very close the botanical garden. Artits and musicians, markets and art galleries, visitors from all over the world enjoy this place.

Great historical district. This is probably my favourite area of Sydney, though it can be quite crowded during times due to the vicinity to the harbour and thus a prime spot for tourists.The area dates by to the late 19th century and historically had the reputation of being a slum area, frequented with sailors, prostitutes and industry workers. It's since been gentrified, with the buildings and much of the area still retaining its original architecture. The sidewalks are now lined with a lot of restaurants and cafes, as well as shops. For me, it's reminiscent of the Distillery District in Toronto, Canada or areas in NYC such as LES.Every Saturday there is a market and becomes overtaken by local artisans selling handmade jewelry, clothing, artwork, soaps, oils, bags. If you can time your visit, I'd make the effort to check the market out! (I had spotted a ring that I fell in love with but didn't purchase it. I consequently had to wait a week for the market to reopen and it took some time trying to find the vendor who sold it, as he was in a different spot!)There's a lot of windy streets, little alleys that will lead you to more quiet areas so I would encourage you to wander the area during an afternoon and see where it takes you...definitely some great photo opportunities (lots of wedding photography shoots in the area too) I'd grab an early lunch in the area to avoid high peak crowds, or afternoon tea/beer.

Saturday markets good for a look. We enjoyed looking around the market stalls on a Saturday afternoon. Highly recommend the Japanese omelettes bought from one of the inexpensive food stalls, clean and quick service.

Didn't see what the fuss was about. We were at the rocks pretty much every day. Liked the winding streets, the shops and restaurants, but for some reason I was expecting to be "wowed" by the Rocks before we went...took a tour, which I thought was just ok...The tour took us behind some buildings and down some alleys which are less congested.
Cool place to hang out.. Great place for people watching...There are lots of nice little boutiques, bars, and eateries.. Short walk from cruise/ferry terminal and Circular Quay train station....

Go for Saturday lunch.. Visited on Saturday afternoon just after lunch to find a market in full swing with lots of yummy street food available! This area is always interesting when wandering the lanes and alleys.

A must for visitors. The Rocks is a great place to visit if you're touring Sydney. It's in the perfect location being so central.- Grab a ferry to Manly or Cockatoo Island from Circular Quay just around the corner- See buskers and Aboriginals playing didgeridoos- Stop into the ice-creameries or fish n chip shops along the way- Get a great photo of the Opera House or Sydney Harbour Bridge- See the tall-ships and ferries sailing by- See some of our history such as the first ever buildings of Australia which are still standing- Visit the famous Pancakes on the Rocks- Many rooftop bars are close by which gives a great view and atmosphere in Summer

Quieter area but a nice feel. More of an old world feel to it, quiet but plenty of bars and restaurants to find. Easy to miss the range of restaurants on the waterfront just next to the park hyatt with nice range of eating options and great views over to the opera house.

Good views. After walking the Opera house, I walked to the Rocks, the historic part of Sydney with stalls, few restaurants, it was very crowded with people on Sunday. I really liked the views of Opera house from there.
Interesting place to stroll around.. There are interesting cafes and architecture in this area, and it's an easy walk to get here from Circular Quay.

Old Sydney Town. Lost some of its charm over the years but still an interesting location to visit. Parking is a major problem (and expensive) but it is still worth the effort to walk the streets of old Sydney town.
Quaint, picturesque and very touristy.. Historic buildings and charm abound. Stroll through the hilly streets to the bottom of the bridge where the old military cannons look out over the bay.

Heart of the city. Sydney is 'The Rocks' and no visit is complete without a visit to this historic heart of the old settlement. Great restaurants, cafés and bars, Sydney's oldest pub, 'The Fortune of War' and good shopping too, all close to Circular Quay. The Rocks Discovery Centre is a mine of information on local attractions and the nearby free museum is well worth a visit. See if you can find the oddly titled 'Suez Canal', a derivation of Sewer Channel, a narrow lane, once traversed by the infamous 'Captain of the Push'. Full of charm and character, this is a must see area of Sydney.

Interesting and glad it has been retained. We were surprised there weren't more restaurants around. We went to the markets on Saturday which were fairly standard but there were a couple of interesting stalls. We went to Sails restaurant which is open air dining with the roof like rigging of an old ship. Views across to the opera house were amazing. The food was great quality and international standard . The service was very attentive. Overall a must see old heritage area with many of the old buildings preserved.

Still a great part of town.. Unusually warm evening for late April, heaps of people about, good buzz and lots of places to eat and have a drink. It is fantastic that so much of the history of early white settlement has been preserved and is alive and being put to really good use. Good job Sydney.
Rock on!. Old part of Sydney with many interesting buildings, pubs and restaurants. Don't miss the weekend market.
A must when in Sydney. We just love to explore the quaint streets, shops, gardens and museums around. For lunch, head to Philip Foote's courtyard and you will be in another world.
Not like it used to be. The Rocks really needs a facelift - has become quite derelict in places. Smelly street drains, uneven footpaths, dingy buildings.

Loads of Character. Great area to relax and enjoy great food in. At the weekend there are lots of covered stalls a kind of street market with loads of interesting and unusual things to buy. If you are not staying in the area it is well worth taking the time to visit and enjoy the atmosphere especially on a weekend.
Great variety for shopping and restaurants.. The weekend set up of specialty shops were a treat for visitors. There was also a nice variety of restaurants at The Rocks.

Perfect place to stay while visiting Sydney. Trains, Buses and Ferries are close by and easy to get to and to get to anyplace in Sydney.Plenty of nice and expensive type hotels, pretty much something for everybody's budget.Food, oh there is food to be found in the Rocks, from fast food all the way up to 5 star places.Things to do and see - Harbor Bridge is just around the corner, Opera House just steps from George St, Shopping every place you look, History and parks close by.Circular Quay is just steps off of George St also with ferries and train and buses to take you any place you want.
Quaint. This is one of the oldest areas of Sydney. Many of the buildings have plaques on them giving the history of the structure. There is a museum and tours are available as well.
Over rated. The Rocks is just a fancy name for another part of Sydney that wasn't too different to anything else, a few reasonable priced restaurants to eat at, but nothing exceptional.

australia's bourgeoisies. This place tells you a lot about the history and the bourgeoisies who used to live there. the streets are so nice to walk around, you can see the harbour bridge and the opera from the other side.With few walks away you can reach the observatory

Our Rocks Visit. We walked through this area on a couple of occasions we walked from our hotel in Darling Harbour to the Sydney Harbour area.
