The old houses in the area looked very pretty and hid a colourful history. The only downside I found in the area is that there is a possibility of the houses being demolished. I think the Sydney council should look again at the issues and refurbish the area to protect their history. On the weekend we were there, there was an open air food court which sold food from around the globe at reasonable prices. There were shops to suit all budgets in the area from cheap to chic. A very pleasant area to spend a day - or two

Sydney Rocks. The Rocks is very popular with tourists as it is an historic part of Sydney with a variety of small shops selling art, craft works, books, boutique clothing, and souvenirs. There is a small arcade housing boutiques,souvenir shops, toilets, and a discrete McDonalds which is not too vulgar. The Rocks is a great place to wander around or to relax in a bar, cafe, or variety of restaurants. Pick a day when they hold their street market and it is even more interesting, with buskers and music to entertain you. The Rocks, practically underneath the Harbour Bridge, is so easy to get to from the nearby rail, bus, and ferry terminus and near the Opera House and City.
Great music. Had a lovely walk through the markets on Sunday - saw a father /son duo playing music - Joshua and Paul Meader - awesome. Great for gifts.

Lots of lovely little shops and rich in history. Visiting this place gives you a good glimpse of how the area used to look when Sydney was just an early settlement. Try to join one of the free guided walking tours being offered, as this place is literally full of so much history you'll probably miss exploring even with a good guidebook. Don't pass up a visit to the free museum in the vicinity too.It also has a lot of lovely little shops where you can find an assortment of goods.
Very quaint. A lovely location with fab bars and restaurants. Also has a weekend market which is well worth a wander around.

Sydney History. This area is the historic area of Sydney with cobbled streets and interesting old buildings with the history displayed at various spots. Its a unique area of Sydney and offers beautiful views of the harbour.

Visit historic Sydney. This is a very historic part of Sydney. It dates back to European settlement in 1788. Explore the cobbled laneways, cosy cafes and restaurants. One of my favourite things to do is visit the The Rocks markets. The Rocks Market is as good a place as any to buy small pieces of art, knickknacks and souvenirs. I have bought paintings and jewellery that I treasure. The Rocks Market is a Foodies Market on Fridays from 10am to 4pm. On Weekends (Saturday and Sunday) the Rocks Market is open from 10am to 5pm.
lively area with good food and shopping. Fun area with great variety. Market stalls,shops,information centre and restaurants. Worth a visit to browse or take part
History to see. old world charm at The Rocks area, old pubs to visit, lots of places to eat, and of course shopping, take some photos....

Sydney's oldest quarter. The tourist brochures will tell you that The Rocks is where Sydney began and that's pretty true. All the other places, around Circular Quay, have long since been buried under skyscrapers, except, perhaps, for the superb "Sydney Museum" on the site of "Government House". The photograph in this review shows The Russell Hotel, a true boutique establishment, with multi-level floors and Victorian decoration. If you can afford it and don't mind the lack of glitz, The Russell is an excellent place to stay: I recommend it always to visitors.There are weekend markets and a variety of speciality shops, as well as the restored buildings. There are walking tours of The Rocks, although I never have taken one. Some people like a bit of background information whilst others just want to soak in the atmosphere.It is best not to drive to The Rocks as parking is not easy. Buses running down George Street end at Millers Point and you can walk to the rest of the area from there.
This has to be the place to stay. Right in the centre of everything. Very close to a transport hub, full of history and great little shops on boutuque hotels and bars. I just love it

Take the tour. The best way to enjoy the maze which is The Rocks is to take the free 1 1/2 hour tour which starts at the harbor just South of the Cruise Terminal. Then, explore on your own. Stop in a pub for craft beer, Wander the shops for interesting items. Definitely part of any sydney must-do list.

A great space to spend your time in Sydney. This is a great weekend destination, especially if you have friends visiting from out of town. From clothes and jewelry to fun Australian trinkets and food, I would definitely recommend as a place for a quick stroll.
The Rocks. An historic area to visit and so close to so many other amenities. It is well worth visiting, and one of the oldest parts of Sydney too.

Must of there. A gorgeous part of Sydney and right by the international cruise terminal and minutes from the ferries at Circular Quay. Some great pubs, shops and restaurants in a very smart part of town. The tourist information centre is in the centre of this area and excellent staff are very knowledgable. They also sell some very good quality gifts made in Australia.

Great history. I love history and being one of Australia's earliest sites this was a great place to visit for me. We went on a weekend when their was markets on which had some really interesting local designs. Definitely worth checking them out.
Beautiful area. Had a walk down by the rocks area, really enjoyed the day at the rocks. Well worth a visit for a few hours. Especially if the sun is out.

A little piece of history. The Rocks was part of original convict Sydney and it is wonderful to wander around and soak up the history and think about how it must have been back in Captain Cook's days.Lots of little bars and cafes, a hotel or two, some great little shops, and a street craft market.
great night life and place to grab a drink. this is the place to go for markets, food, socializing and night life. it always seems to be alive and we had fun every time we went!

The Rocks - From a Sydney Local. The Rocks is one of Sydney's bigger tourist attractions.Located a lazy 10min stroll from the Opera House and picturesque vantage points of the Harbour Bridge, The Rocks is a must for any visitor to Sydney.The Rocks boasts a collection of food, clothing and accessory stores, housed within some of Sydney's oldest, heritage-listed buildings.One is able to wander the streets of The Rocks freely, but one of the best ways around The Rocks would be to take The Rocks Ghost Tour. One is given a in-depth insight into The Rocks, how it formulated and the history behind some of the buildings and streets.Keep in mind, The Rocks is full of boutique and high end stores, so can be quite expensive at times.Enjoy!!

Sydney's heritage. A must for the tourist, the Rocks is a wonderful place to learn the history and experience a little of what life was like when Sydney was taking its first steps to becoming the cosmopolitan city it is today. Wonderful restaurants to discover and the markets on the weekends are really enjoyable. Great pubs with old fashioned flair and the cobblestone streets in parts makes you feel like you are in another world. A delightful experience.

Walk on the rocks. We went on a free tour guide, the guy was good, he knew all the short cuts, the group was large so we couldn't hear him sometimes. We eat at a small cafe called la renaissance. You can also catch a ferry

A little too "touristy". The rocks is one of Australia's most significant and historic locations, but if you weren't Australian you'd never know. It is full of Ugg boot stores, other designer brands and frankly a few restaurants that wouldn't survive if they relied on people having to come again.

Walking tour.. We did a free 2 hour walking tour of the city (picked up a brochure at our hotel) which was excellent. The tour guide was a very clear speaker and could be heard quite easily by our large group. We also did the Rocks Tour at night, again a very good tour. The guides are very knowledgeable and enjoy their work. Payment is by tipping the guide.

The Rocks - A must see when in Sydney. I never cease to be amazed at all the little nooks and crannies that are tucked away in the streets and cobblestone laneways scattered in and around The Rocks. You could spend many hours walking around here, shopping and sampling different little eating and drinking establishments, and still not cover them all, even though the area is so very compact. This is a must see for local and overseas visitors alike.
The Famous Rocks area in Sydney. Such history in this area, the old streets with many great restaurants and cafes. Good shopping, the market is fantastic, can be a bit pricey.

an evening to remember. Lots of nice pubs and restaurants here all the area is refurbed harbour buildings the car on the island a pic to take lovely walking around this area after a nice |italian meal in the evening

A must visit whilst in sydney. The restaurants are a must visit at night. The view over to the opera house are magical. Restaurants are not cheap however one night, the lights & the view is an unforgettable memory
Trip through history. The Rocks - for the history buffs - quaint lanes and streets - lots of tourist shopping - great food - if you walk around great exercise - most is access by wheelchair

Sydney Rocks. I live on the South Coast NSW but really enjoy visiting Sydney a couple of times a year. Stay at Hotels within The Rocks precinct as no matter what the weather on the day there is always something to do. I stroll The Rocks for quirky shopping items. So many places to eat. A favourite of mine is too just sit, have a coffee watch the World go by. Great location and starting point for your Sydney visit. Fascinating insights into Sydney's short history. Just a short walk to the Sydney Harbour Bridge climb. I love The Rocks

The Rocks. Several older style pubs, some on roof tops overlooking the Sydney Harbour, there is the markets on the weekends, many restaurants/cafes and lots of old heritage buildings to see and lots of accommodation around, although, mostly expensive.

Fascinating glimpse of history. A guided tour is the best way to enjoy The Rocks otherwise you miss out on the sense of history and the stories of the people who used to live and work there. An essential part of Sydney's history, The Rocks is a walk through the past, including old buildings, beautiful restaurants and bars, not to mention a lot of shops selling quality goods, art and touristy items. There are also some great pubs and there is a market on Sundays.

Wander the alley ways carved by convicts. The Rocks has history, shopping, museums, restaurants, galleries and pubs.Enough to keep you happy for a couple of hours or the whole day.A definite Sydney must do.

Historic charm within a modern city. Australia's history is young by comparisons, but it's often surprising to see where our first settlers landed and began their lives. The Rocks has many charms, on a smaller scale, and there is plenty to see as well as enjoy the modern cafes in this area - a real contrast.

The Rocks rock. Great area for getting a feel for what Sydney used to be like, with original buildings still in use by modern businesses. Lots of intriguing alleyways to explore, good quality Australiana to be found, plenty of cafes and bars, and the weekend markets are great fun.
Wonderful history. The weekend markets are wonderful and well worth a walk around. The Friday food market is fantastic all the restaurants offer food in stalls on the cobblestone streets very yummy

The most beautiful part of the most beautiful city in the world.. The Rocks has everything from great restaurants, great attractions and the oldest pub in Sydney all surrounded by the beautiful Sydney Harbour.

Historic Sydney's gem. The "Rocks" is the historic heart of Sydney. Sadly Sydney has lost a lot of its historic buildings and precincts as developers moved in during the 60's. The Rocks was also slated for massive destruction and redevelopment as the history of the area was dismissed and the place branded as a slum. The "Battle fro the Rocks" saw the start of community action to protect the precinct and after long legal and civil disobedience, particularly on behalf of the Builders Laborers Unions.So now the area has been rejuvenated and a jewel to walk through its narrow walkways and back streets. Buildings and open spaces hide behind each other and date back to the earliest days of the Sydney story.Cobbled streets, a mix of museums and great pubs, maritime history and some of Sydney's smartest restaurants and nightspots. Artisan's markets take over Lower George St on Sundays as well as little boutique shops and craft shops adorn the neighbour hood.Walk up the hill under the huge road archway of the Harbour Bridge to the Western side of the Rocks - still a residential precinct and a true village to itself. Visit the Garrison Church, Lord Nelson Hotel or even older Hero of Waterloo - Sydney's oldest pub.And finish up on top of Observatory Hill for a spectacular view of the western Harbour, City and ultimately the best view of Sydney Harbour Bridge.

The Rocks area Sydney. What a spectacular, historic place, I love walking around down there looking at all the old buildings, and imagining what life would have been like all those years ago. If you're visiting Sydney, put The Rocks precinct on your must see list. If you're feeling a little more adventurous, go on a ghost tour of the area at night.

A great shopping spot. Combination street market and linkup with the local businesses. You can find many nice gifts here. The area has a mashup of local craft, herbs and food peppered with junk. The location is perfect for moving in and out of stalls and storefront businesses. You are close to the water with views of the bridge and bay and there is much history to learn too. This is where you go when you have spare weekend time and want to pick up trinkets.

Historic Area worth a tour. There is a Rocks Museum which is definitly worth while but the ambiance of the whole area is the true attraction here. There are many blocks of older buildings that are now about 200 years old and the ships and eating places are a big plus. We were told that evenings could be rowdy but day time was enjoyable.

A must for anyone visiting Sydney. This is the most interesting walk in Sydney. Get comfortable shoes, a camera and map for a good half day excursion. The main street is fine but head off the beaten track. Explore the side streets and make sure you visit one of the pubs. This is where Sydney started.

A great location to stay. The Rocks area has it all, it is near to the Bridge, the Opera House, the Circular Quay ferries, the Botanical Gardens. Great pubs restaurants, quirky shops. You get the benefits of being in a large city with the feel of something historic and eclectic

Visited Twice. The first time after exploring the Opera House and Circular Quay, by which time I was quite tired and so didn't do The Rocks justice. I found the Visitor Information Centre and gathered some info on what to do as this was just the 2nd of 8 days I would have in Sydney.Towards the end of my stay, I came back on a Market Day and what a difference - I was fresh and the streets were alive! I happily spent a couple of hours and appreciated the way the stalls were laid out so that you could wander down one side right to the end then come back up the otherside and not miss anything. Getting there and back was easy as my B&B was within walking distance of Central Station from where a free shuttle bus does a continuous circuit to Circular Quay.Unfortunately, I wasn't able to get to the Friday Foodies Market which would have been of great interest to me, but such is life!

Not really special.. Oldest pubs, weekend markets, museums and lots of historical buildings are to be found here.I wasn't impressed by the views of The Harbour Bridge which is best admired from The Opera House.All in all I found The Rocks to be one of those tourist attractions which proved to be a disappointment though in fairness we visited during the weekdays.With The Opera House, Circular Quay and The Botanical Gardens close by these attractions appealed more to our liking.

I love this place - The Rocks. Sydney.. I love this place. Plenty of varied restaurants to see and also give you plenty of options. The historical tour is great and full of history. Don't forget the back streets here as well., also plenty of shops etc. and its all close to the harbour and Circular Quay, you can spend a full day here wandering around, its great

Pricy accomodation but interesting buildings to visit.. This is one of the oldest areas of Sydney. Hotels there are expensive and ironically don't always offer en suite rooms. There are lots of interesting museums and buildings to visit. On Saturday mrnings thee is a good market scene.

History buffs will love this area. So much to look at - you should devote an entire afternoon for this. Great places to eat and drink, such as the Hero of Waterloo and Fortune of War. Walking tours are available through Sydney tourism sight, but just walking and wandering will do just as well.
Good Area. Nice to see so many tourists. Lots of restaurants, ferry terminal, buskers. Could be improved with some little speciality shops. Market area at the weekends.

many of the shops are closed why. the Rocks looks tired these days with many of the shops closed...but location location location and try one of the local pubs to get the flavour of the Rocks could spend the whole day wondering around

Neat area to explore. this area of Sydney has many restaurants and shops, and provides a great view of the harbor. It's definitely worth an evening. There is a market that runs frequently with lots of sellers.

Contain quite a few interesting places. It's actually just right next to the Circular Quay, Pancakes on the Rocks are just around here and it's worth a visit. There's also a museum somewhere around here but wasn't open when we're there.There's a weekend market around this area also, personally don't really find the market interesting, most of the stuffs are priced quite expensive and doesn't seems like haggling works here either. Worth a visit as some interesting attractions are around here.
Old world charm. beautiful old shops, market on Saturdays, 200 stalls.cobblestone laneways,lovely places to eat.Lovely, free museum to discover the true history of the area.

Visit on the weekend. The Rocks is next to Circular Quay and just before the Harbour Bridge. Many of the streets are quaint cobblestone streets with interesting buildings which now house shops and restaurants.On the weekend, there is a covered street market with locals selling many homemade items. Some were quite interesting and would make good things to take home as gifts. We had fun walking around here and would recommend doing it, especially on the weekend.
Great Historic area. Enjoyed a lovely pub restaurant meal at the Orient Hotel in the Rocks. It had a great atmosphere and the meals was delicious

Touristic. Well, there are oldish buildings but a lot of touristic studff: souvenirs, expensive middle-level restaurants and a lot of tourists. The view to the Opera Hourse and the waterfront skyline is excellent, though.

Sunday market is great!. It was a rare chance that I had to spend weekend in Sydney on a business trip. Fortunately I heard about the Sunday Market and indeed it is well worth a visit even if one is not intending to buy anything. Just browse and check things out.Nice additional to my personal travel journal on blogspot. Highly recommended as it is in city center and does not take much time.

Yes, nice place to visit, but I wouldn't rave about it. If you're in Sydney definitely visit The Rocks on a weekend, Market Days. If you don't get the opportunity, don't lose any sleep over it. Yes, it's a nice place to visit, but very, very commercial. I visited many years ago when it still had some of its olden-days character, but now, it's all very glitzy. Nothing like the two hundred year old landing place.Sure there are a heap of stalls on Market Days. There are a heap of restaurants. There are a heap of people.Unfortunately, most of the history is gone....covered up, at least.

Great Place to Eat. Went to a marvellour restuarant which I can't rmember the name of but you cooked your own meat on a BBQ/Hotplate. Service was great as was the food and choice of beverages. The rocks also has an interesting history and the cobbled streets and alleyways were worth walking around. Great place also for something a bit different.

Nothing special. I had expected more of the Rocks before I arrived in Sydney, but when I go there I was left a little underwhelmed. It is of course nice to see historic parts of the city, with residents going about their daily lives, but ultimately there is nothing to do here, apart from enjoy a drink at the Lord Nelson, or some of the other pubs scattered around. I did encounter a nice market in the Rocks, although I don't know if this was special or a regular thing. I walked through the Rocks on my way to the Opera House from Darling Harbour, and it was nice to walk through and take a few photos, but I wouldn't come to the Rocks especially.
disappointing. I discovered this area of SH whilst walking towards and onto the SH bridge. it seemed to be just a bit more upmarket than the rest surrounding it.

Popular Hangout. The Rocks is a good area of Sydney to just sit, get a drink, and enjoy views of both North and South Sydney. There are many bars, restaurants, and hotels in the area so there is always something going on.
Great area. near the harbour, easy to get to, . Great variety of cafes and restaurants, street markets at weekends, galleries, the bridge, dance theatre, old buildings and plenty to explore
A must see. We took the free walking tour. It's a must see area to learn about the history of the first settlers.
A good venue for a Sunday stroll. The markets are an interesting place to visit, lots to see and the history of the Rocks is worth taking seeing.
Highly promoted, but so-so. We walked about the Rocks, had lunch in that area, but nothing to write home about. Browsed at shops, mainly visited that area as a result of promos.
Rock Tour. Went on a tour over the Rocks, just the way to see it and learn a little of the past history and see the quaint buildings that are still there.

So convenient and a lovely atmosphere. We loved the closeness to the ferries which we used quite a lot.
The weekend market was great - bought a lovely print of the area to remind us of our visit.
Quite lively at the weekend so could be a bit noisy.
Nice shopping, people watching area. The Rocks has a nice blend of old and new. It is very close to the various jetties for harbor excursions. Many shops and restaurants are here.

Original Sydney. What a lovely spot, markets, eateries, quirky shops, allegedly the oldest pub in Sydney, narrow lanes and alleyways - and just an incredible buzz about the whole area. Walking tours available of what is an incredibly historic part of an amazing city.
Wonderful area of Sydney. Lovely area to mooch around - and spoil yourself at Pancakes on the Rocks! Wonderful views of the quays and also home to the contemporary art gallery

Historical sight but not as good as i hoped. Slightly over commercialized but features the rocks museum which was free which is always good. There were markets there on the weekend which was quaint. Having been to europe that is steeped in tradition and baroque architecture, the rocks was nothing too fantastic in the arena but still worth a quick look for a quick peek down memory lane in sydney
Excellent scenic area for food and shopping. Give yourself a few hours so you can shop and have lunch or dinner. Great views, lots of shops and restaurants....take you time and enjoy.

Check out the Saturday Markets - They area Great. We took a wander around the Saturday Markets, well worth a look. A little on the pricey side, but everything is quality and often quite different to other markets.

Shopping on the rocks. If you can go on the weekends they have a lot of street vendors with some local crafts and such- Makes for a nice walk and interesting to see the mix of items that are available- I bought a golf marker with a coin from my year of birth-- they also said had food vendors and juices available. Nice day out-- They close by 5

Strolling through history -- what could be better?. I loved the remains of the old houses and lanes, the warehouses with cool shops, the lovely coffee shops and sidewalk restaurants, the art galleries and museums. An easy way to learn about Australia's beginnings.

History comes to life - Free entry. Go to the Rocks Discovery Museum this little treasure is up a laneway but well worth the effort to find it. As well as explaining the history of the Harbour & Sydney & its first inhabitants it then takes you through the various periods of history to modern day thru a series of hands on exhibits. Children will enjoy being able to touch & hear. There are also several short films to watch.

great place for history and browsing. This is the oldest part of Sydney and has historical significance. It is also loaded with quaint shops and restaurants. On Saturday there is an open air market with tons of stalls selling a variety of merchandise. It just is a fun place to stroll around.
A very nice stroll. We liked the neighbourhood, full of little places & restaurants to discover. Don' t make a plan and get lost in the area. You will like it ! !

Must See in Sydney!. Don't miss this. The history is fabulous and there is so much to learn about early Australian life from the Rocks. Most of the old streets and houses are still there just as they used to be. There is an EXCELLENT little museum there and loads of good eateries. It is like stepping back in time; I especially loved it because I'm enthralled by Australian history. I loved learning about the first hospital, walking the "Nurses Walk" and the "Surgeons Walk". What a lot of stories those old walls would have to tell. If you are bringing someone to Sydney, this visit must feature on the agenda. There is also an amazing market there, very much reminiscent of the Salamanca Market in Hobart. It may be open every day till the mid-afternoon, not quite sure. I got a couple of fantastic handmade jigsaw puzzles there, original and very interesting scenes. Book a tour if you can in order to learn more. Don't forget the museum. What a great place it was!

A really great place for visitors!. Great mixture of architecture, markets, alleys, cafes, restaurants, museums, street musicians, buskers, hotels. Views over the harbour. Close to Circular Quay and all the ferries, and to the main berth for ocean liners.
Fun. A little touristy, but this is a great place to walk to from the Opera House. Fun also to see the people walking the bridge directly above you!
A visitor. A great place indeed... great coffee, great shops, great restaurants... perfect. What more can u want...

Another charming spot of the lovely city of Sydney. The Rocks is another great place to go: from there you have a wonderful view of the Sydney Opera House and the Bridge Harbour. You can also find there some nice buildings of historical relevance that today are used as Art galleries, restaurants, bars, museums (such as the Museum of Contemporary Arts), great hotels, etc.

The Rocks. Really enjoyed The Rocks area. Looked through markets and had a lovely lunch at a café. We walked all around and eventually got to Hero of Waterloo as I wanted to see it again as my family and I had visited it before a few years ago

Great Craft Fair. Spent a pleasant Sat going through the covered street craft fair. When our ship came back to
Sydney on our back to back cruise we returned to get a few gifts that we did not get the first time.

Lovely. Great area to stroll through, with beautiful buildings. There was a nice choice of restaurants for lunch, and great upmarket shops. The Metcalf Arcade had some lovely little shops, I especially like the one-off pieces of modern jewellery in the AHW Studio.
Go explore!. lots to see - plenty of eating establishments. Quite touristy tho, although to be expected. Go to the weekend market.

My favourite place in Sydney CBD. I really love the rocks. My fiance and I live out west, and when it's a special occasion we take the 1 hour drive into town. We park near Circular Key and go for a stroll along past the ferries, the usual Aboriginal fella with his didgeridoo entertaining tourists, and start the markets. It takes us atleast an hour, and we leave with bags of goods. Afterwards, we talk under the Harbour Bridge, sit down near the canons, and watch a wedding or two. Very lovely.
A stroll around the shops and restaurants. Great historical area and great spot for seafood and some upmarket shopping with great views of the harbour and opera house

Overhyped. The reality doesn't match the hype, its a moderately interesting area for a half hour stroll but could be a lot better if a little imagination was brought to bear with some quality outlets replacing the existing tatty stalls and cheap restaurants.

Stylish but not historic. As an Egyptian , historic to me means ,something - at least - hundreds years old , but I really loved the Rocks , it is ,relatively, old , with very stylish restaurants , high quality cuisine and service , it is an attraction you can n't miss in Sydney , dinner at one of the Rocks restaurants is highly recommended ,especially , weekend dinners , go and enjoy the delicious food and fantastic atmosphere .

Family Getaway. We loved the rocks. We stayed at the Shangri La which was close and we found the accessibility to everything was wonderful.The market was a great treat too.We would come back to the rocks again. Loved it !!
Great market. Wiled awY some hours at the Rocks Market. Great quality goods and lots of food in a wonderful setting. The buildings are stunning and lots of great places to eat and drink.

Life on the rocks. This is an area not to be missed. Super restaurants, lovely shops and a fantastic pub the Glenmore where they serve lovely food with a roof top terrace that over looks the Opera House. this is certainly the place to meet friends.
Lovely to walk around. Getting to know the heritage of the city by a short distance walk that is definitely worth doing. You'll need comfortable and plenty time to see this side of the city. A must!

A step back in time. The Rocks are a great starting point for any visit to Sydney. So much to see and do from bars and restaurants as well as historic sites and little alleys to explore. A great atmosphere on the weekends or when a cruise ship is docked.

Historic part of Sydney .... The Rocks is an historic part of Sydney, with little side streets and alleyways. There are information boards at various places explaining what they were and the sort of people who lived there. It is now mainly boutique shops and restaurants, but interesting just the same.
histosic .. A really well preserved area , has australias oldest building beautifully preserved , had a ploughmans lunch in the oldest pub , a really fascinating site .

The world's best tourist trap. Get off any Sydney Wharf ferry, turn right and whammo you end up in the Rocks. Outstanding set of historical streets offering premium retail. Wonderful cafe's. One of the best places to find anything and everything touristy to Australia.
worth a look. Fortunately was there when the street market was on. The market was well organised and worth a look. Prices were not too bad and Ugg cheapest in Sydney.

A new take on history. Fun place to visit, many great historic building with many tales to tell.
The market is great with many unique items and souvenirs that are not tacky
Spoilt for choice when looking for something to eat all budgets covered.
Interesting old sydney. This is a great place to amble around and see the sites. Try and go when the street market is on some interesting stalls and food.

Dining out in the Rocks. We caught up with friends and family at the Lord Nelson Hotel which is an old favourite and then walked down the hill to the Argyle Hotels for a really good value Asian set menu dinner

I Guess I Missed Something. I can't believe that the Rocks has a better rating than a tour of the Sydney Opera House. Sure the Rocks was a nice place to walk around, but I guess I missed something because my experience was just average.

street eat and greet. if you want to see all of the world in Sydney go to the Rocks-if you stood for half and hour I'm sure you'd see someone that you knew-everyone is here-shopping, eating, drinking and living the fair dinkum lifestyle

Wonderful area. Take a stroll in the Rocks ! Lots to see and wonderful view over the seaside. I was there on a windy day but it did not matter. I thoroughly enjoyed my walk and see the historic areas.

Fascinating.. In a modern city like Sydney, it's easy to overlook it's history. The a Rocks is a generally well preserved part of the city, with narrow lanes and 18th and 19th century buildings. There is a very useful information centre with good, supplementary information on the city's notorious and exotic past.

Take a map and do some reading before hand. This Old part of Sydney is really interesting but you need to do some homework before you begin otherwise you will miss so much of the history of the area. They have done a good job to post interesting historical displays but it takes time to wander about...plan on stopping for a drink to relax and begin again or pack a bite to eat and sit along the water to enjoy the views across the bay or up to the bridge....see if you can spot people walking the span!

Early Settlement in Australia. The entire area is a designated historic site. Take a tour and learn about the convicts, soldiers and early settlers. Archaeologists have uncovered some of the old homes that were built into the rocks. Very interesting.
Markets are great. The rocks are a lovely way of seeing old Sydney. We went on a Saturday, market day. Lots to see and buy.

A bit of history saved from the developers!. The Rocks is an area of the Harbour which was saved from developers and preserved to our benefit. Much as we love initialled high rise blocks, the city has a heritage which could have been lost if it were not for local people who fought to preserve many of the shops and houses in the area. Of course, the tourist industry has made a big impact, but I liked the way that the history of the area had been preserved not only in the buildings and museum, but also with plaques and boards on the sides of buildings which we enjoyed reading as we strolled around the area. There was a great market at the weekend when we visited including a glassblower! Easy to spend half a day there - we also enjoyed the Bavarian restaurant in the heart of the area - a lot of fun and great food and beer!

Perfect Weekend at The Rocks. This place has everything whatever your age and interests. Take in the sights of the bridge and the opera house, visit the contemporary arts, wander around the weekend market, listen to the fantastic buskers and enjoy a leisurely breakfast or lunch. One of my favourite places to wile away the time.
Can't be missed. Incredible shops, street food galore, and amazing views. Close to the Circulat Quay, Opera House, amazing architecture, cannot be missed.

It isn't what it used to be. This used to be a wonderful place to visit, one could spend hours just walking around. It is very commercialized and this detracts from the Old Rocks, it is now just a cafe culture.
The Rocks Rock. Great place to walk around or just sit and soak up the atmosphere. Plenty to do and see; pubs, cafes, shops and the market (at the weekend). Museums and galleries are close by.

Free walking tour is a must for history buffs. We did the free walking tour which started at 6pm. Ross is a young Guy who certainly knows his stuff when it comes to Sydney & we really enjoyed our time with him. It's well worth doing.
Good place for souvenirs. We picked up everything we needed for presses in a short time and enjoyed browsing all the stalls. We did not find it too expensive

A very interesting place to visit. This area of Sydney has got so much for your to see. You could spend all day there. You need to be able to walk up and down stairs. The history that is on display is awesome. The market stalls make it even better

Lovely area and great markets. Best to take your time to explore this area. Many back lanes etc with interesting shops. Markets here every weekend are very popular. A fabulous French Bakery coffee shop also. Good spots for breakfast.

Best on weekends. Really enjoyable on the weekends with the markets and buskers. Heaps of people out and about to sit and watch. Great market food and a pleasant outlook over the harbour. Take advantage of the free 555 bus to get you their from George Street
Hyped, but there are better places. OK, what about The Rocks? It's hyped by so many people that you'll feel obliged to go. However, there are better places in Sydney, such as Surrey Hills.

Historic Area of Sydney with a bit of Everything. The Rocks was one of the very first areas of Sydney that was settled. At the northern end of Sydney next to the Harbour there are historic old buildings and many cafes. restaurants and bars, the Sydney Museum of Contemporary Art, the entrance to the Sydney Harbour Bridge Climb and of course lots of interesting shops. On Saturday and Sunday you can find a quality street market. There is a free walking tour available too. The Garrison Church is the oldest in Sydney and very charming.
Amazing walking tour. Took the convicts walking tour with Urban Adventures, loved it and learned so much about the settlement of Sydney and Australia. Highly recommend this tour!
A great place to stay. Plenty of good restaurants that are reasonably priced, and a good Fortune Teller! We found him on the Sunday of the weekend market. We also had a massage which was great.
Loved It. We visited The Rocks near Circular Quay every day during our stay in Sydney. Sitting on the benches people watching while eating an ice cream and seeing the cruise ships.
Amazing market. Apart from the history here there is an amazing market here on Saturdays and Sundays. Plenty of places to eat and a great pub close by.

Full of history. The Rocks is a brilliant location for those who love history, culture, markets, cafes, and the like! There are museums and art galleries, and The Rocks is location right next to Circular Quay, making access all to simple. Add on views of Sydney Harbour Bridge and the Opera House, and it is a great stop...even if you just want to have a walk around!

Oldest part of town. Bars and shops also historic places. Next to Circular Quay and the Cruise Terminal. Well worth a visit. Try La Renaissance Patisserie and Café, we loved it particularly the Almond slices. Tourist info is also here.

A Fun Venue. Spent three nights nearby (Four Seasons). Had a great time in and near the Rocks. Ate 3 nights at an Italian restaurant (Appetito on George Street) which we loved. Wandered through the shops (very nice) and spent our last few hours at the weekend market (much bigger and nicer than we expected).Had a great visit to the observatory just beyond the Rocks ( the astronomy exhibits and the tie to Captain Cook were facinating. We visited the first "Garrison" church at the foot of Observatory Hill (terrific views of the city from outside the Observatory). Ate lunch near the Observatory at a cafe run by women for the National Trust - delicious food (cash only).

Lovely Historic Part of Sydney. We visited the Rocks almost every day on our stay in Sydney we loved this part of town. Lots of history, great architecture and fantastic markets. The restaurants are a bit pricey but the views are worth it and its right in the thick of it all.
Nice walking area. Lovely walk around the Rocks. Quite a few pubs to sample the local beers and more than enough shops to satisfy the most discerning shopper. Lovely opal jewelery.

everything and more - so much to choose from. walking around the rocks is a mustthe historical factor is brilliant do the free walk with a tour guidethe B&B's are lovely the staff are amazingthe sights are great i can't fault the place

Beautiful structures with Bars all around. This is one place you definitely do not want to miss when you are visiting sydney. Its near harbour bridge, its got bars all around which serve some great collections. You can have a great view of the harbour Bridge and Opera House after gulping couple of drinks...

Sydney- The Rocks. We really like this area of Sydney for it's history and heritage. It is also quite Bohemian, with its markets, and eateries. Rocks museum is excellent. Be sure to look above eye-level better to see the old buildings and visualise the past.

Best tourist destination in Sydney. A great place to have a few lazy beers or an upmarket meal, The Rocks suits all budgets and tastes. Weekend markets are great, the views exquisite, and the atmosphere buzzing. A great place for celebrations including St Patrick's Day, Christmas, New Years. Walking distance to the Sydney Harbour Bridge, The Opera House, Circular Quay and the city. Some of Australia's best original architecture, and just a great place to be!
Great. Great spot to hang out on a sunny day. Lots of shops, cafes and bars. I really nice atmosphere around the rocks, always worth a visit

Huge weekend marketplace. We went on a Saturday for the outdoor marketplace. Hundreds of booths selling everything from food to jewelry. Lots of people selling Australia-made crafts, jewelry, art, music. Lots of restaurants. Good walking around old town feel.

Loved it. Have been to Sydney heaps of times, but just recently was my first time to the Rocks area. I ws fascinated with the way the modern shops had merged into the old buildings, so very charming, and the range of different shops was impressive. Definitely going on a pub crawl there next visit!

Old history and modern attractions. Walking in and around the streets in the Rocks, if you have time, you can see behind the glamour of the posh shops and eateries and glimpse some of the history. We did a walking tour - well worth it - but there are plenty of information boards as well. The weekend market has lots of individual crafts people, as well as more touristy fare. Excellent food and drinks in many places.

rock on. make an effort to see Australian contempory art museum - well worth an hour or 2 - resteraunt upstairs has great views- rocks is a bit of a rip off but comes alive on weekend nights- a melting pot of tourists and lost Aussies -

Markets on Sundays. I stumbled across the markets on Sunday which was a bonus. Nice way to pass the time. I loved the little cobble stone lane ways and discovered little restaurants tucked away under a big leafy tree. Very quaint.

Pleasant enough - but try and avoid the crowds. Loads of tourists during the day (maybe related to a cruise liner being in dock). If you follow the guide books etc it all just seems a little over-hyped to me. In reality lots of modern buildings with only the odd smattering of the old appearing every now and then. This in itself is completely fine and all jolly pleasant - but I just felt it was being forced down my neck. Why not just take it for what it is?By coincidence, we had walked around the area a week or so before - without any guide book and not really knowing much about the area. It was late in the evening, less people around but considerably more atmospheric. Bars and restaurants bustling etc etc.My recommendation would be a) visit in the evening/night and b) take a map but leave the guide book behind.

Nice Walk. Another nice spot to walk around. Good places to grab a coffee and pastry...a few good restaurants/bars as well. But try to stay away from the places built for the cruise ships and tourists because you will pay.

History. I enjoy walking around the rocks area so much character & history there. Lots of old pubs that as you walk in almost tell you their stories. Sandstone buildings from eras long gone. Well worth a visit, pull up a sit at one of the many lovely spots & have a bite to eat or an ice cold beer.

Atmosphere, charm and great attractions. The markets at the Rocks are always interesting to walk through and there are so many little cafes and pubs to take a little break. We enjoyed Devonshire Tea at a great little Irish Cafe near the markets that had nice tea, great freshly made scones and a tasty range of jams.
More history. So this is where the convicts arrived. For years this was a port for the many sailors. Now a vibrant area for tourists and citizens.

Great piece of History. A Must see you can go on tours,have a drink at the many bars,eat at the several restaurants , or shop!
You may prefer to go on a tour too

A little taste of early Australia. An interesting area to explore the early history of Australia, particularly if you have time to do a guided walk. For tourtists there is plenty of shopping and the pubs offer great food and cold beer.You don't need a lot of time, an hour or two is enough, and the views of the harbour, the bridge and the opera house are spectacular from this part of Sydney.

History - Restaurants - Open Weekend Markets. Sydney Historical area, cruise ships in the ferry area, restaurants including Japanese, 5 star cuisine, pizza, burgers, coffee shops and bus transfers are all found in the local area!

Interesting Neighborhood - Must See. Took the Free Walking Tour through The Rocks at 6 p.m. last week. Great tour and cool neighborhood. I stayed in The Rocks 20 years ago but never walked around the neighborhood. You can walk through the alleys and byways by yourself, but to get the real flavor of The Rocks, you should take one of the tours. The tour guides tell you about the history of the area as well as folklore. The Rocks was established as a neighborhood shortly after the colony's formation in 1788. Over the years there were many attempts to demolish The Rocks. However, due to a variety of circumstances (wars, unions and politics), The Rocks was renovated and became a tourist and commercial area. A great portion of the commercial area are the pubs and restaurants that can be abundantly found throughout The Rocks. There is also a well staff tourist bureau in one of the buildings.

Fun walkabout dripping with history. If you love funky areas to poke about..go. Weekends there is a market, everyday is a free Discovery Museum that will give you mini version of Sydney history.Like Vancouver's Gastown, but more petite.

Lovely area....like a Disney set. The Rocks are beautiful, really easy to navigate, you feel safe walking around in the area and everything is very clean. Really quick to get to the Harbour Bridge or to walk down to the Opera House.Circular Quay is where the buses and ferries go from and all the staff there are super helpful.Only time I felt vulnerable - an aerial attack from a Seagull at Circular Quay...they like sandwiches! Be aware! ;-)

Cool Neighborhood. I visited the Rocks about 3 times while I was in Sydney for dinner, the Saturday Market, and a tour. I loved all the history that the Rocks had to offer. The Saturday market was definitely cool and worth a top. Sydney Free Walking Tour does a Rocks tour which is very informational. There are a lot of bars and restaurants in the area that look very nice and busy. I would recommend a visit.
Lovely area to wander. It's just lovely to lose yourself around the Rocks and allow yourself to get muddled in the little alleys. There's plenty of things to do and see so definitely head there!
brilliant atmosphere. I could never tire of this place. It has everything from museums and art galleries to great food and drink and quirky shops. Brilliant.
History. Great to walk and explore around the reconstructed walkways and old pubs, its like a step back in time!

A lovely part of Sydney. The rocks always has that appeal about it, with the modern city just behind the historical buildings it is a great contrast. On Fridays there is a foodie market which has some interesting multi cultural offerings, it is obviously extremely popular with locals as there were a lot of bussines people around lunch time queing for food. The prices are good and you are spoiled for choice. On Saturday and Sunday there are general markets as well. We were there on Valentines day and there were some lovely local art and craft people selling good quality jewelry paintings and the like. The shopping in the arcade next to the tourist center is good and it is easy to stroll down under the Harbour Bridge for a look, I wouldn't bother with the ice cream from the van though it was pretty awful.

yes, the Rocks is a great place to visit - but certainly go elsewhere. I thought (as others mentioned) it was a little dull, but quaint. Would recommend a walk around it to the Opera house, but there are just so many other parks and places I prefer in Sydney

Most charming part of town. We stayed at the Park Hyatt for 3 nights, which is located right in The Rocks. The neighborhood is very quaint and original, with many of Sydney's oldest buildings and establishments located here. If you aren't already staying here, it's definitely worth a visit to stroll through the many little alleys, and stop in a few shops or catch the weekend market. The views of the Sydney Opera house are of course stunning from this side of the Quay.
Small old Sydney. Nice place to stroll in the small alleys of old Sydney .lots of small shops and good restaurants .we had delicious dinner in one of them.it is recommended to see the well kept Rocks

The Rocks Sydney. Too many good things to list, many many bars and eating houses which are all very niceAll the bars are supported by security outside, as there seems to be an underage drinking culture, not a problem for us!

NICE Tiny shops big reliëf After hanging put in the city, little shops cosy bars Art galeries . I love place inderdaad Not that all but showing heritage and it is having much More character than the city don't expect spending a full Day but worthwhile For shopping And deining
Not too bothered by it. Was expecting too much of the famous Rocks, obviously!Its an ok stroll around but nothing really held my interest for too long.

Wonderful Outdoor Market!. We went to the Rocks neighborhood on a Sunday afternoon, and there was a fun and interesting crafts market (with handmade goods, not touristy-junk), local musicians playing instruments, great food and beautiful weather!
weekend delight. Go at the weekend and join in the fun of the markets and restaurants and food stands - a funky place to be
Love this place. Nice place, especially pancakes on the rocks and the view of the opera house . Would definitely recommend.
A must see. Beautiful old suburb very near the ferries of Circular Quay. Full of history and charm. There is a street market there on saturdays.

Historical Rocks. A great area to meander around full off history from the early convict days .Great pubs and a museum depicting the lives of working class families . A great craft market is in the heart of the Rocks on Saturdays and Sundays with unusual quality items .

you could not miss this place. i like those old streets, old buildings, very unique.
Weekends markets are available, surrounded with many restaurants~

A historical part of the history of Sydney. This area was once the beginnings of Sydney. It was a penal colony where people convicted of minor crimes were sent from England to be punished and isolated. Today it is preserved and you find it right next to the passenger terminal on the harbor. There is a museum about The Rocks that is worth visiting and a walking tour. We found this a very interesting place and an eye on the beginnings of Sydney.
Old and interesting. Has some wonderful bars and restaurants. Also art galleries of all types. If you want to stay in Luxury the Hyatt with great views and proximity to everything.

Nice place to visit old Sydney. The best places to start exploring Australia’s oldest city are at The Rocks. It is situated on the southern shore of Sydney Harbour / Northwest of CBD. It is short walk from the Sydney Opera House and Circular Quay. It is restored 19th century village at the Southern end of the Sydney Harbour Bridge. It is considered to be the birthplace of Australia. The area features cobbled streets and squares, gas lamps, craft shops and small restaurants. Here too are several historic buildings, including one of the city’s oldest, Cadman’s Cottage, built in 1816, and two of Sydney’s oldest pubs. It is recommended that visitors seek information and a map from The Rocks Visitor’s Centre (in George Street) in order to make the most of the neighborhood and its many attractions, which include museums, view sites, markets, monuments and buildings. From The Rocks it is also possible to access the Pylon Lookout on the famous Sydney Harbour Bridge for an amazing view of Harbor and beyond. Step back in time and surround yourself in Sydney's most historic precinct known as The Rocks. Discover the many sandstone buildings, cobblestone streets and monuments marking moments in history which enable visitors to gain an appreciation of Sydney's foundation as a convict built settlement. The Rocks is a popular destination for school history excursions. Visit to Discovery Museum is free. Although historic in nature, The Rocks offers some of Sydney's finest dining and entertainment experiences available. Rocks Market operates each weekend 10am till 5pm.

Has the old building disappeared?. All four of us felt a market building had been gobbled up and replaced by Galleria? Has it? We can all vaguely remember wandering round inside a market building with long corridors and little arch ways but we could not find it. It all seems very modern and clean, not how we remembered it at all. Even the cobbled steps have been concreted over in many places.

Lots of really interesting stores and cafes. You could spend a good half day just wandering around the Rocks. We really enjoyed the coffee houses, and some of the stores are unique - the leathers and shoes and dress shops and the art shops - though you can get better prices on the art in less commercial places.
Old Sydney. A nice area to stroll through in the evening for drinks or dinner. It's one of the original areas from when the Sydney was first established.

Nice place to spend an afternoon. Much history, great shopping, especially the weekend market, and lots of excellent places to eat. Located right off the harbor in view of the bridge and the opera house.

Do not miss it!!. Absolutely something that needs to stay on your itinerary! Find some time to spend at The Rocks...yes Sydney is a big city but when you are here you completely forget about the over 4,000,000 people living in the area!

Wish we had more time to spend at The Rocks. If I ever get back to Sydney, I will spend more time in The Rocks. It's just the type of revitalized historical area that I love. There are terrific restaurants, a couple of nice, small museums, and lots of shops. We ate at two restaurants--Fish at the Rocks and the Waterfront--that were excellent. If you happen to be staying at a hotel near the Rocks, by all means skip the expensive hotel breakfast and wander down to one of the delicious looking bakeries or cafes. This is also a great place to wander casually so that you can admire the 19th century architecture. There were lots of clubs in the area too. This is definitely a part of any trip to Sydney.
Pricey. Nice area to walk along but pricey. Take lots of money. Definitely a tourist area.go a bit further and you'll find the wharf area. Lots of restaurants an eateries around there

Great views, neat weekend market, good food.. We went on a weekend so we got to enjoy the market in addition to the usual attractions. Many small vendors had tents with all kind of wares. Several offered crafts items made from local natural materials such as seed pods, semi-precious stones, and local sandstone. You will just have to be careful not to buy more than you can carry home!I highly recommend "The Tea Cozy" for a pot of hot tea, or a pitcher of great flavored ice tea. It is tucked in behind a Celtic Shop and has great scones with clotted cream and wonderful jams. You will be glad you stopped. You can eat inside or out on the neat patio area.

Explore this area. Great place to spend a weekend shopping, with the Saturday and Sunday markets. Markets were not the same old junk, they were upmarket with plenty of variety in the stalls. Restaurants were very good in this area too. excellent views of Sydney harbour and the bridge. lovely old buildings.

A taste of the past. In a city which, sadly, does not proclaim much of its history to the tourist, The Rocks area is a gem. Well worth the 66 steps up from Circular Quay. Its history is well documented with relevant signage on just about every alleyway and historic building, some of which have been re-invented for the modern day scene. The cobbled streets are lined with eateries, galleries, craft places and niche market shops with very little evidence of the touristy plastic trash one sees so often. No-one trying to push flyers and tourist literature into your hand either. If you have a desire to cross the bridge on foot it's only another 63 steps up to the roadway but you have to walk a fair way before you're actually over water. If you're walking the bridge in summer, starting from The Rocks side affords what little shade there is to be found. The Glenmore pub adjacent to the steps up from Circular Quay boasts a rooftop bar with superb views but don't visit on a Friday late afternoon if you're seeking peace and quiet! I so wish I'd heard about the guided walking tour prior to spending time in the area but it didn't appear on any of the tourist literature I'd picked up. Would have been worth the $25 I'm sure even if, again, they don't acknowledge overseas senior cards. Why oh why is Australia so mean in this regard, especially as it must now be close to the top of the most expensive cities in the world to visit.

The Rocks. This is where we disembarked from our cruise ship. Great area, old buildings and unique shops. Within walking distance of the Ferry Terminal & Train Station, Within walking distance of the Chinese Gardens.
Fun art galleries, shops, Saturday street faire. Loved just walking around and taking all of it in. Great old architecture of the buildings at the Rocks. Plenty of good food and drink opportunities.

Lovely. Great are to wonder aroudn cobbled streets (very hilly)
A good gift store I can recconmen id Harbour Rocks gift store on Harrington Street, is not all the main the main stram gifts you see in the other tourist shops.
Great, Fun area.. It is a beautiful neighborhood. Lots to do and see. Many options for restaurant. Great Saturday and Sunday markets. Right by the beautiful harbor.

Great galleries, restaurants and architecture. this historic area of Sydney city is packed with heritage architecture and little cobbled streets. take time to east in some of the amazing restaurants and look inside the art galleries. you can also walk up onto the Sydney harbour bridge from here, with great views of the harbour and city skyline

Nice on a sunny day. I think you could almost walk past the Rocks and not realise you were there! There are some great pubs/cafes/restaurants and walking around and reading the various signage gives you a nice overview of the history of the area which is basically all about the military. Its free and a nice walk and easily done while in Circular Quay!

A great dining and shopping area.. I would have loved more time there. Lots of cute shopping and dining for everyone. Pubs and nice dining. Very clean and classy place to visit and walk around. Much history in the Rocks.

Favorite place in Sydney. Wow, what a wonderful place. The Rocks was my favorite place that I visited in Australia.It is a beautiful area with so much history. For lovers of dance, stop by Sydney Dance Co down at the wharfs. There are lovely little places to grab a quick bite to eat or places to sit down. I really loved how quiet it is. I'm moving to Sydney in the next two years, and the Rocks is my first choice when looking for apartments.Also: great public restrooms/toilets

Quaint area. The Rocks is a pretty, quaint old area with lots of cobbles, lovely shops, restaurants & cafes. Some great art work too, well worth a half day to walk around. We didn't do the walking tour but think this may well have enhanced our visit if we had.
A great area. There are many shops and restuarants in this area. A very nice place to walk around and then have some dinner.
Nice walking tour. Our group had a nice walking tour of this area with a lovely guide. While you can easily do this on your own, by having a guide we learned more information and history.
quiet. We went there on a day that the market wasn't on and it was very quiet and not much to do.The market really makes this area buzz

What a Sunday Market!. If you're visiting Sydney, you MUST go to the Sunday Market. There's so much good quality stuff for sale, you'll be mesmerised and spoilt for choice! There's good cafes and restaurants around The Rocks too.

Dedicate a half day to just visiting the Rocks. Australia has fairly recently come to terms with it's convict pact. The Rocks is a good place that exhibits this. I did the Rocks Walking Tour Sydney for a few hours as my primer, printed off Wikipedia and then toured and read the well-marked landmarks in this historical and oldest part of Sydney. I found the Walking Tour was a great introduction to the key people and places of the Rocks. i then wanted to dig into the alleyways and learn move about Nurses Row/Walk or the origin of some of the prestigious buildings and fortifications there and stories of how criminals became heralded figures as they moved from the Old World and re-established themselves in the New World. Names of buildings logically originate from some truth here. If you have a fascination with finding unique stories of 'old' Australia and a penchant for scavenger hunts, then this area is the place for you.
great location. this is the area to stay to access all of the good parts of Sydney.some great eateries and drinking establishments to suit all tastes

So many things to do.. The Rocks are not only on the doorstep to Sydney Harbour but they can be a starting point for so many things to do in Sydney.On the weekends try the markets for interesting items from many open air stores. You can also book a Rocks walking tour or by night try the Rocks ghost tour.There are many opportunities for food in and around the Rocks. You can also easily walk to Circular Quay, catch a Ferry and try other Sydney Harbour attractions.Don’t forget to take your camera for shot of historic buildings, the Bridge, Opera House, Tall Ships and even Cruise Ships.
The Rocks. Great place to shop with very old buildings beautifully restored like old Quebec City. Right beside the cruise ship.
Very Different. It showcases a different part of Sydney. There are a lot of good high end restaurants nearby. Lots of crafts and good for some not so typical shopping.

Historic Are, GREAT RESTurNTS. Historic waterfront area dating back to Sydney's earliest days. The old wharves etc have been modernised and the area contains many great restaurants and bars. One of my favourite parts of the city.
Sweet Place. You should visit The Rocks at night,this place are beautiful and a fancy old neighborhood.Take some time to take pictures.

My favorite place in Sydney. I just love walking around in the Rocks. I wish I could've gone everyday. On weekends, there is some sort of market/fair going on. It's fun to walk around. Even without the market, the whole area is just adorable, and filled with wonderful restaurants, cafes and pubs. You can sit outdoors and people watch. Or have a cup of flat white coffee (sort of like cafe au lait) in the French bakery, where the staff has thick French accent. If I have to choose a place to go back to (among Darling Harbor, the beaches, Circular Quay or CBD), this would be it.
Good area for bars and people watching. Definitely go here, have a drink at one of the many places, watch the world go by and drool....great area!

Going back in time. We didn't really go for this area, but "accidently" came this way on our walking tour. The area was a pleasant place near the harbour area and there was some nice and cosy restaurants spread out in the area.
Also just looking at the old but renovated buildings in this area is a pleasure.
Historic and beautiful. We visited the Rocks on a day when the markets was on, it was buzzing with people. The historical buildings were interesting, the views of the harbour - beautiful.
MUST SEE FOR VISITORS!. For anyone visiting Sydney for the first (or tenth) time, The Rocks is a must-see! The historical setting, colonial buildings and views are unique and 100% enjoyable!

Rocking fun. We found out while in Sydney that The Rocks has an art faire on the weekends so that's when we went. We bought so many things, that we actually had to ship most of it home. Some streets are cobblestone, so make sure to wear comfortable shoes. So if your stay has a weekend included in it, make sure to visit The Rocks during that time...
A must do. It is good to walk around The Rocks and visit some of the coffee shops and pubs offering pub deals. The history behind the area is interesting and was very glad it was preserved.

Historical, hip and happy!. Everyone must stroll about The Rocks for the atmosphere with the history, eateries, interesting old narrow laneways and views of the harbour. It's a part of the Sydney experience.

Australia Day was a great time to visit!. There were so many vendors, the streets were closed for only foot traffic here and there. We had pancakes for breakfast and walked the area for the rest of the day. The prices were reasonable for most of the items. We found one vendor that was ok with the US dollar, I am sure there were others vendors that would take US dollars. I am sure these vendors are there some on one are days of the week We can back to this area on our last day so I could eat a steak (kangaroo), I like my beef steaks medium well but the kangaroo was prepare medium which was very red. It was ok, not like a beef steak to me. The restaurant is on the first corner as you enter the area from the city. We met couples that had been in Australia for a month or more, they all had spent some time in The Rock area. I was able to exchange money and sometime ask for five more dollars for the exchange. Look for the candy-man, he and his wife are great to talk too. We visited them a second time licorice and some jellybeans to eat at the hotel and bring back home. Great trip!

Great buzzing little place. The Rocks has no many eateries and great things to see. The view across the water is fantastic and the markets on a Sunday are a must for the tourists. Lots of little aussie things to buy and take home.

Get out your walking shoes. This is the real old town Sydney where all the settlers originally landed. The location is near the Central Quay/Sydney Harbour Bridge.We actually walked around the outside of the rocks to the Harbour Bridge then worked our way down through the steep narrow pathway streets where you get the full feeling of how tough it must have been in the early days. Plenty of Bars, cafe's/restaurants plus shops to view whist you are there. Be prepare for hills to you opt to climb through the street from Harbour level.
Do not miss !. If you are an old couple like we are, you get back your youth. Relaxing with the opera house on the other side and many young people celebrating...

Love the place. This was our second visit to The Rocks and we just love the place. Wether it is the restaurants and little eateries and pubs or the old buildings or market and shopping there is something here for everyone.
Lovely place to walk. This area is not as crowded as Darling harbour and I loved it. Several eating options along the water side..

Flavour of old Sydney. It is quite an interesting walk from Circular Quay to the Rocks. There are some interesting older buildings around the Rocks itself including some of the oldest in Sydney. Friday evening is a good time to visit as there is the market and street entertainment going on. There is a wide selection of places to eat and drink in the area. You are in close proximity to the Bridge and there is the opportunity to get photos of it from different angles to those you usually see.
Rocks Market. The Rocks Market is truly an authentic market place meets contemporary designers. Great place to visit.

Crowded, but fun. The Rocks has music, street performers, restaurants & bars, street food, shops, and galleries. All of these make it a fun and happening place. The location right on Circular Quay means that even if you don't intend to go there, you probably will. But that's okay, because it really is a good place to be. We were there on Australia day, which made it too fun and too happening to entirely enjoy, but you can't blame the Rocks for it's attractiveness. This was our vantage point for some of the activity on the harbour on that day, such as the tall ships coming in.

Rambling Rocks. Over rated unless you go on a market day.Lots of restaurants and cafes to choose from but many are obviously targeting tourists - very dear!As were the souvenir shops.Close to other attractions which is a bonus.Lots of high end designer shops - yay!

Great Markets On The Weekend. On Saturday and Sunday there are the Rocks Markets and they are worth visiting. Lots of handicrafts. There are also some great restaurants in the area to check out. Take time and wander the streets and look at some of the old buildings.

Great markets! Great restaurants, and Great seaview :). The Rocks markets are on Sat and Sunday, and its close to the water front too so take a day out to enjoy the markets, then wander around the waterfront (Darling Harbour) and Circular Quay, also close by the Sydney Opera house too! We spent a day around there loved it :)
Spend time On the Rocks. Great shopping, loads of history, and wonderful food and pubs. What more could you ask for On the Rocks.

A must when visiting Sydney .... So historic and such lovely place to pass the day or evening by. Great restaurants, gift shops and bars with great views of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge. They run walking tours of the rocks which are highly informative. Good Tourist Office here is you are seeking things to do in or around Sydney.

Good bars. Great plAce to hang out
Was there on Australia Day so packed
Mercantile is a good bar
Also harts bar
Well worth a look
Walking distance from centre
A few good eateries down there too

Plenty of bars in this part of town. Very close to the Sydney Harbour Bridge - and plenty of restaurants and bars to eat/drink at. Lots of stairs as this area is quite hilly - which made it feel like you were doing a work out - while having a look around
Historic. Really cool area to walk around with some great places to eat/drink. Place comes with an interesting history to it. Best to check out the "model home".

Enjoyable visit. Thoroughly enjoyed our visits to The Rocks. Plenty to see, interesting shops, cafés and restaurants. Market stalls offering good quality goods as well as the usual tourist goods. Good atmosphere.

a wonderful place. This section of Sydney gives you the feeling of the total Sydney experience with wster all atound, a bustling harbor and the Opera House as your neighbor. Very walkable and friendly

Not As Good As It Used to Be. The Rocks would still be on my list of places to visit in Sydney, but the area has lost some of its luster since a visit a number of years ago. The historic sights are certainly worthwhile along with the Museum of Contemporary Art, but we found only one store this time with quality art and craft. Many had turned to souvenir kitsch.

A history lesson plus. The Rocks is the historic neighbourhood of Sydney where the convicts/ poor used to live, close to the docks. Markets, bars and restaurants are all there in the midst of all the history. It would have been a miserable place to be a hundred or so years ago but it is great now.
Great Location in Sydney. We just love this location and the convenience of all the shops, historical buildings, and scenic views.

History...while eating & drinking. We took a tour through the Rocks & got a bit of History (I'll review that tour in another review). What a cool spot for eating & having drinks. Great views all around. A lot of history in the area...take a tour & learn more about it.

Splendid area for a walk, day or night.. Went to this place with a friend once last year. Amazed at all the good stuff that were located in this part of the capital. We went to a German restaurant for dinner. It was good, although a little bit expensive. But hey, it's The Rocks. Big plus was the fact that there were not many annoying Mainland Chinese tourists. Mostly civilized tourists and locals. Thank goodness.

Great location. Top spot to stay for exploring the rocks and surrounding area of Sydney. There are many bars and restaurants nearby. The hotel also has a cool bar and happy hour. The famous rocks markets are within 50 metres of the hotel lobby. The staff were friendly and helpful. Will definitely be staying there again.
Great. The rocks is a great place to visit been there before and always on the top of our list to go there fantastic place to take a stroll through
Wonderful market at The Rocks. Really enjoyed the weekend market with lots of stalls, and nearby restaurants were also great. We went for the market, and returned for the atmosphere in the evening.

Expensive and over rated!. I think that the clue is in the title!! Take out a small mortgage and you may be able to eat there unless you go to the Lord Nelson or Curry at the Rocks which are just on the periphery of the area.

Living History. There is something to do every step of the way, down at the Rocks. Whether you're into shopping, dining, history, walking, views, bars, markets, being under the Harbour Bridge ... it's all here. Both old and new. You simply cannot think you've "done" Sydney until you have a morning, afternoon, or whole day at The Rocks.

Beautiful Views of the Bridge. This area of Sydney is right under the approach to the Harbor Bridge.Beautiful older area reminiscent of old town London. The cruise ship terminal is on one end of the area and great shops and a hilly incline quite a way up is on the other. Great restaurants abound and if you are there in the summer (Jan-Feb.) there are local markets and street fairs on weekends. Worth a visit!
Cosy. The most cosy place of Central Sydney. It has a nice market on Saturday and it has nice terraces. Just minutes away from the Harbour.
New Years Eve. We stood at this area on New Years Eve, wow!!! What a Spectacular view. I have never seen anything like it, what a fabulous night. Well done Sydney you did yourselves proud.

Historic heart of Sydney. The Rocks offers a multitude of activities, places to eat and drink and see and do. It is a historic and interesting part of Sydney with little alleyways and rock faces. I have always enjoyed visiting this part of Sydney and adore the views it has to offer

Worth a look around. Beautifully looked after, The Rocks has almost a quaint feel to it. Just a 10 minute walk from the CBD it is definitely worth a visit. Plenty of cafes and restaurants, shopping for souvenoirs and guided tours for those interested in the history.

My favorite section of Sydney. The rocks turned out to be my favorite part of the city of Sydney. I liked all the old style pubs and the shopping. This is an area with small cafés and independent shops. It is quite a contrast to George Street with endless malls and huge corporation stores.This is a great place to people watch while being right near the harbor
Bit of living museam, but still lovely. feels a bit like a theme park sometimes but beautifully restored, maintained and has a great atmosphere. Always busy, and its easy to see why.

The Rocks. Great place to visit and the views are legendary. So well worth a stroll around this area.Beware of the hotels immediately on the front such as Wolfies and the Waterfront, they charge heavy prices and the times we have been there have found the service to be somehwat chaotic, wouldn't go back to them. There are plenty of better eating establishments in the area.

Laid back vibe. The old town feel with it's cobbled streets feels a million miles away from the high rise of the CBD although only a couple of blocks away. A great place to chill out, sit in a bar or watch the world go by over looking the harbour. There are many small boutique and artisan shops for souvenirs. A nice place to spend an afternoon

Arts and crafts!. The Rocks has lots of bars, and small shops where you may want to but some souvenirs. I didn't really buy anything but it is nice to walk around, have some lemonade, and see some tourists.
Lots of Restaurants here!. If you are looking for a great location to stay in Sydney stay near the rocks, there are lots of hotels and restaurants.

One of my favorite spot in Sydney. When I stepped in the Rocks area from Darling Harbour, I felt a cozy feeling. The vibe of the buildings in this street was different with the historic building near Hyde Park and Royal Botanical Garden. The Rocks felt warmer and more inviting. I imagined it to be dull and dry when I looked at the pictures on the web, but it didn't felt like that at all when I was there.The day I visited was quite hot, but there's enough trees and shades from the shop that makes your walk pleasant. I even went in a small street called Nurse Walk where you can find a nice button shop (it has various buttons from cute to sophisticated hand made ones), stones and crystal shop (the owner really understands her stones, if you're interest with alternative healing) and nice coffee shop and cafes. There's a very small alley to go out from Nurse Walk to George St. where there's printed tins in men or women silhouette wearing vintage clothing that has explanation on the Rock's history. I visited on Saturday, so there were some spots that had Saturday markets. The goods that were sold was sooo cute and unique.There were people who sold decals, wood works, home decorative, accessories and lots of clothes.Obviously, being Sydney's oldest area, you find lots of Sydney's oldest, like Pubs, Cafe, Resto, Hotel, Banks. They still keep the vintage look.I didn't try any of those places, since I was keeping space for Pancake on the Rocks pancakes which serves huge, sweet pancakes.If you're interested in art, just near Pancake on the Rocks, there's Ken Dome's gallery for you to visit.Apart from the history, the ambiance makes it one of the must place to visit when you're in Sydney :)

Well worth a visit. As this was the first part of Sydney to be developed long ago it is worth a visit if time allows. It is quite touristy now but safe to walk around, there is a market at the weekend which is fun and if you are interested there are guided walking tours around which help you understand what life was like for the early settlers.
