Quirky. The Rocks are a must see place. Narrow streets, arts and crafts, good food and pubs there is a lot going on all day.
Rocks Markets. What a great place very alive and full of energy on the day of the markets. Some really nice restaurants as well a very enjoyable day just walking around.
Overpriced tourist trap. Walk through but don't eat here it's overpriced and a tourist trap. Everyone says its so cool. But it's just a street in with resturants.
Great place to wander around. So much history, so many great old pubs, very good restaurants, cafes and bars. The markets when happening are well worth a browse.

Wonderfully historic part of Sydney. Superbly historic part of Sydney and ideal for a few hours stroll. I suggest, for a relaxed ramble, that one visits the Rocks during the week and avoids the office midday lunch hour. For a more hectic experience go at the weekend when the Rocks arts and crafts markets are being held.A good way to start a walk of the Rocks is to commence at Circular Quay and then progress into the rocks along the Harbour Foreshore with the Opera House and Harbour Bridge adding to the spectacle,Visit the lovely Garrison Chapel in the heart of the Rocks, where I actually got married, and the small cluster of old Sydney cottages that retain their colonial charm.

Enjoyable time at The Rocks. Walked around The Rocks Sydney - great weather enjoyed pancakes at the Pancake restuarant and shopping in the precinct - filled in the morning well. Would like to go back sometime when the markets are on.

Great area, weekend markets were a bit too busy.. Great area and lots of nice restaurants and interesting shops. The markets had lots of good stalls with interesting things for sale. However it was a bit too crowded for my liking. Lots of pushing and shoving and I would worry about losing young children. Beautiful buildings and streets!
My favorite part of sydney. This is the oldest and most interesting section of Sydney in my opinion. Definitely would recommend visiting.

Love the Rocks. The Rocks is a very expensive part of Sydney, however it is one of the most historical and beautiful parts. If you really want to experience scenery, history, and quintessential Sydney, this is the area to stay - but at a cost. It has great bars, coffee shops, gallery's, and eateries.

Nice area for a walk. This is Sydey's historic neighborhood. It is surely worth a visit and you can enjoy XIXth century architecture as well as plenty of restaurants and cafès.
From this area you can get a very nice view of the Opera House and take some nice pictures. The Museum of Contemporary Art is also there.
Go the markets on Saturday / Sunday. Super area of bars and restaurants close to Circular Quay. The weekend markets are wonderful and will take hours to get around.

Olde Worlde Sydney. The Rocks is the old original area of Sydney. Despite the busy streets now running through the Rocks, its historic old past is plainly visible where it was home to merchants and sea captains. There are numerous small boutique shops selling anything from souvenirs to artworks and some very expensive opals. There are plenty of small cafes with great atmosphere, lots of alleyways, mostly all cobbled, leading down to the Harbour. There are always lots of tourists there, and it's always bustling and busy but there's never enough time to explore. Heartily recommended, and yes, I will definitely visit there every time I go to Sydney.

Visit the Rocks on Sunday. On Sundays, the Rocks becomes an artists' market. Home-made food, crafts, gifts, etc are available. The pubs are alive with music and visitors. The Art Gallery is nearby for those who are overdosed on markets. It is the historical convict past of Sydney has offers a mix of history, beautiful old buildings, narrow streets and modern shopping. Great location.

Lovely place to walk, eat and enjoy. Had a really nice time in the Rocks, we went a few times and had a lovely walk round, nice to look at the markets, had a nice coffee and cakes there. Atmosphere was nice too although food markets were ridiculously busy at lunchtimes which we expected.

So worth experiencing. If you're intrigued about the convicts coming to Australia and what it was like back then, and basically the history of Australia, you would enjoy the area and spending a day walking around. Be sure to wear comfortable shoes and be ready to climb hills, stairs, and walk on uneven ground. This was especially challenging for my elderly father who can see out of only one eye, but we took our time and they stopped to rest wherever they could. Here and there are markers to tell you things, but mainly it's the buildings and surroundings and how they deteriorated over time, and remarkable to see how some places were restored and some were left "as is" and how they function with it that way. The architecture, from regular housing buildings to larger business buildings, is amazing.You have to be willing to walk down alleys if you see a shop, because most of the time, that will lead you someplace else. There's an actual place where you can see what was left from a housing unit and how utterly small the rooms were. Great photo op! Lots of little shops everywhere, eateries and even a travel/information center with restrooms and a fabulous souvenir shop, amongst a mall of sorts. UGG products everywhere. You are also walking in the area where you go for the Sydney Bridgeclimb, which is behind the bridge on the side. We ate lunch where the had an elevator for the top floor restaurant, literally by the bridgewalk climbers with a fantastic view of Sydney Harbor Bridge! After spending the day there, we walked away wth a better understanding of Australia's culture.

Nice place. Be there in the morning on weekend to see the morning market with lots of interesting things. Restaurants, coffee shops, shop lots. Access is easier from Circular Quay, the Rocks is just opposite of the Opera House. Perfect location for your photo shoot with the Opera House background.
Nice place for the weekend. Lots of food stalls and people playing musical instruments. There are also stalls selling art objects.
The rocks. Again the rocks was great, not as I remembered. It the last time I was there was 15 years ago. But was enjoyable to walk around and have a look

Great views of the bridge. Spent the weekend in the rocks, walking around and experiencing what it had to offer. On a beautiful sunny day, we walked George Street, visited the harbour, lunched and visited the old pubs.Walking under the Sydney harbour bridge, there is a great photo opportunity which is not full of tourists and barely any traffic. It is true though that this can not be said for all parts of the rocks. After visiting, I was almost tempted to take out a massive loan and move into one of the original cottages.

something for everyone. lovely area with plenty of history to be seen, vast variety of eating places covering all tastes, amazing range of shops from souvenirs to Ralph Lauren lots of guided walking tours around and small interesting museums.
Really Neat Part of Sydney. The history, the self guided walking tour, quiet streets, close to the Harbour and shopping, good restaurants.

Sights, sun and shops. Gorgeous sunny day in Sydney and the Rocks was a perfect place for a stroll. Street theatre, good quality craft markets with excellent vendors, all the sights of the harbour and opera house, lovely cheap eats, history - its all here at The Rocks.
Not as exciting. We walked through the Rocks and didn't find anything too special. I wouldn't say it's a must do but the history around the Rocks is quite interesting.

Fortune Hotel. We were a bit lost at The Rocks as we didn't know the history that well behind it. We spent and afternoon with friends at the Fortune Hotel (Sydneys oldest hotel) and had a lovely time. Very friendly new owners (Sean) - thanks for a great afternoon.

Great Markets on the Weekends. Our hotel was in The Rocks area and was there for the Saturday markets. I love to shop at markets wherever I go so it was cool we were there for the market. It was really packed but had lots of different things for sale and also lots of different places that where making food and drinks, candy for sale and there was also a guy who was making art with spray paint on poster boards. I brought one of his painting because it was so amazing how he created pictures of Sydney with spray paint. I thought some of the stalls the items for sale were a little expensive, I collect license plates from where I go and the stall had them but selling them for $25 so I decided on the Spray Paint Painting instead because it was better. I would highly recommend checking out the Rocks when the Markets are there and when they aren't to experience both.
Rocks Market. Had a fab day at the Market. So many people!! I had scones and coffee in a little Irish Shop which was really wonderful. Great day out.
Saturday Markets. Went during the Saturday Markets. They had some cute stuff for sale and it was pretty busy. On a weekday it's much more calm if you aren't into crowds.

Vibrant and lively!. The markets were fantastic...so much variety in goods available to purchase. I love the quaint old buildings which house the variety of shopping or dining venues. We enjoyed the street entertainment!A charming place to visit while in Sydney.
Fun place. Fun place for food and shopping. Loved the observatory and the view from it. Great place to wander around and lots to see.

Enjoyable. A fantastic place to visit on weekends for the craft markets. There is something for everyone. Some very talented craft showcased. The guy with the spray painting art is worth standing for 20 minutes watching his masterpieces come to life. The handcrafted jewelry on offer is exceptional. The fashion available from designers trying to make their name stand out is worth exploring. The variety of food on offer is almost too hard to make a choice from. For locals or visitors a couple of hours well spent

Well worth a wander - very touristy. Nice old architecture, lovely walk under the bridge and view across to the Opera House. Very touristy and therefore many people and expensive touristy stuff. Worth looking around.

A village in the city. The Rocks is obviously the most famous area of Sydney Harbour, the place where the first convicts landed and later settled.The Rocks has been decently preserved from any excessive development, as it is the historical heart of Sydney.It is really nice to stroll along the few cobbled streets bordered with 19th century listed buildings and discover the layout of the first buildings that were erected there.Recent excavations uncovered some of the very first houses and lanes that appeared on this rocky hill that today stretches at the foot of the impressive Sydney Harbour Bridge.It looks like a tiny village with its market place and church.A monument –sculpture pays tribute to the first colons, soldiers and convicts who landed on the Rocks and built the colony.This picturesque area is home to a few museums and listed houses, but is mostly occupied by restaurants and pubs, as it is one of the major tourist landmarks of Sydney.The wharf has been highly redeveloped with contemporary buildings that are nice but may not fit very well with the ancient style of the area.The Rocks is great during the day but even more attractive in the evening when all the restaurants are busy and crowds stroll in the streets. It is a very nice area, a small village on the edge of the big city, however, it comes across as a bit fake and artificial, like an historical recreation for tourists.This being said it is obviously a Must See when in Sydney as it is really a great spot from where you can see both the magnificent Harbour Bridge and Opera House.

Nice and Historic. We went to the rocks and its a nice area not to far from Circular Quay. Lots of nice restaurants, pubs, and shops. I recommend that you stop by I recommend that you stop by the First Fleet restaurant and bistro, its the oldest continuously run pub in Sydney. They pour a good pint and the people are very nice.

ROCK'IN THE ROCKS. The Rocks is a great strolling area that includes several shops and comfortable restaurants. The streets are cobbled stones and the walls surrounding the area have been cut out of large rock. You can shop here for tourist souvenirs, including opals, Uggs, and Aboriginal designed items. There is also a tourist office located on an upper floor, which has all the information you will ever need about Sydney and Australia. This area sits just alongside of the Sydney Harbour Bridge. Weekends include an outdoor local market that is very enjoyable.Cross over to Hickson Street and visit Pier 8. It's a great area to stroll around and see the updated, trendy wharfs that are now home to several businesses. Stop in at the Pier Ate Restaurant and have a great breakfast or lunch with a great view.

Atmosphere, history, markets, bars, restaurants, excellent. The oldest and first settled area of Sydney, tucked in behind the Sea Terminal and the Harbour Bridge. We would often take the ferry from Mosman to Circular Quay and walk into the Rocks, stop and have a drink in the Fortune of War, walk up to mingle with the masses in the street market (weekends) and end up in the Mercantile or Australian for more beer and food, try a crocodile pizza in the Australian! The Rocks Rock!
The Rocks. Lovely old area of the city, close to the harbour area. Some great old pubs in the area, each of which now their complete provenance

Bit average. Not sure if I missed something here but found it to be a bit of a non starter. Lots of stalls selling th same stuff and nothing particularly original. Ok to wander to say that you've been but nothing special

A wonderful place for locals and tourists. Love it on the weekend when the markets are on. Not tat, very nice arts and craft, jewellery etc. Take a walk in the back streets to get a real feel for the place. And don't forget to pop into one of the pubs. Really one if the nicest places for a stroll, shop and look

The Rocks,rock. The Rocks forms part of a colorful promenade stretching from The Harbour Bridge to the spectacular Opera House. This precinct reflects what the early colony looked like,characterised by cobbled pavements,narrow side sreets,dockside warehouses,pubs and shopfronts that reflect the area's maritime history. Heritage is what you are experiencing,which makes this area vibrant historically and lively with pedestrian traffic. A market is held every Saturday which showcases aussie artisanship,and while here a great place to explore is Susannah Place Museum which examins the working-class domestic history of the area and the Rocks Discovery Museum,giving you the background to the Aboriginal and maritime history. My suggestion is to start with a coffee at Campbells Storehouses overlooking the waterfront. These bondstores contain restaurants catering to a range of tastes. Relax with the bustle of boats criss-crossing the harbour. Take note of the pulleys that used to haul cargo from the wharves,up at the top of the buildings. Now you are. travelling. CHECK OUT THE sAILORS'hOME,A GALLERY FOR ART LOVERS WITH A GOOD tHAI EATERY BELOW. dWARFED BY THIS BUILDING IS CADMAN'S cOTTAGE WHICH WILL FURNISH ALL THE INFORMATION ABOUT tHE hARBOUR TOURS AVAILABLE. For a genuine 'Ye Old' world dont miss the Argyle Stores housing retail,fashion and eateries around a cobbled courtyard. Good vibes and ambience....Amble further up the hill to the Garrison Church for a taste of military place of worship,but your goodness will be sorely tested at The Hero of Waterloo,a picturesque inn serving brews and spirits. Should you want to stretch your cultural bones,head down to the Wharf Theatre to enjoy a production or lunch at its reastaurant which commands superb harbour views acroos to the bridge.
check out the O z shop. there are some fab shops in there thereis one that makes rock sweets. which you can watch them doing it. lots of very good Aborigonal art works there to.
Wow something for everyone. Brilliant day outMarkets with local works and produceGreat old pubsDelicious lunchawesome historical feel about the place
Good for food & drinks. Zia Pina Pizzeria in the Rocks has the best pizza & pasta in town. They do cater for specific dietary requirements, including gluten free pizza :)

The markets are fab!. If you are in Sydney on the weekend, then you must visit the markets at the Rocks. We were lucky enough to be there last month during the Coffee Festival and it was a great way to spend a Sunday as a family.
Fun weekend market. Interesting neighborhood. Outdoor market was fun and had some unusual items. Cool shops and restaurants.

Been to The Rocks!. We spent an hour or two on a weekend at The Rocks and really loved the olden day feel of the area with its old buildings and cobble stone roads...There were many stalls set up selling all kinds of items - also food. We also explored some of the stores inside the building behind the market and found lovely souvenirs there - very reasonably priced - to take back home and also to give out as gifts. It’s in close proximity to Circular Quay and the Harbour Bridge.

Full Of History. The Rocks is Sydneys historical area, with most of the buildings still the same as they were in the days of the first settlers and convicts.There are many great old pubs and fantastic restaurants to choose from for a meal or a cold beer after a day touring the historical laneways, and numerous shops. The Rocks also is home to Sydneys famous Rocks Marketplace every Saturday & Sunday as well as the Foodies Markets every Friday. You're sure to find a bargain !!

The Rocks - The Beginning. We are into "historic districts," and The Rocks fills the bill. This is where Sydney began. We did not do any tour, other than our own walking, reading and poking around.Our visit would probably have been better, but we discovered the Wine Odyssey Australia. We first did their tasting, and then a late lunch with even more wine. The next thing we knew, it was time to walk back to the hotel, to get ready for dinner.While The Rocks was a good location for history, and just hanging out, the Wine Odyssey Australia got two thumbs up - from each of us.

Great location for relaxing. Nice place to walk around looking at the old buildings, some nice little bars, markets on the weekend had the usual market stuff. some real nice bars for a couple of drinks

A great place to people watch and eat.. Liked - all the people watching, markets and food. Great place to wander around taking in all the sites.
Disliked - Nothing I can think of.
Great taste of tradition. The rock is a great street with sense of old British feel, lots of giod restaurants, shops and a spectacular place neae the opera house

So good. The history of Sydney isn't very long in comparison to other countries such as in Europe, so The Rocks is an "historical" precinct of the city. It is very interesting with quite lovely old buildings in winding little streets. There are some buildings/places which are open to the public and which are, more or less, museums, or 'historical houses'. They are well worth a visit. If one enquires from a tourist bureau, there are walking tours of The Rocks area available and which are worth taking if one is not familiar with Sydney. Also - there are some fabulous restaurants within the area.

Rocks Markets. Great. Not sure what to expect didn't spend too much money here but had a good range of unique gifts. Food places were great and reasonable and were varied. You could sit down to a gourmet meal or just have a snack choice is yours. Spent a few hours here. Husband met us for lunch here( he went off on his own and joined us later) Had a very pleasant day.

A historic place. The old coble stone streets provides a link to Sydney's historic past. The Rock's Markets are great and you can always find some unique gifts. A guided tour provides an understanding of the history of the area.

the Rocks area in Circular Quay. The rocks is situated just over the road from Sydney Harbour and we came across it by accident.there are some fabulous little restaurants there, an art gallery...a fabulous Swiss chocolate shop and café, The reputed to be the oldest pub in Sydney... and some really lovely intimate restaurants. we ate in an Italian there which was as good food as we have had anywhere.

The Rocks - great to wander around. We went to the market on a Sunday - well worth the visit. It's great for presents with local crafts for sale. I also bought two Sydney designer pieces - would highly recommend Eyvie and Nixx for unique clothing. Got an icecream at Copenhagen - yum - coconut was delightful - great texture. A great place to spend a few hours wandering around. So close to the ferries too.

Enjoy it every time I go to the Rocks. I had a lovely time at the Rocks. I had to fill in 2 hours waiting for my family.Devonshire tea at The Tea Cosy behind the Irish Design Shop.Traditional tea in a teapot with its own cosy. Warm scones too.Saturday market was fun and I popped into Ken Done gallery.Loved it all.Only negative - a few too many tourist 'tacky souvenir' shops here now.

Worthwhile. the oldest district of the city of Sydney. Excellent for shopping, especially for souveniers and presents. Also a good source of delving into the history of this city. Several interesting artgalleries. So do not miss!
Beautiful. The markets on the weekend was lovely. Not you typical flea market Items, it was more you high end items. A lovely way to fill a day.
Excellent area. We visited on a Sunday morning, so the markets were on and there was so much to see. Situated right under the bridge.

Great place to spend a few hours.. I wandered around The Rocks area on a Sunday afternoon. They have a open air market on Saturdays and Sundays which is a great place to see local artists and pick up a unique gift/momento.
Tried and true. Always worth a wander but bedlam on a Sunday and hard work to get so much as a cup of coffee due to crowds and under-staffed outlets.

Historic. A lovely olde worlde part of Sydney. Full of old buidlings, narrow streets and absolutely steeped in history from it's colourful past.
Spend time here to see before yoy leave

lions on tour. the rocks is the cheaper part of sydney and for a reason it is well past its sell by date and in urgent need of a good refurb, unless you like the back street pubs with nicotine stained walls stay clear, but it is cheap!!

Do the guided rocks walk.. Fantastic way to start Sydney sightseeing. Get the history with a qualified guide then hit the rocks information centre. Also do the rocks ghost tour...heaps of fun and cheap

Great place to shop and eat. Come to the rocks on weekends and shop the open air market! It is the best shopping around for the value. I bought handmade soap, tea mug, scarves, kids gifts, souvenir magnets, and a wallet (and I had just arrived in Sydney). I also ate at Pancakes on the Rocks for lunch which was very busy and tasty. This is a short walk from Circular Quay. You can take the scenic Sydney Ferry from Darling Harbour to Circular Quay.

Merriman Street, The Rocks. Head towards the tall, maritime observation tower at the western end of The Rocks. It's beside Merriman St; you can't miss it. As a local and a photographer, I love tiny, little Merriman St in the afternoon, simmering in the westering sun. This cute terrace of turn- of- the-century houses overlooks the harbour and is a great stop on your walk from Circular Quay. There's also a shady little kids playground and seats for mum and dad. No toilets but on your way from Circular Quay, stop off for a coffee on one of the wharfs and I know what a relief that can be! Merriman St is in too good a position to last, so get in before the developers. Somewhere from a bygone era.

very atmospheric. It was a sunny Saturday morning where they had an open market. We walked from the Inter-continental Hotel to there via Circular Quay. The short 10 mins walk was wonderful along the waterside. There were street performers & stall sellers. It made me relaxed, happy and did feel like a tourist. There were plenty of art & craft products that I have never seen before. I bought back home a flower vase made of natural stone and stainless steel.

Quaint. I bypassed this area the last time we were in Sydney other than when the HOHO was driving through so was determined to see it this time and glad I went. It’s got charm and appeal and some lovely quaint (albeit pricey) cafes to sit in and take in the ambience.I loved reading the various plaques/information there are up around the area to learn more about its past and what happened at that particular point in the year X.An area easily bypassed and forgotten about but one that you should aim to try and see.

Lots to offer. We visit The Rocks on weekends when it is "alive" and buzzing with activity because the markets are on. There is a variety of dining opportunities on Saturdays from the inexpensive hold-in-your-hand-and-walk-around type to the sit-down-and-enjoy-fine-dining with a classy glass of Australian wine!
Harbourside history!. The history we discovered about Sydney while walking through this area was astounding. Tonight we're doing a ghost tour of the Rocks! Wish us luck.

A part of Sydney's history. Sydney's history is young, compared to European cities. The Rocks is a lovely area to stroll through and see a part of our 200 year old history. There is something for everyone to do in this area.

Beautiful views. Definitely go here if you're new to Sydney especially on a Saturday when the markets happen! Good free history of the rocks (or there is a tour you can do), or just walk around and enjoy the beautiful views of Sydney

Lovely to walk around and take in some history. We had a good walk around the rocks area one day and found it full of history of early Sydney. It has some very old lovely looking houses in the area and lovely little shops to browse in. We found the best ice cream shop here by circular quay. The area was reasonable priced for food but expect to pay more as this is a more expensive part of Sydney after all.

Where Sydney Began..... The Rocks area is the most historic area of Sydney so it is worth a little exploration. The best thing about it is that it is not completely touristy although there are a few stores that absolutely are. That aside, the old cobbled streets and the restored woolstore buildings and the tiny houses will give you a great feeling as to the early settlement in Sydney. Being in the heart of the business district there are also plenty of good restaurants at all price points and of course the Aussie Pub which is worth a visit for a drink or a "counter lunch". There are markets on the weekends and festival activity throughout the year and of course it is also home to the Museum of Contemporary Art on the waters edge.

Not bad, but not the best. Due to it's location there is no getting away from the fact that the Rocks are FULL of tourists. With the international terminal located there it means there are loads of Americans (mainly) that swamp the place. I would suggest steering clear of here when there is a ship alongside. However, when there are no ships the place has got some fairly decent restaurants and some good bars too. Be adventurous and get in to the lane ways and see what you can find.

A Lot of History.. The Rocks Area is full of History,and all the Old buildings have been Preserved, it is lovely to take two or three hours and have a wander around the Area. There are nice Restaurants and Cafe for a bite to eat,or just to sit and take everything in, and lots of lovely shops. The Rocks Markets on the weekends, also wonderful views of the Harbour and the Opera House. Regards, Marion.

Old Sydney has nice features. Take one of the free tours to learn the sites and history of the rocks. To know a bit of the history of the place helps to appreciate it. The late afternoon is particularly nice to do it.

Sydney Rocks. The Rocks just under the Harbor Bridge is one of the oldest settlements & ports in Australia's history, the building that were restored and the existing are made of convict cut local sand stone. This can been seen buy surrounding sand stone walls which you couldn't really miss and the buildings were used storage and ware house .Be sure to have walking shoes on because the Rocks is more accessible buy walking up and down sand stone stairs. Shopping restaurants & views of the Sydney harbor bridge and the Opera House Luna Park & Nth Sydney which to me is the gate way to Sydney's northern beaches by car or public transport.You will see buskers, fine art, galleries and museums and the oldest pubs but the buildings at the Rocks make for a great day out. A very interesting place for information in Sydney's settlement and history a place that will keep your camera busy with walking distance to the Opera House and Sydney's Botanical gardens.

Sydney Birthplace. The Rocks is an area that can capture your imagination at anytime. Historically it seems low key, the markets, the hussle of the dining areas and continual line of traffic seem to take away the origins that hide there. Take a moment to sit and look at the old sandstone buildings and retrace the old stairways, a hint of morning sea mist, ferry horns and yes you can slip back in time

Oldest Part of Sydney. This is one of my favourite spots in Sydney with quite a lot of the history in the area thankfully still preserved, despite plans to demolish all the buildings many years ago. One man intervened and created such a noise, he managed to stop further development, so we can now enjoy the olde worlde charm of the little streets and old shops and pubs. I've not done it yet but I'm sure a Night Tour with some ghostly stories would be great - I think they do a pub tour too. The place is always lively whatever time of day but on a weekend when they close off some streets for the Rocks Market, it is great.

My favourite part of Sydney!. This is where the modern history of Australia began. The character of our fair city is here and along with some great restaurants and on the weekends, the Rocks markets, it is a hive of activity. It also is the area of the best views for both the Opera House & the Harbour Bridge.

Nice to just walk around or sit and have lunch with an ale at an one of the old taverns.. The historic Rocks area isn't that big, so you can walk around easily with the family. Visits by day are relaxing, safe and family orientated. The weekend markets are a must. Sample the varied beers at these old pubs. Night times (especially Fridays to Sundays) - would not recommend for families or the more conservative demographic, due to crowds of young pub-goers that flock to the area after the sun goes down - but hey, that's most places these days.

Great part of Sydney. The Rocks is the area that shows how life began in Sydney .It has some of the best pubs and bars in Sydney and many restaurants to visit. Each weekend The Rocks markets are on and worth a visit. Accomodation is not cheap I this part of Sydney but you are near the harbour, Opera House and Harbour Bridge. School holidays provides activities for children.

Sydney history on show. The rocks will educate you to the past times of sydney, Old buildings and walkways, lots of good eateries , but can be expensive if your on a budget. If you go to the visitors centre and get a brochure it contains many discount coupons for some attractions
A pleasent stroll around the Rocks. Well worth a few hours to wander around and look at the shops and market stalls and choose from one of the many restaurants

history on the harbour.. the rocks is a great spot to learn about our early settlers and some old pubs and locals can tell you many stories.the best time is to go before dark on the weekends,the place attracts lots of unruley people at night.eating at the rocks can be quite expensive best to walk around then head down to the haymarket area plenty of chinese food outlets there and priced well.if you really have a day to spare get up early catch the palm beach bus it will take you over the harbour bridge along the coast line with wonderful views of the beaches alight from the bus at the palm beach ferry wharf.then catch a ferry to ettalong beach you are now on the central coast of nsw.ettalong is a quite village have a walk around then onto another bus to woy woy a very short ride .once at woy woy head to fishermans wharf for a fabulous fresh seafood meal.you can eat out the back with full service or the same food out the front at half the price.when finished walk over to the railstation for a quick ride back to sydney about 1hr 15 min ride.you will see some great views of the hawksbury river and the bushland.a long day but well worth it.all you need do is enquire for a day pass travel.you should enjoy it.
Interesting History. The Rocks has a lot of historic things to browse through, nice restaurants within easy access, pubs and bars, plus the Australiana shops where you can purchase nice souvenirs.

The beginning of Sydney. Excellent place to visit,absorb the history of Sydney,close to the Harbour Bridge which you can walk across free.lots of craft and Art places to visit and many good little coffee shops

Step back in History. Loved the history associated with the Rocks and old Sydney. You can wander round the cobblestones and explore the designer shops that are there. The old Woolshed is worth a look for shopping and nice places for cake and coffee. There are old pubs on most corners where you can watch the world go by. The fish and chip shop on the corner of Argyle is a bit pricy as are most of the eateries but its a definite experience. You can get a good view of the bridge from the top of the hill at Argyle Place and can access the underside of the walking track of the bridge from this area. From the harbour you can get a water taxi to Darling Harbour and China Town. Loved it.

Quaint, Historical & Lively. The Rocks is the oldest part of Sydney city where the first settlers came to Australia to live. The area boasts lovely views onto Sydney Harbour, is situated beneath the Sydney Harbour Bridge and is a lovely leisurely walking experience. If you go on Sundays you will experience a wonderful market place atmosphere with lots of little stalls everywhere. The Rocks has great boutique shopping (including duty free), offers fantastic culinary dining experience restaurants, most boasting views to the harbour and talented basquers are everywhere keeping you entertained as you walk. Parking is on the doorstep underground, and most offer flat evening or day rates. Great place to visit.
Fascinating. A popular destination for tourists but fascinating to visit never the less! The Rocks has many little laneways and areas to see and admire. Step back into Sydney's past.

Entertainment plus. I regurlary come to the Rocks for entertainment there is so much to do during the day and at night.The markets are a must on the weekends and in the summer they have twilight markets art/crafts and the unusual are all on display then when your tired plenty of eateries around the place. I have been on a walking tour here also and it was amazing how they lived when they first settled here it would be beneficial if you go on a walking tour as they explain what has gone on through the ages of our amazing city of Sydney.I could go on about how amazing this place really is and if you come to Sydney it is a must see and do in the area....................pubs are fantastic in this area also! All within walking area of Circular Quay

A Memory Frozen in Time. The Rocks area of inner Sydney is walking distance from Circular Quay, where you catch a ferry to cross the harbour. This area was one of the earliest established during the British colonization of Australia and was a bustling port venue for the early settlers. Today it is considered to be an iconic destination when visiting Sydney. So, the question remains, ‘What can you do at The Rocks?Well, for one thing, it is located in one of the oldest building sites in Australia, easily accessible to and from the harbour side. Not far from where millions of immigrants got off their ship after weeks of voyaging to the land Down Under. The architecture is a storybook reminder of the lives who helped build early Sydney - the sandstone steps, the old pubs, the iron fences. You can stand on George Street and take yourself back in time. Some streets are still lined with the old sandstone blocks chiselled by the early convicts whose sweat and hardship helped build the city. The Rocks sits on a bit of a high spot in Sydney so you can actually look down into the famous Sydney Harbour (British English).The café’s, restaurants, the galleries, souvenir shops, boutique stores, the buskers and also the Museum of Contemporary Art all are important elements of what really occurs in this great historic venue. However, if there is a ‘must see’ it would be The Rocks Markets which adds to its rustic flavour. It reminds me so much of the wonderful markets I frequented in Europe, especially the ones just outside the ancient walls of Como, Italy. Here you can buy just about anything you desire whilst enjoying Sydney’s world famous sites. The markets are open Saturday and Sunday from 10am till 5pm. I believe the Friday markets host specialties of different cuisine. For more information you can also visit http://www.therocks.com/sydney-Shopping-The_Rocks_Markets.htm.The indigenous Gadigal people who once flourished here and were one with this area of Mother Earth should be recognized. As a memory frozen in time The Rocks Markets is also a perfect place to eat, drink and enjoy good old Aussie hospitality… and if you have had one too many drinks you might get to hear the distant voices of the ancient gritty sailors and port hands singing their songs whilst spilling drink over the olden rough wooden tables… Salvin0.

Oh My Gosh, this is an experience!. The Rocks is simply a must see! This is right on the opposite side of Sydney Harbour, across the water from the Opera House. A very unique area and has many coffee houses and cafes along with a lot of shopping. This area has basically been around since the beginning, from 1788. There is so much history and o e can walk the bricked and cobblestone streets. Also, every weekend they have an outdoor market.
Rocks Pubs. Many of the Rocks Pubs serve food at O.K prices and there's also live music which can often be good fun. Can't go to Sydney without a night t the Rocks

Great Place to Stay. The Rocks is the historic area of Sydney. It is close to Circular Quay from where you can catch ferries across the harbour to other interesting places - e.g. Taronga Park Zoo, Watson's Bay, Manly, Darling Harbour etc. The Rocks has many older style pubs. It is close to the Harbour Bridge (do a Bridge Climb) and also the Opera House. The area is close to Circular Quay & Wynyard train stations and there are also many buses. There are organised walks of the area which point out historic buildings etc. There is a range of accommodation, many of them quite expensive. However, there is a YHA (Youth Hostel) hotel which is quite modern, not just for young people & is more moderately priced. I can recommend this area for visitors who want to be close to everything even if a bit touristy!

A nice place to look at during the day.... I am from Sydney, but live in London, so perhaps that allows me to look at The Rocks from both the perspective of a local, as well as a visitor. The buildings and history in The Rocks is great and well worth the time and effort to walk around and consider. The shops are disappointing, full of tourist nonsense and the majority of eating is poor and over-priced. Beware of The Rocks around the pubs at night-all too often I fetched by hordes of drunken people on birthday parties, office parties etc. there are a few exceptional restaurants, but if you asked a local where he or she would spend their leisure time, I bet The Rocks wouldn't feature very highly. Flatters to deceive.

some history some inns. Worth a wander around and then in the evening wander around again for a beer or two.The Nelson does some of its own beers and are well worth it. Try the darker ales.Although not part of the rocks, the Harts pub ( Essex Street, back towards the city ) has some great beers too.

Steeped in history. If you want to learn about early life in the colony, take a tour, or just take a stroll around this lovely part of the city. Even if you are a local you will still want to go there.The markets are also well worth seeing, for a wide array of different goods.Close to historic pubs and also the Opera House.

Iconic Sydney - The Rocks has history...!. If there is one place you must visit, it's The Rocks. There is so much history in this northern end of Sydney Town. There are so many pubs, hotels, cafe's, entertainment venues, shopping, markets, walks - there's even a Harbour Bridge....!Australia Day, New Years Eve - 2 of the biggest parties are right here in the Rocks.You must do this....

Typical of the Old City like many cities. Every capital city has its old city buy being only 225 years old Sydney cannot compete against European and North American cities. It is worth a visit, can be walked through in an hour and being under the Harbour Bridge makes it more interesting. It has very expensive souvenir shops so do the shopping elsewhere.

The oldest part of Sydney. I lived in this part of Sydney almost 4 years, and I liked and enjoyed every single day. Close to everything but somehow secluded. Great events and a lot of culture and histiry, something not so easy to find in Sydney!

A great reminder of yester years. I just love going for a wander around The Rocks. Although Sydney is relatively young compared to the rest of the world, The Rocks has a lovely old world feel to it with its little laneways and odd shaped buildings. Be sure to visit the information centre to put you on the right track so you don't miss anything and find out the history of some of the buildings. There is nice restaurants and bars scattered around and accommodation ranges from budget to 5 star. A great base to stay as it is in walking distance of most attractions in Sydney.
Young people's meeting place. Great place on Sundays during the day for the markets,few pubs there to relax and have drink.Five minutes from the bridge and Circular Key rail and ferry Terminal

The start of European Settlement. Compared to Europe, Australia is still just a babe in arms. But then if you are heading there its almost certainly not because of it's deep western history. Of course, if you're coming to check out the history of Aboriginal culture, you can delve back over 40,000 years! As for western history in Australia, the Rocks is as old as it gets. In the past 20 years, the Rocks has been given a much needed face lift which has also brought increased commercialisation. However, you can still see some of the original Maritime Authority housing - and Stevedores and other harbour workers still live in the area. The real working class past has therefore not been completely sanitised. You can easily spend a day strolling around the main streets, taking in Circular Quay and exploring the back alleyways and hidden staircases. Be prepared for a bit of climbing so keep a bottle of water with you - and there are plenty of watering holes along the way. If you want authentic Australian souvenirs, you will find plenty of choice in the many shops in the area but please check out prices elsewhere. The Sunday market at the end of George Street is well worth a visit. Best to get there early because, on a warm day, it gets pretty busy.

well preserved part of old Sydney town. Originally this part of town was slated for redevelopment in the late '60s and early '70s. Fortunately it did not go ahead due to public and union opposition. It has retained it's human scale and a lot of character.There has been some very creative repurposing of the original building stock. The Rocks Discovery Museum is well worth a look to get a feel for the place. The old warehouses on Campbells Cove are also a reminder of Sydney Harbour's past as a working port, which it is no longer.There are plenty of places to eat and shop, and everything is close to public transport, the city, the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge
Nice little shopping district. Nice galleries and shops to browse. Outdoor food market offering sausage/honey/baked goods was yummy.

great place. this is the centre for art and craft stuff in sydney. it is great to walk around and see the area and come to all the shops that sell different stuff that you will not find anywhere else in sydney. many coffee and food shops dot the area and sell great stuff at reasonable prices.

Great location for bars, restaurants and shops. We stayed at the Four Seasons Hotel which is right by the Ferry Depot in The Rocks.As a location, it's full of bars and restaurants and a few minutes walk to the main shopping area of Sydney. You can also walk to the Opera House and Botanic Gardens.In July 2012 we stayed at the Shangri-La Hotel in The Rocks and can recommend getting a drink or two in the Blu Bar which is on floor 36 and overlooks the Opera House and Harbour Bridge area, stunning!
Historical. Oldest part of Sydney and Aus and here you get a sense of what the first settlers had to endure. Oldest pubs in Aus and houses so worth a look

Stunning Markets. We went to the markets on Saturday - was happy to see that there is a lot of original art, a lot of handmade stuff and truly exceptional stalls. Not just another market - really worthwhile and pleasant - enough room to walk around and enjoy the food stalls etc. We be back and do recommend it !

tourist trap but a nice walk around. The Rocks by itself is a very historical and great looking area to explore. There are some great bars and nightlife there. The shops are expensive and cater to the tourist dollar. Its a great place when they have their weekend outdoor market to walk around. I think they also have one during the week in their summer months. Its for the young crowd after dark and can get loud and boisterous.

Older Buildings. The Rocks section of town is the old part. It could have been demolished, cleared, new modern buildings built in its place. However, it was saved and now is a very in place to see. Pubs and shops everywhere.

But for Union Bans the Rocks Would Have Been Lost.. If you don't know much about Sydney, or Australia, well the Rocks is one of the oldest areas in town. In the 1960s the developers wanted to rip it down and repace it with highrise buildings.Many of the buildings are carved out of Sydney sandstone, or simple wooden workers cottages, built on steep gradients and into cliff-face. A union worker, by the name of Jack Munday realised it was irreplacable Sydney heritage and led a movement that imposed "green bans" on its demolition, thus saving it for you to visit today. Although the main drag is full of expensive tourist shops and restaurants swarming with day-trippers, the place still has atmosphere. Once you move out into the narrow streets and laneways, you can really get a feel for Sydney's colonial past.Of note is Susannah's House, with a terrific little museum and friendly staff.Moreover you can still meet genuine locals, showing how the culture has shifted and developed into the Sydney of today. And fabulous exercise negotiating the many steps and climbs.Great views of the underbelly of the Harbour Bridge, as you walk around from Circular Quay too!

Great spot. Great spot for a walk. Beautiful glimse into Sydney's early days. Magnificent old buildings have been lovingly restored and the place is full of quircky shops, great cafes and old historic pubs. Great views of the Bridge and the Harbour. Don't miss this when in Sydney.
Worth a visit. First time at The Rocks. Visited the museum and watched a bit of the videos playing. Went through the markets. The Rocks is interesting and definitely worth a visit.

seeing some of the history of Sydney. the small museum is worth a 30 minute stop. The weekend street fair is a gret place to stop for lunch, and just strolling is fun. If a cruise ship doesn't block the view then lunch from the 4th floor of the museum affords a view of the harbor for an adult lunch (but the street arcade is more fun for kids and less pricey)
poor. a lot of people, very overcrowded, very dirty the streets near the markets area, I felt uncomfortable.
One of my Fav's. Love this place, there is so much to do and see here, the food is also great. I love to roam around and check out new and old things in The Rocks.
Mercantile Hotel. Spent great afternoon with friends in Mercantile Hotel down at the Rocks on the afternoon of the final Lions test - atmosphere was electric - great place.
Perfect place to base yourself in Sydney. Great restaurants, shopping, Opera House and botanical gardens all within walking distance. A centrally located and hip neighborhood to stay in.
Bars and Eateries. Great little area to find an Aussie bar and then eat out. Wide choice of locations, styles and prices.

Nice to walk around especially the back streets. Nice to walk around especially the back streets. You get an idea of the way things were. Keep walking under the bridge for a different perspective and visit one of the restaurants in Walsh Bay

Lovely Sat/Sun Markets. Interesting market stalls interspersed with great food and coffee.
A range of handmade items for sale at reasonable prices.
So Cool. Enjoyed our morning walk through the Rocks! Had breakfast a a great, health breakfast. Enjoyed the markets and a causal stroll window shopping.

Must see & do in Sydney. Walking around the rocks gives you history of Sydney. Many small shops and little alleys are delightful. Some even have their own story and history, for example, Nurses Walk. Of all the things We did in Sydney (harbor cruise, city tour, casino, Opera House, Blue Mountains, etc.), this was the most enjoyable. When in Sydney, don't miss the rocks.
The Rocks Rock!!. You must wander around this area for the best cafes, bars, patisseries and a truly fantastic outdoor market.
Peek into the history. Get engrossed into the history of Australia, walk down the lanes of rocks and learn more about the people and the past.
So much History. Went for a walk through the rocks and was able to get up close with alot of great blast from the past. Also great markets on the weekends

Artistic place. You can find artistic buildings in the area and it is definitely a good place for experiencing the culture and history of Australia. The Pancake on the rocks and the Guylian cafe are great and worth of a visit!

is a very romantic place to walk. it is like small town into the city and because it was the first construcions most of them from 1900 you feell like you are part of the history, dont miss the Street market saturdays and sundays. it is a good expirence

Fascinating history; Quaint streets; Eat elsewhere. Fascinating history, quaint streets, but eat elsewhere. Great crafts fair. Enough has been preserved to trigger imagination of what early settlement might have been like, but more should be described explicitly to inform a visitor.

Love The Rocks!. We visited on a Saturday morning specifically because of the market I'd read about and I'm so glad we did! Absolutely love The Rocks and the stalls at the market. The stalls carried really interesting items and food and we had a nice time chatting with the stall vendors, sampling their products and picking out what we wanted. I loved the whole vibe going on there and highly recommend that you visit The Rocks on a Saturday morning when the market is in full swing!
Good pubs. You can find loads of good pubs around the rocks, some can be quite expensive but it is worth. The food is also delicious and the old buildings are great.

The place to be.. The pubs in the Rocks are the oldest and best in Sydney.The Fortune of War is an iconic pub which was clearly popular with Welsh visitors. We met David Pickering,Shane Williams and Sean Holley there during our brief-ish stay.

WildFire at the Rocks. Pricey but scrumptious seafood. HIghly recommend the salt and pepper live crustaceans. Get a medley including balmain bugs, yabbies and mud crab along with the prawns and lobster. Worth the splurge!

High quality arts and crafts. Saturday and Sunday Arts Market is terrific for finding jewelry, textile/fiber arts, clothing, soaps, food, etc. all made by Australian artisans. Fair prices - not cheap - but unique and authentic.
Markets a buzz on a Sunday. Enjoyed the walk around the markets on a warm Winters day. Lots to see and enjoy. Art, clothes, food and other trinkets.

Saturday or Sunday this place comes alive.. We strolled through the rocks on a Tue and wondered what everyone was talking about. Then we went there on Sat and the place was ALIVE and fantastic. Love it here.

Saturday or Sunday 10 AM to 5 PM. This is a very nice area, and it has a market every Saturday and Sunday from 10 AM to 5 PM. It's worth seeing the market. In general, it's a very nice area, and worth the stroll!

Do not miss this. Great at he weekend when the outdoor market stores are open for private business. Saturday is foodies day, delicious home made breads, cheeses, and garden produce for sale, Sunday is clothes day, independent designers selling one offs. Get a bargain before these designers make it big and go to Paris!

A bit touristy, but still great. This place is very Sydney. It does have a little bit of a touristy feel, but there's many great restaurants and cafes around and it's very quaint. Also a must see for any visitor :-)

Cannot get bored here.. We come back here time after time. We love the atmosphere and the unique stalls at the markets. The food is beautiful as is the local patisserie. lots of unusual gifts found here.

Sunday Market Stroll. Fun to go on Sunday to see the markets. Extremely crowded with tourists but still and enjoyable walk and good sightseeing. There are lots of food options, and shopping in the area.

The Where? you haven't been there yet? GO!. Take your time, sit in the bar of the oldest Hotel in Sydney "down at the rocks" The night life here is awesome and very entertaining. All types of people catered for here, well worth the walk around.
An area with lots of personality and charm. Great restaurant, shopping, street markets and attractions (eg bridge climbing), museum of contemporary art,

Great Place to eat drink and enjoy yourself while in Sydney. Last visited the Rocks in 2001 and while some of the old buildings have unfortunately gone the Rocks still retains its character . Great places to eat shop and drink and read and feel about the history of Sydney. A place where you never get bored.
Old Sydney and very Historic. Good to visit The Rocks as brings the history of Sydney and it has some nice restaurants and pubs. Good experience from Old Sydney to New Sydney.

Great fun. The Rocks is the oldest part of Sydney and it can be the best fun in Sydney, especially when the market (selling food and other products) is happening. Ignore the so-so shops in the arcades and seek out the smaller stores around - and eat off the main streets. Go down toward the Harbour Bridge and sit and relax watching the groups of climbers who regularly move along the structure before heading back to Circular Quay and the rest of Sydney's delights. Great fun!
Great area. Perfect place to stroll. Go when the market is open so you can buy some things to take home, and stop for a bite to eat.

Main Sydney area for tourists. This is the main "tourist" area, where the Opera House, Bridge, ferries, Sydney fair are all located. A great place to visit and probably the best location for your hotel. You definitely must take at least one full day to visit the area if you are staying far from there.
Great renovation. Walking distance from the CBD.Lots of action and activities.So find a table and a single malt and enjoy the views.

Great for Shopping. Loads of places to get good value for souvenirs. Alot of the shops around the harbour are quite expensive, walk for another few minutes to get the same ones for better value. Watch out if you are buying Ugg Boots. There are quite popular and alot of places sell fake ones that are made in China and still charge the smae amount as you pay for the real ones. Make sure the outside of the store says Ugg Australia and that if you pay any less than $140 they are probably fake.
Fun area. Fun and loaded with small bars and restaurants. Do check it out for a nice dinner and beer. Very intimate area.
Hard Rock. The Hard rock cafe in the busy and the happening sydney harbour excellent to have lunch here and then move around to major attraction then againg come for eveniing tea and relax
Nice place for a walk!. This place isn't all that big but it's a nice place to go for a walk. Old style looking building. Great places to eat or have a drink. Great atmosphere!

Cool place to have a drink. The Rocks is an area in sydney under the bridge and is full of little bars and cafes that cater for anyone and everyone. From $5 pancakes to $150 stake it is a great night out when in sydney

Super Cute. Super cute area. We were there during the day on a Sunday, there is a nice market you can go to. Definitely try Tea Cosy Irish tea house if you go for DELICIOUS scones! Right on the one main street by the market. Definitely a cute area and would be very nice at night as well with the pubs and bars.
Atmosphere from another time. You feel as though you are transformed to another time, like in the book 'Playing Beatie Bow', which is set in The Rocks.

Weekend Market. Enjoy the bustle in the narrow alleys of the Rocks when the weekend market is on. Crafts, jewellery, crystals, candles, if you can't find something to tempt you, you haven't seen it all. And there's food stalls to keep you going.
Dissapointed. I have expected to find a market of artistic handicraft , but I find o lot of kitsch .Good place if you have time and money to spend. For me was nothing interesting there.

A place to stroll.. We have had several strolls through the Rocks area and on weekends it is abuzz with stalls both eats and products. There is something for everyone to stroll amongs and plenty off places to stop and eat of get a cuppa. Lots of people there on every occasion that we have been there. If you are looking for something different this is where you need to go.

Only small but you have to go. Any establishment that is open, away from the main drag, can only survive by being good. Best of all: find the Wharf Theatre in Hickson Road, go right to the far end, and try the tapas-style food down there.
Great vibe. This area of Sydney is great. The atmosphere is always excellent, there are many pubs, restaurants and markets everywhere you look. Very close to the Harbour Bridge and Circular Quay
Unique. If you refer to the rocks as the three sister rocks in Blue Mountains this is the only attraction after sydney harbor and the Opera House. This place is amazing.
A great place to wander. So much history. Go on Sundays for the Rocks markets - buy some fudge and a paid of earrings! All good fun in an incredibly historic and interesting setting.
The Rocks. What a great place to stroll around whether the markets are on or not. Caught a ride on a motor bike going over the bridge and around Kirribilli and the Rocks -awesome!!
A rocks visit to remember. A great place to visit day or night -great markets -plenty of places to eat & great pubs & bands .must visits regards Nicole watts

The Rocks tourist area in Sydney is full of overpriced restaurants... But right smack dab in the middle of over-priced restaurants is the Orient Pub... Their Mega Deals are Monday $10 bar food, Tuesday $10 steaks, Wednesday $12 pasta, Thursday $10 burgers! Yum!

If you like history, this is the place to stay and see. the Rocks is the old section of the city, down near the waterfront. There are still many of the original buildings from the 1800's including the Reynolds Hotel (very charming boutique hotel - right in the heart of The Rocks)

Great places to stay and eat. I looked all over Sydney for places central to the "action" and this worked out great, train from the airport drops off right on the water and the BUS service here is fantastic.

Can get bit crowded and rowdy. Best time to visit is of a daytime if you have children wth you as nigts can get crowded and rowdy, especally Friday and Saturday nights. Well worth the visit as it is interesting and there are somegood retaurants in the area.
Oldest licensed pub in Sydney. Visit the oldest licensed pub in Sydney whilst at The Rocks - Fortune of War, great history to see at the pub, lots of interesting memorabilia

Good Place to be at Night. Stumbled upon this place after taking a cruise at Sydney Harbour area and saw that there was a night market going on. The place was packed and the queue for the food was horrendously long. Food were quite exotic from the different countries. There was also a few stalls that were displaying their crafts. Do check it out at night, as it was quite an experience for me, which I didn't quite expect at Sydney.

Great place to imagine the history of Sydney. I know that the Rocks is totally geared to us tourists, but who cares - I love it! I love wandering around the little lanes and imagining what it must have been like 150 years ago. I also love the little markets that are held on Friday and over the weekend - a great place to pick up unique goodies and have dinner.

Great place in which to wander and have a coffee or a pint. Our trip to Au and NZ started in Sydney with our cruise ship The Marina by Oceania Cruise Line docked at the wharf by The Rocks. I had done a lot of travel research and knew to wander around The Rocks. We spent a morning enjoying the architecture and bridge views and having a coffee in a French Bistro while waiting to board the ship. Glad we explored this area before we got started on harbor ferries. This was March 14 and when we returned to Sydney for 5 days in April, we spent our last morning in The Rocks before driving to the airport. Lovely to have the old original Sydney so close. A great deal of new construction with a casino and "6" star hotel being developed on the other side of The Rocks going into Darling Harbor. Certainly hope it will not take away from the quaintness of this area.
Walking Tour. Highly recommended - very well done, informative, interesting. History and current status of The Rocks - easy walk.

Must do..... We stayed in the area not knowing anything about it before making our reservation. Looking for a trendy area of the city this is it. Stroll the side streets and alleyways to find interesting up of the way places. Go the the visitor center for local ideas of events, dining, and places to stroll. Every turn of the corner has a wonderful sight. A must - The Rocks Museum - gives you a history and appreciation for the area.

olde world charm. Bit of a tourist trap in places but the little alleys and byways as well as some old style pubs make this one of my favourite places to visit when I'm in town. Love the Mercantile, Australian and the Glenmore pubs - make sure you go up to the rooftop beer garden at the Glenmore for a pint, best views for free right down the harbour and up to the bridge. Could combine with bridge visit as entrance to pylons is just across the road...

Saturday night markets ... something different for everyone!. I hadn't been to The Rocks for years and was surprised to head there for afternoon tea at The Guylian Belgian Chocolate Café - yummo (x 78)! After a little walk with my daughter we came across the night markets - lots of different things to anything I'd seen before. I wished I hadn't have spent all my money on shopping!

A tourist must do.. This old part of Sydney is a very interesting area to experience. It is full of history with old pubs and plenty of good restaurants to try. You can spend a day exploring the old streets and shopping areas.

Eh.......... Not sure what I was expecting, but it was definitely more than I found. Touristy shops and historical buildings. Not a very big area to walk around. I guess it depends on what you have to compare it to. Confused by the rave reviews. Took maybe 20 minutes to see it....and decided I didn't need any overpriced tourist trinkets, so that was that. See it, but don't expect much.
exciting. it is so good to be able to walk around this little piece of history and to visit the rocks market is a must there is so many thinks to see the old buildings are so impressive .
Nice restaurants and historic things to see. We wandered around the Rocks looking in shops, eating in cafe's and taking in the history. A lovely old area with lots to see for free

Oldest and most beautiful part of Sydney. Definitely worth a visit, the sandstone buildings and water views are stunning, so much history and beauty here, best to visit during the day or early evening, best to avoid after midnight on the weekend, it does tend to get a bit rowdy then

Historic rocks. This is a great area for walking and getting a feel for the past. There are some great buildings with historical significance, spend time wandering. The small galleries and shops make it worth taking a peek and some yummy bakeries offer lovely cakes and coffee. Some wonderful restaurants offer meals that you can enjoy while looking over the harbour and looking at the "bridge".

A step back in time.. Love wondering the alleyways of The Rocks. One of the amazing things is the old ruins of buildings that we found.If you go to The French Patisserie just beware of the chairs in the courtyard behind. I sat on one only to have it collapse beneath me. It and another that we found was missing a bolt in the cross arm of the legs. Little interest was shown by staff when it was pointed out.

Nooks and crannies. From what we understand, this is a recent renewal project. It was well worth it, this is the 'old town' and is quaint, with many interesting little shops to nose around in. Plus, there's the Australian Heritage Hotel with it's Oz-cuisine and 130+ local beers to choose from. Add this area to your day on Sydney Harbour Bridge.

Relaxing and interesting. The Rocks has a great atmosphere and deserves its reputation as a great spot for both tourists and locals. There are so many interesting galleries, restaurants and shops that represent the Australian way of life. The Rocks market on weekends is one of the best in Australia with truly interesting stalls. It has a very pleasant atmosphere and one can enjoy the harbour as well as the historic buildings.

Love the history and activity. One of the better parts of Sydney to visit - it has both a sense of history plus vibrancy and activity.You can see how Sydney was developed with its old pubs and workers cottages - close to the Harbour and circular Quay so it is easy to get to. Lots of pubs, cafes and restaurants to go to.Many stores for tourist shopping.

Vintage!. A few minutes of walk after Sydney harbor & you find yourself in a much quieter place comparatively to most of the city surroundings & the city itself.Many nice old stores having been there for ages & having kept their vintage looks. As they old is gold! You may find a number of brand shops as well as comfortable pubs & bars and restaurants as well, to relax at during midday under a scorching sun( and why not with a nice chilled beer?)

Fantastic Experience with historical significance. Fantastic views as you potter arround the cobbled streets and alleys portraying the scenes of yesteryear. I have found little curios and items particularly in their weekend markets that are must haves. The view from most of the streets of the harbour. opera house and bridge are fantastic and it is a place for all seasons with pubs and eateries (love the Orient hotel and Pony restauant) when the weather is cold/rainy or when it is a great sunny day there are many cafes and free benches to sit on and admire the scenery while people watching.

old Sydney. love this area as it is seeped in history , see the oldest town in Australia and where we all originated from. Marvel at the convict labour built houses , pubs , bridges and wharves . Truly a marvel and something to be thankful for the convicts that started our colony .
nice style. it is one of the top places to visit in Sydney, there are very good stores around and the options for entertainment are endless

Great place to walk around. I loved the old buildings and shopping was great and it's easy to walk around. Cruise ships come in right there and because we were staying at the Grand Quay hotel we just walked right over to the ship, dropped off our bags and got in line.
Wonderful ancient city. The place where the first settlers and convicts arrived. Marvelous architecture. Narrow streets, the whole atmosphere...
historic. just great strolling around this area , some old historic buildings well preserved , a great tourist site of sydney , most enjoyable

Enjoyable few hours off a cruise ship. This is a fun place to spend part of an afternoon. This is the area where Sydney began and there are two old sites preserved near the port itself. There is also a Discovery Museum worth visiting if you have the time and are interested. The Rocks district is within a five minute walk if your cruise ship is at the Overseas Passenger Terminal so there is no need to take a taxi to it. It has a variety of (and sometimes overpriced) cafes, bars, pubs and restaurants. The walkways are cobblestone and the streets have some interesting old buildings on them. If you are there on a weekend a trip to the open air market is a must. While there are lots of the usual over-priced souvenirs, there are also some unique crafts people with unusual items for sale e.g. million year old stromatolite fossil bracelets and cut leather jewellery. Residents of Sydney can enjoy festivals and special events all year round, but if you are a tourist I suggest that you check out The Rocks website and see what will be on while you are there - it is worth the visit. And for cruisers - get off the ship - walk up the hill and enjoy this part of Sydney.

The Rocks Rock. This is such a great little hide away shopping district. It is made up of the original Sydney, old old buildings, shops and the roads are not really made for cars. (It would be best if they closed the Rocks to all vehicles in the day, only allowing vehicles in to restock the stores at night.) The shops and architecture is a sight you must see. Don't leave Sydney without a day on the Rocks.
Fantastic. Wonderful atmosphere and safe at night, love the city lights, and the old cobbled stone walkways off the side roads..Great views of the harbour bridge :)
For a londener now living in OZ this is my Covent Garden. Always something going on, markets, entertainers, great food and pubs,perfect place to start looking around sydney

Rustic and Modern Combined. The bars was mostly look like classic old bars, you can find most what you need only in walking distance, they have beautiful buildings, but some place are really over priced!

best place in sydney. nowing now sydney if i shoud chose a place to sleep will be the rocks. lovely neibourhood, small but charming, english felling streets, well mainteined buildings, nice but expensive i should say. there is a lovely markets iin he weekends, australian made crafts. near the harbour and nice sights.

Happy browsing through history. A stunning area that is steeped in history and all the retail outlets have been built to add to the aesthetic appeal. Excellent boutique wine outlets and great coffee. Bought some fabulous hand made diamond earrings ... shops offer something different to CBD

The only place to stay.. We stayed at the Lord Nelson Pub and Brewery a small boutique hotel/inn. There are only eight rooms on the top two floors and all have been beautifully renovated. The price is very reasonable considering the area. There is a continental breakfast included in the price of the room. There is a dining room on the first floor, we did not eat there. The pub is on the main floor and the meals are excellent in the pub. Great place to stay and withing walking distance of many attractions. You can see the Coat Hanger Bridge from most rooms as well as the harbor. We were boarding a Royal Caribbean ship and were able to walk to the harbor and check in on April 24/13. Try not to stay anywhere else, and book one year in advance. Happy travels.

The Rocks rocks!. It's a wonderful stroll there to and back from the Harbour Bridge. Streets are intermingled with hotels, shops, restaurants and a wonderful historical museum called Rocks Discovery Museum as well as the Museum of Contemporary Art. During the weekends, there is an outdoor market to buy souvenirs and knick-knacks. Have lunch in the Museum of Contemporary Art while enjoying the views of Sydney Harbour!
Great food and shopping. The market on the Rocks is a great place to pick up unusual craft gifts and enjoy street food.Late afternoon the bars are crowded!
Historical Sydney!. Take a guided tour by Peek Tours around the Rocks and you will appreciate all the history the area has to offer. Lots of little shops and restaurants.
good to wonder. Just near to the Bridge. Interesting area, and very busy when the market is on - but still the best days to visit! Lots of good bars in the area when you need a rest.

Where it all started.. Australia has so little history behind it's European settlement that it is good to visit a place that oozes it from almost every corner. From the historic old pubs to the excellent archealogical remains beneath the YHA there is so much to absorb.
I like this place. Sometimes feels like a cowboy town when you're at The Rock where most of the buildings are old but wonderful...even some of the shops signboard wrote with "cowboy" Font

A real taste of early Sydney. Make sure you visit, or even better stay at the Rocks when you visit Sydney as part of a trip to Australia. It is the birthplace of European Australia and there are many great restaurants, hotels and pubs. The Rocks weekend markets are a must for all international visitors. One of the best views of Sydney is from the rooftop pool area of the Holiday Inn Old Sydney in George Street. It is an ideal base for any visitor to Sydney, within walking distance of the Harbour Bridge, Opera House Circular Quay, Botanic Gardens and city.

Don't miss this evening walk from Circle Quay hotels. We walked over from our Marriott at Circular Quay, and thoroughly enjoyed the evening. We are window shoppers, and love looking at the old buildings. Waterfront, too. It's a fairly easy walk and you can just meander without any special athletic ability. This trip, we walked to the tunnel, got a little lost looking for Fish on the Rocks (never did find it) and then wound up enjoying fun shots, real beer, sausages and a salad at the German place. On the way home, we indulged in the very best ice cream cone ever: butterscotch and honey at a place I think was called Royal Copenhagen or something like that. There are also a few bars with live bands playing 80s and 90s material ... Plenty of fun and dancing seemed to be happening. This is a great, cool evening way to enjoy old Sydney ... And it doesn't have to be expensive. Nice alternative to yet another $100 dinner!
Must do place to spend time.. I must go here every time I go to Sydney. It is always humming. Lots of restuarants, historic walks to do, the markets and the friendly atmosphere are so enjoyable.

Get lost and enjoy it. Is a snapshot of a time gone by, old and new, funky nooks and crannys,markets on weekend a must and after I did bridge climb on a Friday they had fresh and incredible food stalls on offer.

Very Touristy. Very popular witht the tourists, but price hikes accordingly. Try the Frid lunctime food markets, some little gems serving up delicious food at very reasonable prices. Much better than most of the overpriced restaurants nearby.

Potentially overrated. If you're looking for more than souvenir shops, overpriced art galleries and buskers give the Rocks a miss. Head up to Macquarie Street if you want a dose of Sydney's history - the Hyde Park Barracks, Parliament House and the old Hospital are a more authentic, more relaxing experience.

My most favorite place in Sydney.. We stayed at the Four Seasons Hotel in Sydney and the Rocks was few minutes walk. It is such an awesome place, I never get bored when I am at the Rocks. Had breakfast every morning at the Rocks and lunch at the weekend Market was yummmm!? Every stone at the Rocks is full of history. it is a must visit when you are in Sydney.

My most favorite place in Sydney.. We stayed at the Four Seasons Hotel in Sydney and the Rocks was few minutes walk. It is such an awesome place, I never get bored when I am at the Rocks. Had breakfast every morning at the Rocks and lunch at the weekend Market was yummmm!? Every stone at the Rocks is full of history. it is a must visit when you are in Sydney.
Great Markets. Lovely place for lunch or dinner,plenty to choose from.On a nice day lovely meandering around markets and listening to live music,buses great service.

Interesting place. Put on your walking shoes, grab a map with historic points of interest and enjoy your day/half day depending on how many stops you do along the journey. Loved the old terrace houses, The hero of Waterloo pub for a quick drink (will go back for a meal). Meander around all these streets and will be lost in your imagination. Excellent.

A very central location.. Great pubs and some great eats if you choose the right places. Do some research before you visit here, you can get some fantastic eateries at a reasonable price if you choose the right place.
Old Sydney. I loved the rocks area, the buildings were beautiful and it had a great night life . real lively at night and had a great day market going on while I was there
lovely area for a stroll. A great place to visit especially the markets on the weekend. Get some chocolates and some great handicrafts. Nice views of the bridge too

Beautiful and busy tourist area. We spent 2 days at the Rocks..Sunday we spent at the craft market, best market I have ever been too..So many crafters with there wares..prices exceptional and choice of goods awesome..

Excellent place to explore. Recommend visiting the Lord Nelson Hotel and microbrewery and strolling through the streets, learning about Sydney's past. There are also a number of walking tours available. Many pubs offer luncheon meals with harbour views from their rooftops.
Still charming. Yes it's busy on the weekends...but it's still charming and a delight to walk around. Don't rush it. Enjoy the small streets and markets and cafes etc. Can't wait to go back again!

Nice experience of the old town for a quick walk around. Its a nice view of the old town and conveniently located near circular bay. We visited the place on a Friday walked from circular bay. There is a market on Friday but not much stalls. They closed at 5pm so be sure to visited before 5pm. The place is quite small and nothing much except some nice building. Would be able to complete within 1 hour.
Historical. Its a good place for those who enjoy markets but there is a small variety of eating places but mostly english style dining such as sandwiches and tea, coffee etc.
