Don't miss the Saturday market!. The Saturday market includes many vendors, musicians and great food. The products being sold are generally nice. It is not your crap-tourist-cheap-souvenir kind of market. The market opens at 10am. We wondered around and stayed for lunch. The market and a trip to Manly on the ferry made for a perfect Saturday in Sydney.

Great for pubs!. Really nice little pubs dotted around this area, some aren't even busy on a Saturday which is good. It always makes me feel like i'm walking around New York or something when i am in this part of Sydney. Def worth a visit.

Very photogenic. It is hard not to get a great photo here with the juxtaposition of new and old. Thank goodness for those Green Bans in the '70s that preserved this beautiful and historic areas. I did feel that the quality and range of shopping has diminished over the years.

Totally Worth It. Fabulous little corner of Sydney, so many eating/drinking places. I took a guided walk and the commentary and history provided were brilliant. Lots of up-market shops in the area as well. Markets on weekend. All good - a must do when in Sydney.

Preserved Sydney in fine location. The stone buildings were the commercial heart of Sydney. Now they have restored homes, restaurants and hotels in a charming, safe neighborhood. Walking the hills needs good legs but provides exercise in a beautiful setting. The harbor bridge and observatory park give outlooks over the city.

The Rocks - Great Area Of Sydney. On our recent trip to Sydney we walked around the Rocks area a few times. Found numerous great places for food in this area. Some great views of Sydney also, easy walking distance to Circular Quay

Loved the Rocks Market. Our family of six traveled to Sydney for the Christmas holidays. The Rocks Market was one of the highlights of this trip - the shopping was incredible. We had a fabulous lunch at an Italian restaurant on the corner near the entrance to the markets - can't remember the name of it, but the food and the atmosphere were incredible.

Charming area to see where "it all began".. A lovely and historic area that let's you see where Sydney all started. Great restaurants, historic buildings, close to Circular Quay, major museums, and the cruise ship terminal.

Great place for a walk, sights, and getting a meal at a cafe.. We stayed at a hotel nearby and enjoyed the walks through this area just stopping in for food and shopping. Fun to see the older buildings and lots of great places to catch a meal outside and look out at the bridge and harbor. The weather was great while we were there too.
Don't miss it!. Try the Thai Restaurant in the Rocks!!! Explore the shops and don't miss the view of the Opera House and Sydney Harbour Bridge from a unique angle.
Rockin Rocks. The Rocks was such a fun place to visit having so much to do and see. The food was fantastic and the shops were so fun to browse in.
Visit the history of Sydney. Spend a few hours in this area of Sydney and immerse yourself back in time. Range of cafes and restaurants to cater for all tastes and price range.

Great the best of the cream. Good to take picture of both the bridge and the Opera House. Little galleria and restaurant than coffee shop, the market, the access to climb the bridge, nice old buildings.
A day trip. The street performer, artists, ferries, the contemporary art, the history, you can spend a day here. The fortunes of war pub, and the cafes.

Full of character, food, market. Loved the cobbled streets and historical buildings. Found some great and varied food. Ate at The Rocks Cafe twice - breakfast and dinner - had wonderful shepherds pie! Worth a walk through the neighbourhood...
Iconic yet Friendly. So much to do and see in The Rocks. Great cafes, pubs, little hidden away shops, historical interest - and on the weekends a fab market.

It's old Sydney at it's best. Lots of restaurants, places to walk and see and all within walking distance of Central downtown Sydney. Not to be missed. We went later in the evening and the place was jumping with activity. Highly recommend

Love History? Go!. A great place to have a great "sense of place". Especially enjoy the weekend market fair (not all that brilliant stuff but fun).
Ditto the Susan Place Museum, old houses almost lost to development but not. Well worth the visit.
Pure early history. Great old pubs, fantastic historical areas marked out and basically just an atmosphere my wife, myself and our friends just love.

Windmill. There is always something to do at the rocks. Currently there is a mock up windmill to see where you can grind your own flour. Markets are on Saturday and Sunday and the near by MCA has a photographic exhibition you should check out. Plenty of pubs and cafes to while away the hours

Weekend market and cute shopping area. We enjoyed the weekend market, buying several unique souvenirs available from the vendors. It would take a full weekend to fully see all of the items available. The Rocks area is scenic by itself, however. The buildings are older and historic, and filled with shops with a variety of merchandise. We enjoyed pastries and coffee at the Guylian chocolate shop. One store featured Australian merchandise with Aboriginal designs. Whatever souvenir you want was available in The Rocks area.

Lot's to see. Check out the markets, the harbour, there is a free guided walk which talks about the history of the Rocks, and Susannah Place Museum is well worth the $8. You can easily spend an afternoon or longer here.

Transported back to another time!. The Rocks has so much to offer - a sense of Australian history, stories of old, sandstone architecture and quaint terraces. The markets are a bustle of activity and a treasure trove of goodies. there are a number of eateries as well.
Great markets. Markets over the weekend are brilliant! So much to look at! Take a lot of money! Quay restaurant was also amazing - delicious food and the infamous Snow Egg for dessert!

Brilliant Stuff. Large number of make shift shops selling/showcasing a huge variety of items. Paper Tole impressed me the most. it is hand made from original Australian postage stamps. This is a place where you can buy some excellent stuff.

Showing overseas visitors around. A good place to park early is the Observatory and walk down the steps to The Rocks. On the way you will get a good elevated view of where you are about to go . A bit of everything for everyone , Pubs, eating and coffee houses , markets and great souvenirs.There is even an alley called "the suez canal" , see if you can find it. Maurice B

Nice way to spend a morning/afternoon. We were there on the weekend when the markets were open and had a great time looking around- anything from jewelry to native art to pottery from Turkey. Nice architecture, easy walk from our downtown hotel, plenty of places to eat and shop.

The Rocks on Anzac day is a gambling mega fest. My only real experience of The Rocks was on Anzac day this year. A friend suggested we play a bit of 2-up, which is a traditional game for this day. In fact it is illegal to play it on any other day in the year, or so I was told by a friendly Aussie. We headed to "The Australian" bar. As we got near we could hear a roar, like a football crowd and we realised it was coming from the pub we were going to. The 2-up was in full swing. I'll try and explain it, but if you want to know how to play properly, ask an Australian. The people there were happy to explain it. Basically, a massive crowd gathers round a stage where a volunteer from the crowd flips 2 coins. The crowd has to bet on the outcome. To bet, you have to hold up your money and show if you'd like to choose heads or tails. If someone sees you and wants to bet the opposite then you have a betting partner. The person who wants to choose heads holds the money from both parties and waits for the outcome. It starts off with $5 going up and then the more drinks go down, you start seeing people holding up $50 and $100 notes. I won $5. Re-sult. Boom!
The heart of Sydney. Wonderful little streets and alleys, old and new pubs, lots of different restaurants and even markets on the weekends

A Great Place to Walk Around. This area is one of the most iconic in Sydney. It is basically where the city began. It now has a bit of a feeling of being a tourist trap but the quality of the offerings allows you to overlook this. The historic value and the unique feel provide you with all the justification needed to spend some time here.

The Smell of Sydney. Being in the Rocks area will give you a taste of what Sydney is all about. The smell in the air, the view, the stairs and the old buildings enhance the harbour views. It is a must to get the aussie feel.

Nice to walk, few shops, best way to get to Bridge.. The Rocks is the historical district of Sydney. The buildings are old, there are many shops, cafes, and bars.
The Rocks are the best place to get to the Bridge Walk from Circular Quay.

This is the area to stay.. The rocks is the center of activity in Sydney and the best location to stay to visit the Opera House, Botanic Gardens, Harbor Bridge and several other sites. Great restaurants here too.

Old Sydney with charm. The weekend street market was a great way to experience "The Rocks". A lot of locals walking around. The music is loud and entertaining at night. The food was great. I short walk from my hotel.
Interesting Market. On Sundays there are market stalls selling local products such as soaps, candles, clothes, jewellery, wooden toys, etc.

Interesting and quirky non mainstream area. There isn't much that's corporate about the Rocks. It's main small shops, bars and restaurants, with some business. It's one of the oldest areas is Sydney (and Australia) and this shows in many of the buildings that are old(ish) and have character compared to the more modern quarters of Sydney.

Spent an enjoyable day exploring the Rocks.. Started off our time at the rocks with a visit to the Rocks Museum for orientation to the history of the area. (Free Entry). Then off to the West Pylon of the Harbour Bridge for a view of the harbour. To climb the two hundred stairs to the viewing platform inside the pylon cost $11.00 but as I was already foot sore did not bother as the view form the bridge was spectacular. We were at the rocks on a Friday so had lunch at the Foodies Market -an abundance of choices and very affordable prices. Next visited the Museum of Modern Art Museum (Free Entry). Visited Susannah Place Museum to see how families lived in the Rocks over a hundred year period. What an interesting place - the four terraces have been conserved not renovated so you you really get a sense of what it would have been like to live there. Tour Guides were well informed and passionate about this place. (Cost $8.00) By this time we were very tired and decided to stop and have a drink in some of Sydney's oldest pubs. Stopped at The Harbour Views, and The Glenmore and finished our day at The Argyale. The rocks is a vibrant and interesting palce to visit.
A stay at the rocks. We spent a week there so full off history my son loved it so much to do and see he loved pancakes. And shopping around there in the heart off everything.
Nice Neighborhood. This neighborhood was the area where the European founders first arrived. Today it's filled with restaurants, bars and boutique stores and fun to walk around on a sunny afternoon.

A good base to stay. The Rocks is the original place where the first convict ships finally made their base. There are lots of excellent hotels within walking distance of The Sydney Opera House and The Bridge. It is the largest ferry terminal in the Sydney harbour. It is easy to get anywhere within the harbour area. Each weekend there is a market with lots of things to buy from clothes to Aborigine art and crafts, Pictures, food, Ugg boots, sheepskin. Everything! There are lots of good restaurants and coffee shops and you can walk all those extra calories off with a tour of the Botanical gardens.From the Rocks it is about a half hour walk to Darling Harbour or fifteen minutes on the ferry.
Old Sydney. Rather touristy and often ful of fairly drunk young people, but it is one of the really oldest parts of Sydney and must be seen.

historical sydney. Nice to walk around especially the back streets. You get an idea of the way things were. Keep walking under the bridge for a different perspective and visit one of the restaurants in Walsh Bay

Definitely worth seeing. You cannot miss walking thru the Rocks to get the "heart" of Australian history. I have read so much about Australia's past and this place has brought it all to life. I like that there is less of the hustle of the tourist areas and prices are much more in line. The service people are much friendlier in this area as well.

Quaint historical area right in heart of Sydney. The Rocks is located right on Sydney Harbour down at Circular Quay and the international shipping terminal. Lovely quaint buildings, nice shops and eateries, but best of all are the weekend markets where you can buy some really different things made by local craftsmen.

A must see. The Rocks is near Circular Quay and is an enjoyable walk through the "old" part of Sydney. It is full of old architecture, shops and neat little restaurants. should you happen to be there on a weekend, the Market could keep you entertained for hours.
The start. of Austrlian convict history. This is a classic place to visit and a few nice bars under the bridge too. A really good place to start your holiday from.
always worthwhile. no matter how many times youv'e been there you will always enjoy another trip to the rocks plenty to see and good food

Old Sydney + Market = Time well spent. We ventured down to the Market on Sunday and met some of Sydney's characters both in the Market and on the streets of the Rocks. While there is the usual mix of souvenir-type goods in the Market, there were some truly remarkable artisans with higher end offerings. If you're in town on a Sunday when the market is open you may find as we did some jewelry and crafts worth your attention. The Rocks street scene is worth an hour of just people-watching. The array of restaurants, bars and the old architecture offer something for just about everyone.In addition, the Rocks is the gateway to the bridge climb, the marina and quays for ferries around the harbor. We strongly suggest that if you're "holidaying" your best bet is to stay at one of the hotels close by the Rocks and the quays. Plenty of dining and bar options up and down the Rocks streets. We made the mistake of staying in the central business district and that is long walk back to the hotel...or...tiresome cab rides that are not cheap and many of the drivers are surly or indifferent.

This is where the city began. The sparkling waters of the harbour looks like diamonds and hence the name according to some. This is where the city took birth as a colony of settlers in 1788. The original buildings were made mostly of local sandstone, from which the area derives its name according to most. From the earliest history of the settlement, the area had a reputation as a slum, often frequented by visiting sailors and prostitutes. Steeped in history and because it is co close to the Circular Quay and Harbour Bridge, this is a place often visited by tourists. Many trendy curio and souvenir shops and eateries make it a nce place for an evening stroll. Fortune of War and the Lord Nelson are two of the oldest pubs in Sydney and they are here on the rocks!

"Old". Here you can see something that is in terms of white Australia "old". This quarter is now a tourist place with lots of little shops and restaurants. On certain days you can stroll over the market and look at all those things you don't need.Close by is the terminal for the ocean liners, quite interesting to see those big boats stopping over in Sydney.

A must see when in Sydney. This place combines all the great things of a quick trip into a beautiful city; Great restaurants, shopping, history and views that are stunning. Plan on one or two full days in this area when in the city.

A must do. The rocks is a beautiful place with amazing architecture. It has great restaurants, museums, and it's perfect to go for a nice walk. There's a market open on Sundays, where you can find many great Aussie souvenirs, clothing, books... it's just excellent.

Free walking tour. Visited the Rocks whilst on a free walking tour of Sydney which started on George Street close to St Andrews church, a great way to get an informed view of the city. The Rocks was vibrant with loads of bars and restaurants, had a good meal in a German one which had an oompah band outside. A great area with lots of history.
Markets on the weekends. Make sure you visit the market on the weekend! Lots of great deals and you can even watch a glass blower at work!

Shopping and dining. A little compact area of pleasure and enjoyment, well worth the experience if you have the time, quirky shops, not just the high streets ones, nice bars and restaurants to relax after shopping or waiting for your other half to finish their.

More there than you might think. We walked thru The Rocks and were not particularly impressed. Then we joined a tour and really understood what it was all about. We went on a Friday when they had a great little food market with very reasonable food. On Saturday they have a bigger market with a lot of jewlery, clothing, etc.

Plenty to do at the Rocks. We spent a lot of time in the Rocks area. The 2 different Markets on the weekends, Discovery Museum was really great with activities for the kids to do going through. Plenty of great pubs for a drink or meal. Worth exploring

Interesting and Quiet. We folllowed a walk from our guide book, but there is a tourist info centre in the Rocks where you could pick one up. Really interesting history and buildings; you get a feel for the early settlement. The museum was very informative but small and therefore manageable. There are lots of cafes in the area when you need a rest!

The historical original downtown of Sydney.. The Rocks is a great space to spend a few hours walking around, shopping, or dining. Saturday is outdoor market day in the Rocks and there's always entertaining things going on at the Circular Queue area by the Rocks. One time we even saw a guy juggling chain saws. It's very quaint but also popular with the young crowd. Lot's of pubs and places to eat.
A special part of Sydney on the Waterfront.. This part is close to the ferry harbour Circular Quai. Nice old buildings, market on Sunday, good restaurants, pubs and bars.

The place to stay in Sydney. Great area to stay when visiting Sydney, with all the iconic buildings and views just a 'stones throw' away. Great markets, shops and restaurants to experience without the hustle and bustle of the city centre.

Historical..... Tours operate, facts are told, you stand around. It is interesting, genuinely, if you have plenty of time, have run out of things to do, and haven't learnt about the history of Australia from anywhere else- otherwise, it really is just a repetitive speil in a beautiful(ish) place.

Don't miss the Rocks. A group of us from the USA were in Sydney for over a week staying at the Shangri La Hotel (outstanding hotel and location) at The Rocks. In a city with so much to offer, the Rocks seems to be the heart of where one wants to be, walk around, dine and just people watch. Restaurants, shops, galleries, museums, etc - it is all there in the preserved architecture of old Sydney. Don't miss The Rocks.
Nothing special. You can skip the walking tour of the Rocks.Except for old buildings and narrow lanes ,unless you have plenty of time to spend.

Great neighbourhood. Can't visit Sydney without going to The Rocks. Great restaurants and pubs to visit. We found the shops to be expensive as it is a tourist area. Lots of historical buildings and very charming to walk around.
fun. it was good to wander around and check out the little shops and bars in this trendy area, my wife loved the shopping as much as i loved the cold beer
Great view, cool Markets. The Rocks, on the harbour, has great views and an interesting History. Nice restaurants , great Thai, and really good markets.Definately worth a visit.

Fascinating Neighborhood. We stayed on the Rocks for ten days. Very convenient location being next to Circular Quay, so easy access to ferries, buses and trains. Good selection of restaurants and pubs (several nightclubs) -- interesting street markets on the weekends. Several interesting historical sites, museums, and wonderful walks along the harbor and around and across the Harbor Bridge. Will stay on the rocks again when we return to Sydney next year.
Over rated. A few nice historical buildings but mostly it is restaurants and expensive shops and galleries. I felt is was basically a tourist destination.
Great area. There is great hotels, restaurants, and especially shopping. Weekend street markets were amazing. Navigation is easy but some streets are hilly.

A historical tourist town that comes alive at night. When you first arrive at The Rocks, you can be easily taken in by the historical buildings in the suburb. Some of the pubs and bars can easily be 100-200 years old. However, many buildings are still very well preserved and offer some of the most delicious and unique meals.When the sun sets, The Rocks transforms into a whole different place. Bars, clubs, and bands rock the streets. The perfect place for a night out with friends.

Best place in Sydney for a few drinks. We went out and about this are mainly for nice meals and a few drinks and I thought it was the nicest area. It tends not to be overloaded with tourists as it is a little bit pricier than some other places. Not much in fairness, as the whole of Sydney was expensive.

Very pleasant district!. Almost in the center and surrounded by skyscrapers, the Rocks feels like old Europe with small buildings, nice coffee shops and bars. A good place to rest from the activity of Sydney center and enjoy th view on the harbour bridge and the Sydney Opera house.

The Rocks history & art. Tool 1.5hr walking guided tour. Ticket available from Tourist info desk at the Rocks. Learnt quite a lot of the inside history of this area in our history that you cannot get from books. After the tour had lunch at a bakery Cafe situated amongst historical buildings in a shaded courtyard area. Walked to Circular Quay & returned on Saturday morning to The Rocks Market which is rich in art & crafts, food, clothing & much more. Very enjoyable.

More shopping, good restaurants.. We tried for the "time" tour twice, and missed it both times. But the area is full of history (first part of Sydney that was settled) and charm. There are so many shops, there is no need for a craft market, but there is one. Within view of the Opera House, it is easy to do both in one day.

Historic. We thoroughly enjoyed wandering round The Rocks area and imagining life here in the early days. Lots of places to eat, we found a small coffee bar which offered free wifi (sorry - can't remember its name)...great coffee too! Numerous photo opportunities, informative plaques to read, shops to visit etc etc
The Rocks. We visited the Rocks area on Easter Sunday afternoon and came across a fantastic Sunday Market, with many locally made arts and crafts on display. A wonderful place to visit.
Sydney as it was.. Great to wander around the old roads and buildings and to visualize what Sydney was 200 years ago. We found great little passageways and shops.

Great combination of sea, Architecture and nature!. Amazing location for a walk, seat and enjoy a drink, dinner or just appreciate the astonishing view. Many cafes, restaurants and large open space fir a good walk! If you get in Sydney, cannot lose.

Weekend Market Fun!. On Saturday and Sundays part of the Rocks area is closed off to traffic for a street market. Interesting products and local hand crafts are available for sale. Its probably not the cheapest goods but some of the more unique items were very nice. I particularly liked the Chilli Sauce and the Closet fresheners stalls.We enjoyed a beer and some great sausages while people watching from the Lowenbrau...a very entertaining afternoon.

The Rocks and weekend markets. Interesting part of town with all of the sandstone walls. Lots of restaurants and shops. We find the shops to be overpriced and the wares at the market were not so unusual to justify collecting more stuff. Not much different from our street markets in Cali.

Interesting area, great atmosphere. This is a great area for shopping, having a coffee or a beer. We found the tourist information office very helpful. It is an area to pass a pleasant hour or two before going on to other places.

Sydney's history in one compact area. The Rocks historic area is one of Sydney's gems. It is a unique blend of modern attractions and historic buildings that date from Sydney's early colonial days, with just a little bit of trashy, crass touristy commercialism. But the blend seems to work and it provides plenty to see and do plus a large number of dining choices, from pizza to pub food to some quite classy restaurants.Walk the back streets and lane ways to see early Sydney and read the helpfully descriptive wall plaques to understand more.The weekly Friday food markets offer some intersting fare, incluing artisan cheeses and jams. The larger weekend market spreads for blocks and offers a huge variety of clothing, trinkets, arts and crafts, foods and hand made jewlery.

Great place to wander. Very old architecture and streets make rambling through the Rocks a treat. The do have a market there on Saturdays that makes it rather cramped, so if you don't like crowds, avoid that day.

One of the best parts of Sydney. The rocks has it all....great little shops, lots of restaurants and pubs, open air markets....and is close to all of the major hotels.Definitely put in on your tour list.....a tour of Sydney would not be complete without it.

History of old Sydney. The Rocks always offer a great day out, the guided walks are an enjoyable way to find out about the history of the area and well worth doing. The weekend markets are a mixed bag with some local crafts and a lot of imported crafts and jewellery. The food area is growing with Japanese, Turkish, Indian and German being avaiable as well as cafes and restaraunts. There is a nice little wine bar in an old house on the corner opposite the German Beerhouse with intersting wines, the dishes are expensive for what you get $8 for two tablespoons of creme brulee although it was delicious just not enough, but there are plently of other options including Haigs on the corner with coffee and hot chocolate to choose from.

Quirky shops and buildings - and good food when you need a rest. This is one of Sydney's older area's and has a quirky range of shops and eating places which all seems to work well together - it's easily accessible via the Circular Quay Station and from here you can also walk past the ferries to the Opera House and Botanic Gardens so for a day out in Sydney, it's an easy and well worthwhile addition.

Morning walk and dinner in the Rocks. It was a pleasant place to walk around for an hour in the morning before making our way to the Opera House. We had a muffin and tea at a little place called G'Day with tables in a garden one morning and ate dinner at a sidewalk cafe on a corner one night. All pleasant enough but not a destination for more than an hour or two.

Atmospheric. Very atmospheric lots of stalls selling artisan goods.Good bars and foods places.Check out menus first some are very pricey.Expect to pay $10 to $12 for a glass of wine and it,s a small measure.
Charming. Ferry terminal, great restaurants, historic buildings, the Opera House, the bridge..can't ask for much more. Fabulous views at the harbor. Clean, safe and fun. Even has a Starbucks.

Sunday in the Rocks. The shopping in the Rocks was fun. We went on Sunday to the open market, where there were many kioks selling lovely handmade items. It was fun to see all the crafts for sale and talk with the merchants. I came away with some lovely local handmade soaps.There was also food booths with snacks and drinks. I also enjoyed shopping at the Rocks for gifts for family memebers.

Great place for a stroll, a lunch or a coffee. Although it used to be the "gheto" place when Australia was established as a colony, The Rocks is now a cozy, picturesque 19th century neighborhood with many a great restaurant and coffee place. Take the time to walk around.Super easy to find: between the Opera House and the Sydney bridge (and next to the Quay).
Great History. A definite must when visiting Sydney. Lots of history and cute shops. Good markets on Saturday and Sunday

Popular outdoor market. I like to check the local market in the ROCKs. So many little interesting gifts and snack to try. I love the butter corn and it tastes delicious. Very easy to access and walking distance to Sydney harbour as well.

The rocks rock. Put on your walking shoes and explore the rocks whether you do it with map in hand or with an organized tour. Lots of shops,galleries and restaurants, (many of them hidden off rugged lane ways ) are there to be explored and enjoyed.

Don't Miss The Rocks!. If you can only visit one neighborhood in Sydney, it should be The Rocks. It shows a good piece of what Sydney was 100 plus years ago. To think that there was a move afoot several years ago to level The Rocks area and put up skyscrapers as you see just south of The Rocks. Fortunately, saner minds prevailed and you'll find the old buildings with mostly modern, restored interiors. There is great shopping, eating, and hotel living here. Don't miss it - and stay here if you can!

Shop and eat--shop and eat. Wonderful area to shop and wander. Quaint and friendly. There was an art fair and a street market going on in addition to shops and galleries. We spent hours wandering in and out and around the streets and alleys. Lots of places for food too. We will return each time we visit.

Great Bar. Found a great bar here on "The Rocks" called "The Argyle" wine from 9 dollars a glass and really tasty. Even do Rose wine which seemed to be a bit hard to find in Oz, it's up a little street and you go through a archway, food very good too!

Great History. Great Selection of bars & restaurants make your choice and pay your money. Great selection of shops some "High End" others less so.Great history from the early days have been preserved here with some "New" architecture creeping in. Don't miss the street market which starts on a friday night and goes on through the weekend there are some realy quirky stalls to view.Definitely a must go to area and the tour city buses (hop on hop off) pass right through here.
Good bars and food. We had several meals in the Rocks, plus we went to several bars. They all had friendly staff. The visitor center here was very helpful.

Good shopping and art museums. The Rocks is where the first settlers lived and its full of history with its share of original shops with a wide range of places to eat.
The history of how the area both developed and survived you can see at the free museum.

I don't know the fuss is about. Most of this area was going be flattened by developers in the 1970s, but communist backed unions prevented it. And thankfully they did.
maybe this area will be of interest in another three hundred years time, but I'm struggling to find much to recommend this tourist trap.

Wonderful area!. An absolutely lovely area to discover by foot! Don't get hungry though as the restaurant prices were just horrendous :-) But lots of nice bars as well and a great atmosphere both during the day and night
very cool place. This area offers some history along with great cafes and bars as well as unique street vendors on weekends. Easy walk from Circualr quay and the Harbor.
The Rocks. Nice area to walk around, great places to eat, but can be expensive. There is also some historic sites but I have not visited these.
Plenty of atmosphere here with some cracking pubs. Can get very crowded on a special day - but worth a visit for the atmosphere! Some great history here if you look for it!
If you're in Sydney for a short break, stay here.. History, sightseeing, restaurants, cafes, bars, markets, views, and more. This area has style and charm.
Worth a visit. If you want to sample a bit of fine dining then the rocks is the place to visit. Many top class restaurants serving top quality food with great views across the harbour.

Historic Area. The rocks is the original point that europeans settled in Sydney and despite its central location still has an old world feel. There is a Rocks Tour every evening at 6 p.m. on a 'pay what you think' basis - see the Free in Sydney GUide for details. The Rocks Museum is free and very interesting and comprehensive about the early settlement here.

So much to see.... The markets are great. Plenty of art, street performers, places to eat, take a walk to the observatory. There's so much history in the rocks that you could spend a week there and still not see it all. There's always something going on...

Old meets the New beautifully. This area is like a little pocket of history right on the edge of the busy quay. The old buildings, lanes, steps and cobblestone roads remind you of the depth of Syndeys history and how far it has come in such a short time. We found ourselves here to look at the bridge one day, grab a bite for breakfast on another, and for a few drinks one evening too. A definate must see for any visitor to Sydney.

Still more to do. The Rocks is one of the places you can never really say - DONE. There are so many things happening, so much history, such a lovely vibe, that it is always worth visiting again. And if you are planning a visit, good walking shoes, and plenty of time will serve you well. Don't rush it, you will only have to go back again. Enjoy the shops, museums, markets.....and don't forget to find out about all the ghosts....

do the ghost tour!. I love a good ghost story so although my feet were already tired from our Sydney walks we joined the tour! The area at night is very spooky and our guides hillarious! Light hearted they might be but they take the grizzly history of the place very seriously! Take the tour- atmospheric and highly enjoyable!

A great place to be.... I love the area of The Rocks, It is a great place to wander around during the day or go out at night. Make sure to take a look at the view of the Opera house here! Looks sensational at night. A Stop at Pancakes on the Rocks is a must! They are open 24hours
Walked this every day. For 6 days, compelled to walk this every day, beautiful area. very peaceful, we loved this highlight of our daily stay in Sydney.

Great location from which to explore Sydney. Apparently this is the historical heart of not just Sydney, but also Australia, and it certainly is a contrast to the the modern high-rise Sydney just behind it and the Circular Quay. We stayed here in the excellent Lord Nelson Brewery Hotel (see my review) and it was the perfect base from which to explore the city. In The Rocks there are many eateries and shops and the Harbour Bridge, the Opera House, the Botanical Gardens, the Observatory, the Museum of Contemporary Art and the Circular Quay are all very easily accessible from here. The city centre (Hyde Park, Australia Museum, Aquatic Centre etc) is a little further away but still well within walking distance. The market around George and Argyle streets at the weekends is worth visiting and gives a good atmosphere. If you're new to the area you should visit the Visitor Centre (corner of Argyle and Playfair streets) where the staff could not be more friendly and helpful about not only the immediate area but also Sydney in general and beyond. Check out the restaurants for their specials which they have on varying nights for good deals - Sydney is not cheap. Yes it is touristy, but if you're visiting Sydney you've got to do the iconic places like the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge and this is the perfect starting place.A little hint for you. If you want any basic supplies (food, drink, cosmetics etc) do not use the convenience stores in the area which don't even bother to price up their goods and are expensive. Go instead to Woolworth's just off George Street for a decent deal.

Nice afternoon stroll. We like the rock and even like it better in good weather. We can spend a lot of money in the rocks whether it was shopping or dining its just a fun place to hang out and have a good time.

Great restaurants, terrific market. This place has a real buzz to it. I've been to most of the restaurants and have found them to be great. There are lots of quaint shops and little side streets to explore. The market that appears at the end of George Street on weekends is well worth a visit.
great and relaxing. Great to spend half a day. great variety of cultures, items on sale, various foods to try. defintiely recommend.

A bit of a tourist trap. The rocks has some great old buildings and is worth walking around just to soak up the history. There is also a good street market on Saturdays and Sundays which is worth a look. Much of the shopping however, is targeted squarely at the tourist market with a lot of very ordinary souvenirs on offer. Stay away from the shops and just walk the streets and you will be better off.

Great area to explore. We loved walking this area with a lot of history. The discovery museum was worth the half hour to learn about the significance & history of The Rocks. Lots of shops & restaurants, cafes and bars... Loved this area!

different and fun. a little like greenwich village in NYC with restaurants shops and just about everything you could ask for, including a unique button store selling yes buttons. take the time to visit the information center and to read the street signs telling about the area's history. enjoy the great chocolate store

Get a room there!. We stayed in the Rocks section and loved it. It is convenient to Circular Quay, the Harbour Bridge, the Opera House, George St, the ferries, the train.......we even walked to Darling Harbour and the tower. Everything we came to see was here.

Pubs, real pubs. There are pubs and great beer here. Forget the bridge, ardent and opera house. On holiday, far away from real pubs, there are several here that are just great to sit at whilst the ladies go round the market. In fact, bung them $50, and you get to stay there all day !

A hard day's work. Our bus tour guide gave us interesting insight that each prisioner was given a certain pattern of chiseling the rocks so the authorities could tell how much work teh prisioner had done. I was hard to realize there's so much rock in Sydney. Cute stores and eating establishments in the area. The Rocks Market has great food stalls (witness the lines) and craftsbooths. It's all good.

Amazing story. Well its about the first settlers to Australia other than ofcourse the aboriginals. Had guided tour of the Rocks and how the convicts made it there homes and there struggle..just 200 years back

European feel. We didn't have very much time there, but has a lovely lunch at a small bakery and walked around a bit, had fun looking into some shops. Quite touristy, but had a European feel, I guess because of all the old buildings.

Rock by name Rocks by Nature!. Travelling solo ... Lady of certain age rucksack on back I booked into hostel in the Rocks. The district was awesome. The people so helpful. Everything so handy ... Buses ferries trains!I had 4 fantastic days here filled to bursting with sights & sounds of my first visit to Oz before mountains!!Few pics on my Oz blog...Downunderlost.wordpress.comSingle senior & solo it felt safeEnjoy if you are on your way x

Interesting historic buildings, but too many tourist shops. The historic buildings are somewhat interesting in this otherwise modern city, but most of them are converted in to restaurants (which look promising) or shops selling tourist crap. (Do we really need any more UGG boots in this world?)
Fun to walk around. Cute market at he weekend and nice bars and places to snack. Good view of the harbour bridge and the opera house. It is worth a look for sure

Touristy. Nice for a walk and stop to eat though restaurants for the most part are pricey. Very good tourist info center and if there on the weekend the market is nice, but otherwise not that great, mainly just a lot of tourist shops and galleries. Is an interesting archaeological site and architecture.

Worth a visit!. Fun area, but pretty crowded. We stopped here after the Sydney Bridge Climb and walked through the shops that are set up on the street. We found some great deals - pearl necklace and a great leather bag - and also some very interesting artwork from locals. If you're in the area it's worth taking a stroll through to see the shops and admire the architecture. It's not far from the cruise ship port, so you will get lots of crowds headed up there.
Awesome place to visit. Brilliant we were here on a holiday had a great time around The Rocks stayed just up the road and had plenty do to and see
The Rocks. A good area, but a little touristy - so prices are higher here than in other areas, but the scenery is gorgeous- so take a few minutes to walk around the area.

Argyle Pub. Great place - lots of people around and really nice buzz about the pub. The building is old and looks like it used to be some kind of warehouse. Check out the toilets - amazing. The men's urinals are made in the shape of schooner glasses - WOW!!
Lots to discover. Access the bridge climb here. Lots of great restaurants, we loved Pony Lounge, Apetito and the little patisserie on Argyle. Convenient to Circular Quay
Lovely area. Great area for a stroll , the nice little shops and restaurants are not to be missed, great way to spend a sunny afternoon

Enjoyed market. Saturday morning market - great diversity of Australian wares. Enjoyed Breakfast in cafe by the Quay. After Market enjoyed browsing the wide variety of other shopping outlets as we made our way to the centre of Sydney. Easy to stroll about in Sydney and you can get quickly to various sights on foot which enables you to see more of the city
Funky, historic, central.. We stayed in the Rocks and loved it, especially since it's right on Circular Quay and a great jumping off point fro everywhere else.
Great area to explore. Lots of little streets to explore and history. Lovely old buildings. Good views when you get to the top. Nice to be away from the CBD and traffic.
My favourite place in Sydney. I love the Rocks, I love its History, the food and the markets. The little pubs and the ghost tours are a must see.

Pleasant Area but Nothing Special. Can understand locals enjoying wandering around looking for a beer. However, if you have visited European cities there are are lot more interesting specific places to spend your time when visiting Sydney.
If you like bars this is for you. Lots of beer bars and not much to eat in them. Not a lot of places to eat at here. Saw an old LOO near the water.

History and modern times meet. The Rocks in Sydney is well worth an afternoon spent strolling through the streets and shops. Take the time to appreciate the history of the area and then accept that the area is modernizing. There are hidden alleys with stores (art, clothing, etc), pubs, and restaurants throughout the area. The Aboriginal Art store (Spirit Gallery) has a great selection of Aboriginal Art and high-end didgeridoos, and the prices seem competitive for a city centre.There is easy access to the Opera House, the Botanical Garden and the Sydney Harbour Bridge (all worth walks on their own).
great place to wander. A great, artsy neighborhood that just begs to be wandered. Had our best meal in The Rocks, found a great little wine shop and enjoyed wandering the art galleries. So much fun!

Take Time To Explore The Rocks!. The Rocks is Sydney's oldest suburb and the contribution of convict settlement is everywhere! Make sure you are wearing your best walking shoes (lots to see!) and start at Cadman's Cottage next to the Overseas Passenger Terminal on Circular Quay. Plan to explore the Sydney Visitor Centre, Dawes Point underneath Harbour Bridge, the workers' terraces on Millers Point, with plenty of historic pubs along the way. The Lord Nelson Brewery Hotel (the oldest built in 1834), the Glenmore Hotel with good harbour views from the rooftop terrace, and the Harbour View Hotel tucked under the Bridge on Lower Fort Street ... the upper lounge offers a great chance to watch those excited bridge climbers as they come and go. There's plenty of climbing along old laneways so plan your walk carefully ... just get a local map and spend the day on The Rocks!

We like this area very much!. If you want to see and get an idea of early Sydney, this is the area to see. It has been nicely protected and restored and the shops, restaurants, parks and history were great.
Great Atmosphere & Market. Loads to do here and just a short walk from Circular Quay. Great market on a Sunday - spend a whole day there.
market shopping. Enjoyed the market experience on sunday with many lovely and interesting stalls. Had a lovely lunch in a french restaurant near the water

Great place to buy gifts at the weekend craft fair. On Saturdays and Sundays, several streets are closed in the Rocks area, so that artists can show their creative crafts.Will be able to find something for everyone from jewelry to clothes to purses and children's items. Unusual gifts withan Australia theme. While shopping you can view a lot ofthe important places in this area that is the oldest part ofSydney.

Historic. The Rocks are where the first convicts settled when they arrived in Australia. The old houses and warehouses have been renovated and the whole area is now very attractive. The locations is very central as it lies between the Opera House and the Bridge.

Australia's Oldest "White" History - Wander these cute laneways with spectular views of the harbour around most corners. The Nurse's and Doctor's Walks were so full of history and I loved the cobblestone laneways - reminded me of the gorgeous roads in Europe. Such an interesting slice of our history and well marked with historical facts as you wander up and down the streets, checking out the quaint storefronts and eating in cute terrace houses - some with cool, hidden courtyards around the back. The markets are great. Well worth a couple of hours of your time.

Character PLus. What else is there to say - the Rocks area is a must see if you are in Sydney. So close to all the other major sights of Sydney and close to Circular Quay - gateway to fantastic ferry rides if you are keen

Great. Awesome! Just last weekend we've pretended to be tourists and walked all the way around Botanical Gardens, The Rocks, under the bridge etcPlus it was Sunday and the local markets were open, which was a pleasure just to browse through

Fun shops - little cafes and wine bars. For a day of strolling around, the Rocks provides lots of quaint shops, wine bars and places of interest to mull around. Safe and easy to locate, you can do a self guided walk.

Fantastic pocket of Sydney city. This is my favourite part of Sydney city. I'd recommend a visit on the weekend when the markets are there. They sell a range of different things (lollies, artwork, jewellery) even if you're not buying its fun just to have a browse.The area itself is lovely, great city location but with a more intimate and old world feel. Plenty of cafes and bars, but not the cheapest area.
Fun Neighborhood. Lovely old buildings and lots of shops, pubs and restaurants. Great spot for lunch and afternoon drinks.
Old Sydney. Walk around the high and rocky outcroping at the base of the Sydney Bridge and you can gain a feel for old Sydney. Look for a small corner wine bar near the small park.

My favorite part of Sydney. I love the rocks! It's a very quaint neighborhood of old buildings, pubs, restaurants. Give yourself plenty of time to stroll around, there's so much to see and do here. Stop in for a beer at one the pubs! The weekends offer a very nice marketplace with all sorts of good souvenirs.
HAS NOT CHANGED. Great to return to The Rocks after 12 years away still great place to eat, drink and enjoy. Th prices are reasonable and the place just is so alive.
Great historic neighborhood. The Rocks is a great place to wander around, do some shopping, see some history, drink in a pub & generally just relax. Go on a Saturday or Sunday for the outdoor market.

Historic and another must-do. Walking through the Rocks you will get a better sense of Australian history. There is interesting architecture, shops and restaurants and a real sense of the past. Take a walking tour if time permits. There is the oldest pub which is well worth a visit too.

The Rocks. Quaint old town style. Near The Bridge. Lots of galleries and Ausralian art/crafts. Lots of nice bars and eateries. $12 for a glass of Rose wine though...everywhere very expensive compared to UK. ..But well worth visiting.

Great market at The Rocks. We weren't hugely impressed by The Rocks - but thought the market was great and well worth a visit. There were a variety of stall-holders and the quality of goods was pretty good.
nothing special. we walked all over The Rocks and it was nothing special compared to all the other things we did. Seemed like a CBD to me. walking a couple blocks would be enough

Great place on Saturday and Sunday. The Rocks were more lively when the weekend market came to town with some interesting handcrafted goods. One stall had delightful cards and another lovely china with cats in the designs.

Great for shopping. The Rocks are worth a look. Its mainly a shopping street which runs parallel to Circular Quay, look for the cruise ship thats normally docked in the Quay and The Rocks area is opposite, behind the front buildings. There are some great gift shops selling unusual stuff, hand made bits and pieces which are not the normal tourist tat. Worth a look
Lovely place. Lovely place on the Mornington peninsula with great views of the harbour. The food is a mix of seafood and Asian little bites and yummy and fresh salads. Definitely worth stopping by!

fantastic. A walk around the rocks on any day is an experience. the history of place is visible at every turn, cafe's restaurants from reasonably priced to silver service style are there for the choosing, "olde world" shops, plus the Sunday market make it an experience to behold....Plus of course a stroll by the harbour and its views.
Great Character. Lovely little district with bags of character, lovely eateries and a smashing market. Well worth a lazy browsing day in Sydney.

Sunday Visit to The Rocks Worth the Effort. While in Sydney during February and March, 2013, my wife and I visited The Rocks Market on a Sunday. It has lots of shopping and places to eat, but few bargains that we could find. My wife is phsyically limited due to disease, so she found the going hard. We only stayed at most two hours, but that was no one's fault. We had to do that due to the effects of my wife's disabilities and her constant pain when walking. It was sunny and hot. If you go, then wear a hat and use sunscreen. Stay well hydrated. Nonetheless, I do recommend this as a place to visit. It was fun to see the jewelry and other things created by individuals, things to be sold to tourists and others. Do not expect bargains, but the prices listed were not unreasonable. I understand it is a business and they want to make a profit for their efforts and design.Once we left there, we went to nearby Circular Quay and took public trasportation back to the hotel.

Lively Rocks. The Rocks are located at circular quays where most ferries depart, it is a lively area and although busy, very clean. Beware about the food prices though, some of the side stalls selling what seems like a good deal can cost a bit more. Sydney is expensive anyway, but you might be better off walking a little further into the city for better value.

Old world charm.. Good to see the origins of Sydney. Lots of original buildings and information about the area. We were there on a rainy day so having lots of places to pop in to was helpful. The middle of the area seems to have been taken over by a market andshops which spoilt the effect a bit.
Fun to walk around and see a historic part of Sydney. There are lots of shops and the buildings look pretty cool. Take an evening and walk around the area.

Everything in one place. Great shopping, art museums (check out Ken Done the modern art museum) and views of the bridge and opera house. Check out Pancakes on the Rocks for affording dinning. They are open 24 hours.
Market days. VIsit the Rocks on Saturday and Sunday and see the Rocks Market. Well worth a visit. Hilly at times, but some good shops to window shop.
Great time. Very interesting buildings and people, a great place to spend some time. We went to the market on Sunday and found some nice original souvenirs. Many restaurants and pubs as well.

Interesting Area.. Very clean + buzzy area with great views of Sydney Harbour, Bridge, + Opera House. It has many cafes + several small shops as well as the historical buildings in the area.It has a great Tourist Information Centre with good service + plenty of brochures etc.- a must visit for visitors old + new to Sydney.

Always want to go back. We have visited The Rocks on many occasions and every time we pass through Sydney and never fail to find something new and exciting. Twice this year alone and with the bonus of Australia Day.What a great atmosphere, full of noise and entertainment. Look out for the hot sweetcorn stall at the bottom of the open market - delicious and messy but what the heck. Some of the stall items are a bit pricey so beware but with some great ideas for the folks back home.Take in the architecture and grab a beer whilst soaking up the ambience. The scene changes from day to night so at least two visits are necessary to get a good idea of what is going on.Take the train to Wynyard and walk and ... enjoy.We will be back.

The Rocks, a must see in Sydney. Very interesting buildings and people, a great place to spend some time. We went to the market on Sunday and found some nice original souvenirs. Many restaurants and pubs as well.
Nice shopping area. Great place for some shopping or a bite to eat or have a drink. It's just across the street from the Quay and easy to get to.

Rare piece of Australian history. The Rocks is one of the most unique things about Sydney as an Australian city. The area is a piece of history to be treasured - having such old streets and buildings so well preserved is a rarity. It hints at the country's convict past and is great to walk around.

Old Sydney ! A MUST in SYDNEY. Probably the most beautiful part of Sydney: small shops, narrow streets, nice cafes and restaurants. You are minutes from the harbour, and yet the neighborhood feels much older, much more authentic compared to the other side of the harbour. We had better food and drinks in the restaurants and cafes in this area compared to the more expensive ones on the harbour.

beautiful and historical. This is the original place where the whites settled in sydney along sydney harbour forshore. the rocks is well preserved and very historical a must place to visit when your in sydney
Rocks area. Explore the shops and restaurants of this first site of Sydney. The area has a great atmosphere and good food.

great place to visit. went there on a tour bus and had a look around, it is great for the history buffs, a museum that is free is just up the road near information centre.Great little shops and galleries in some of the old terrace houses, which in there is really interesting themselves.We went back there one night and had dinner at an italian resturant, can't remember the name but was a great night out

Historic and interesting. In a relatively young city, it's to find an historic centre where you can get a feel for the old world. The Rocks is a lovely place for a walk and has several cafes and restaurants that offer good, however overpriced, food. There are great harbour views and also the weekeend markets are ideal for buying souvenirs.
Beautiful !. Wish I had time for a coffee at a restaurant with a view. The buildings are picturesque and the area is quaint. you'd feel transported instantly into another world.
The Rocks, historical Sydney. There is lots of variety around here and surely everyone will find something to please. The markets at the weekend are good. Head to The Rocks from the ferry terminal.

Great place for a walk, very touristy. The rocks has several great bars and restaurants as well as shops. Its a very touristy area, but also one of historical importance. For Sydney, it's all old there. It is definitely worth a trip to walk through it, find a cafe and enjoy the world going by.

The history of the rocks is so interesting... I went on a FREE tour of the rocks at 6pm they meet every day in front of the cottage on the west side of the quay. It was 1 and a half hours long and he really went into the history and ended at an amazing view point :) he asks for donations after so give what you think :)

past times. Loved the way old buildings were preserved. Also very good time snippits and historical "plaques" to give a feel of the "growing" and making of Sydney. Very informative, also captivating if interested in history.

A don't miss. Look at the old warf buildings! A way to step back in time. The architecture is incredible! Explore the byways look in the shops. The Spoils fo War was an interesting pub. Last remodled in 1922. The beer is a little pricy. Have one and move on. If you are a history or architecture buff a great place to spend the day!
Historic place to visit. You can walk from Circular Quay to the Rocks and enjoy the old part of Sydney. There are walking tours you can take.
Loved The Rocks!. We stayed on Circular Quay ,the Rocks and absolutely LOVED the area! Great restaurants and art galleries,views of the Harbor,shops...it was fantastic!

Interesting historic precinct. Sydney's not an old city by European standards so don't expect any ancient stuctures. Lots of nice eateries and harbour view vantage points. Watch out for the tourist trap shops selling pretty junky stuff. The weekend markets are lots of fun
Think I will stay there next time!!. Loved the Rocks. Great restaurants. Bohemian atmosphere. Great transport links. Just sorry I did not have time for the walking tour of the area.
Trumps Altoego. I have a facial from the Trumps Altoego day spa and it was magnificent. So relaxing, my skin has never looked or felt so good. Highly recommended if your staying in the Rocks area.

Quaint area....good food places... The old part of Sydney not far from Circular Quays where boats dock...Interesting historic buildings and plenty of places to sit and eat....good food , easy going attitude from folks...Weekend markets a must visit if possible.....access to the Tower of the Sydney Harbour Bridge that you can climb......

early sydney. its heritage sydney right where the invaders landed in 1788 lots tourist shops resturant pubs markets great to walk around views of opera house bridge etc its easy walking lots to do for free and on a nice sydney day its great touristing

Cruise Ship Damaged. This was once one of Sydney's most evocative neighbourhoods, but on a recent visit I was shocked by how far it has fallen. During our entire three day visit an enormous cruise ship blocked any view of the Rocks from the Opera House and visa versa. I can't believe Sydney aithorities permit such large ships to come into Circular Quay and destroy the ambiance of the historic core. Unless you are a history buff there is no compelling reason to venture here, particularly during cruise ship docking. this enormously important neighbourhood may be well on its way to exuding the charm of Montego Bay or Key West. A shame.
Has it all!. The title says it all. The markets are fabulous, the restaurants great (if a bit steep price wise) and the history very interesting. Worth exploring the back lanes.

Great Neighborhood. We stayed in the Rocks neighborhood while we were in Sydney. It is a great area with lots to do. Our hotel was very nice and there were many options for food and drinks. There is also a lot of history in this area and I would recommend taking the Rocks Walking Tour if you are interested in the history of the neighborhood and how Sydney got its start. There is a great market on the weekends to explore with a wide variety of different items. We felt safe walking around and had no issues while there. Our hotel was close to the Harbour and it seemed there were endless things to do. Check it out while you are there!
Andrew nz. great weekend markets and some lovely old historic buildings recommend a visit to the local museum and the local pub in george street it is the oldest pub in sydney
great area. Lovely area, the oldest area in sydney infact. Theres some great pubs here and every sunday a very cool art market which is worth a visit

Favourite area of Sydney!. Hands down without a doubt this was my favourite area of Sydney . It's a series of old streets with boutique stores and yummy cafes. But what I didn't realise was it was one of the oldest areas in Sydney and some of the building actually used to belong to the convicts and setters when they first came to Australia. Two things I highly recommend if you go to the Rocks, don't miss the Saturday markets! We'd gone earlier in the week and went back a second day just because we liked the area do much. Without realising it our second visit was market day and it was fab. The stalls weaved through the streets and had loads of great gift selections. Secondly I really enjoyed the museum there, I think it was called 'the rocks discover museum' or something similar. It only took an hour or do out of our day and gave a fantastic background into The Rocks and its past. It was really nice to walk through the streets afterward once I knew some of its history.Favourite area in Sydney and probably a highlight of my holiday.
Lost. I was at the side but did not see much to shout about. Looked like just another city area. Nothing so adventorous unless you are a hungry for history tourist.
Historic and Spooky, go see. Original Sydney at its best, a myriad of shops and cobblestone history. It has a great energy to the place albeit somewhat eerie. Do it, a must see

Take a tour of the Rocks.. I loved learning about the history of the Rocks. Think it was called Itour Free..It is a free tour offered but informs you that they depend on tips for what you feel it's worth. 10:30am 2:30pm and 6:30pm every day...check with the tourist info booth ...I took the 6:30 tour around the Rocks and it ended on a high hill at sunset...Beautiful and very informative

The Rocks certainly does-Rock You!. What a vibrant area of Sydney this is-never a dull moment.Adjacent to both the Harbour Bridge & Circular Quay with a view over to the Opera House.There is always activity-human traffic connecting to one of the many ferries that criss cross the Harbour or passengers embarking/disembarking from the huge Crise ships that dock at the Passenger Terminal on a daily basis.Retail is well represented by Cafes/Restaurants & Tourist Gift Shops. These are augmented by the Rocks Markets at the weekend. A really interesting line up of diverse stalls.If its action you want then its the Rocks for you.

Do Not Miss!!. Any visit to Sydney is incomplete without spending time in The Rocks. This is the historic part of Sydney where it all started with the arrival of the first convict ships. Now,as well as the museums giving the detail of the history, the area is also vibrant and noisy with numerous cafes, pubs, restaurants and nightclubs. Visit on Saturday or Sunday and you will also experience the market.Great views of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge from Circular Quay.
Great Vibe. We went for drinks and music to the Fortunes of War hotel, cosy pub with a band. Clean modern bathrooms. Great night

Our favourite place. We like to stay in The Rocks - usually at The Old Sydney Holiday Inn. Why? close to Circular Quay - we love the ferries as a mode of transport and close to the trains. Lots of good cafes and restaurants and plenty to see and do. An easy walk to Bridge and Opera House and plenty of old Sydney history. We think The Rocks is more interesting than Darling Harbor

Worth a visit. Our hotel was situated in the Rocks area so we had plenty of opportunity to explore. It's a great area for a few drinks or a meal in the evenings. We also had breakfast at a fab little place called the Fine Food Store which is highly recommended - best breakfast I have had in a long while!
Great scene. Every where you look there's something to do, markets, cafes, parks, curios, very interesting and some great photo opportunities.

My Favourite Place in Sydney. Great sunset view of the city. For a special treat, try Doyle's for Dinner with a Harbour side table. You can take the ferry during the day, but they don't run very late, so you will have to take a bus back to the city. No big deal...
Weekend markets are great fun. I enjoy going to the market at the rocks as there are some great stalls. I always come away with something unique.

Perfect location. The perfect place for seeing Sydney, Every attraction within walking distance, centrally located for transportation, beautiful scenery. Perfect price range for everyone. All the icons for Sydney Plus great access to the gardens and photography of the bridge and the Opera House. Great location for tours, photography, food, and relaxation. I would certainly make this my best location for visiting Sydney.
busy area.. a market is held in the streets on weekends attracting food vendors and good variety of stalls.several good pubs and resturants in area within easy reach of darling harbour.

Great on a Sunday. Craft market for the connoisseur. Great coffe shops, ice cream parlours and brilliant hand made crafts. Visit the pen guy. Each one is unique and he knows his product. Remember Real Men use a fountain pen!!
Mixture of old and new. The Rocks is a mixture of many things, arty and new, cafes and restaurants. It's nice to just wander around looking at many different things.
Foodies Delight. Restaurants, shopping and old buildings dating to the time of first habitation. Great way to spend a day and into the evening. Love Caminetto's Italian Restaurant.

The Rocks is misnamed. Call it "Renovo" or "Little Phoenix"--- this is one bird that has risen from the ashes of times past to be resurrected in a charming way to provide shopping, wandering and eating experiences .
very fun shops and restaurants. lots of fun little shops and restaurants all along this area. it's also right alongside the harbour, so there's plenty to do afterwards.

The Rocks (of Sydney) rocks !!. This is the oldest part of Sydney and was where the early settlers (pioneers) landed when they arrived. You just need to walk further up at the Harbour and take a left turn after you past Quay No. 6 and several other interesting locations.During weekend there is a Bazaar selling fresh fruits and veges and if you walk further up, you'll reach a Specialty Bazaar where they only sell "Made in Australia" products. There are clothes, hand-made natural soaps, essential oils, candies sauces, opals, pearls and many many interesting items.I love the fashion stores as they are truly beautiful and there's even a store that sell vintage clothing. There are simply gorgeous but be prepared to pay premium price for them. The prices are actually "boutique-prices".There's an artist at the end of the Bazaar who spray-paints while he turned on music from famous artists and he'll finish his masterpiece when the song finishes, Bravo!! Best part is...it's not expensive and you sure can afford to buy his masterpieces to bring home.The Rocks are lined with interesting colonial and vintage buildings and it really acts character to the street.The Rocks sure rocks !!!!

Take a tour to appreciate The Rocks area of Sydney. You really need to take a tour in order to understand the history and to appreciate this area. ($25) We booked a 90 minute tour which included history, ruins of old homes, alleys - places you would never find on your own. Our guide was Margaret and her pride in her city and her heritage were admirable. Great tour! You can find the office for the walking tour in the Clocktower Square, Harrington and Argyle streets, The Rocks.
Wonderful galleries and shops. The Rocks is easily accessible, filled with restaurants, cafes and lovely arts and crafts galleries. The Contemporary Art Museum is also there.

Wonderful!. This area is great just to walk around on a nice day and appreciate the history, architecture and scenery. First Fleet park is lovely, the art museum beautiful and the views of the water and Opera House are wonderful!
Iconic. Great location, probably one of the best in the world. Great choice of place to eat, drink or just sit outside and watch the world go by. Markets were god fun on Saturday ad Sunday.
Very interesting place to visit. Lovely location and great resturants and coffee shops. great markets with gifts for everyone. very historic area well worth a visit

Awesome pub atmosphere. If you like to visit old pubs dating back to when this country was first settled, then The Rocks is the place to go.There is so much history to be seen in the Rocks area.There are so many great bars The Argyle near the Harbour bridge being one of my favorites for atmosphere, friendly patrons and the best view from the roof bar, especially after dark when you can see the Opera House at its best.Another great pub is the Orient hotel.The food is great,the bands are always awesome and you can dance up a storm and meet new friends as everyone is usually so friendly.The markets,little cafes and Art galleries are great to visit too.So much to see and do 24hrs a day in the Rocks:)
Great area for a leisurely stroll.. The markets on Sunday are fabulous. Lots of great places to eat, plenty to see and do. Good shopping. Make sure you visit here as part of your trip to Sydney.
Must have dinner here!. Interesting to see the inscription at the memorial site. Take time to walk around to see the restos and the awesome view of the harbour bridge. Best enjoyed at night.
Lovey and historic. A great place to stroll and shop. Different feel from center city. However, don't eat at the Cut unless you are famous. Terrible service ruins the fine but pricey food.
great shops and history. This historic section has great shops, bars and restaurants. Great for taking in some of the rich history of sydney

Great place to explore. Have been on walks around the Rocks on many occasions and never get sick of looking, there is always something new to look at and the market stalls on Saturday and Sunday are amazing, so much variation.

Great place to shop!. Visted the Rocks market on a Sunday and it was amazing! Had fun looking at the stuff being sold there. There's a lot of souvenir shops at the Rocks Center. I went back there for a second time just for some last minute shopping.

Taken Back in Time. Very informative walking around the rocks area. Found the oldest pub in Australia the Lord Nelson which is situated on the top of a steep climb but worth the effort.Go to the Rocks information place to get a map and their ideas. Had a great time.
Best Markets. Always a delight to walk around the picturesque part of old Sydney. The weekend markets are fabulous & you will find unique gifts, clothing & accessories that is usually all handmade.

Take the free walking tour. The place has a ton of history and you won't know what your looking at without the tour. The tour has walking so wear comfortable shoes and if you are doing this in the evening it's near the water and can get cool. And don't forget to tip the guide as that is what they get paid!
wow ammmmmmaaaaazzing. The beeeessst place to go to in sydney, it rocks at the rocks and meet the most amazing people and would be keen to move here better than melbourne

Nice atmosphere. Pleasantly surprised by the nice weather and the atmosphere. Nice touches of the engraved history on the stones and banners along the small lanes describing the history of the places.

Lots to do in The Rocks. There is so much going on in The Rocks from the weekend market to the Discovery Museum and everything in between. Lots of eating (and drinking) places, unusual shops, souvenir shops, and of course access to the Harbour Bridge. Although I highly recommend the Bridge Climb and/or the Pylon, if you don't like heights, take a walk across the bridge and back. Lots of photo opportunities of a magnificent view.

Party central. This area has interesting shops and lively bars and restaurants that are hopping until late into the night. The market is well worth a visit and we enjoyed walking through the alleys with their historical descriptions.
get fit for the steps. OMG steps everywhere...and so steep...there is otherways around the rocks if you need to avoid steps....so it can be managed!

Old Sydney at its best. I love the Rocks, the place of Sydney's first settlement. Lots of historic building, pubs and places to stay, shop and dine. Many of the pubs have live music and serve food which makes for a nice day/night out. There are markets there of a weekend as well. There are many place to dine from high end establishments to lovely little cafes. You can find the international cruise ship terminal there as well as the museum of contemporary art. A must see for all visitors to Sydney.

Great feeling. We used to frequent this area when my daughters first went to Sydney to study. It's unusual, unique only to Sydney. It is a touristy area, but nice for window shopping and just walking the are and taking in the sounds and sights of the harbour. Some good cafes for breakfast and lunch

Great Markets. We had a great day. Great markets with local produce. Lots of people who appear to be in holiday mode which is so pleasant. We spent the morning at the rocks and then headed to Darling Harbour, all in walking distance

Becoming a bit of a cliche. Having visited this area several times over the years, the gloss does wear off. Doesn't seem to be anything new to offer and most shops peddle the same old tourist offerings. Still some wonderful historic sights to enjoy and some good eating amongst the standard fare.
Wonderful markets. The Rocks markets are always full of great stalls with prices varying from reasonable to astronomic - and plenty of good places to eat and drink.

Terrific!. Loved exploring The Rocks! Great personality and history, and well-preserved. Fun little restaurants and shops, quirky little alleys and walkways. We particularly liked the signage here and there that explained background and added a lot of local color.The Rocks is memorable, and we loved all the tourist sourvenir shops. A huge variety of shops and eateries, so you've got some great choices.

pure history. just walking through The Rocks if a walk back in time, a must for locals and tourists alike. If you're lucky enough to there on the weekends the Rocks markets are full of local artisans and their craft as well as musicians and food.

The Rocks rock. It's area is my favourite place of all time. The best pubs, restaurants, Markets ever. Caters for mixed age rather than just the kids. Love The Argyle and The Glenmore is brilliant if you go during the week when it's not so busy. This trip we discovered The Rocks Cafe. Coming from Perth we are used to everything closing early during the week. To our amazement this place was open and serving food at 10pm on a Tuesday night. Very impressed with the service and food. We went back a couple of times it was so good!
Love the atmosphere.. Always love coming here. The food, artists, markets. Excellent atmosphere. Good for families and girl weekends.

Wash on the Rocks. Ok, I realize this is pretty specific, but if you are staying in the harbour or Circular Quay or Rocks area, Wash on the Rocks (clever name) charged only $15.50 for a humongous bag of laundry to be washed, dried & neatly folded. A few extra dollars gets you delivery to your hotel. Bargain, since our hotel charged something like $10 to wash one t-shirt.

Saturday adds an outdoor market. If you are there on a Saturday, there is an outdoor craft fair which streches along several streets. There were lots of local crafts and some good Souvenir shopping. Otherwise i didn;t find the Rocks that much different from other slightly upscale neighnorhoods. Some Cafe's, a few nice Restaurants. and some of the older Pubs in Sydney.

Wonderful neighbourhood. I highly suggest you do the "we're free" walking tour of the Rocks. It's filled with great anecdotes and historical factoids about life in the area. And, the tourguides take you around to all the great old bars and pubs, and down all the neat side streets and alleyways.
Sunday in the rocks. The cafes, the shops, the people, the whole place just makes you feel alive. Little back streets and alleys, a real look at early Sydney.

PUB CRAWL. The Rocks, has pubs, food, and markets and a great view. Perfect for a family day out, an event at the Rocks is always happening. Perfect for pub crawls with pubs which are lining the streets, its perfect for just about anyone to do just about anything.

First settlers. this is very interesting, being the oldest part of past 1788 Sydney. There are guided tours available or just loaf around on your own and enjoy the very different athmosphere and breath of history.
Interesting area of Sydney. Loads of historical interest, local musuem, and pub. Visited on market day, where we purchased some arty/crafty souvenirs. Well worth a visit.

The living Christmas tree!. I was in this very hip part of Sydney before Christmas and was taken in by the awe-inspiring living Christmas tree. This area was well worth walking through. There was so much to do and see, and you can have meals at the wonderful restaurants along the way. A well-preserved historic part of the city!

historic with modern facilities. Came in on a cruise and had the day on shore so we wondered around Circular Quay. .literally within minutes of off loading the cruise ship we were in the rocks. To see Sydney as it was when it first started is facinating to say the lease when in some back alleys it still had the smells of urine and th elikes. It cannnot be more authentic than that!!!Other than that the shops were well prsented although a bit pricey for souveniers however the food shops were really all VERY reasonablelbe... coffee latte around $3.5 to $4, cakes from $5 and burger at under$10!!!!The best coffe and cake/chocolates was right outside the entrance to the cruise harbour at Gurlaines, but right next door is a French pastry shop , It was about 20% cheaper and had some great savories and desserts too!! Being a diabetic this was my call and we had morning tea at Gurlaines and Afternonn tea next door!!! Service was much better at Gurlaines but you pay for it. The french pastry shop was typically french service standards... a bit snobby!!!. But you don't pay for it!!!!Walking the cobble stone lanes and taking the bike tour was just perfect for our day out in the rocks but just a stone throw away at the other end of the harbour cove is the Sydney Opera house.
