We walked there and in the summer heat still very bearable with the sea breeze. We spend a bit of time there and it was well worth the extra distance we walked!!! The Sydney opera house may sound old fashion but is a truly manificient building and shape!!! Another must do for vissiting Sydney. A bit further on is the botanicall gardens. It looked really interesting but as time was pressing we did not venture on . We wanted to get up close and personal with the sydney Harbour Bridge.so off we went back to the other aside of the cove and past the rocks area. We were only 8 minute walk from the cruise ship and when we got underneath the bridge it was AWESOME, such large bolts and nuts to hold it all together. A giant meccano set. We went on to the bridge to see more and could have walked across the brides but chose not to as we were due back to the ship soon. But we did walk around the park where the old obeseavatory was . Well worth it as it was pleasant and seem like the natives both white and coloured Australians have a close afinity as there were people relaxing on the greens every where. Sooo pleasant and peacefull with the rumble of traffic crossing the harbour bridgeFor photo oppurtunist, the view from the bridge across to the water is great seeing the cove and opera house. From the opera house th eview is just as good seeing the harbour bridge.

Historical centre. The Rocks is the historical centre of Sydney where you will find a large number of historical buildings and alleyways preserved. In a picturesque position between the Harbour Bridge and Circular Quay it is worth visiting for a ramble among the old buildings during the daylight hours. Or if pubs, clubs and restaurants are more your scene then this is the place to come during the twilight hours.

Love The Rocks. You get that feeling that the first days of Sydney have truly been preserved, that you could almost touch the very beginning of this great nation. Many of the buildings have been retained and are now used for restaurants and local businesses. Spend a day, walk around, there is so much to see, taste and do !

Brilliant part of Sydney History. The Rocks is a must see on any trip to Sydney. While it is not old in European terms it is still the beginnings of the colonisation of Australia and gives you an insight into what Sydney looked and felt like after settlement. It also has real significance to the Aboriginal owners, so its a great location to visit. Go on the weekend to enjoy the markets. Good quality and resonably priced items to take home for family or enjoy. No tacky souveniers. Also on the weekend there live bands and good music supported by the Sydney Harbour Foreshore Authority. Lots of good places to eat and some market stall food as well. Take a tour around the area for more historical information. The Rocks is the cultural heart of Sydney. Get there from train to Circular Quay, bus to Circular Quay or ferry to Circular Quay. Also visit the Museum of Contemporary Art if you are interested in that world.

Fascinating and fun.. The Rocks is obviously an important area of Sydney being the home of the first settlers. It is fun to walk around and investigate the buildings, shops and the Saturday market. Their are also a lot of good restaurants to choose from making it a very lively place especially in the evenings. A guided walking tour of the area is also worth doing, if you want a deeper insight into the historical facts of Australia.

shoppers and boozers palce. you can find some good places to booze and shop, their is a haunted place here which is a good tourist attraction, its got a very nice view of the luna park and sydney bridge

Great place to wander. I dont get to wander the rocks often, as I'm in Sydney usually on business but everytime I do, I find something new. If your a visitor to Sydney you must go to the rocks for both the history and the food. Restaurants and pubs are everywhere and seafood places particularly brilliant.

Nothing to rave about. To be honest I dont know what all the fuss is about , there are so many great things in Sydney the rock is nice but I dont know that I would make the effort if my schedule was tight, Darling Harbour would come first

Fascinating area. Well worth a visit if you have time but make sure you get a real sense of its history before you go there otherwise you may find it doesn't make a lot of sense! Interesting and diverse area and well worth visiting the small museum [forgive me forgotten its name!] that doesn't charge but asks for voluntary contributions. Gives you a real sense of its aboriginal routes and the activities of the transported individuals that realy built their wealth and reputations there after departing the UK on slightly less than positive terms!! A great story and an area that has great hotels, great food, great atmosphere and great history.
Great shopping area. Fun just to walk about the Rocks area. We happen to be there when they were having a fair. Lots of cute items and mingling with the people.
Great area. I love this area of Sydney! A fantatsic vibe and so much history. The markets held here are a must visit

A Real Piece of History. Great spot for the family or the history buff. Make sure you visit the Visitors Centre for maps and directions. So much to see - museums, harbour views and shopping. Can involve a fair bit of walking so wear comfortable shoes. Lots of great eateries and pubs around!

Good for a pass through stroll while seeing the Opera House. Our I'm Free walking tour took us through The Rocks. Neat history and winding alleys, but nothing impressive. It's okay if you miss it if you have limited time. There is a museum you can visit if you're so inclined.
The Colonial Past. The area is changing, all for the better. A few sandstone monuments set up along the paths to remind us of the colonial past are very interesting.

OK but not as good as The Lanes in Brighton. The Rocks were described to us as being the equivalent of The Lanes in Brighton (UK) - they aren't. The weekend market is ok, but the whole thing is a bit small and is certainly not a 'must see' destination
So Much to do!. The rocks is great place for drinks and dinner especially before a show at the opera house. There is a free walking tour at 6pm, not to be missed!

Get out of the main streets!. This is a tourist trap, but it is worth wandering off into side streets, perfectly safe by day. Any establishment that is open, away from the main drag, can only survive by being good. Best of all: find the Wharf Theatre in Hickson Road, go right to the far end, and try the tapas-style food down there. It is fairly quite until just before 6, when the mobs arrive. I rate them excellent for service, for food and for drink.
Great area to walk around. Spend half a day in the Rocks, so much to see, great weekend market, well recommend it. Lovely cafes and places to have a drink
History on Foot. It is great spending hours exploring the alleys of The Rocks. Photographers note that there's always something around the corner that dates from Australia's early beginnings.

Good for a stroll.. Something to do while waiting for a ferry if you've been around the Opera House. It is a very pleasant stroll but quite overrated compared to places like Battery Point in Hobart or anywhere in Europe. They have an OK market there if you have forgotten to buy presents.
Nice area to walk and shop. Nice little area,to,walk around - great alternate view of the opera house and cute little shops - lots of souvenir shopping too

Beautiful Area. We had such a good tiime here. A plethora of wonderful restaraunts, galleries, shops and coffeehouses!!! And, the architecture alone, was worth the walk through this area. Have comfortable shoes. Lots of uphill walking and cobblestones here...

A great bit of history and some good shops. I spent 3-4 hours showing my wife around the Rocks recently. There was plenty of parking on the western end of Argyle street and it was very pleasant walking along Lower Fort Street under the southern pylon of the Sydney Harbour Bridge to look at the lovely old convict-carved sandstone blocks, and then around lower George street looking at all the lovely old buildings. There were many little side streets, all of significant historical interest, with numerous plaques on walls or footpaths pointing these out. There were also many tourist shops, some of which sold items that were certainly not the everyday tourist souvenirs that you expect to find. It's worth the time to look around as you often find the most amazing little shops run by helpful, enthusiastic shopkeepers and their staff. Their are many places to eat so you'll never have to worry about finding somewhere to eat. Thoroughly recommended!

plenty of history, atmosphere and things to do. As the place where our convict history began, I love the old buildings, the cobbled streets, the pubs and the stories behind them. A few of my favourite places in the Rocks include Susannah Place, Foundation Park, Observatory Hill, The Garrison Church and amongst the pubs I love the recently refurbed Glenmore, The Hero of Waterloo, The Australian, The Lord Nelson and Hart's. To get a good overview of the Rocks a walking tour is a must and the best from my experience is from The Rocks Walking Tours. I have been on several others that are entertaining but without the background depth of knowledge.The Rocks Discovery Museum is also a great place to visit especially if the weather is not so great.
oldest and coolest. the rocks is the oldest area in Sydney and is packed with bars and lovely cafes. there is a market on weekends there, and street events on occasions.

Great Historic Area of Sydney. Take this one in after you've walked around Circular Quay.The souvenir shops are not too bad and the bars and restaurants should please many tastes.If you a ready for a pub lunch then walk all the way up Argylle Street to the Lord Nelson Hotel and after that walk along level Kent Street to the back entrance of Wynyard Station.
Best area in Sydney. Walking around in the Rocks, you get a true Sydney experience, the restaurants, the streets, the shops all come together to give you a unique neighbourhood experience.

Always something happening. Whether its on a weekend or evening, lots of things to see and visit, like museums, restaurants, pubs and markets. It is the old historical centre for the port of Sydney and you can download a free MP3 audio walking tour of this area which I thorough recommend. A lovely area to spend time!
History meets modern fun. Great walk around the historic part of the city, but it is newly updated with nice shops and restaurants. Good place for lunch and a scenic walk.

Beautiful Old Architecture. We went twice to the Rocks and one time were there as their week-end market was opening. It was a lot of fun with a lot of bargains. The Rocks area has many beautiful old buildings turned into charming shops and restaurants and is an easy area to ealk and explore.
Hidden Stories..... You wont know its real spookiness behind all the nice restaurants, just walk around and get lost around the hidden alleyways and find many places to get a coffee like a local

Cool Market on Sat and Sun. We stayed in the Rocks at the Russell Hotel and WIne bar. The area is close to everything including the Harbour, transit, Opera House and shops. The area itself celebrates the history of Sydney and is where the first settlement was. There is a unique and amazing market on Saturday and Sundays, don't miss it!
Markets and Mellowness. Great street market - and historic atmosphere. Try the pubs, cafes and restaurants before settling in for the night with a little live music!

Historic Sydney. A lovely place to wonder around, with little laneways and hidden stairs to discover. Right in the middle of everything- we were there between walking over the Harbour Bridge and visiting the Museum of Contemporary Art. The took the ferry from Circular Quay afterwards- a beautiful way to finish our day!
The markets. Loved walking the cobble streets and seeing everyone out and about. Disliked nothing. Loved everything!

Nice to See but nothing outstanding. Some quaint builidings and pubs with shopping. Market is on certain days but not whilst we were down that end of town. Right next to the Ferry Terminal and also where the Big Liners dock.

IT'S WHAT THEY SAY TO DO. A visit to the Rocks is recommended in many sources, but it wasn't my favorite thing to do. We ended up having lunch at the Loewenbrau and that was satisfactory. I had expected to experience much more of the atmosphere of prisoners lives, but maybe I was looking for the wrong thing. The photographer, always with an eye out for interesting things, did get some good photos.My conclusion: we should have taken a tour.

Upmarket!. Great market at weekends with everything from lollipops to necklaces made from very old watches.
A must for something for yourself or a gift to take back to the U.K.
loved spending time here whilst on holiday in Sydney.
Oh, and plenty places to eat and drink.
My Favourite area in Sydney. I love expolirng this area it is old and beautiful and you would be surpirsed at what you find, worth visiting.

Trinkets everywhere. The rocks has a lovely market to visit on the weekend. You can buy gifts for yourself or people back home. Some of these are a little pricey and you'd pay less if you got them at some of the other lesser known markets.

A Must-See Are While Visiting Sydney. In September 2012 a friend and I visited Sydney, with a highlight being The Rocks area. We found Opal Minded Jewelery where, on 3 separate visits, we bought 4 opal necklaces for our daughters-in-law back home. Across the street is Baroque, a french bistro, where we enjoyed delicious macarons, and on more than one occasion! Make sure to be in the area on Rocks Market days too, lots of great shopping and eating-on-the-run done there. We meandered through the area and found some fabulous architecture, and photographed the Harbor Bridge from some awesome angles.

Bars, clubs, and a great atmosphere. Where to begin... on weekends you'll find these nice little stalls opening up alongside Circular Quay where you'll find everything from little jars of marmalade to exotic necklaces and items of clothing being sold by regular people. Then there is the wide variety of food outlets and places to grab a feed or a drink. Everything from Japanese through to pancakes can be bought, and if you're up for a bit of dancing, there are a couple of clubs on the Rocks as well which'll allow you to kick up your heels and have a great time!Best days to go are on sunny Sunday afternoons. Not so much of a crowd compared to Saturdays.

wander the back lanes for a sense of history. also head up through the Argyle Cut to Argyle Place and past the terraces in Millers Point under The Bridge, or up to Observatory Hill Park. Recommend a climb up the South Plyon on The Bridge inside. Cost 10% of Bridge Climb. 60% of the view..

Tourist trap. Simply an artificial part of the city where you only see tourists, artificial buildings, overpriced restaurants, pseudo Art galleries. Darling harbour is touristy, too, but much better -- at least does not pretend to be authentic.

Choices. The Rocks was a great area, we first went to the market and purchased some great buys. A dog lead and collar, some baby grows, a hat. Lunch at the market was a wrap - yummy. Evening walks lovely here and we ate at Sake - OMG! Not cheap but excellent Japanese food.
rocking on the rocks. Fantastic place to vist when in Sydney plenty of eating and watering place . The little side streets are hidden gems and the walk back to the Quays along the river a dream

A piece of history. There are several pubs claiming to be the oldest in Sydney. Each one has a great sense of history and are,indeed, very old. There many unique ships and lots of great restaurants and cafes in the Rocks.

Great walk in Sydney's oldest neighborhood. The Rocks is a charming neighborhood, underneath the Sydney Harbour bridge. Sydney's oldest houses, boutiques, restaurants, galleries, pubs and of course the markets. We visited the Rocks market which is filled with clothes and jewellery stalls, Sydney memorabilia and indigenous artifacts and everything small or large one can find in a market. A must see in Sydney.
An absolute must-see. You get Australia's history here and you are left speechless when you see the trajectory of progress.
historical area of the city. Always enjoy a visit to the Rocks. Food wonderful whether you use a cafe or one of the many restuarants and pubs. Always lots of interesting happenings here!

Great shopping with an historical twist. We visited the Saturday morning market as well as generally strolling around the fancy shops on George Street. We liked the Nurses' walk too and the cafes there. Well worth a look on your Sydney visit.
It's so very different from my first visit in 1983.

Lovely afternoon stroll. The Rocks is a great place to have a bite to eat and an afternoon stroll. Try and visit the area when the Friday Foodies Market is on or one of the night markets. They are fantastic!

A bit of history in Sydney. The rocks is great place to stay whilst visiting Sydney, it is far more relaxed that the main center of the city. The area has some old pubs and a good selection of restaurants. It is very close circular quay with it good links to the rest ogf the area. The rocks has some interesting old buildings, when we were there ther was a free walking tour in the evening, if you see this advertised be sure to go along

A great place to shop. If your are in Sydney on Sunday, be sure to visit The Rocks. There is one big long flea market in the street and goes for many blocks. The stores in the area are also open at the same time. A really fun activity, as well as good buys.
a must see. weekend market is worthwhile experience with lots of authentic hand made articles at fair prices . Also wonderful gallaries & restaurants to visit at all price levels

The Rocks. Like to go here because, there are many thigs you can do , see and enjoy..for me, the weekend market fair is lovely..the walking on many streets with many small shops around to see and in the night you can enjoy a good night out in many eateries and have music with drinks in pubs around the The Rocks..

It's busy and can be expensive. We wandered around the market on the Saturday before Christmas and it was packed. To be honest, I'm not sure what I was expecting but on reflection the mixture of tourist stuff that's on offer shouldn't have been a surprise. There's an Irish pub there and they had live music but the price of beer is so high that you might want to hang around outside to listen to the music. The Rocks as an area is much bigger than I expected and many of the buildings are difficult to identify. In reality it's probably one of those places that you need to go to because you can't go to Sydney and not go to The Rocks, but I wouldn't bother to spend much time there.

Great part of Sydney. This is the old part of Sydney and well worth walking around. There is a market here on each Saturday and Sunday where many local wares are sold. Very relaxing to walk through with plenty of pubs, bars and cafes in old houses.
Beautiful history. I love the Rocks area. There is so much history there and I just love casually strolling around the area. The markets are great on the weekend also. Beautiful place!

The best neighborhood in Sydney. We are so glad that our travel agent booked us in a hotel near this neighborhood. Thank goodness for the people who decided to fight to keep this quaint area from being demolished decades ago. It is now a charming, albeit somewhat gentrified, area with nice restaurants, pubs, museums, and shops. The best part for us was that we were very comfortable there as a family even when walking through the side streets in the evening.
busy busy busy. Thought is was going to be a trashy tourist trap but wasn't - OK it was touristy but there was a lot of locals there too. Great choice of restaurants.

Old historic district- quaint and lively. Take a walk up to Lord Nelson' pub an hotel. you pass old houses and see the town how it used to be. Argyle street is where the main "action" is-- cafes, pubs ect. closet to cars. The only negative is--n not much is open past midnight
The Rocks rock!. I love the rocks - little places to grab something to eat and the best views of the opera house. Shopping is also everywhere but make sure you park within your time limits.

Rocks. I lvoe the Rocks late afternoon and night and often take accomodation down the area the base of George Street. Remember this is where our Royalty & Hilary Clinton choose to shop when visiting Sydney so it must be magical...don't miss, have a grat pub meal.
A good place to visit. Lots to see and do here - very historic and some excellent restaurants.Nice near the harbor foreshores.
nice to walk around especially on weekends. don't miss the street markets.... nice interesting objects... not really a lot of bargains...or any really .... it's for us the tourists.... fun!

Perfect location, cool restaurants and shops. Loved the markets and shops. There is a great atmosphere around the rocks and surprises round every corner. On one street there is an archaeological dig and on another there' s an old style hardware shop . Loved this place!

Saturday market. Had fun at the last Saturday market before Christmas, and even
had a bit of whimsy with a psychic reading, lol. Lots of interesting and unique items, and well worth a look around. And with all the bars/restaurants around, there are plenty of places to
rest and rehydrate if needed
Interesting. I have too much expectation before I come. There are many interesting stuff in the stalls but the price range are quite high.

Was There To Celebrate NYE 2013! :D. I was just about to leave Circular Quay after a tour when I decided to walk a bit - it was 6.00 pm ish and I didn't know I was walking into The Rocks area until I saw the signage :D I love the buildings there. Along with hundreds of other people, I walked from The Rocks along George Street to Central Station after the 9.00 pm NYE 2013 fireworks and it was nice. The street looked even more interesting at night :D The next morning, I walked to The Rocks again with a friend this time. And I was really impressed to see how clean The Rocks was again in less than 12 hours after the NYE celebration there (it wasn't like it was dirty the night before by the way). :D
Lovely area. Quaint shops, cafes, market on weekend was worth it with lots of unique items for sale. Take time to wander the back streets. Woollies was great for new year and worth the 300 dollars!

Love the Rocks!!!. Can't get enough od th rocks love all the history sights an sounds. went to the Rocks Markets all expensive but purchased some yummy creamed hiney and jams and fished with counter lunch at a pub.

nice little area to walk around if visiting for the first time.. this is one area i wouldn't care if i missed the next time i visit sydney. nothing really stands out from my time at the rock minus the museum of contemporary arts.

Atmosphere great in the evenings. Take the time to stroll around after you dine out in the area. Some evenings there are markets on with all sorts of great things on offer. Great food stalls and I found some amazing handmade chocolates which I bought as gifts for home. Evenings are buzzing and if it is warm most people are taking their time and wandering.
Historic Rocks. Full of history, great restaurants and galleries. Check out the markets. have a beer at one of the old pubs. Do the Ghost tour - very spooky, historic and interesting.
Especially nice on weekends. Lovely area to stroll around anyway, but check out the market on Saturdays and Sundays for an even nicer afternoon in town.
Friendly. Nice to walk in, you have restaurants and bars, pedestrian streets and nice heritage buildings.Not far from the city center and circular quay.

Weekend market in the Rocks. Pleasant hour or so wandering through the Rocks and browsing the weekend markets. Some stuff you can get cheaper at Paddy's Markets but the Rocks is the more pleasant of the two.

Wished there was a little better signage.. We headed to The Rocks for lunch, and settled on a little hole in the wall, as we didn't really find much, and were getting really hungry. After lunch we wandered some more, and found a bunch more restaurants. We stopped in at the Museum, and it was very interesting to learn the history of The Rocks. Take the time to watch the 4 or so short films upstairs. We are very glad to see this part of historic Sydney preserved. There are many beautiful heritage buildings in this area.

fascinating. it's always surprizing to go there and see our history. it is very upmarket with markets and many restaurants and bars. walk around and get the feel of the place. there is always something happening there. then go to the Orient Hotel for a drink which is very near the water.
walk the rocks.. talk a walk to the rocks during evening,so beautiful view,color,enjoy the food around that area.you can see the scenery is to wonderful,

Market is fab!. I loved the market. You can wander around it for ages without becoming bored. I also found everything most reasonably priced. A lovely area with lots of quaint cafes, bars and streets to enjoy. Also visited the free museum which was excellent.

Great Area. This is a fantastic area of Sydney. My fiance and I stayed here in November 2012 and loved it. As the oldest part of Sydney it's full of history and cool buildings. It's relation to Circular Quay is nearly unbeatable as our hotel was 5 minutes walk from it. If you're looking for a cozy, older looking place to stay that's close to it all this is where you want to be.
Good to wander round and soak up the history. Very touristy but you can find some great historic sites and there are awesome views of the harbour, bridge & opera house.
Slightly disappointing. The guides all made this sound like the place to go but the resaurants were all out of our price range and there was nothing of any real interest.
Atmosphere and history. The most historic part of Sydney and my favourite. History, architecture and great pubs. You can tell that it was founded by the British.

Christms Visit. Was incredibly hot, very busy with Chritmas rush, but wonderful none the less. Purchased some fresh watermelon from the markets and sat under a tree beside the harbour watching the people go by. A couple were playing musical instruments, cruise ship was in, great little interlude.
love this funky area. Its such a great place to wander through and grab a bite. Don't forget the Saturday markets, everything from nice snacks to signed movie memorabilia is on sale!
Best Part of Sydney. The rocks actually feel like there is some heart to Sydney. Sydney is so sprawling and the CBD is a bit clinical, so finding somewhere with history and character is a real joy

worth a look if you happen upon it. This place is ok but i personally wouldn't make a special effort to see it. Mainly tacky gift shops and people selling tat. If you happen to be walking through then ok, but don't go out of your way to go there.

Great place to explore. We drank at the Lord Nelson pub which make there own real ale beers and cider. Quiet on Monday evening but a lovely building and atmosphere. Walk to the Opera House for a performance through the Rocks and it has a wonderful old world charm about the area.

The Rocks Rocks!!!. The Rocks does rock!! So many great pubs and restaurants to duck into. There is also a market on the weekends so make sure you do that if you're there over a weekend. Lots of great artists bring their work in. From clothing to glass works, ornaments, etc. And to shop after having a brew makes it easier to let go of some cash! :)

Old Sydney. You could wander around here for ages, the markets are great especially the food variations. It's a taste of the original Sydney that's appears to have been fairly well preserved. Hard to imagine when there is a massive cruise liner parked at the end of the road about 200m away.

Bustling Area. The markets are fantastic filled with vendors that have a great array of offerings all that are well priced.The food stalls are wonderful with so many choices and good value for money. There are many things to look at so allow at least a couple of hours to meander through

Great Shopping. Take a few hours on a Saturday morning to visit the Rocks and enjoy shopping and Aussie culture. Loads of crafts and unique art await you along with great food, drink, and sunshine. I found it to be safe and clean, somewhat upscale but comfortable. The merchants are fair and friendly. I found a guy who makes cufflinks from watch movements and another vendor selling ornaments. There is also a great selection of jewelry, and items made from kangaroo bits. It's a greta way to spend the morning.

Sydney's Origins. Good old pubs and restaurants..where Sydney started...bit of tourist ripoff territory-but you can find some good value if you search the backstreets for the " Hero of Waterloo or' Lord Nelson" pubs....walk under the Bridge ....look at or touch the nuts and bolts that secure this massive structure...I go there often
Good Selection of Stalls. We had a great time mingling around the gift stalls and food stalls - good quality items at reasonable prices
Rocks has everything. This area has shops, bakeries, bars and restaurants everywhere. It is the perfect place to stay or just visit. Don't miss all of the narrow alleys and the cafes hidden ther.

Up and down around the Rocks. We loved this area as there is a lot of history here to see and good restaurants too. Hard on those who are not fit and able as it is, as the name suggests, up and down hills.

Historic spot with interesting shops and markets. The Rocks is another historically rich area of Sydney so close to many tourist attractions. There are many interesting shops, walkways and eateries. The harbour views surrounding the Rocks make it a special place too. Worth a couple of visits!
A great walkabout.... The Saturday festival. Great place to buy funky clothes. The 100 year old pubs in the northern part of the rocks.

Old Sydney. The Rocks is the oldest part of Sydney and is an interesting rabbit warren of narrow streets and old buildings with bars cafes and guest-houses. Its an easy stroll from Circular Quay which it abutts.

architecture mildly ok, but overrun by tourists and often by drunks. Supposedly very historic, and up to a few years ago, the history dominated the scene. However it has been progressively commercialised and tourist-oriented, so that the historic character has been largely subsumed into just another tourist trap. Moreover on some nights, the drunks and other antisocial types start running amok, so there may be a spectator sport of watching police deal with the idiots but it's not a recommended environment. Its proximity to Circular Quay, the harbour bridge and the CBD make it a natural part of tourist movement, but you'll need to visualise what it once was rather than admiring its present status.
Rocks. Great Markets, bit pricey but good variety. Definitly worth a visit. Restaurants ok not as good as Darling Harbour
Charming. Lovely to walk around the weekend market or stop for a drink and a meal in some of the restaurants. Spent New Years Eve here too - great time
Enjoyable historic district. The Rocks is the heart of old Sydney, and thankfully was saved from the wreckers ball. Just a delightful neighborhood with many lovely little eateries and pubs.

It's only alive during weekends.. As said, during weekdays, there ain't much activities going around, so the best time to visit The Rocks will be the weekends. There's a good mix of everything, from excellent street performances, to good food outlets, and not forgetting the unique shopping experience. However, one thing to note for bargain hunters: selling price of souvenirs, which may be readily available in other parts of Sydney, are higher. So if you wanna get those tourists souvenirs, it'll be best to get them in places like, say, Paddy's Market in Chinatown.

Over-crowded and full of schlock. It's where the city started, so interesting from that point of view, and some of the architecture is good, but there's lots of over-priced shops selling kitsch, and ordinary restaurants, and dreadful fast-food shops. It's worth a walk past the architecture , but I wouldn't shop or eat there, except at a few excellent places, like Sake, Sailors Thai or Rockpool. If you find yourself there, walk along by the water to the Quay and on to the Botannic Gardens.
very quaint. the little shops and cafes in and around the rocks are great to get into. can feel the life and the people there are very friendly

Sandstone and quaint pubs. We dropped into the old Ivanhor Pub and there was a Jazz band playing.The lady on the horn and sax was 85 yr old!! Downstairs is an old tunnel to the wharf where they would drop the drunken sailors down so they could get back to their ship.The multicultural waiters will show you!
History!. A great place to see some fantastically-preserved colonial architecture from early Australia, back in the convict era. This are is well worth exploring.
Stunning. Beautiful. The architecture is amazing, I wasnt expecting to see a man made area so beautiful in Australia.
A few beers at The Rocks. We did a mini pub crawl, about pubs, and a feed at an Italian Restaurant. Could have spent more time here. Will definitely have to go back
Overtouristed but still worth a visit.. The main road is just touristville but get into the back street and you can imagine Sydney as it was when the first flet landed.

Doesn't look historical.... Okay, the place is like 200 odd years old. Doesn't feel very "historical". The story about the architect who built it was interesting though. He was a convict turned high contributor to the community.Do not recommend this place to anyone who is looking for an epic history tour.
Evening Walk. We went on a evening tour conducted by a volunteer lady,Enjoyed by most in the group,The downside was not ending the tour at the start point.

18th century feel. The rocks are great.Nice old buildings with great little pubs on every corner.Has kept its old school feel without becoming to modernized.Saturday Markets are always great to visit, plenty of little things Australian which are great for gifts.
Very atmospheric. Excellent to have a look round and reminds me of London's Hoxton Square, trendy types seem to concregate there. Some nice bars and interesting shops

Favorite part of town. This was our favorite part of town when we visited Sydney. We went here 3 of the 4 nights we were in town.
Great pubs and restaurants!

The Rocks -- rocks. The best part of travelling through Sydney is The Rocks. The vibe is fantastic, the pubs are awesome and the restaurants can't be beat. besides, there is something to do in The Rocks almost every night, but especially heading into the weekend. Definately my favorite part of travelling to Australia.
Quaint and Interesting. Nice to look around, lots of boutique shops, cafes and restaurants and a small market. Lots of history.

A MUST BE DONE TOUR. The ROCKS is a tour that everyone who visits Australia MUST do. It’s a MUST too for the locals. I have been to Australia a few times and after doing the Rocks, it has help me understood Australia better; it's history, the people and the important role the indigenous people played over the years and I am happy to say that my ancestors lived similar lives and very admirable. It’s amazing how every story has a strong connection to Mother Nature. A lot of people say even a few friends of mine say that if you have not been to Kings Cross, you haven’t been to Sydney ….... but I would say to those visiting Sydney, if you don’t do the Rock tour, you have NOT BEEN to Sydney!! It’s a must to know Australia!!!

I love and Hate the Rocks. I love it due to its historical meaning to this town. At some points it really is like stepping back in time. gorgeous little alleyways and endless stairs with amazing views of the harbour truly paint a picture of 1920 Sydney. - But i hate how touristy it is!! everything is Sooo Fake and all the shops are geared toward the type of traveller that has only heard of Australia through Crocodile Dundee's movies. I like to compare it to a really hot girl dumbing herself down for attention.
Good. There is a very good place. It has got a cute bazaar, you should see it. You can drink good wine and eat delicious calamari. You should go there!

Step back in time. Great way to visit and discover the time that was in sydney. Recommend taking a history tour to see the hidden past or wandering in the shops and looking at what Sydney has to offer

Disappointing. 21 years ago we visited The Rocks and only had half a day to see it. We really felt disadvantaged because there was so much to see and do. 21 years later everything is geared to income and a short sight seeing trips that may last 1-2 hours. The whole experience was overly commercial.
nice area. watch them doing the bridge climb,also go across to darling harbour ,really good shops and restaurants in this area
Historical. Great place to experience the Historical buildings of the Rocks. Great Shops, Cafe's, Restaurants, Pubs to enjoy. Markets at weekends.

A stroll back in time. The Rocks is a great place to stroll the narrow streets and admire the historic buildings and at the same time enjoy the spectacular views of the bridge, the opera house and the harbour.
An easy walk from Circular Quay.

Rocks shopping.. The Rocks is a cute shopping area, which has lots of quirky shops, with market stalls, which feature locally made items, which you won't find in other shops. Look out for the Irish tea rooms which serves delicious home made scones and afternoon teas. The scones are massive!!!! Again, not cheap, be prepared to pay high prices even for drinks.

Worth the Climb. Walking through the Rocks District is a step back into history and worth it even if your calves are sore the next day. Be sure to stop at the pub -- have a pint and move on. On Saturdays, there are brides everywhere snapping photos.

The Rocks is a vibrant fun place bursting with life.. The Rocks is a great place to eat drink and shop. There is a market there every Sunday. The market is full of crafts, clothes and jewellery. Fabulous place, well worth a visit.
I loved it all, didn't dislike any of it.

The Rocks - an historic ramble through old Sydney. If you like strolling through historic backstreets then this is for you. The Rocks has plenty of colonial buildings to look at and there is a good self walking tour available from the Visitors' Centre. I would recommend that. When you get tired there are plenty of places to eat and drink and the place comes alive at night, especially at weekends. Highly recommended.
Lovely!. Lovely restaurants, great art gallery, fantastic market. What more can be said, it is what it is and it rocks!
Nice little place. Bars, cafe's, shops - very oldie world - the markets at the weekends are lovely to look around. Different foods & gifts. Old with the new.

Unmissable!. I have been to Sydney many times over the last 30 years. Two things I always do, take the ferry to Manly and walk The Rocks. The last time we actually stayed in The Rocks at the YHA. I knew about the weekend markets, however, the live entertainment was something new from my last visit. Exciting, if not exhilarating, there is always something different about it every time I visit.I am going to Sydney for a short break through New Years and will again be staying at The Rocks. There are so many small shops which sell food at reasonable prices, there is no need to go to one of the high-end restaurants near the water, although I have done so. But then I wasn't paying.

Excellent Friday evening markets and entertainment til xmas. Really enjoyed the current Friday markets. Suitable for most ages and abilities. Pity taxi drivers weren't aware it was on as we nearly didn't go down on one's advice.

No trip to Sydney is complete without a visit to The Rocks. I took two visits to the Rocks during my last Sydney visit, first to have lunch with friends and later to revisit some recommended sights. The first visit was on a Saturday when the craft markets were in full swing, and it was delightful to wander amongst the stalls before we stopped for lunch. The second visit was an afternoon in which I had more time to wander around. I visited Susannah Place, the Big Dig, the Discovery Museum, a couple of pubs with el fresco dining, and the visitor center. Walked along the Gloucester Walk to marvel at the Argyle Tunnel that was dug by convict labour. Don't listen to anybody who tells you that The Rocks is only interesting for shoppers, as it has so much more to offer than that!

Lovely walk through beautiful streets. Spent a lovely morning wandering through the streets of The Rocks with friends. Enjoyed a free exhibit about the area's past and stopped at La Renaissance Patisserie in Argyle for a macaron - had been there previously for a salted caramel that was memorable and this time delighted in a pistachio.
Good if you like shopping. We walked around the Rocks but we aren't into shopping that much. If you were it would be a little paradise....
Historical quarters. Interesting part of town where a lot of convicts lived in the early days. Some interesting buildings and pubs left that are worth a visit.
Fun Place. Neat little area of Sydney. There are a lot of hills, so be prepared. This is where Lord Nelson's brewery is. We walked from the brewery to the bridge and it was super easy.

Tourist central. Probably the highest concentration of tourists in Australia. Yes its the gateway to the Harbour Bridge and Opera House - but the restaurants are all overpriced and its always busy. Recommend that you just pass through it en-route to somewhere else, and eat further afield - like in Surry Hills or Darlinghurst.
Rocks. The rocks rock, great food and good sights, I enjoyed a traditional german pork knuckle, the crackling was the best of my life

Heart of the city - don't miss it. The Rocks is the oldest section of Sydney and sits right next to Circular Quay where all of the ferry activity takes place. Wander the back alleys of The Rocks for some interesting shops and restaurants. Murals and old photos give some history of this first area of settlement. There is a nice market on Saturdays and Sundays - worth a visit. Hard to imagine visiting Sydney without spending at least one afternoon here.
The historic Sydney Rocks. The rocks has some of the best cafes and bars in Sydney. The historic buildingds are treasures of Sydneys past. Also has a great market on Sundays with masses of stalls
Many stairs. You have to be in good condition for all the stairs and know the sneak routes but it is a great area to explore and with nice shops and markets.

Awesome Eatery. The rocks offers some amazing unique souvenirs especially on the Sunday Rock Market. Find amazing arts, hand made crafts, where you would never find anywhere else in the world. There are also amazing eatery places as well as coffee places here at the Rocks.

Finally some culture. The Rocks were a really nice place, with authentic buildings and nice views over the habour. Also the people and the whole atmosphere is a lot more relaxed. If you are in Sydney it's a must-do.

Love The Rocks. Any visit to Sydney should include a walk around The Rocks. Centrally located nearby the Opera House, Sydney Harbour Bridge, Circular Quay and the City centre, The Rocks is alive with a vibrant atmosphere. There are many restaurants and pubs to enjoy, and on the weekend there is a craft market that is very popular. Take the time to wander around the many little streets and you will find some hidden treasures. We also found that the breakfast / brunch offered at many cafes was very reasonably priced compared to other parts of the city Well worth a few hours to walk around!

Rock Market Rocks. Head to the Saturday or Sunday market and you will find all sorts of items on display. I personally like art-y stuffs so I found the market very interesting. Prices are mostly fixed but you will get some good buy if you take the time to look beyond the crowded stalls. If you do not intend to spend at all, it is still a great place to chat up with the locals and get to know the place better. They are a friendly bunch.

Great for a nice walk around. W spent Friday evening and Saturday morning strolling around the rocks. There are some interesting markets and shops around if you are looking to buy something a little different
Love the place. Thanks to the residents that petition against the Rocks redevelopment. There's so much character in the area with it's charming little alleys - can't get enough of it.
The Rocks - Sydney. Cosmopolitan yet with a fascinating history. Beautiful buildings, trendy bars and old style pubs. Try the Orient for dancing to 90s music or the Argyle for a quiet drink.

Interesting and exciting. A something truly Australian. Wonderful sights, amazing buildings and market which full of Australian-made souvenirs. The Rock market is strongly recommended as the best place to buy souvenirs.
The Rocks. Busy and bustling, good to see some of the same shops were still there like the Pancake at the Rocks restaurant and to see the ships was wonderful. Restaurants over-rated

The Rocks. A great area of Sydney. Unreal views of the bridge. This is where the cruise ships dock and people just seem to slow down and chill out. Great restaurants, takeaways and coffee shops but beware of the seagulls, they're master thieves....

Stay here if you're staying in Sydney!. It's a perfect location - I picked it just based on reading information, but, after touring through other Sydney areas like Darling Harbour and downtown, I am even more sure it is the best place to be - accessible to great attractions, either by walking or going to the Circular Quay and picking up some sort of train, bus or ferry. Very quirky neighborhood with lots to see, do and eat! Oh, and watch cruise ships!

Old Australia. Cobble stoned streets, changing wharf line, antiques, amazing food, museums, galleries, the new with the old.I'd prefer more original streets (as they were), but the history is ever-present. This is where it startedDC

Busy and touristy. The Rocks is a great part of Sydney. It was really bustling when we visited as there was a cruise-ship in. The markets were very crowded and full of lots of stuff - none of which interested me much! Lots of places to eat and a great atmosphere.
Great History. It is great to walk round here and see the history, unless you like crowds avoid the weekend markets.

Overrated as a tourist stop. The best thing about The Rocks is the Tourist Information site on Argyle...what a great store! They didn't have all the answers (in fact, she had to Google answers to my two questions, and I still didn't feel like I got what I was after). She was, however, very cheerful and friendly, providing maps and such. The parts of The Rocks we saw looked a little trashy, and I don't recommend straying far from the main areas.

The oldest part of the city. The oldest part of the city but is one of the most interesting with lots of cafe's studios,neat shops and a few of the nicest bars in the city. It is located just at the back of the cruise ship dock.

Holiday in own backyard. Have lived in Sydney for over 30 years and despite having walked across the Sydney Harbour Bridge many, many times, I have never ventured into the Observatory Hill precinct. Alighting the train at Milsons Point and walking across the bridge is without a doubt a MUST DO for all visitors to Sydney for our harbour is something superb that one never tires of. But when you get to the south side, instead of veering left onto the Opera House side, follow the signs to Observatory Hill and you are in for a sightseeing gem of the bridge. The park has great space for kids to run around in and there is a little play equipment. During school holidays there are children's activities at the Observatory but you need to book. We walked down to look over Barangaroo and down to The Lord Nelson Brewery Hotel where we had a refreshing drink. It was lovely. The restaurant looks appealing too. The bathrooms were up the stairs and impeccably maintained. Coming down the stairs the walls are filled with historic mariner items but what took my eye was First Fleeters names and we found our relatives, so made us feel really chuffed. We walked through to the Rocks enjoying all the little narrow streets and terraces that are being done up. The Rocks on Fridays was a gastrointestinal extravaganza. The information centre in Argyle Street had some great and reasonably priced gifts. We found Sydney Symphony opposite in the Clocktower and bought tickets and then walked up to St. Patricks Catholic Church Hill and went to mass. A wonderful day right in our own backyard. Just a note of warning, there is a lovely outdoor seating area behind the information centre but the seagulls are OVERLY FAMILIAR and will take your food before you blink, especially if you have sushi! Enjoy the ambience of the old Sydney.

The Rocks - Rocks!. If you're going to travel all the way to Sydney, why not spend some time in The Rocks area. For those familiar with New York City, it is both Wall Street and Fifth Avenue at the same time. It offers easy access to all Sydney Ferries, trains and busses to everywhere imaginable. But then again why would anyone want to leave this area with a multitude of restaurants, pubs, cafes, bars, shopping, you name it, for all tastes and budgets (if you are selective and willing to do your homework in advance). A definite place to see and be seen. The Rocks – rocks in its very own way, not as “wild” as Darling Harbor on a Friday evening and not as “gritty” as King Cross or as “free spirited” as Bondi Beach, but just the right amount of “laissez-faire” which leads me to conclude and have to admit that I cannot quite put my finger on it but The Rock has a certain amount of “je ne sais quoi…” which is really nice.

Fantastic Place. Full of culture, lovely architecture, amazing restaurants and bars. The Sunday Market is well worth a visit. The Friday foodies market is too.A very chilled out vibe in The Rocks but not pretentious in any way. The shops are great too.
Interesting visit to The Rocks.. Walked to the Rocks from quite a distance but since it was a market day it was worth it. Lots of shops to see as well.

Quiet Old Downtown area. The Rocks is worth visiting once to get a feeling of what Sydney downtown used to be before development took over. There are not many activities or shops in the area except for a few restaurants. The low rise buildings with their facade and which have been well maintained over the years is a plus point for the area.

The Rocks. Where Sydney began after the First Fleet landed in 1788. Historic buildings, just like stepping back in time.Visit Cadmans Cottage to find out about the National Park Harbour Islands tours.

Lively area with shops and bars. After taking the free, 90-minute walking tour of the Rock and learning some of the history and stories I wandered around on my own. I went on a Friday evening and there was a Friday market - I believe it was called 'Village Bizarre'. Quirky shops and welcoming bars and eateries abound and the street musicians added to the ambiance. Definitely worht a stroll.

market. enjoy the cultural over there~ specially many things over there u cant see at other place!thumb up!n there is one restaurant name "pancake on the rock"! the pancake there tasty too!!must try!!
always a good outing. Love going to the rocks, heaps to see and love the old pubs and buildings in the area, sends me back in time. love it

great atmosphere and markets. A great area, compact and easy to walk with interesting offshoots to explore. Friday and Saturday markets are fantastic. Next to the harbour and opera house areas it was our favourite place to wander.
A fun place to visit. A scenic and interesting mix of buildings, shops and restaurants under the Sydney Harbour Bridge. This is a neat place to spend a few tourist hours.
The Markets at the Rocks are Excellent. We love walking at the weekend markets. There is a lady that sells excellent home-made soap. I would buy them to send to my sister overseas!Great atmosphere.

great area for good food and drinks. The Rocks is a great areaof Sydney, right on the Harbour near the Bridge and overlooking the Opera House, excellent atmosphere in the bars and restaurants there, vibrant and throngs with people in the evenings, had a very nice meal in the Orient Hotel in the Rocks.well worth a visit

Unique area and so different from CBD. Hard to believe this area exists right next to high rises and circular quay but it is a funky, fun area with some great sidewalk cafes and old historic charm in the buildings.

A must see in Sydney. The Rocks is the oldest part of Sydney full of heritage buildings, little lanes and old pubs. Its great on the weekend as they have the markets there - one of few opportunities in Sydney to buy locally made gifts and souvenirs to take back home from Australia. I love the Guylian chocolate shop - a must in that area! Also, enjoy a pint of cold beer at Glenmore Hotel - with best view of the harbour (on their rooftop) and go to Bar100, a glamorous new bar with yummy and well priced food during the day and great parties at night (on the weekend)
plenty to do. great little collection of streets though some are a little rickety. fabulous market held here at the weekends where u can buy gifts and great prices.

Worth a visit. We stayed at the Rocks on our trip to Sydney. There are many cafes and resraunts at the area and as we were there when the Melbourne Cup was ran,many drunks.To be fair much of the day families are about but at late night it can be rowdyThe area had a poor reputation in the past but that makes it interesting to wander about and let the imagination take over.

Go on a Friday evening. Great area with a savage atmosphere. On a Friday night during the summer they have markets in the rocks which are gorgeous, have lots of yummy food and other treats, there are also bands that play and they are brilliant. That finishs up around 10pm then you shoudl go to the Irish bar the Mercantile for drinks or else hit up the Argyle for a more night out. Lowenbreu is also fab, German place with loads of different bears.

Lots of history. Lovely traditional area. If you're there at the weekend be sure to visit the market - loads of different goods available and well worth a visit. We bought a few sourvenirs from here. Also visit the Rocks Museum (it's free) and have a browse - tells you some history of Australia and Sydney.
Always worth a visit. Went back to the Sydney Market on a Sunday (it's every week), which I haven't done for years. It's always worth it, but The Rocks is great on any day.

The rocks at night - very vibrant. I have visited the Rocks a few times before but always in the day time. I did a walking tour after a few visits which I would highly recommend as they walk past and over so much history here without even knowing. ie the streets made by convicts, stories behind the street names. This time we visited in the evening and it was very party like atmosphere. We walked around and looked at some of the night time market stalls and then found somewhere to eat. We were a bit surprised by how few good cafes and restaurants were actually there and this explained the queues outside some of the better ones. We did find a well priced cafe to eat at and spent a lovely couple of hours eating and drinking at an outside table whilst watching the night life wander by.

Food and fun. A great place for an historic walk;harbour and Bridge vistas and lots of opportunities to eat well and watch the world go by.Just one of many wonderful locales in one of the world greatest cities!

Just great.. Here you get ferries to pretty much everywhere during the day and at night there are lots of beautiful restaurants to eat in. On a quiet evening, a walk round the area is stunning, with great views of the Opera House lit up. There are some neat pubs nearby too - we met some locals over beer and live music!

Very Touristic. I visited the Rocks last time in Sydney and thought I would try again. Although fine to walk through it really caters to the tourists with many gift shops and prices that go with it. Check it out since you are there but don't expect much.

walking down olden days. The sandstone buildings, cool and dark in the summer heat ~ takes me back to what is must have been like. This place has so many points of interest that it's important just to go and see for yourself.

Great atmosphere. Love it Love it, great place for wandering around, meeting friends having dinner, has it all really, reminds me a little of covent garden, without water of course but the atmosphere is great, defintely go there again
Yes, it's touristy but.... it's still a fun place to walk around. There are some nice bars and restaurants here (overpriced), and the scenery is charming.

The "heart" of Sydney. The views of the habour with the opera house in the background are great. Also some of the most historic buildings Australia are here. By sure to visit The Fortune of War, Sydney's longest licensed pub.

Old time sydney. Visited the rock on a weekend....Saturday to be precise...wonderful stalls with different craft and artefacts.....lots of stuff to see....maybe a tad pricey...but things were quite good...reminder of the old time sydney...lots of of food stalls...and. Food was great and quite cheap....wonderful day to spend a few hours on a bright sunny weekend afternoon in sydney before heading over to darling harbour for dinner....
Beautiful.... Awesome part of Sydney, so much history. We did the ghost tour of north warf, the weekend market,& Madame Tussaud's Wax Museum.
Historical Value. This area has so much history. The people on the weekend are everywhere. The markets are there on the weekend and offer many different products

Old Sydney. its the old part of Sydney and really nice great for walking around as long as a cruise ships not in as it obscures the view. A few interesting walks and facts and figures about the area are on plaques all around and a new museum of australian contemporary art has just opened

What a great surprise!!!!!. As I went to tour The Rocks I didn't have great expectations and just went there because it was indicated on my guide. It was one of the best decisions.... walking around is just great, it is a totally different atmosphere from the rest of Sydney, the small pubs and bars you can find in the middle of the old houses is something you shouldn't miss. Having lunch on the "patios" after walking all day among all that history is a great experience. Don't miss the museums, the history of the houses and the people who lived there.
The Rocks. This is another great place to walk around and see a little Australian history. The museum is open in the afternoon.
Fun place. Spent a Friday evening at the rocks - in November they have the markets and events all round the area - very entertaining.

The Oldest part of Sydney. Full of history and the best Harbor views. It's just a stretch about 1K long and 1/2k wide but it's packed with history, shopping, food, and art. Don't miss the weekend markets where you can get food, crafts, souvenirs, and pretty much anything else you can think of.

The origins of Sydney. Once the colonisation of Sydney commenced, this is where it happened!! Don't miss the Museum (free). Its tucked away between Circular Quay and Darling Harbour, under the shadow of the passing cruise liners!! Link this with a walk over the lump to Darling Harbour, taking a pause to view the Bridge from the bandstand in the grounds of the Observatory.

Rocks markets are a must!. Visited the Rocks markets recently with my husband. There are so many stores/stalls full full of lots of lovely and interesting things to buy (or even just look at) I reccommend you give yourself a good few hours. There are lots of nice restaurants througout the rocks, however there is also lots of yummy food and drinks you can try at the market. A must when visiting Sydney!

The Rocks Markets. I loved this market! Great atmosphere , awesome food and stalls set out in a great way that you get to see everything easily. Can watch glass blowing and painters etc. The corn on the cob on a stick was a great snack.
History of the first fleet. My ancestor landed with the first fleet, I always feel so connected. We are so lucky that it has been preserved for prosperity.

Nice place to wander about. Parking is wlways a problem, so bus is best to go to The Rocks - a short walk from Circular Quay, then a longer walk around the place and in the little alleyways, that features cafes, restaurants and nice boutiques.Taking a tour is good idea. I thought I know a lot about The Rocks after hundreds of visit in 30 years, until I joined a tour, which gave me a new look, a new feel about the area with its history and observation.
Go on a Sunday. There is a really great market here on a Sunday to wander around and find unusual things to buy. Great little places to stop and have lunch in.
Great Walk through the Rocks. Had a great walk through the Rocks. Karen the tour guide was terrifically informative, even as an Australian born native told me things I didn't know.
Great Sunday Markets and Restaurants. A fascinating and interesting market surrounded by fabulous boutique type shops. The local restaurants are inviting and plentiful. Pubs are also worth a visit.

Wonderful Piece of Living History. The Rocks are in Sydney offers the visitor both old and new. You can step back in time to the beginnings of Australia and walk the streets our earliest settlers walked. There are also some wonderful little restaurants, pubs and markets. A great place to visit!!!!!

Lots of great pubs. Glenmore has great view from Rooftop. Lord Nelson has some great local brews. Hero of Waterloo has live Irish Music on Sunday night. Oriental Hotel has pub and restaurant. Easy to walk, but be sure you have a map.

The night bazaar was fun!. “The Rocks” is the peninsula to the left (north) of Circular Quay (pronounced “key”) in Sydney. Back in the days when convicts still did most of the manual labor, a bunch of them spend a few years digging through the rock down the middle of the peninsula so that it would be easier to get from one side to the other. Having the story of its creation in mind makes the “Argyle Cut” is interesting to walk through.this area is loaded with pubs, cafe and restaurants. On weekend nights the place turns into a night bazaar full of tents with food booths and vendors. We had a great time wondering the streets eating and shopping.Get out of your hotel and walk this area! You will be glad you did!

Aussie Culture.. We spent the day wonering around the rocks taking in all the area had to offer, and we loved every minute of it! Lots of cafes, resturants and of course the markets. The buildings are beautiful, much effort has gone in to preserving the charm of yesteryear. The Rocks are a must see if visiting Sydney, it is a totally enchanting spot.

Markets, Pubs, History and Cafes. Excellent weekend markets with a bit of everything, Mostly handmade and organic. The place certainly buzzes with lots of History in the narrow cobbled streets. Plenty of Pubs to wet the whistle and losts of places to grab food and certainly lots of variety.
Nice markes. Nice markets are on on a friday night! And a German Bavarian pub called Loewenbraeu. Very popular and alway very busy. Everybody wants to try a real German beer :)
Great evening. Lots of great restaurants around the area, always pumping with energy and always something going on.
good fresh and well priced. Fresh and well presented food.Was also surprised the bill was very decent for the generous servings.Will definitely re visit and recommend the place
such am amazing place. we had the best time , i loved every minute of my trip , we crammed in a s much as posible and i would do it all again april 2011
The rocks. this is a very nice area for a meal in the evening,its very lively,always something going on,also a nice place just to have a coffee and peolpe watch
A Tourism trap. Make no doubts the Rocks is a excellent place to go...history etc... but go one street beyond and pay much less for a beer or a meal, it still has great atmosphere at half the price!

Step Back into Australian History. Great old pubs, cobbled streets and a wonderful place on the weekends when there is a wide variety of stalls in the marketplace where you can pick up interesting trinkets and souvenirs. A very historic and interesting part of old Sydney.

Uniquely Australian. At the base of the Harbour Bridge across the wharf from the opera house is a shopping and services village like no other. If you want a 100 year old pub - Done, If you want a top Hotel dusted, if you want fine dining - all sorted. if you want a good beer you want be dissapointed (Harts Pup - The Lord Nelson)If you are there at night stop in the Blue Bar on the Top of the Shangri la hotel.

The Rocks. I would go back!!! Lovely area, great location, better if you enjoy a quieter holiday, as we stayed in the YHA, Harbour Rocks. We didn't think that there was an awful lot to do in the evening but we had full days and enjoyed the local bar.
Always happening. No matter what time of day, or your choice of entertainment, you can always find something to do at the Rocks!

Some good free entertainment. Hanging around here for lunch one day brought us an interesting array of "things to observe" we saw a couple of aboriginal performances, some interesting buskers and plenty of cultural diversity.

Beautiful old part of the city. The Rocks have a lot of old, restored buildings which gives the area a lot of charm. There's no shortage of places to eat or go for drinks. There are some really nice restaurants and cafes in this area.

True Australian History. A lovely diversion in Sydney, great old buildings, lovely street cafes, unique boutique shops and usually gr weather make for a good half day stroll through this historic part of Sydney
Awseome atmosphere. great restaurants and bars and view of the harbour. Quirky little shops in hidden away alleys.Always somethng to see and buy

Wander the markets. We like to visit the rocks on a weekend if in sydney, have a coffee and wander the weekend markets.Close to walk around the harbour to the opera house and take in all the sights.A lovely part of sydney to explore!

Rock on. Take the tourist bus to Bondi but be prepared to linger an stroll along the footpath/scenic route to The Rocks. Th mighty ocean and the views back to Sydney Harbour are a delight for young and old. The bus can drop you of at several stops to take advantage of the views.cafes' etc
Not for me. The Rocks are great for finding boutiques hops and bars but if you struggle walking, my opinion is forget it. The hills put me off and the uneven ground didn't help.

Great weekend markets. Little slice of England in Sydney. Some really old traditional pubs, shops and restaurants. Great craft market every Saturday and Sunday. The place just seems to come alive. Little gem hidden away under the Bridge.

What a fascinating old place. We wandered around the Rocks area and enjoyed looking at the old streets and buildings. An ice-cream van under the bridge ramparts was welcome on a hot day. We went back another day and spent half a day at the street market then found a nice little restaurant to relax in for lunch.

Worth a visit even if only to browse the old buildings. I love the Rocks - I have ever since reading the book "Playing Beattie Bow" as a child. It's very touristy now but I still love to walk the cobblestone paths and imagine myself transported back in time. Visit the hand made candle shop off the main street - it kind of feels like you're underground but the candle creations can be pretty spectacular! And there are street markets some Fridays too :-)
Love it. The Rocks area is a great place to learn, sight see, dine, and shop. It has so much to offer in a great walking location.

Magnificent The Rocks. Walking around the area leisurely with beautiful houses, restaurants, museum, art work shop, souvenier shops, and looking out to the sea, with very nice view of Sydney Opera House. Observing the many ship coming in and out, listening to wave and sound of the sea with breeze. Fantastic day outing.

This is Sydney!. The historical relevance of The Rocks is very important in understanding the experiences of the early (non-indigenous) settlers. The buildings, the cobble-stoned passages and the proximity to the beautiful Sydney Harbour are all part of The Rocks experience. Visit one of the pubs, dine at one of the first class restaurants, do a bit of shopping, look over at the Opera House and other significant landmarks and enjoy just being in Sydney. I recommend you stay at one of the hotels nearby.
Great place at night. We were here at night and really enjoyed it. Didn't go to any restaurants here as we had already eaten at the Quays but went for some drinks. Lovely views of the skyline.
my favourite part of sydney. Amazing restaurants, history, bars and shops , the markets on Sunday are a highlight, Avoid this place at new years unless you like being crushed

Very nice both for sights and going out. I was staying in this area when visiting. There are many sights, and it is also close to Sydney Harbour bridge. Nice area to walk around in as it is full of history. There are also many small places and pubs to eat or have a drink. A must if visiting Sydney.
food is great. restaurants are around, beside the harbor. penguins hovering around, nice weather @ lots of humans. hahaha. enjoy human watching

beer on teh Rocks. a blast. there is a pub for every taste and some that are not evene pubs. The streets were lined with various vendors and teh food and drink was great at a few of the joints we visited. Only draw back was I wished we had more timer as we did not get to check some of them out.

Great markets + Entertainment. I went on the weekend and as usual, there is a sense of hype and atmosphere with live happenings at the Rocks. It is a great place to walk around where there are market stalls (usually on Sundays), live music at the Lorenbrau and a few pubs to visit for a quick drink!It can get crowded at times but there are always something to see and do..... a mix of history and aussie culture mixed in with Designer labels of LV, Ralph Lauren and Gucci to name a few... So lucky to live in Sydney!

Lovely cobbled streets. Lovely to walk on the cobbled streets and enjoy the enormous variety of shops and stalls. It was also a great place to access the Harbour Bridge from with its spectacular views.

Beautiful. Great spot. Plenty of boutique shops to wander around but also some good value souvenir shops too. Lovely quaint alley ways and old streets brimming with history to walk round. The free museum is really worth it and there is a great information center here too.Good selection of cafes and restaurants.
old cobbled streets. lovely setting with bars and places to eat in abundance,would highly recommend it to anyone visiting sydney.
Nice Walk. Loved the area. narrow streets and history abounds.Had breakfast and did some people watching. Accessed the bridge from the Rocks
Gorgeous area. Def worth a walk around this area, just to take in the scenery and building styles - very hilly so wear comfy shoes.

Heaps to do in a very walkable harbourside spot right in the city. The Rocks is a fantastic base for a Syney holiday or just a great day destination if you are staying elsewhere. You can walk to everything in the Rocks (and the heart of the CBD) within 15 minutes. Don't be deterred by the "tourist trap" reputation - there are tons of things to do for free in the Rocks, including (1) Museum of Contemprary Art plus tens of smaller private galleries (2) harbourside walks, (3) historic building walks, (4) weekend markets and (5) a great park under the harbour bridge with fantastic views. Culture Vultures will find Sydney Theatre Company and Dance Company housed on Hickson Road to the West of the Rocks. Drinkers and foodies have a huge range of options. Check out the Argyle Centre which has a huge pub in a restored warehouse with a cobblestoned central courtyard. Have a picnic on conservatory hill for more wonderful views. Take 10 mins at the Tourism Info Centre to find out what is happening because there are always great things on like the coffee festival, Latin American Festival plus a lot more.

Great Area to Enjoy the Views. This is historic area between harbour Bridge and Circular Quay is a nice area to walk around and take in the early history of the city. Excellent views at every turn with nice pubs and historic architecture.
A moment in time. We were driven around the Rocks area and one could almost see the new arrivals and the transportees. The wonderful old architecture and the liveliness of the whole area was great.

Much more fun than posh areas. We stayed in The Rocks when we visited Sydney and loved the area that was close to everything including Circular Quay, Sydney Bridge & the Opera House. It has cramped tight alleys, flagstone streets & old buildings but it all makes it great fun to walk around. We stayed in the Bed & Breakfast Sydney Harbour and would recommend it to anyone (see my review for more info).

History galore. Take a guided tour around this unique part of old Sydney Town. It is well worth hearing about the antics of the inhabitants of a bygone era. The history is fascinating, and if that is not enough, the Rocks Markets are a great way to pass a day away, buy unique gifts and eat yummy food. Cafes, great pubs and resaurants abound, a great choice awaits you here. This is one of those Not to be Missed places
Great weekend markets. See some of the history of Sydney, a place to walk around and spend time looking at the buildings. Great places here to stay and also to eat.
Quirky and wonderful place. Loved it ! As a nurse, I found the on-street history and " nurses walk " a fascinating experience. Thank you Oz, for sharing your history !

wonderfull place. No matter where you stay around the rocks you can find great hotel, excellent restuarants and the walking is a delight, try walking under the bridge around circular Quay and into the botanic gardens, just lovely
We strolled and we ate.. We strolled through the area of the Rocks. There are a lot of shops and restaurants, pubs, etc. We stopped to have something to eat. The Rocks are definitely worth a stroll.

old and quaint. this is an area of Sydney just under the bridge that was nearly lost to demolition until the workers made a stand and refused to demolish it! Now it is a warren of narrow cobbed street with bars, cafes restaurants and shops.
Great resturants. The resturants are the best I have been in the world. The service is out of this world. If you want to be spoilt then visit here. You will not regret it.

Yay to the Rocks. Now I am bias as I used to live in this area but if I looked around as though a tourist I would say that The Rocks is an interesting area, from the shops to the architecture. The views are outstanding from the Observatory Hill. You can walk across the Sydney Harbour Bridge from The Rocks, or down to Circular Quay and to the Sydney Opera House. Go for a stroll. You will enjoy it.

The original Sydney. This is the historic centre of the old city. Cramped, tight alleys, flagstone streets, and monuments to the criminals, seamen, rogues and followers that first settled Australia.Lovely scenes and numerous outdoor restaurants. A perfect walk from the centre of town. Totally safe, and no remaining scoundrels! Do not miss this area!

More fun than anywhere else!. Aussies love a drink-up and the young, ladies dressed beyond the hilt, thrive in the Rocks. The sound, of an evening, is a long, loud laugh-and-chatter you should experience, even if you are on the long side of 40.

Must Have been Hard in the Past. For me The Rocks area, houses with tin roofs and picket fences was nostalgia time having many, many years ago lived in Port Stanley, Falkland Islands - I suppose it is the colonial heritage. Took a number of walks around the Rocks areas, somehow felt pulled to the area. It really must have been hard for the early settlers, cramped, limited building materials - yet real sense of community. Visit The Rocks museum for stories of the area - they bring the history to life.

Full of drunks. Maybe interesting in the day, wandering around toursit shops, etc., but at night the area is filled with loud, drunk people. And the mornings show evidence of the drunks in the waste they leave behind.

quirky. lovely area for cute little shops and cafes. over the month we were there they had a few evening activities for free going on so look out for those, and dont forget to visit the chocolate cafes around the area

Great Historical reviews. walked here from the hotel and had a great time wandering about, loads of market stalls and soon found myself in buying mode, had to ship half the stuff home. Went to what I think was stated as the oldest bar in Australia and had a few glasses with the locals, cricket was on so not much talking but a great time

Rock On. This was once a great commercial centre with warehoses and bonded storage. Many of the buildings have been converted into the more modern concept of commercial buildings. The narrow lanes, many cobbled host pubs and cafes a plenty. There is a variety of independant traders and a small shopping mall again with independant traders. The streets accomodate a variety of market stalls and you stumble across a street entertainer as you pass along. Well worth a visit.

Great food everywhere. We had a couple of meals at The Orient and you can't walk down the street without popping into one of the bakeries with their magnificant cakes in the window. Lots of little shops and interesting nooks and crannies.

The best. I stayed at the YHA Sydney Harbour which is located in the rocks. So much history and where Sydney was founded. George Street offer some nice hsitric bars and resturants as well as many tourist souvenir shops. A good way to get here is via Wynard Station and walk down hill to Circular Quay if coming by rail.

The historic centre of Sydney. The "Green" movement in the 1960s saved most of this convict-era settlement of Sydney from the wrecker's ball, and we're the beneficiaries. It is full of atmosphere, groaning with eateries of all manner and description, trendy boutique hotels, jazz venues, art outlets, even a couple of museums. In short, there's something for everyone.

Walk The Rocks, the original Sidney. Try and plan to enjoy your morning or afternoon at the Rocks on Saturday or Sunday when there is a truly delightful street market. Then, spend an hour or so in the Modern Art Museum and enjoy one of the many cafes in the neighborhood.

Fun shopand caves up the hill on Nurse's Way. Only sewers will understand how thrilled I was to find Button, Buttons, Buttons. hand painted buttons for Christmas stockings are a great souvenir. Go up the hill from the Harbour street for better prices, service, and quirky shop and lovely outdoor cafes.
