Just don't get it.. I know it's popular but I just don't get it. Wander around the narrow alleys searching out overpriced shops & eateries. Much prefer the modern vibrancy of Darling Harbour with all that goes on over there.

Fun. Wear a sport shoes caused need to walk and go up and down stairs if there on Sunday make sure you have enough money there is Sunday market you don't want to miss out any thing , enjoy the view with a cup of coffee near the shore it's so great

Go on the weekend and enjoy the market. Art and craft market, really cool stalls with souvenirs and clothing and art to enjoy. Love Ronni Arts, a British artist who has settled in Sydney and sells lovely prints at great prices, ships worldwide too!
Excellent tour. If you want the real story of the Rocks then take the walking tour. An absolute must! You will go places and hear about things you never knew existed.
Nice atmosphere. Hard to find a parking space in this area, but when you wak around this place, you never regret your hard effort to get here. Come on weekend, so you can see the street market
excellent. We loved it, well presented and the staff were very helpful, friendly & the buildings are full of character & history.
Steeped in heritage. Spent Sunday morning here at the markets. Parking very expensive. Food a bit pricey, but to walk amongst the heritage was worth the experience
Lots of character.. The Rocks are great to walk around and see the old buildings and have a drink or two in the Orient or one of the other old establishments.

Nice place to visit. You'll enjoy walking around the Rocks area, apart from all of the history of the area, there is a wonderful weekend market and some lovely restaurants, recently my daughter and I went to "Pancakes at Rocks" .

Excellent!. This is my most favourite place in Sydney. I love going to the weekend markets. I love the old buildings. Walking around makes me feel as though I'm in one of the old cobbled stoned cities in Europe!

Truly the Historic Part of Sydney. We enjoyed meandering around this area of Sydney and wished we had spent more time there. The restaurants we enjoyed very much were "Fish at the Rock" on Kent Ave. and the Oktoberfest restaurant. Sydney is very developed and this was the only area we found that truly gave a sense of what Sydney might have been like in the old days.
Ghost tour. Went on a ghost tour and it was excellent. Really interesting history about real people, visited hidden away nooks and crannies, very entertaining story teller. Well worth doing.

A step back in time. It didn't take much imagination to see what the Rocks looked like 200 years ago as the area is nothing but 18th century architecture. Narrow limestone alleys lined with shops and eateries. Boutique hotels and pubs abound and the outdoor market keep your day busy. The Rocks is conveniently nestled between Sydneys' two icons, the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge so you don't have to go far to take the both of them in. The Circle Quay is right there too should you wish to take a ferry ride to some other place on the harbour or just a lunch cruise on the water. If you want to expand your sightseeing, hop on a double decker bus that will take you around Sydney as many times as you want. Sydney is a bit pricey, but if you can get by that, it is a great place to visit.

Very european feel - old world meets new world.. The Fri food Market & Weekend Market adds gastronomy & charms to the cafe, atmosphere etc Many cafe, restaurants in the area too. There is a very helpful visitor's centre that has lots of material for tourist too.
The Oldest Part of Sidney - A small town in a big city.. Great shopping, great dining, great views of the Sydney Harbor Bridge and great street markets on Saturdays.

Worth discovering. Unfortunately we didn't have much time to walk round the Rocks, but there are a number of interesting places to visit, including the Rocks Museum and the big dig. The small lanes are picturesque and there are places to eat which are better value than down on the harbour front.
Old Sydney town. Nice history, great shops in the old customs houses/bond stores. Really great handmade markets there on thevweekend

An Enjoyable Area. We walked to The Rocks from our hotel. We walked the area and visited the shops. We had dinner at The Rock Cafe. We had dinner the second evening at a nice open air restaurant (sorry I do not remember the name of it). We had a nice meal at both places and the prices were reasonable and the food good.

The Rocks Weekend Market Rocks.... Visited The Rocks weekend market on a Sunday and it was a really nice experience, much preferred this to the Paddy's Market at Haymarket. Take a stroll along the charming alleys, enjoy gorgeous views along the harbour, and you'll find lovely handicrafts and souvenirs from local designers; seashelled lipbalm, honey products, street snacks, roasted nuts etc. - quite pricey but more interesting, unusual finds.
Markets by the Rocks. Love the old colonial style apartments and broad array of crafts at the markets. Old cobble stone and handmade bricks!
Nice little walk. It was nice to have a little walk around here plus they have a weekend market and some really friendly bars.

Mid week is disappointing. I had a great time when I came here 3 years ago however this time it was mid-week when I visited and I was very disappointed. It lacked the atmosphere of the market stalls being out-but in saying that the restaurants were open so you could have a drink and do some people watching. If you plan to visit, I would suggest the weekend if at all possible.

History, Food and Culture.. The heart of Sydney history and right in the center of the Sydney! Check out some of the smaller bars like Argyle for a bite. You'll love the mood of the old Sydney streets. Day is nicer than night.

The Rocks Market. The rocks are in the oldest part of Sydney situated on the harbor side by the bridge. A great place to spend the good part of the day browsing and of course spending. .There were 200 stalls selling clothes, handmade jewelery, art, music, you name it and it was there. We bought some great Christmas presents. Some very talented musicians playing throughout the day. Plenty of cafes, bars etc to get something to eat and drink while listening to the music.

I don't get it. Everyone seems to love the Rocks area. Yes, it is historical and a large part of Sydney's history but I would not recommend going unless you ran out of other things to do. Any of our visitors found it "OK", nothing special, or a bit boring.

The only place quaint part of City Center. The rocks are quaint and interesting because of the history they represent. Take a walking tour and learn about the stories of buildings that are still there. The Rocks is where the first shipment of convicts landed.

great markets. we were disappointed that it was raining during our short stay in sydney as we thought the rocks markets would be washed out.To our pleasant surprise it turned out that most of the stalls are under cover so you can enjoy them with out getting wet.

Total enjoyment in the Markets at the rocks, great little places for lunch and dinner....... The people really enjioy helping everyone and we all had interesting conversations about the history, when we went for a "Little" walk... The motorbike rides are great as well.... And the view of the Harbour bridge and then the harbour. I'm glad the buikdings are still there and not pulled down...

So much to see. History, history, history...so much to see, The Rocks is a wonderful place to explore, so many little shops to browse, so much history to learn about, it is pretty hilly in parts so can be a bit tiring if you are not a walker but it is possible to do a lot of it on the flat, lots of pubs, restaurants and cafes (our Princess Mary met her Prince Frederick of Denmark in a pub at The Rocks, maybe you'll meet your Prince Charming!!)

Nice to spend some time. However I think that it is a little over advertised as teriffic....!!!It is nice to have look but not much to do, not many spots that you can sit down to have a nice beer, overall we Liked it but wont go back for a second time

Always a pleasure to visit. The Rocks is one of my favourite destination in Sydney. It's nice to sit in a cafe on a nice sunny day and enjoy the views, or stroll through the many stalls at The Rocks market on weekends. It may seem a tad touristy but trust me, there will be something for you to buy!
Friday market. The smells, choices and quality of the food is one of our memorable moments from our recent Sydney, Blue Mountains and Hunter Valley trip.

Too late to enjoy the place. It could be because I arrived after 5pm, so most shops were either closed or about to be closed (but isn't this a tourist attraction, surely they could open till later...). I didn't see much attractions and felt it was just so-so.

loved walking the old streets. There are a lot of shops and restaurants, but also historic sites. The nurses walk was especially interesting, seeing the old first hospital sites from 1700. Lots of deals to be found, so shop around for a while. We spent 3 afternoons there just cause it had a great atmosphere.

always something going on. This place is always alive, from quaint pubs to markets, and lots of eating places. Variety plus, from little art galleries to oldern style buildings with lots of history plus entertainment is the square during the day (on the weekend we went there was, not sure if its all the time).

The place in Sydney;. So much history here and lots of shops and very good restaurants.Easy to stroll around , quite a compact area and wander along the harbor promenade to the Opera house afterwards.A good half day here;

not The Rocks of days gone by. I have been to the Rocks a few times over many years and last visited in July. I have to say I was a little disappointed to find it all a bit upmarket now. The quaintness of the area is not there as it was. A lot of shops seem to have left with places left vacant. We missed seeing the markets unfortunately, and I expect that is the best time to come to the Rocks.

Like you weren't going there. Explore anything you like from here. Start here, wander around, end here - you've had a good day. Performers, museums, art, shops, food & beverage, street markets, its all here.

Must do the market. A great area in Sydney close to the Bridge and Opera House, full of history and yet thanks to some great restaurants and designer shops,it's also bang up to date. The market (Sat and Sun 9-5) is well worth a visit. Yes there are some of the "usual" souvenirs, but there are also some lovely crafts on display. There is a wonderful hat stall, some wonderful art and I couldn't resist treating myself to a very unusual necklace which looked at a distance like fine metal but turned out to be leather so ultralight to wear. Well wor a wander.

Historical Sydney. Fabulous restaurants (try the pancakes/breakfast), Saturday and Sunday markets, modern architecture blends well with the clearly labelled buildings of early Sydney. It is easy to access by public transport and walking from Circular Quay. Take a jacket, it is often windy or chilly (at least in Sept we felt so) in the shadows of the buildings.

OK, but rather touristy. Restaurants and shopping are OK; check out the oldest Irish pub in Australia (ask to see the secret tunnel) "The Hero of Waterloo". Also check out the Lord Nelson Hotel (which is a pub).
The Rocks rock. Enjoyed wandering around this area very much. There were some interesting shops with local goods - particularly enjoyed the art at the Argyle Gallery.

Don't be the early bird. We visited The Rocks area recently. We walked all around the area, and were attacked by two birds on separate occasions when we did! Having said that the incidents were down by the water area. We also went before 11am on a Friday morning. Not a lot was open, except for a couple of cafes, so we would recommend going to The Rocks in the afternoon instead. Guylian hot chocolate is a must, better than Lindt hot chocolate!

Old School. My mother is particularly found of this part of Sydney as it contains many 'old' school buildings where despite attached, can slice the buildings edges and clearly separate them.Good if walking to bridge climb or for shopping.

Colonial Class. Have been to The Rocks a number of occasions and every time we go we always stumble across a new alley/restaurant or bar. Choose where you dine wisely as some of the more well-known places tend to be a bit overrated/priced.

Great Markets on a sunday. Great Markets on a sunday so much to do there. Great views from there to see the harbour and the opera house, great eateries too i totally recommend to spend at least half a day there.

The best place to stay in Sidney. Our hotel was located in this area. It has some of the oldest buildings as this is where the first convict ships came ashore. You can walk to a lot of the areas iconic landmarks (Harbour Bridge, Opera House, Botanical Gardens) and the Circular Quay is also here which provides you access to the other mass trasit systems to go where ever you want in Sidney and the surronding areas. There are several breweries and great pubs to go to and great places to eat as well.

Great clean area gives good impression of how Sydney has changed. from Convict times incl many older buidings (By Aussie standards 200years is a long time) Architecture
Food, Pubs, a real party district on Saturday Nights and New Years, on NYE t's quite a young crowd but there are options for mature revellers including the Hyatt
Armosphere
Is a bit touristy but worth all the same

Great place to walk around. Its a very clean location, great architecture and history and great scenery to be around, has some nice little shops and restaurants and a fair in the weekends...Take your camera and walk around you won't regret

Always a good experience. We've been here many times over the past twenty plus years and always enjoy being here.
It's a large part of what makes Sydney one of the best tourist destinations on the planet.
So many things to do and see.
The market; the pubs, cafes and fine dining restaurants; the ferries; Street performers......

Fascinating history. Lots of great shopping, fascinating history and great vibe. The Rocks Market on the weekend is really excellent with a good range of products. Not a cheap market, but well worth a visit.

Great place. Very nice place to stay, easy access to transport at circular quay and nice places to eat including for those on a budget and ones by the harbour which is a short walk if you want something more specialised.

Colonial Sydney - Step Back in Time. Right in the heart of the modern antipodean city of Sydney is the small colonial precinct called simply "The Rocks". With its pubs and markets it's a hive of boisterous activity - like nothing has changed in 200 years. Love it! AW (Tony) Scott

Fabulous to walk around. The quaint little buildings tucked in amongst the monolithic skyscrapers are so cute. Great place to wander, especially for people watching. Some great little cafes and restaurants - surprisingly not expensive as you may think.

THE ROCKS, SYDNEY. A fantastic area of Sydney, luckily preserved for future generations to see the style and history of early Australian settlement. Do take time to wander through the laneways and quirky buildings. The Big Dig, under the YHA, is a fascinating area with photos and descriptive plaques of life back around 1880 and so on. Remnants of homes, built from rock hewn on site by men and carted by horse, with some artefacts.......Life was tough back then......Then enjoy a beverage at one of the many hotels in the area, that have also kept the charm of their particular era. I love The Rocks, and visit it every time I venture to Sydney and always find something new to look at.

Clean, safe, fun place. Good pubs and cafes in a historical setting. Very good policing to ensure it is safe at all hours of day. The Sunday Rocks street market was excellent and my wife bought some unique jewellery.

Great location. The best location in Sydney. We stayed at the Holiday Inn at the Rocks and it was perfect, just a very short walk from the harbor bridge, the opera house and all of the ferries. The opera house is the perfect place to watch all of the sunrises you'll be awake for when you first get there. Also a 24 hr pancake house just around the corner, also for those early mornings when you'll be awake. There are plenty of shops and restaurants very close by.

Overpriced.... Overall this was a good experience. I went on a friday night when the markets were on. Everything is extreamly overpriced (but i guess everything in Sydney is) and the only cheap things in sight are sold by Asian stalls, which are very tacky and not worth the money! The nightlife is great, but it is very touristy, sometimes it seemed as if i were in chinatown. And some of the stall owners get very rude if you refuse to buy anything and just want to look.There is a great pub almost directly under the bridge that gave out decent sized meals and had a great atomosphere. Reccomened to all :)

A must for the Brits. Great nightlife and even better when the crickets on!What an atmophere, locals and tourists united :) great selection of bars with live music most nights, daytime good selection of shops and a small market. There an ice cream shop there and its the best ive ever had.Go and enjoy your night, when you come out your right next to the cruise liners which add to the views.
Interesting. Nice to get to know a little about old Sydney and the origins of the settlement. The Rocks Museum is small but worth a visit and some of the buidlings in the area are beautiful.
A little bit tired. Too touristy. The Rocks markets were very disappointing . Aimed at tourists but low quality merchandise. Still good to walk around though.

Great for night life in sydney. Having a walk around the rocks after a big slap up meal was the icing on the cake for us. then to see the building all lit up at night is wonderful. the bridge looks great at night also.

My fav place in Sydney!!. I just love the feel and energy of this place. The best time to visit is on the weekend when there is weekend Market. There are so many shops and such variety right from jewellery, dresses, funny t shirts... Actually every week you may find new stuff. Then there is street side food vendors , its fun trying their stuff. You have to try mango beer. There is a quaint Irish tea shop where you get home made scones and jams. My fav is fig and ginger jam. Love the feel of walking on the cobbled streets, surrounded by old building .... Makes one feel as if we are in a different era. If you take a walk you get great view of both harbour bridge and opera house. If you are feeling down go to The Rocks and you will feel happy!!

Nice walk. A bit seedy?. The Rocks on a Sunday morning in April was a little bit seedy. The first people we 'met' were still out drinking from the night before and we had trouble shaking them off. We finally found somewhere serving sit-down breakfast, but spent 40 minutes waiting for it. We managed, but some of the other customers were getting pretty tetchy. The shops were not especially enticing - most catering to cashed-up international tourists. The area itself is worth visiting for anyone interested in the history of the area, but more could be done to make the historical sites interesting and informative. I think I would have enjoyed all this more if I hadn't spent a long lifetime hearing that the Rocks in Sydney was a 'must see'. As a pleasant place to walk on a sunny morning - it's perfectly fine.

A day at the Rocks!. I enjoyed the walks and markets that we took on the Week end. Also being so close to Sydney Harbour was a huge bonus. Everything was close and handy: transport, food, entertainment and markets.

The place to see. While in Sydney, you must take some time to stroll through The Rocks. Eclectic shops, happening clubs, fine dining, weekend markets, and tons of historic buildings and scenery. Take a walking tour, then relax and enjoy a nice meal as the harbor lights come out.
History and shopping.. Not to be missed, from the cobbled streets, historic buildings, galleries, restaurants and the weekend market.
Weekend Markets a must. The Rocks markets are a must do. Australiana crafts, jewellery, handbags, clothes, so much more. A great place for brunch on the weekend

attraction. with so much to see and do u run out of time. every time we go to the rocks we find different things to see and do. just take the time to walk around and enjoy all of the narrow street and different shops but dont forget to call into the local hotels to enjoy a drink at the end of the day
Massive outdoor market. A bit too professional with enclosures and higher than needed prices, but a thorough representation of area crafts.
Great markets. My friend and I walked from our hotel to the Rocks markets and had so much fun wandering around the lovely stone streets hunting for treasures. Well worth a look if you are in Sydney.
Be Prepared for a Climb!. If you're up for walking it's a brilliant area, full of history. We took a "free" walking tour with a guide who lives on tips and thouroughly enjoyed it.

The Rocks - look outside the box!. We had been told to just wander when we got to the Rocks but it took us 2 trips to find the best bits. The Susannah Place area and museum is terrific. The guide, Margaret, made the whole experience well worth the effort of the return visit. Brought back many memories of how things used to be. All parents should take their teenagers there to see how life used to be in even the 1960's. Well done Historic Homes.
Old World. We have had many a walk around The Rocks. The weekend markets are interesting to browse around and find something unique..

History on foot. There are a number of good wlking tours for the Rocks, but I love just to wander around the buildings and see what I can discover on my own. The Doctors and Nurses walks are small lanes between buildings and you can visit may different shops, from the expensive to the facinating. There are lots of good places to eat too, so spend some time amongst Sydneys earliest buildings

The Rocks Markets. Love this place. Great hand made goods, jewellery, gourmet food goods like nuts, nougat & chocolates etc. Timber, Australian wares great for tourists, candles, clothes & funky bags etc. You could spend a good few hours here then go somewhere like one of the local pubs or cafes for lunch & wander down to the Harbour afterwards. Great day out!

Always worth a visit. Lots of great pubs, dining options and full of that 'historical area meets modern hangout' vibe. Sure, there's the touristy aspect, but it's still a place we head to to drink or eat when we're in town.
Spider drink. we enjoyed a light meal and a drink called a spider it was delicious, with so many small shops to look at it took us ages to see most of it

Good place to visit any time!. Walking distance to train station Opera House and Darling Harbour
Good service good food.Will visit with my friends in near future.

History alive!. Oh, the markets - just fabulous range of craft, art, and food to suit everyone - allin a setting full of history. So close to the Quay , the ferries and don't forget Ken Done's gallery.

Around the Shangri La hotel The Rocks. We went to The Rocks to attend a Confernece but as we arrived early we had the opportunity to walk around the area of our hotel. Was really surprised by the degree of preservation of the old buildings that reflect the early period of Sydney's history. Came across an archeological dig just down the road from our hotel. They have cleverly incorporated these exposed ruins into the building housing the YHA which floats above them. The foundations of numerous homes from the turn of the twentieth century have been preserved and are on display with boards giving details of the people who lived in them and a history of the area. A most remarkable idea and an example of 'living' history

Average markets, great food..... Visited here recently and was disappointed at the lack of great products at the local markets for such a big city. Food was delicious though. Very busy area to navigate on weekends too. Overall though very clean and well looked after area.

Depends on the events!. If you want to get lost in the markets, get our tarot read, devour some popcorn and get a handmade gift for a friend and maybe some lavender soaps to ward off silverfish in the wardrobe? Come to the weekend markets. Avoid if you do not want to fight for a seat during Oktoberfest though! But we did turn up with our eight month old... Not sure what we were thinking but we loved it nonetheless! So, overall, a charming piece of history.

The Rocks. Probably didnt make the most of this historic area, maybe should have done a guided walking tour.Good food shops and a free mini musuem as well. Must see the YHA archaelogical dig, under the accomm, but easily walked through. not underground.
this is the best part of sydney. The hidden away eateries and bars and the quality accommodation at Sydney old rock holiday inn make this area so wonderful. Whenever I am in Sydney this is our base.

History meets Cosmopolitan city!. A fantastic place to visit whether you are a history buff or not! There are restaurants for any taste or budget and it's truly beautiful! I'd recommend a trip to The Rocks as a day trip or as we did stay there and use it as a base!
Loved It. Will return. Amazing atmosphere. Great stalls with lots of different things to look at. Something for everyone. Great history and quaint shops.

Lots on at The Rocks. The Rocks offers visitors lots of choice for dining and shopping. There are historical pubs, including the oldest pub in Sydney, The War of Fortune. On the weekend, check out the markets - well worth a visit.

Wonderful Place to spend a sunny day. I LOVE coming here on a lazy Sunday. Lovely cafes and restaurants! The market is adorable - some pretty awesome finds (clothes, art, knick-knacks etc). Views are great as well!
Worth coming to see if you've got a sunny day in the City

Well Worth a trip to the oldest part of Australia. Its well worth a trip to the Rocks area of Sydney. This is where Australia all began and there are lots of cool buildings ,pubs ,cafes and restaurants. You can also walk around the foreshore of the Sydney harbour and under the Sydney Harbour Bridge. There are Sunday markets with lots of cool things to buy.

History and commercialism crammed together. The Rocks is of course a must see for all Sydney tourists, and certainly you will get an opportunity to buys the sorts of things you either never knew you needed, or that will never see the light of day when back home. However, if you take yourself away from the cruise tourists, and sidle up the hill you will find excellent examples of Georgian and recent historical buildings, soem excellent pubs (Hero of Waterloo, Lord Nelson, The Australian) and the observatory. Those who are fortunate to visit on weekend, will find the sight of numerous weddings and their parties jousting for photo opportunities, and who happily exchange chats and your ogling! A wonderful piece of Australian lifestyle.

Feel the history. Being from Sydney, the Rocks and Circular Quay are great places to see, however, I was upset with the homeless and beggars around the Quay area, so be prepared to see the other side of life in these areas.

Thrice. In less than a week, I have visited this place. Lastly visited when the Saturday market was about to close down. Worth taking the walking tour. Worth wandering around. Worth checking out the market and having a stall seller fit you in their latest products. Very cute place, lots of pubs, lots of history. I'll probably make another trip there before I leave....and please note, I'm spending 10 days in Sydney.

Nice for a walk. It's a walk and it's free, so just go for it to get a feeling of the historic center of Sydney. There is nothing special to look for, so don't over-expect, but you get to see some old buildings.

Saturday morning stroll. We started our walk from Shangri-La at 8.15am and roamed around for over an hour. The markets were just being set up and looked like loads of fun - we unfortunately had an engagement at 10.00 - early morning joggers, late night revellers, old buildings, history and generally stuff to light up ones senses. Do not miss.
Fun and interesting. Lots of history here...interesting architecture, guided tours(or you can easily stroll and read the signs) some great pubs and cafes and market stalls during the weekends.
okay. was nice place to visit, because it was one our touristic guide. But we didn't see anything that was really outstanding there, but was still nice....

This is the best place to stay if you are in Sydney, close to everything and has great pubs and restaurants.. The history of the rocks is very interesting plus it has the best markets all day Saturday and Sunday. The entertainment in the pubs is excellent and just walking around and taking the place in is great, for it was alot of character.
Nice. The rocks is such a beautiful neibourhood! It's the most 'historical' one I saw while I was in Sydney. Great for taking pictures and just walk around, buy a souvenir and have a coffee

sunday. very enjoyable stroll the the markets held on Sundays till 5pm
lots of local craft and artists. this area has so much history

Shops and a market (ie. more shops). Some nice cobblestones. If you want to go shopping then it is a pleasant place to stroll around. Europeans are unlikely to be impressed. There are some nice streets with cobblestones and it has a slightly 'historic' feel to it. At least, as historic as non-indigenous Australia can get...
Beatifull old neighborhood.. This is the "Old part of Town" with most of the houses built in the 17th century. Go Saturday for the street bizar.
Full of history. You can't visit Sydney and not be enchanted by the Rocks area. This is where Sydney began and that sense of history is still there. Wonderful.
Review on places in sydney. I liked it becasue of its location, the service was good, the location is brilliant and the view is awesome
Rocks in your head. Though there are many places of interest at the Rocks the last time I was there I found dinning was expensive, a number of the streets had a lot of rubbish.
rocking rocks!. we went to this pizzeria which had cheap pizzas! and they were wonderful. they also had a free tour around the rocks! go online for more details!
Lovely place with lots of history. The Rock is a very nice place with lots of history. We were very surprised to find lots of English houses along the street.
I like the market. I enjoy going with my family to the weekend market and walk around. That is the oldest suburb in Sydney and I like how they keep it original.

nice vibrant market at the Rocks. a nice stroll eating peppered corn and browsing thru' the stalls... the area is a bit touristy being near the bridge and quay but there are some nice stuffs to look at.. some street performance liven up the place..

Highly recommend these markets. There are some very talented & innovated people selling their products at the Rocks Markets. From womens and childrens clothing to souvenirs, health products and homewares/souvenirs this market is a cut above many of the markets you go to nowadays were there is a lot of the throw away product that you see at the dollar discount stores. Definitely worth a couple of hours at the markets and some lovely cafe/restaurants to while away another couple of hours in this beautifully restored and historic area of Sydney.

Almost there. Great area that is clearly on the way up. The shops are nice, but there needs to be some better dining on the water. The restaurants were often empty and not recommended by our hotel. Some small pubs or cafes down by the harbor would make it better. Nice art galleries.

Convict Territory. Take a step back in time and enjoy meandering through the rocks area. Take time out to enjoy refreshments in one of the many excellent cafes and restaurants. Marvel at the old buildings and enjoy the weekend markets.

Early white history. It is great that we have this are to remind us how much we have changed as a nation since white settlers arrived. The sandstone is lovely. Explore some of the narrow passageways they are worth a look.

Something for everyone. Hadnt been to The Rocks for a while but visited during Sydney Vivid Festival. The place was buzzing with thousand of people out and about. Great variety of resturants and bars within easy walking distance of Circular Quay. Day or night its a winner.
It rained but the corn on the cob was still great. There is so much to see and it looks like they are improving the quality of produce sold at the market stalls.

See the Opera House under the Harbour Bridge (almost). Love the Rocks, a lot of nice bars and restaurants and the views are nothing short of spectacular. Recommend the restaurant Wildfire!!!!! Churasco is amazing and worth every penny. Or if just for a drink, go and sit in the Samba bar.

Beautiful historic buildings, homes and churches.. Take the Argyle stairs to access the upper area of the Rocks. There are numerous pubs (with awesome food and beer), the oldest church established in Australia (stained glass is beautiful), original row houses that are in the process of being restored, and beautiful views. You will want to wear good walking shoes, but it is well worth your time if you love historic architecture as I do.
A walk on the Rocks. The Rocks has a lot to offer. I normally spend a couple of hours here during my visits to Sydney and enjoy a cup of coffee or lunch at different cafes and restaurants.

nice little streets to walk about. Littered with cafes and boutiques, the place is slightly touristy for our liking. The weekend market was interesting to get lost in for a couple of hours. Museum was great. It was nonetheless great to spent some time roaming through the little streets and deeper into the neighborhood where the Garrison Church stands.
chilled spot for a pint. had a pint or 5 at the orient market was on and altough nothing that seriously interetsed me at the market but plenty of people and a good vibe for a pint

A Bit Disappointing.. The Rocks are a bit touristy. It would have been nice to see more about the history of the area. If you are at Circular Quay maybe worth a quick walk through but certainly not worth more than that.

Great atmosphere!. Enjoyed wandering around the stalls and eateries, the atmosphere was great, the stalls had some unusual items (although beware lots of chinese products skillfully displayed and marketed at inflated prices) the handmade chocolates taste wonderful! A nice way to spend a few hours, have done the historic tour in the past and it was very informative.
Rocks great cafe good market. Bought some great dresses had a fabulous meal at local cafe with courtyard - quiet and leafy couryard and brillant food and service
Rocks Markets. Fun, fun fun, the marketeers were great and the whole experience was excellent - excellent, unique hand made goods too.

Love on The Rocks. What an amazing place....wander in and out of little shops, discover and explore the market full of wonderful crafts and gifts, have a drink in Sydneys oldest pub...just spend hours people watching. Just perfect....wish I were there now!
Trendy Neighborhood. Very walkable neighborhood near the CBD and the water, filled with restaurants, shops, galleries, and bars.

excellent!. Great for a day exploring - my friend and I spent the whole day just meandering around the Rocks, in and out of shops, looking through the vintage stores and ending up below the bridge for some great pictures! Also, a must do is to stop into the oldest pub in syndey for a drink!

Nice place for a Sunday walk!. Nice place for a Sunday walk but don't expect cheap souvenirs, A$25 vs A$20 at Paddy's Market for a pair of Rooballs can opener.
Still, love the open air bazaar feel.

History of Sydney.. That the 'old Sydney' is still there. So much of our beautiful City has been changed over the last decades, but the Rocks holds so much of our history. A must see if travelling to Sydney.

Historic Sydney. Love this part of Sydney, Market Days are lovely but the real plus is the lovely old buildings in the area. Great to wander the streets have a bite to eat in one of the old pubs stroll along the harbour front, shop in the boutiques and get an idea of some of the history of this beautiful city.

Yet another trendy Sydney suburb. The Rocks, like many other parts of Sydney, is packed with trendy and funky restaurants and cafes. There are some great waterfront areas and some amazing views of Sydney landmarks like the Opera House and Circular Quay. Up from the waterfront are some great little lanes and walkways to explore, packing with great little shops and more eateries. Some of the old architecture in the area is great too. The Rocks is a pretty cool part of Sydney. It is always very busy at The Rocks, so give yourself plenty of time to explore and enjoy the area.

Historical & Beatifull. Great view, Many Historical building / houses, Rocks still exist, some restaurant / cafes worth to try. Come on the weekend are the best cause have market which sell artistic goods. Good place to relax.

Fun place to explore. my daughter and I stayed at the Rocks while we were in Sydney just recently. This is such an interesting part of Sydney. We loved walkining around and exploring the lanes and streets. The weekend markets had some fabulous stalls with local handicrafts. We would definitely put this on your list of things to do while in Sydney.
markets are for overseas tourists not the locals. Great food stops and pubs all the way around tho I might add that are more attuned to the Aussie requirements

Indeed The Rocks of Ages.. Fabulous restaurants, Saturday and Sunday markets(10am-5pm) with agreat Foodiesmarket the same times on Fridays, modern architecture blends well with the clearly labelled buildings of early Sydney. It is easy to access by public transport and walking from Circular Quay. Parking can be difficult. Take a jacket, it is often windy or chilly in the shadows of the buildings.
Historic Area. This is close to the harbour bridge and is were Sydney and Australia started. Lots of historic buildings within walking distance.

Something for everyone. The Rocks is a semi commercial/semi historical area and affords some photo opportunities. Go on a market day for added attractions. There are some good restaurants offering deals at certain times. Myself and my brother got 2 drinks and 2 steaks for 30 dollars, great value if you are on a budget. Shop around, don't go with the first place you see and you will pick up a bargain.
Not thrilled by the market. The market was very pricey but the stall holders were more than willing to assist for a purchase. I'm not sure what I was hoping for but I have been to better markets.

Lots to see.. There is so much to see at the Rocks and you can spend hours walking the back streets to find more of Sydney's history. There are many old buildings and trees worthy of a photo or 2 and a few Irish pubs to quench the thirst after a trek through the back streets. There a varying vantage points of the Harbour bridge.

Saturday.... Saturday morning we took the Metro to Milsons Point and then walked over the Sydney Bridge...when you get over the bridge you end up right in the Rocks district and can enjoy strolling around the area. Because it was Saturday we were able to tour the Saturday Market (which was slightly disappointing compared to other markets I have visited in the past). Though, we did have an amazing lunch from one of the street vendors - I'm still dreaming of my roasted pumpkin with feta and walnut pesto wrap I had there. Lunch prices from the vendors were very reasonable - so I'd definitely recommend it. After lunch we toured the small history museum there - I'm drawing a blank on the name, but I definitely think it is worth a visit.

A Great place to wander. A fantastic selection of arts and crafts and for finding that souvenir that is a little bit different. Open on Saturday and Sundays and there are plenty of places around to have a break and a bite to eat or a drink

Interesting history and shops. The Rocks are worth visiting if you are interested in the history of Sydney or you like shopping at smaller shops. The highlights for me was the visit to the Superbee Honey Shop on Playfair Street. There are a few shops like this which feel unique and interesting but otherwise there are also a number of touristy souvenir shops which are less interesting. Try and visit on one of the market days, which are the weekend and sometimes on Fridays, as this offers a wider range of shopping opportunities.

This was nice. We enjoyed walking around The Rocks and seeing all the little touristy places and the museum. Stopped at the Ken Done Art Gallery and bought some prints. They also had like an outdoor market going on which was fun.
Tourists tourists tourists. Big brand shops, restaurants... but a nice irish bar playing irish favourites on a weekend afternoon.

Nice old part of town. I stayed in the Rocks area for 6 nights while on a business trip in Sydney. It is a very old part of town but it has a lot of history and culture. Tons of old style pubs and restaurants and on the weekends they have a "flea market" with tons of random items for sale. Its a great way to get outside and spend the day walking around and enjoying the good food and atmosphere. It is a bit of a tourist trap and with that comes along a little more expensive restaurants and drinks.

Good vibe ... could get crowded. It's nice to stroll along the back alleys, sit down in a quiet courtyard (if you could find one) for a cuppa. Always nice to visit the Aroma Festival at the end of July.

The Rocks Markets. Held every Sat & Sun, this is a must see. The products are quite unique, some handmade, high quality. The markets run through a main street and small lane ways. The atmosphere is great. There is a local pub and small quaint cafes to enjoy a meal. The markets are near Circular Quay, the Opera House and the Botanical Gardens.

Love everything about the Rocks!. Try the pancakes on the Rocks. Its really good. comes in both sweet and savory pancakes. Portion is huge and reasonably priced. Went to the flea market during the week end. There are alot to see. From food to books or just some artistic handicraft. There is also a shop around that sells really tasty honey that comes in different flavour. You will be able to try all the flavour there before buying. Shop owner is friendly and honest.
LOVED IT. best hotel location ever.Fab array of delis / cafes and places to eat.Superb selection of shops (very helpful advice given at tourist info) Definitely a place to visit.

Just walk around and explore!. Loved to walk around and find little walkways between the old buildings. Check out the Sunday markets too. Can easily walk up the stairs to the Harbour bridge from here.We stayed at the Holiday Inn Old Sydney - perfect for this location.
Old Sydney. It is good to walk up the hill towards the Bridge pylon look out so that you can experience the street and the area where houses were demolished to stop the plague carrying rats.

Fantastic People Watching. The Rocks in the summer with it's street market is a fabulous place to shop for those souveniers whhich are a little bit special. Fabulous place to wander and people watch the rest of the time :-)
Aroma Festival. Went to the Aroma Festival in The Rocks. Very crowded. Enjoyed looking at the booths and sampling foods and drinks. Lots of great shops for browsing/souvenier hunting.
Nice place to visit. Nice place for grab some beers. Nice restaurants. Old houses. Art galleries and markets. Nice view of Sydney CBD.

Not as great as I read. All the reviews had me very excited to visit the Rocks. It may have been the day I went (rainy cold saturday) but it was pretty disappointing. There were only about 8 shops, 6 of which were small food stands. Other than that the shopping in the area was pretty standard for the rest of Sydney.

Nice Market Area. We only spent a couple hours here but the open air market was very good and loved the sculptures. We then walked up to the Australian Hotel Bar and had a beer and a Kangaroo Pizza that was excellent.

Great ambiance. Love this place for being a little away from the frantic city itself, but with the harbour bridge approach right behind you (up the hill) and Sydney Cove and views of the Opera house around every corner, you feel like you are getting an authentic old Sydney experience. Plenty of evidence of the sandstone that this part of Sydney was cut up for and used to build various buildings when the First Fleet arrived, along with the remains of some of the original houses in the area. You can access the stairs up to the Harbour Bridge behind here, as well as enjoy a quite drink or meal at plenty of eating and drinking spots here. Can get a bit feral on Friday night still I suspect.

great place to spend the day. The Rocks is a wonderful area of the city to just hang out. Lots of bars and restaurants. During the weekend they have a market set up in the streets where local vendors sell their stuff. Lots of nice souvenirs, authentic stuff.
Touristy. Visited the Rocks market. Not that great, lots of tacky souvenir stuff and the rest whilst nice was very expensive
History pur. The history of Sydney starts here. Nowerdays you find also galleries, shops, restaurants and cafes. A real tourist attraction
Enjoy a stroll. This area is cobblestone with shops and restaurants - it's nice but not something I would go out of my way to return to see.
A multicultural treat. Saturday afternoon markets, a lovely eclectic mix of stalls and people. Stand still and count how many foreign languages you can hear.
A Rich Experience. Met up with old friends and spent the day cruisin' the Rocks. The choice of food in the area is incredible but "Sailors Thai" is the pick!
Something for everyone. Great little markets and stalls and lots of great things to see and do. Old pubs and cafes to eat in or grab a cofffee or pastry

Full of historical value. The oldest place in Sydney. I love the weekend flea markets where I could find many unique items.
The Rocks also have many old bars and antique buildings. It's a nice place to visit in Sydney
Quaint area. Fun to walk around, see the many shops, and get a bit of liquid nourishment in the pubs. Allow a few hours at least. Easy walk to Circular Quay.

Great market. We visited the rocks on a Sunday and had a really enoyable walk around the market. Not sure if it is there every day, but well worth a visit! Lots of variety, and different cultures, and all good value for money.

Great eating and shopping. A great part of Sydney, take some time to walk around and experience all it has to offer. Take a walk under the bridge, there is a beautiful public park which for the most part is empty of visitor. A great little secret to be shared.

Fabulous Rocks. I loved the cobblestone style of this place with its many unique and romantic little cafes by the waterside calls for great company! It just has a lovely vibe to it with the bridge and the opera house on each side! Awesome place to stroll-by in the sunset!

A Hidden Gem. Most would head for the Opera House and Sydney Harbour Bridge, but forget to visit this place which is at the middle of these 2 Sydney icons. The Rocks is rich in history, has a very lively nightlife and shopping area. It is a must-visit and I recommend picking a hotel in this area as base for a Sydney visit.

Stroll around the historic rocks. Grab some lunch or dinner look in the shops walk around the rocks head towards the Opera house, Circular Quay or Harbour Bridge, such a nice area you could almost forget it's in the heart of busy Sydney,
Aged. Its good to take a walk through the rocks so much to see and some nice places to have a meal and the age of the buildings is great.

Getting a seat at a restaurant here is getting tricky on busy nights. It's getting harder and harder to find food around the rocks. My quest for a good coffee the other Saturday morning endede in tears. Needs more coffee and casual dining venues please!

Nice. Nice place to walk. You can take the stairs to the bridge (free), go to the observatory (amazing view from the garden, and free). Oldest district in Sydney. Nice but mos of restaurants are expensives
Great Food. Its got great food and drinks. A very nice and posh place to be. The bar is great, the ambience is awesome. A bit expensive, but worth it.
Charming & Friendly. My husband and I visit the Rocks once a month. Go on a weekend to visit the markets. We finish each day with pancakes at The Rocks, which has been there for years. Lovely.
The Rocks. probably the best markets around with a huge range of gifts and oddball stuff and great entertainment

Like another town.. I loved the Rocks!
I loved walking around there, looking at all the different buildings and shops.
Enjoyed the market - saw TV celebrities going about the market also.
Popular place. Great location.
Old Sydney at it's best. My favourite part of Sydney. Old, classy and gorgeous boutiques and restaurants. Stay here - loads of nice hotels and a very nice place to stay. Close to everything
Historic. Oozing history and character. So much to see and do. Could meander around for hours and hours. Unmissable.

Too touristy and expensive. The idea of converting the 19th century warehouses into living places is very good and nowadays young people enjoy it much as it is a place where a lot happens with lots of pubs, expensive restaurants, overpriced boutique and souvenir stores all over. The views of Sydney Opera house and to a lesser extent the Harbour Bridge are excellent.

Hero of Waterloo pub.. This is a great Rocks pub with an authentic feel of history. The local who brought me here told me sailors were shanghaied in this pub back in the late 19th century. I don't know if the story is true, but it fits the pub perfectly!

Markets, Back Lanes and Great Pubs. hit up The Rocks on the weekend for the markets, wander down the Nurse's walkway or stop into one of the old pubs. Pricey (b/c it is a tourist area) but well worth it. I have heard the ghost tours are great.

Ambling through the Rocks. Strolling through the early morning area with no one around and watching Sydney coming to life is a wonderful way to start and experience the new day, breakfast taken in a small quaint cafe with the smell of fresh coffee and the bakery The historic places are best seen when no one is in your way and you can amble along at your own pace and enjoy the ambiance of the buildings the sounds and not the mad hectic rush during the rest of the day wonderful must visit

A Happening place, in a great heritage location in the heart of Sydney. This is a heritage district on the waterfront at the rocks, adjacet to the harbour bridge. lots of eateries, pubs and things to see and do, with a quaint buzz happening. A must place to visit, when in Sydney
Fun market. We walked through the market at the Rocks on a Saturday and had a blast looking at all the vendors and sampling fun Aussie foods.
Don't Miss the weekend street fair. Its a little pricey but lots of goodies to see and buy. perfect for those that love crafts and other handmade items as well.
The Aroma festival made the Rocks a lot of fun. There is a great selection of bars restaurants for every budget. I visited Sunday and there were lots of stalls serving food and selling gifts.

Flee market on Weekends is great. Ireally liked the flee market. There's also a german restaurant situated in the corner which has great beer and food too. You can also enjoy different kind of world cousin. Its clean and figurelicking good.

Good shops. A bit touristy but some good art galleries and eateries. Clean, friendly area that feels like what Sydney must have been around a hundred years ago. Some modern structures but must are the old facades and interesting details.
great. lovely setting plenty of nice places to eat. went to the market held weeky. brought some great souveniers

Beautiful historic area. The Rocks is a beautiful historic area - well worth a visit particularly on the weekend when The Rocks Market is operating. It is a really good market with a lot of Australian handmade products sold by the actual designers.We had a great early breakfast in Playfair St where the market starts and then followed it through to up under the Harbour Bridge. Go to the Visitors centre and get a map as there is a lot to see and it is a bit of a rabbit warren with small cobbled streets that are hidden away - alleyways that appear out of nowhere etc. Could also top the day off with. bridge climb - a lot of fun and good shopping!
The Rocks. Lots of quirky shops and great places to eat, use your leg power and walk from Darling Harbour, it is probably a bit more expensive than other places in Sydney
An attractive part of Sydney. Good restaurants here and good shopping, nice character and a good place to have half a day.Visit the Visitors centre which has great info about Sydney.

Enjoy the Ambience. Go on the weekend with an empty stomach when the market is on and enjoy the abundance of street food as you check out the craft and produce. The sausage with sauercraut in a roll with sauce is yum and the cup cake stall provides great dessert choice then finish it off with a beer or coffee at one of the many pubs and coffee shops. With a contented stomach walk it all off with a stroll around to circular Quay. What a great day out.
Great restaurants in the Rocks. We spent quite a bit of time walking around the Rocks. We found it to have a good choice of food, all of which we tastes was fantastic.
Great shops. We love the shops along The Rocks. Be sure to check out the Ariel book shop and the little puppet shop. It's great to explore this area - I head here every time I'm in Sydney.

My favourite drinking holes in Sydney. There is such a variety of pubs in this area,its a must for anyone to go for a night out in Sydney.Pick a pub for live music,aussie charm and locals,an amazing selection of local ales or quiet beer,There are pubs for everyone.Also check out the Rocks markets .Think they are Friday nights and Saturdays and Sundays

If you like history, walk around the Rocks. This it the first place I came to on my first visit to Sydney in 2008. Came back again to walk around the area in 2010. This is the old section of Sydney - an interesting place to spend some time. I highly recommend visiting Susannah Place if you're a history buff.

quaint old waterside neighborhood. the neighborhood has a lot of quaint old victorian buildings from the old harbor shopping days, which have been saved as shops, pubs and restaurants, plus there is a big street market on the weekends.
Good sunday Market. Just loved it. Crafts and delish food in abundance. Lots of history too. A must for any visitor to Sydney.

This was what we expected Sydney to be. Lively, vibrant, fun, beautiful and expensive.
It is a must see place in Sydney, we stayed there and that makes it even better, just walk everywhere

Great food and pub location. We visited the area before and after the Sydney Bridge Climb. We went on a Friday when they have the tents set up selling local goods and food from the nearby restaurants. Had my first gözleme (Turkish savory pastry)...yummy!!!
Great hangout after Bridge Climb. Nice neighborhood, great street market shopping on weekends. This is a convenient stop after the Sydney Bridge Climb.

Great Beer, Great Food, Great Atmosphere,. The Rocks provdies an abundant variety of Pubs, Restaurants and Shop's. The Rocks is a herritage area of Sydney meaning that the majority of the area looks and feels like your back in Old Sydney town. Some area's can be very touristy and therefore expensive but these places arent bad to visit from time to time to mix things up even for the sydney locals. Would be hard not to find something to cater for anyones taste.

Welcome to the Rocks. Get out your walking shoes and explore The Rocks. Plenty of cafes, shops and pubs. There is a street market on Sundays. The G'Day Cafe offers a great breakfast for about $10 (a bargain in expensive Sydney).

Market on Weekends. Enjoy the market on weekends at The Rocks (Saturday and Sunday). It was fun - especially in winter when there were fewer people and the smells of foods hung in the air. Great choice of restaurants and pubs nearby too
Full of character!. A great walk around one the most historic parts of Sydney and well worth a visit
Great views and history here!. Right under the Sydney Harbour Bridge with so many little shops amongst all these historical buildings! Just a short walk form the Opera House
A glimpse into Sydney's past. If you love history, you need to take a walk through the Rocks. And then come back again when the weekend markets are on and enjoy the lively atmosphere!

Neat place to walk around. We've visited Sydney a number of times & have always enjoyed sauntering around the Rocks. Lots of neat shops to look in, lots of interesting history & lots of neat places to eat. A must visit if in Sydney
$$ boys. if you love a gay sex worker or you want a job as one, head down to the rocks

Beautiful area-a must see!. If you're sight-seeing through Sydney, it's not an option to discover the rocks! From the MCA to Pancakes on the Rocks, The Rocks is rich in art,culture, and history. Every Saturday, there are markets on The Rocks that is certainly a must-do with great jewelry,art,clothes,and food vendors!

Great place to visit. Contains places of interest for everyone. Good views, great little shops (I particularly loved the Ken Duncan Gallery), lots of coffee shops, interesting historical spots. Great place for everyone.
Wonderful. The oldest and most historically intact part of the city, something new to find every time
Sydney frozen in Time. What Sydney looked like 100 years ago, pubs restaurants, fine accommodation make the Rocks a must.
Calm in the big city. A wonderful area of central city with lots of nice cafes and shopping. Vibrant at night with nice traditional pubs

Not much to entertain. Apart from the obvious of Sydney harbour bridge the rest is designer shops and expensive hotels. In the day the markets are there but are basic. In the evening there are a few bars but lacks atmosphere

The Rocks Sydney. Try to visit The Rocks on a Saturday when they hold the markets, which have some unusual things. You can stroll around and window shop, sit and have a coffee or glass of wine while people watching.

Best part of Sydney!. The Rocks is the best part of Sydney. It lies right on the Harbour so you have stunning views of the Bridge and Opera House. The market on weekends is great and I have always been able to pick up some gifts to send to family and friends overseas.There is a multitude of restaurants and cafes and bars although it does get crowded on Friday and Saturday nights so make sure you have reservations wherever you are going.The buildings are mostly historic and Nurse's walk has cobblestones so there's a nicer feel to the place.
Love this area. The day we visited the market was on. There were a great selection of handcrafts and souvenirs available. A very relaxing morning.
Great. Another one of those places you can return to and love every time. Lots of different little shops, markets, alleys. A definite must when in town.
surround yourself with Sydney's history. everywhere you look and walk. friendly people, interesting weekend markets, food abounds and a pub on every corner. cheers to Sydney

Great walk in the past.. On an overnight stay in Sydney on our way overseas we once again had a walk in the rain on a Saturday around the "rocks"area. Such a great atmosphere with the markets around Argyle Street area, the smell of food cooking at the stalls, and the variety of goods on offer. The history of this area is palpable, as it has been left with buildings dating back to early settlement and has a very distinct historical feel, great ambiance away from the skyscrapers of today!!

the perfect area in the weekend. The place is full of old buildings, great restaurant and bars and shops and to top it off, there's a market on weekends where you can find a heap of cool clothes or original products.Moreover, you can catch great views of the Bridge, Circular Quay and the Opera House.

We always like older areas. We were here in February and again in April. It is a short walk from Circular Quay but get a map as it can be confusing. There are many shops and places to eat and drink. We went to the Saturday market twice and bought something we hadn't seen anywhere else. There are many interesting products for sale. We walked under the bridge to see the older buildings on the other side, and down many of the side streets in the Rocks, again to see the shops and older structures.

where to go before the theatre. If you don't have much time, but want a nice meal, try Ventuno befoe going to the Sydney Theatre. They often open early on theatre nights so that patrons can dine first. And this is also a great restaurant for dining with friends or family when the weather is good. A beautiul spot on the water.
Nice area of Sydney. It's just nice to walk in that quiet area of Sydney.
Favourite part of the city. Always worth a visit. Try Hart's Bar followed by Pancakes on the Rocks

Tourists please stay here. As a Sydney-sider for 4 years now ... this remains my favourite part of Sydney.Something for everyone - high end restaurants, affordable eats, Sydney's oldest pub, rooftop bear gardens, markets (day and night) ...... what about the views?! Opera House, Sydney Habour Bridge.Endless choice of places to eat, drink and sleep. One of the oldest parts of Sydney, while being close to the action at Circular Quay and the CBD.When I feel like being a tourist in my own city ... I come here. It never disappoints.
disappointing. told all bout it huge hype didnt live up to expectations
Sydney markets. The Rocks is a lovely area of Sydney to just wander around the markets and absorb the atmosphere .
Found an Italian Restaurant great food. Had dinner at a wonderful Italian restaurant excellent food and atmosphere

A family fair. The Sunday rocks markets always have something for the young and the old. Family friendly and get the entire family entertained. The historical buildings are like the icing on top. Would definitely re-visit.

This is where Sydney Town's ghosts hang out!. The Rocks is the old part of Sydney, full of colonial sandstone architecture, hidden winding lanes with names that reveal their original purpose.These days this location has been sexyed up for tourism activities, like restaurants, coffee shops and souvenier shops. This is also where there is a regular weekend Market. The goods on offer are high quality and interesting. The busking is usually of a high standard: I listened to a student opera singer and a quite good pop singer, complete with amplification. The restaurants are a little formulaic and are hell bent on churning those covers through. They are staffed usually by eager young backpackers from all over the world, which makes it interesting. The Rocks seems to be on several levels, literally, so it affords an interesting walking tour. Being right on the Harbour waterfront gives you easy access to other parts of Sydney's harbourside suburbs and attractions, as well as access to the CBD. The Rocks is a Must-Do destination when you visit Sydney. And if you sit quietly while you are having that relaxing coffee as the sun sinks to the West, you may catch a glimpse of some of Old Sydney Town's resident ghost population as they dart between the shadows of some of those old cobblestone lanes.

Favourite spot in Sydney for restaurants and pubs. As a Sydney-sider, this is still one of my favourite spots to hang out. Fill with fabulous restaurants and cobbled-stone streets to markets and pubs, it is fantastic.Fav restaurants along here are Sailor's Thai and Rockpool.The markets on the weekends are fabulous. The pubs are the real-deal!

Markets at the Rocks!. Brilliant! We walked around the markets and they were fantastic! so many stalls to choose from! yummy little things to eat! great cafes and restaurants! jewellery to home wares, they had quality items! second visit to the rocks markets, and i will be back again deffinately!

Quirky, artsy and fun!. Take a stroll through the rocks, check out the markets on every sunday, stop by the little french patisserie/cafe on the corner for some amazing pastries and little treats, and make sure you go to the MCA as well!

The Rocks, Sydney. Nothing special here but a pleasant place for a walk if you have nothing else to do. A lot of restaurants and cafes and walking distance to the major tourist sites such as the Harbour Bridge and Opera House.

Great place to visit with and without children. The Rocks area is full of history, the children love to explore the alleyways and various staircases discovering how early settlers lived.There are plenty of shops, places to eat and have a drink. There are also night and day markets , foodstalls on the weekends and other occasions. It is also a great starting point from which to explore the Harbour foreshore.

The Rocks rock..... great markets yummy food, atmosphere is wonderful, take your time and go exploring . love it. the pubs are great fore a refreshing ale. watch artists paint, listen to buskers. roam the piers.The convict built roads,paths and buildings are fascinating to look at, the bridge is an icon stand on it, under it.great views
Tourism heaven!. Lots of history, interesting shops, a great market with local makers and lots and lots of tourists!

markets and a museum: retail and culture. I always like the Rocks markets, although the proportion of original items is diminishing...although the generic jewellery does seem to sell.I enjoyed the tour of Susannah Place, quirky and nostalgic....no renovations here, the sloping floors and layers of paint and lino bring home the ordinary nature of the terrace houses and I loved reminders of my Nan's home. Highly recommended.
did a pub crawl. the music started in one pub and when they had a break it was a short walk to the next pub for another beer when the next act started.

Great for walking. The Rocks is a fun place for walking and seeing some of Sydney's oldest buildings. If you can find the free walking tour, go for it. The guide only expects a small tip for a lengthy tour. Also try to get to the Rocks for the weekend street market: good food, crafts and momentos for sale for several blocks. This was one of the highlights of our visit.

Great weekend markets. I went with my mum and sister to the Rocks late last Sunday afternoon (around 430pm). We wish we'd got there just one hour earlier, because most of the stall holders started packing up by 5pm. Nonetheless, if we wished to buy or inquire they were most helpful. They have really creative and interesting products, many of them made by hand by the people selling them and the stallholders were so friendly and chatty, it made it a wonderful evening experience.

Go strolling through The Rocks. They have lots of stalls with various booths setup for you to peruse while visiting The Rocks. There are lots of alleys and main streets to explore and various cafes where you can sit down and have a coffee between shops. Also, there are plenty of restaurant to choose from. This section of town has a great vibe and shouldn't be missed if you're visiting Sydney. Take a reusable shopping bag. You're bound to find a treasure or two you'd want to take home with you.

Lovely to stroll around.. I'm a sucker for lovely stone walls with moss, ferns, and other plants growing through the cracks, so this is a beautiful spot to wander around, up and down steps (like the Agar Steps near the Sydney Observatory), in and out of side streets, enjoying balcony gardens of geraniums, palms, ferns, cherry tomato vines, whatever greenery flourishes in shadowed corners or narrow lanes.

A little bit of history. Have always enjoyed this area. Knowing the stories and feeling the history as you walk along cobbled roads is fantastic. Lots of facilities and some great shopping (although pricey)

it has much to say. Fantastic place. It's laneways and sandstone, wrought iron and cobblestone, terraces and old versus new. Explore it on a cold winters' night with nary a living soul about and let old Sydney speak to you.

Fun to visit.. The Rocks area is a lively part of Sydney with shopping and a variety of dining options. It is down near Circular Quay and the harbor so there are always things going on. Worth a visit.
The Rocks. A great place to wander about. Good restaurants and pubs.

So much history. Great place for young and old, Sydney has a great and colourful history and the "Rocks" is the place to learn about it. Many shops and places to eat, great old and new buildings and all beside the harbour and under the bridge. you will not be disappointed!
Took my Grandson. Great place when the markets are open, the kids love it.

Great by day and night. The richs is a great place to head through the day, particulary for famalies because thereis lots to do, and lots of history to learn about.The rocks is predominatly heritage listed so it gives a good look into old Sydney (although its not that old).At night there are a lot of good bars, and there is something for everyone depending on what you are looking for.

A cool and vibrant area of Sydney to check out. This is a cool and vibrant area of Sydney to check out and I was taken here by a local who spent much of her university days in The Rocks. Some great bars and shops and a really good buzz about the place. Highly recommended!
Very nice area of Sydney. The Rocks are a very interesting area with great restaurants and view of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge.

The Best of many things. This has plenty of appeal, bars, cafes markets and the shopping all in one area that gives you hours of pleasure, the german beer cafe is fun, a stein will not go amiss here, 2 get you going or visit a small boutique wine bar, there is plenty of choice
Fabulous Walk. This is a nice area to walk while visiting downtown Sydney!!!
Rocks or Stone?. Initially, I thought that can see Rock (stone) at this area. Instead, I found church, restaurant, some street event and couldn't find any rock stone.
The Rocks Rock. Fantastic place, so diverse will lots of shops and restaurants. Can't wait to go back there
have to go. very interesting area. a lot of restaurants, bars, pubs. Definitely have to go.

Nice area for a pub crawl in Sydney !. If you want an area in the city for a few beers and atmosphere, then the rocks is the place. Nice bars, European style, and worth a look. Also at the back of the rocks, there is a hidden gem of a bar like The Hero of Waterloo.....
Wandering the Rocks. The Rocks is a great place to just wander around. It houses some of Sydney's hidden history. There are great little shops and fantastic outdoor markets on the weekend.

Rocks outdoor market rocks.. Definitely make a trip when the outdoor markets are on Friday and Saturday I think. Amazing food, interesting stalls and wonderful atmosphere, talented buskers, sublime smells and fun people.

Rekindling old memories. Had been to Sydney 12 years ago so wanted to retrace our steps so re-visited the refurbished Harbour Rocks Hotel were we got a nice welcome from the staff the place is so different now but great it's a wonderful location just in Harrington Street. For a cosy pub that's been there for years we called in to Fortune of War it was just the same and had a lovely meal in the Rockpool.
Visit the Past. A lovely area to wander around in and shop, have a drink something to eat learn about Sydneys past history.
Loved it. Had a great time strolling around the rocks, check out the weekend markets.
A trip back in time. Enjoyed walking through the buildings, the market , the archeological site and the museums. The cobbled stones, laneways, stairs, and houses, it 's a terrific open museum.
Wonderful unusual merchandise. Some of the most beautiful handcrafted items I have seen for a while. Great to talk to the artists
Pancakes!. Real tasty. Nice area of town. Good sized pancakes. Savoury food was just okay, it's the pancakes you should go for.
The past is the present. So rich in history and the buildings make you feel you have stepped back in time...Love the pubs at the Rocks because the character has not changed over time

NO REAL WHEELCHAIR ACCESS. If you are a wheelchair user, take care if you are interested to visit The Rocks which it is not very wheelchair accessible. What I could see was very famous and it is really something to see... but most of restaurants, streets, and boutiques there do not provide any access to wheelchairs. About restaurants, most of them are very expensive: more than the other parts of Sydney.

Awesome markets here.. Friday is just food markets but Satudays and Sundays til 10pm is Arts and Crafts and various nationalities cooking up their specialties. Very Yummy !!If you do visit the markets a must see is the funny boys making the rock candy in one of the acades. The owners name is Richard. Tell him the heart of Brisbane sent you !! He'll get a good giigle out of it.
Rock~. Great fun place to hung out with friends where not just for the tourist :P local bar, eating out, markets, touring around. Just fabulous!
Well Worth a Visit. Charming area with restaurants and bars, right at the water. Gives the harbour much character.P.S. Watch out for the cockroaches along the road at night, though! :)
Lovely part of town. This is a beautiful part of town and a real surprise to me as a first time visitor to the city, wish we'd had longer to have a better look around
Nice restaurants. We ate here a few times. Lovely Indian and a fantastic Thai!

Nice Area. We were able to walk from our Hotel to The Rocks, it was interesting to see where early settlers lived, some of the area is not in great repair.However most of the Rocks area is being kept in very good condition and is well worth a visit, We didn't go into the Museum because we didn't have enough time, but we will visit it in the future.
An Look into Historic Sydney. Convict settlements and beautiful buildings aline all the streets right under the city and Harbour Bridge.
excellent night life. lots of bars and restaurants great views and the Irish bars are amazing , the music is lively and the night life is great well worth a visit.
Interesting walk glad it was saved.. Lots of small shops, interesting history, too commercial for me but worth a visit,
Great place for a Saturday Morning. The Rocks market on a Saturday morning is a great place for local shopping and eating brunch. Also good in the evenings with some great restaurants.

An awesome area.... ...and a perfect place from which to stay and see Sydney from. It's within easy walking distance to Circular Quay from which you can catch a ride on many convenient forms of public transportation. Also within walking distance is everything you came to Sydney to see in the first place, including the Harbour Bridge and the Opera House
History at The Rocks. Lovely old buildings and streets to wander around. Markets on weekends.

Explore the maze. Some of the most interesting parts of The Rocks need to be discovered on foot, with both eyes open. Be prepared to go through back alleys and old stairways. You will need to be nimble and fit to do this! There are too many commercial "tourist traps" in the highly visible areas. Get some guidance from the tourist office to fully appreciate it. Remember to look at the ground for interesting (and sometimes humourous) historical markers. Visitors should be careful in some places after dark. There is trouble lurking for visitors and locals. Day visits are safe for anyone.

The Rocks: Downtown Sydney back in Time. The Rocks, on the southern shore of Sydney’s inner harbour, is the place where the city began, established in 1788 after the colony’s formation. Convicts, colonialists, sailors, hookers, and all manner of disreputable and dubious characters lived in this quarter and many of the old sandstone buildings, after which it’s named, from that era have been fixed up as hotels, pubs, restaurants, and shops, as well as galleries for local art. We wandered through the narrow cobblestone streets, following the Nurses and Surgeons Walk, and spent some time in the Rocks Museum looking at the artifacts taken from the old houses. A small section of the museum provided material for creating one’s own display and so my partner left behind a classic British Columbian memento, an inukshuk out of stones. Several plaques along the way give information about the history of the buildings.We also tried some vertical planking in interaction with the local art works. The colonial buildings here have been beautifully restored and many have been converted into art galleries and craft shops. One harbourside building, a three story structure formerly used as a sailors’ dorm, is now a gallery featuring the work of Sydney artist Charles Billich; the building is fabulous. There are many restaurants and pubs and the area is close to the Harbour and the Observatory. See more info and pictures here: http://lmaclean.ca/2011/10/downtown-sydney-the-rocks-sydney-observatory-and-chinatown/
What history. To be able to see and touch history like that was special, great markets to top it off
Walk back in History. Step back in time and see the old traditional buildings and unusual shops and bars. Great place for just wandering around.
Beautiful. Theres always something going on at the Rocks. Wander down for a beer at a pub, visit the markets, have lunch, or just look at the old buildings.
interesting spot. Make sure in go down all the side streets ,lots of hidden gems tucked away.Love the history and general feel of the place.Pubs get packed though.

A memorable weekend market trip. It was a Saturday,as we came early the crowd was small thus very easy to walk around.The locally made products sold at the market were of very high quality at reasonable price.From The Rock,we walked to the waterfront 5 minutes away.We really enjoyed the sceneries of 2 Australia's icons,Sydney Opera House and Sydney Harbour Bridge .We took good shots of these 2 icons from the Waterfront.

Great Saturday Morning at The Rocks. To fill in some time on the morning after checkout my boyfriend and I headed down to The Rocks, only a short stroll from our hotel on Jameson Street. We had breakfast at Pancakes on the Rocks and it was delicious! After than we went looking through the adjacent stores and bought a few items at the Candle Factory - so many gorgeous things to choose from! Then we headed out into the infamous Rocks Markets and bought a funky floor lamp, a framed original film cell and an artwork from from Darren Germain, the artist who does his spray paint art live in from of the crowds - he is amazing!!! I also boughta cute vintage style dress from one of the vendors there. My tip is to go with plenty of cash! We were there early and were the first sale of the day for the floor lamp vendor and as we were paying by EFTPOS we had to come back in 10 minutes after he had set up his machine.
