Also, some vendors don't take card - we ended up finding some cash in our wallets/pockets to pay for our spray paint artwork - otherwise he would have had to do the transaction through his friend the Glassblower. So they do have systems in place to take card but it's a bit of effort!! I really wanted some hot corn on the cob and some chocolate dipped strawberries and some caramel peanuts.... but we didn't have any cash! Oh well, I didn't really need them.....

Don't miss the Argyle for a drink and a casual meal.. The Rocks has upmarket shops and boutiques, but its worth the walk and do have lunch or dinner at the Argyle and visit their very interesting rest rooms before moving on!
Must see. Restored buildings, lots of atmosphere, rather relaxed compared to the center

Beautiful stroll during Vivid Sydney. We didn't know that Vivid Sydney was taking place at the same time we were there. Walking through the Rocks and seeing all the lights on the buildings along the cobblestone streets was quite memorable and a highly recommended experience. I'm sure this area is pretty any time of year, but Vivid Sydney adds a bonus wow factor that is unforgettable.

You could go here heaps of times and still be happy...HEAPS. My wife and I love hanging out here and though many talk about the pubs and such, theres always an atmosphere that'll hit the spot, whether family outing, night out with the fellas or even a church group outing haha. My wife and I have enjoyed heaps of Saturday afternoons just sitting with a cold drink from one of the many cafes and enjoying the nice views of the harbour and the bridge. At night it can get a bit annoying with the clubbers and pub-crawlers coming out and getting pissed but if your into that then this is another good (albiet pricey) spot to hit up. We love it in the summer time and often there are little concerts or events going on outside that keep you busy. Good times indeed!

great beer. be sure to go to the top of the shangri la hotel for a terrific sunset view and cocktail...we went in our shorts and tshirts, as many others did, and felt right at home. drinks range from $10 to $10,000!

Nice little cafes, Average market. Love the few cafes i went like Guylian, and the cake shop just next to it (sorry i can't remember the name... just recalled is "Le xxxxx at Courtyard". )THe cakes there were fantastic though staff service were just average compared to the good friendly services i received elsewhere! Went to both the Night market and Saturday market... not overly impressed... personally prefer the wider range of stores and products available at Paddington's market...

An iconic Australian site, but sadly it has become very commercial!!. I find the Rocks area very commercial, the scenic aspect is awesome but sadly I feel the area has been overrun with tourist shops. The walk around to the Opera house is excellent and there is some excellent eateries in this area.
Always something new. Stayed in the area for 8 nights and every day discovered a new shop or restaurant . Plenty of redeveloped historical building to take in as well.
A historical site of Sydney. I love the Rocks on a Sunday, there are so many stalls selling all kinds of food and handcrafts.
Go see The Rocks. Make sure you go and visit Susannah Place - Sydney's version of The Tenement museums in New York and Glasgow.

Great market on Sat/Sun. The market at the Rocks is a great place to go, especially on a Sunday morning early. Large number of stalls offering interesting items, many made in Australia. Some items a bit pricey, and you can get better prices on scarves ( 69$ vs 125$) inside the building where the information centre is.

Fun and interesting right in the heart of Sydney.. The rocks are a great place to wander about and take in the sights of the city. On Sundays there is a big craft market and its full of local artists and craftsmen selling lots of Australian souvenirs to take home with you. There are also wonderful views of the Opera house and Harbour bridge from the rocks.

Great place to wander. The Rocks is well worth an hour or two to explore. There are many guided tours which really explain the history of the area and are well worth a few dollars to understand what you are looking at. The Rocks Discovery Museum (free) is definitiely worth visiting whilst in the area. It can be a bit hard to find though - so perservere!

Great Food, Great Markets and Great History. The Rocks has many hidden gems including the Susannah place museum, which captures life in Sydney over the years. It's not far to the Observatory or Harbour or Bridge Climb and there are great restaurants, my favourite The Mercantile, an Irish pub under the bridge on the market street. They do the best menu and have a real taste of Ireland.

The best part of Sydney!. The Rocks is just the best place for a wander in and out of shops and if you time it right (Sunday) there is a great street market with artists spray painting as you watch - a great holiday souvenir

Fun area but touristy. Some things you have to do no matter what, and The Rocks is one of those in Sydney. You won't find the best meal or best bar, and the shops are very souvenir oriented and over-priced, but you have to visit the Rocks. Definitely go to Philip's Foote as well and cook your own steak!
Characterful with good range of restaurants. The old buildings and close proximity to circular key are great, the range of restaurants and range of prices available are also great.

Definitely go on the weekend and look at the markets. The Rocks are a beautiful historic part of Sydney and a definite 'must see' for anyone visiting Sydney! If you visit on the weekend, you can wander through the Rocks Markets, which have an amazing array of food, jewellery, knick knacks and clothes.
A great little jewel in the middle of Sydney. A must in Sydney especially the markets or the nice french patisseries...
Historical site. get a sense of sydney's beginning as you prowl along one of the cities' most treasured historical area. weekends are a good time to visit coz of the weekend bazaar.

Wonderful place. The Rocks is an interesting place to visit for food, hotels, retail stores, markets, and historical value. If you want to go on historical walks make sure you book through your hotel so as not to miss them (walking tours) I'm sure you will find it very interesting. You can also get on a boat trip and meal around the harbour on the ""Bounty"in full sail from the Rocks wharf and I recommend this one to all
LOVE THE ROCKS. I love the Rocks. Cute little alleyways, lots of history, great markets on a Friday and fabulous restaurants.

Lots of fun!!. Stayed at Shangri-La Hotel right there at The Rocks. Many smaller and fun restaurants, clubs, shops, and wine bars. The "old" part of Sydney that is a great place to visit with its heritage buildings and trendy restaurants, pubs, and bars.
Great shopping and restaurants. A fun place to walk around. So many tempting eateries to chose from.
Historic. One of the oldest areas in Sydney and a great place to visit. The markets are on every weekend. Plenty of places to explore and plenty of places to eat and drink.

Fabulous neighborhood. Fabulous Sydney cultural neighborhood full of history, great restaurants, galleries, and shopping. The views of the harbour are fantastic and the vibe is lively. Highly recommend spending some time in this very fun area.

Interesting history and great views. I love The Rocks. I love the cobblestone streets, the wonky buildings, the history, and especially, the arts market. Go for a walking tour through The Rocks and then visit the Susannah Place Museum.
Love the Rocks! Love the oldness of the town. The old pubs etc. Always love to stroll around the rocks. Check out the market if they are on. Love the restaurants.
It was great night out. Currently, there is Vivid exhibition and due to this The Rocks had a night market - I love night markets. It was a great night out and lovely architectures.

Nice historic area. The Sunday market at the Rocks has great local products. A little pricey because it is target on the tourist. Really nice area to hang out with an old English/Italian nostalgic feel to this historic precinct.

Wonderful. Historic, lively, wonderful nightlife. What more could you want? I went often with friends but also took a full tour with a guide and found it fascinating. The history is just incredible. A must see in the city!
Historic Rocks. So much to do, weekend Markets, Ghost tours or just wander through all the alleys and find yourself a fantastic cafe or restaurant - the Rocks is the place to be in Sydney
Go on the weekend for the markets. There were a lot of temporary markets set up in the area on the weekend! Some very cute little shops that were not there during the week.

restored perfectly. unlike many places in the world that have been disneyfied, The Rocks in Sydney was restored beautifully. Architecturally it is stunning. Its a perfect place to go for a walk, have a meal at one of many great restaurants and a fantastic weekend market that can be missed.
FULL OF ATMOSPHERE. You can feel the heritage and atmosphere of years gone by just by walking around The Rocks. Plenty to see and do

Original settlement. This is apparently where the first settlement was and is now pubs, cafes, craft stalls etc. I wasn't there at the busiest of times but it certainly has atmosphere. The Contemporary Art Museum is worth a visit for the view from the top floor terrace over Circular Quay. I have to say that I thought the contemporary art was a joke - one of which was just confetti scattered on the floor and window sill.A bit more surreal is the Ken Done Art Gallery just up the road. It's colourful and very popular but if you want to buy any, arrange the bank loan before you go.Best of all is just sitting in the small park at the entrance to the Rocks looking out over Circular Quay and drinking in the atmosphere.

Rocks I need more time. We did a free evening tour of the Rocks. It was interesting but I feel they need to become a little more professional about what they offer. It is desired that you offer a renumeration at the end. The Rocks is a fasinating place lots of history and marvellous old buildings. Some wonderful shops ( tourist information centre needs more knowledge) interesting markets,
Markets enjoyable but up-market prices. Enjoyed wandering around The Rocks Markets but didn't find it the place for a bargain as prices were up-market (but the quality was good also!)
Australia's oldest pub here.. A walk around the rocks is a hoot. Old pubs and funky restaurants. Easy access to Harbor Bridge from there.
Still well worth seeing, but increasingly built up. The wonderful old buildings are still there, but the views are now more blocked by recent building.

history and culture - new and old. The Rocks has a great story - walk around either in a paid tour or on your own and then stay and enjoy the changes that happen as night falls. Great places to eat and shop and enjoy.
Plenty to see and do. I work in Sydney city area , near The Rocks. Even after all these years, The Rocks still offer plenty to see and do, especially now the Vivid Show is on. A must see.
Love Love Love. I love just walking around.... The building and little hidden restaurants. I also feel I am missing something...

Hidden secret after hidden secret. Take the time to visit the Rocks and you won't be disappointed. We visited the markets and were treated to a big range of tasteful items from handcrafts to artworks. There are a large number of cafes and restaurants - just take your pick! The prices are a bit high but I imagine so are the overheads. The history of the Rocks is ever present and even if you don't spend a cent, you will go away richer.
Atmosphere. We went to the rocks just before Xmas and it was so great. It was cheaper than taking the kids to Europe and nearly as good.
Great deals on attractions!. A lot of history, spectacular views, incredible people and tons of unique food choices.

A trip back in time!. This area of Sydney makes the trip worthwhile. The preservation of the old buildings is precious. Australia is a young country from a European perspective so there is little in terms of older architecture which has survived since the arrival of the First Fleet. The Rocks has it in spades. It is also a vibrant hub of the city with plenty of retail outlets, eating and drinking establishments and the arts. It is wonderfully located in relation to some of Sydneys icons like the Opera House, Harbour Bridge and the gallery of Contemporary Art. It is also readily accessible by public transport be it by bus, train or water. Sundays in The Rocks are particularly interesting with street stalls and often, street theatre. Despite having some more expensive eating places it is also able to offer very inexpensive and good dining experiences. It is a good place to pick up some souvenirs and gifts from Sydney particularly on Sundays or indeed other days of the week.
Interesting to walk around. Consider doing a walking tour or just get a map and wander around especially if it a nice day..many interesting shops.
i like the rocks nice bars and restaurants. bars , restaurants, view , location harbour .. close to sydney cbd, ease of transport.

Shaken, not stirred!. This is one of the oldest parts of the city. You can get a sense of what It must be like in the past. Cobbled stone streets, rustic heritage buildings. They say this was a rough neighborhood back in those days, but today there are lots of interesting shops and museums to explore. However, like any touristy areas, the food was a bit expensive!

It's a must you should visit.. Integrated to the harbor area there are museums, antiques and even the oldest pub in Sydney. Pathways, stairs and little close walks makes a nice place to spent a whole day finding out the precious of the hidden treasures in the oldest part of town.
Nice Walk. Small enough to walk around and take your time whilst also getting an idea of what to plan your time around on trips with lots of food available.
Lots of history.. A timeless feel here. Loved the aboriginal shops, cafes, the market days. We came twice.

The Rocks markets are worth a visit. We always try and have a Saturday or Sunday in Sydney just to reacquaint ourselves with this area especially the Rocks markets. Lots of original crafts and arty things to see and buy. The whole area though commercialised is still steeped in history of what life must have been like for the early settlers arriving in this area. Previously we have done a night ghost tour of this area which was one of the better spooky tours we have done

Don't miss the markets. The Rocks District is a prime tourist destination in Sydney for good reason - it has charm, history and a great deal of variety. If you have control over your schedule, be sure to go to The Rocks on one of the market days - Fridays from 10-4 features the food market, with a more general market Saturday (10-5) and Sunday (10-4). It's colorful and hugely entertaining with a lot of opportunities to see some native crafts without going to a more tourist-oriented shop

Brilliant!. We didn't really get enough time here but lovely buildings, great markets, lots of variety and creativity in the items sold here. Great place to eat as the views are amazing. Lots of choice.

Shop for souveniers here. We bought an abroginal puzzle to remind us of our trip to Australia. There are numerous flea market shops on the weekend to purchase a wonderful souvenier for yourself. We also visited the museum to aquaint ourselves with the history.

Spend time walking around The Rocks. The Rocks is the town in the heart of Sydney with historic buildings, shops and restaurants. On Sunday, the Market in the Rocks is not to be missed. Enjoyed the roasted corn on a stick while browsing the booths. I particularly enjoyed the man from The Licorice Shop. He is in a stall just outside the main area and insists on serving samples of all of the different types of licorice he sells. Absolutely lovely to talk to and enjoyed his delicious treats. Bought several containers as gifts as Australian licorice is known to be the best.Also, while in the Rocks, I strongly suggest you go to the Museum of Contemporary Art. The exhibits are varied and interesting. There is no admittance fee to the museum. While there, go upstairs for lunch. The restaurant on the top floor overlooks all of Sydney Harbour - not to be missed!

Great History. Great place for history buffs, the place is packed with the history of Sydney, very clean area. Nice old building. There is a lot of stairs to walk so pace yourself accordingly. Cannot miss a visit if you are in Sydney. There are some free walking tours there where the guide works for tips.

Only if you have time. This area has a little sense of history but really you have to be interested. Some shops including upmarket ones mixed in with souvenirs. Too touristy for us but you could take look if you have time on your hands.
Another world at the Rocks. I loved the quaintness of the Rocks, and the history, but was disappointed that there weren't many old buildings open to get a sense of the history.

Good for the market + cafes. The place to go if you feel like spending some cash - lots of characterful market stalls - with everything from liquorice to jewellery. Lots of cafes and options for a coffee, or glass of something stronger.

Nice but.... The rocks are a nice Area to visit for 1rst time Sydney visitors, since they´re more or less the oldest part of the city, with lots of pubs, shops (souvenir & others) and are close to the other main attractions harbour bridge & Opera house anyway. Very touristy though & during the peak season somewhat overrun.
history food souvenir views. The french patisserie is to die for. Get lost walking through the back lanes, make a point to stand under the bridge and go to the MAC museum

Old World Charm in modern city. Not too many places left in Sydney that offer so many historic buildings next to each other. Take a walk there on a sunny day and enjoy the wonderful atmosphere. Always full of people, locals and tourists alike. Heaps of places to eat, boutiques galore and of course fantastic views of the harbour. Whenever we have visitors from overseas we recommend The Rocks as a 'must-see'

Great Night Out. Really nice night out, a bit pricey in comparison to other areas in Sydney but your paying for its location and the fact its big with tourists. Some nice bars and restaurants in this area but make sure your have enough cash on you if you want a decent night out.

OK if you have the cash!. My wife visited Sydney in 2001 and was disappointed with the Rocks on her return visit in January this year.Most of the pubs have turned into gastro wine bars with equivalent prices, the restaurants are expensive but I have to say the atmosphere in the Rocks is great. The Aborigines who perform on Circular Quay are fantastic and worth a visit.If you go to Sydney visit the Rocks but see my review of the Lord Nelson pub if you want good food and good beers

Fun in the sun (perhaps not in the rain!). Interesting, highly scenic, but costly area. We did not find any reasonably priced restaurants. The weekend outdoor shopping stalls with locally made items was a pleasant surprise.
OK but a bit too touristy. I enjoyed walking around The Rocks on a lovely afternoon but was a little disappointed in the trashy style tourist shops which are dotted around.

Interesting & historical. Happened upon a Rocks walk map in the little Rocks Discovery Museum. It led us for a walk that ensured we missed nothing of the historical areas of The Rocks. Most worthwhile and enjoyable few hours.
The rocks walkabout.. Loved the ambience of the place. It was a sunday and the markets were in full swing. Great to sightsee. Love the place.

History + art + gourmet experiences = yes. Walk for only two minutes in this iconic area and you'll feel the history. Rich with beautiful buildings and the small interesting museum that educated us as to our convict heritage, The Rocks has a lot to offer.We partcicularly like the gourmet night markets where we bought produce from Orange and met the farmers who are selling their albours of love.Check what is on at The Museum of Contemporary Art (MCA) and the cafe there is fronting the harbour.Expect to pay more in most cafes and restaurants in the area.Walk round to the uber glam Park Hyatt for a cocktail, a meal or even a night or two there!

Weekend Market. Speak with your hotel about the weekend market in The Rocks. It is amazing and has so many vendors. We did not know about this before we went and were told by chance. When we arrived I feel in love. It has a great vibe and is a great way to sample food while shopping for the perfect gift or souvenir.
History all around.. This old part of Sydney has lots of character and interesting shops. @ hours well spent.
Excellent Tour Guide Made the Difference. If you like history, this is a great area to visit. Also filled with some very neat pubs and beer gardens.

Unique!. The Rocks area of Syndey is a excellent example of early Sydney architecture. Much of the early architecture has been retained and visitors can spend a full day walking around exploring shops and enjoyng the views
great for restaurants. the rocks is a lot bigger than we had thought, lots of restaurants and bars to choose from!! nice for a stroll about

Ok for tourists!. But what about us mere locals?
Touristy, expensive & just nothing there for us!
A few ok cafes, nothing to brag about. Needs a major overhaul & new life injected into the area.

beautiful...just not pram friendly. A beautiful part a Sydney to see. Rich in history and tastefully renovated in parts. Not particularly 'kid friendly' - don't bother taking a pram if you really want a good look around. Worth the effort for a few hours though.

Beautiful Photo Opportunities. The Rocks is full of history and beautiful old buildings and it is wonderful walking around the cobblestone laneways, There are many photo opportunities of both the buildings and Sydney Harbour, The Harbour Bridge & The Opera House. On the weekends there is The Rocks Markets, it gets very busy but is always nice to have a wander through with vendors selling an assortment of unique items.My husband, toddler & I were there on Sunday so that I could try out my new camera and we could all enjoy the beautiful Sydney weather. Unfortunately, they are doing some work near the bridge pylon on The Rocks side which made it difficult to walk around with the pram - hubby ran ahead to check which was the best way to go and we ended up having to double back on where we came from. It may also be difficult for wheel chairs or the elderley.
A stroll. Unfortunately heavy showers of rain spoilt an interesting walk around this part of the city,being rescued by a bus to get back to near central and my hotel.

Great historic place to visit. We walked around the Rocks and took in all the old buildings. I would recommend getting a tour guide so they can quickly tell you what each place is all about. A must see for those interested in Aussie history!
quaint. The rocks is the old part of Sydney where the settlers were.There is a great market there
excellent. We walked around just after sunrise, excellent, very peaceful, great location for taking photos and the cockatoos followed us too.
Gotta go.. Lots of history--this is were the convicts lived! Nice clubs, restaurants, interesting area

A Must Just to See. This is the older section of Sydney but is not old comparatively for travelers from other parts of the World. Of course, it has been designed for tourists but has tried to avoid many of the touristy traps. There a good choice of restaurants, shops and amenities in the area, unfortunately with the higher tourist prices. The new Museum Od Modern Art opened when we were there so had the advantage of the additional buzz in the area. A nice, clean and welcoming "Old Sydney" section part of town.
nice time. the rocks was worth a visit. nice to walk around, great restaurants and pubs.
Love this area. This is a great place to visit. The markets on the weekend are well worth a visit.
alive. when we returned to Sydney the second time we stayed in the Rocks area full of life and great area and good resturants.
Holiday Down Under. This is a must see for travelers. A lot of history in the area. Shopping was good and the restaurants were nearby. Great place.

Our favorite haunt in the city. Come meander around these streets, go under the rocks of the bridge support, and take so many pictures of Circular Quay, the Sydney Bridge, and the iconic Opera House. Yes, there are many tourists, cruise ships, and shops-but you can still find quiet pedestrian streets to explore!
rocking!. I went at a wrong time. late evening so was not able to take good snaps.. but a very nice view from all around.Try "The Rocks" cafe for Kangaroo burgers and great aussi wine...

Get yourself lost in the Rocks. The Rocks is an iconic location for Sydney and for travellers. Come here during the day and enjoy the rich history of Sydney's past. When the sun goes down, there are pubs, restaurants, and a number of cafes to pick to enjoy a great meal. A highly recommended spot to bring your relatives and friends from interstate/overseas. Don't forget your camera!
Needs a face lift. The Rocks area is still a lovely location but the area needs sprucing up and some of the restaurants are closed.
A must do. A lovely place to wander around and climb the steps, nice small shops and heritage

great place to explore. loved it all. the history abounds, the coathanger over head, the wonderful markets, the friendly people, the great coffee, amazing food options. the little lane ways, the unique shopping. it was all so good that we spent a full two days just exploring the rocks area. we also had the best breakfast in a little spanish style cafe, unfortunatley i cant recall the name, sorry. we will go back

A gem. It's delightful to wander the streets to see the history that still lurks there. Lots of historical buildings have plaques to detail their history etc. the Rocks markets are also fun to explore.

Quaint little area.. The unfortunate part about the Rocks is that the lovely buildings are all blocked from the bay by the new glass terminal. We went there during the set up stages of the Sunday morning market. It was pleasant walk, but nothing really special since the tourist enticing element was quite apparent. Nice walk, but can always give it a miss!
Special. Lovely Market on the week-end, good pubs and restaurants right throughout, wonderful waterviews, just lovely

Our favorite area in Sydney!. The Rocks is such a unique area in Sydney; three out of our four dinners were here ("Pony", "The Cut", "Caminetto") as well as the art gallery that we purchased our authentic Aboriginal art from.

Visiting The Rocks. The Rocks is a must visit for tourists to experience the best shopping in Sydney. The area offers a wide variety of stores at decent prices that are sometimes "negotiable." The back drop of the Harbor creates a very relaxing atmosphere.

Old, but worth a look around if you have time.. The rocks is worth walking around if you have some extra time. There are also a few markets that are here on weekends, which would add value. All told though, it didn't do much for me personally and I would recommend spending more time in Darling Harbor or the Botanic Gardens

Good view and good shopping. On a pleasant morning stroll at The Rocks, we chanced across The Rocks Markets which offered many different homemade foods and crafts for sale. A good place for tourists looking for something different to take home.
Great. Good food and shopping. I loved the book shops, foodie haunts and snazzy clothes
Walking through the Rocks. The Rocks, Lovely place Old World. Oldest part of Sydney. Stopped at the Australian Hotel for the best becon pizza I think we have ever had. Plenty of shops and bars.

Touristy area. The Rocks is a must visit because of the history of the place (too much history to go into here - search "the rocks" and see for yourself). Plus you can get a beautiful view of surrounding Sydney. Stop for a beer in one of the many pubs after roaming around Sydney and surrounds for hours and hours! We were expecting more from it after folks told us we should go. We were there on a market day so it was extremely busy. The market was great if that's what you like, but it was really just more of the same you see in markets wherever you travel.
A great place to wander..... Lots of cool little shops and very quaint setting!
A Piece of History. Walking around here was like being taken back in time. On weekends, there's a great market here!
Explore. Nice to walk around and see all the sights and lots and lots of great bars and eateries.Our favorite hangout

Well worth a look. I looked this area of Sydney. We visited on a Saturday and there was a street market (not sure if this is every day) which was fun. Also a really old part of the city reminding you of how the city might once have looked.
Love the history. Has one of the best views of the Harbour bridge and the markets are vibrant and colourful , It is a very good place to take oversea visitors

What a lovely place to wander around. This is one of my favourite places to wander around. It has a real buzz about it, but minimal road traffic. The buildings and tiny alleyways reflect the early history of Sydney, and the range of eateries means that you are sure to find something that pleases the mood. The markets on sundays are a great place to find goodies and trinkets or good quality items to take home.
markets!. very nice market with little crafty/homemade stuff. very entertaining for a saturday morning. lots of nice cafe too.

My favorite Restauant in Sydney. I have loved the restaurant for a long time fantastic menu and the service is always great atmosphere the best. It is not a cheap meal especially with wine but a great treat and well worth the spend.

Weekend visit only. Crowded with lots of flea markets during the weekends. During the week nothing much going on. Same for restaurants. May have to wait 1-2 hours on weekends while during the week could walk right in.
Nice walk with lots of pubs. cool place to hang out within walking distance of the famous Sydney opera house and the bridge

Very well preserved. I was last at the Rocks area 21 years ago so interesting to go back and pleased to say it is now a far nicer area, restoration has been incredibly sympathetic and it has a charm that is totally unique in Sydney, I think the area takes on its own charm at night with the area having a real buzz with cool bars, lovely restaurants, beautiful shops and cafes, such a nice place just to stroll around and you always have the great views of the bridge and opera house at every other turn. You could spend hours just wandering around the many streets in the rocks, no trip to sydney would be complete without some time spent here
Nice place and foods... Still open even at late night, lots of foods to order, waitresses are nice and a very big place...

Small little niche craft market. Partner & I had our first Aussie market experience here and it wasn't disappointing at all. Visited on St Patrick's Day so there was a crowd queueing up at the adjacent but there's still enough space for everyone! Definitely pass by here while touring the harbour side and then grab a bite at the corn stall at the end of the market, garnished with chicken salt, pepper and a generous amount of butter (they even provide tissue boxes!)

Old Sydney at its best. If you travel to Sydney and avoid the Rocks you have missed part of Sydney's history. Simply walking through the many streets and seeing some of the older buildings is really worth the effort. Many of the buildings were constructed out of local sandstone and the name 'The Rocks' became the endearing term for this area. You will want to visit Cadman's Cottage (a sandstone structure that was built in 1815-16 as the ‘Coxswain’s Barracks’ ); Campbell's Warehouse or Stores (the only surviving warehouse of their type at Sydney Cove) and the Lord Nelson. These are just a few of the many fine buildings. Allow at least a minimum of a a half day so that you can leisurely walk around this historic area and feel the history. Don't forget to try an ale or two at the many fine hotels.
Nicely preserved. A real effort has been made to ensure that this area retains the charm of the early city. There is a very interesting market as well as various cafes and bars.
Average, will not go again unless for other reason. To me, very average. It is like you need to visit some famous places in your life, but once is enough.
Sydney - The Rocks. This region provides a good glimpse of the Old Town. Also, it provides beautiful views of Harbour Bridge and Opera House

Lots of History, quaint town. There are lots of different dining options, shopping and the weekend markets. Within walking distance of The Quay, and with views of Sydney Harbour and The Opera House, makes the Rocks a great place to visit.

The Rocks Rock!. A fantastic place to visit, especially on the weekend when the Rocks Market is on. Lots of unusual stalls selling Australian souveneers.... There are some lovely food stalls there if you are hungry. Guylan has a shop there, lovely to sit outside on a nice day with a hot chocolate and muffin. If you prefer alchohol with your food, try the german restaurant/beer garden. Check out the Nurses Walk, little speciality shops there like the button shop. If you walk behind the pub in the middle of the Rocks market, you can see the remains of the old houses that used to be there, check out how small they were. Keep walking up the stairs,turn left, go past the pub, cross the road and you will eventually reach the harbour bridge entrance just to the right of the zebra crossing. Enjoy......
Nice, quiet historic town centrally located.. Walking distance to Circular Quay, bus and train stations, Queen Victoria Building, Museum, Darling Harbour, China town.

Nostalgic. Lots and lots of shops ranging from exclusive to tourist stuff. Architecture is worth a look with meandering streets and new things to see arround every corner. Some great reasonably priced food outlets as well. really do need a map to know where you are going however. Don't even think about drive and park. Use the trains and buses. Really efficient and easy to use. I gotta say however that the level of service provided in Australia is consistently poor. More about flogging you stuff you don't need and what they have handy rather than staff listening to what you want. Wanted to buy some specific fragrances from a number of high end outlets and they didn't have what I wanted, could direct me to where I might get what I wanted, no product knowledge about what they had and kept on about 'do I want fries with that' approach. We really need to do better if these edifices are to survive in their current form and compete with online. Eventually got what I wanted online.I discovered that The Rocks is mainly owned by NSW Govt Social Housing. This was inetresting given the views and other advantages. Overall a good experience.

Everyone should visit The Rocks. So much to see and experience. We had breakfast, went to the Museum, did a walking tour, had lunch and went into a pub that had the most unusual sinks and toilets. Did you know it is all public land so you can walk anywhere...so many interesting lanes and shops.
Gem of a place. Walk around here safely. They have a great little flea market on the weekends, lots of knick-knack stalls. plenty of cafes to take your pick from. great views of the bridge too.
Nice area to walk around. The rocks area is a great place to wander thru, eat and or drink. lots to see and do but very pricy. The lowenbrau pub is fun as is the Australian Hotel (bar)

Love The Rocks Sydney. The Rocks is such a great place to wander around. The markets are fun and there are lots of gorgeous shops. The Mercantile hotel is a must visit and is in the midst of the markets on a weekend.
not what it used to be. went there a decade ago and loved it, this time it was very dissapointing, closed shops etc
Great views. Our Taxi driver insisted on taking us further on (nothing to do with greater fee I'm sure) to this place and it was well worth it as we were just going to Rose Bay initially.

A taste of Sydney. Great markets, street entertainment, pubs, restaurants. The Hero of Waterloo pub is a MUST to visit - excellent beer and fantastic live band. The lead vocalist plays saxophone and trumpet and is brilliant (she is also 84 years old)!
Lovely pace to spend some time. This area of shops bars and cafes is totally wonderful. Enjoy wandering past some interesting little shops or stop for a coffee and watch the world go buy.Lovely!
Great atmosphere. We stayed at the Holiday Inn, which is right in the area, so was able to see it all through various times of the day. Great atmosphere.

love, love, love!. great food with the most amazing views in the world. i recommend that you have dinner with your special person if you are ever in Sydney. the food did a good job in matching the spectacular view.
shopping & Sightseeing. Excellent opportunity to purchase present and souveniers, good value & quality. Do visit the Garrison Church - it's lovely.
Interesting Part of Sydney. I recommend the free (tip based walking tours) so interesting and great fun.

See the origins of Sydney. Sydney has to rate as one of the most if not the most beautiful harbour-side city in the world. It's origins all begin around The Rocks. The oldest building in Australia, the convict built warehouses, the beautiful boutique hotels and the oldest school in Australia (Fort St) which dates back to 1849. Great restaurants as well.If you have an interest in history then this area is a must to visit. Don't miss the weekend markets.
a hint of europe. the only place in Sydney with a reminiscence of the old continent, if sometimes you feel home-sick this is the place to go.

Sandstone. Went on a weekend - enjoyed the markets and the atmosphere, the little galleries, the views of the harbour and the harbour bridge, lots to see, but not too crowded. Very well maintained streets and public areas. Could do with some picnic tables I think.
Fantastic Atmosphere. Great place to go lots to do has lots of beautfiful historic buildings
Great place to get lost. We love eating at Phillips Foot, and all of the other old pubs in the area are really fun -- lots of characters to meet if you have a free afternoon to sit and tie one on.
Feel the history. This may be the oldest part of the city, but it is vibrant and lively with a well preserved feel. Easy to walk around and no fear of coming to any harm, even if alone.
The Rocks. A great place for a walk or stroll. Excellent cafes for breakfast and lunch and a good market on Saturday and Sunday.
A bit of history. Well worth a visit to see the oldest part of Sydney and find out about the first white settlers there
Historic. We love this area and always manage to find something new! May sure you take a different street each time you visit!
totally scenic walk. this is a wow , stunning veiws , a must do in sydney

Walkers Delight. We walked around, through, up and down all the small lane ways feasting our eyes on the delights at every turn. Be prepared to take all the stairways where you find them. They will often show you how the small suburb truly is backed into, wedged between and sits upon the rocks to the side of the Harbour Bridge. There are many spots for a great breakfast, lunch or dinner & shops to enjoy - all a little touristy but this can be easily forgiven for the brightness and fun they bring. At the Harbour end of the Rocks, check out the new Gallery of Contemporary Art. Fascinating exhibitions - depending on your taste. The 4th floor Sculpture Terrace is a fabulous place for a coffee - and the views across Circular Quay are stunning. Take the escalator down to the walkways around the water for lunch at the bar below the International Terminal. Good food, lovely location.

Museum Of Contemporary Art Australia. This is a must for all ! It has recently been reopened and has some wonderful exhibits and the glass elevator with views over the harbour is a great ride. The new roof top cafe is a nice way to finish of your visit to the MCA
Craft Market. Nice outdoor craft market every Saturday and Sunday
Fascinating area. Nice to be in an area with some history. Shops and markets really appealed to the wife!! Good restaurants in the area.
The Heart of Sydney. Stayed 9 days alltoghether in the Rocks, and there is still more to see.
Nice Area. Nice hotels, restaurants and bars to visit in this area. Nice and upscale.
lovely area. lovely area - nice restaurants :) trendy area :) some interesting stalls to buy from :)

Such a friendly location steeped in activity. The rocks is steeped in history, café's, bars, , markets, crafts and banter. Great part of Sydney not to be missed, follow the routine down from Observatory hill towards the Botanic gardens you wont be disappointed

the markets. make sure you visit the markets 10 AM till 4 PM sat sun
really worth buying if you like something

Blast from the past.. Take a stroll and walk back in time to old Sydney. This is where the city began to take shape and where most of the early migrants and convicts landed. Streets are very European, narrow and steep. Most buildings are heritage sites. Cobblestone streets will delight you with stories of convicts, colonists and famous traditional characters. You can visit the Susannah Place Museum, where you can see by yourself how old Sydneysiders lived. And if you want to see how they do in the after-life, there's even a Ghost Tour you can do.
Don't miss the market. Great wares and atmosphere at The Rocks Market. My daughter and I bought everything from artistic jewelry to hot chili.

Great place to wander around. The whole area is terrific any time of day and night. The only downside is that massive cruise center, that seems completely out of place in the area. Never the less, the Rocks is definitely worth a visit, and you can easily spend a half day there taking in the sights, as well as enjoying street perfomers all day and well into the evening.
very attractive at night. argyles night club alot of nice people there and nice drinks

Historical Sydney. The unions save The Rocks. In the 70s council wanted to knock it down and develop the area with high rises. They put green bans on the work sites and prevented this. They did us all a favour. It has been renovated and is a great pleasure to walk through. There are several small shops, restaurants. It has become a tourist attraction. At Xmas they have the Xmas markets where souvenirs, handicrafts can be bought.
oh, the history. trying to imagine what it was like 150 years ago and having a lot of shops to choose from

A walk back in time. Stroll the cobblestone streets for a history lesson on Sydney's origins. Lots of interesting shops and restaurants along the way, wish we could have been there for the weekend market. Lovely way to spend an afternoon in this beautiful city.
The rocks is unique. Love the Rocks markets atmosphere held on Saturday great variety of food, drink and gifts

Nice place to visit, but don't hang out here.. I really hate writing the same review over and over, but given that I have no idea who will read what, I feel compelled to repeat. Sydney is the third most expensive city in the world. Average cost of a Coke is $6 US/AU. The average cost of an entree on the Rocks is easily $30 and soda refills are NOT free. Most of the dining establishments immediately around the Rocks area fast food, once you cross the strees and get "off" the Rocks, there are many more choices and the variety and creativity of the dishes is fantastic, but you will pay for it. In addition, this part of the city is quite LOUD, so moving even farther off the Rocks may prove beneficial for more than one reason.

Architectural highlight. Buildings at The Rocks have been very sensitively preserved. One gets the impression that it's not only tourists who patronise the shops and restaurants. This is a living part of the city.

Interesting afternoon. We visited this area on a Sunday, when the markets were on. It was a fun and vibrant place and we enjoyed the experience. Some of the market stalls are interesting, many are just the same as you would find in most markets across major cities, such as Covent Garden in London, but all in all worth a look. As the Rocks are only a two minute walk (I really mean two minutes and not a brochure version of two minutes) from Circular Quay and the Sydney Opera House, you can combine a lot of things into one afternoon.
Great Fun in the Shadow of Harbour Bridge.. Beautiful to walk around during the day. Great Pubs, Bars and Restaurants. It ranges from authentic pubs to German Beer Bars.

Yummy. Loved the market there, went both Saturday and Sunday. The food stalls (not on Sundays) were great value, tasty and fresh. After dropping over $100 at a waterside restaurant, for $5 I would have been better off having a japanese pancake, been more satisfied and quite frankly superior quality!
Nice ambience. Great place to walk around, get a very expensive drink and people watch

The Rocks - The wonderful combination between ancient and modern. As the oldest area of Sydney, The Rocks recently had a surprising change: the old town suddenly transformed into the space of cafes, restaurants, shops, stalls are excellent for for tourists. But this did not seem to destroy the ancient and fascinating capital of the region has a long history as The Rocks because the city planners have set out a long term plan to restore and preserve relics and character of the Rocks, harmony between modern beauty and traditional values ​​precious. When to visit this place, visitors can leisurely stroll and see the ancient architecture and art to enjoy the extraordinary cuisine from around the world.

The Rocks. I love The Rocks - Sydney's oldest area. There are heaps of bars and restaurants to keep you happy. Some bar suggestions - The Argyle, The Orient, Bar 100. Try Sake for dinner, if you like Japanese food, or Pony for Modern Australian.There's also a Tourist Centre in the Rocks, which is well worth a visit for Sydney information.Shannonwww.urbanchicguides.com
Nice old part of Sydney. We enjoy walking down to the Rocks each time we visit Sydney but must admit it is becoming more commercialized each time.

A dip into Sydney's early history. Good place to walk around with free museum and lot's of places to eat away from the pricier establishments on Circular Quay.
Pub grub and beer is excellent.
Wandering around The Rocks. Fantastic location, and a nice pieve of early (modern) Australian history
Great day out. Always something to look at, things to do and lots of cafes for that coffee just the way you like it.
The Rocks is the place to be during any Sydney festival. Great place, lots of activities, pleny of pubs and people to meet. Weekend see the Rocks markets. Great for tourists
lovely place to see. lovely place full of little cafe and shops and eating places.
lovely area. If you like discovering on foot, go to the Rocks. Nice shops, good food. Close to train station and ferries.

Easy addition to any itinerary. The Rocks are between Circ. Quay and Darling harbour,and hard to miss. Its a cute area to walk through,and the markets on the weekend shouldnt be missed. Visit the free Rocks Historic Museum,which is quick and easy to visit,and tells the story of the neighborhood's beginning as a convict settlement quite well.
The Rocks. The architecture of the old buildings is grand where the history still remains very interesting
Charming place for a wander. Very hilly walk but worth it for the charm of it all. A must see is the Susannah Place house museum!

The historic centre of Sydney. A great place to walk around and see the period buidlings, some great pubs and restaurants many in historic buildings. it is in the centre of a large city and feels like a village, amazing

The Rocks is a great place. Love the Rocks -- history, great location close to other Sydney attractions, good restaurants (be sure to stop in at the French bakery and Guylian Chocolates), and great views of the Harbour Bridge.

Quaint part of Sydeny with an all day street market- well worth a look round.. The Rocks is a very quaint part of Sydney and right next to the Opera House. There are some lovely shops to walk around and lots of nice restaurants.I particularly liked a street market which was set up all Saturday and Sunday when I visited. They closed off the streets and there must have been 100 stalls with everything from fresh corn on the cob for sale, handmade silver jewellry to glass blowing.I bought lots...well worth a lovely day meandering round all the stalls.

sydney in one day ...... If you only had one day in Sydney, 'The Rocks' is the perfect choice to 'almost' see it all. Begin your day wandering through the various market areas - everything is available there and it is the perfect place to buy top quality souvenirs. If you haven't found what you want at the markets, wander onto adjoining George Street where there is any number of quality buying opportunities. Shopping done, cross George street and spend a couple of hours in the Museum of Contemporary Art - the new extension looks amazing and due to open any day now. Perhaps have lunch at the excellent cafe there, outside, overlooking the harbour. Sit for a while and watch the never ending stream of ferries coming and going from Circular Quay. You can listen to the live didgeridoo music played by various Aboriginal folk. From there, stroll around the foreshore to the Opera House. Spend some time both inside and outside and take in the glorious view of the harbour. Continue on from the Opera House and walk into the Botanical Gardens. There is so much to see there, including the ancient Wollemi Pine tree, the extensive herb garden, and Government House. Again, sit for a while under the shade - maybe indulge in some afternoon tea at the kiosk there. Revived - then trace your steps back past the Opera House, around the foreshore, past Circular Quay and keep on going. Shortly you will find yourself looking up at the beautiful Sydney Harbour Bridge. You may want to come back a little later for dinner at one of the many excellent restaurants housed in the Old Wool Sheds right there. If you feel like wandering a little more inland, look out for the Lord Nelson Hotel - its a small pub, supposedly the oldest in Australia, and indulge in any one of the excellent wines or beers on offer. And if you're not too tired - why not see whats on at the Opera House that night - the view of the bridge, and Luna Park over the water, is quite stunning at night. So, you've 'almost' seen it all, only thing missing is one of the many beautiful beaches in Sydney - you'll have to come back for another day!

Step back in time...and enjoy the pubs!. The pubs here are great. The cobblestone paving is great. The tiny tight laneways and walkways are great. The markets are great. Really - a visit to the Rocks is a Sydney experience MUST! Step back in time, absorb the history, and sip on a delicious ale.
Historic area of Sydney near the CBD. Many early buildings, great views of the Harbour and lots of cafes make this a wonderful place for tourists to experience early Sydney.

Interesting for a stroll. The Rocks area is worth a look . You can take a stroll and check out many interesting shops and the historical aspect of the area is interesting. We felt that it was very pricey especailly the food - we walked around the area, took it all in and ate somewhere else.
Historic !!!!!!!!!. you have to look at times but its all there, history that is, plenty of modern distractions, for the souvenir hunters !!!!!!!!!!
The Rocks. Gave a history of the past and the feel of the trials endured with a mix of upscale shops and dining

THE ROCKS ROCK! HISTORICAL, GREAT FOOD AND SHOPPING. The Rocks is a section of Sydney abutting The Circular Quay, under The Bridge, and across from The Opera House. It gets its name because most of the buildings are built of stone. The Rocks is the oldest area of Sydney. It has been transformed into a major attraction by converting warehouses and very old buildings into restaurants, trendy shopping, a class outdoor market area (weekends mostly). The effect is clearly old world charm. There are numerous restaurants here and check Trip Advisor for reviews. We liked restaurants in the alley way behind the major street running along the harbour. Quiet, with outdoor dining or inside depending on your wishes.The Rocks is the oldest area of Sydney and has recently undergone an amazing metamorphosis, the old district being transformed into a vibrant pocket of cafes and restaurants and interesting tourist shops and stalls. This has been achieved without destroying the area's Old World charm and historic buildings. Sydney's town planners have put in place a sensitive conservation program that has preserved the heritage and character of The Rocks and brought about an interesting fusion of modern amenities in an old and valued setting.
Take your time!. You must take your time with the Rocks, there is lots to see and do do do go during the weekends 10am - 5 pm for the markets! Spectacular!!!
Markets are great. Great markets on Saturday and Sunday. If you don't want to spend a packet leave the wife in the hotel. Plenty of great little items to buy for the home.
Great shopping!. A must see when in Sydney, great shops and restaurants, unique gifts nd handmade gifts from locals. Close to all hotels and ferries.

Fabulous Saint Patrick's Day - would love to make it an annual pilgrimage - and I'm not even Irish!. We were lucky enough to spend St Pat's Day on The Rocks where pubs were offering "cooked breakfast and bottomless Guinness". The whole area was a sea of green with people in hats, t-shirts, flags and even guys in kilts. We spent the afternoon in a pub called "The Orient" and were royally entertained by a very energetic Irish band. In the pub were young and old, singing along to "Wild Rover", "Danny Boy" and other such well known Irish tunes. I found it impossible not to tap my feet and at times had to restrain myself from breaking into a full jig. It was wonderful to share the experience with other fun-loving folk who were clearly having the time of their lives. Put this on your list of things to do before you die or regret it for all eternity!

Good. The Rocks markets are famous but every time we come it always has the same stalls so alittle bit boring. A few good restaurants but never able to just walk in and get a table so have never actually tried any. End up walking over to King St Wharf area and/or Cockle Bay/Darling Harbour restaurants.

The Rocks Sydney. We've always been here for two things mainly. It's where the Australian Family History Society have their offices, (my husband is very much into family history) and for the market held on the very steep hill in The Rocks at weekends. Believe me, unless you'e plenty to spend you will literally be "on the rocks" if you buy everything you like!! There is also, in the nearby area, the old, but modern ANA Hotel, now known as The Shangri-la. We stayed there some years ago and were lucky enough to be upgraded to the 'Executive' Floor room and the views from there were out of this world, looking out over the Harbour as far as the eye could see including the Opera House and the Sydney Harbour Bridge. We picked up a bus from The Rocks which took us a little inland to The Barracks which again holds many convict records. But that is another story. The Rocks, Sydney go there. (visit prior to 2011)

Neat place to walk around. We walked the Sydney harbour bridge and then waKed around the rocks. We had breakfast at pancakes on the rocks which was more like dessert than breakfast but a fun indulgence. Shops, coffee places and restaurants were plentiful. We saw the QE2 docked while there which was pretty impressive.
Vibrant. Enjoyed browsing the interesting shops and great dining.
Historical site made too touristy. Very busy day and night. Lots of restaurants and cafes. Can be crowded when cruise liners dock.

Beautiful little pubs, especially good on market day!. the markets here are great on saturday mornings. you would get lost strolling around the little streets and there are so many little bars and eateries here you have plenty to choose from
On The Rocks. A quaint area adjacent to the Sydney Port and just before the Bridge. Some good eateries and old tyoe shops - well worth a stroll along (before you undertake the bridge climb !)

A historic part of Sydney. The Rocks at Circular Quay is an amazing place to discover. From waling around the harbour forshore or along George Street the building remain from convict days. Although many have been modernised inside the history is very evidentt. There are cafes, restaurant and pubs whish are a hive of activities. The shops are numerous from clothing, jewellery to art galleries. There are markets held each Sunday when the road is closed to traffic. You can walk right up under the Harbour bridge. A great place.

Little shopping. Great little place to wander around a bit on the weekend when there are markets. Beautiful, artistic, sophisticated things for sale. Incredibly hard to resist. A few nice, interesting restaurants but nothing marvelous.

The Rocks Market really rocks!. A visit to The Rocks is well worth it, especially in weekends when streets close and the markets take over. It is full of activity with loads of specialty stalls, aroma's of freshly cooked food, buskers and live bands...lot's of fun!For other things to do in Sydney (over 7 days) check out my blog on www.sydney-jono.blogspot.com
The Rocks, wait for it.... rock.. Great restaurants, small shops, and small streets. There is a walking tour that was terrific.

The Rocks Markets!. The Rocks really is a beautiful place in Sydney- good for tourists and even good for locals. The Rocks Markets are fun and have great food!! :-) Check it out while you're in Sydney!!

Quirky and fun. Stunning area with numerous small shops and bars great cafe's and some very reasonably price eating establishments.Weekend markets is a must as there is some fab stalls and great fashion and gifts for friends back home.
awesome markets and lovely afternoon at the Mercantile!. lots of interesting and unique gifts at the markets. great atmosphere at the Mercantile hotel with a band playing and cold Bulmers on tap!

Historical. Have a guide explain all the buildings and structures from the early founding of Sydney by the immigrant prisoners to the present nicely built houses. Lots of places to eat and enjoy the walk around this historic area.
Great for weekend shopping. On the weekends there are little markets set up all along the rocks selling bags, food, clothes, jewelry and other vintage stuff. There's tons of cute restaurants too!

Great place to explore.. Lots of history and best seen walking around the area. Nice to see they are preserving the old buildings. On the weekends there is a really good outdoor market with quality goods being sold.
Best place to stay!!!. Enjoy The Rocks!!!. The pubs are excellent, lots of eateries to choose from and the wonderful markets stalls. Its a pity when we were there the rain that dampen the morning.
Fantastic. We enjoyed eating out at various eateries. We could not fault service.

Discover Sydney. Great tourist area for eateries (restaurants & cafes), pubs, shopping, weekend markets. Easily accessible from Circular Quay (10 minutes walk) for trains and ferries. Plenty of accommodation choices (budget, moderate to 5 star). Good area to use as a base for all harbour activities/attractions, including Opera House, walking/climbing the Sydney Harbour Bridge.Go on a night Ghost Tour to get a wonderful insight into Sydney's short but colourful history!

Quaint Old World Sydney. Stroll the streets of the quaint old world area of Sydney and you will be inundated with plenty of shopping, cafe's, restaurants, bars, and there is even a farmers market on several days each week. There is a distinct old world English flare about the area. Loved it!

Pretty but watch for louts. The Rocks is the Old Town of Sydney, and is very pretty nestled by the Harbour. Head away to the back streets and hunt out old pubs like the Hero of Waterloo and the Lord Nelson. Steer clear of the place on Friday and Saturday nights as it fills with drunken louts and can be quite dangerous. Better during the day.

Not Good For A Wheelchair User. The Rocks are worth a visit but due to the steep hills much of the area is not suited to wheelchair access. We did get an access map from the Information centre but even this is on the top floor of a buiding and the lift is located out of the way.
Historic. Easy to get lost in, so grab a map. Lots of lovely pubs, cafes and shops.

Great shopping. Really cool shopping at the rocks on weekends only and not a lot of junk there is a guy there at the end that sells hot sauce and it is Made with the hottest pepper in the world have a glass of milk nearby or see the pub about 30 feet away
Sydney's History. Walk around on a Sunday Morning to check out the Markets. Then lunch in any of the old pubs in the area, then check out federation Square for a brief history of Sydney.

Intriguing.. Loved the Rocks Museum and some of the shops tucked behind the renovated buildings fronting the harbour. These shops, up steps across the road from the back of the harbourside buildings, had a wide range of goods at prices much less than in central Sydney, and the service was fantastic. Its worth exploring the whole Rocks area - very interesting.

To Market to Market. I highly recommend the markets at the rocks, they are a great way to kill a couple of hours.
Tip: Look for the corn man and do yourself a favour. Its a taste sensation!

Somewhere everyone should visit.. The Rocks are a wonderful historic area that everyone should visit when they see Sydney. Studded with backstreet pathways, cafes, and shops, the rocks are a wonderful place to spend a couple of hours exploring.
Just be prepared for stairs. The easiest way of traversing the area are via the multiple staircases, and they are fairly steep.
Nice walking tour. Had casual walk through the area - site seeing and shopping. Had lunch nearby.

Definitely worth a visit, go when the market is on. I loved this area and it is of course sooo historic. One wonders what it must have been like for those first brave people who arrived there way back. The market is full of very interesting stalls, everything from wind chimes, glass blowers, ceramics, essential oils, foodstuffs - one could easily spend 2/3 hours here. Plenty of cafes and places to sit out and enjoy the atmosphere. Make the effort to go a few streets away from the market to get a non touristy and more atmospheric feel.
Great place for an afternoon. Nice vibe. Lovely place to potter about. Nice restaurants, although a little expensive.
History. Facinating to understand the long history of the first settlement and how reliant we were on a good local !

Fun to walk around and explore. Whilst the rocks is touristy, it is a fun place to look around on a sunny Sydney day. Markets on a Saturday are a bit gimmicky and touristy, but can pick up the odd good thing (may suit others more than me!) Apparently there is a foody market there on a Friday which I did not get a chance to visit but be keen to next time in Sydney
Terrific Location. So much to see & do withing easy walking distance....shops restaurants and historical sites.
Take a walk around. Walk around the alleys and backstreets, stop for a cold drink in an old pub - very interesting (although food / drink prices a bit steep)

The Rocks. We stayed at a B&B in The Rocks which was, in our opinion, far better that the run of the mill hotels. We had really good genuine Aussie hospitality in a listed building B&B and thoroughly enjoyed our stay which really was home from home.
Touristy but some nice bars tucked away. Found a couple of quaint bars tucked away - lots of atmosphere

Great history!. Ambiance!!! This is the oldest neighborhood in Sydney, and it has a real sense of history. The whole area was once terrace houses, a working-class neighborhood. Many of the old buildings have been preserved. Some are hotels, some have restaurants in them. Some are residences. Some are offices. There are lots of signs around the area telling bits of its history. The Rocks Experience and Susannah Place more thoroughly explain the history of the area. The "Big Dig" is an archaeological excavation that hs been kept open for viewing. The youth hostel constructed their building on stilts in order to preserve the old foundations rather than just build on top of them. If you're not into history and historic preservation, go for the weekend market and the variety of restaurants. Just go there and wander!

Step back in time.... Wander around the Rocks and imagine what life was like in Sydney 200 years ago. It's a lot cleaner now, but much of the old charm has been preserved. It's very touristic, but still very nice. Photogenic, interesting. Take some time to potter around and explore. It's especially nice in the early evening.
Chill funky area. We really enjoyed wandering around this area, looking at the history and going down Nurses' walk
Don't miss it!. We enjoyed walking around this part of Sydney, with lovely places to eat or shop.
Quite an active place. The Rocks is filled with restaurants, clubs and shops. It attracts a younger crowd and is really lively.
Awesome View. Great place to eat and shop! a visit (its on the way to the Opera House)

Great historical perspective.. Whilst the rocks has been transformed to meet the needs of the modern tourists it still has a whole wealth of history. Take a walk, guided tour from the information centre. Learn of the history of the first fleet and convict era. We stayed away from the tourist food and restaurant areas
The Rocks Markets. Make sure you visit the Rocks on a saturday or sunday. The market is brilliant, filled with unique souveniers.

Great area to eat, walk, and experience Sydney and it's inhabitants. The Rocks is a preserved area of old Sydney. Here you can find and feel the history of Sydney in the buildings as it was first colonized. This is also a great evening for dining or watching people during the many weekend events held in the streets. Markets on the weekends or outdoor seating in some areas for drinks with friends or relaxing from your touring. Shops abound the streets from touristy kitsch to current artist gallery.Time required - Depending on how many shops you wander into but a walk through the Rocks can take one hour or a whole afternoon. Services - There are many bars and eateries here that warrant a visit. It could be the "Fortune of War" bar est. 1828 and is the whole in the wall come as you are kind of place or Rockpool, one of the higher rated places in Sydney to eat and showing up without reservations is extremely ill-advised. Grab a pint at Lord Admiral Nelsons brewery and visit the more unknown views at Observatory hill for scenery of the Rocks and the harbor.Day or night this section of Sydney warrants a visit.There are several statues in around the walk and the Contemporary Museum of Art is located here. At the time of writing is was closed for renovations.
History Plus. A great place to spend a day with amazing history all around you.Great markets and shops.
Market sundays are always fun. Always something interesting to see or buy at the Rocks on Sunday..
Great to wander around. Lots of nice shops / restaurants & cafes, very relaxing to wander around & sit outside with your coffee / french pastry

Best place for tourist to stay in Sydney. In the middle of everything tourists want to see and do in Sydney. No better place to stay. Ferry, train, bus, restaurants all close and galleries, opera and gardens are walkable for minimally fit person.
Love the Rocks. I always have a fantastic time at The Rocks.I wish I could live here :)

weekend market and entertainment. Great weekend market with upmarket souvenirs. Great cafes and pubs to sit and people watch, lots of live music and historical sites as this is the "old town" of Sydney. Easy access from the city of Circular Quay (ferry wharves). Galleries and interesting shops.

Market on the weekends. The rocks area has lots of restaurants and cafes but also has galleys and on the weekends comes alive with the weekend market. The market has a wide selection of novelty gifts for tourists including Australian aboriginal boomerangs and didgeridoos. This is a great scenic area to look over the bay at the Sydney harbour opera House.
Good shopping. Interesting area to explore. Market on a sunday and lots of different shops.

Heritage Sydney. There are alot of old pubs and buildings down at The Rocks and there are also walking tours and Ghost Tours of an evening, as well as Markets on a weekend to soak up the atmosphere of this historic section of Sydney and then Circular and Sydney Harbour are just around the next bend.

Good atmosphere. Good atmosphere and many dining options. They also had the markets and my friends and I pick up gifts for people back home. Be sure to leave some luggage space for dried cranberries, chocolates and honey!

Love this area!. I really love going to the Rocks. There is always something going on, and the markets on the weekends are my favorite thing about Sydney. Love all the little cafes and pubs, love the location. Love it all!
History. Old Sydney early settlers and convicts labor built buildings. A good place to visit.

Nice area to grab a bite.. It is a must in Sydney, it is the most antic zone of Sydney, but it is a beautiful area to walk packed with restaurants and shops where you can buy from souvenirs to beautiful paintings.
Great history. Clean, safe. Do a guided walking tour. Good markets. Plenty of variety for eating and drinking
Step back in time. get a real taste of what life was like back when white man settled in Australia, great shops, pubs and good vibe. The ghost tours there are excellent a must do!
Alternative to Paddy's Markets. Markets aren't as well known as Paddy's Markets, but I think they're better. Also, while you're there, head to Pancakes on the Rocks. You won't regret it
Old centre to a modern city. Great people watching in the original centre of Sydney. Not too touristy (no worse than other cities)

Great area for strolling. There is a charming market in The Rocks on Saturday and Sunday. It's great for buying little gifts for your friends and family back home. I picked up a wooden puzzle of Australian animals for my grandson and some beaded bracelets for my daughter. I also found a refrigerator magnet with a penny from the year of my birth. It's a nice place to stroll, shop, and grab a bite to eat.
Don't miss the MARKETS. Loved the history, the food venues, the lanes, but most of all loved the MARKETS
Great vibe at the market. If you are lucky enough to visit during a market, or even for a relaxed lunch, it's worth it. Great people watching and beautiful views.
An Historical Adventure. Interesting old part of Sydney. Try to go on a Sunday when there is a bustling street market.

Early evening walk around the Rocks. While many of the various shops / stalls were already closed by the time we walked to the Rocks area, we still found some of the historical alleyways like the Nurse's Walk pretty cool and almost too many restaurant choices. If there, check out the "Vintage Cafe" in the Nurse's Walk area (portuguese tapas with live Bossa Nova music).

Attend the Rocks Market. On Saturday and Sundays the market Area has vendors with some unique items to purchase. Handmade dresses, crochet childrens hats, wood working, jewelry, puzzles, art work - paintings. Check out your favorite movie clips in framed setting! Count on a few hours of browsing the streets.

food stalls at the rocks. struck a night where food stalls were out and the food was excellent, we were going to a restaurant but ate standing up and sampled at least 6 stalls, the stall holders were so friendly

What a lovely spot.. We wandered down to the Rocks Market from our hotel in York Street.It was a short walk and we passed lots of lovely shops before we found the market. The market was lovely to wander around, and we came away with quite a few great finds. The market runs Saturdays and Sundays and has a nice little spot to stop for a cold drink 1/2 way around.

Great Historical Site. The Rocks is a wonderful destination in itself - the location steeped in history. The area has been transformed into a tourist attraction, but still manages to maintain many of it's original buildings and character. The Rocks also has some great restaurants and is a wonderful place to find unique Australian gifts.
Grab a Souvenier. Good on Market days lots of stalls. And interesting buildings.Relax at a cafe for refreshments.

For shopaholics of quality items. Lovely shops, pleasing to the eye. Bought a lpretty summer hat and my partner bought an Akubra as well, very well priced we thought for Sydney prices. Interesting art pieces along the way and with stonework the Rocks is famous for.

Pubs, shopping and history.... The oldest part of the city of Sydney - The Rocks has so much to offer. You can enjoy a tour around to find out the history of the area, or you can grab a bite to eat or a few drinks at one of the many pubs in the vicinity. Then there are the night markets where you can purchase something for that special someone.
What a huge disappointment. It had been close to15 years since our last visit there. Nothing to see, apart from cafes, cafes and more cafe, what ever happened to all those wonderful shops...

A quaint charming and absorbing Sydney. ots of nooks and crannies, where you find treasures of all kinds. Don't be frightened though it seems no more expensive than any other part of Sydney, and it feels Old town, right next the Bridge and Quay.There were many cafe's and we sampled a few, all had great fare at good value and if you picked your location you had a view of the Harbour. A great place to stroll around and enjoy Sydney....No hype!
amazing piece of aussie history. make sure you get off the main streets and take a wander down any laneway you come across, full of surprises
Artisans Abound. Ceramics, glass, paint, etchings, Aboriginal art, beads, knitted products, it's all there in the shops and even more when the markets are on. The food at the markets is good.

Undecided. The Rocks area is a mix of historic housing, eateries and tourist shops intermingled with hideous 70's and 80's architecture. quite steep in places with plenty of stairs, it is easy to go too far and find yourself worn out rather than enjoying the experience. Stick to the harbour surrounds and find some oysters and bubbles and watch the people go by.

The Reliable Rocks!. It's always a pleasure having a walk around The Rocks, particularly when the markets are on. Naturally it helps when the weather is sunny but it is definitely a location one should visit when in Sydney but allow more than just an hour or two or you will feel frustrated that you haven't seen everything.

Quaint & Historic Sydney. A mix of history and the omnipresent pace of progress - the smell of fumes from the traffic and then around a corner you step back in time with the old but hey presto across the road modern buildings - the Overseas Shipping Terminal, Quay Restaurant, hotels...Loved browsing, buying and the stroll through the Rocks Markets on our lazy Saturday sojourn. Purchasing corn from the roadside vendor and then finding ourselves directly underneath the southern pylons of the historic Sydney Harbour Bridge at Dawes Point, and looking across the water with the magnificent views of our other Sydney Harbour icons including our world-renowned Opera House. A regular treat together with various members of my family and friends, either local or visitors. A must for another visitor and you do not have to spend money just feel and witness the atmosphere AND the magnificent views.

Great weekend market. We really like the Rocks area. It has a great atmosphere. We went to the weekend market twice on our trip. There were lots of unique items for sale, making it a wonderful place to purchase gifts and souvenirs.

Loved the Rocks!. The Rocks is like no other place that you'll visit in Sydney. So much history and a lot of orginal buildings still standing. Lots of little pubs and restaurants and you can visit the markets on certain days of the week. Wish we could have spent a little more time here, or even spent a night.There are great views of the harbor and Circular Quay from many points in the Rocks.
Being gentrified. Great to see the old buildings being restored. Good use of information boards and self guided walks to ensure you see the most of area in limited time.
Beautiful. Beautiful Place with alot of stuctures of old Sydney with various restaurants and cafes.

A great place to kill some time and chill out.. this area is great to chill out in but it is entirely a tourist area with lots of Back packers. However on the down side it is an expensive area to eat and drink.
Just sit and watch the world go by.. Multi functional for eating, drinking, the ferries, cinema, The Opera House or just having a nice sit and watching the world and it´s people go by.
Where the life is !!. Stayed in the Rocks area - loads of restaurants and great food, but expensive due to poor exchange rate for Stering
lovely area. we enjoyed strolling around here!!! its not a cheap area but it is the oldest part of sydney.
History and night life. Very historic with lots of tales to tell, weekend markets with a nice array of handmade items and lots of little eateries and taverns.

The first place to go. Home to the original harbor which would bring the prisoners to Australia, it's packed with history. More importantly, it has the most complete and helpful Visitor's Center you'll find in all Sydney. You'll also find the oldest pub, narrow alleys now peppered with arts and boutiques, and a relaxed atmosphere. It's a bit hilly, and some of the stone pathways are probably a couple of hundred years old, but it's worth the visit. The bar at the Orient Hotel has great dinner specials each night under $10.
Fun Area. The Rocks, near the Harbor Bridge, is a very fun area.
Great for NYE Fireworks. Great Spot for Watching NYE Fireworks! Will do it again!

The Rocks. We liked the Rocks area which was ideal to walk to the harbour and boats for boat trips etc. There are shops and restaurants within easy access and altogether we are glad we stayed in this area.

Historical pub-crawl anyone?. This is our oldest built environment in Sydney and there are a lot of historical sites to be enjoyed while stopping for a few coldies along the way in one of the dozens of hotels. The Harbour View has a roof top seating area with great views of the coat hanger (Syd Harbour Bridge) and Lunar park, Opera House. The Orient has always offered good food and entertainment, there is a place that will suit everyone. And the puppet show is a must-see for kids and kids at heart, one of the best (and free) shows I've seen.
