Night markets, Sydney Festival, Five star harbour side restaurants, too many attractions to rate them all. Just go and wander around, or do a ghost tour on a dark and windy night.
A bit of history. We did the organised tour and learnt a lot about the history of Sydney.
Heritage Sydney. Easy to walk around, and so much to see. So Sydney. Shops are all a bit pricey, but the history is priceless.
Best place in Sydney. History, character, charm, great food, markets. Says it all.
the rocks. had dinner here a few nights it seems to be a nice place to eat.

Great Sydney Attraction. We were quite impressed with The Rocks. It has various aspects to it.History - There is a lot of history to the Rocks. You can find out from the Rocks Museum, or the I'm Free walking tour.Entertainment - diverse street performances around the areaFood - plenty of cafes, restaurants and pubs around. Or just try out some of the food stalls in the markets on Saturday.Shopping - a lot of funky shops, and checks out the stalls in the markets.Really enjoyed it. Wished I had more time there. Definitely worth a visit.

Stayed Close to the Rocks.. Our condo was very close to the Rocks area so we spent lots of great time there. It was especially nice on Friday when they had the open air market people there. The food offered by the vendors was wonderful.

Must go here. Go and eat at Phillips Foote Pub. For one price AUD$31 you pick your meat (steak, chicken, etc.), select from a variety of sides, and cook you own meat. Also, try go go during time when they have their version of a craft market. Definately a must go to place.
interesting. its a must see area and try and go with a guide to learn about Sydneys origins
The best area. lots of pubs and restaurants. history abounds, great to walk round and get lost

Wonderful sense of history. All cities must retain some semblance of history and the Rocks certainly achieves if for Sydney.This are allows visitors to see the balance of Sydney with the history contrasting with a wonderful harbour (probably the most intimate in the world and even better than San Francisco), the iconic Opera House opposite and a dynamic thriving modern city just hundreds of metres away.

Have to do it.. Touristy, yes; Busy, yes; Noisy yes, at times very.But you have to see it, and also the part around the bridge and the Observatory. Its the old part of Sydney where you (sometimes) can feel a bit of how it used to be.Spectacular views over the bridge, harbour and opera house and still a few oldfashioned (more or less original) pubs and even some locals.
Old world charm. I love this area of sydney, although it can be very busy it has so many old buildings and great pubs. The Hero of waterloo has so much history. It a great place to explore.

Find the "I'm Free" Tour!. On our first day in the city, we joined a free walking tour with the "I'm Free" tours. The guide wears a bright neon green shirt so you can't miss him. It starts at the cottage in Circular Quay and goes for about an hour and a half. Great way to get the real story behind the first convict settlement in Sydney.

Great suburb. This place has so much history you can actually feel it when walking through. I discovered a whole new part the other day, so make sure you don't just walk down George Street, but also head up to the Lord Nelson Hotel and check out the other streets. You won't have problems finding a place to wine and dine.
Enjoy the vibe. Vsit the Rocks on a Sunday morning and enjoy the vibe of the market.
Throbbing with life. Street entertainment, great cafes and market on Saturday. Huge cruise ships tie up there. Can get crowded.
Amazing tourist spot. Loved wandering around the diverse range of markets, sampling the different foods, strolling through the markets and seeing artists at work painting new creations.
Good View. Almost anywhere you go around the rocks you can see the Sydney opera house and the bridge. Very nice area and a good time! A lot of places to eat drink and be merry!
Worth walking around. Worth just having a good walk around and looking at the shops and restaurants. The area goes back more than you first think.

full of history and wonderful old buildings. The Rocks is takes you back to what Sydney was like in the 1800's with lovely laneways and coppr water spouts and limed sandstoned walls cobbled roads and cobbled wooden roads kept,if you look up and around you will find surprises hidden that a camera shot will keep...a fern growing out of the sandstone wall. Small wooden doors with brass knobs...The market on Saturday full of atmesphere buzzing with tourists. Corn on the cob and pidgeons pick up the fallen corn...sit and watch..
Historic Sydney. It was like stepping back in time. Went for a walk at night and also had breakfast in a cafe the next morning. Loved all the old buildings and streets. Kept tripping over though!

Australia's Oldest and Fairest Quarter. This is where it all began ... where our proud ancestry commenced, where our convict fathers struggled against all odds to build what has become a beautiful nation. A visit to The Rocks is a must for anyone who appreciates history, heritage and architecture. In the sandstone buildings which line the streets there's plenty to discover; museums, art galleries, quaint shops, boutiques, markets and pubs. It's always worth exploring behind the obvious, there are many little side alleys that will suprise!
Merits a half hour walkabout. Some interesting heritage buildings, but felt like a tourist trap and we couldn't find any attractive water views of the harbor.
History Plus. Great to get back in time here, with the exception of the food and entertainment this area has day and night.

Old Sydney now tourist precinct. Many restaurants, bars, tourist shops. Sunday markets great for souvenir hunters. Lovely location on harbour foreshore - a great place for lunch or dinner in good weather
The Rocks is tops for shops. All manner of shops and market stalls selling local crafts and upmaket goods. Many open air cafes / restaurants. Great way to spend and hour or two.

Quiet, safe area of Sydney - authentic and local feel, not touristy. The Rocks is a great part of Sydney - quaint shops, restaurants, and accommodations. Overall, very quiet and safe. Within easy walking distance to the harbour.

Overrated but worth lifting a pint when going to or from the Bridge. The Rocks is very good at rolling harbour visitors, separating them from their coin, after centuries of practice. Forewarned, you can still enjoy yourselves, especially lifting a pint of Fat Yak on George Street.

Quaint neighborhood with lot of character. Quaint neighborhood with lot of character being Australia's first European settlement. Perfect location adjacent to the Sydney Harbour Bridge, Circular Quay. Lots of great restaurants, bars etc.

Lots of activity and history. There is so much history on the Rocks. So many restored buildings. A historic walking tour is a must. The restaurants pubs are interesting and fun. It's a great place to be on New Year's Eve.
Great Place. Full of little shops, boutiques and restaurants. A great day can be spent here.

Great museum. Down at The Rocks there is a very good tourist information centre and a lovely little museum showing life in the rocks as it used to be.
Well worth a visit.
History & Fun. Incredibly fun area for a multitude of restaurants, pubs, shops, museums, combined with all the history of the area's past

ye olde Sydney. The rocks is more than a little touristy with prices often reflecting this, but it has a huge amount of character and oozes old school charm. There's a huge amount of eateries there that are worth checking out, and lots of great harbour views

The notorius Rocks Area of Sydney was once considered and area to be avoided.. Now it has been restored and reinvigorated so that all visitors can see the sort of buildings were originally built by the first colony of New South Wales. This area is home to the Lord Nelson Hotel and Botique Brewery. The Hero of Waterloo is another hotel with a reputation of transporting drunken sailors (Shanghing) to the various visiting ships and forcing them to work as crew to earn their keep.
quirky. like this area of sydney, always a nice vibe. needs a few more thrash cans though as littering in sydney seems to be an issue!

Very original old Sydney. The Rocks has some of the oldest continually occupied buildings and streets in Sydney and the country. Much of the district has been refurbished and is now actively used in pleasing and satisfying ways. Like an old country village really. Well worth the walk.

A Trip Back in Time. The Rocks has many examples of interesting architecture dating back to Sydney's earliest years following settlement. There is nowhere better to see this than at the Rocks. The businesses in the area seem to be pitched at the high end of the international tourist market. Good quality uniquely Australian items can be purchased here, but usually at a premium price. Plenty of good eateries at affordable prices however. Also some high quality and more expensive restaurants.

Olden Sydney. This is the one of the oldest parts of SYdney and has mostly become a tourist area. There are some upper end shops in this area selling Asutralian souvenirs, and a market on the weekends. There are some nice old pubs in the area, Guylian cafe and La Renaissance cafe (cute patisserie where you can have cake and a coffee in their courtyard) are among the many eateries available to you.
Cool place to visit with lots of great history. Loved it. Great place to start a tour and learn about the history of Sydney.

Australia's cultural centre. A lazy day walking around the rocks is a must when in Sydney.
Take in all it has to offer, galleries, restaurants, cafes and many shops.
It looks even more beautiful at night with the harbour lights in the background.

Plenty of bars/restaurants and market stalls. A great place to explore, many small alley ways and old bars. It is a good place for people watching and having a beer as the sun goes down. There is also a market that sells all sorts of trinkets. A pleasant place to spend a couple of hours. Its particularly busy at weekends with many tourists coming here for drinks.

Culture, Restaurants and Parties in the middle of Sydney.. An easy walk along Circular Quay, The Rocks have many guided tours on offer, but by yourself is as easily done. From luxury to souvenir shopping, to the Museum of Contemporary Art, to Latin, German, upmarket, Pancake eateries, The Rocks has many things to offer. Be warned of the cobble stones and in certain areas, there is a steep incline as well as the cobble stones. The Rocks is always busy on a Friday and Saturday night and I would highly recommend it as an evening place of fun for visiting tourists.

Great area for history, eating and market shopping. Its is a small area but the little laneways take you into the past. There is alot of history, still evident, in the Rocks area. There are many cafes and restaurants squashed into the small area. The best part about The Rocks is the markets on Sunday, you could spend a whole day looking at all the stalls and sampling the wares.
Travel Into History. This place has a special feeling that makes you think what it was really like many, many years ago. A happy place that you never get tired of.

Chic blast-from-the-past. First European settlement in Sydney. Some wonderfully-preserved architecture. A bevy of fine and casual restaurants and delis to suit any budget. Quaint specialty shops. Cobblestone roads. Charming atmosphere resulting from a healthy mix of many cultures. Perfect for lone travellers, couples, families or groups of friends.
Lovely area. great shops, great view, great atmosphere. stunning!
Love it. To get out of the hustle and bustle of the city centre the rocks is a great place to relax and enjoy a good meal
Easy, Central with great views. Loved the views from our hotel roof ( holiday inn on george st).Some great cafe's, were there for Australia and free music festival - Fantastic!

What to do on a rainy day in Sydney?. Go for a walk around the Rocks area. There are plenty of shops to poke around in and a couple of museums. Plenty of cafes/pubs and restaurants. There are companie that do walking tours in the area and they are worth chasing up to do. The markets on friday, saturdays and sundays are always worth a look at.
The Rocks. The Rocks is a beautiful historic part of sydney and has some of the best pubs.
Bit touristy. Nice older part of Sydney but a bit touristy with lots of souvenir shops.
our history. It is a must see and you feel the mix of then and now and the history is so plain to see.
Cool Place!. Lots of shops, restaurants, pubs. Open air shopping on the weekends. Very cool!

Lovely Part of old Sydney. Visit the numerous pubs, the restaurants (Rockpool is my favourite, but ain't cheap) and in particular all the older pubs that Sydney has to offer including, Orient Hotel, Mercantile, The Argyle, The Lord Nelson, and my favourite the Australian for Kangaroo or Shark Pizza.
A trip into Sydney past.. This is what Sydney looked like.The old buildings and the cafe's are worth the time .

History and a Pub Crawl. We checked out the historical habitats in the Rocks and then did our own little pub crawl (Fortune of War, Hero of Waterloo, Lord Nelsons, Australian Hotel, Glenmore rooftop). Great way to see the area and spend time with the locals.
Old world charm. Great old Pubs and architecture, showing the early history of Sydney.
great little restaurant. Sailors Thai, great place to eat. One big communal table, but quick and tasty food. Will remember for next time.

Chaotic but awesome!. If you visit Sydney you have to go to the Rocks, do a pub crawl, the Orient Hotel is cool! Great dining, beautiful views! Get a water taxi over to Watson's Bay and have a pic nic!
Old sydney, nicely restored. Go there for a nice meal. You will find different galleries as well and some days there's a market.
Well worth the visit. Lots of little restaurants and little shops, also the markets are well worth visiting.

The rocks, rocks. Loved, loved, loved the Rocks. I felt safe walking around at night. Loved all the action down by the Quay, with performers etc. Bit gutted that the museum wasnt open. Resturants, bars and people were super friendly. Love the feel that the Rocks is touristy but hasnt sold out and has its own vibe going on.

Living History saved from the wreckers Ball. This part of Sydney is so central and important to Australia's history and is also a great and exciting spot to visit.
Thanks to the green ban by the 'rogue' BLF (Builders Labourers Federation) destruction did not occur and history was saved. A few good old, and new pubs worth a visit and a coldie.
The Rocks. The history, the restaurants, the buzz, the buildings.

A fascinating piece of Sydney history.. This area just a stones throw from Circular Quay is a must for those visiting Sydney. There is ample histort here and it is well documented and displayed. No shortage of great places to eat and shop. Coffee and sweets at the Le Renaisance Cafe is a must.

The closest thing Sydney has to historic. Australia was only first settled in 1788 so it doesn't have really really old stuff (except for the aboriginal rock art in the Northern Territory which is older than anything Europe has produced). The Rocks area of Sydney is the oldest historic architecture - 18th and 19th century buildings. There's a buzzy atmosphere at weekends with a market, there are old warehouses that have been turned into shops, the pubs are cool, there are some decent restaurants at the overseas passenger terminal and one 3 hat restaurant called Quay which is utterly superb but you need to book in about 6 months ahead and it is NOT cheap. The Museum of Contemporary Art is worth a visit.
Interesting place. Great shops, restaurants and bars. Brilliant atmosphere on a night. Lots going on.
Sydney History. Alovely place for views of the Harbour and a stroll through historic streets
Great. Nice walk, history, great bars and restaurants, picturesque.

Rocks Pub Crawl World Class. The best pubs in Sydney with so much always happening around you. Walking through the oldest parts of Sydney with spectacular water views and a variety of hidden cool pubs. Grab a map and find the variety of pubs on offer
Food and Drink. Actually you can drink in the History of the area. great balance of Historical buildings and great places to eat and drink. Could get lost on the pleasure of the area for days.

nice. The walk in The Rocks is like taking a walk in the past..the quaint stroes, pubs and history was fun .. the Guide gave us a tour of the prison cells and holding areas .. which was quite a story.. over all a must see when you in Sydney

A great place to wander around and explore. There are plenty of great little museums and shops in the Rocks. Simply walk here from Circular Quay and keep an eye out for the signs that direct you to all the attractions (such as the Rocks discovery museum, Cadman's Cottage, observatory hill and of course- the Harbour bridge!)

Brill wine bar etc. The wine bar located at the Rocks is a great place to go and chill.
The food was excellent and although small, the "optic" tasting was a bit of a gimmick but we loved it.
The staff were great.

An area rich in history, and beautiful scenery and restaurants!. It is understandable why Sydney is famous for its Bridge & Opera house, they are beautifully positioned in the harbour, in an area called 'The Rocks'. An area rich in history, and beautiful scenery and restaurants!
Alive !. great area to visit through the day and evening, lots of places to eat or just stop and have a coffee

Worth a wander. Nothing amazing but worth a morning, afternoon or evening to wander around. Some good restaurants but do your research beforehand as most are very average and over-priced tourist traps. Nice little market operates on Sundays.

Love this area. Great restaurants and bars, and atmosphere.
Love the little small pubs and had dinner at the Lowenbrau, pancakes on the rocks which I´d recommend both.
Love the markets on Saturday they should be a must do while in Sydney.

You need to be a walker here. Historic area but difficult manouvre if you dont have a guide map. I got off a cruise boat to find 5 levels of steps to climb to find the markets and the rocks area. Bit tricky for an asthmatic and older person No signs at the bottom of the steps to offer an alternative to this steep climb to a person unfamiliar with the area. Once there quite atmospheric
Kinda disappointing. Although the Rocks area looks older, it is disappointing. My husband is a history buff, and it wasn't very informative.

Eat and drink and be merry. But beware, the pubs close at 11pm - on the dot! Great pubs and restaurants in the area. Really interesting market with original (not mass produced) items such as jewellery and clothing on Sat/Sun.
Never getting bored of The Rocks. At least once a month we go walking around the rocks, occasionally stopping a one of he great restaurants or caffes. Pony comes to mind, or Rennaissance.
The Lord Nelson Brewery Hotel. Amazing choice of locally brewed beer. Nice meals too.
Lively on the weekend. I like the history of the rocks area but obviously as it is geared to tourists it is expensive.

Historic and groovy.. The Rocks are beautiful, There is so much history and you can just feel it as you walk through the street. There are some great restaurants and bars to visit, it is close to everything. Worth a visit.
Awesome. Not a huge shopper, but the flea market was amazing. Blocks and blocks of nice things. Great restaurants as well.
Over priced area. Nice looking area but very costly to shop. If you are there on a weekend they have a market with some interesting items.Excellent coffee shops to stop and take a break.

Trendy Shopping/Dining Area. The Rocks is a trendy and upscale shopping & dining area. There are some great pubs around as well....it is usually a busy place, but as most of the places are on the pricier side, its not crowded.

Small but cute. It feels a little like London here. It is nice to wander around and see the old buildings. It takes you back in time a little. Not that Australia has much history...
There are lots of nice cafes and bars. On Fridays there are stalls that you can enjoy.
Sydney. Excellent atmosphere. Culture diversion and blending

Worth seeing as part of the whole. I thought the historical area would be a little larger than it really is. If you are there you should walk through it but it will not impress you as much as other things in Sydney will

Loved the Rocks!. Lots to see and do, smell, eat and listen! Great market at the weekend, lovely little boutique stores, good smelling restaurants, some lively cafes and bars (at least 5 pubs claiming the title to be the oldest in Sydney!) and we also went on a free tour of the Rocks (well, you pay the tour guide what you think it is worth at the end) seeing things we wouldn't have seen otherwise. The Rocks Museum wasn't well signposted, but definitely worth a visit.

Beautiful cobbled stone streets with iconic views. The Rocks is a fantastic place to lose yourself in the colonial history of Sydney. The narrow cobbled stone streets and beautiful buildings set an amazing atmosphere all while you can see the famous harbour bridge. Make sure you take the time to stop at one of the iconic pubs and have a drink or take a ghost tour for a different experience.
A nice walk. Good restaurants and a smart stop especially if you do the Sydney harbour bridge walk

want a bargain then this is the place. if you want hand made crafts then this is the place to be , you can spend half a day looking at all the stalls. you can also get a harley ride round sydney from here.
A place of interest.. We just strolled around took in the sights,had a meal at one of the resturants, a few photos and enjoyed the visit

Historical fascinating place with lots to see and well located. The Rocks is one of the most important historic areas in Sydney. Located near Circular Quay, the COntemporary Art Museum, the Opera House, the Royal Botanical Garden, the Rocks is easily found and accessed. This area contains historic buildings, some wonderful art and craft shops, and some fabulous restaurants.

This is a lovely historic area. The founding of the colony and the first settlers lived at the rocks and it is streaming with history, stores cafes and restaurants. A great place to visit. Very interesting and do the Ghost walk tour it's fun.

Sydney's Colonial Heritage. The Rocks is Sydney's old colonial part of town down on the Sydney Harbour in the shadow of the Harbour Bridge. It is lovely to walk around the Rocks and see the old restored buildings where Sydney began. Great old pubs, upmarkets shops and there are outdoor markets on the weekend. For a cheap meal or snack go to "Pancakes On The Rocks" There is also boutique hotel accommodation with views of Sydney Harbour. The Rocks is another must do for tourists and locals.
Nice bars. Nice bars here, great for a drink at night, felt very safe there too.
Excellent walks and food. Walk the back streets.. Still has that colonial, convict charmStill has some old gorgeous cottages around their

The rocks abustling. This is a walk back in time and history every occasion it is visited the only modern splashes are some architectural renovations, people and the goods & services. The history is etched into the stone and you feel the convict era passed.

A must stop in your vacation to Sydney!. I've been to Sydney a few times now and each time I visit the rocks. The walk from the harbor is beautiful and the shopping is amazing. Pattys market is where you go for cheap knock offs, but if you want quality handcrafted souvenirs, head to the rocks! There is always music and entertainment and lots of restaurants in the area.
Steeped in history. Cracking re-juvinated part of town. Lots to see and do. Some of the oldest pubs in Sydney mixed in with trendy new restaurants.
Just wander around. Pretty historic area of Sydney, nice to just wander around and look at all the old architecture.

Coolest part of Sydney. This has replaced Darling harbour for our favourite place to stay. The lower town is great. The market on Sat + Sun is fun. But explore the higher part of town. There are little restaurants and pubs up on top of the rocks that take 5 minutes to get to but are super.We stayed at the Sebel Pier One... wow it's seems like it might be far away but it's just a great walk along the wall. Bar100 is worth a visit for lunch... really great food that you wouldn't expect... At night it's a party place. Sailor Thai was so good we ate there twice in four days.

Leisurely. Taking a walk around the Rocks is a leisurely way to pass an hour, watching the ferries sail in and out and it affords a great view of the opera house, close by I stumbled upon a lovely little street market with a huge variety of aboriginal craft and local art for sale at very reasonable prices.

so old. What fabulous work they have done on this very old area. Great cafes and the shops with the crafts and galleries. So much to see it in this area. Great cake shops there are several here. Walking under the bridge is fun as well.
Olde Worlde Sydney. A lovely enclave of boutique shops, pubs, restaurants and galleries just minutes from bustling Circular Quay. A must see, if only to visit the terrific Sydney Tourist Info Centre
so/so. while it is interesting to look at, there is also a overproportional number of tourist traps to avoid. Some good views of the harbour
And to think it was almost pulled down!. Who can forget the "Green Bans" of the 70s that saved The Rocks. Atmospheric. Love it.

Nice and lively. At the feet of some hotel skyscrapers (such as the Shangry La hotel), you will find this ancient district, which gives you a warm welcome into the old England dating back to Victorian times.All those red-bricks houses transport you back in time. It is really nice to see the characteristic market with any kind of souvenirs and typical food. Strolling down the road you will be soon at the harbour and you can decide to take a ferry or to go in Geroge's street which is instead very modern with high buildings and modern shops.I think that the Rocks is a good starter point to visit Sydney.
The Rocks in Sydney. Markets on weekends mainly home made. The place bustles with people & you get to be part of Old Sydney.
Definitely worth visiting. Given its convict history background, it is a must see for every visitor to Sydney. It is very hilly and so those with motility problems may want to avoid it.
Superb. A Must see in the vast amount of attractions around the Opera House

Great fun, great pubs. I revisited an old haunt, the Mercantile Hotel for my 50th birthday celebrations and it was great to see that they still have high quality bands on a Saturday night, not to mention the Guiness!

Great place to visit. We loved the rocks area. It was near our hotel and we went there a number of times to eat and browse around. The architecture was old and interesting and there were a number of shops and places to eat.

Nice area with a cozy feel. We walked around the outskirts of The Rocks. It has this cozy feel, which I think is mostly because the buildings are not new and modern. If you want to walk around try to find the pathways off of the main road and are between the buildings. You'll appreciate the area more, especially when you get peek-a-boo views of the Harbour Bridge.
Nice walk in the old quarter of Sydney. Beautiful (not so old) houses and streets, very beautiful views from the southern pylon of the Sydney Harbour Bridge.

Nice Weekend Market. One of the places to view the Australian life on the weekend, lots of stalls selling souvenirs, accessories, Kangaroo's leather till art & craft works, good for a stroll and people-watching.

a walk through Sydney's history. I read Playing Beattie Beau years ago (sorry about the spelling - I can remember the title not the spelling) and always wanted to wander around the Rocks area. It was just like the book - the alleys and the buildings, the views and the street signs...great eating places when you are tired of walking.

I suppose you must see it but nothing spectacular.. For historians it is well worth a visit to this area. Food and drink wise it is average. An obvious tourist focused area. It is better when the street market is there. Make sure you walk some of the back streets. Toilets are located towards the bridge end of the main street. A good place to have a beer. Shopping is not great but for oversees visitors, you will find something.

Pancake on Rocks is a must. everytime i travel to sydney i always take my time to enjoying fascinating The Rocks . The Rocks Market is more than just a shopping experience. With jewellery, Indigenous artwork, evocative photography, gits, homewares, sweet and savoury treats and arts and crafts, The Rocks Market is a weekend essential only . The market takes place every Saturday and Sunday from 10 am to 5 pm at the northern end of George Street. don't forget to enjoy the famous pancakes and i recommend for its ribs. fabulous !Pancakes on the Rocks 4 Hickson RdMillers Point New South Wales
Trendy, excellent food party all night long. Great history in the area, selection of all types of international food, incredible servioce
Great range of eating & drinking options. Atmosphere through the day & evening is always pleasant and you'll find something to meet all tastes.

Nothing really interesting.... Well... It's a couple of streets you will go through because it's in Sydney downtown, in the middle of attractions worth to see : bridge, opera, ferry... But in itself there's nothing really interesting to see... A few houses in we have everywhere in Europe with no specific style. Except if you are writing a thesis on Australian history, you won't spend more than 30 minutes there

Nice place to stroll around. This is a great part of town to stroll around. On the weekends, they have a touristy market but it's still pretty interesting just to browse. All very low-rise and some very old buildings and laneways (don't forget to go up and down some back streets). Favourite parts are Lord Nelson Hotel for a pub meal and National Trust shop up on Gloucester Street.
Sydney's little beauty. Lovely area with heaps of places to eat, you must try to guylian chocolate cafe. theres a DFS area there for international travellers.

Quaint and a nice piece of Sydney history. Lovely to wander around with great pubs. There is a good market on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays. The Glenmore (pub) rooftop area is great on summer days too!
Trouristy but good architecture. worth a visit, gallery of modern art is here, good architecture, ok shops designed for the tourist.

SHOPS AND CAFES. There are many shops with lots of high priced stock to pick from plus a few acceptable tourist shops .. lots of places to stop for coffee then pick a great estaurant for lunch or dinner .. easy access to a walk up George or Pitt street and more of the same to chose from?

Walk around during the day for families. Nice art galleries. We weren't interested in the nightlife, but it is supposed to be excellent. Easy to walk there from Darling Harbour and Opera House in 20 minutes

Great older style buildings and lots of life. The look of this place is a mix of new and old, most of the places are the traditional sandstone buildings and it has a really great feel to it, there are some great little bars and places to go here and it's close to the harbour where you can stroll down to the water. On some days there are some markets which are cool to check out, it's great in the day, but worthwhile seeing at night for sure.

Don't miss this fun historical area arounnd the harbor. The Rocks is an interesting and fun area around the Sydney Harbor that is in easy walking distance of the Sydney Circular Quay (they pronounce this "key'"). There are many places to eat in historical buidings that have been beautifully re-purposed.

Must see on your Sydney visit. I am a regular Sydney visitor and always find myself at The Rocks. I like to have a drink at Sydneys oldest pubs like The Hero of Waterloo or The Lord Nelson. Have tea and scones at the Irish Cafe or just walk around tha laneways with so much history.
Amora Jamison. Very over priced for the snadard food provided. However the atmoshphere is quite nice and is a nice treat for a one off dinner.
Wonderful Old Sydney. Cobbled streets old buildings interesting shops bars cafes and restaurants great atmosphere. Street market held at weekends

A great area. This area has certainly improved since the last time I visited 16 years a go. It is vibrant with lots of eateries and designer boutiques. The buildings harp back to the docks era and are amazing. The area is very safe and very close to Circular Quay. Worth a visit!

Walk around here is a must. Lots of eateries and historic area. Walking around here is a must and perhaps enjoy lunch or dinner in one of the many Reastaurants etc.- some famous ones around this area.

Yes, A must do. This area is the closest to the original Sydney and still had all the feelings of being back in this time. For travellers do not buy your souvenirs here as they cost at least 4 times as much as the shop owners know you will want to buy something. The jewellery is nearly 10 times it normal price to try and trick you. Just take a short walk back into town and you will find the same thing at a much cheaper price. Take lots of photos though.
Groovy spot to explore. Great area to wander and a diverse range of artisan and memento shops to explore (beware; on some items you will pay a hefty premium to buy in this location).
Old Sydney Updated. What a great place to experience Old Sydney! A nice place to see the sights in the daytime, but it really comes alive in the evening!

The Rocks area used to be more interesting. Now, it is adjacent to the cruise ship terminal and that's changed it.. Before all the cruise ships started docking adjacent to The Rocks, it felt more authentic. Now, there's the usual spate of shops that cater to cruisers and the crowds when ships are in make it unpleasant. I wish they had kept more of the original buildings - maintained them - because the character there 20 years ago is not there today. Here, this was the birthplace of Sydney and it would be nicer if it were really kept as an architecturally accurate representation, as much as possible, to those olden days. It is fun though to walk through the cobblestone streets (some are not now) and to visit the outdoor markets. My husband and I stayed at The Russell Hotel years ago, and I must say that this building has maintained it's old world charm. they still use room keys and you turn them in when leaving the hotel....the rooms are charming, antiquated and so what you would hope for an area like The Rocks.

Hot Rocks!. Great shops along George Street - check out UGG store for the real deal and Louis Vuitton's brand new store where you can get custom-made men's shoes (for a price!). Nice little artsy book store, delish fresh ice cream place nearby. Nice stroll along the harbourside with perfect views of Opera House. Pubs crowded and noisy. Everything open late. Young crowd. Fun atmosphere.
The Rocks. Walked around and then went to the market that was there.

charming, fun historic area. wouldn't stay anywhere else. There is so much to see, lots going on, great restaurants from a fun outdoor restaurant where you cook your own steak to more elegant affairs, old historic pubs, cute little shops on alley ways and several museums.
Lots of good eats. Be sure to venture down to the Rocks area for lots of great restaurants and beautiful views. A must see, right around the harbour bridge area.

Very rocky place. A bit of a caricature is here, old Sydney places mix with luxury shops, which is unique in Sydney, people arent paying so much attention to the brand and international fashion. There are nice shopping and restaurants, Circular quay is in front with huge ferries crossing by, like Queen Mary. So it s a paradise for cruisers from overseas. My favorite place is the Contemporary art museum, MCA where you find serendipities at the shop, mugnificient restaurant, beautiful exhibitions, and a bit of fun !
Quaint Area. Quaint and hidden. A few bars and unique shops. A must to visit as there's some history for this area.
Rocky!!. It was OK but overrated as an attraction / area. Very commercialised and mainly shops, bars and places to eat. Market was OK at the weekend, mainly tourist bits.
old world charm. I haven't actually been to the rocks for some time now but going on my previous experiences I will definitely go again. The Rocks is full of history and old world charm.
Must visit. Beautiful, historical area with many cafes, shops, pubs and a nice walk
Old World Charm. See Sydneys history. A few too many souvernir shops have taken over, but you still get to see some original houses and buildings.
Interesting. I love the history surrounding The Rocks and the old buildings are awesome. Great to walk around.They have markets here and again plenty of pubs etc.
lovely area. Good location for having a few quiet ones after work, although, you pay a premium for it. Plenty of choices for food and drink with history around every corner

Great little market on the weekend. Lots of neat stuff at the market on the weekend. We also found a nice meal along a back sidewalk. One day a gigantic cruise liner was docked right there and weddings happening all over!
The Rocks, Sydney. The Rocks is like stepping back in time, but with all the modern facilities nearby. Great pubs and restaurants. The Rocks Markets are a must to visit.
Great Artmosphere. We spent quite a bit of time here you can go round the back to where they start the Bridge walk from. Good food options to.
Lovely. A really love place to dawdel along! Lovely weather made it all the more enjoyable.
Old part of Sydney. Very nice to visit the back lanes and good food the markets on the weekend are good
The Rocks. See some of old Sydney, lots of action, many restaurants and great views of Sydney harbour.

Best pub crawl in Sydney. If you like pubs, you'll love The Rocks. The birthplace of Australia and it's settlement, this place knows how to pull a schooner and it's not afraid to make some noise. Great place to go on Australia Day or NYE. Will be back time and time again!

Stepping back in time. Lots and lots of laneways, pubs and markets to explore. It's easy to spend hours wandering around The Rocks. The views of Sydney harbour are magnificent especially on a sunny day. There is always something to see and do at The Rocks.
spend a day here... then spend another!. this area of sydney is full of things to do. Modern galleries, rustic markets and great bars. Plan to spend some time here, you won't regret it.

great to see and walk. just walking in the rocks markets sunday morning is an experience really different...in the beautiful city of sydney...u might find something to buy to look at to eat great great great

Busy market around the rocks. The rocks is a fascinating part of old Sydney during the week-ends the area is packed with tourists and Sydneysiders there are many small streets to wander around and it is a pleasant walk around to where the ferries come and go in the harbourI love watching the buskers they are so clever and funny during the week ends a large market is held and unlike overseas markets there is not a lot of the same thing repeated for saleHandmade jewelery can be bought from it 's creator and many different and interesting hand made crafts It is mainly a craft market but of the highest quality paintings stamps hand painted glass souvenirs wind chimes chocolates lollies and a lot more to look at or buy the market is huge taking over a number of streets around the RocksThere are also galleries and shops hotels and food stalls outside cafes and restaurants and my favourite pancakes on the rocksThe rocks is a great way to spend a day and learn about old Sydney town

surprise visit. we stumbled on this and they appeared to be having a festival where nearly everything was free, rockabilly dancing, musicians and some of the best street food we've had anywhere in the world, we had food from 5 different stalls and all extemely good. We seemed to walk 2 streets up and down, but it all seemed to be one happy festival party.

What a cool place, so much to seee!. Don't get in a hurry. Go slow and pay attention. Don't be scared to climb every set of stairs. You never know where they might lead. Great places to eat and shop are scattered everywhere.

Are of great historical significance that you can feel. One of the best places to be located for a first time visit to Sydney as it is on the edge of many of Sydney's main attractions. There are a few good 'olde' pubs in the area that are worth visiting, including a pub/brewery. Greatly entertaining.
Great place to explore "Old Sydney". Full of history with lots of little bars and cafes.

History galore. Lots of Sydney's history around here. Good pubs as well. Suggest maybe a walking tour with a reputable company. The Ghost Tour we did was good and well done for tourists. Maybe not so good for locals who would already know most of the info.
pubs in the rocks. A great way to have a few beers on a hot Aussie summers day
Old Sydney, the Rock's is a Gem!. Great Old Architecture, Museums, Theatre District, Bridge, Art Galleries, Restaraunts. Diamond in the Rough Location!

Great on a Sunday. This is a great part of town particularly on a Sunday when the markets are on.This part of Sydney has history, great pubs, great views and a variety of good places to eat. As well as the markets, if you are into arts, take a walk through the Argyle Arts Centre. You can walk up the hill to the Garrison Church and over to the Lord Nelson pub, or stay down there harbour and try the Lowenbrau, Orient or the Australian hotel. If you want someowhere up marke to eat, try Wildfire or Quay or walk round a bit further toward the bridge and oyu can sit oudoors at Wolfies, The Italian Village or one of a couple of other good eaterines with great food and service
Historical district - full of shops.. There are bunch of shops and eateries - some older buildings (about 100 years) are there but nothing much more.
Lots to see and Do here. We loved the twighlight markets, the pubs, and pop-up shops, the intrigueing alleyways and the MCA

I liked the rocks market. I liked the rocks market which held on sat and sun!! There was so many interesting to get there, and so many things to see!!It will be lovely if you manage to arrange your itinerary on sat and sun, as you can visit the rocks with market where selling handmades item, localized goodies, foods, their artworks and prints, where located at CBD area!!!

Nice but overrated.. The view of the harbour from a different angle is the only thing interesting. Unless you want to climb on the bridge which starts here. A great Millefeuille is served at the caffe opposite the Visitor's centre.

Not that impressed. The Rocks are a somewhat touristy area of what appear to be largely victorian houses and shops. Coming from the uk, with lots of older buildings, I couldn't see what the big attraction was.
Great restuarants and food. I love this part of Sydney, just a few minutes from the harbour. It is filled with great bookshops, restuarants and bars with live music.
Historic. Good atmosphere and trendy (expensive) shops but beware when cruise ships arrive it gets swamped.

Quaint, but not much else. I'm glad we didn't say in a hotel in The Rocks. There's not quite as much to do there as in the CBD (as far as close proximity to restaurants, shopping, etc.). We walked around there and were finished within a half hour at the most.
Where history began. This historic part of Sydney is a delight and most of the "Old town" has been restored. Great historic oubs and many alleys to discover
Never boring!. A great historic area where one cannot get bored. lots of really cool pubs too!

Love it!. Great history. I love going there on Thursdays for the Market on the Rocks. Pick up a map from the information center and walk around. The ghost tours that operate there are rather boring and not scary at all! But the place itself is full of character.
Market time. A perfect night at a foody market right in amongst the charm of the Rocks. Food was great, needed more shopping items!

Love it specially during christmas market, its bigger!. I met new friends hère. The moelle are nice, you can drink fresh juice, there is food.Some restaurants are open in the site. There is designers selling their own design and discuss about how they Madeleine it. Some Time you CAN order a spécial gift.You CAN buy opale at a Good price, Some dog designer are there too.Some foreign dezigner are available hère too.I bought dog staff and opale ne kava and Some Ammolite hère. At Tom store in front of the Italian restaurant, hé is spécialisée in fossils and in particular ammonlite.Hé designed me a pendant within 2 days. That was amazing and kind from him.Don t Forget to stop by his shop. There is also a designer in scarfs and porcelaine design. She Doris on silk and merino.She is friendly and new in the market she came for the périod of christmas.

Connect to the past. Most times when i am in Sydney I try to visit the Rocks as I feel connected a little to the past. Love going into the shops knowing that this was someones front door of their home etc

well done, you preservationists!. Unlike a lot of cities in the UK, Sydney has saved a lot of its precious heritage, and here it is, in the Rocks. It's also very touristy, and the quickest way to part with your cash. (If you have more money than sense, stay for a week!). Very interesting, very swanky. I stayed a couple of hours, then walked up to The Bridge
Great on a Sunday. Go here on a Sunday when their markets are on. Good fun, good food and an easy stroll to the amazing Lord Nelson Hotel!
Quaint area. Walking around the historic buildings and lanes gives a real sense of history.

Interesting history, GREAT PARTY!. The Rocks has it all - varied history ( from the original settlers and First Fleet, to the housing for the bridge constructors, and 'entertainment' for visiting sailors in all ages), Great hotels, and every manor of food and pub. I particularly enjoyed the open market held the weekend I was there (mid Nov). Most of my meals on the go were enjoyed from the street vendors or pubs along the narrow streets.At night, the party was fantastic. From dj's getting the crowd moving to live acts whipping the faithful into a rock-n-roll frenzy. While all good, I recommend the Orient Hotel and Pub. Good two-man band and friendly crowd made for a memorable Saturday night. And the crowd was right-aged for this traveler (30's-40's set). Sure there were plenty of places for the kids, but wasn't looking for that.Next time, I will try to stay at the Four Seasons located in the thick of the Rocks district. Easier walking distance after a night of sampling the local brews and dancing too much!

Lots of character and reasonably priced restaurants. We enjoyed the vibe of this charming neighborhood. Lots of places to eat, an interesting Sunday market, and plenty of small shops with everything you can imagine.
A Bit of History - loved the Corn. We strolled the Rocks area and loved the Sunday markets. Lined up for corn as the smell was divine. It was worth the wait.
Worth seeing. A glimpse of Sydney as it used to be before they built the skyscrapers.
Great location. The Rocks are busy night and day, and there's a mix of traditional and contemporary pubs, yet the area is a bit disappointing for eating out.

The Lord Nelson. Walked through The Rocks with friends from Singapore. It was dusk so a great time to go and we decided to sample the still fine beers at The Lord Nelson. Great service and still good Quayle Ale. If you like real ale,it's a must!

This rock is a Diamond place.. We were fortunate that our hotel ( Holiday Inn) was located in the heart of the Rocks area.,The market ( which my wife loved) was just outside, the Bridge was just a few yards to the side, and the Harbour was a few yards to the front.The Rocks is a great area that has managed to hold on to some old character / charm.Yep the rock certainly rocks at the weekends, when it seems the whole of Sydney has a party, and boy do they party. I swear we saw the walls moving in and out at times with he noise, and although not for us, it did not worry us at allSo don't miss the rocks and soak up the atmosphere even if it not normally you..
Give it a try. The rocks were a nice place to see. Many bars and restaurants to suit all tastes.
Great day out. head to the markets .. they are fabulous, but can get crowded.
Great mix of old and new. History, culture, great little shops and restaurants.
Love the Rocks. One of my favourite places in Sydney. Lots of bars, restaurants and shops. Good vibe in this area
Wander around.. Fairly touristy but provides a look at "old" Sydney. Stop in at a pub for a refreshment during your wlk.

Return visit, it seems to have lost some of it's buzz. I used to love these markets, the crowds the buzz and the bargains! Going back again I was hoping for a rip down memory lane, but the buzz is gone, people walking through and not buying, lots of touristy stuff, lots of clothes but little else and all very expensive....nice but not what it used to be!

Worth a look. Weave through the old pioneer village streets and imagine what life was like for the early settlers. There is lots of character. The famous puppet shop is no longer there, but there is a great candle shop and German Restaurant if you get the time. Markets are good - don't expect absolute cheap bargains, but more so gorgeous unique gifts and yummy foods.

Vibrant and historic!. The rocks are one of my favorite places in Sydney. The weekend market is great, plenty of restaurants and the oldest buildings in Sydney. Definitely a place to take a wonder, buy something at the market and then sit and have a drink and a meal while you watch the world go by.
Rocks iconic of Sydney. Friday nights at the Rocks is not do be missed is all the fun food etc you can imagine,just go in the evening eat and be merry there,

rocks market a must visit. visit rocks market on thurs through to sunday this is much more an up market market! lovely aussie gifts lovely unusual christmas decorations and much classier than your usual market

Market is very cool. We did enjoy the market on the weekend. The Rocks itself is a pretty nice place to check out, but with the cruise ship terminal so close it's kind of the same as every other cruise ship terminal. There are some fun pubs and restaurants, but have your wallet loaded.

Where it all began in Sydney. The Rocks have spruced themselves up in the past two decades, and on the weekend you can view a local market filled with hand crafts (and more). Pubs along the way offer a good lunch (tucker). You walk through the Rocks to the Sydney Harbour Bridge climb starting point - a must do as well.
See the place where it all begun. At the rocks you can see Sydney's oldest and first house. Step in for free and have a look how people lived at these times and what the coast line was at that time.

Hotels & Pubs. We stayed at the Four Seasons Hotel - wow! A luxurious, well appointed room with everything you could imagine on hand, including delightful Occitaine bathroom products to pamper ourselves with. We had a glorious 10 dollar steak on the rooftop of the Glenmore Hotel (Tuesday special - recommended). Also tapas and beer at the Australia Hotel after our Bridge Climb - food great, staff very friendly and courteous.

Lovely markets in great location at Sydney harbour. The Rocks is the oldest area in Sydney as it was the first area of settlement. It is still a residential area but parts of it have been carefully developed into an area of restaurants, cafes, galleries, pubs and tourist shops. It is located at the foot of the Sydney Harbour Bridge, across from the Sydney Opera House. There are many photo opportunities here!The area is very popular with tourists. One of the attractions is the Rocks Market which is held on Saturdays and Sundays. A roadway is closed to traffic, the canvas coverings are strung up and the markets open to offer many interesting goods to the shopper. There are original artworks and prints, jewelry, gourmet foods, dresses, leather work etc.The location of the markets in an historic area together with the range of goods on offer, gives this market a great feel. If you tire of looking at the markets, there are many restaurants and cafes in the area to sit down for a bite to eat.

Classic place for history and shopping. The Rocks have all of the history involving the start of Australia. They have turned part of the area into restaurants and shopping. Located across from the Opera House and Ferry Terminal, there are tons of things to see and do. Typical tourist area, but worth the look and visit.
Extremely good view of the harbor.. Restaurant choices are plentiful. We ended up at Italian Village. Good food and good mood!

Not just a tourist trap. Whilst outwardly this looks a typical tourist trap and is full of visitors, there are actually some excellent things to see - particularly a the weekend markets'. Support Kangaru (weekend market)for imaginative and quality tea-shirts and the Society of Arts & Crafts of New South Wales for some excellent and unsuual gifts to suit all budgets: so much better than any of the 'souvenir' shops, that really do sell trash. Try 'Fish' or 'Wildfire' for a special dinner or 'Woolfie's Grill' for a less formal atmosphere.
Vibrant and Fun. A great area of Sydney with a huge amoubt of heritage. Lots of places to go to eat and drink with a great atmosphere !
Harts Pub. Great pub underneath the shangri-la. Fantastic choice of Australian beers on tap and brilliant pub food.
Not as big an area as I thought. It is a very cute area with great wine bars but the entire area is quite small, only a very few short city blocks. Would have enjoyed it more if the area was larger.

Fabulous Markets. The Rocks Markets are just fabulous. Great atmosphere to wonder around at your own pace to enjoy a lazy weekend with the option of some great places to eat or chill out with a beverage!

Historic buildings and cobblestone laneways. Located next to the iconic bridge and opera house, the historic rocks area is riddled with stories of the past and a blend of interpretive panels scattered in back alleys to read and learn about the past.
Good way to spend couple of hours. Plenty of eating places, to sit and spend time planning your day
Nice area. It is a nice area to walk around. There are lots of shops and exterior markets. Worth going!
Nice area for travelers. The Rocks was a nice area for tourists since it was close to Circular Quay, shopping, Sydney Harbor Bridge, and restaurants, yet also a residential area so it was quiet.

Need more time to see it all. Walked around here on ghost tour, like to go back during the day to see the unique historical sites. Not a pleasant place to be late at night, very noisy, glad our hotel was not here. The pubs are wild and woolly and to be avoided if you are not into that sort of thing. The view from Observatory Hill at night is worth the climb

Super Friday !!. Went to the Rocks and dined - it was one of the super Friday - all kind of people around - family, couples, friends, so you cannot be out of place. Lot of food being cooked on the street (I am a vegetarian so tried just the strawberry with chocolate which was yummy).Very interesting place to hang around in Sydney.

Love the markets. Try and visit on a Sunday to make the most of a trip to the Rocks. Not only do you get to experience the history of the Rocks but the hussle and bussle of the vibrant Rocks weekend market
very historical. Many old buildings and shops to see. close to train and ferry station. Also close to the bridge.
Very Cute with shops and bars.. You can walk up the cobblestone streets and grab a cute hat nothing "touristy". great little boutique finds. Grab a bite at a cafe or a drink and just relax.

Nice area, but really busy on weekends, expensive pubs. I really liked Harts pub, great tapas, yet most of the other places were a rip off.
We also went to the Australian Pub had a duck piizza, highly recommend.
Markets on the weekends were okay, some nice little arcades. Make sure you have comfy walking shoes, lots of hills and steps.

The Rocks Markets Worth a Visit. The Rocks is worth a visit, the markets were on when we went on a Saturday morning and it was a pleasure to stroll through and check out the small stalls. We then headed under the bridge to a little pub which had a great view of the Harbour.
My favourite place in Sydney. History, great pubs, markets, restaurants and the best views around, whats not to like!

Good for those unusual pressies. The weekend markets are a gret place to find unusual gifts and can be a lot cheaper than other locations - including the duty free oiutlets at the airport. We meandered around the shops and market stalls and had a very relaxing cool drink too. Well worth a visit. One of the stops on the City Sightseeing HOHO bus.
History all around you. The Rocks area of Sydney has so much history from the time of the convicts to the 1970's and present day. Visit the excellent Rocks Discovery Centre to learn more.

a must do!!!. the sunday rocks market are the same every time we visit which gets a bit boring as it is always the same overpriced tourist rubbish. However for the month of November there is a market every friday night in the Rocks which was absolutely amazing with local clothing, jewellery, food and free entertainment. Finished off our evening with a steak at the Orient Pub.

The Rocks Rock. (Forgive the cheesy title, couldn't help myself).A fun quirky charming part of Sydney with a charming old-time feel. The cobblestones and store fronts add to the lovely vibe of the place. Don't let the "oldness" fool you though, the Rocks are filled with amazing restaurants (don't miss Sake...best sushi in town) and cute little book stores to pastry shops. It's different enough from the rest of Sydney, that it's worth a walk around.
History meets chic!. The Rocks is a great quaint place! The markets are a must for affordable gifts for family and gifts for self!!!!!
Wonderful place. Full on vibrant scene and a great place to shop at an extensive market. Good selection of eateries/restuarants/takeaways to suit all needs/tastes/budgets. So much to see.

Why wouldn't you?. This place is great and historic. A great place to find restaurants and just walk around. They have Pancakes o the Rocks restaurant and Lowenbrau German restaurant. Many other places to choose from.
Place to let loose. Great atmosphere,with very old pubs. Lots going on

Obsessed, Want To Live There. My favorite place in Sydney. Gorgeous, historical yet with some very hip and high quality restaurants. Absolutely loved that area. You can see the Harbor Bridge and Opera House.

Flea Market and pancakes. I first walked through The Rocks on the I'm Free Tour, and liked the feel of the area so returned on Saturday. Pancakes on the Rocks was recommended by several locals as a Sydney institution and was delicious. We arrived at 9 and were seated promptly, but by the time we left the line was outside and up the stairs.We then went to the very expansive flea market, a combination of local artists and dealers, plus souveniers and food items; there weren't any antiques or vintage items though. Combination of outdoor stalls and the permanent shops surrounding it.
excellent view of sydney. you could have the famous birds eye view of Sydney after climbing a little mountain.
Interesting. I am not familiar with this kind of place, so I find it very interesting
Love the Rocks. The Rocks has a great feel mixing modern with original very well

Penty of cafes and shopping. Enjoyed the market place at the weekend...lots of crafty shops and gift shops. Plenty of places to eat where you can sit outside and enjoy the weather. No wasps like they have in the UK!

Old meets new. The Rocks used to be the red light district many years ago. Now it is peaceful a haven contianing interesting smaller and "arty" shops, a Sunday market, some very old pubs full of character and some boutique hotels. It is just next to Circular Quay, and not too far from the night life hub of Darling Harbour. There are many warehouses converted into shops, restaurants and hotels. Watch out for the oldest pub in Sydney - The Fortune of War, and another one called Phillip's Foot where you buy your meat and cook it how you like on their open BBQs. Every trip to Sydney should include a visit to The Rocks.
The Rocks market. The Sat. market in The Rocks is well worth a stroll. Lots of food, jewelry, bags, soaps, etc. A great way to spend a few hours and to pick up a few gifts for everyone back home.

Great market on the weekends. The Rocks is a must see spot for the traveler. It has a different feel in the evenings if you enjoy pub hopping this is a great spot. It was just a short walk from our hotel - the Four Seasons and from Circular Quay which was very handy. The street market on the weekends is great - lots of crafts - but watch out for imported stuff if you are trying to bring home a bit of Australia. Lots of street side cafes that are nice to stop at for a bite to eat or a drink. And if your traveling partners isn't into shopping he can wait comfortably at a table at a cafe or pub and people watch while you shop. Don't get there too early for the vendors seem to get started between 9 and 10 am and close at 5. It does get very crowded by mid afternoon

Try The Waterfront Reastaurant. Ask for a table on the wall, sit back and enjoy a relaxing afternoon of seafood, cocktails or choose from the extensive wine list while taking in the views of the harbour and Opera House. Make sure you meet James, one of the managers as he has a vast knowledge of the local area and the best wines, all delivered with a great wit and cheeky smile.
Best pubs around. Great fun atmosphere, a must do experience, then you have the faultless service of the waterfront restaurant.

a taste of history. The Rocks is a pleasant change from downtown Sydney. It is like a little bit of Britain as you weave your way around the streets and alleys. The buildings are original from the early days of Sydney with interesting architecture including the oldest pub in Sydney built in 1858....a nice place to stop and have a drink on a hot summers day. We enjoyed the Rocks!

make it to the market!. went strolling through here and didnt realize there was a market (during the weekend I believe). it was really fun to see the crafts and merchandise. loved the street food! yum!

The Rocks market - Sundays. A nice market to explore on Sundays - lots of handmade crafts and souvineers to be found. Kangaroo scrotum...crocodile jaws...not my thing - but someone out there might like them! Fantastic art - fireglass works, jewellery, clothing. Must try the lemonade at the front of the market - so delicious!
Great area. Fantastic buildings.. great shopping. Easy to walk around and HIstoric spots are very interesting
The Rocks Market. Go down to The Rocks area in the city on the weekend for the markets and grab a pub lunch.
Great area. Love the atmosphere. Used a couple of the restaurants and enjoyed lour meals.
market on sunday. best place to shop for handicrafts and even gourmet food!
Particular. "Little" suburb. Plenty of bars, restaurant, shops. The market on Saturday is really big and particular. Closed to the Harbour Bridge. To see. Fantastic.
the rocks. interesting to wander around the streets and enjoy the old buildings

the most famous old town in australia really delivers. cobbled roads, old buildings, by Australian standards, and bustling environment. The rocks is an awesome way to spend a Sunday afternoon. There are so many great pubs, street vendors and interesting shops. I spent a couple of hours here and reminisced about my university days drinking Guinness. What can I say if you are in Sydney you have to get to the rocks.
Great Fun. Lots of historic buildings, lovely, individual shops and a pub with the best rooftop garden, not to mention the beer! Also a fascinating museum...

Must visit The Rocks. Up and down stairs, interesting laneways, lots of little boutique shops and galleries. This is a MUST if you are a first time visitor to Sydney.The Hero of Waterloo is an very old pub, worth a visit. Glenmore Hotel for sunset drinks - good views over the habour and the Quay.The Mercantile for live music and drinks on Friday night. Le Renaissance patissiere for yummy cakes and coffee!

Historical Sydney - worth a visit!. My friends and I had a girls day out on the weekend before last. It was such a beautiful day to explore the historical part of Sydney. The architecture of the buildings is so nice and it is really like stepping back in time to the early 1900's! They also have the markets on the weekend and we picked up a few home made goodies. We then had lunch and few alcoholic beverages at the Orient Hotel. We sat in the beer garden and it was just lovely soaking up the atmosphere. Nice food and we didn't leave hungry!

Great Restaurants and Views. The rocks is a great spot for a nice walk and offers many photo opportunities. The are lots of great little restaurants located here and even though a bit pricey they seem to fill up with locals at night. If you are going to eat there on a weekend, call ahead and make a reservation. We tried 3 restaurants last night and were turned away since we didn't have one. As you walk up the hill, you will also have some great views of the Opera House and Bridge.
Gotta love The Orient!!!. This is THE place to party in the Rocks. The music's good and the crowd is fun.
Make The Rocks part of your day. This is a great place to walk around and take in Sydney. There are some really good restaurants to choose from.
love the rocks. The Rocks is always a special place to be. With great restaurants, and such a short walk to the Opera house and botanical gardens, it's very lovely.

Interesting walk. Interesting place to walk around. The weekend market provide an insight to australia art and culture. We had pancakes on the rocks which served an amazing variety of pancakes and crepes.

great area to stay and visit. Good bars and restaurants. Sailors Thai restaurant was outstanding. We ate upstairs in the "canteen" .Beautiful food, friendly helpful service and enjoyed chatting to people we were sat next to.

Well done. Very well done. They market The Rocks as the reinvented old town. The streets are extremely fun to stroll around. Good shopping if you want, some great food as well. Saturday afternoon there's an open air market set up that had great booths. Very neat area of town.
Beautiful, historic gem. Gorgeous streets, lots of cafe's Markets on the weekend are fantastic!
historic. A fascinating showing how Sydney was settled and the life of the convicts and early settlers. Some good eating places around there too.
Great Markets. Loved the markets at the Rocks and the range of goods available. Very clean, good eating places, and helpful stall holders.

The rocks still rocks. The rocks is still a great place for a night out. We headed to the Orient Hotel for hens night and it brought back memories of my own at this hotel more that 29 years ago. Dont change a thing about the Rocks its still got it all!!
Great area. Such a cool area and it is definitely touristy. A ton of restaurants and shops and the history is all around.
Steeped in history. This area is quite historical and provides a peek into Sydney's past. The architecture is gorgeous.
Love the Rocks Markets. I really do love walking around the Rocks. I especially like walking around the Rocks Markets on the weekend. I always end up buying something :-)

Do the Markets!. The Rocks is a great neighborhood in Sydney that's fun to explore. It has great views of the Harbour, interesting architecture, a fascinating history (early settlement, a period of decline, a renaissance), and a nice mix of bars and restaurants. My favorite part, however, is the markets that take place on weekends. It's a great mix of vendors selling all kinds of goods, from hand-made jewelry to cool lamps to more touristy stuff. There's also great street food vendors, so stay for lunch!

THE place to be in Sydney. Beautiful area near the harbouor bridge and opera house. Very accessible with circular quay train, bus and ferry terminals here. Lovely bars and restaurants with views of the bridge and opera house.

Historic Sydney. Although I lived in Sydney for 32 years and have taken visiting friends here for years, with time to spend between meetings on a recent business trip back to Sydney, I decided to go and check it out again. This really is the birthplace of European settlement in Australia although it also has an ancient significance for local Aboriginal people.The Rocks is a collection of historic stone buildings, shops, market stalls, hotels and galleries as well as having a wide variety of pubs and places to eat, from first-class restaurants (expensive and a bit over-rated) to more casual, family-style places. It is rather touristic but not as tacky as some places can be and the sense of history is all-pervasive. Given its proximity to the Harbour Bridge and Circular Quay, there are many interesting walks through narrows streets and alleys and then the many options harbour-side for a cooling drink! Sydney Harbour is spectacular and on a fine day, extremely popular with families and tourists taking in the sights and sun.

The Rocks is a fascinating neighborhood with much to offer. This is the most historic part of Sydney. It is a maze of old streets just below the Sydney Harbour Bridge (beside Circular Quay). There are many great restaurants, pubs, and shops. It is definitely worth an evening of walking around and eating.

Birthplace of Sydney. Great for walking around. Full of early buildings and remnants of the convict life. Also modern pubs, bars and restaurants. So in essence, something for everyone and a must see area when in Sydney all in the shadow of the harbour bridge.Markets on weekends and always something happening!

A great place to mosey on a weekend afternoon. This is a great place to walk around in as a tourist because walking around is free! The Rocks has a fabulous weekend market to buy really nice souvenirs (not all tacky, but some are). It's a little expensive, but many of the stalls take credit card, which is handy. The historical center reminds me of Georgetown or Williamsberg in architecture, and if you are craving some German food or a British pub, this is the place for you!I highly recommend walking to the Harbour bridge for some great views of the Sydney Opera House and the Quay.

One of the few attractions in Sydney where you do not have to pay.. 'The Rocks' is the first area in Sydney to be settled in by convicts who had served their time. It is just back from the harbour (with the famous Bridge & Opera House) and it costs nothing to wander around. The sheer feat of hewing houses into those rocks beggars belief. It is a truly remarkable example of the Australian spirit! Most of the area has been conserved & panoramas show bits that have been lost. A very good example of Australia's not too distance past - don't miss it! However, all the restaurants around are pricey (considering the rate of the £).
A must!!. Visit the historic sites, the restaurants or the pubs!! Great place to walk around during the day or in the evening. Don't miss the Waterloo.

Historical wonderland. My boyfriend surprised me with a 4 night trip staying in The Rocks. I have never felt a desire to visit Sydney and touristy places are not regarded very highly by either of us, so when he told me where we were going I was a bit dubious that we could fill 4 nights happily. I was to be proven very wrong.I guess you could do The Rocks on a day tour and later talk about the old buildings, cobblestone walkways and sandstone blockwork, but we decided that we wanted to really discover The Rocks, learn as much history as we can and not even venture out of the area much at all and that's what we did.We filled all of those days and learnt so much, visited so many pubs (3 at least say that they are the oldest), read so many plaques, walked so many miles, ventured down laneways and discovered hidden gems, met wonderful people and did a couple of tours. We were not impressed by the touristy markets that are set up on weekends, but that's just not our thing, but there is so much else to see, do and experience. We did the Rocks Ghost Tour and and a laughing good time, learnt a lot of history, then put our free drinks vouchers to good use.We also visited Suzannah Place Museum and our guide Annie was a fabulous character. On the surface it's just a few old buildings, but the stories that go along with those old homes are priceless.If you want to really discover what The Rocks is all about I suggest a good pair of walking shoes and a fair bit of time and patience to get a bit lost and stop to read all the bits of information that pop up in front of you here and there.We loved it all and will return later in the year.
The rocks has a great vide in a tourist area without being overpowering. I enjoyed the market on Friday night and Saturday morning.Plenty of variety for eating and drinking.

Historic area worth some time. Not a large area to cover.  The city's best tourist info center is here.   Go for breakfast and tour the area and its history.  On weekends there's a small street market.  At night, there are more pubs than restaurants, but if looking for a good restaurant, go to the Waterfront restaurant by the Park Hyatt facing the Opera House - incredible views and pretty decent food, but pricey.  The views at night by the Park Hyatt are stupendous.

The Rocks, Rock. such a cool place, just by circular quay, surrounded by many shops and restaurants. only place i know where you can see so much history, modern shops, great food, history and get handcuffed to a flag pole by a 1800's policeman haha.. great times.
Great area!. We found ourselves going back to The Rocks time and time again. Shops, restaurants, markets, historical buildings - great area!

The Rocks Pub Tour. This was the very first thing I did in Sydney and I highly recommend it! I was travelling by myself and it was a great first way to be exposed to Sydney, meet people, and learn to navigate your way through The Rocks. I booked my tour online for $35. The downside of this was that it said it started at 5pm and it actually started at 6pm, which I wouldn't have found out had the Visitors center at the Rocks been so helpful. It begins at Cadmans Cottage the the tour guide gives you historical information about The Rocks and Sydney in general throughout the tour. There are many opportunities for photo ops, especially by the observatory at sunset. You get to visit 3 different pubs and get a drink at each one. They are supposed to be the half pints, but two of the pubs ended up giving us full pints. We visited the Australian, Lord Nelson Brewery, and Harbor View Hotel, although they differ every tour. Our tour guide, Vic, was awesome. He was full of information, funny, friendly, and personable. At the end of the tour, he gave us 2 for 1 coupons to use at Harbour View Hotel and didn't put a date on them so you could use them whenever you wanted. He also gave us recommendations as to where to eat, which was really helpful. I ended up meeting people I hung out with all night and ended up frequenting two of the bars we visited throughout my trip to Sydney. For $35 you can't get a better deal and have a better first night in Sydney. highly recommended!
A Peaceful Place in a Hectic City. Great place for a stroll day or night. Very safe. Good place to go shopping or grab a bite to eat. They also have great festivals in the streets.

Sydney Urban Adventures Bike Tour. Easily the best thing I've done in Sydney. Our bikes were soooo comfy and our guide was very safety conscious. I loved the morning tea and bevvy with my co-riders. We did so many icons in just a few hours - I am going on The Rocks Pub Tour too so I am really looking forward to that as it is run by the same team :-)

The Rocks Pub Tour. When visiting Sydney a good way to tour The Rocks is through the walking Pub Tour. You can book the Pub Tour or any other tours through the visitor center locations. We did ours online in advance to reserve our spot. The Pub Tour last two hours and each tour has a different guide and different pubs to visit. The tour guide drank with us and knew all the bartenders which came in handy on this venture. She was knowledgeable about the history of the pubs and some stops along the way. She was able to take a group of strangers from all over the world and have us exchanging emails by the end of the night. We all ended up hanging out at the last bar buying each other rounds at one of the oldest pubs in Sydney. Cheers mate, no worries!

Take time to explore the hidden gems!. When you are in Sydney, you have to visit the Rocks. Visit the Discovery Museum on Argyle Street. It's free, and very informative. The interactive displays are really cool. Take the time to read them. Donations are appreciated (or so the guy at the front desk said), and after the day I spent there, they really deserved it.After you leave the Museum, explore a little. Wander around the alleyways and narrow back streets--I highly recommend the Suez Canal street. it looks like a really narrow alley, almost like it is just a way for water to drain (by the way, if its raining very hard, I don't recommend it). There's a pretty cool display that I never would have expeced to find. I just happened to stumble upon it.Cadman's Cottage was built in 1816, and is worth a look. It doesn't take long, but it is interesting inside, with a few small displays and information about excavating the old buildings in the area.There are plenty of shops, both touristy and upper-end fashion shops. You can find some really cool things here. One shop that is a must-see is The Puppet Shop at the Rocks. It is downstairs from the Chamber of Commerce, right off George St. It is amazing! The owner makes many of the puppets by hand, and the prices for the puppets are not bad at all! It is truly an amazing and magical experience.Next, take time to walk across the Harbour Bridge and back. It will take about an hour, but it is an amazing experience. The views are spectacular, and its free. Stop at the first pylon and climb to the top for a great photo op. That costs about $10AUD, and is well worth the effort (there aren't too many steps, they aren't steep, and there are a few benches along the way). You can also climb the bridge, but that costs over $200, and you can't take a camera with you. I hear the views are amazing, but I prefer to be able to take pictures and save money. Whatever you want, though.Enjoy a nice dinner at any of the restaurants in the Rocks. Most of them have indoor and outdoor seating, and are located in beautiful old sandstone buildings. Phillip's Foote and the G'Day Cafe are good finds.Finally, get a drink at one of the many old bars in the Rocks. Some of them are truly old, with liquor licenses going back to the mid 1800s in many cases. End your evening with a night stroll along Circular Quay, or a ferry ride to Darling Harbour, to enjoy the lights of the city (and the Opera House and Bridge) on the water.

The Rocks - great museum. “The Rocks” is the peninsula to the left (north) of Circular Quay (pronounced “key”) in Sydney. An excellent museum (free, but we gladly made a donation) was small but very well done. The hour we spent there went too quickly. Back in the days when convicts still did most of the manual labor, a bunch of them spend a few years digging through the rock down the middle of the peninsula so that it would be easier to get from one side to the other. Having the story of its creation in mind makes the “Argyle Cut” is interesting to walk through. At the Quay (south) side of the cut we were intrigued by a passage between two old warehouses (or some other type of ancient brick buildings) where something seemed to be going on. A sign and a menu said “The Argyle” and we walked between the buildings to find a huge cobblestone courtyard in the triangle formed with a third old building. In the center of the triangle was a large bar surrounded by many tables. It was cool on this September evening (think of it like March if you live around 40 degrees north of the equator) and people were carrying out and lighting gas heaters on proverbial “ten foot poles” with reflectors above the flames to direct the heat downwards.

great area to stay..... we chose a hotel in the Rocks area and loved the location. easy access to the Quay and the harbor ferries, lots of restaurants, great neighborhood to walk around the rehabbed houses, great views of the Opera House and Bridge and access to the walk across the Brifge footpath. There are tours of the area and other activities accessible from the Info Center, which had one of the best shops in town surprisingly. Make sure you are there at night whan it's at it's best.

Not to be missed. The Rocks is certainly worth a visit. Plenty of small shops with interesting merchandise.
If you want a snack we highly recommend SWAGMAN'S POST COURTYARD CAFE at 36 George Street.
Their courtyard garden at the rear is a little gem. The coffee and homemade cakes are superb.

The Rocks. We walked to the rocks area for look around and found the markets were lovely. We managed to pick a few bits up for souvenirs and presents. It was so clean and todi and everyone was so friendly. We stopped for lunch here and had a lovely afternoon wandering around. Worth a meander.

Markets a must. If you want touristy souveniers or some truely wonderful memories of sydney these are the markets, they are run on weekends during summer (maybe other months too) and are almost right under the harbour bridge.the rocks in general are a wonderful place to get lost in, lots of small laneways with cobblestones and ssandstone walls.there are some great places for kids - a puppet shop that holds a puppet show during the day, although it is difficult to find.the rocks are next to circular quay so you can see a few attractions in the one day, but not spend your time running around. Avoid the foodcourt and stop into one of the surrounding cafes with courtyards that mean you can avoid the crowds.
Take the guided tour to really enjoy. Great place with many interesting hidden treasures, but need a guided tour to find them and appreciate the history.
